site_title: Oil prices post 3% annual decline, slipping for second year in a row
summary: Oil prices declined by 3% in 2024, marking the second consecutive year of a drop, due to stalled demand recovery, China's struggling economy, and increased global supplies. Analysts expect oil output to reach a new record of 13.5 million barrels per day in 2025, offsetting efforts by OPEC to shore up the market. Brent crude futures settled at $74.64 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settled at $71.72 a barrel, with prices expected to trade around $70 a barrel in 2025.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect the Japanese currency to be supported by further Fed easing and rate hikes by the Bank of Japan.
Looking ahead, investors are pricing in about 50 basis points of additional rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: South Korean inflation picks up as political fallout spreads
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation rose 1.9% in December, faster than the 1.5% rise in November, due to political turmoil and a weaker currency. Economists predict the Bank of Korea may limit its room for reducing interest rates next year, as economic growth may weaken further. The nation faces additional challenges, including a deadly plane crash and a mourning period, which may weigh on consumer sentiment. The BOK governor expressed concerns about the economy's growth prospects, and analysts see weak private spending, a cooling export rally, and deteriorating consumer confidence as key factors driving the central bank's easing next year.

images.alt_text: Economists are increasingly speculating the BOK may accelerate its easing cycle as the economy slows more quickly than anticipated.
The Composite Consumer Sentiment Index falling below the threshold of 100 means consumers have turned pessimistic over the economy.

site_title: Two plane crashes lead to deadliest year in skies since 2018
summary: Two plane crashes, one in South Korea and another in Azerbaijan, have resulted in the deadliest year in commercial aviation since 2018, with 318 fatalities. The Jeju Air disaster, which killed 179 people, was attributed to a bird strike, but investigators are still unclear on the exact cause. The crashes have raised concerns about airline safety and the need for better training for pilots to respond to outlier events. The incidents mark a reversal from 2023, which was the safest year in aviation.

images.alt_text: Experts say many questions remain, including why the Jeju Air plane, powered by two CFM 56-7B26 engines, appeared to be travelling so fast and why its landing gear did not appear to be down when it skidded down the runway and into a concrete embankment.
Many victims of the plane crash, the worst in the country’s history, appeared to be returning from vacation for the holiday season, officials say.

Video showed the Jeju Air plane from Bangkok landing on its belly at Muan International Airport, skidding off the runway as smoke streamed out from the engines, before crashing into a wall and exploding in flames.

Police forensics personnel and National Bureau of Investigation officials work at the scene where a Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 aircraft crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport in Muan.

site_title: Just what the doctor ordered: Thailand pivots from Middle East medical magnet to longevity sanctuary
summary: Thailand is shifting its focus from being a medical tourism hub in the Middle East to a longevity sanctuary, with stem-cell treatments and anti-aging remedies gaining popularity. The country generated US$850 million in medical tourism revenue in 2023, with 2.86 million international patients visiting, and is expected to grow to 3.07 million in 2024. Cosmetic procedures, dental care, and orthopaedic services are among the most sought-after treatments. Thailand's competitive advantages include high-quality services at competitive prices, internationally trained physicians, and a relaxed medical visa policy. The country aims to position itself as a global medical hub, with a 10-year plan to invest in cutting-edge medical technology and promote wellness tourism.

images.alt_text: epa11783271 Buddhist devotees pay homage outside the pagoda containing the Sacred Lord Buddha's tooth relic, during an enshrinement ceremony at the Sanam Luang Royal Grounds in Bangkok, Thailand, 18 December 2024. The Sacred Lord Buddha's tooth relic from China was enshrined in Bangkok to honor the Thai King's 72nd birthday on July 2024, and to commemorate the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between Thailand and China. Known as Phra Dattha Thatu, the Buddha’s Tooth Relic is believed to be a physical remnant of the Buddha himself.  EPA-EFE/NARONG SANGNAK

site_title: Will 2025 be a year of caution or celebration for Singapore?
summary: Singapore is gearing up for a year of SG60 celebrations marking its 60th year of independence, amidst global uncertainty. The country's political leadership will navigate a campaign year, with the General Election (GE) due in 2025. US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration on Jan 20 may lead to import restrictions, tariffs, and a potential trade war, dampening global trade and sentiment. In response, Singapore's government, led by Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, is focusing on a forward-looking stance, aiming to garner support for its vision of the future.

images.alt_text: Higher-than-expected tax collection in FY2024 so far has put government finances in a “good position”, said Maybank economist Brian Lee.

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.
In introducing 10 extra weeks of shared parental leave, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong made no reference to the usual economic and existential fears surrounding population issues.

site_title: Biden announces US$2.5 billion in fresh military aid to Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden announced $2.5 billion in fresh military aid to Ukraine, including $1.25 billion from US stockpiles and $1.22 billion from the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative. The aid will provide Ukraine with immediate and longer-term supplies of air defense, artillery, and other critical weapons systems. This brings total US aid to Ukraine to $175 billion, but its future is uncertain under President-elect Donald Trump, who has expressed a desire to bring the war to a swift end.

images.alt_text: Friday’s payout brings the total disbursed under the programme since it was signed in March 2023 to around US$9.8 billion.

site_title: China December factory activity expands at slower pace as trade risks rise
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded at a slower pace in December, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 50.1, above the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. However, services and construction sectors recovered, driven by growth in financial services, telecommunications, and travel sectors. The economy continues to struggle with weak consumption and investment, and policymakers hope recent fiscal and monetary measures will spark a turnaround in the property market. The World Bank raised its growth forecasts for China for 2024 and 2025, but warned of subdued household and business confidence and headwinds in the property sector.

images.alt_text: Employees work on the production line at the Midnight Charm Garment lingerie factory in Guanyun county of Lianyungang, Jiangsu province, China November 25, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Why Singapore retail investors shun most locally listed stocks
summary: Singapore retail investors largely shun most SGX-listed stocks due to low liquidity and poor quality of listings. The country's ageing demographic, lack of diversification, and growing preference for professionally managed investments also contribute to this trend. Scandals and permanent loss of capital from delisted S-chips and penny stocks have further deterred investors. Efforts to address these issues, such as improving liquidity and attracting listings, are necessary but rational investor behavior should prevail until then.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of SGX. For stories related to derivatives, liquidity and stock trading.

site_title: Putin’s period in power hits 25 years
summary: Vladimir Putin celebrates 25 years of rule in Russia, becoming one of the longest-serving world leaders. Despite widespread criticism in the West, he remains popular in Russia and may win another term in 2030 if he maintains good health. Putin's rule has been marked by significant economic growth, but also controversy, including the annexation of Crimea and ongoing tensions with the West. His legacy is complex, with some viewing him as a skilled leader who has tapped into Russia's national pride, while others see him as a divisive figure who has undermined democracy and human rights.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks during a press conference following a meeting of the Supreme Eurasian Economic Council in the Leningrad region, Russia, December 26, 2024. Sputnik/Alexei Danichev/Pool via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY./File Photo

site_title: SingPost deliveries in whistle-blower report faced issues like conflict zones: fired CEO, CFO
summary: SingPost's former CEO Vincent Phang and CFO Vincent Yik, along with head of international business unit Li Yu, were fired for being "grossly negligent" in handling a whistle-blower report and subsequent investigations. A significant majority of shipments in question were linked to conflict zones, and the executives claimed they were not part of the investigation and only learned of the full facts after external forensics team investigations. The trio plan to fight the terminations, with shares of SingPost ending trading up 1.9% on the news.

images.alt_text: 新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。

site_title: House of a Singapore pioneer
summary: A shophouse in Singapore's Katong neighborhood, once owned by prominent Hainanese immigrant Wee Cheow Keng, has undergone a complete makeover by his descendants. The renovation, led by RT+Q Architects, aimed to preserve the shophouse's heritage while incorporating modern elements. The result is a harmonious blend of tradition, legacy, and modernity. Key features include a new steel staircase, monsoon windows, and a pink skylight in the dry kitchen, which have been well-received by the family, including Yvonne Wee-Doo and her three daughters.

images.alt_text: Originally built in the early 1970s, this intermediate terrace house has been totally transformed.

site_title: South Korean air crash investigators examine airport embankment, bird strikes as possible factors
summary: A South Korean Boeing 737-800 jet crashed and burst into flames at Muan International Airport, killing 175 people and injuring two. Investigations are focusing on possible factors including bird strikes, disabled control systems, and a possible design flaw in the airport's embankment near the runway. The National Police Agency is working to identify the victims and extract data from the flight recorder, which is missing a key connector. The US National Transportation Safety Board and representatives from Boeing have joined the investigation, and inspections of all 101 B737-800s operated by South Korean airlines are scheduled to be completed by January 3.

images.alt_text: Experts say many questions remain, including why the Jeju Air plane, powered by two CFM 56-7B26 engines, appeared to be travelling so fast and why its landing gear did not appear to be down when it skidded down the runway and into a concrete embankment.
Many victims of the plane crash, the worst in the country’s history, appeared to be returning from vacation for the holiday season, officials say.

Video showed the Jeju Air plane from Bangkok landing on its belly at Muan International Airport, skidding off the runway as smoke streamed out from the engines, before crashing into a wall and exploding in flames.

site_title: Nvidia closes US$700 million Run:ai acquisition after regulatory hurdles
summary: Nvidia has completed its $700 million acquisition of Israeli AI firm Run:ai, following European Commission approval and US Department of Justice antitrust investigation. The deal was scrutinized due to potential market dominance in AI graphics processors, but Run:ai plans to make its software open-source, expanding its availability to the entire AI ecosystem. The acquisition is part of regulators' efforts to monitor tech giants' acquisitions of startups to prevent market consolidation.

images.alt_text: All of Nvidia’s AI semiconductors now use Ibiden’s substrates, although Taiwanese rivals such as Unimicron Technology are eyeing the field.
Nvidia has listed 11 job postings in Vietnam – all them for remote working, with half not specifying a particular city.
Nvidia Corp's offices in Shanghai, China, Dec 10, 2024. Nvidia is expanding its headcount globally as it works to fulfill runaway demand for its artificial intelligence chips.

site_title: Ex-mDR group COO Richard Siua charged with criminal breach of trust
summary: Former mDR group COO Richard Siua and sales director Peter Ng were charged with criminal breach of trust for allegedly misappropriating company assets. Siua is accused of misappropriating 4,057 mobile devices and accessories valued at over S$2.5 million, while Ng allegedly misappropriated 155 devices and accessories worth S$200,560. Both men face charges under the Penal Code, with penalties including imprisonment and fines. The charges follow an investigation by mDR and the police, and their employment was terminated in December 2021.

images.alt_text: mDR fires COO Richard Siau amid investigations into suspected misconduct
2 mDR senior executives misappropriate S$2.08m

site_title: Singapore stocks’ showing may hinge on reforms in 2025, but outlook for some sectors look bright
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index is expected to outperform in 2025 if market reforms are implemented to raise its relative valuations. Analysts predict a 5% rise in earnings-per-share growth, with the index reaching a base target of 4,000 and a bull case target of 4,410. Industrials and banks are seen as key sectors to outperform, with companies like Sembcorp Industries and UOB expected to benefit from market reforms and low interest rates.

images.alt_text: OCBC has a 33.3 per cent stake in Hong Kong Life.
Sembcorp was the sole addition from Singapore in this year’s edition of the Asia-Pacific Index.
Singapore market unlikely to repeat 2024’s high; moderate returns expected for 2025

site_title: Gold flat; en route to best year in more than a decade
summary: Gold prices remain flat at $2,606.07 per ounce, marking its best annual performance in over a decade with a 26% increase. The metal's appeal is reduced by high interest rates, despite being considered a hedge against inflation and turmoil. Trading activity is expected to be quiet on the last day of the year, with the market awaiting fresh catalysts, including upcoming US economic data and president-elect Donald Trump's tariff policies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: The alternative investment gender gap: Marketing to female clients
summary: Women retail investors are underrepresented in alternative investments, with men allocating twice as much to these assets. Research by Barbara Stewart found that women's favorite alternative investments include private equity, art, and real estate, while marketing strategies that resonate with women include explaining products effectively, making them personal, and targeting their interests. Women's forums, events, and communities also work in promoting alternative investments. However, the industry still needs to address marketing shortcomings and create a more inclusive environment for women investors, with 52% of interviewees stating that the current marketing approach does not work for women.

images.alt_text: Let’s not forget that America is a population of 335 million people. There are still 7.6 billion people that producers and manufacturers can sell to if America should decide to go down the path of mercantilism and impose penal tariffs on imports.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar International, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Wilmar International is acquiring Adani Group's remaining stake in Adani Wilmar for up to 305 rupees per share, potentially recognizing a US$1.5 billion gain. Meanwhile, Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager received a requisition notice from unitholders seeking to internalize its function and replace its adviser, potentially revitalizing restructuring talks with creditors.

site_title: Keppel delivers higher asset monetisation as it gears up for next phase of its transformation
summary: Keppel has delivered higher asset monetisation in 2024, unlocking S$1.5 billion, exceeding the S$950 million in 2023. The company's FUM has grown to S$85 billion by mid-2024, on track to hit the interim S$100 billion target by the end of 2026 or earlier. CEO Loh Chin Hua attributes this growth to tailwinds from energy transition, digitisation, and AI, as well as real estate demand. Keppel plans to expand its data centre portfolio, with an additional S$10 billion FUM growth, and is developing the Keppel AI Platform to enhance efficiencies and generate insights.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar strongest since 2021 on record funding costs
summary: The Hong Kong dollar reached its strongest level in three and a half years, reaching 7.7609 per US dollar on December 30, surpassing its June 2021 level. This surge is attributed to year-end liquidity replenishment by banks, higher dividend payouts by Chinese firms, and stronger interest in Hong Kong stocks. The overnight Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (Hibor) soared to 6.5%, a record high, and is expected to continue supporting the currency. The city's currency is confined to a trading band of 7.75 to 7.85 per US dollar.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong dollar Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Yen edges higher while dollar still reigns
summary: The Japanese yen edged up 0.16% to 157.55 per dollar on Monday, strengthening from recent five-month lows. The dollar index fell 0.1% to 107.86, while the US dollar remains dominant due to rising yields and expectations for higher US interest rates. The yen's gain is attributed to concerns over Japanese intervention and the Bank of Japan's potential rate hikes, with some policymakers gaining confidence in an imminent rate increase.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on December 5, 2024 shows new Japanese 10,000 yen notes (currently worth approximately 66 USD), which were released in July 2024, on display in Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Contract to run 27 public bus routes in Tampines from 2026 up for bidding
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has called a tender for the contract to run 27 public bus routes in Tampines from 2026, with electric bus operations to be a key factor in the evaluation process. The existing contract with SBS Transit is set to expire in July 2026, and LTA expects to award the new contract by the second half of 2025. The new contract will support the upcoming East Coast Integrated Depot, which will house over 500 buses and charge more than 200 electric buses.

site_title: US Steel jumps most in a year on Nippon Steel offer to Biden
summary: US Steel shares surged 14% on December 31, 2024, the largest intra-day jump in a year, after Nippon Steel offered a proposal to the Biden administration, aimed at addressing concerns over the Japanese company's takeover of US Steel. The proposal would give the US government a veto over any reduction in US Steel's production capacity. The US Steel takeover has been blocked by the US national security panel, with President Biden indicating his opposition to the deal, which was first announced in December 2023.

images.alt_text: The fate of the once-fabled US steelmaker has become a hot political issue since the company reached an agreement to be taken over by its Japanese suitor almost a year ago.

site_title: US Treasury says was targeted by China state-sponsored cyberattack
summary: The US Treasury Department confirmed that it was targeted by a China state-sponsored cyberattack earlier this month, resulting in unauthorized access to Treasury workstations and unclassified documents. A third-party cybersecurity service provider was compromised, allowing the actor to remotely access the Treasury systems. The department has taken steps to secure the compromised service and has no evidence of continued access to Treasury systems or information. The incident has been attributed to a China state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) actor, and more information will be released in a supplemental report.

images.alt_text: Ttelecom carriers including AT&T and Verizon were hit by the Salt Typhoon network intrusions.
Salt Typhoon is the name given to the hacking group behind the attacks.
Browser extensions are typically used by Internet users to customise their Web-browsing experiences, for example by automatically applying coupons to shopping websites.
The attack began at 7.24 am and affected the company’s internal and external systems, JAL says.

(FILES) This illustration photograph taken on November 22, 2024 in Istanbul shows physical banknotes and coin imitations of the Bitcoin cryptocurrency. Bitcoin burst past $100,000 for the first time December 5 as traders welcomed Donald Trump's pick to head the US securities commission, while Seoul stocks slipped as South Korea's president faced impeachment after his brief imposition of martial law this week. (Photo by Ozan KOSE / AFP)
The rise in crypto heists comes as bitcoin jumped 140 per cent this year to surpass US$100,000 mark.
Last year, the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Agency said TP-Link routers had a vulnerability that could be exploited to execute remote code.
Sichuan Silence provides Chinese government intelligence officials with varied hacking and cybersecurity services, US authorities say.
Salt Typhoon has collected intelligence and targeted phones belonging to president-elect Donald Trump and vice-president-elect JD Vance, among others.

site_title: Citigroup, BofA exit global climate-banking alliance
summary: Citigroup and Bank of America are exiting the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), a global climate-banking group, amid increasing pressure from Republican lawmakers to distance themselves from industry groups supporting reducing carbon emissions. Both banks remain committed to achieving net-zero emissions and will continue to work with clients on reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Their departure follows Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo, which also left the NZBA, and comes as the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ) makes changes to "redouble its efforts to mobilize private capital" to support the energy transition.

images.alt_text: Citigroup is still working on a January pledge to eliminate about 20,000 jobs globally, or about 8 per cent of its workforce.

site_title: Singapore economy grew 4% in 2024; government will continue to cushion impact of cost-of-living increases: PM Wong
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4% in 2024, exceeding the forecast of 3.5%, according to Prime Minister Lawrence Wong. He attributed the growth to strong employment and rising real incomes, with median income increasing 2.2% above inflation. Despite global cost-of-living pressures, Singapore remains a beacon of stability, and the government will continue to cushion the impact with targeted support. PM Wong announced plans to sharpen the country's economic competitiveness, creating exciting opportunities and good jobs for Singaporeans, and will outline the next steps in Budget 2025, focusing on building a "fairer and more inclusive society".

images.alt_text: Higher-than-expected tax collection in FY2024 so far has put government finances in a “good position”, said Maybank economist Brian Lee.
Singapore market unlikely to repeat 2024’s high; moderate returns expected for 2025

Generic pix of a worker in the clean room processing Wafer-level packaging (WLP) at the Singapore semiconductor firm, STATS ChipPAC office in Yishun on April 12, 2023. Can be used for stories about manufacturing, semiconductors, electronic industry, clean room, wafer fabrication.

site_title: Thailand’s central bank chief on its rate cuts, household debt and fintech
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is addressing long-standing issues such as high household debt and the need for monetary policy innovation. Household debt in Thailand stands at 90% of GDP, exceeding the recommended 80% threshold. The bank has cut interest rates, but the main concern is the balance between economic growth and debt reduction. The Bank of Thailand is also working to innovate the Thai banking sector, driving digital payments and facilitating green growth. The central bank is managing the baht amidst volatile global markets and is exploring the potential of central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) in the domestic market.

images.alt_text: A copy of the prospectus for Mao Geping Cosmetics'  IPO on it s trading debut on Dec 10. Its shares rose as much as 92 per cent before closing the day 77 per cent higher.
Singapore has been taking the lead in regulating fintech, aiming to take advantage of new technologies while minimising risks.
Geopolitical tensions and supply chain security have made the semiconductor industry an indicator of national strength.
A director oversees a micro-drama shoot in Dongyang, Zhejiang province. China’s micro-drama market grew 267.7 per cent year-on-year to 37.4 billion yuan (S$6.9 billion) in 2023,

site_title: US: Wall Street ends lower, capping a banner year
summary: US stocks ended lower on New Year's Eve, capping a record-breaking year for equities, with the Nasdaq surging 30% and the S&P 500 gaining 23%. The Dow posted a 13% advance for the year. Investors are pricing in 50 basis points of additional interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve in 2025, citing stretched valuations and uncertainties from the incoming Trump administration. Despite this, the AI boom is expected to continue driving growth.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.0 per cent to 42,573.73, while the broad-based S&P 500 lost 1.1 per cent to 5,906.94 on Monday.

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024. Federal Reserve officials lowered their benchmark interest rate for a third consecutive time, but reined in the number of cuts they expect in 2025, signaling greater caution over how quickly they can continue reducing borrowing costs. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: US pending home sales advance to highest level since early 2023
summary: US pending home sales rose 2.2% to 79 in November, the highest level since early 2023, as homebuyers adjusted to high mortgage rates and increased inventory. The National Association of Realtors attributed the surge to consumers recalibrating expectations on mortgage rates and taking advantage of available inventory. Despite this, housing affordability remains under strain due to high prices and elevated borrowing costs, with the Federal Reserve signaling a slower pace of interest-rate reductions in 2025.

site_title: Appeals court upholds verdict in Trump sexual abuse case
summary: A US federal appeals court has upheld a jury verdict ordering President-elect Donald Trump to pay $5 million for sexually abusing and defaming writer E. Jean Carroll in a 1996 incident at a Manhattan department store. The court rejected Trump's attempt to overturn the $2 million judgment for sexual abuse and $3 million for defamation. The decision upholds a New York jury's previous ruling that Trump had sexually abused Carroll and defamed her with false statements.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, Dec. 9, 2024. Stocks struggled to make headway, following a furious rally that put the market on pace for its best year since 2019, with traders awaiting key inflation data that will help shape the outlook for Federal Reserve rates. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
Jimmy Carter was the oldest living ex-US leader and the nation’s longest-lived president.
US president-elect Donald Trump once supported a TikTok ban, but he has spoken more favourably about the platform in recent days.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump attends a viewing of the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship rocket, in Brownsville, Texas, U.S., November 19, 2024 . Brandon Bell/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks tumble towards year-end
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.0% to 42,573.73, the S&P 500 losing 1.1% to 5,906.94, and the Nasdaq Composite Index plummeting 1.2% to 19,486.79. There was no major catalyst behind the decline, attributed to the typical low-volume period before New Year's Day. Investors will closely watch consumer inflation readings to gauge the US Federal Reserve's potential rate cut decisions. Tech stocks, including Tesla and Facebook, also slumped on the day.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024. Federal Reserve officials lowered their benchmark interest rate for a third consecutive time, but reined in the number of cuts they expect in 2025, signaling greater caution over how quickly they can continue reducing borrowing costs. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Elon Musk wants weak Europe, says Germany’s vice-chancellor
summary: Elon Musk's support for Germany's far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) party has been criticized by Vice-Chancellor Robert Habeck, who sees it as a strategic move to create a weak Europe that can't regulate strongly. Musk's endorsement of the AfD in a guest opinion piece for the Welt am Sonntag newspaper has sparked controversy, with the government accusing him of trying to influence the upcoming election. Habeck views Musk's actions as a logical and systematic attempt to weaken Europe and limit regulation, which aligns with the AfD's anti-establishment and anti-immigrant stance.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall in final full session of 2024 as bond yields remain higher
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% on Monday, closing at 504.85 points, amid still-high government bond yields. Technology and healthcare sectors led the decline. The market closed ahead of the New Year holiday, with thin trading volumes.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.0 per cent to 42,573.73, while the broad-based S&P 500 lost 1.1 per cent to 5,906.94 on Monday.

site_title: Bank regulator gives BlackRock January deadline on bank stakes
summary: The US Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) has given BlackRock a January 10 deadline to accept an agreement allowing the agency to scrutinize its investments in FDIC-regulated banks. This comes after a similar deal was reached with Vanguard, strengthening rules for passive investors in FDIC-supervised banks. The FDIC is pushing for "passivity agreements" to monitor compliance and prevent influence on bank business decisions. BlackRock has already made legally binding commitments to the Federal Reserve Board to remain a passive investor in US banks, but the deadline remains unclear.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BlackRock logo is pictured outside its headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., May 25, 2021.  REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: In 2025, global businesses must be ready for a new payments ecosystem
summary: Global businesses must adapt to a new payments ecosystem, offering diverse and seamless payment experiences to capture international markets. A recent survey found that four in five payment leaders need to overhaul their payment technology, but technical debt and lack of buy-in from management hinder progress. To succeed, businesses must tailor their payments, leveraging local expertise to innovate and expand, and invest in building payment infrastructures that can evolve as the market demands.

images.alt_text: Nets has a domestic merchant network of over 130,000 acceptance points, of which 96,000 can process QR transactions.

According to the Bank of England, global cross-border payment flows are projected to surge from almost US$150 trillion in 2017 to over US$250 trillion by 2027 – a rise of over US$100 trillion in a decade.
Digital payment options level the playing field for consumers who may struggle to access traditional financial institutions.

site_title: Dollar dominates on cautious Fed, Trump trade
summary: The US dollar reached a two-year high, with a 7% annual gain expected, as the Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates higher than peers due to inflation above its 2% target. Analysts also predict US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, including deregulation and tariffs, will boost growth and add to price pressures. The dollar index rose 0.4% to 108.49, while the euro is on track for a 6.2% yearly decline. Other currencies, including the Japanese yen and sterling, also fell against the dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on pressure from elevated Treasury yields
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, December 30, 2024, due to sparse trading volumes and rising Treasury yields. The Dow Jones fell 128.3 points, or 0.30%, to 42,863.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 50.2 points, or 0.84%, and the Nasdaq dropping 261.6 points, or 1.33%. The traditionally strong year-end rally for equities was disrupted by concerns over rising Treasury yields.

site_title: China’s frigid north-east thrives on ‘little potato’ tourism boom
summary: China's northeastern city of Harbin is experiencing a surge in tourism driven by social media, particularly among young people from the southern provinces. The phenomenon, dubbed "little potatoes," refers to tourists who visit the region, often wearing winter gear and taking photos, which are shared on platforms like Douyin and Xiaohongshu. This has led to a significant increase in visitors, with the first half of 2024 seeing a 171% rise in tourism spending and a 60% year-on-year increase in operating income for the region's cultural, sports, and entertainment industries.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on December 17, 2024 shows people having picture with a snowman sculpture in Harbin, China’s Northeastern Heilongjiang province. Animal ears and pom-poms on fuzzy hats adorn tourists’ heads on the street of the frigid northeastern Chinese city Harbin, enjoying a surge in visitors driven by social media. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP) / TO GO WITH: China-tourism-economy-internet, FOCUS by Mary YANG

site_title: Investors to Ken Griffin: Multi-strategy hedge funds are still booming
summary: The multi-strategy hedge fund market is still booming, despite a slight dip in assets under management to $366 billion at the end of June. Demand remains strong, with performance improving this year, and the "war for talent" to attract billions of dollars continues. Some smaller funds have seen significant growth, with Schonfeld Strategic Advisors posting a 17% return and Cinctive Capital Management returning 11.75%. Larger firms, such as Citadel and Millennium, are expected to consolidate, with Ken Griffin predicting some smaller multi-managers will merge or exit the market.

images.alt_text: ELon Musk has used his position as the world’s richest person to turbocharge Trump’s campaign, making him one of the biggest donors of the 2024 election.

site_title: Year of the Snake offers active investment openings in Asia amid policy shifts
summary: The article highlights the potential for active investment opportunities in Asia, particularly in China, India, and Japan, amid policy shifts and uncertainties from the incoming Trump administration. Volatility is expected to remain high in 2025, with a focus on developments in the US and China. Asia is the world's second most integrated trade region, with nearly 57% of its trade value originating within the region. Investors should consider diversifying and managing risks, focusing on sectors with visible earnings growth drivers, such as technology and consumer staples. Asian currency bonds could offer attractive yields, and generative AI technologies are expected to transform industries and create new investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: China’s push to produce essential technology at home drove many of the other biggest stock gains in China this year as well.

site_title: Analysts positive on S-Reits in 2025 after a roller-coaster year
summary: S-Reits in Singapore are expected to perform better in 2025 due to falling interest rates, according to analysts. Despite a 11.3% decline in 2024, the sector is seen as a "compelling" investment choice with yields of around 6%. Analysts predict a turnaround in Reits' distribution per unit (DPU) by the second half of 2025, driven by lower interest costs. Overseas-focused Reits, such as Manulife US Reit and Cromwell European Reit, outperformed in 2024, and the retail, industrial, and hospitality sectors are expected to benefit from continued rate cuts.

images.alt_text: BHG Retail Reit was the largest decliner in terms of percentage as at 3.50 pm, shedding 11.1 per cent or S$0.05 at S$0.40.
As general market sentiments improve, SGX is poised for heightened IPO activities next year, said observers.
Last month, Keppel DC Reit launched an EFR exercise, seeking to raise around S$1 billion, including S$600 million from a private placement and S$300 million from a preferential offering.

site_title: 2024: A year of market volatility
summary: Global markets experienced volatility in 2024, marked by ongoing conflicts in Ukraine and the Middle East, and the US presidential return of Donald Trump. Despite this, the global economy maintained steady growth, with inflation moderating and monetary policies easing. The Straits Times Index outperformed major global benchmarks, rising 19.8% year-over-year. Central banks in Southeast Asia kept rates steady, while the International Monetary Fund advised regional banks to focus on domestic price stability. The US stock market edged down from records amid tariff threats and the tech firm Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall.

site_title: Penalties for pollutive light commercial vehicles to increase; incentives for cleaner ones continue
summary: The Land Transport Authority and National Environment Agency have announced changes to the Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) in Singapore. Starting April 1, 2025, a higher surcharge of S$20,000 will be imposed on vehicles in Band C, mainly diesel vehicles. Incentives for vehicles in Band A, mainly electric vehicles, will remain at S$15,000. The incentive for vehicles in Band B, mainly petrol vehicles, will be removed. These changes aim to promote cleaner vehicles and align with the government's vision to have all vehicles run on cleaner energy by 2040.

images.alt_text: Penalties for pollutive light commercial vehicles push buyers to switch to heavier vehicles instead

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends 2024 with nearly 20% rise
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed at 39,894.54, rising 19.22% for the year, driven by a weaker yen and low-interest rates. The index fell 0.96% on its last trading day of 2024, as investors locked in profits, but remains at a five-month closing high. Markets will reopen on January 6, 2025, after the New Year holidays.

images.alt_text: China, India and Japan (above) are some of the world’s most dynamic and influential economies.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei was down 0.75 per cent at 40,020.00 points on the last day of trading until Jan 6.

site_title: Europe: Stocks clock worst quarterly showing since 2022
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 recorded its worst quarterly showing in over two years, declining 3% in the final trading session of 2024. The market's cautious mood was driven by uncertainty around interest rates and the Trump administration's policies, despite strong gains in the US. European stocks had hit an all-time high in September, but were weighed down by concerns over the slowing European and Chinese economies, as well as political turmoil in France.

images.alt_text: Looking ahead, investors are pricing in about 50 basis points of additional rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate edges up in November, but overall takings dip
summary: Singapore hotels saw a slight increase in average room rate to S$273.11 in November, up 0.5% from October, but overall room revenue dipped to S$430.4 million, down from S$440.1 million the previous month. Tourist arrivals from top sources fell, with Indonesia surpassing China as the top source, but full-year international visitor arrivals reached 15.1 million, exceeding the lower end of the Singapore Tourism Board's projection.

images.alt_text: Some F&B players noted stronger spending, by both regular diners and corporates.
Rates declined across hotel categories month on month.

site_title: A look at real estate in New York City in 2024
summary: In 2024, New York City's real estate market saw significant trends, including soaring housing costs and changes in commission structures. The most sought-after amenities among renters and buyers were in-unit laundry, access to an elevator, and pet-friendly homes. Manhattan neighborhoods dominated the top 10 lists, with Tribeca and SoHo being the priciest areas, with median asking rents of $8,295 and $6,100, respectively. Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights also saw high demand, with median asking prices exceeding $2 million.

images.alt_text: New York City's market for luxury home deals in November was the strongest its been in three years.

site_title: Household electricity, gas tariffs to fall in Q1 on lower energy costs
summary: Singapore households can expect lower electricity and gas bills in Q1 2025. Electricity tariffs before GST will decline by 3.4% to 28.12 cents per kWh, while gas tariffs before GST will fall by 0.25 cents to 22.72 cents per kWh. The decrease is attributed to lower energy and fuel costs, with energy costs comprising 76% of the Q1 electricity tariff. The changes will take effect from January 1 to March 31, 2025.

images.alt_text: SGX indicates that the top 100 most-traded stocks had total returns of 11 per cent in the first five months of the second half of 2024.
Given the broad consensus on China’s threat, tariffs on Chinese imports will inevitably rise. China has over US$300 billion trade deficit with the US
Electric cars getting charged at a Shell station in Singapore.  The availability of charging infrastructure is as critical as any other factor in driving EV adoption in the region.
SP Group and City Energy have attributed the fall in tariffs to lower energy and fuel costs.

site_title: How has the 21st century gone so wrong?
summary: The 21st century has been marked by significant decline in global prosperity and social progress, contrary to expectations of a "golden age" post-Cold War era. Despite initial optimism, the world has faced numerous challenges, including rising poverty, climate change, and economic instability. A majority of the global population now believes the world is getting worse, with both traditionally optimistic America and stagnating Europe sharing this sentiment.

site_title: Chery adds JPMorgan for US$1 billion Hong Kong listing
summary: Chery Holding Group has selected JPMorgan as its lead arranger for an initial public offering (IPO) of Chery Automobile in Hong Kong, potentially raising up to US$1 billion. The IPO could take place in the second or third quarter next year, with the company seeking a valuation of over 100 billion yuan (S$18.6 billion). This move follows Chery's selection of China International Capital, GF Securities, and Huatai International as arrangers for the listing.

images.alt_text: At least six firms have said they intend to hold initial public offerings in Hong Kong by late January, raising a combined HK$3.3 billion (S$578 million).

site_title: Hong Kong sees rush of IPO filings on last trading day of 2024
summary: At least six companies have announced plans to list shares in Hong Kong by late January, raising a combined HK$3.3 billion (S$578 million). This surge in IPO filings comes as the Hong Kong bourse relaxes requirements for mainland-listed companies and China's securities regulator encourages firms to list in the city. The move is seen as a response to potential economic uncertainty under a new US administration, with investors seeking to complete listings before January 20. Hong Kong's IPO proceeds have nearly doubled in 2024 to about US$10 billion.

site_title: Venezuela fines TikTok US$10 million over viral challenge deaths
summary: Venezuela's Supreme Tribunal of Justice fined TikTok US$10 million over viral challenge deaths, citing negligence in stopping content encouraging hazardous activities. The court ordered TikTok to open an office in the country and pay the fine within eight days. The fine is in connection with three adolescent deaths from intoxication by chemical substances linked to viral challenges on the platform.

images.alt_text: US president-elect Donald Trump once supported a TikTok ban, but he has spoken more favourably about the platform in recent days.
TikTok’s owners have sought to have the law struck down, and the US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case.
From next year, any major messaging and social media service provider operating without a licence from the Malaysian government will face legal action.
The plan is far from finalised and McCourt faces considerable obstacles to a possible deal.

site_title: The climate scorecard is looking bleak in 2025
summary: The climate scorecard is looking bleak in 2025, with greenhouse pollution barely slowing its growth pace over the past two decades. Despite a surge in solar power and electric vehicles, coal consumption has reached previous records and is expected to increase for several years. The loss of political goodwill towards clean energy is a significant concern, with China, a major electricity consumer, being a crucial factor. The world needs drastic carbon emission cuts to avoid damaging global warming, and the current trend is alarming.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024
Removal of atmospheric CO2 will require scaling up investment in carbon-removal technologies from US$5-13 billion today to US$6-16 trillion by 2050.

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos signs into law record 6.33 trillion peso Budget for 2025
summary: Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. signed the country's record 6.33 trillion peso budget for 2025 into law, increasing government spending by 10% to support economic growth and reduce poverty. The education sector received the largest budget allocation, followed by the public works ministry. However, budget advocates criticized cuts to the education budget and the removal of a government health insurance subsidy. The budget is higher than initially projected and is expected to contribute around a fifth of the country's economic growth, targeting 6 to 8% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Inflation has averaged 3.2 per cent for January to November, within the central bank’s 2 to 4 per cent target range for 2024.
Both Vietnam and the Philippines consider the US a key trading and geopolitical partner, and these policy changes are set to take place as the new Trump administration comes in.
The BSP capped off the year with a third quarter-point rate cut on Thursday, as inflation remained on target and economic growth slowed.

site_title: South Korea court approves arrest of President Yoon in martial law investigation
summary: A South Korean court has approved an arrest warrant for impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol, who is accused of imposing martial law, making him the first sitting president to face arrest. The warrant is valid until January 6 and, if exercised, would lead to Yoon's detention at the Seoul Detention Center. The arrest is part of a broader investigation into Yoon's short-lived imposition of martial law, which was met with widespread criticism and opposition.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivers an address to the nation at his official residence in Seoul, South Korea, December 14, 2024.   The Presidential Office/Handout via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Record year for momentum trade is ending with widening cracks
summary: The momentum trading strategy, widely used by quantitative traders, has experienced a record-breaking year in 2024, with a 31% gain, but its dominance is starting to wane. Despite this, the strategy's popularity persists, with many investors continuing to use price momentum as a key factor in their investment strategy. The S&P 500's 25% return masked a gain of half that in its average member, and value and small-cap shares struggled. The Fed's fickle stance and inflation's refusal to go quietly have contributed to cross-asset malaise, raising concerns that momentum's impressive streak may not persist without a break.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin blew past US$100,000 earlier in December, shattering previous records on hopes of a lighter regulatory touch by the incoming Trump administration as well as a broader risk-on appetite.

site_title: South Korea orders airline safety probe following  worst domestic crash
summary: A South Korean Boeing 737-800 belly-landed and skidded off the runway at Muan International Airport, killing 175 people, including 175 passengers and 4 crew members. The crash occurred when the plane declared an emergency and attempted to land, but failed to stop on the runway. Investigators are examining bird strikes, disabled control systems, and pilot actions as possible factors. The government has ordered an emergency safety inspection of the country's entire airline operation and is working to identify the victims and support their families.

images.alt_text: Many victims of the plane crash, the worst in the country’s history, appeared to be returning from vacation for the holiday season, officials say.

Video showed the Jeju Air plane from Bangkok landing on its belly at Muan International Airport, skidding off the runway as smoke streamed out from the engines, before crashing into a wall and exploding in flames.

site_title: China’s top stock of 2024 eyes boost from AI self-reliance
summary: Cambricon Technologies, a Chinese AI chip designer, is expected to see additional growth in 2025 due to China's push for self-sufficiency in artificial intelligence. The Shanghai-listed stock has climbed 383% this year, outpacing global leaders Nvidia and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. Demand for AI chips has surged, with sales jumping 280% in the third quarter. Analysts predict significant growth in 2025, with Cambricon's market share potentially rivaling Huawei's. The company's addition to the Shanghai Stock Exchange 50 Index may also boost its market value.

images.alt_text: Beijing set a growth target of “around 5 per cent” this year, a goal it says it is confident of achieving.

site_title: No internal controls are fully fraud-proof, SingPost tells Sias
summary: SingPost, a Singapore-based postal services provider, has assured investors that its internal controls and risk management systems are adequate in addressing relevant risks, but no system can guarantee against deliberate misconduct or fraud. The company's board has terminated three former key management executives over the mishandling of internal investigations, but the sale of its Australia business is not expected to be affected. SingPost will announce a new group chief executive "in due course" and has appointed Gan Heng as acting chief executive officer of its IBU operations.

images.alt_text: Yu Li says he will enforce his legal rights and vindicate his reputation.
新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。
SingPost intends to use a portion of the proceeds from the Australian business sale to repay borrowings.

site_title: Tax attorney, therapist, wealth adviser: What the US$1.26 billion lottery winner will need
summary: A US$1.26 billion Mega Millions jackpot winner is advised to build strong relationships with a wealth adviser, tax accountant, estate attorney, and therapist before making decisions about the payout. The winner may consider opting for the annuity, which distributes the prize over 30 annual payments, or the lump sum, which allows for immediate investment. Financial planners note that the annuity may be a better option for younger winners, while the lump sum may be suitable for older winners. Winners are also cautioned to avoid bad investments and to keep their earnings safe.

images.alt_text: This jet could be mine, but you’ll never know.

site_title: Layoffs and job cuts in Singapore in 2024
summary: Singapore has seen prominent layoffs in 2024 across various sectors, including beverage giant Yeo Hiap Seng (25 employees), Canon (low single-digit percentage of its 700-strong workforce), Doctor Anywhere (45 jobs or 8.1% of its total headcount), Carousell (76 jobs), Samsung Electronics (undisclosed number), Dyson (undisclosed number), Shein (17 jobs), Ninja Van (5% of its workforce), MoneyHero (80 employees), Epson (350 employees), and Lazada (about 100 staff in Singapore). The job cuts are attributed to companies restructurating operations, cutting costs, and adapting to market realities.

images.alt_text: MOM expects the labour market to remain tight, supported by economic growth and strong business sentiment.

site_title: Goodman Group shines among Australian property firms on data-centre push
summary: GOODMAN Group's stock has surged 45.8% this year, driven by the growing demand for data centers amid the AI boom. The company, Australia's largest property developer, counts major hyperscalers like Amazon and Microsoft as customers, with 42% of its portfolio under development being data centers. Analysts expect Goodman's growth to continue, but some warn of valuations getting rich and risks of data-center obsolescence. Despite these concerns, Goodman's existing pipeline and access to land with power supply remain key advantages.

images.alt_text: Global tech giants such as Microsoft, Google and Amazon have committed to building data centres in Malaysia.

site_title: What a Trump presidency means for US business
summary: US stocks have reached their highest level since records began, driven by hopes of deregulation and tax cuts under a potential Trump presidency. A record $149 billion was invested in US equity exchange-traded funds in November. However, research suggests that right-wing populist leaders often deliver subpar stock market performances and rising consumer prices. Studies have shown that such leaders lead countries to lower economic growth, greater national debt, and inflation. Investors and business leaders are advised to be cautious of these potential outcomes.

images.alt_text: The original cryptocurrency has climbed roughly 120 per cent this year, outstripping traditional investments such as global stocks and gold.

site_title: Jeju Air shares slump to record low after deadly plane crash
summary: Jeju Air shares plummeted to a record low after South Korea's deadliest air crash, killing 179 people, on Sunday. The crash, which involved a low-cost airline founded in 2005, has sent shockwaves through the industry. Jeju Air shares fell 8.4% and AK Holdings' shares hit their lowest in 16 years. South Korea's acting President ordered an emergency safety inspection of the country's airline operation system. Analysts predict consumer sentiment will be hurt, but overall travel demand may not weaken structurally.

images.alt_text: Video showed the Jeju Air plane from Bangkok landing on its belly at Muan International Airport, skidding off the runway as smoke streamed out from the engines, before crashing into a wall and exploding in flames.

site_title: America needs more Jimmy Carters
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter, who died at 100, left a lasting imprint through his post-presidency work as a peacemaker, diplomat, human rights champion, and advocate for the homeless. His life offers lessons for leaders, showcasing his integrity, values, and vision to restore honor to government. Carter achieved notable foreign policy successes, including the Camp David accords, and domestic triumphs like deregulating oil and natural gas prices. Despite challenges, he continued to play a crucial role in promoting peace and democracy, earning him recognition as one of America's greatest ex-presidents.

images.alt_text: Jimmy Carter was the oldest living ex-US leader and the nation’s longest-lived president.

site_title: Both ‘Mufasa’ and ‘Sonic’ claim North America box-office supremacy
summary: Disney's animated drama "Mufasa: The Lion King" dominated the North American box office with an estimated $63.8 million in the five days from Christmas Day to Sunday. However, Paramount's action comedy "Sonic the Hedgehog 3" took the traditional Friday to Sunday stretch with $59.9 million, edging out "Mufasa" by $38 million. New vampire movie "Nosferatu" also posted impressive numbers, with $40.3 million for the five-day period.

images.alt_text: Jim Carrey plays mad scientist Dr Ivo Robotnik.

site_title: Oil rises on diesel demand boost in sparse holiday trade
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday as investors bet on a drop in temperatures to boost diesel demand. Brent crude futures rose 22 cents to $74.39 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 39 cents to $70.99 a barrel. Diesel futures surged 2.5% to their highest since November 5, driven by concerns of colder weather in the US and Europe. US natural gas futures also surged 17% to their highest level since January 2023.

images.alt_text: A man harvests coffee beans at the Venecia farm, in Chinchina, Caldas Department, Colombia, on Novemeber 29, 2024. Coffee workers express satisfaction as Colombia celebrates a record domestic coffee price of around $600 per 125-kilo bag, at a time when the arabica variety is at historic highs on international markets. (Photo by JJ BONILLA / AFP)
Oil prices were also supported by optimism for Chinese economic growth next year that could lift demand from the top crude oil importing nation.

site_title: Government ramps up supply of industrial sites in H1 2025 amid still-rising rents
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to release 14.07 hectares of industrial land across 10 sites through the Industrial Government Land Sales (IGLS) programme for the first half of 2025. Seven sites, totaling 9.71 hectares, are confirmed, while three sites, totaling 4.36 hectares, are on the reserve list. The move aims to maintain a steady supply of industrial space beyond 2027, as the projected supply of single-used factory space is expected to decline. The release of industrial land is expected to moderate growth in industrial property prices and rents, making Singapore a more competitive business location for manufacturing, logistics, and technology firms.

images.alt_text: JTC buildings near the Ayer Rajah industrial estate on 29 October 2019.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, December 30, 2024
summary: Jeju Air shares plummeted to a record low following a deadly plane crash. Meanwhile, SingPost appointed interim leaders amid a leadership scandal. In the Philippines, President Marcos signed a record 6.33 trillion pesos budget for 2025.

site_title: Gold heads for biggest gain since 2010 in mixed year for metals
summary: Gold is on track for its biggest gain in 14 years, with a 27% advance in 2024 driven by US monetary easing, geopolitical risks, and central bank purchases. Despite a stronger US dollar and rising real Treasury yields, gold has set multiple record highs. Other metals have had a mixed year, with iron ore slumping 28% and lithium on track for a second annual decline. Investors focus on uncertainty around US monetary policy and potential frictions from the Trump presidency in 2025.

site_title: Dasin unitholders call for another EGM to internalise manager, replace adviser
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's trustee-manager has received a requisition notice from a group of unitholders seeking to internalize the manager's function and replace the current adviser, FTI Consulting (Singapore), with Banda Capital. The unitholders, who own over 10% of voting rights, are calling for another extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove the current trustee-manager and replace it with Banda Capital. They aim to "revitalise" the trust's restructuring talks with its creditors.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall is one of four malls whose commercial and property management agreements will not be renewed upon their expiry this month.
The trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust says the announcement represents the view of most of the board.
The trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust demands that both minority directors stop obstructing the trust's restructuring efforts.
Amendments to the trust deed requires the approval of the bourse operator, said the trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust.

site_title: South Korea investigators request arrest warrant for Yoon over martial law
summary: South Korea's joint investigation unit has requested an arrest warrant for suspended President Yoon Suk-yeol over his brief imposition of martial law on Dec 3, amid allegations of insurrection. Yoon has failed to respond to multiple summons for questioning, and a Seoul court will decide on the warrant. This is the first time an arrest warrant has been sought for a sitting president in South Korea, with insurrection being one of the few charges for which a president does not have immunity. A Constitutional Court trial is ongoing to determine Yoon's fate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivers a speech during his briefing on state affairs at a press conference at the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, August 29, 2024. Chung Sung-Jun/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Protesters wave placards reading "Arrest Insurrectionist Yoon Suk Yeol" during a rally in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 16, 2024.

The constitutional court formally began proceedings at 10 am (GMT 0100) on Monday. Yoon Suk Yeol was removed by South Korea’s parliament on Saturday over his short-lived attempt to suspend civilian rule, which plunged the country into its worst political turmoil in years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 30)
summary: SingPost says the sale of its Australia business won't be affected by the termination of three former key management executives. The company's board focused on high governance during recent investigations. The Ministry of Trade and Industry launched 14.07 hectares of industrial land for the first half of 2025. Singapore hotels' average room rate rose 0.5% to S$273.11 in November, but overall takings dipped. Household electricity and gas tariffs will fall in Q1 2025 due to lower energy costs. Singapore stocks closed higher despite regional declines.

site_title: Xi says China’s 2024 GDP growth set to hit target of around 5%
summary: China's President Xi Jinping announced the country's 2024 GDP growth is expected to reach around 5%, in line with market expectations. The economy is considered "overall stable and progressing amid stability," with risks addressed and employment and prices remaining steady. Xi called for more proactive macroeconomic policies to aid the economy's recovery, as a similar growth target is expected for 2025 to counter potential US tariff increases.

site_title: Malaysia attorney-general's office says house arrest bids must go to pardons board
summary: Malaysia's attorney-general's office has clarified that requests for prisoners to serve their sentences under house arrest, including former Prime Minister Najib Razak, must be submitted to the pardons board chaired by the king. The board's decisions, which include granting pardons or commuting sentences, cannot be challenged in court. The clarification comes after a lower court struck out Najib's request to confirm the existence of a royal order allowing him to serve his sentence under house arrest, which is set to be heard by the Court of Appeal on January 6.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers as the jailed politician left the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 31)
summary: Singapore's economy grew 4% in 2024, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stating that the government will continue to cushion the impact of cost-of-living increases. The country aims to sharpen its economic competitiveness to create jobs and opportunities for Singaporeans. Meanwhile, e-commerce platforms are focusing on improving customer experience and costs, with concerns raised about the "better for cheaper" race. The stock market is expected to be volatile in the coming years, with income investors advised to focus on cash flow.

images.alt_text: “However, no system of internal controls, no matter how robust, can provide absolute assurance against deliberate misconduct or fraud,” says SingPost.

site_title: Rajat Verma appointed as CEO of DBS Bank India from March 2025
summary: DBS Bank India has appointed Rajat Verma as its new CEO, effective March 1, 2025, succeeding Surojit Shome who will retire in February 2025. Verma, 63, has 27 years of experience in consumer and corporate banking and has grown the business across all client segments since joining as head of institutional banking group in June 2023. Verma will join DBS' Group Management Committee and succeeds Shome, who expanded the bank's India franchise through the launch of digibank and subsidiary in India.

images.alt_text: Han Kwee Juan, managing director and group head of strategy and planning at DBS

site_title: Bitcoin rally fuelled by Trump loses steam as year draws to close
summary: Bitcoin's rally fueled by Donald Trump's election victory has lost steam as 2024 draws to a close. The digital asset has climbed 120% this year, outpacing traditional investments like global stocks and gold. However, scaled-back expectations for interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve have cooled the speculative frenzy. As of December 30, Bitcoin wavered at $93,678, about $15,000 below its record high in mid-December. Smaller tokens like Ether and Dogecoin also struggled for traction.

images.alt_text: The rush to stablecoins will enhance the role of blockchain in payments on top of a slightly different product that major banks such as JPMorgan Chase have been exploring: deposit tokens.
Tokenisationisr the process of creating digital representations of real-world assets on a blockchain.

site_title: Hong Kong’s billionaire Cheng family seeks to sell China toll roads for US$2 billion
summary: Hong Kong's billionaire Cheng family is seeking to sell its China toll roads for approximately US$2 billion, as part of a strategic review to raise cash and boost value for investors. The infrastructure arm, CTF Services, is in early-stage discussions with China's state-owned Yuexiu Group, and has also considered other buyers. The potential sale aims to provide stability for the family, which is struggling with losses and mounting debt at its sister companies, New World Development and Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group.

site_title: Could SingPost’s Parcelgate scandal underscore the ‘better for cheaper’ race in e-commerce?
summary: Three SingPost executives were fired for allegedly bypassing internal controls to avoid penalties in a scandal known as "Parcelgate". The executives, not directly involved in the alleged fraud, made false assertions to the audit committee investigating the matter. Industry experts suggest that the intense competition among e-commerce platforms to improve customer experience and costs may have driven the actions, highlighting the unsustainable nature of this "better for cheaper" race.

site_title: Big Lots’ new rescue deal at risk following creditor opposition
summary: Big Lots' rescue deal is at risk after creditor opposition. The company proposed selling its business to Gordon Brothers Retail Partners, which would transfer 200-400 locations to Variety Wholesalers, but creditors claim they haven't reviewed the agreement's terms. Big Lots' lawyers argue the deal is the only option to avoid liquidation, but a judge is now considering a delay in approving the deal. The company is conducting going-out-of-business sales at most of its stores, which operated over 1,300 locations when it filed for bankruptcy in September.

site_title: Gold’s 26% advance stands out in mixed year for metals markets
summary: Gold is on track for one of its biggest annual gains this century, with a 26% advance in 2024 driven by US monetary easing, geopolitical risks, and central bank purchases. Despite a stronger US dollar and rising real Treasury yields, gold has set a succession of records, with other metals like iron ore and lithium struggling due to China's economic slowdown. Investors are now focused on uncertainty around US monetary policy and potential frictions from the Trump presidency in 2025.

site_title: Singapore shares retreat at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks started trading in negative territory on Dec 31, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening 0.4% or 13.49 points lower at 3,782.24. Losers outnumbered gainers 69 to 15, with entertainment group mm2 Asia tumbling 7.1% and local banking stocks all down. This mirrored global market losses, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite indices declining 1%, 1.1%, and 1.2%, respectively.

site_title: Swiss plane crew member dies after emergency landing
summary: A Swiss International Air Lines crew member who was hospitalized after an emergency landing of an Airbus A220-300 jet on December 23 has died, the airline announced on Monday. The plane, carrying 74 passengers and five crew, made an emergency landing in Graz, Austria due to engine problems and smoke in the cockpit and cabin. The crew member died in the hospital in Graz, with the airline expressing "deepest sorrow and regret" over the loss.

site_title: UK consumers to save on essentials, splash on events in 2025
summary: UK consumers are expected to continue saving on essentials and splashing out on events in 2025, despite growing real incomes and easing borrowing costs. Spending on essentials increased only 0.9% in 2024, down from 3.9% last year, while non-essential spending held up thanks to live events and "lipstick effect" spending. This cautious consumerism is a warning sign for the Labour government's growth ambitions, with households prioritizing travel and entertainment over big-ticket purchases.

images.alt_text: CEBR expects Britain to narrow the gap with the poorer-performing German economy over the next 15 years.

site_title: Malaysia faces delicate balancing act as it prepares to lead Asean in 2025
summary: Malaysia is set to lead the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) in 2025, taking the reins at a time of global uncertainty. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's pragmatic diplomatic approach, particularly regarding China's Belt and Road initiative, could yield trade and infrastructure benefits. However, the country faces challenges in balancing competing interests and managing relations with the US and China. The appointment of former Thai Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra as an informal adviser has raised eyebrows, and Malaysia's economy has fared reasonably well despite global uncertainties.

Malaysia’s firm recovery and low inflation support BNM’s decision to extend its rate pause even as central banks worldwide pivot to easing.

site_title: Biggest danger in Trump era is risk of US economy overheating
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's economic policies pose a significant risk of the US economy overheating, according to Wall Street strategists. Trump's plans for deregulation, tax cuts, and increased tariffs could lead to market volatility, with economists warning of wage inflation and increased costs for imports. The stock market is already richly valued, and some experts, including Jeremy Grantham, warn of an AI bubble similar to the dotcom era, with potential for a correction in the short term.

site_title: US and foreign leaders praise Jimmy Carter’s legacy
summary: US and foreign leaders are paying tribute to Jimmy Carter, the 100-year-old former US president and Nobel peace laureate, following his death. Leaders such as Joe Biden, Donald Trump, and Bill Clinton praised Carter's legacy as a global mediator, rights activist, and humanitarian. Carter's impact extended beyond his presidency, with leaders like George W. Bush and Barack Obama highlighting his efforts to promote peace, human rights, and democracy. Carter's legacy has been recognized globally, with leaders from Egypt, Israel, Palestine, and Europe paying tribute to his contributions to peace and human rights.

images.alt_text: Former President Jimmy Carter in 2015.  Carter redefined what an ex-president can do after departing the White House, leaving a lasting imprint through his work overseas.
Jimmy Carter was the oldest living ex-US leader and the nation’s longest-lived president.

site_title: Gold gains on safe-haven demand amid global uncertainties
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,622.93 per ounce on Monday, driven by lifted geopolitical turmoil and uncertainty. Despite higher interest rates reducing its appeal, investors look forward to the US Federal Reserve's 2025 interest rate outlook and Donald Trump's tariff policies. The metal has gained 27% this year, reaching an all-time peak of $2,790.15 on October 31. Trading is expected to remain quiet at the year-end as investors prepare for major policy shifts in 2025.

site_title: Prepare for a bumpy year in coffee, oil and other commodities
summary: Commodity prices are expected to rise in 2025 due to supply chain disruptions and unpredictable politics. Key factors include a potential OPEC+ production increase, a looming trade war, and lower oil prices. Coffee prices may surge due to a crop shortfall in Brazil and Vietnam, while cocoa prices remain high due to a West African supply shortage. Coal consumption is expected to remain high, and iron-ore prices may drop due to increased supply from Guinea. The writer predicts a bumpy year for commodities, with potential for higher prices and lower prices depending on political choices and economic trends.

site_title: Yen gains as some BOJ policymakers see rate hike soon
summary: The Japanese yen rose against the dollar on December 27, reaching a five-month high, after a summary of opinions from the Bank of Japan's December policy meeting showed some policymakers gaining confidence in an imminent rate increase. The BOJ cut its monthly bond purchases, and some policymakers predicted a rate hike in the near future. The yen's decline in recent weeks was attributed to rising US Treasury yields, but analysts believe the yen may stage a comeback as Treasury yields are expected to decline.

site_title: Macau sees surge in bond listings in pivot away from gambling
summary: Macau, a former Portuguese colony and the world's top gambling hub, is boosting its economy by establishing itself as a bond trading center. The Chongwa (Macao) Financial Asset Exchange, known as MOX, has seen a record $28.1 billion in bond listings this year, with 63% of them being yuan-denominated and issued by Chinese local government financing vehicles. The move aims to diversify Macau's economy and provide a financing bridge between the mainland and the outside world.

site_title: Singapore’s ‘election Budget’ expected to tackle cost of living with generous handouts
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 is expected to focus on immediate challenges such as the cost of living, with potential generous handouts and social transfers. The government may prioritize "near-term benefits" like cash transfers, utility rebates, or job creation programs. However, economists also expect the government to address long-term challenges, such as economic transformation and sustaining long-term growth. The budget may include measures to support workers, including upskilling and enhancements to the SkillsFuture framework, as well as targeted support for businesses to maintain competitiveness and adaptability.

summary: Oil prices slipped lower on Monday, Dec 30, in thin holiday trade, amid anticipation of economic data from China and the US later this week. Brent crude futures fell to $74.11 a barrel, down 6 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped to $70.52 a barrel. Optimism for Chinese economic growth, which could lift demand from the top crude oil importing nation, supported prices. Investors await China's PMI factory surveys and the US ISM survey for December to assess growth in the world's two largest oil consumers.

site_title: Singapore shares muted at Monday’s open; STI up 0.03%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Monday, edging up 0.03% to 3,772.85, amid muted global markets ahead of the New Year holiday. Global shares fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.8% and the S&P 500 sliding 1.1%. Asian markets also declined, with the MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan dipping 0.2%. Local banks were mixed, with UOB decreasing 0.03%, DBS inching down 0.1%, and OCBC rising 0.1%.

site_title: Chinese youth flocks to civil service, but slow economy puts ‘iron rice bowl’ jobs at risk
summary: China saw a record 3.4 million young applicants for the civil service exam, driven by high youth unemployment and a desire for lifetime job security. The civil service offers subsidized housing and stable employment, making it an attractive option amidst an economic slowdown. The exam numbers have tripled since 2014, reflecting the demand for stability in the private sector. Despite local governments struggling to pay wages, the civil service remains a safe haven for those seeking employment stability.
