site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks at slower pace: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity shrank at a slower pace in December, with the manufacturing PMI rising to 49.6, indicating the softest contraction in three months. The decline in production and new orders eased, with employment expanding for the first time in two months. Firms cited subdued demand and rising costs, including the weak yen, as factors behind the contraction. Despite the slowdown, manufacturers remain confident about their outlook due to the launch of new products. The PMI remains below the 50 threshold for the sixth straight month.

site_title: AT&T, Verizon say networks now clear after Salt Typhoon hack
summary: AT&T and Verizon have confirmed being targeted by the China-linked Salt Typhoon hacking operation, which attempted to gain foreign intelligence. The carriers stated that their networks are now clear, with Verizon containing the threat and AT&T complying with notification obligations. The incident affects a small number of high-profile customers in government and politics, with AT&T and Verizon cooperating with authorities. The White House confirmed nine telecom companies were breached, but US officials remain unsure of the extent of the damage.

site_title: Former US president Jimmy Carter dies aged 100
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter, the nation's longest-lived president and Nobel Peace Laureate, has died at the age of 100. Carter, who was in hospice care since 2023, died peacefully at his home in Plains, Georgia, surrounded by his family. He was known for his commitment to human rights and social justice, brokering the Camp David Accords and promoting peace and diplomacy worldwide. Carter's legacy has been widely praised, with leaders from around the world paying tribute to his character, statesmanship, and humanitarian efforts.

images.alt_text: epa11798052 (FILE) Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter gestures during his speech at the American University of Beirut (AUB) in Beirut, Lebanon, 12 December 2008 (reissued 29 December 2024). Carter died on 29 December 2024 at his home in Plains, Georgia, The Carter Center confirmed. He was 100, the longest-lived president in US history.  He took office as President of the United States on 20 January 1977 and succeeded Gerald Ford until he left office on 20 January 1981 to his successor Ronald Reagan. James Earl 'Jimmy' Carter, Jr. was born on 01 October 1924 in the village of Plains, Georgia, USA. After school he enrolled in the US Navy until 09 October 1953 after which he returned to his native village to extend the family peanut farm. In 1961 Jimmy Carter was elected to the state senate and on 12 January 1971 he became Governor of Georgia. In 2002 he became the only US President to receive the Nobel Peace Prize after leaving office. Outside of his political career Jimmy Carter was also known for his volunteer work with the 'Habitat for Humanity' organization.  EPA-EFE/WAEL HAMZEH

site_title: US economy surprises again in 2024 despite Fed, election drama
summary: The US economy defied expectations for a slowdown in 2024, driven by a resilient consumer. Despite uncertainty around the presidential election, elevated interest rates, and a cooling labor market, economic growth remained solid. Household spending advanced 2.8% in 2024, supported by wage growth outpacing inflation and rising household wealth. However, cracks emerged in the consumer's resilience, with slower hiring, higher unemployment, and increased delinquency rates on credit cards and loans. The Federal Reserve maintained a higher-for-longer approach to interest rates, and inflation progress stalled, with mortgage rates approaching 7%.

site_title: Supply crunch seen for Singapore Core CBD Grade A office market
summary: Singapore's Core Central Business District (CBD) Grade A office market is expected to face a severe supply crunch in 2025, with no new supply slated for completion in the next three years. CBRE, JLL, and C&W project rents to rise 2-3% in 2025, outpacing increases this year, while Knight Frank and Savills predict flat rents. site_title: US dollar eyes best year in almost a decade
summary: The US dollar is poised for its best year in nearly a decade, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rising over 7% this year, driven by the strength of the US economy and President-elect Donald Trump's protectionist policies. The dollar has strengthened against other currencies, with the euro near $1.04, while the yen, krone, and New Zealand dollar have declined more than 10% against the greenback. Non-commercial traders have increased bullish bets on the dollar, with $28.2 billion in contracts tied to a future rise in the currency, amid expectations of US economic growth and tariffs.

site_title: Tokenisation has become Wall Street’s latest favourite crypto buzzword
summary: Tokenisation, the process of creating digital representations of real-world assets on a blockchain, has gained momentum in conventional and crypto finance circles. Despite initial hype, only 0.003% of the world's assets have been tokenised, with many companies on the brink of bankruptcy. However, with a more favourable US regulatory regime and the launch of tokenised funds by major asset managers, the technology is gaining traction. Industry experts predict that tokenised fund assets under management could reach $600 billion by 2030, with potential benefits including increased liquidity, reduced costs, and improved efficiency.

Authorities cite a bird strike and adverse weather conditions as likely causes. The plane, a Boeing 737-800, crashed into a wall and burst into flames after skidding off the runway. Only two flight attendants were rescued, with 179 confirmed dead, and DNA retrieval has begun to identify the victims.

site_title: China’s record dividend payout intensifies pressure on the yuan
summary: China's record dividend payouts are putting pressure on the yuan, as Hong Kong-listed Chinese firms are expected to disburse $12.9 billion in interim dividends between January and March, a record high for the first quarter. The dividend bonanza is adding to the yuan's woes, which are already weighed by a resurgent US dollar and growing US-China tensions. This could test Beijing's ability to maintain market stability without compromising its long-term economic goals.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration taken on December 5, 2024 shows new Japanese 10,000 yen notes (currently worth approximately 66 USD), which were released in July 2024, on display in Tokyo. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Drama-prone fintechs face mixed regulatory environment in 2025
summary: Fintechs raised nearly $24 billion globally in the first three quarters of 2024, posing a growing competitive threat to traditional banks and asset managers. The US administration's financial deregulation policy and the uncertain future of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau have made the US an attractive market for fintech startups. However, regulatory challenges persist, as seen in the bankruptcy of Synapse Financial Technologies and fines against Chime and Dave. The CFPB has also issued guidelines for buy-now, pay-later lenders, and the FTC has taken action against SoLo Funds and TomoCredit.

images.alt_text: The London-headquartered firm is now Europe’s most valuable fintech.
Fintech funding in the six largest Asean economies has fallen by less than 1 per cent for the first three quarters of 2024, a significant improvement from the year-ago period.

site_title: Cocoa market stands at crossroads in volatile market
summary: The global cocoa market is experiencing volatility, with prices peaking at $12,646 per metric tonne in December 2024, a three-fold increase from the previous year. The market's rollercoaster ride is attributed to adverse weather conditions in West Africa, home to 70% of the world's cocoa production. To stabilize the market, addressing climate change, supply chain inefficiencies, and promoting sustainable production practices are crucial for the long-term outlook.

images.alt_text: Given the extreme situation facing cocoa stock, even small supply disruptions in 2025 could ripple into huge price volatilities, says Jonathan Parkman of Marex.

site_title: Sembcorp’s Middle East greenfield renewables project to begin commercial operation
summary: Sembcorp's Manah II Solar Independent Power Project in Oman is set to begin commercial operations four months ahead of schedule, exceeding its initial target. The 500-megawatt solar plant, developed by a joint venture between Sembcorp Utilities and Jinko Power Technology, is expected to be accretive to the company's earnings per share. The project is backed by a 20-year power purchase agreement and aims to increase Oman's renewable energy contribution to 30% by 2030.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp was the sole addition from Singapore in this year’s edition of the Asia-Pacific Index.
This represents Sembcorp’s first solar and battery energy storage system hybrid project in India.
Cosco Shipping has begun work on Phase Two of its logistics hub on Jurong Island on Tuesday.

Sembcorp on Thursday (Dec 5) received an appeal judgment affirming that its 2018 divestments of its South African municipal water assets for 718 million rand (S$70 million) were valid and enforceable, the group said on Tuesday (Dec 10).

site_title: China plans dam near India that could be world’s biggest
summary: China has approved plans to construct the world's largest dam near its border with India, the Yarlung Tsangpo river in Tibet, generating three times the power of the Three Gorges Dam. The $186 billion project, requiring a decade to build, has raised concerns about reduced water flow and potential impact on India's major rivers. The dam's construction could give China leverage in times of political tensions, as the Yarlung Tsangpo runs through the contested Arunachal Pradesh area.

images.alt_text: China’s top policymakers have adopted a more pro-growth policy stance for next year, including pledges to use fiscal tools, as a new Trump presidency could lead to more US tariffs.
China’s economy has stuttered this year due to a prolonged property crisis, massive local government debt and fragile consumer demand.
Industrial profits are a vital gauge of the financial health of factories, mines and utilities, shaping their investment decisions in the months to come.
Beijing set a growth target of “around 5 per cent” this year, a goal it says it is confident of achieving.

site_title: Box shipping’s voyage of uncertainty expected to continue in 2025
summary: Container shipping is expected to face market uncertainty in 2025 due to ongoing geopolitical tensions, trade wars, and labor disputes. Analysts predict freight rates will remain buoyed, with DHL expecting volatility and freight rates unlikely to drop to pre-pandemic levels. The US trade policy under President-elect Donald Trump is also expected to influence the sector, with potential new tariffs on Chinese imports. Despite a 4.5% expected rise in container demand, some analysts predict a 3% increase in 2025, easing volatility. Shippers are already front-loading freight to avoid tariffs, and route diversions due to attacks on merchant vessels in the Red Sea are causing congestion.

images.alt_text: LONG BEACH, CALIFORNIA - DECEMBER 04: Shipping containers are stacked beneath shipping cranes at the Port of Long Beach on December 4, 2024 in Long Beach, California. U.S. President-elect Donald Trump is threatening new tariffs on multiple countries as his second term approaches after making tariffs a signature of his 2024 Presidential campaign. The ports of Los Angeles and neighboring Long Beach is the country’s busiest container port complex.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Container ports from Houston to Miami and up to Boston have been closed since the labour contract expired on Tuesday.
Danish shipping company AP Moeller-Maersk's revenue was US$15.8 billion in third quarter, beating the US$14.4 billion forecast by analysts.

site_title: Vietnam PM seeks steps for double-digit GDP growth next year
summary: Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh has urged officials to focus on disbursing public investment from 2025 to create growth momentum, aiming for double-digit GDP growth next year. The government has set a 6.5-7% growth target, but Chinh believes 8% is achievable. Officials must develop expansion plans, set targets, and submit proposals to the premier by January 3. The government also plans to speed up key transportation projects, attract investments in high-value added sectors, and boost exports through new markets.

images.alt_text: Under new rules being shepherded by the OECD, a minimum 15 per cent tax will be charged on multinationals with an annual global turnover of more than 750 million euros (S$1.06 billion), regardless of their location.

site_title: Cracks emerge in Trump’s Maga coalition
summary: Cracks are emerging in Donald Trump's "Make America Great Again" (Maga) coalition over his stance on immigration and H1-B visas. Billionaires Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, who bankrolled Trump's 2024 campaign, have sparked controversy by advocating for foreign engineering talent, contradicting Trump's "America First" stance. Immigration hawks, including Trump loyalists, have accused them of ignoring US achievements in technological innovation, potentially threatening the Maga movement.

images.alt_text: Greenland is known both for its strategic location at a time when the melting of Arctic ice is opening new commercial and naval competition and for its reserves of rare earth minerals needed for advanced technology.

Elon Musk falsely claimed that each member of Congress would get a 40 per cent pay raise, when in fact they are scheduled to get a 3.8 per cent cost-of-living bump regardless of the bill under consideration.
TikTok’s owners have sought to have the law struck down, and the US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case.
Donald Trump (above) has tapped Musk to head a cost-cutting and deregulation effort he calls the Department of Government Efficiency.

site_title: Lessons from 2024, when the penny finally dropped for South-east Asia’s startups
summary: In 2024, South-east Asia's startups faced transformative trends, including the impact of elections, supply chain disruptions, and e-commerce shifts. The year saw a surge in digital brands, consumer strength, and clean-energy innovation, with promising IPOs in Indonesia and Malaysia. Notably, the "penny finally dropped" for the startup ecosystem, with investors loosening up purse strings and founders adapting to down-to-earth valuations. As the region looks to 2025, there is renewed optimism for growth, with a focus on omnichannel strategies, electric vehicles, and generative artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Both Vietnam and the Philippines consider the US a key trading and geopolitical partner, and these policy changes are set to take place as the new Trump administration comes in.
South-east Asia’s potential cannot be ignored. While its AI industry is sputtering, its digital economy as a whole is growing in the double digits both by revenue and profit, according to a study.
When the noise of market exuberance subsides, founders and investors alike can focus on long-term vision rather than chase short-term wins.

site_title: SingPost says executives were given ‘opportunity to be heard’ before sacking
summary: SingPost confirmed that its executives were given the opportunity to be heard before being sacked, following a proposed $1 billion divestment of its Australia business. The company outlined two phases of an investigation into the matter, emphasizing its commitment to corporate governance and accountability. The termination of the executives was seen as a result of the board's decision to proceed with the divestment plan, which is now expected to move forward.

images.alt_text: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore), or Sias, noted that the company’s 2024 annual report – published in the last week of June this year – did not specifically mention any whistleblowing report.
At 1.22pm on Dec 23, the share price of SingPost had fallen by S$0.06 or over 10 per cent to S$0.50, with 56 million securities changing hands.
新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。
SingPost intends to use a portion of the proceeds from the Australian business sale to repay borrowings.

site_title: Tourists return to post-Olympic Paris for holiday magic
summary: Tourists are flocking to Paris for the holiday season, with a surge in bookings and visitor numbers following the successful Paris 2024 Olympics. The city's tourism industry has rebounded, with hotels experiencing a 70% increase in demand for Christmas vacations compared to last year. The Olympic Games are credited with inspiring a comeback, with wealthy international customers making a comeback and the city's top establishments seeing a significant increase in bookings. The reopening of Notre Dame cathedral has also attracted visitors, with around 270,000 people visiting the site in its first eight days open.

images.alt_text: Laurent Ulrich, the archbishop of Paris, leading prayers for the consecration of the main altar, designed by French artist and designer Guillaume Bardet which replaces the old one that was destroyed in 2019, during a mass at the Notre-Dame cathedral on Dec 8, 2024.

site_title: Hong Kong IPO market stages comeback after dismal 2023
summary: Hong Kong's IPO market has staged a comeback after a dismal 2023, with 63 companies from mainland China listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange this year, raising a combined HK$83 billion. The market's recovery is attributed to favourable policies, improved market sentiment, and the success of recent IPOs, including Midea Group's blockbuster listing in September. The exchange is expected to regain its position among the top three global exchanges in terms of IPO fundraising, with total fundraising projected to reach HK$100 billion to HK$120 billion in 2025.

images.alt_text: CATL has been weathering the impact of an ongoing price war in China’s EV sector, with an increase in third-quarter profit growth.

site_title: Coal phase-out value chain presents investing opportunities for LGT despite coal exclusion policy
summary: LGT, a Liechtenstein-based private banking and asset management group, can still invest in the coal phase-out value chain despite a coal exclusion policy. The group can buy transition credits and invest in ancillary enablers of coal phase-out through its private equity platform, Lightrock. Transition credits are generated when coal plants are decommissioned earlier than their original retirement date and replaced with renewable energy sources. LGT aims to build an investable pipeline for transition credits and is exploring opportunities in green hydrogen, carbon capture and storage, and other climate technologies.

images.alt_text: Generic photo for ESG stories pertaining to sustainability

site_title: Trump asks Supreme Court to pause law threatening TikTok ban
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has asked the Supreme Court to pause a law that would ban TikTok if its Chinese parent company is not sold. Trump filed a motion, citing concerns over free speech, and said a pause would provide "breathing space" for the court to consider the case. The law, set to take effect January 19, is aimed at addressing national security concerns over data harvesting by TikTok. The Supreme Court will hear the case on January 10, with Trump seeking a negotiated resolution that addresses both free speech and national security interests.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s owners have sought to have the law struck down, and the US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case.
From next year, any major messaging and social media service provider operating without a licence from the Malaysian government will face legal action.
The plan is far from finalised and McCourt faces considerable obstacles to a possible deal.

site_title: Social enterprise Wings looks to expand across South-east Asia
summary: Wings, a Singapore-based therapy and learning centre, is expanding across South-east Asia, with Indonesia as its first target. The centre, founded by Judith Julia Justin, offers goal-setting and customized programmes for children and youth with special needs, focusing on intensive therapies such as Spider Cage. With a 70% success rate, Wings aims to make therapy more accessible to lower-income families through its Wings For Good programme. The centre has already seen progress in clients like baby Angela, who can now sit independently after just a few months of therapy.

images.alt_text: (From left) Jerome Wong, Lim Wei Jie and Nadi Chan, part of Foreword Coffee Roasters' new training and development team at Foreword Bakehouse.
Our Barehands works with artisans in marginalised communities, such as Afghan refugees living in Malaysia, to create versatile and handcrafted products.

site_title: Mizuho Bank Singapore brings festive cheer to needy students
summary: Mizuho Bank Singapore organized a half-day Christmas event for over 40 students with additional needs from AWWA's Special Student Care Centre. The "Gift a Smile" initiative, under the Mizuho Singapore Foundation, distributed 350 gifts including toys, school supplies, and shopping vouchers. The event reflects the bank's commitment to supporting the community and was part of its 50th anniversary celebrations in Singapore. This marks the foundation's first major initiative, which also includes donating handmade lanterns to seniors at Care Corner in January to spread joy and light ahead of Lunar New Year celebrations.

images.alt_text: Judith Julia Justin with her son, Jake, during therapy at Wings.
Chefs setting up the 88-m-long stollen on Wednesday.
Touch Young Arrows beneficiaries making Christmas cards with volunteers at the festive celebration on Saturday at Coliwoo Boon Lay.
Minister for Social and Family Development,Masagos Zulkifli hands out certificates to the participating designers and models.

site_title: Elite UK Reit expands into the ‘living sector’, but still plays it safe
summary: Elite UK Reit, a UK-focused real estate investment trust (Reit) listed in Singapore, is expanding into the "living sector" by converting vacant government-backed assets into student housing or build-to-rent residences. The Reit aims to reposition vacant offices and retains its government leases, seeking to diversify its income stream. Despite expanding into a new sector, the Reit remains cautious, focusing on safe bets and organic growth. CEO Joshua Liaw emphasizes the importance of having a Plan B, citing the stability of government credit and the demand for student accommodation and build-to-rent residences.

images.alt_text: The 15,785-square-foot St Paul's House, is on Marshfield Road in Chippenham, England.
KGI Securities says Elite UK Reit’s latest data centre development at Peel Park, Blackpool represents a “significant growth opportunity” as a low-emission data centre.
Newport Road, Cardiff, Wales. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead, and a building in Newport Road (pictured).

site_title: 10 Singapore stocks to watch in 2025
summary: Global markets head into 2025 with excitement and volatility expected, fueled by Donald Trump's return to the White House. The Business Times predicts moderate returns for the Singapore market in 2025, unlikely to repeat 2024's high. Key stocks to watch include NTT DC Reit's public offer, which was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology's potential revenue and operating loss. Interest rates are expected to ease, while investors will be monitoring market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions, particularly between the US and Europe. Stocks may be affected by these factors, leading to a cautious outlook for 2025.

site_title: Will South-east Asia’s ambitious EV targets drive the region’s sustainable future?
summary: South-east Asia's ambitious electric vehicle (EV) targets aim to drive the region's sustainable future, but the pace of adoption is hindered by high purchase prices and insurance costs. Despite incentives, EVs remain more expensive than internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles in countries like Malaysia, where domestic manufacturers dominate the market. The availability of charging infrastructure is also a critical factor, with countries like Thailand and Singapore facing challenges in scaling up their charging networks to meet demand. To achieve long-term sustainability goals, further investments in infrastructure and affordable alternatives are essential.

images.alt_text: Electric vehicles (ev) getting charged at the Shell Recharge charging station at Shell Lakeview station, 7 August 2023.

site_title: China to cut import tariffs on some recycled copper and aluminium raw materials
summary: China will reduce import tariffs on ethane and certain recycled copper and aluminium raw materials, effective January 1, to advance green and low-carbon development. The Ministry of Finance announced adjustments to various import tariff categories, including a reduction in tariffs on items such as sodium zirconium cyclosilicate and nickel-titanium alloy wires. The China-Maldives Free Trade Agreement will also come into effect on January 1, with tariff reduction implementations. The moves aim to increase imports of high-quality products, expand domestic demand, and promote high-level opening-up.

site_title: Bitcoin boom validates Wall Streeters who jumped into crypto
summary: A group of former Wall Street professionals, who left high-paying jobs for cryptocurrency, saw their career risks pay off when Bitcoin surged past $100,000 in December. Many, who took 75% pay cuts to join the crypto industry, are now seeing blockchain firms hire again and investors fund new projects. Despite knowing the rally won't last, they're taking the current gains in stride, with some even celebrating with champagne. The industry's recovery is attributed to the launch of crypto exchange-traded funds and institutional investors entering the market, making it more accessible to Main Street investors.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sparks strike representation of cryptocurrency Bitcoin in this illustration taken November 24, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, December 27, 2024
summary: Indian rupee and Japanese yen near record lows, while a Singapore renewable energy stock surged more than 370% this year. Chinese bonds posted their best returns in a decade with further gains anticipated.

images.alt_text: Both Vietnam and the Philippines consider the US a key trading and geopolitical partner, and these policy changes are set to take place as the new Trump administration comes in.
Tourist arrivals are gaining momentum in Asean post-pandemic.
SGX indicates that the top 100 most-traded stocks had total returns of 11 per cent in the first five months of the second half of 2024.

site_title: Cristiano Ronaldo slams ‘unfair’ Ballon d’Or result after Vinicius Junior snub
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo criticized the Ballon d'Or result, stating that Vinicius Junior deserved the award, despite losing to Manchester City midfielder Rodri. Ronaldo believes Vinicius' Champions League win should have been enough to secure the prize. The five-time Ballon d'Or winner was speaking at the Global Soccer Awards, where the ceremony was marred by controversy after Real Madrid boycotted the event.

images.alt_text: A view of the National Stadium at the Sports Hub. The new WTA 250 Singapore Tennis Open will be played at the Kallang Tennis Hub in January.

site_title: German president dissolves parliament for Feb 23 snap elections
summary: German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier dissolved parliament on December 27, paving the way for snap elections on February 23. The move comes after Chancellor Olaf Scholz's three-way coalition collapsed due to the departure of Finance Minister Christian Lindner's Free Democrats. Steinmeier called for a fair and transparent election campaign, emphasizing the need for a government capable of acting and reliable majorities. The conservative challenger Friedrich Merz is leading in polls, and the far-right Alternative for Germany is slightly ahead of the Social Democrats.

images.alt_text: Assuming the no-confidence vote passes, Olaf Scholz and his ministers will remain in office in an acting capacity until a new government is formed, which could take months if coalition negotiations prove lengthy.

site_title: Nasa spacecraft ‘safe’ after closest-ever approach to Sun
summary: NASA's Parker Solar Probe successfully completed the closest-ever approach to the Sun, passing 6.1 million kilometers from the solar surface on December 24. The spacecraft, launched in 2018, is operating normally and will send detailed telemetry data on January 1. Temperatures reached up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit as the probe flew into the sun's corona. The mission aims to study the Sun's outer atmosphere, heat, solar wind, and energetic particles, rewriting textbooks on the Sun's operation. The team plans for further flybys in the extended mission phase.

images.alt_text: China’s spacewalking milestone this week comes amid a flurry of other recent cosmic achievements that have boosted Beijing’s competitive footing with the US.

site_title: OCBC sells stake in Hong Kong Life Insurance for HK$589.3 million
summary: OCBC has agreed to sell its 33.3% stake in Hong Kong Life Insurance to Yue Xiu Enterprises for HK$589.3 million (S$103 million). The sale, subject to regulatory approvals, is not expected to impact OCBC's net tangible assets or earnings per share. This move allows OCBC to focus on its core banking business, while Yue Xiu Enterprises gains control of the insurance company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People pass an OCBC Bank signage in Singapore July 11, 2023. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Allocate to optimism – Positioning for growth and innovation in 2025
summary: The US economy is poised for an innovation-led expansion in 2025, driven by AI-driven productivity gains, accommodative monetary policy, and forward-looking deregulation. Key factors include the incoming administration's push for deregulation and government efficiency, the rapid application of AI across multiple sectors, and reindustrialisation of the US economy. The Federal Reserve is expected to maintain a neutral-to-dovish stance, supporting growth while balancing inflation risks. Despite some risks, the outlook is positive, with significant opportunities for investors to allocate to optimism in 2025.

images.alt_text: Given the broad consensus on China’s threat, tariffs on Chinese imports will inevitably rise. China has over US$300 billion trade deficit with the US

US president-elect Donald Trump has been clear about his policy priorities, which include a mix of widespread tariffs on imports to the US and more severe tariffs on Chinese imports (with the possibility that tariff threats could be used as a bargaining tool), along with mass deportations of immigrants believed to be in the US illegally
Even as the Fed chairman Powell stays in inflation-fighting mode in 2025, continued economic expansion and corporate earnings growth may well support further advances in the S&P 500

site_title: Netflix with Beyonce make splash despite NFL ratings fall
summary: Netflix's debut NFL broadcasts on Christmas Day received positive reviews and record streaming ratings, but still drew fewer viewers than linear broadcasts last year. The streaming giant paid a reported $150 million per year for a three-year deal for the games. Despite this, the venture was seen as a significant milestone for Netflix's entry into the sports market, exciting the sports business world after years of anticipation.

images.alt_text: About a 10th of the NFL’s audience comes from streaming, according to Sportico.

site_title: Montenegro to extradite crypto entrepreneur Do Kwon to US
summary: Montenegro will extradite South Korean cryptocurrency specialist Do Kwon to the US for his suspected role in the multi-billion-dollar bankruptcy of his company, Terraform Labs. Kwon is also wanted by Seoul for the same incident, which wiped out $40 billion of investors' money. His lawyers will appeal the decision to the European Court of Human Rights, citing European conventions on extradition. The extradition follows a year and a half of court rulings and reversals, with the majority of criteria favoring the US request.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representations of cryptocurrencies in this illustration taken, January 24, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Hackers hijack a wide range of companies’ Chrome extensions: experts
summary: Hackers have compromised several companies' Chrome browser extensions, including Cyberhaven, a data protection company, and at least one extension related to artificial intelligence and virtual private networks. The attacks, which began in mid-December, are believed to be part of a wider campaign targeting Chrome extension developers. Experts say the hackers appear to be opportunistic, using multiple compromised extensions to vacuum up sensitive data. The US cyber watchdog Cisa has referred questions to the companies involved, and Alphabet, the maker of Chrome, has not yet commented.

images.alt_text: The attack began at 7.24 am and affected the company’s internal and external systems, JAL says.
Sichuan Silence provides Chinese government intelligence officials with varied hacking and cybersecurity services, US authorities say.

site_title: Hin Leong’s founder OK Lim, children declared bankrupt
summary: OK Lim, founder of Hin Leong, and his two children, Lim Huey Ching and Lim Chee Meng, have been declared bankrupt after agreeing to pay US$3.5 billion to court-appointed liquidators and top creditor HSBC. The family's bankruptcy stems from a 50-day civil trial, with the court ruling they must pay the debt plus interest from April 2020. Lim, 82, was previously sentenced to 17 years and six months in prison for two counts of cheating and one count of forgery in a trade financing fraud case.

images.alt_text: Lim Oon Kuin has been sentenced to 17 years and six months imprisonment for three cheating and forgery charges.
Tan Sook Eng, the wife of convicted Hin Leong founder Lim Oon Kuin, has put her 999-year leasehold GCB in Queen Astrid Park on the market.
OK Lim and family have indicated they will file for bankruptcy after consenting to their creditors' judgements.

site_title: Brazil yanks temp work visas for China’s BYD after trafficking claims
summary: Brazil has stopped issuing temporary work visas for BYD, a Chinese electric vehicle producer, following accusations of human trafficking at a factory in the northeastern state of Bahia. 163 Chinese workers were found to be employed in "slavery-like" conditions, with some being victims of human trafficking. BYD has denied any wrongdoing and has agreed to assist the workers. The decision comes amid Brazil's growing relationship with China and BYD's significant investment in the country, including a $620 million factory complex.

images.alt_text: Hybrids will be “at the core of BYD strategy in Europe.
BYD has been on an extraordinary expansion this year, growing capacity and undertaking a massive hiring spree to turbocharge revenue.

site_title: SBF’s Lim Ming Yan to succeed Tan Gee Paw as CAG chairman in April 2025
summary: Lim Ming Yan, chairman of the Singapore Business Federation (SBF), will succeed Tan Gee Paw as chairman of Changi Airport Group (CAG) on April 1, 2025. In the interim, Lim will become CAG deputy chairman on January 1, 2025. Lim has extensive experience in large-scale project development and leadership, making him well-suited to lead CAG as it embarks on the next phase of growth. Tan Gee Paw will remain on the board as a director to support the transition.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
CAG says that North Asia continues to lead its passenger traffic this quarter.
Lim Ming Yan is re-elected as SBF chairman at the business chamber's 22nd annual general meeting.

site_title: Bezos’ Blue Origin gets FAA license for its first New Glenn rocket launch
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued a commercial space launch license to Blue Origin's New Glenn rocket, allowing the company to proceed with its first launch. This comes after Blue Origin, owned by Jeff Bezos, was selected, along with SpaceX and a Boeing-Lockheed joint venture, to compete for national security space missions under a $5.6 billion US program. The license marks a significant milestone for Blue Origin, which has struggled to bring its giant New Glenn rocket to market. The company is now poised to launch its first mission.

images.alt_text: It’s the latest tit-for-tat between the world’s two richest individuals, whose businesses compete in the commercial space industry.

site_title: Flood-soaked US homeowners face a costly choice: raise or raze
summary: Flood-soaked US homeowners are facing a costly decision: either raise or raze their homes to avoid future flood disasters. The cost of house lifting, using hydraulic lifts to push homes upwards, can exceed the home's value, with prices ranging from $75 to $200 per square foot. Despite federal assistance, including low-interest disaster loans, many homeowners are opting to pay for the lifts themselves, as the process can take years and funds are limited. As a result, neighborhoods like Shore Acres in Florida are becoming an eclectic mix of elevated homes and destroyed ones, with some homeowners willing to pay the price for peace of mind.

images.alt_text: The Shefman family at their elevated home, in HoustonÕs bayou-hugging Meyerland neighborhood, on Dec. 17, 2024. As climate change intensifies, flooding is emerging as a threat for homes not previously seen as high-risk. Some residents are responding creatively by lifting up their homes. (Mark Felix/The New York Times)

site_title: Chicago loses another financial firm as Peak6 moves HQ to Austin
summary: Peak6 Investments, a financial firm with a portfolio of early-stage businesses and professional sports teams, is relocating its global headquarters from Chicago to Austin, Texas. The move aims to bring the executive team closer to the majority of its workers, who are already in Texas. Peak6 cited Austin's educated workforce, business climate, and culture as top reasons for the relocation. This marks the latest corporate departure from Chicago, following firms such as Citadel, Caterpillar, and Boeing. The firm will maintain a Chicago office after the change.

images.alt_text: Built in 1995, during the height of Jordan’s time on the National Basketball Association’s Chicago Bulls, the home is on a seven-acre lot and has nine bedrooms and 19 bathrooms.

site_title: Impeached South Korean president defies summons third time in a row
summary: South Korea's suspended President Yoon Suk-yeol defied a summons to appear for questioning for the third time, rejecting investigators' demands to answer for insurrection charges. The conservative leader, a former prosecutor, was stripped of his duties by parliament on December 14 following a short-lived martial law declaration. Yoon faces impeachment and potential life imprisonment or the death penalty. The Corruption Investigation Office will review future measures, with a possible fourth summons or arrest warrant in the coming days.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivers an address to the nation at the Presidential Office in Seoul, South Korea, December 12, 2024. site_title: Jaecoo J7 review: Good wheel hunting
summary: The Jaecoo J7, a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV), has impressed with its seamless transition between electric and petrol modes, offering an 80km electric range and a full tank of 1,200km. The J7's PHEV powertrain bridges the gap between battery power and fossil fuels convincingly, making it a viable option for daily commuting and longer drives. With its handsome design, decent cabin space, and commendable build quality, the J7 is a car of hits and misses. Its overall performance and efficiency make it a strong contender in the market, potentially popularizing plug-ins in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The 001 FR’s battery pack dumps out so much energy, it could power 97,000 household LED bulbs, meaning it could light up a few HDB blocks by itself.

site_title: Drone maker Baykar gets nod to buy Italy’s Piaggio Aerospace
summary: Turkey's Baykar Makina Sanayi ve Ticaret Anonim Sirketi has received authorization from Italian authorities to purchase aviation and defense company Piaggio Aerospace. The deal, which has not disclosed financial terms, marks the relaunch of Piaggio Aerospace, which has been in state-supervised insolvency proceedings since 2018. Industry Minister Adolfo Urso hailed the acquisition as a strategic asset for Italy, with Baykar expected to bring a clear and ambitious industrial vision to the company.

images.alt_text: Prime Air drone package deliveries, first launched in December 2022, are currently operational in a couple of US locations in Texas and Arizona.
Multi-rotor drones are inherently limited in speed and range compared to fixed-wing drones but have better control and manoeuvrability.
The defence department maintains an updated list of Chinese military companies as part of the National Defense Authorization Act.

site_title: Five sports wishes for a happy 2025
summary: Sports enthusiasts are looking forward to exciting events in 2025, including top-class tennis at the Singapore Tennis Open, potential visits from European football clubs to Singapore, and a wider range of live sports on streaming platforms like Netflix. Fans are also eager to see a closer fight in Europe's top football leagues, a potential reunion in golf, and the rise of F1 rookies, including 18-year-old Kimi Antonelli and former Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton's return to Ferrari.

images.alt_text: 位于加冷一带的新加坡体育城（Singapore Sports Hub）外观。

site_title: MAS chief Chia Der Jiun on crypto, AI and battling inflation
summary: MAS chief Chia Der Jiun discusses the central bank's stance on crypto, AI, and battling inflation. MAS has been taking a lead in regulating fintech, aiming to take advantage of new technologies while minimizing risks. The central bank kept its monetary policy unchanged in October due to the country's strengthening growth momentum and anticipated decline in core inflation. MAS has made progress in fighting inflation, with core inflation coming down to 2.1% in October. The central bank has also announced plans to issue a digital Singapore dollar for wholesale settlement and is working on a regulatory framework for cryptocurrency exchanges.

images.alt_text: Singapore doled out 13 crypto licenses in 2024 to a range of crypto operators including top exchanges OKX and Upbit, as well as global heavyweights Anchorage, BitGo and GSR.

site_title: JBS, Marfrig shares tumble as China launches beef-import probe
summary: China launches a probe into its imports of beef from Brazil, Argentina, and Australia, amid concerns that a surge in overseas shipments may have hurt the domestic industry. The investigation, launched at the request of China's domestic industry associations, is likely to determine if protectionist measures are needed. Shares of JBS, Marfrig, and other major meat companies have tumbled, with JBS falling as much as 3.3% and Marfrig losing as much as 7.8%. The probe could lead to tariffs, potentially harming major exporters and companies in the US.

images.alt_text: Industrial profits are a vital gauge of the financial health of factories, mines and utilities, shaping their investment decisions in the months to come.
Beijing set a growth target of “around 5 per cent” this year, a goal it says it is confident of achieving.
China’s top leaders has placed boosting domestic demand as their top priority for economic work in 2025.

site_title: Bank Indonesia’s 25% stake in bond market fuels liquidity fears
summary: Bank Indonesia, Indonesia's central bank, has purchased about 25% of the country's outstanding bonds, a record high, amid efforts to boost the rupiah and stabilize yields. The central bank's quantitative-easing program has fueled liquidity fears, with some experts warning that if it reaches 30% ownership, it could reduce liquidity in the secondary market and lead to inflation. The bank's purchases have helped narrow the yield gap between Indonesian bonds and similar-maturity Treasuries, but investors remain wary of potential stress in the bond market.

images.alt_text: The raid was on Thursday, days after the agency conducted similar search at the central bank’s headquarters, Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) said.
The rupiah had weakened by as much as 1.03 per cent to 16,250 per a dollar as of 0240 GMT, its lowest level since Aug 2.
Bank Indonesia on Tuesday said it respected the investigation and would cooperate with the anti-graft agency.

site_title: China says new housing metrics behind upward revision to 2023 GDP
summary: China revised its 2023 GDP upward by 3.4 trillion yuan, or 2.7%, to 129.4 trillion yuan, due to changes in housing sector calculation methods, which will affect 2024's GDP size but have little impact on growth rate. The change comes from switching to using rental values instead of the previous housing cost calculation method, resulting in a 1.3 trillion yuan increase in housing services' contribution to the economy. This revision affects the size of the economy but not its growth rate.

images.alt_text: China’s home prices fell at the slowest pace in 17 months in November, supported by government efforts to revive the sector, official data showed.
Property developers in the country are still suffering from a yearslong slump that has sapped the confidence of potential buyers.
The government will promote the recovery of the property market through measures such as increasing demand and controlling the supply of land for new development.

site_title: OpenAI mulls plan for a more conventional for-profit business
summary: OpenAI, the artificial intelligence company, is considering a restructuring plan that would create a more conventional for-profit business alongside a non-profit arm. The company's existing for-profit arm is currently controlled by its non-profit organization. Under the new plan, the non-profit arm would hold shares in the for-profit entity, aiming to balance profit and societal goals. The board is evaluating the proposal, which has been in talks with regulators in California and Delaware. The move aims to create a more conventional business structure while retaining the non-profit's mission to better society.

images.alt_text: Microsoft 365 Copilot is an AI assistant built into Microsoft’s suite of enterprise software including Word and PowerPoint.
FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
OpenAI’s new o3 and o3 mini models will be more powerful than its previously launched o1 models.

site_title: Taiwan’s science ministry warns spending cuts could hit chips, AI funding
summary: Taiwan's Ministry of Science and Technology warns that funding for semiconductor, AI, and aerospace projects could be reduced by NT$20 billion (S$828 million) for next year due to opposition party laws requiring cuts to economic and technology spending. The opposition parties' legislation, passed last week, redirects spending from the central government to local municipalities, strongly opposed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. This reduction may impact Taiwan's international AI technology partnerships and collaborations with tech companies such as Micron, AMD, and Nvidia.

site_title: China’s Xi says nation faces ‘arduous’ reform, stability tasks
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated the nation faces "arduous" reform, development, and stability tasks in 2025, following the achievement of economic and social targets in 2024. Xi urged officials to address people's pressing needs and vowed to deepen reforms to boost economic recovery. The Communist Party will also combat corruption with a resolute attitude. In response to a potential new Trump presidency, China's top policymakers have adopted a more pro-growth policy stance, including the use of fiscal tools to mitigate the impact of potential US tariffs.

site_title: Bitcoin’s ‘Kimchi Premium’ jumps amid South Korean political turmoil
summary: South Korea's political turmoil has led to a surge in the "Kimchi Premium," a metric measuring interest in Bitcoin from investors in the country, to a four-month high of 3-5%. The premium, which compares Bitcoin on South Korean exchange Upbit to Coinbase, indicates elevated demand from South Korean-based investors. The turmoil, which includes the impeachment of President Yoon Suk-yeol and Prime Minister Han Duck-soo, has led to increased economic challenges and nuclear threats, causing a decline in the South Korean won against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Trump plans to issue a flurry of executive orders and directives on everything from immigration to energy on his first day in office on Jan 20.
Singapore doled out 13 crypto licenses in 2024 to a range of crypto operators including top exchanges OKX and Upbit, as well as global heavyweights Anchorage, BitGo and GSR.
The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.

site_title: Bezos’ Miami neighbour seeks US$200 million for empty 0.7 ha lot
summary: A Miami neighbor of Jeff Bezos is seeking $200 million for a 0.74-hectare waterfront lot in Indian Creek, a man-made barrier island dubbed "Billionaire Bunker." The lot, purchased in 2018 for $27.5 million, features pre-designed plans for a 2,322.6 square meter estate. Bezos has bought three properties in the area since 2023, including two adjacent to the lot, and the sale is expected to set a record for the region. The seller is willing to negotiate, but the price is seen as a significant reflection of the area's growing luxury market.

images.alt_text: Jeff Bezos has been steadily offloading Amazon shares this year.

site_title: Philippine central bank extends 2% to 4% inflation target through 2028
summary: The Philippine central bank has extended its inflation target of 2-4% through 2028, citing a manageable inflation outlook despite upside risks. The target range remains suitable for the economy's current structure and macroeconomic outlook. Inflation has averaged 3.2% from January to November, within the target range for 2024. The bank believes that prospects for aggregate demand and supply-side conditions support a stable inflation environment.

images.alt_text: Both Vietnam and the Philippines consider the US a key trading and geopolitical partner, and these policy changes are set to take place as the new Trump administration comes in.
The BSP capped off the year with a third quarter-point rate cut on Thursday, as inflation remained on target and economic growth slowed.

site_title: Europe: Shares close out holiday-affected week higher on finance, healthcare boost
summary: Europe's pan-European benchmark Stoxx 600 index closed 0.7% up, its first weekly advance in three, driven by gains in healthcare and financial shares. Autos was the biggest percentage advancer, while Eurozone banks added 1.3%. Despite scaling all-time highs earlier this year, the index's 2024 gain stands at 5.2%. Geopolitical tensions, a sluggish Chinese recovery, and a lackluster domestic economic outlook have contributed to the slow momentum, contrasting with the US S&P 500's 25% gain for the year.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 gauge closed 0.1 per cent higher.

site_title: Choi Sang-mok is South Korea’s second acting president in weeks
summary: South Korea's acting President Han Duck-soo was impeached by lawmakers amid disagreements over appointing justices to the Constitutional Court. Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok, 61, has taken over as acting president for the second time in two weeks, following the impeachment. This marks the first time South Korea has impeached an interim leader. The move fuels political uncertainty in the country, which is Asia's fourth-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Economists are increasingly speculating the BOK may accelerate its easing cycle as the economy slows more quickly than anticipated.

site_title: Alibaba joint venture EV brand IM Motors to take on Tesla, XPeng in Singapore
summary: China's IM Motors, a joint venture between SAIC and Alibaba, will debut its electric vehicle (EV) brand in Singapore at the 2025 motorshow on Jan 9. The brand will offer premium, high-tech EVs, competing with Tesla and XPeng. IM Motors will be positioned as a premium sub-brand of MG Motors, with distribution handled by Eurokars Group. Two models, the IM5 sedan and IM6 SUV, will be showcased, with sales set to begin in the second half of 2025, competing with Tesla Model 3 and Model Y.

images.alt_text: People stand under the logo of IM Motors, an electric vehicle (EV) brand jointly founded by SAIC Motor, Zhangjiang Hi-Tech and Alibaba Group, during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/file photo

IM Motors, which is also backed by Alibaba Group investments, says its EVs could be among the first models approved as legitimate highly autonomous driving vehicles by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT).

site_title: Chinese bonds post best returns in decade with more gains seen
summary: Chinese government bonds are poised for their best year in a decade, with a predicted 9% total return in 2024, driven by prolonged economic weakness and bets for more monetary easing. The 10-year yields have plummeted 84 basis points since January, dropping to 1.71%. Fund managers forecast yields to drop further to 1.5-1.6% by 2025, despite concerns over increased debt issuance and a surge in special treasury bonds. The People's Bank of China's accommodative stance and subdued economic growth are expected to absorb the increased supply, supporting the local bond market.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders has placed boosting domestic demand as their top priority for economic work in 2025.

site_title: Oil settles up over 1% on large draw from US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Friday, settling at $74.17 per barrel, driven by a larger-than-expected drawdown of 4.2 million barrels from US crude inventories. Brent crude futures gained 1.2% to $74.17 per barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose 1.4% to $70.60 per barrel. Optimism over Chinese economic growth and year-end trading contributed to the gains. However, tensions in the Middle East, including the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine, may impact supplies next year.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down 32 US cents, or 0.43 per cent, at US$73.26 a barrel.

site_title: Singapore’s blue-chip gauge closes 0.3% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher on Friday, December 27, driven by gains from Jardine Matheson and Thai Beverage. The blue-chip gauge surpassed its last Friday's close by 1.4%. Trading volumes were low, with 852.8 million securities valued at S$538.9 million being transacted. The market is expected to drift until significant economic data is released, according to SPI Asset Management's managing partner Stephen Innes.

images.alt_text: ST20240422_202439334845 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the SGX logo at the SGX Centre 1, located in Shenton Way, on April 22, 2024.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.1 per cent at 43,325.80.

site_title: All fuelled up: Renewable energy wave pushes this Singapore stock to surge more than 370% this year
summary: Singapore's top stocks have surged, with the Straits Times Index reaching a 17-year high in November. The top 100 most-traded stocks have seen a 11% total return in the first five months of the second half of 2024, driven by broader gains in local manufacturing stocks and real estate investment trusts. Stocks such as Oiltek, Wee Hur, and Beng Kuang have outperformed, with Oiltek's shares surging over 370% this year, Wee Hur jumping 117% and Beng Kuang rising 259%. The strong performance is attributed to stronger economic momentum in Singapore and the Asean region.

images.alt_text: As general market sentiments improve, SGX is poised for heightened IPO activities next year, said observers.
Low liquidity and poor quality of listings cause Singapore retail investors to shun most SGX-listed stocks.

site_title: Japan government approves record Budget for ageing population, defence
summary: Japan's government approved a record budget of 115.5 trillion yen (S$996 billion) for the next fiscal year, with 8.7 trillion yen allocated to defence spending to tackle regional threats. The budget includes increased social security spending and aims to address Japan's ageing population, with 29.3% of the population aged 65 or over. The move is part of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's efforts to strengthen defence capabilities and address the country's security environment, which has been described as the "toughest and most complex" since World War II.

images.alt_text: The Tokyo inflation data is closely watched by policymakers for clues on how much progress Japan is making towards durably meeting the BOJ’s 2 per cent inflation target.
A positive output gap occurs when actual output exceeds the economy’s full capacity, and it is considered a sign of strong demand.
Shigeru Ishiba is a strong advocate of raising spending on defence and improving the working conditions of those employed in the nation’s military amid a tense regional security environment.
The BOJ next meets for a rate review on Jan 23 to 24, followed by another meeting on Mar 18 to 19.

site_title: Big Lots strikes deal to save stores, stop brand from closing
summary: Big Lots has struck a deal with Gordon Brothers Retail Partners and Variety Wholesalers to save hundreds of stores after an earlier sale fell apart. The proposed transaction will transfer the Big Lots brand, stores, and distribution centers to other operators, potentially avoiding the closure of all locations. Variety Wholesalers plans to acquire 200-400 locations, keeping the Big Lots name and employing associates. The deal is subject to closing conditions and must be approved by a bankruptcy judge.

images.alt_text: Big Lots shopping carts outside a store in Los Angeles, California, US, on Saturday, Sept. 7, 2024. Discount home goods retailer Big Lots Inc. is preparing to file for bankruptcy as soon as Sunday, and plans to sell its chain of stores via a court-supervised process, according to people familiar with the plans. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks tumble at end of holiday week
summary: US stocks plummeted at the end of the holiday week, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 0.8% to 42,992.21, the S&P 500 sliding 1.1% to 5,970.84, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropping 1.5% to 19,722.03. Major tech companies, including Microsoft, Amazon, and Nvidia, saw significant declines. Analysts attribute the sell-off to a "year-end adjustment" and rising US Treasury bond yields, which are putting a "brake" on the market.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Monday, Dec. 9, 2024. Stocks struggled to make headway, following a furious rally that put the market on pace for its best year since 2019, with traders awaiting key inflation data that will help shape the outlook for Federal Reserve rates. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Bitcoin rally fizzles as token’s record-breaking year winds down
summary: Bitcoin's record-breaking year is ending with a decline, as the token fell 3% to $95,600 on Dec 27. Investors await US President-elect Donald Trump's crypto-friendly policies, which may include a national Bitcoin reserve. The crypto market is also bracing for the expiry of substantial options contracts on Friday, which could lead to a "choppy market." Despite MicroStrategy's expansion of its Bitcoin purchases, Bitcoin is headed for its first monthly decline in four.

images.alt_text: Trump plans to issue a flurry of executive orders and directives on everything from immigration to energy on his first day in office on Jan 20.
Singapore doled out 13 crypto licenses in 2024 to a range of crypto operators including top exchanges OKX and Upbit, as well as global heavyweights Anchorage, BitGo and GSR.
The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.

site_title: Philippine, Vietnam investors say ‘shake ‘em off’ to taxes and tariffs in 2025
summary: The Philippines and Vietnam may attract more investor attention in 2025, dubbed as the "next Indonesia", amid economic challenges in the region. The Jakarta-based unicorn eFishery is undergoing an investigation due to alleged financial irregularities, and Indonesia's dwindling middle class is squeezing consumer startup brands' margins. Meanwhile, Vietnam is seeing a surge in foreign investment following sweetened US trade terms, with stocks popping as investors return. The region's economy is facing growth jitters due to tariff threats, with Malaysia implementing a rate cut to shield its economy.

images.alt_text: Game publishers are expected to enforce a time limit of an hour per game session and not more than 180 minutes a day for all games.
Nvidia has listed 11 job postings in Vietnam – all them for remote working, with half not specifying a particular city.
One of the ports in Haiphong, Vietnam, which are now among the busiest in the world, Nov 28, 2024.

site_title: Osamu Suzuki, who ran automaker for five decades, dies at 94
summary: Osamu Suzuki, the 94-year-old former president of Suzuki Motor, died of lymphoma on December 25, 2024. Suzuki, who ran the automaker for five decades, led the company's global expansion and formed partnerships with General Motors and Volkswagen. He was known for his leadership philosophy of "never stop, or else you lose" and his expansion into India, where Suzuki Motor's Indian unit, Maruti Suzuki, became the biggest carmaker. Suzuki's tenure saw the company sell 3.2 million vehicles worldwide in 2024, but trailing Japan's dominant carmaker, Toyota Motor.

images.alt_text: Chair of Japan automaker Suzuki to step down

site_title: Hong Kong home prices flat in November
summary: Hong Kong's home prices remained flat in November, marking a potential bottom for the struggling property market. Prices have dropped nearly 30% from their 2021 peak, driven by higher mortgage rates, an outflow of professionals, and a weak market outlook. Following a 0.9% rise in October, home prices are expected to fluctuate in 2025, with forecasts ranging from a 5% drop to a 5% rise, depending on interest rate cuts and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is reviewing Hong Kong brokers, representatives of US underwriters and investors backing the Nasdaq-listed companies in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is on track for its first annual gain since 2019, rising more than 18 per cent so far this year, boosted by a sharp rally in September.
Once synonymous with Hong Kong nightlife and in particular the city’s expat community, Lan Kwai Fong’s business mix is now changing to reflect what is becoming an increasingly Chinese city.

site_title: Shell shuts Pulau Bukom unit after suspected oil leak
summary: Shell has temporarily shut down an oil-processing unit at Pulau Bukom in Singapore after a suspected leak of a few tonnes of oil mixed with cooling water discharge. Containment measures have been activated, including the deployment of absorbent booms, dispersants, and an oil-skimmer system. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, along with the National Environment Agency and other agencies, are monitoring the situation and have placed oil absorbent booms at nearby marine parks and beaches. The shutdown does not affect navigational traffic or bunkering operations at the Port of Singapore.

images.alt_text: An oil absorbing boom has been deployed at the East Coast beach.

site_title: ‘Squid Game’ stocks tank in South Korea on Netflix new season letdown
summary: Shares of South Korean companies related to Netflix's 'Squid Game' plummeted following the underwhelming debut of the show's new season. Artist United, a movie distributor, fell 30% and Wysiwyg Studios dropped 25% after the season's release on Dec 26. The third and final season is set to premiere in 2025. Despite some positive reviews from critics and viewers, The New York Times described the season as "stalling" and lacking in pursuing larger ambitions. The poor performance has sharply lowered the stocks of related companies.

site_title: Thailand to implement global minimum corporate tax rate from Jan 1
summary: Thailand will implement a global minimum corporate tax of 15% starting January 1, 2025, following the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's (OECD) framework. The tax will apply to multinational enterprises with an annual global turnover of over $1.06 billion, regardless of their location. This move is expected to align Thailand's corporate tax rate with other countries, including Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore, which also plan to implement the minimum tax rate in 2025.

site_title: A New Year’s resolution for progress: Focus on what works
summary: A new year offers a fresh opportunity to focus on interventions that yield the highest return on investment for people, the planet, and future generations. The UN's 169 Sustainable Development Goals have struggled to make progress due to trying to do too much. Instead, experts recommend prioritizing the 12 smartest global goals that deliver the most return on investment. These include providing essential nutrients to pregnant women, improving learning through individualized education, and tackling diseases like malaria. By focusing on what works, individuals and governments can make a significant impact in one year, achieving more than in a decade of dithering.

images.alt_text: Patients diagnosed with tuberculosis in Maputo, Mozambique. TB has been treatable for more than 50 years, yet still kills more than 1.4 million people annually.
The second Sustainable Development Goals summit in New York. Progress on the goals is happening at less than a quarter of the pledged speed.

A fallen saguaro cactus decays in the Sonoran Desert near Arizona, US, Aug 2. The cacti are under stress from extreme heat during Arizona’s brutal summer. Heatwaves capture the headlines but globally, cold causes far more deaths.

A Yemeni child waits for her mother receiving food aid, at a camp for Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) on the outskirts of Sana'a, Yemen, April 2022. Years of civil war have resulted in severe food insecurity, and hence a crisis of hunger and malnourishment, for millions of Yemenis.

site_title: Quartz watches are having a movement
summary: Quartz watches are gaining popularity among collectors and enthusiasts, who are appreciating their accuracy, convenience, and affordability. Brands such as Tag Heuer, Grand Seiko, and Citizen are releasing high-quality quartz timepieces, including limited-edition models. This shift is attributed to a growing emphasis on design and technological advancement, as well as the industry's efforts to overcome the stigma associated with quartz watches since the 1970s. Some watchmakers, such as Hz Watches and Furlan Marri, are embracing quartz as a core component of their designs, offering high-end watches at affordable prices.

images.alt_text: The Vulcain Nautical Legacy Massena LAB.
Teamwork is key at Tag Heuer
The Aquaracer Professional 200 is slimmer than previous models.

site_title: World Bank raises China’s GDP forecast for 2024, 2025
summary: The World Bank raised China's economic growth forecast for 2024 and 2025 to 4.9% and 4.5%, respectively. The increase is attributed to recent policy easing and near-term export strength. However, the Bank warns that subdued household and business confidence, along with challenges in the property sector, will weigh down growth next year. To revive growth, Chinese authorities plan to issue a record 3 trillion yuan in special treasury bonds. The growth target for 2024 is "around 5%," but a turnaround in the property sector is not anticipated until late 2025.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders has placed boosting domestic demand as their top priority for economic work in 2025.
China in 2019 cut the VAT rate for manufacturers to 13 per cent from 16 per cent, and to 9 per cent from 10 per cent for the transportation and construction sectors.
The overseas spending is contributing to a gloomy outlook for the Chinese currency.
Determining whether the debt swap programme can succeed in rescuing rich provinces will likely take months, if not years.

site_title: Vietnam says to impose 97% anti-dumping duty on Chinese wind towers
summary: Vietnam plans to impose a 97% anti-dumping duty on wind towers originating from China, effective 15 days from signing, for five years. The move follows a 15-month investigation into the sector, which found Chinese-made towers were dumped and caused significant damage to domestic manufacturers. Vietnamese authorities concluded that domestic producers can produce high-quality wind towers for export, except for one Chinese firm found not to have engaged in dumping. The tariff will apply to almost all Chinese firms, with an exception for Jiangsu Zhenjiang New Energy Equipment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Vietnamese flag flies atop the State Bank building, near the Vietcombank and Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam buildings, in central Hanoi, Vietnam November 23, 2017. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: China’s local-finance cleanup opens new chapter with state firms
summary: China has approved two state-owned enterprises, China Reform Holdings and China Chengtong Holdings Group, to raise 500 billion yuan ($93 billion) in special bonds to stabilize the economy and expand investment. This is the first time such debt has been authorized by the central government, replacing local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) with greater oversight. The move aims to address the financial risks posed by LGFVs, which have been criticized for their lack of transparency and low returns on investment. The two companies will use the funds to invest in major national projects and support the government-led cash-for-clunkers programme.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders has placed boosting domestic demand as their top priority for economic work in 2025.
Determining whether the debt swap programme can succeed in rescuing rich provinces will likely take months, if not years.
Among individual nations, Beijing garnered some three out of four votes in Muslim-majority Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei.

site_title: US mortgage rates rise for second week to highest since July
summary: US mortgage rates rose for the second week to 6.85%, the highest level since early July. Despite the increase, homebuyers are still active, with contracts to buy homes up 4.1% from last year and new-home sales climbing in November. The new-home market is also showing signs of resilience, with inventory reaching its highest level since 2007. Economists expect mortgage rates to ease and housing inventory to grow in 2025, but limited home supply is expected to boost price growth.

site_title: Thai government suffers setback in bid to influence central bank
summary: The Thai government's bid to influence the central bank, the Bank of Thailand (BOT), has faced a significant setback. The Office of the Council of State ruled that former finance minister Kittiratt Na-Ranong, a nominee for chairman, is not qualified due to his role as an adviser to the prime minister and involvement in government administration. This decision could lead to political risks and challenges for the government if it tries to push ahead with Kittiratt's appointment. The BOT has cut its benchmark rate to 2.25% this year, but policymakers argue that rates are appropriate and other measures are needed to boost growth.

images.alt_text: “From our perspective, if it can be reduced, it’s good. We want it to be in line with inflation,” says Pichai Chunhavajira.
Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput also said debt support measures would be announced next week.
FILE PHOTO: Cargo ships are pictured near the port in Bangkok, Thailand, March 25, 2016. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo
Thai banks' non-performing loans hit 2.97% in September, highest in nearly three years, due to a loan base decline and higher NPLs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 27)
summary: Singapore's container throughput surpassed 40 million TEUs in 2024, breaking its record. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver the 2025 Budget statement on Feb 18. A new electric vehicle brand, IM Motors, backed by Alibaba and SAIC Motor, is set to debut in Singapore in 2025. CSE Global's financial performance may be affected by a US lawsuit. Singapore shares rose 0.3% on Friday, closing marginally higher after a little changed Wall Street overnight.

images.alt_text: PM Lawrence Wong fielding questions during the media wrap up after the Apec summit in Lima, Peru on Nov 16, 2024.

site_title: Higher education and the AI revolution in business
summary: Embedding Artificial Intelligence in business processes can boost the performance of entire economies. Companies and employees can make tremendous leaps ahead in competitiveness and productivity by infusing AI into business processes. A successful approach to modern technology education is to bring theory and practice together, such as gamified learning and real-world case studies. This approach allows students to gain hands-on experience and develop critical competencies, including analytical thinking and decision-making skills. By fostering collaboration between universities and companies, theory and practice can mutually inform each other, driving innovation and success in the AI age.

site_title: China industrial profits set for steepest annual drop since 2000
summary: China's industrial firms saw their profits drop 7.3% in November, on track for the steepest annual decline since 2000. Over the first 11 months, profits shrank 4.7% from the same period last year. The decline follows Beijing's efforts to revive the economy, but corporate finances remain under pressure due to weak domestic demand and deflation. The threat of steep tariffs under Donald Trump's presidency may further disrupt China's export sector, posing new challenges to the country's growth target of around 5% this year.

site_title: Asia: Japanese shares gain on weaker yen after Christmas break
summary: Japanese shares rose over 1% on Friday, driven by a weaker yen, which hit 158.08 per US dollar, its lowest level in almost six months. The Nikkei index also gained momentum from Thursday's 1.1% increase, boosted by the Bank of Japan's chief comments and Toyota's share price gains. However, investor attention is now focused on whether the Nikkei average will reach 40,000 points by the end of the year. The yen was slightly stronger on Friday after data showed inflation in Tokyo rose for a second month in December.

images.alt_text: Stock markets have traditionally fared well in the last five trading days of the year and the first two in the new year, a trend known as the “Santa Claus rally”.

site_title: China Eastern to debut C919 on Shanghai-Hong Kong route in January
summary: China Eastern Airlines will launch the first commercial cross-border service operated by C919 on the Shanghai-Hong Kong route on January 1. The daily return flight marks China's efforts to secure the first international customer for the C919, a narrow-body jet developed by Comac. The new service expands China Eastern's network to nine cities and comes as Comac seeks to obtain certifications for the C919 from the European Union by 2025. This launch is significant as it marks China's expansion into international markets for the C919, a jet with potential to rival the Boeing 737 MAX and Airbus A320neo.

images.alt_text: International flights from mid-tier Chinese cities are coming under scrutiny as the CAAC seeks to reign in services that may only exist because they are heavily subsidised.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar sees invaluable opportunity from Thaksin ties
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has expressed optimism about the potential benefits of his country's ties with former Thai leader Thaksin Shinawatra, who has a "unparalleled network of relationships across the region" and "unique expertise". The two met on Dec 26 to discuss regional priorities, including fostering peace in southern Thailand and addressing the Myanmar crisis. Anwar believes that Thaksin's connections will open opportunities for Malaysia and Asean to tackle these challenges with greater confidence and efficacy, as Malaysia prepares to take on the Asean chairmanship next year.

site_title: Inflation in Japan’s capital accelerates, keeps rate hike prospects intact
summary: Japan's Tokyo core inflation accelerated to 2.4% in December, exceeding market expectations, and keeping interest rate hike prospects intact. Factory output fell 2.3% in November, suggesting softening overseas demand is affecting the export-reliant economy. The Bank of Japan will consider these factors at its next policy meeting on Jan 23-24, with some analysts predicting a near-term interest rate hike.

site_title: South Korea’s business confidence tumbles by most since pandemic
summary: South Korea's business confidence plummeted 7.3 points to 82.4 in the Bank of Korea's composite sentiment index, the largest decline since April 2020. The drop reflects concerns over economic turmoil, including martial law and Donald Trump's tariff threats. The country's economy was already facing challenges, including weakening export momentum and semiconductor demand. Economists predict the Bank of Korea may accelerate interest rate cuts due to the economy's faster-than-anticipated slowdown. The decline in business confidence follows a separate consumer confidence index that also fell to its lowest since March 2020.

site_title: Singapore’s container throughput hits over 40 million TEUs in 2024, breaks record
summary: Singapore's container throughput reached over 40 million TEUs in 2024, breaking its previous record of 39 million TEUs in 2023. The milestone was achieved on December 24, surpassing PSA Singapore's previous annual high. Meanwhile, Shanghai Port's container throughput reached 50 million TEUs in 2024, setting a new global record. The strong performance is attributed to a "pro-business approach" and a strong tripartite partnership in Maritime Singapore.

images.alt_text: A cargo ship is seen past gantry cranes at the Pasir Panjang port terminal in Singapore on November 22, 2024.
