A logistics complex in Tilburg, the Netherlands, that is part of Cromwell E-Reit's portfolio.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares rose at the Tuesday morning open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.2% or 7.96 points to 3,760.29. Gainers outnumbered losers 57 to 27, with actively traded counters like Geo Energy Resources and Seatrium rising 1.7% and 1.6%, respectively. Banking stocks were mixed, while global markets followed overnight gains, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 rising 0.2% and 0.7%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Seatrium's twin cranes will be employed in a deepwater new-build floating production unit project in the Gulf of Mexico.

site_title: ASML sells ‘Lego’ model of most advanced chip machine to workers
summary: ASML Holding, the manufacturer of the world's most advanced chipmaking machines, is selling "Lego" replicas of its TWINSCAN EXE:5000 machines to employees as a 40th-anniversary celebration gift. The miniature models, priced at 208 euros, are not intended for public sale. The real machine costs 350 million euros and weighs as much as two Airbus A320s, with Intel being the first to receive a shipment. Employees are calling for wider availability, but the company says it's a "fun item for employees only."

site_title: China’s wild markets send Hong Kong derivatives to third record year
summary: Hong Kong's derivatives market has hit a record for the third consecutive year, with over 377 million futures and options traded since January, a 14% increase from 2023. China's economic stimulus package boosted trading, but the market's volatility surged due to traders betting on the market in a cautious way. Daily stock turnover in Hong Kong and China rose by over one-fifth, and the market is expected to continue growing, with efforts to expand the derivatives market and introduce new products.

images.alt_text: HKEX and SFC review all listing proposals in Hong Kong but there is currently no set timeframe to approve or reject an application.

The positions Wilfred Yiu will step down from include the deputy CEO of the Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) and the CEO of both the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK) and Hong Kong Futures Exchange (HKFE).

site_title: Indonesia probes ex-leader Megawati’s aide for graft, Detik says
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency, KPK, has identified Hasto Kristiyanto, a close aide of former president Megawati Soekarnoputri, as a suspect in a bribery case involving a former election commission official. The case, described by the opposition party as politically motivated, emerges weeks after Megawati's party expelled former president Joko Widodo for backing Prabowo Subianto's presidential bid. The KPK will issue a statement, and the party has vowed to protect democracy amid the pressure.

site_title: SEA unicorn list: Singapore’s Tyme Group joins US$1 billion club
summary: Tyme Group, a digital bank in Singapore, has joined the exclusive US$1 billion club, becoming the second South-east Asian startup to reach this valuation in 2024, following Silicon Box. The economic climate has made it difficult for startups to achieve unicorn status, with funding reduced by over 65% in 2023. The number of unicorns in the region has dwindled from 51 to 38 firms, according to Tech in Asia's analysis. Tyme Group's valuation is attributed to a recent $250 million funding round led by Nubank.

images.alt_text: Coen Jonker, co-founder and chief executive of Tyme, says the US$250 million raised is part of preparations for a listing in three to five years.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls as politics weigh on outlook
summary: US consumer confidence fell in December for the first time in three months, dropping to 104.7 due to concerns over the economy and politics. The decline was led by consumers over 35 years old and was attributed to uncertainty around the Trump administration's policies, including tariffs. A measure of expectations hit a five-month low, with 46% of respondents expecting tariffs to raise the cost of living. Economists attribute the decline to the incoming administration's spending cuts, which contradict Trump's election pitch.

images.alt_text: Labour market resilience has been driving economic expansion through strong consumer spending.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell  announced that the Federal Reserve is lowering interest rates by a quarter percentage point to a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent, Washington, US, Dec 18, 2024.
Manufacturing continues to tread water in the aftermath of the US central bank's aggressive monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 24)
summary: Business owners face difficulties accessing e-services and processing transactions on Acra's new Bizfile portal. Gojek and Tada raise platform fees from Jan 1 to cover costs from the upcoming Platform Workers Act. SingPost's proposed A$1b Australian business sale remains on track despite recent executive firings. Thai billionaire Charoen retires as F&N chairman in 2025. Condo resale prices rise in November, with volumes falling. Singapore stocks rise before the festive break, with the STI up 0.5%.

site_title: Singapore pulls ahead of Hong Kong in race to be crypto hub
summary: Singapore has pulled ahead of Hong Kong in its bid to become a cryptocurrency hub, doling out 13 crypto licenses in 2024, more than double the number awarded by Hong Kong the previous year. The city-state's supportive environment and more flexible regulatory regime have attracted top exchanges such as OKX and Upbit, while Hong Kong's restrictive policies and slow progress have hindered its efforts. Singapore's framework encourages interaction between new entrants and established institutions, creating a more innovative environment, according to experts.

images.alt_text: The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.
Much of Tether’s earnings come from investing its reserves backing stablecoins into US Treasuries, gold and other securities.
Worldcoin aims to create a global identity system by getting people to have their irises scanned in exchange for free cryptocurrency and a digital ID.

site_title: Thai billionaire Charoen to retire as F&N chairman in 2025; Koh Poh Tiong to step up
summary: Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi will retire as Fraser & Neave (F&N) chairman on Jan 16, 2025. He will be succeeded by Koh Poh Tiong, who has been serving as a non-independent and non-executive director since 2013. Charoen will be appointed as chairman emeritus, and his brother, Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi, will take over as vice-chairman. Charles Mak Ming Ying will retire from office, while shares in F&N rose 0.8% on the day prior to the announcement.

site_title: Malaysia targets Tier 2 cities in Indonesia and China for next wave of medical tourists
summary: Malaysia is targeting Tier 2 cities in Indonesia and China for its next wave of medical tourists, building on its 2023 revenue of RM2.25 billion from 1.4 million visitors. The country aims to maintain its cost advantage of up to 80% over higher-cost countries while offering high standards of care. Penang and the Klang Valley remain key hubs for medical tourism, with a range of treatments available, including fertility treatments and chronic disease management. The government has introduced a 30-day visa-free policy for key markets and a medical tourism visa, and analysts expect steady growth in the sector.

images.alt_text: Industry observers believe Singapore still has what it takes to remain at the top – largely by taking on complicated treatment and surgeries.

Chinese healthcare companies looking to increase their reach overseas are generally small- and medium-enterprises involved in medical devices, diagnostics, phamaceuticals and life sciences tools, says GL Capital partner Wang Yifei.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.

site_title: Shimao cuts asking price for Hong Kong’s second-largest hotel: source
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese developer, has reduced the asking price for a Sheraton-branded hotel in Tung Chung, Hong Kong, by a quarter to at least HK$4.5 billion. The 18-storey property, which comprises over 1,200 rooms, was first listed at HK$6 billion in March 2023. This move is part of Shimao's efforts to cash in on its offshore assets as it works on its restructuring, following a default in 2022. The sale may form part of an asset package for Shimao's debt restructuring plan.

images.alt_text: The development adds to the momentum gained by Shimao to push through the restructuring plan and continue operations.
The developer has been negotiating with creditors to refine the term sheet ahead of its next liquidation hearing in December.

site_title: PropertyBT: Are property agents still relevant - Insights from OrangeTee’s CEO
summary: Singapore's property market has over 35,000 agents, sparking debate on their value. OrangeTee's CEO Justin Quek says agents offer flexibility and human interaction, but technology is chipping away at their value proposition. High commissions often come from developments near ABSD deadlines, and the industry is considering changes to allow agents with fewer transactions to remain in the business. A Memorandum of Understanding aims to implement best practices, such as buyers paying for agents. Despite concerns, Justin believes human interaction remains essential in real estate transactions.

images.alt_text: Outlier housing transactions can capture the public's imagination.
Do property agents provide a valuable service?
Tony Tan, CEO of the manager of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT)

site_title: Gold steady ahead of holidays; US Fed outlook weighs
summary: Gold prices remained steady ahead of the Christmas holiday, trading flat at $2,614.87 per ounce, as investors anticipate a less aggressive path of interest rate cuts from the US Federal Reserve in 2025. Despite a 27% annual rise this year, the best performance since 2010, higher interest rates are expected to dull the appeal of non-yielding bullion. Markets are pricing in 35 basis points of rate cuts for 2025, but the outlook is uncertain with the return of US President Donald Trump in January.

images.alt_text: Spot gold traded flat at US$2,621.19 per ounce.

site_title: Japan, US blame North Koreans for US$300 million crypto theft
summary: A North Korean hacking group, believed to be part of the Lazarus Group, stole over US$300 million in cryptocurrency from Japan-based exchange DMM Bitcoin. The TraderTraitor group used a "targeted social engineering" operation, where a hacker posed as a recruiter on LinkedIn to gain access to the company's system. The hacker then manipulated a legitimate transaction request, resulting in the loss of 4,502.9 Bitcoins. The FBI and Japanese National Police Agency are investigating, and the US government is vowing to combat North Korea's use of cybercrime and cryptocurrency theft to generate revenue for the regime.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin’s pullback reflects expectations of slower US Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts in 2025.
Trump plans to issue a flurry of executive orders and directives on everything from immigration to energy on his first day in office on Jan 20.
The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.

site_title: Planned COE supply hikes in 2025 may not mean lower premiums
summary: Singapore's COE supply is expected to increase by at least 17% in 2025, driven by older vehicles exiting the market and government efforts to boost supply. However, the number of deregistrations is uncertain, and the distribution of 20,000 additional COEs announced in February 2025 remains unclear. Despite these unknowns, demand is expected to stay strong, driven by electric vehicles, especially in Category A, and owners looking to replace ageing cars. COE prices may not decrease significantly due to the supply hikes, and uncertainty over deregistrations and COE distribution may impact the market.

site_title: What to make of 2024
summary: 2024 was a tumultuous year marked by global conflicts, economic challenges, and shifting power dynamics. Geopolitical tensions escalated as war raged on in Gaza, Lebanon, Ukraine, and Sudan, while authoritarian regimes like China and Russia faced economic and social backlash. However, democratic resilience was also evident, with peaceful elections in India, South Africa, and the US, and a strong economy in the US that outpaced the rest of the G7. The year also highlighted the weaknesses of autocracies, with China's slowdown attributed to its political system and Russia's economic woes.

images.alt_text: America Inc under its brand new CEO Trump feels less like a blue chip and more like a private equity firm: it's a highly leveraged, short-term play with an average hold time of around four years.
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: US new home sales rebound in November after hurricane drag
summary: US new home sales rebounded 5.9% in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 664,000 units, exceeding economists' forecasts of 660,000 units. The sales pace for October was revised higher to 627,000 units, and sales increased 8.7% year-over-year. Rising mortgage rates, however, could hamper sales in 2025, with the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate rising to 6.72% last week. The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate, but projected only two rate reductions next year due to ongoing inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: New home sales plunged 17.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 610,000 units last month, the lowest level since December 2022.

site_title: Amicorp rejects 1MDB’s US$1 billion asset recovery claim
summary: Amicorp has rejected 1MDB's US$1 billion asset recovery claim, stating the claim is inaccurate and will be assessed by the BVI Court of Justice. Amicorp denies allegations of facilitating over US$7 billion in fraudulent transactions and claims it has cooperated with authorities on the scandal. The US$1 billion claim is part of a multibillion-dollar scandal involving former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, who is in jail for graft. Authorities in Asia, the US, and Europe are coordinating their investigations into the 1MDB money trail.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traffic passes a 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) billboard at the Tun Razak Exchange development in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 6, 2015. Malaysia's ringgit hit a 16-year low on Monday as political tensions mounted over a report that linked Prime Minister Najib Razak to probes into alleged corruption involving state fund 1MDB. Najib has denied taking any money from the debt-laden state fund or any other entity for personal gain. REUTERS/Olivia Harris/File Photo

site_title: TSMC shares touch record high, eyeing best year since 1999 on AI
summary: TSMC shares reached a record high, surpassing its November peak, as the company is poised for its best annual stock performance in 25 years. Expected to report 36% sales growth and a 58.3% gross profit margin for the December quarter, TSMC is a major beneficiary of the AI spending boom. The company's shares have surged 84% this year, driven by investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence trades, with analysts citing TSMC as a key player in the AI theme without picking a winner or technology.

site_title: How long can the Fed ‘put’ hold sway?
summary: The US Federal Reserve's "Fed put" has been a long-standing belief that the Fed will intervene with accommodative monetary policy to support the US equity market, particularly in times of market turmoil. This phenomenon, which has been in place for over 30 years, has been credited with stabilizing the market and preventing a complete rout. However, some experts argue that this reliance on the Fed put may be unsustainable and that the market is due for a correction, as the consensus among analysts is overly optimistic and the Fed has signaled fewer cuts next year due to inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: The "Fed put" first appeared in 1987, setting the precedent for Fed intervention and bred the belief that the central bank will always step in to ensure a quick recovery if the market crashed.

site_title: Australia’s risks tilt to downside, IMF says, urging restraint
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Australia's balance of risks is tilted to the downside, citing a potential stall in disinflation and urging restraint from the government. The IMF advises supporting the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) restrictive monetary stance with fiscal policy that avoids excessive spending. Australia's strong fiscal impulse has led the RBA to resist joining a global easing cycle, with its key rate remaining at a 13-year high of 4.35%. The IMF expects a soft landing for Australia, but warns of downside risks.

images.alt_text: Australian retail spending has risen strongly, underlining tax cuts and strong consumer confidence, and is expected to pick up in 2025 after the Australian central bank begins to ease interest rates.

Facing a tough election next year, the centre-left Labor government led by Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said the economy had slowed under the weight of high interest rates and elevated inflation, but insisted public spending would help ensure a soft landing.
The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index of consumer sentiment fell 2.0 per cent in December, unwinding a little of the sharp gains seen over the previous two months.

site_title: Microsoft works to add non-OpenAI models into 365 Copilot products: sources
summary: Microsoft is diversifying its Microsoft 365 Copilot AI product by adding internal and third-party AI models to reduce dependence on OpenAI's technology, which is currently used in the product. The move aims to lower costs and improve speed for enterprise users, with Microsoft seeking to customise other open-weight models to make 365 Copilot faster and more efficient. This effort follows similar moves by other Microsoft business units, such as GitHub, which have started using alternative AI models. The goal is to make 365 Copilot less expensive for Microsoft and potentially pass along savings to customers.

images.alt_text: Hui Li Lee, Managing Director, Microsoft Singapore.
Microsoft acquired a minority stake in Cruise in January 2021 in a combined new equity investment of more than US$2 billion.

Tech companies that compete with Microsoft in renting out cloud servers, such as Google and Amazon, also want to host OpenAI’s models so that their cloud customers don’t need to access Microsoft servers to get access to the startup’s technology, the report said.
Microsoft’s existing data centres will continue to use a mix of older technologies, but new projects will begin using the zero-water designs in 2026.

site_title: Greenland is not for sale, its leader says in response to Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has stated that the US feels "the ownership and control of Greenland is an absolute necessity" for national security and freedom. However, Greenland's Prime Minister Mute Egede responded that the island is not for sale and will never be for sale, emphasizing the need to protect its long struggle for freedom. The Danish government has also rejected any discussion of control over Greenland, with a member of parliament stating that any US activities aiming to take control must be prohibited and countered.

images.alt_text: The Old Colonial Harbour in Nuuk, Greenland, whose upgraded airport will make it more accessible to tourists wanting to visit this icy land with its rugged landscapes.

site_title: US: Wall St mixed at start of holiday-shortened week
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Monday, Dec 23, as investors contended with a slower pace of rate cuts from the US central bank next year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 39.8 points, or 0.09%, to 42,800.49. In contrast, the S&P 500 rose 9.4 points, or 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 68.5 points, or 0.35%. The mixed results were attributed to a stopgap government funding bill averted a partial shutdown, easing concerns.

site_title: US Fed floats major changes to bank stress tests in light of legal rulings
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering major changes to its annual bank stress tests in light of recent legal rulings. The proposed changes include allowing lenders to provide comment on the models used and hypothetical scenarios, and averaging results over two years to reduce volatility. The moves follow the Supreme Court's overturning of a precedent that gave deference to government agencies in interpreting laws, making the stress tests more vulnerable to litigation. Industry groups have been lobbying for increased transparency and the changes are seen as a victory for Wall Street banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building is seen in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo
Powell voices waning enthusiasm for interest-rate cuts and sent stocks and bonds to their worst sessions in months.
The Brazilian real sank overnight to a lifetime low, prompting the central bank to sell dollars via a spot auction.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, Sembcorp, F&N
summary: Seatrium awarded a contract by BP Exploration and Production for a deepwater new-build floating production unit in the US Gulf of Mexico, utilizing its twin cranes. Sembcorp Industries joined the Dow Jones Sustainability Index, and Fraser and Neave's board chairman, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, will retire on Jan 16, 2025, with Koh Poh Tiong succeeding him.

site_title: US crypto industry eyes possible day-one Trump executive orders
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is set to issue executive orders on January 20 to overhaul the country's cryptocurrency policy, a move that could help push tokens mainstream. Industry officials are pushing for orders that would create a Bitcoin stockpile, ensure access to banking services, and establish a crypto council. Analysts are divided on whether Trump can use executive powers to create a strategic bitcoin reserve or if an act of Congress is necessary. The industry is also seeking executive orders to address issues such as regulatory scrutiny and the lack of access to traditional financial services.

images.alt_text: Singapore doled out 13 crypto licenses in 2024 to a range of crypto operators including top exchanges OKX and Upbit, as well as global heavyweights Anchorage, BitGo and GSR.
The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.
Much of Tether’s earnings come from investing its reserves backing stablecoins into US Treasuries, gold and other securities.
Worldcoin aims to create a global identity system by getting people to have their irises scanned in exchange for free cryptocurrency and a digital ID.

site_title: US insurer MetLife acquires PineBridge Investments in up to US$1.2 billion deal
summary: US insurer MetLife has agreed to acquire PineBridge Investments, a global asset manager, in a deal valued at up to $1.2 billion. The deal includes an $800 million upfront cash payment, with additional $200 million tied to 2025 financial targets and a multi-year earnout structure. The acquisition excludes PineBridge's private equity funds group business and its joint venture in China. The deal aims to expand MetLife's investment management capabilities.

site_title: US: Tech gains lift stocks despite early weakness
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, despite early weakness, driven by gains in tech equities such as Nvidia. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.2%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.7% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1%. The market's gains were partly attributed to low trading volumes ahead of the holiday. The US consumer confidence index fell to 104.7 in December, down from 112.8 in November, amid concerns over new tariffs threatened by President-elect Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024. Federal Reserve officials lowered their benchmark interest rate for a third consecutive time, but reined in the number of cuts they expect in 2025, signaling greater caution over how quickly they can continue reducing borrowing costs. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Telegram profitable for first time after app pays down debts
summary: Telegram has become profitable for the first time after paying down $2 billion in debt, with total revenue exceeding $1 billion in 2024. The messaging service has over 900 million active users and $500 million in cash reserves. Despite facing scrutiny over the spread of misinformation and illegal content, Telegram claims to be committed to combating misinformation "responsibly" through verification systems and content filtering. CEO Pavel Durov faces French charges related to alleged crimes on the app, and the app has been banned in Ukraine due to concerns of Russian spying.

images.alt_text: Oon Yun Cong is convicted for making false statements in two Telegram chat groups, namely ‘SGX Penny Stocks Discussion’ and ‘SGX-Trade with the Wind (TW2)‘.
Telegram is heavily used in both Ukraine and Russia and has become a critical source of information since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

In a lengthy post on Telegram, his first comment since his arrest, Pavel Durov said it was “surprising” he was being held responsible for other people’s content and added that it was a “misguided approach” to charge a CEO “with crimes committed by third parties”.

site_title: South Korea consumer sentiment weakest since 2022 on political uncertainty
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment has hit its weakest level in over two years, falling to 88.4 in December due to growing worries about political uncertainty following President Yoon Suk-yeol's impeachment. The country's Composite Consumer Sentiment Index has dropped below 100, indicating a pessimistic outlook on the economy. Thousands of protesters gathered in Seoul after the parliament's impeachment vote, and the benchmark Kospi plummeted in the days following President Yoon's declaration of martial law. The political turmoil is expected to weigh on the South Korean economy, with the central bank calling for fiscal support to ensure growth remains intact.

images.alt_text: Bank of Korea said that following the impeachment vote, the predictability of the political process is expected to improve, and financial market volatility is anticipated to decrease.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar’s popularity rises on his investment push
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's approval ratings have risen to 54% after two years in power, driven by his push for more investments and improvements in the civil service. However, voters gave a mixed assessment on the economy, citing concerns over cost of living pressures and subsidy cuts. The economy remains the top problem facing the country, with 65% of respondents pointing to it as the number one issue. Anwar faces a delicate balancing act to spur wage growth, reduce living costs, and manage the country's fiscal deficit.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

site_title: Seatrium wins contract for deepwater new-build production unit
summary: Seatrium has secured a contract with BP Exploration & Production to perform engineering, procurement, construction, and onshore commissioning work for a deepwater new-build production unit, the Kaskida FPU, in the Gulf of Mexico. The project will have a capacity to produce 80,000 barrels of crude oil per day. Seatrium's "game-changing" Goliath twin cranes will be used to integrate and lift the topsides module to the hull, reducing safety risks and enhancing project efficiency. The company expects to successfully execute the project and deliver the Kaskida FPU safely and on time, marking its fourth successful FPU project for the region.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Seatrium's contract with Japanese construction company Penta-Ocean Construction is expected to be awarded in the first quarter of 2025.
Seatrium says its latest contracts are from various long-standing partners and regular customers.

site_title: The disinformation storm is now hitting companies harder
summary: Major companies are facing a growing disinformation storm as AI intensifies the risks of online falsehoods and misinformation. Falsehoods can derail businesses, with threats including fabricated news, phoney social media accounts, and fake content. A survey found that 80% of executives worry about the impact of disinformation, but fewer than half feel prepared to tackle these risks. To mitigate these threats, companies should consider building credibility, mapping and tracking disinformation sources, and finding vulnerabilities in their crisis responses.

images.alt_text: The upcoming four more years for Donald Trump have raised concerns of legitimising misinformation about vaccines, climate change and other health issues.
The websites mimic typical news publications and are unlikely to raise suspicion to the untrained eye. ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI
Social media posts are falsely accusing the government of waging “weather warfare” with recent storms “deliberately deployed against red states” likely to vote for Republican Donald Trump.

site_title: Indian Ocean tsunami 20 years on: Improved warning systems but better forecasting still needed
summary: The Indian Ocean tsunami, which occurred 20 years ago on December 26, 2004, resulted in 226,408 deaths and over 1.5 million displaced people. While warning systems have improved, better forecasting and resilient infrastructure are still needed to mitigate the economic and human costs of such natural disasters. Scientists have made progress in predicting earthquakes and tsunamis, including the use of holistic geophysical forecasting, but more research is required. The region is also at risk of a massive earthquake, known as "The Big One," which could cause hundreds of billions in damage and tens of thousands of injuries and deaths.

images.alt_text: Indonesian tsunami warning buoys not working when quake hit
Tsunami drill unfolds across 40 countries from Asia to Americas

site_title: In bull market, investors still putting money into ESG funds but at much slower pace
summary: Investors are pouring money into ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) funds at a slower pace than in the past bull market, with ESG funds currently holding about 4% of overall investment assets. Despite a perceived decline in popularity, the principles behind ESG investing are likely to continue, driven by an unstoppable economic movement towards sustainable economics. Companies are expected to focus on sustainable practices, rather than making a show of their ESG credentials, and the trend is likely to survive under a different name.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken and released by the French Securite Civile on December 17, 2024 shows members of the Securite Civile walking with chainsaws amongst felled trees and vegetation at an undisclosed location on the French Indian Ocean territory of Mayotte, in the wake of Cyclone Chido. It is feared that the toll from the devastating cyclone that ripped through the French overseas territory of Mayotte at the weekend will rise. Currently 21 people are confirmed to have been killed by Cyclone Chido when it barrelled into the archipelago, as authorities fear that hundreds, and possibly even thousands, will be confirmed dead once the true scale of the toll is revealed after the rubble is cleared and roads are unblocked. site_title: ECB plans to clamp down on banks ignoring its demands for fixes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) plans to crack down on banks that fail to respond to its supervisory demands, aiming to reduce a backlog of over 5,000 measures issued annually. The ECB will press banks to have plans to reduce outstanding findings and measures, and those that repeatedly miss deadlines may face fines. The move is part of the ECB's efforts to make its oversight more effective, following criticism of the "follow-through process" for some orders. The ECB aims to shift its focus from risk identification to risk remediation, with banks expected to implement sound remedial action plans in a timely manner.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay

site_title: Oil prices ease on surplus concerns, US dollar strength
summary: Oil prices eased on Monday, with Brent crude futures down 31 US cents, or 0.43%, to $72.63 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures down 22 US cents, or 0.32%, to $69.24 a barrel. Concerns about a supply surplus in 2025 and a strengthened US dollar led to the price drop. A stronger US dollar makes oil more expensive for holders of other currencies, and analysts project Brent prices to average $70.50 a barrel next year, down from this year's average of $79.64.

site_title: Sembcorp makes debut on Dow Jones Sustainability Asia Pacific Index
summary: Sembcorp Industries became the sole new entrant from Singapore in the Dow Jones Sustainability Asia Pacific Index for the first time, joining five other Singapore companies including CapitaLand Investment, ComfortDelGro, Keppel, ST Engineering, and Wilmar International. This recognition aims to drive positive impact for stakeholders and enhance ESG standards. Other Singapore companies retained their positions, with ComfortDelGro marking its sixth consecutive year on the index.

images.alt_text: More companies in the Asia-Pacific  now appear to be disclosing their process for managing climate-related risks and opportunities.

site_title: Malaysia’s Alpha IVF set to double centres in two years
summary: Malaysia's Alpha IVF plans to double its network of fertility care centers in Asia by 2026, capitalizing on rising demand for assisted reproduction services and IVF treatments. The company, founded by Dr. Colin Lee, currently has four centers in Malaysia and Singapore, and is expanding into Indonesia, China, and the Philippines. Revenue from Indonesian patients has grown significantly, contributing to Malaysia's operations. Alpha IVF aims to meet the growing demand for IVF services, despite declining fertility rates globally, with estimates suggesting one in every 800 individuals may require IVF services.

images.alt_text: Embryo storage area at Thomson Fertility Centre.  Thomson Medical notes a 70 per cent increase in the number of IVF cycles done in Singapore over the last 10 years.
FILE PHOTO: Children feed pigeons in Harbin, Heilongjiang Province, China, February 10, 2023. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo
After a lacklustre performance in 2023, Bursa Malaysia’s initial public offering (IPO) market has gained momentum in 2024 and growing stronger.

site_title: 2025 equity outlook: Policy clarity brings fundamentals to the fore
summary: US Federal Reserve policy clarity and the resolution of the US election have mitigated uncertainty, allowing companies to resume capital expenditures and investments. The US president-elect, Donald Trump, has outlined policy priorities, including tariffs on imports and lower corporate tax rates, which could positively impact financial companies and US industrials. However, emerging-market equities face headwinds under a second Trump term, particularly in China and Mexico. The global easing cycle is expected to continue, driven by innovations in technology, automation, healthcare, and green spending, with companies benefiting from these trends.

images.alt_text: As you celebrate Christmas, consider these questions: what trophies are you holding on to today? What are you focusing on that is temporary? What needs to be changed to focus more on the permanent?
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 inches up as Novo Nordisk surges at start of Christmas week
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe rose 0.1% at the start of a holiday-shortened week, driven by a 5.7% surge in Novo Nordisk shares, which boosted the healthcare sector. The healthcare sub-index rose 1.4% despite Novo Nordisk's disappointing results for its experimental obesity drug. Volkswagen shed 1.3% and BT rose 3.8% after Aviva announced a £3.7 billion deal to buy Direct Line. The eurozone is close to reaching a 2% inflation target, according to ECB president Christine Lagarde, who also opposed retaliation to US tariff threats.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closes 0.9 per cent lower.

site_title: Who’s pulling ahead in South-east Asia’s data centre race?
summary: Malaysia is emerging as the frontrunner to challenge Singapore's dominance in the data centre market in South-east Asia. Despite Singapore's current lead of 1.4 gigawatts (GW) of total capacity, analysts predict Malaysia will surpass it due to its substantial leg up in terms of space and power constraints. Global tech giants such as Microsoft, Google, and Amazon have committed to building data centres in Malaysia, and the country's government has approved digital investments totaling RM141.7 billion (S$46.8 billion) in the first 10 months of this year. Thailand is also gaining traction as a potential competitor, with its abundance of power and renewable generation making it an attractive option for hyperscalers.

images.alt_text: NTT DATA announces a proposed land acquisition in Johor Bahru to build a data centre

site_title: Malaysia Airlines grounds new Airbus jet over safety concerns
summary: Malaysia Airlines has grounded its new Airbus A330neo jet just days after its maiden flight due to technical issues, citing safety concerns. The airline's CEO, Izham Ismail, stated that technical faults with a new aircraft are "not acceptable" and "embarrassing." The root cause of the issues is believed to be related to a faulty component. Rolls-Royce has identified the problem, while Airbus is ready to assist Malaysia Airlines. The incident marks another operational setback for the airline this year, following reduced routes and manpower issues.

images.alt_text: Flight MH370, a Boeing 777 carrying 227 passengers and 12 crew, vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing on Mar 8, 2014.
Izham Ismail who has been running Malaysia’s flagship airline since 2017, was initially due to retire at the end of 2024 when his current contract expires.

site_title: We’ve been getting human nature wrong for 100 years
summary: For 100 years, scientists have believed that humans are predators by nature, based on the discovery of a "missing link" fossil in 1924. However, a re-examination of the fossil in the 1990s revealed that it was likely the remains of an eagle nest, and not evidence of human predation. Archaeological findings also suggest that early humans were more prey than predators, with weak bodies and teeth suited for eating plants. This new understanding challenges the assumption that humans are natural-born predators, and could help soothe today's intense political animosity by increasing sympathy for opposing views.

images.alt_text: The core idea of “institutional neutrality” is that organisational leaders don’t go out of their way to take party political positions on behalf of their organisations.
The top 1 per cent now hold a greater share of wealth than the entire middle 40 per cent; three decades ago, the reverse was true.

site_title: Xerox to buy printer maker Lexmark from Chinese owners in US$1.5 billion deal
summary: Xerox to acquire printer maker Lexmark from Chinese owners in a US$1.5 billion deal. The purchase aims to bolster Xerox's mainstay business as demand for printers and related equipment declines. Xerox expects to finance the deal through a combination of cash on hand and debt financing, with the likely closing date set for the second half of 2025. This deal brings Lexmark back to US ownership after it was sold to Chinese investors in 2016 for US$3.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Xerox in talks for deal with Fujifilm: WSJ

site_title: South Korean president snubs summons for second time
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol has refused a second summons for questioning from an anti-corruption body investigating his declaration of martial law, which led to his impeachment and potential jail time or death penalty. The summons was sent to his office and residence but was not received, with the postal system showing it was "unidentifiable". If Yoon fails to appear, the Corruption Investigation Office could seek an arrest warrant, making him the first sitting South Korean president to face questioning by an investigative agency.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korea Vice Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok speaks during an interview with Reuters in Seoul, South Korea, June 16, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
Han Duck-soo (above) was elevated to acting president in accordance with the constitution while President Yoon’s case moves to the Constitutional Court.

site_title: Apple approaches US$4 trillion valuation as investors bet on AI momentum
summary: Apple is closing in on a $4 trillion stock market valuation, driven by investors' enthusiasm for the company's AI enhancements, which are expected to rejuvenate sluggish iPhone sales. The company has seen a 16% jump in shares since early November, adding $500 billion to its market capitalization. Analysts attribute the rally to investor expectations of a "supercycle" of iPhone upgrades fueled by AI advancements. Apple has pulled ahead of Nvidia and Microsoft in the race to reach the milestone.

images.alt_text: The absence of AI capabilities in the latest iPhones sold in China has become a major setback for Apple.

site_title: What we know about SingPost’s Parcelgate scandal so far
summary: SingPost has fired three senior management executives, including group CEO Vincent Phang and CFO Vincent Yik, after an investigation found they were "grossly negligent" in handling a whistleblower's report on the company's non-regulated international e-commerce logistics parcels business. The executives were accused of committing "serious breaches" in the company's code of conduct, including manual updates of delivery failure status codes without supporting documents. The company also filed a police report and agreed to a settlement with one of its largest customers.

images.alt_text: From left: Group CEO Vincent Phang, group CFO Vincent Yik, and CEO of the company’s international business unit Li Yu.

site_title: Apac companies stepping up in sustainability reporting, but challenges remain: study
summary: A study on sustainability reporting in the Asia-Pacific region found that companies are making progress in disclosing climate-related risks and opportunities, but still face challenges in providing accurate data on Scope 3 emissions and climate scenario analysis. Despite an increase in disclosures, 45% of companies only reported minimal Scope 3 emissions, while 9% did not disclose any categories contributing to their greenhouse gas emissions. Only 18% of companies with net-zero targets had them verified by the Science-Based Target initiative. The study highlights the need for robust governance frameworks and actionable climate strategies to drive sustainable development in the region.

images.alt_text: Whether you like or believe in them or not, both climate change and the clean-energy transition create risks and opportunities for companies. It’s bad business to ignore them.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 23)
summary: Singapore's core inflation slowed to 1.9% in November, slightly above expectations. Accommodation, services, and food prices eased, while retail and other goods, as well as electricity and gas, maintained their inflation pace. Two new ride-hailing operators, Lah and Trans-cab Services, received provisional licences, while SingPost shares fell 10% after three senior executives were fired for negligence in handling internal investigations.

site_title: Malaysia, Indonesia to battle for IPO supremacy in 2025 as signs point to Asean market comeback
summary: Malaysia and Indonesia are poised to battle for the top spot in the Asean initial public offering (IPO) market in 2025, following Malaysia's successful year in terms of deal number and size. Industry observers attribute the expected improvement to lower interest rates and economic growth in the region. With Malaysia's positive economic indicators and robust investor support, it has emerged as this year's IPO winner. Indonesia's return to political stability following a general election is also expected to boost its IPO activity in 2025.

images.alt_text: Mr DIY store in Jakarta
With exits, capital can be returned to investors to be recycled back into VCs, which in turn provides funding for startups.
Industry watchers are divided on the reasons for the underperformance of counters on the Catalist, the Singapore Exchange's junior board.

Industry watchers are generally positive about the review group’s establishment, but note that some companies may opt to take in any possible changes announced by the group before considering a Singapore listing.
As general market sentiments improve, SGX is poised for heightened IPO activities next year, said observers.
Across South-east Asia, the top performer was Indonesia, which raised US$3.6 billion across 80 listings, according to Bloomberg data.

site_title: Builder Jinke reveals details of court-supervised debt plan
summary: Chinese developer Jinke Property Group has revealed details of its court-supervised debt restructuring plan, which involves setting up an eight-year trust for debt payment backed by shares in 20 subsidiaries. Under the plan, bondholders could receive up to 2.5 shares for every 100 yuan of debt principal, with a potential second round of repayment. The company aims to reduce its liabilities-to-assets ratio to 30% and provide 700 million yuan for project funding. A consortium of local firms has agreed to provide 1.8 billion yuan to support the restructuring, subject to creditor and court approval.

images.alt_text: Vanke's contracted sales for November declined 34.4 per cent from a year earlier to 20.1 billion yuan (S$3.7 billion), widening from a 22.8 per cent drop in October.

site_title: India puts brakes on a 10,000% stock rally over fake disclosures
summary: India's securities regulator suspended trading in Bharat Global Developers' shares after the company falsely claimed to have won large orders from prominent corporates, including Reliance Industries and Tata Group. The stock surged over 10,000% in 12 months, prompting the regulator to bar several investors from accessing the capital markets and impound "unlawful gains". The case highlights the dark side of India's stock market boom, where small investors are drawn to impressive returns, and comes amid a series of crackdowns on companies manipulating their stock prices through accounting frauds and fake disclosures.

images.alt_text: Global funds pulled out more than US$10 billion on a net basis in October, helping drive the benchmark stock index towards a so-called technical correction.

site_title: Elon Musk makes ‘overstaffed’ Fed target in quest for efficiency
summary: Elon Musk has targeted the Federal Reserve, calling it "absurdly overstaffed" with 24,000 employees, significantly less than comparable institutions. This comes as US President-elect Donald Trump also criticizes the Fed's role in monetary policy, seeking to have a say in interest rate setting. Musk, set to lead a new agency focused on government efficiency, made the comments on social media, sparking a debate with ECB President Christine Lagarde, who defended the Fed's work.

These developments come as markets in Asia track the US inflation rate, with concerns easing regarding rate worries.

site_title: Singapore’s core inflation slows more than expected to 1.9% in November; headline inflation at 1.6%
summary: Singapore's core inflation slowed to 1.9% in November, beating expectations, and headline inflation was 1.6%. This may prompt the Monetary Authority of Singapore to ease monetary policy in January. Economists predict a downward recentring of the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate policy band and a reduction to its slope. However, the central bank may wait until April to ease policy if core inflation proves sticky. Core inflation is expected to remain under 2% for the rest of the year, averaging 2.5-3% in 2024 and 1.5-2.5% in 2025.

site_title: In emerging markets, ‘better luck next year’ is a hard sell
summary: Emerging markets underperformed major asset classes in 2024, with the MSCI EM index gaining less than 5% for the year, trailing the S&P 500. This year's struggles are attributed to the inability of most countries to keep pace with the US dollar, with nine EM currencies posting 10% or more losses against the greenback. Fixed-income investors have also seen underperformance, with local-currency EM sovereign bonds returning 2.4% this year, underperforming alternative fixed-income assets. Despite this, some experts believe emerging markets will eventually bounce back, citing the need for global diversification and the potential for growth in frontier markets like Pakistan, Kenya, and Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 18, 2024. Federal Reserve officials lowered their benchmark interest rate for a third consecutive time, but reined in the number of cuts they expect in 2025, signaling greater caution over how quickly they can continue reducing borrowing costs. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Euro edges down, dollar hovers around two-year high
summary: The dollar index rose 0.39% to 108.2, nearing its two-year high of 108.54, driven by the Federal Reserve's projected measured pace of rate cuts ahead. The euro edged down 0.38% to US$1.0392, trading near its two-year low, as investors digest expectations for globally diverging rate cut paths in 2025. The dollar's rise was partly due to the averted US government shutdown, while the euro was impacted by European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde's comments on potential rate cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Canadian dollar coin, commonly known as the "Loonie", is pictured in this illustration picture taken in Toronto, January 23, 2015. REUTERS/Mark Blinch/File Photo

site_title: OCBC, UOB to pay out second cost-of-living bonuses for junior staff
summary: OCBC and UOB will pay out one-off cost-of-living bonuses to their junior employees, with approximately 4,000 OCBC staff and 6,000 UOB staff receiving S$1,000 each, totaling about S$7.5 million. The payments will be made by April 2025 to help employees cope with ongoing cost-of-living pressures. This is the second consecutive year the banks are providing such support, with the goal of ensuring the well-being of their junior colleagues amidst high living costs in Singapore.

images.alt_text: OCBC has given clients a deadline to confirm they are Singapore residents with verified addresses, or face service restrictions that could lead to account closures.
money, savings, piggy

site_title: Christmas reflections on the vanities of life
summary: A Christmas reflection on the importance of focusing on the permanent and not the temporary in life and finances. The author shares a personal anecdote of letting go of material possessions and prioritizing meaningful relationships and experiences. He cites Jesus' message in the Bible (Matthew 6:19-21) about storing treasure in heaven rather than accumulating earthly possessions. The author concludes that by focusing on the permanent, one can avoid the pitfalls of vanity, self-centeredness, and short-term thinking, and instead, live a life worth living.

images.alt_text: US president-elect Donald Trump has been clear about his policy priorities, which include a mix of widespread tariffs on imports to the US and more severe tariffs on Chinese imports (with the possibility that tariff threats could be used as a bargaining tool), along with mass deportations of immigrants believed to be in the US illegally

site_title: SingPost shares tumble over 10%; OCBC lowers target price after fiasco
summary: SingPost shares plummeted 10.7% after the company fired three senior executives, including its group CEO, over handling of internal investigations into a whistle-blower's report. Despite this, analysts maintain a "hold" rating on the stock, citing the company's plans to enhance shareholder value and monetize non-core assets. Maybank Securities keeps its "buy" rating, while OCBC lowers its target price to S$0.54 due to increased corporate governance risks.

images.alt_text: 新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。
As at 9.04am, the counter dipped by 8.04 per cent or S$0.045 to S$0.515, with 10.6 million securities changing hands.
From left: Group CEO Vincent Phang, group CFO Vincent Yik, and CEO of the company’s international business unit Li Yu.

site_title: South Korea finance minister sees political turmoil weighing on economic growth
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Choi Sang-mok, warned that the country's economic growth forecast for next year will likely be lowered due to ongoing political turmoil. The minister attributed the concerns to domestic uncertainty and a weakening sentiment. The South Korean won hit its weakest level in 15 years amid the turmoil. Choi emphasized the need for fiscal policies to play an active role in addressing potential economic challenges, and the government will work with the Bank of Korea to respond to sharp volatilities in the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Two new ride-hailing operators awarded provisional licences in Singapore
summary: Two new ride-hailing operators, Geo Lah and Trans-cab Services, have been awarded provisional licences in Singapore, allowing them to launch their services in 2025. Existing operators will have their licences renewed, while new regulations include reduced fees for taxi driver vocational licences and increased transparency on trip information. The Land Transport Authority's (LTA) P2P sector review aims to stabilise taxi supply, improve service reliability, and cater to a wider range of users. The first phase of updates comes into effect on January 1, 2025, with further changes expected in the second phase.

images.alt_text: Major updates to improve taxi, private-hire car sector in Singapore effective from January
Private hire cars  currently use the same Certificates of Entitlement as passenger cars and have been blamed for driving premiums up.
The profit is due to improvements in group-adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation.
The Platform Workers Act introduces one of the world’s first frameworks that treats platform workers as a distinct category with tailored protections.
Uber doesn’t currently separate out its payments to drivers, to restaurants and to insurance providers as part of its “gross bookings” in quarterly financial statements.

site_title: Uber investors are calling for more transparency into driver pay
summary: A group of Uber investors, representing less than 1% of the company's stake, are calling for increased transparency into driver pay. They propose a resolution requiring the firm to disclose a more granular breakdown of driver compensation, including payments to drivers, restaurants, and insurance providers. The investors argue that the current level of disclosure is "unusually opaque" and leaves investors in the dark about driver earnings and commissions. Uber has not responded to the proposal, and the company may try to block it by filing a "no-action" request with the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

images.alt_text: Uber doesn’t currently separate out its payments to drivers, to restaurants and to insurance providers as part of its “gross bookings” in quarterly financial statements.
Uber Technologies, partnering with China's WeRide, launched its first autonomous rides outside the US in Abu Dhabi.
The FTC is investigating Uber over enrollment and cancellation aspects of their subscription service, according to documents viewed by Bloomberg.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on interest rate cut expectations; STI edges up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% on Monday, driven by expectations of interest rate cuts, following a Wall Street rally. The STI gained 32.4 points to close at 3,752.33. Only four component stocks closed lower, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC increased. Despite a decline in Singtel, the blue-chip gauge still edged up. The gains were also influenced by Asian markets, with Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rising 1.7%.

images.alt_text: At 1.22pm on Dec 23, the share price of SingPost had fallen by S$0.06 or over 10 per cent to S$0.50, with 56 million securities changing hands.
Singapore shares open xxx on Monday,

site_title: Starbucks workers expand strike in US cities, including New York
summary: Starbucks workers have expanded a five-day strike to four more US cities, including New York, with over 10,000 baristas participating. The strike, which began on Friday, has added locations in New Jersey, Philadelphia, and St Louis, amid unresolved issues over wages, staffing, and schedules. The union, Workers United, is seeking a 64% immediate wage increase and a 77% increase over a three-year contract, which Starbucks considers unsustainable. The strike may impact the company's Christmas sales, with over 200,000 US employees affected.

images.alt_text: Starbucks has recorded three straight quarters of same-store sales declines.
The shrunken bonuses embody the sales woes that Starbucks has experienced this year as customers dinged by widespread inflation cut back on their lattes.
The Blue Yonder breach is affecting company-operated stores in the US and Canada.
Starbucks has faced pressure from activist Elliott Investment Management, which wants it to commit to reviewing its Chinese business.

site_title: South Korean opposition threatens to impeach Han over martial law counsel
summary: South Korea's main opposition party, the Democratic Party, has threatened to impeach acting president Han Duck-soo if he fails to approve legislation to launch a special counsel investigation into President Yoon Suk Yeol's failed bid to impose martial law. The opposition claims Han aided Yoon's attempt and has accused him of hampering the Constitutional Court trial. Han has previously tried to block Yoon's martial law declaration but apologized for failing to do so. The opposition will initiate impeachment proceedings if the legislation is not promulgated by Tuesday.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivers a speech during his briefing on state affairs at a press conference at the presidential office in Seoul, South Korea, August 29, 2024. Chung Sung-Jun/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

Protesters in Seoul celebrate after the result of the second martial law impeachment vote was announced on Saturday. Lawmakers successfully voted to remove Yoon from office for his failed attempt to impose martial law.

site_title: UK insurer Aviva to buy Direct Line in US$4.65 billion deal
summary: Aviva, the UK's largest home and motor insurer, agreed to buy Direct Line in a $4.65 billion cash-and-stock deal. Under the terms, Aviva shareholders will receive 0.2867 new shares, 129.7 pence in cash, and up to 5 pence in dividend for each Direct Line share. The deal, Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc's largest acquisition, aims to expand the company's presence in Britain, Canada, and Ireland. It also allows Aviva to increase its dividend by a mid-single digit percentage after completion.

images.alt_text: Aviva had a combined operating ratio in the first nine months of 96.8 per cent, compared with 96.3 per cent a year earlier.
FILE PHOTO: The Aviva logo on a window at the company's head office in the City of London, Britain, March 7, 2019. REUTERS/Simon Dawson/File Photo

site_title: SingPost’s Parcelgate fiasco is a corporate governance disaster
summary: SingPost, Singapore's national postal service provider, fired three senior management staff after an external law firm found them "grossly negligent" in handling a whistleblower's report. The report, received in early 2024, related to the company's non-regulated international e-commerce logistics parcel business. However, SingPost failed to disclose the report in its 2024 annual report, sparking questions about corporate governance. The terminations followed internal investigations and an external review, which found the trio had "committed serious breaches" of the company's code of conduct. The move raises concerns about the company's culture and the role of its chiefs in handling the whistleblower's report.

images.alt_text: From left: Group CEO Vincent Phang, group CFO Vincent Yik, and CEO of the company’s international business unit Li Yu.
新邮政中心（Singpost Centre）、新加坡邮政中心（Singapore Post Centre）外观。
At 1.22pm on Dec 23, the share price of SingPost had fallen by S$0.06 or over 10 per cent to S$0.50, with 56 million securities changing hands.

site_title: 1MDB sues Amicorp for over US$1 billion for allegedly facilitating US$7 billion fraud
summary: Malaysian state fund 1MDB has filed a lawsuit against Amicorp, a Hong Kong-based financial services provider, for allegedly facilitating over $7 billion in fraudulent transactions between 2009 and 2014. The lawsuit seeks damages of over $1 billion and accuses Amicorp of playing a "vital role" in laundering misappropriated funds through a complex network of shell companies and fake transactions. Amicorp had previously faced regulatory action and fines in various markets, including the Netherlands and Abu Dhabi.

images.alt_text: Rosmah Mansor, 73, was acquitted of 17 charges, including money laundering and income declaration failures, due to insufficient evidence.
Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi (centre) leads the scandal-tainted United Malays National Organisation that Anwar counts on to stay in power.
The multi-billion-dollar 1MDB financial scandal has led to criminal investigations around the world, including in the United States, Switzerland and Singapore.
Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers as the jailed politician left the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: Just how frothy is America’s stock market?
summary: The US stock market has reached a 54% gain since 2022, surpassing only a handful of times since its inception in 1957. Despite recent jitters, investors remain optimistic, with 56% of respondents in a survey expecting share prices to rise in the next 12 months. However, valuations are at an all-time high, with the cyclically adjusted price-to-earnings ratio exceeding 98% of its historical range. Analysts warn that sky-high valuations and low yields could indicate poor future returns, and investors have heavily bet on the bull run continuing, with aggregate equity allocation at 49% and cash allocation at an all-time low.

images.alt_text: US earnings growth would not look so exceptional if not for the supernormal profits of its big tech firms, and massive government spending.
America’s share of global stock markets is far greater than its 27 per cent share of the global economy.

site_title: Chinese EV makers hit EU wall as tariffs inflate cost of imports
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers BYD and Saic Motor's MG have seen a decline in market share in the European Union, with 7.4% of EV registrations in November, down from 8.2% in October. The EU imposed tariffs of up to 35% on imported EVs, including those made by Western brands, in response to an investigation into state aid provided to China's EV industry. Despite this, BYD's registrations more than doubled in November, while MG's dropped 58% from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nissan Motor's Universal Powertrain Mounting System with a two-layer pallet structure, compatible with EV, e-POWER (HV) and gasoline vehicles is pictured in Kawachi-gun, in Tochigi prefecture, Japan October 8, 2021. REUTERS/Maki Shiraki/File Photo
A BYD Yangwang U9 car on display at the Essen Motor Show in Essen, Germany, Dec 4, 2024. China’s total November car sales grew 16.6 per cent, the highest growth since January.

site_title: Disclosure of buyers’ identities, citizenship required in all landed home sales, including GCB deals: MinLaw
summary: The Singapore Ministry of Law requires buyers of landed residential properties, including good class bungalows (GCBs), to disclose their identities and citizenship when selling these properties. This includes GCB deals carried out through trusts or shell companies, and regardless of whether a caveat is lodged. The move aims to combat money laundering and ensure transparency in property transactions. The Ministry of Law has also issued correction directions to media outlets for publishing false and misleading information on the issue.

images.alt_text: Property taxes rates for both owner-occupied and non-owner-occupied residential properties will be revised in 2 steps starting from 2023.

site_title: JPMorgan exits Australia’s Star Entertainment
summary: JPMorgan Chase has ceased to be a shareholder in Star Entertainment, an Australian casino operator, due to the company's challenging operating conditions, liquidity concerns, and a fall in earnings. The investment bank's 5.09% stake in Star Entertainment reflects its diminished influence in the company. Star Entertainment faces a perfect storm of regulatory inquiries, declining tourist visits, and lengthy closures, which have led to its share price falling to multi-year lows. The move is part of the company's efforts to address its financial struggles.

site_title: US investors pay biggest premium for TSMC shares in two months
summary: US investors paid a 24.6% premium for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) shares in the US, the highest since October, due to the company's inclusion in popular indexes and easier access for foreign investors. TSMC's US-listed shares closed 1.3% higher on December 20, while its local shares closed 3.3% lower. The premium narrowed to below 20% after TSMC's local shares rose 4.4% on Monday morning.

site_title: SingPost shares fall nearly 10% after 3 senior execs were fired
summary: SingPost shares plummeted nearly 10% after the sudden termination of three senior executives, including group CEO Vincent Phang, CFO Vincent Yik, and international business CEO Li Yu, on December 21. The firings followed an investigation into their handling of a whistleblower's report, which was deemed negligent. The stock's decline was largely driven by the sudden change in leadership, with 19.4 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Dire situation in China is one reason for Honda, Nissan merger
summary: Honda and Nissan are in merger talks, with China being a major reason for the move. Japan's automakers, once leaders in the Chinese market, have seen their popularity decline due to the rise of electric and hybrid vehicles made by Chinese companies like BYD. As a result, Honda and Nissan are looking to cut capacity in China, with Honda planning to close factories and reduce output by 20% and Nissan planning to slash global capacity by a fifth, with China accounting for over half of the reduction.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nissan Motor's Universal Powertrain Mounting System with a two-layer pallet structure, compatible with EV, e-POWER (HV) and gasoline vehicles is pictured in Kawachi-gun, in Tochigi prefecture, Japan October 8, 2021. REUTERS/Maki Shiraki/File Photo
Foxconn, which has been investing heavily in factories to build electric vehicles, would be interested in the entirety of Nissan Motor – not just the Japanese firm’s plants and equipment.

site_title: Trump says it could be worth keeping TikTok in US for a little while
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has expressed support for allowing TikTok to continue operating in the US, citing the platform's success during his presidential campaign, which garnered billions of views. Despite a US Senate law requiring TikTok's Chinese parent company, ByteDance, to divest the app due to national security concerns, Trump opposes a potential exit from the US market. The US Supreme Court has agreed to hear the case, which could result in TikTok being effectively banned in the US on January 19, one day before Trump takes office.

images.alt_text: From next year, any major messaging and social media service provider operating without a licence from the Malaysian government will face legal action.
The plan is far from finalised and McCourt faces considerable obstacles to a possible deal.
TikTok argues that the law, the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, violates its First Amendment free speech rights.
TikTok's CEO Shou Chew is one of many tech leaders choosing to meet US President-elect Donald Trump before his inauguration next month.

site_title: Gold prices hold steady in thin trading
summary: Gold prices held steady at US$2,621.19 per ounce on Monday, as thin trading occurred after a softer US dollar and Treasury yields on Friday. The US inflation data showed a slowdown in November, with the personal consumption expenditures index rising 0.1% last month. The Federal Reserve's cautious stance on rate cuts also supported gold prices. Meanwhile, the Russian central bank kept interest rates unchanged, and Comex gold speculators cut their net long position by 16,251 contracts.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,594.59 per ounce.

site_title: AI may wreak havoc on Singapore’s office buildings
summary: Singapore's office buildings face potential devastation as artificial intelligence (AI) may lead to job losses in the knowledge worker sector, eroding demand for workspace. Despite office landlords' efforts to future-proof their properties through wellness and sustainability features, AI could disrupt the industry, with many jobs potentially being automated. However, experts suggest that building conversions could be a viable option, with Singapore's government and authorities adapting to repurpose office spaces for other uses, such as housing, hotels, and healthcare facilities.

images.alt_text: Generic of the central business district CBD skyline on Sept 17, 2024.
Data shows that prices of office space in the central region rose by 0.6 per cent in Q3 2024.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: SRS secrets to grow your retirement fund and save on taxes
summary: Financial experts discuss the Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS), a voluntary retirement savings plan in Singapore, on the Money Hacks podcast. The SRS offers attractive tax benefits, allowing contributions to be tax-deductible, and encouraging Singaporeans to save for retirement. To enjoy these benefits, contributions must be made by December 31. Hosted by Howie Lim and featuring insights from DBS Bank's Shawn Lee, the episode explores the SRS's advantages and considerations, providing guidance for those looking to boost their retirement savings.

images.alt_text: What instrument would be best for your SRS account?
Are fractional jobs the perfect fit for modern hustlers?
What are the three simple steps to financial success?

site_title: News Corp sells Foxtel unit to DAZN in A$3.4 billion deal
summary: News Corp has agreed to sell its Australian cable TV unit Foxtel to British-owned sports network DAZN for A$3.4 billion, including debt. The deal values Foxtel at seven times its 2024 Ebitda. News Corp will retain a 6% stake in DAZN and a board seat, while DAZN gains streaming rights to the Australian Football League and the National Rugby League. The transaction is expected to close in the second half of 2025.

images.alt_text: The Foxtel headquarters stand in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, Jun 21, 2012. Photographer: Ian Waldie/Bloomberg

site_title: China arms itself with stronger law to fight money laundering
summary: China has revised its Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Law to strengthen its efforts against money laundering and terrorist financing. The updated law, effective January 1, expands the definition of money laundering and requires nonfinancial institutions, such as real estate developers and precious metals traders, to monitor risks and implement due diligence measures. The law also makes AML a national security issue and increases penalties for non-compliance, with fines up to 10 million yuan. The revisions aim to bring China into line with international standards, including those set by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF).

images.alt_text: The Indonesian report said Yan is a fugitive wanted by Interpol China for online gambling, and that he is suspected of being involved in a criminal gang that allegedly laundered money.

Linda Sun, a former aide to New York State Governor Kathy Hochul, exits Brooklyn Federal court after she was charged with acting as an unregistered agent of China’s government in New York City, US, Sept 3, 2024.

site_title: Honda, Nissan formalise merger talks, aim to combine by 2026
summary: Honda and Nissan Motor have signed a basic agreement to merge, aiming to complete the deal by 2026. The move is seen as a response to aggressive competition from China, forcing legacy carmakers to rethink their business models. Honda will buy back up to 1.1 trillion yen (S$9.5 billion) of its shares, and a holding company will be created to house the new entity, which will be listed by August 2026. Honda will nominate a majority of directors for the holding company, providing the Japanese automaker with more control over the merged entity.

images.alt_text: Japanese automakers are not the only ones suffering in China.
