Foxconn, which has been investing heavily in factories to build electric vehicles, would be interested in the entirety of Nissan Motor – not just the Japanese firm’s plants and equipment.

site_title: Rome’s Trevi Fountain reopens to limited crowds
summary: Rome's Trevi Fountain reopened on December 22 after a three-month clean-up, with limited crowds of 400 visitors to avoid congestion. The city aims to finance upkeep with a potential entry fee. The fountain, a baroque masterpiece, was once visited by 10,000-12,000 tourists daily, generating around €10,000 a week for charity. The clean-up is part of Rome's preparations for the 2025 Jubilee, a year of pilgrimage and prayer expected to attract 33 million visitors.

images.alt_text: A general view of the San Lorenzo neighborhood in Rome, Italy, December 3, 2024. REUTERS/Yara Nardi

site_title: Chinese investors buy record amount of Hong Kong stocks via link
summary: Chinese investors have bought a record HK$3.3 trillion of Hong Kong shares since the trading link began, with a cumulative HK$778 billion purchased this year to Dec 20. This represents a 45% share of trading in the city and is the highest annual amount since 2016. The surge in buying is attributed to a revival of animal spirits, a weakening yuan, and Beijing's stimulus blitz, creating an appetite for US dollar assets.

site_title: The two IPOs at the tip of the megatrend iceberg
summary: Two mega listings in the pipeline, a data centre Reit from Japan's Nippon Telegraph & Telephone Corp and a healthcare Reit from French property asset manager Praemia REIM, could inject life into Singapore's stagnant stock market in 2025. The data centre Reit could raise up to $1 billion, while the healthcare Reit might raise several hundred million US dollars. The listings are emblematic of larger investor preoccupations, including the growing demand for data centres and healthcare spending.

images.alt_text: As the US and China endlessly slap-fight each other, analysts have looked for opportunities in other markets and settled on India for its favourable demographics and lower tariff risks, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
If you haven’t gotten in on any of the Magnificent Seven US megacap stocks, don’t despair even if the basket of stocks has advanced 60 per cent this year, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
Haidilao’s Sichuan Spicy soup base is red as all heck, but the restaurant operator’s bottom line no longer is, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: TalkMed receives S$0.456 per share in privatisation offer via scheme of arrangement
summary: TalkMed Group, a tertiary healthcare services provider, has received a privatisation proposal from TW Troy, a special purpose vehicle managed by Tamarind Health. The offer price of S$0.456 per share is a 20% premium to the last traded price of S$0.38 and represents a 22.6% premium over the volume-weighted average price per share for the one-month period. The deal aims to improve patient care and attract patients from the region, while allowing shareholders to exit their investment at a premium.

images.alt_text: TalkMed Group faces growing competition for medical tourists in South-east Asia, due to a strong Singapore dollar.
TalkMed will update shareholders in due course when it becomes aware of any material developments.

site_title: Nippon Life’s US$12 billion acquisition spree is just beginning
summary: Nippon Life Insurance, Japan's largest life insurer, is seeking a majority stake in US asset manager TCW Group as part of its global asset management expansion. The company has already invested $3.3 billion in TCW's private credit strategies and plans to invest an additional $550 million. Nippon Life has committed up to $12 billion in deals this month alone, with a total of $17.3 billion earmarked for acquisitions to 2026. The move aims to diversify the company's business at home and abroad, driven by Japan's shrinking and ageing population.

images.alt_text: Blackstone will continue to be Resolution’s investment manager across private credit and other areas after Nippon completes the acquisition.
Nippon Life, Japan's largest insurer by assets, is trying to diversify its profit drivers as the local market faces demographic challenges that are hindering growth prospects.
Nippon Life will buy remaining shares in Resolution Life from Blackstone and others, making it a subsidiary in 2025.

site_title: Oil prices firm on hopes of US policy support for economic growth
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures increasing 26 US cents to $73.20 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbing 31 US cents to $69.77 per barrel. The increase was driven by cooling US inflation data and hopes of further policy easing next year, supporting global economic growth and oil demand. The US Senate passing legislation to end a brief shutdown also contributed to the rise. Concerns about European supply eased after the Druzhba pipeline restarted after technical issues.

images.alt_text: A weaker dollar makes oil cheaper for holders of other currencies, while rate cuts could spur economic growth and boost oil demand.

site_title: Bankruptcies, suicide rise as Japanese struggle with mounting debt
summary: Japan's personal debt is surging, with consumer loans rising at the highest rate in 16 years, exceeding incomes for the first time last year. The country's lowest average salaries among G7 nations and rising borrowing costs are exacerbating the issue. Bankruptcies and suicides related to debt are also on the rise, with the number of suicides reaching 792 in 2023, the highest since 2012. Household debt has reached a record 122% of average disposable income, and experts warn that young people with unstable incomes are particularly vulnerable.

images.alt_text: Inflation has become a key economic and political topic in Japan after years of falling prices.
BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.
Japan's exports rose 3.8 per cent year-on-year in November, more than a median market forecast for a 2.8 per cent increase and following a 3.1 per cent rise in October.

site_title: Japan’s bond market is set to absorb biggest supply in a decade
summary: Japan's bond market is expected to face its largest supply in a decade due to the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) plan to almost halve its bond purchases from July 2024 to March 2026, resulting in a 37.6 trillion yen fiscal year decrease. This increase in supply, combined with rising interest rates and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's spending plans, is expected to add to the woes of debtholders. The Ministry of Finance is set to release its plan for debt sales in late December, which could see a 64% increase in supply to 61 trillion yen.

images.alt_text: The review warned that the negative effects of former governor Haruhiko Kuroda’s massive monetary stimulus  may last longer than expected and become bigger in the future.
Inflation has become a key economic and political topic in Japan after years of falling prices.
BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.

site_title: China’s Nio unveils 788,000 yuan EV to take on Porsche, Mercedes
summary: China's Nio unveiled its flagship EV, the ET9, priced at 788,000 yuan ($146,294), targeting Porsche and Mercedes-Benz. The 10-seater sedan boasts a 100 kWh battery, allowing 650km of range on one charge, and can recharge to 225km in 5 minutes. Nio also launched a budget-friendly sub-brand, Firefly, with a starting price of 148,800 yuan. The company aims to double annual sales to 440,000 vehicles in 2025 and become profitable by 2026. Deliveries of the ET9 and Firefly models will start in March, with Nio targeting Europe in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of Nio is pictured on its car at the Beijing International Automotive Exhibition, or Auto China 2024, in Beijing, China, April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
November's figure was slightly lower than the 20,976 vehicles delivered in October.

FILE PHOTO: People look at the newly unveiled Onvo L60 SUV, the first vehicle of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio's new lower-priced brand, in Shanghai, China May 15, 2024. REUTERS/Zoey Zhang/File Photo
Nio to date has only manufactured pure EVs.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street rally as US inflation eases rate worries
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday after the US inflation data showed a lower-than-expected reading, tempering concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) index came in at 2.4% in November, lower than expected, and led to a pullback in US Treasury bond yields. The news boosted stocks in Asia, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and other markets rising, and the US dollar losing value. Investors also welcomed news of a last-minute government shutdown deal in the US, averting a potential shutdown.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians reflected on an electronic stock board outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 9, 2017. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi
Tokyo, Shanghai, Manila and Jakarta edged up, but Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington and Taipei sank.

site_title: Samsung Electronics, Texas Instruments finalise Chips Act awards
summary: Samsung Electronics and Texas Instruments have finalized agreements to receive billions of dollars in government support for new semiconductor plants in the US, as part of the Biden administration's Chips Act initiative. Samsung will receive up to $4.8 billion, while Texas Instruments will receive $1.6 billion, with the funds tied to specific project benchmarks. The agreements aim to boost American semiconductor production and counter China's growing manufacturing capacity in the area.

images.alt_text: SK Hynix is one of three makers of so-called high-bandwidth memory chips, which are essential components of computers used to create artificial intelligence software.

site_title: Johor-Singapore SEZ poised to fuel next-level growth for Malaysia and Singapore: Standard Chartered Malaysia CEO
summary: Malaysia and Singapore's Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) is poised to drive growth and seamless connectivity between the two countries, according to Standard Chartered Bank Malaysia CEO Mak Joon Nien. The zone will leverage the countries' economic strengths, with Singapore being Malaysia's second-largest trading partner and Malaysia ranking as Singapore's third-largest. As Malaysia assumes Asean chairmanship in 2025, the JS-SEZ will underscore the region's commitment to economic integration and dynamism, unlocking new growth opportunities for the two countries and the broader region.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.
Forest City will be the first location in Malaysia to offer zero per cent tax rate for family offices.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI rises 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 6.85 points, or 0.2%, to 3,726.78 in early trade on Monday, following cooler-than-expected US inflation data that eased concerns over interest rate cuts in 2025. Advancers outnumbered losers 75 to 41, with 69.3 million securities worth S$49.4 million transacted. Banking stocks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also gained, while Singapore Post and Advanced Systems Automation declined.

site_title: Why companies such as OpenAI and SpaceX are staying private longer
summary: Private tech companies like OpenAI and SpaceX are staying private longer due to a lax regulatory environment and the lack of activist investors. This trend has led to a significant shift in the number of publicly listed companies, with the US alone seeing a nearly 50% decline from 1997 to fewer than 4,000 today. Companies can raise billions of dollars from private investors, creating vast wealth for employees and early-stage stakeholders, while shutting out most retail investors. The private market has become a lucrative source of capital, with over $3 trillion tied up in private-equity-owned companies and $5 trillion in venture-backed unicorns.

images.alt_text: While Google plans to appeal that ruling at the end of the case, it says the upcoming “remedies” phase should focus on its distribution agreements with browser developers, mobile device manufacturers and wireless carriers.
The price of Bitcoin, which typically leads market rallies, jumped from the US$69,000 level on Nov 6 to push past the US$100,000 mark a month later, buoyed by Trump’s election win.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Top Glove, TalkMed
summary: Three senior management staff at Singapore Post (SingPost) were terminated after being found negligent in handling internal investigations over a whistleblower's report. The terminated staff included group CEO Vincent Phang, CFO Vincent Yik, and International Business Unit CEO Li Yu. SingPost shares closed 0.9% higher on Friday. Meanwhile, Top Glove reported a net profit of RM5.5 million (S$1.7 million) for its first fiscal quarter, reversing a prior year's net loss.

site_title: Trump says talk that he’s ceded presidency to Musk is a ‘hoax’
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump denied rumors that he had ceded the presidency to Elon Musk, calling the claims a 'hoax'. Trump has tapped Musk to lead a cost-cutting and deregulation effort, but it's not an official department. Musk's involvement has raised concerns about conflicts of interest due to his many businesses regulated by the federal government. Trump praised Musk's technological acumen, crediting him with helping win Pennsylvania in the US election, where Musk donated $238.5 million to a pro-Trump PAC.

images.alt_text: “I told the European Union that they must make up their tremendous deficit with the US by the large scale purchase of our oil and gas. Otherwise, it is TARIFFS all the way!!!,” President-elect Donald Trump said on Truth Social.

site_title: UK business morale falls to 2024 low but pay growth strong: survey
summary: UK business confidence fell to 39% in December, its lowest level of 2024, as firms worried about the new government's first budget. The economy contracted in September and October, with employers concerned about tax increases for employers. Despite this, pay growth remained strong, with average salaries increasing by 6.5% year-over-year, and the labor market showing signs of recovery. The Bank of England forecast zero growth in GDP for the final quarter of 2024, but interest rates were kept on hold.

site_title: Apple’s US$1 billion investment may be fleeting win for Indonesia
summary: Apple's $1 billion investment in Indonesia may be short-lived as the country's protectionist policies could deter future investments. The investment was made to lift a ban on the sale of iPhone 16s, but experts warn that this approach could harm Indonesia's economy. Analysts say it's not the best time to play hardball, as neighboring countries are offering more attractive incentives to investors fleeing China ahead of potential US tariffs. This could lead to Indonesia missing out on economic opportunities.

images.alt_text: The absence of AI capabilities in the latest iPhones sold in China has become a major setback for Apple.
Meta has made 15 interoperability requests thus far, more than any other company, for potentially far-reaching access to Apple’s technology stack, the latter said in a report.
The move is part of a broader shift in how Apple approaches payment services.
The AI features will be available on the latest iPhone series, as well as the Pro and Pro Max versions of the previous iPhone 15 line-up.
Apple’s AI chip is internally code-named Baltra and is expected to be ready for mass production by 2026, the report says.

site_title: Canadian dollar posts fourth straight weekly loss amid Trudeau uncertainty
summary: The Canadian dollar has posted its fourth consecutive weekly loss, falling 0.8% amid uncertainty surrounding Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government. Strong US economic data and a more hawkish Federal Reserve contributed to the decline, with the loonie trading 0.3% higher against the US dollar. Trudeau's government stability is questioned after Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's sudden resignation, and a potential early election is seen as a threat to the country's economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Sterling edges into positive territory on Tuesday after data showed regular UK pay rose more quickly than expected in the three months to October.

site_title: SingPost fires CEO Vincent Phang, CFO Vincent Yik over handling of whistleblower’s report
summary: SingPost has terminated the employment of CEO Vincent Phang, CFO Vincent Yik, and international business unit CEO Li Yu due to their handling of a whistleblower's report. The report, received earlier this year, alleged serious breaches of the company's code of conduct by IBU managers. Investigations found the three executives were "grossly negligent" in handling the report, failing to consider material facts and undermining the company's internal audit unit. Phang and Yik have rejected the accusations and will "vigorously contest" their terminations. Isaac Mah has been appointed as new CFO, and an acting CEO will lead the IBU pending a board review.

images.alt_text: SingPost intends to use a portion of the proceeds from the Australian business sale to repay borrowings.
S&P said on Thursday it has placed Singapore Post on credit watch negative, following news about the potential sale of its Australia business.
The deal comes after a strategic review of SingPost's Australia business.

The Singapore Post board noted that incoming chief financial officer Vincent Yik is expected to lead "the continued transformation of our business, especially with Australia as a key part of our strategy".

site_title: ‘I never thought we would become farmers,’ says F&N CEO
summary: F&N, a beverage manufacturer, is developing its first large-scale dairy farm in Malaysia to secure a reliable supply of milk. The company's CEO, Hui Choon Kit, cited supply chain disruptions and price increases due to hurricanes in the US as reasons for the move. The farm aims to grow its own animal feed and incorporate technological solutions to mitigate methane emissions. While dairy is the only commodity for which F&N is going upstream, the company is also exploring alternative sourcing for other raw materials. This shift is part of its broader strategy to manage climate-related risks and adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: F&N's FY2024 revenue growth is largely driven by the strong performance of its F&B segment.

ThaiBev says that Thailand’s alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverage industry continues to show signs of improvement, supported by the recovery of the tourism sector. Hotter weather conditions also contributed to the industry's growth.
The valuation accorded to F&N under the deal is 232 per cent above its last closing price, while the valuation accorded to FPL is 136 per cent above its last closing price
F&N's revenue is up by 2.1 per cent for the first nine months of FY2024 compared to the same period last year.
The share swap will be executed at an estimated ratio of 1.88 Frasers Property shares for each F&N share.

site_title: First Singaporean golfer at Masters hopes ‘not be in awe’ of heroes
summary: Singaporean golfer Hiroshi Tai, 22, is set to become the first Singaporean to tee off at the US Masters in April. Tai's victory in the NCAA championship in May secured his invitation to the prestigious tournament, where he hopes not to be in awe of his golfing heroes, Hideki Matsuyama and Scottie Scheffler. Born in Hong Kong to a Singaporean father and Japanese mother, Tai aims to play to his abilities and finish as high as possible, with a future professional career in mind after graduating in 2026.

images.alt_text: The talks between DP World Tour and LIV Golf may see the two entities merge, creating a shared schedule and allowing golfers to play in events hosted by both leagues.

A bird's eye view of Sentosa Golf Club's world-renowned Serapong course, which has played host to dozens of local and international tournaments over the years.

site_title: Bitcoin approaching first weekly decline since Trump’s victory
summary: Bitcoin has dropped over 7% for its seven-day period, its largest decline since September, amid a cautious Federal Reserve policy outlook. The largest digital asset fell to around $95,000, about $13,000 below its record high set on Dec 17. This decline comes after US President-elect Donald Trump's pledge of friendly regulations and his backing for a national Bitcoin stockpile sparked optimism in the crypto sector. Experts predict a "bullish trajectory" into the first quarter of 2025, but warn of potential volatility in the final days of the year due to high options expiry events.

site_title: Higher-for-longer rates a boon for savers
summary: The US Federal Reserve's guidance on interest rates in its latest meeting has dampened expectations for rate cuts in 2025, with markets now pricing in only one rate cut or none. This shift has made fixed deposits and lower-risk options such as six-month Treasury bills and Singapore Savings Bonds attractive for savers. Higher-yielding options, including robo platforms and bank deposits, are also available for those willing to recalibrate their risk and liquidity requirements, with some offering yields exceeding 3%.

site_title: Google says it could loosen search deals in US antitrust case
summary: Google proposes loosening its agreements with Apple and others to set it as the default search engine on new devices, addressing a US ruling that it unlawfully dominates online search. The company plans to appeal the ruling and focus on distribution agreements with browser developers, mobile device manufacturers, and wireless carriers during the "remedies" phase. Google could make these agreements non-exclusive and unbundle its Play Store from Chrome and search. The proposal is narrower than the government's bid to make Google sell its Chrome browser, and a trial will be held in April to determine the need for wide-ranging remedies.

site_title: Uber investors are calling for more transparency into driver pay
summary: A group of Uber investors, SOC Investment Group, is calling for greater transparency into driver pay, proposing a resolution that would require the company to regularly disclose a more granular breakdown of driver compensation. The current practice is deemed "unusually opaque," leaving investors in the dark on driver pay and commissions. Uber has declined to comment on the proposal, which could face a "no-action" request from the US Securities and Exchange Commission.

images.alt_text: Uber Technologies, partnering with China's WeRide, launched its first autonomous rides outside the US in Abu Dhabi.

site_title: ‘Sonic 3’ zips to top of North American box office
summary: Sonic the Hedgehog 3, a new action comedy, topped the North American box office with an estimated US$62 million opening, beating predictions. The film, based on the popular Sega video game, rode positive reviews and strong audience scores. It outperformed Disney's Mufasa: The Lion King, which placed second with US$35 million, and Universal's Wicked, which took third with US$13.5 million. The weekend's top 10 films include Moana 2, Homestead, Gladiator II, and The Lord of the Rings: The War of the Rohirrim.

images.alt_text: Cast member Jim Carrey attends a premiere of the film Sonic the Hedgehog 3 at TCL Chinese theatre in Los Angeles, California, U.S., December 16, 2024. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni
In "Moana 2",  Moana joins an unlikely crew to travel the rugged seas of Oceania to break the curse of an evil god.

site_title: Insights from Thailand’s issuance of sovereign sustainability-linked bonds
summary: Thailand has issued a 30 billion Thai baht (S$1.2 billion) sustainability-linked bond, marking a notable advancement in the sovereign-labelled debt market. The bond links the coupon to specific environmental, social, or governance targets, offering a viable alternative for developing countries to finance national sustainability strategies. This is the first sovereign SLB in Asia and the first non-South American sovereign SLB to come to market, bolstering local capital-market development. The issuance demonstrates the growing momentum of sovereign SLBs globally.

site_title: Are investors right to worry about waning corporate climate commitments?
summary: High-profile companies such as Volvo, Air New Zealand, and Shell have withdrawn or scaled back their climate commitments, sparking concerns about the durability of corporate climate leadership. This trend follows a broader backdrop of corporate commitment to addressing climate change, with over 2,000 companies signed up to the Science-Based Targets initiative. While some companies, like cloud providers, demonstrate genuine climate leadership by persisting despite challenges, others may be retreating from their commitments, raising questions about greenwashing. The true test of climate leadership lies in delivering practical implementation, not just setting ambitious targets.

site_title: Luxury labels bulk up on lower-priced goods to appeal to middle-class shoppers
summary: Luxury brands are expanding their product lines to appeal to middle-class shoppers, offering items priced under $500. This shift is a response to slowing sales and a broad decline in demand for high-end goods. Companies like LVMH, Kering, and Gucci are introducing affordable products, such as scarves, belts, and home goods, to attract price-sensitive consumers. However, this strategy may erode profit margins and damage brands' exclusive auras. Global sales of luxury personal goods are expected to be flat during the holiday season, with a shrinking client base of aspirational shoppers.

site_title: China property flare-ups resurface as crisis enters fifth year
summary: China's property debt crisis enters its fifth year, with distressed developers struggling to repay debt despite government efforts to ease the housing slowdown. One major developer, China Vanke, is facing liquidity risks, and its US dollar bonds have slumped to record lows. Hong Kong-based developers New World Development and Parkview Group are also facing financial struggles, with New World asking banks to postpone loan maturities and Parkview seeking buyers for a commercial complex. Experts warn that the sector may not recover until 2026 or later, with a possible increase in defaults next year.

images.alt_text: Vanke's contracted sales for November declined 34.4 per cent from a year earlier to 20.1 billion yuan (S$3.7 billion), widening from a 22.8 per cent drop in October.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market experienced a mixed week, with the Capesize market initially showing optimism before weakening due to oversupply of tonnage. The South Brazil and West Africa to China routes showed some resilience, while the Panamax market saw steady rates in the Atlantic. The Ultramax/Supramax market remained positional, and the Handysize market continued to slide. The Clean market saw minimal activity, while the MR market remained positive, with the UK-Continent MR's stalled this week. The Suezmax market faced pressure from charterers, and the Aframax market saw improved rates in the North Sea. The LNG market had a challenging week, with minimal movement across most routes.

site_title: Never mind Trump, stocks may get a lift in 2025 from resilient US economy and corporate earnings
summary: US stocks may experience further gains in 2025 due to a resilient US economy and corporate earnings growth. Despite Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's hawkish stance, continued economic expansion and inflation projections support a strong market. Analysts predict a 12.6% rise in the S&P 500, with healthcare and energy sectors expected to see significant gains. Meanwhile, beaten-down Reits in Singapore may be ripe for bargain hunting in 2025, driven by a potential easing of inflation and rate cuts by the Fed.

FY2024 on outlet closures, rising costs
summary: Soup Holdings expects to report a loss for FY2024 due to outlet closures, initial losses from new operations, and rising operating costs. The company's revenue declined 0.6% to S$20.7 million in the half year ended Jun 30, 2024, while net profit fell 87.9% to S$167,000. Two outlets were closed for renovations and three for redevelopment works, while two new outlets and a central kitchen underperformed. The company incurred impairment losses and a decline in revenue from its food processing segment.

site_title: OpenAI unveils 'o3' reasoning AI models in test phase
summary: OpenAI has unveiled its new 'o3' and 'o3 mini' reasoning AI models, which are in the test phase and aim to tackle complex problems. The models are more powerful than its previously launched 'o1' models, which were designed to spend more time processing queries to solve hard problems. OpenAI plans to launch 'o3 mini' by the end of January and 'o3' after that, with a public release expected to follow. The company is also opening an application process for external researchers to test the 'o3' models.

site_title: The battle of the wealth hubs: Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong
summary: Singapore, Dubai, and Hong Kong are vying for wealth migration as the global wealth market shifts. According to Henley & Partners, 128,000 millionaires are expected to relocate in 2024, with Singapore, Dubai, and Hong Kong emerging as top contenders. Singapore's stable and safe environment, favorable policies, and diversified sources of wealth attract high-net-worth individuals, while Dubai offers tax incentives and lower barriers for visas and business licensing. Hong Kong remains a key location for wealth coming from China and individuals seeking access to the country. The three hubs are not in competition, but rather, they cater to different needs, with Singapore focusing on portfolio and foreign direct investment flows, Dubai on tax incentives, and Hong Kong on proximity to China and North Asia.

images.alt_text: Dubai – and the rest of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) – has become a strong magnet for private wealth and talent in recent years.

site_title: China says its astronauts complete record-breaking spacewalk
summary: Chinese astronauts Cai Xuzhe and Song Lingdong completed a world-record 9-hour spacewalk outside the Tiangong space station, surpassing the 2001 record set by NASA astronauts James Voss and Susan Helms. The spacewalk, part of China's Shenzhou-19 mission, included the installation of space-debris protection devices. This achievement marks a milestone for Beijing's expanding space program, which has also seen recent successes such as landing a rover on Mars and retrieving rock samples from the moon's far side. China aims to land its first astronauts on the moon by 2030.

images.alt_text: The round-trip mission is part of a step-by-step plan to land humans back on the moon at some point this decade.

site_title: Nasdaq affected by interest rate expectations
summary: The Nasdaq-100 Index has maintained a bullish momentum, rising 25.46% as of December 19, despite corrections in mid-November and mid-December. The Federal Reserve's decision to reduce interest rates by 25 basis points in its December meeting has led to market volatility, with investors adjusting expectations for 2025 rate cuts from four to potentially just two. The index's uptrend remains intact, with support zones defined by the 50-day SMA and Fibonacci levels, and potential resistance at 21,525 and 22,000 levels.

site_title: Behind the numbers: Navigating banking processes to avert scams can be frustrating
summary: Singapore witnessed a 16.3% increase in scam cases in the first half of 2024, with losses rising by 24.6% to an estimated S$385.6 million. Government impersonation scams were the most lucrative, causing an average loss of over S$116,000 per victim. A recent incident involved a police impersonation scam targeting a DBS customer, whose account was compromised due to limited English proficiency and a rigid verification process. Experts suggest empowering frontline staff to make informed decisions and providing multilingual support to better serve Singapore's diverse population.

site_title: China’s most exciting car brand is searching for its soul
summary: Chinese electric car brand Zeekr is rapidly expanding its product line and entering new markets, but it faces a challenge in establishing an identity within the crowded automotive landscape. The company aims to reinvent every product segment it enters, with models like the Bugatti-baiting station wagon and almost fully self-driving cars. Zeekr's 001 FR boasts 1,300 horsepower and can power 97,000 household LED bulbs, but its success is threatened by the need to balance performance with polish and heritage, a challenge many Chinese brands are facing in the EV era.

site_title: Volkswagen unveils major job cuts in cost-saving drive
summary: Volkswagen has reached an agreement with unions to cut 35,000 jobs in Germany by 2030 as part of a drastic cost-cutting plan, saving the company around 4 billion euros per year. The deal includes production site closures, job losses, and reduced production lines, with 4,000 jobs to be lost at the flagship factory by 2030. The agreement aims to reduce excess capacity, labor costs, and development costs to a competitive level, and will be implemented in stages, including a pay freeze and reduced bonuses.

site_title: South-east Asia venture capital hitting the wall in 2024
summary: South-east Asia's venture capital sector faces significant challenges in 2024, with many VCs dropping out and pessimism prevailing. However, the author of Vertex Ventures believes this year could be foundational for building portfolios with strong returns over the next five to 10 years. Historically, some of the best investments were made during periods of doubt and fear, allowing founders to focus on long-term vision and sustainable growth. The market's maturity and diversification offer opportunities for investors, with a growing pathway for exits and local tech giants showing increased appetite for acquisitions.

site_title: Festive cheer for Singapore’s F&B scene as reservations roll in earlier than last year
summary: Singapore's F&B scene is experiencing an earlier surge in bookings for the festive season, with many restaurants reaching full capacity by mid-December. Demand for Hilton Singapore Orchard's buffet restaurant Estate has improved year-over-year, while Pan Pacific Hotels Group and Sofitel Singapore City Centre are also seeing strong bookings. Despite a decline in revenge travel, tourists are still making reservations, contributing to the increased demand. Overall spending on festive meals is expected to be higher this year, with diners willing to splurge on quality dining experiences and special occasions.

site_title: Catalist stocks’ poor performance highlights structural issues, market problems
summary: The Catalist, Singapore Exchange's junior board, has seen many newly listed companies struggle to perform well, with some tumbling in price and seeing low trading volumes. Industry watchers are divided on the reasons, with some attributing the issue to structural gaps in the junior board, while others blame low valuations and a market problem. Experts suggest reviewing listing criteria to prioritize companies with strong fundamentals and simplifying disclosure requirements to reduce costs. However, others point to macroeconomic conditions and a lack of investor education as contributing factors, highlighting the need for a more nuanced approach to addressing the issue.

site_title: China’s hottest stock, Pop Mart, rockets 370% on craze for collectibles
summary: Pop Mart, a Chinese consumer brand, has become the hottest stock, rising 368% this year, driven by its global success in attracting consumers via intellectual property, design, and products. The company's unique toys, such as PUCKY Roly Poly Kitty dolls, have gained a massive following, especially among Gen Z, with fans queuing for hours to get new releases. Overseas sales have surged fivefold, and the company is expected to account for half of its total revenue next year as it expands to North America and Europe.

site_title: Car sales to grow modestly in 2025 as global output falters
summary: Global auto sales are expected to grow 1.7% in 2025 to 89.6 million units, driven by increased vehicle supplies, but production levels are likely to fall as carmakers aim to manage inventory. US sales will grow 1.2% to 16.2 million vehicles, while global production will decline 0.4% to 88.7 million units, mainly due to concerns over demand resiliency. China and South America are the only regions likely to see production gains, with EV deliveries set to jump 30% to 15.1 million units, making up 17% of total light vehicle sales.

site_title: Qualcomm defeats Arm’s claim over chip design licence breach
summary: Qualcomm has prevailed in a trial against Arm's claim of a licence breach over chip technology. The US federal court in Delaware ruled that Qualcomm did not violate terms of an agreement covering Arm's chip products after incorporating the technology in its chips without paying a higher licensing rate. Jurors were unable to agree on whether Nuvia, a US$1.4 billion acquisition target, breached the licence. Qualcomm's shares rose 2% in after-hours trading, while Arm's shares fell 1.9%. The dispute is significant as many tech companies rely on Arm's chip architecture.

images.alt_text: A Qualcomm Inc. baseband modem integrated circuit (IC) chip from an Apple Inc. iPhone 6 smartphone is displayed in an arranged photograph in Bangkok, Thailand, on Saturday, Feb.3, 2018. *** SECOND SENTENCE HERE ***. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Digital assets expected to charge on in 2025 amid bullish sentiment, say industry players
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's election win has boosted bullish sentiment in the digital assets market, with Bitcoin prices jumping to over $100,000, driven by investor optimism and potential pro-crypto policies. Industry players expect this momentum to continue into 2025, driven by innovation and expansion in areas like tokenization and payments. Despite existing interoperability issues, market players see a promising outlook for digital assets, with potential benefits for Singapore's ecosystem.

images.alt_text: New wealth generated by Bitcoin’s recent highs comes as the luxury industry faces its biggest slump in years and searches for new sources of growth.

site_title: Tether sees US$10 billion in net profits for 2024
summary: Tether, the world's largest stablecoin issuer, is expected to close 2024 with over $10 billion in net profits, according to CEO Paolo Ardoino. The company's USDT stablecoin has seen a surge in demand, adding nearly $50 billion to its market capitalization this year, now standing at over $140 billion. Tether plans to deploy at least half of its profits in investments, including in artificial intelligence and other sectors, and is exploring investments in the US with favorable regulatory conditions under President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: Nanofilm Technologies reappoints founder as CEO
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has appointed its founder Shi Xu as the new CEO, effective January 1, 2025. Current CEO Gary Ho will remain in his position until June 13, 2025, to ensure a smooth transition. Shi, who previously served as CEO from 1999 to 2017, was chosen by the board due to his leadership experience and expertise. Shares fell 2% following the announcement.

site_title: Mexico City to boost mobility, security ahead of Fifa World Cup
summary: Mexico City is preparing for the 2026 FIFA World Cup with plans to increase investment in mobility and security, with a proposed budget of nearly 7 billion pesos (S$472.6 million) for mobility initiatives. The city's subway system will receive a record high budget of 23 billion pesos, while public works will invest 13.5 billion pesos in infrastructure, including the historic Tlalpan causeway. The city aims to ensure a safe and efficient experience for fans, with 600 million pesos set aside for security cameras in the subway.

images.alt_text: The combined proposal from Morocco, Spain and Portugal will see the 2030 World Cup take place across three continents and six nations.

site_title: Australian authorities urge hundreds to flee out-of-control bushfires
summary: Australian authorities have issued an evacuation order for hundreds of residents in Victoria's west due to out-of-control bushfires. The fires, sparked by lightning strikes, have burnt over 28,000 hectares and are being fought by 400 firefighters. Authorities have warned of a high-risk bush fire season this summer, following several quiet seasons compared to the 2019-2020 "Black Summer" fires that destroyed an area the size of Turkey and killed 33 people. Residents are advised to leave immediately as conditions become too dangerous.

images.alt_text: Australia a harder country to live in because of natural disasters, says Scott Morrison

site_title: Billions of dollars, bold action: Emerging markets battle a surging greenback
summary: Emerging markets are taking bold action to combat a surging US dollar, which has pushed their currencies to multi-year lows. Central banks in Brazil, South Korea, and Hungary are intervening in the currency market to defend their currencies, while China's central bank continues to support the yuan. The move comes as the US Federal Reserve signals a shift towards inflation concerns, with policymakers in developing markets taking action to boost inflows and address demand and supply imbalances. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index has fallen 3% since end-September, with the real, Hungarian forint, and Chilean peso among the hardest hit.

images.alt_text: The central bank lowered interest rates by a quarter point on Wednesday and indicated two additional cuts in 2025.

site_title: Powell’s battle-ready Fed gives the Trump trade a stress test
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's hawkish stance on interest-rate cuts has sent stocks and bonds to their worst sessions in months, reversing the momentum of the Trump trade. Powell voiced waning enthusiasm for rate cuts, citing the need for further progress on inflation before easing further. This move has sparked extreme positioning in markets, with investors betting on the Trump trade's continued run in risky assets. Despite a rebound on Friday, the S&P 500 still slid 2% over the five days, while small caps and value stocks fell a third week.

images.alt_text: Labour market resilience has been driving economic expansion through strong consumer spending.

site_title: Europe: Shares see worst week in more than 3 months as healthcare slides
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.9% lower, its second straight weekly fall, as the healthcare sector led losses. Novo Nordisk's disappointing obesity drug trial results and US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on EU purchasing US oil and gas to avoid tariffs contributed to the downturn. The healthcare sub-sector dropped 4% and the Danish benchmark tumbled 13.2%. Real estate was the only sector to gain, advancing 1.4%.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 1.5 per cent lower, hitting a three-week low, with all the major sub-sectors in the red.

site_title: Another year to remember in the world of sports
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The past year has been filled with memorable sports moments, including Rafael Nadal's retirement after a 23-year career, Mike Tyson's comeback loss to Jake Paul, Spain's Euro 2024 victory, and France's Leon Marchand's record-breaking performance at the Paris Olympics. Nadal won 92 singles titles, while Marchand claimed five gold medals and set an Olympic record in the 200m breaststroke. Novak Djokovic continued to dominate tennis, winning the Olympic gold medal, and Spain's young squad won their fourth European title. These events will be remembered for years to come, showcasing the unpredictability of the sports world.

site_title: Ho Chi Minh City launches first metro line, plans to fast track 7 more by 2035
summary: Ho Chi Minh City has launched its first metro line, the Ben Thanh-Suoi Tien section, after a six-year delay. The line, part of a comprehensive mass transit system, is funded primarily through Japan's official development assistance. The city plans to fast-track seven more metro lines by 2035, aiming to reduce reliance on official development assistance. This marks Vietnam's third metro line, following the first two in Hanoi.

site_title: Suspected attack on German Christmas market kills at least 2
summary: A suspected attacker drove a car into a Christmas market in Magdeburg, Germany, killing at least 2 people and injuring others. The incident occurred on December 20 evening, and the market was closed afterwards. The government has been under pressure to boost security nationwide following recent violent attacks. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government has been calling for stricter immigration rules ahead of an early federal election in February, amid rising public frustration with migration policies.

site_title: US House passes bill to avert shutdown, Senate vote to follow
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a bill to avert a government shutdown, keeping federal agencies running until mid-March. The bill, which includes $110 billion in disaster aid and financial relief for farmers, was approved with bipartisan support. However, the Senate must vote on the bill by midnight, and a shutdown will occur if it fails to pass. President-elect Trump has threatened to see a shutdown if he doesn't get his way, and Elon Musk's influence on Republicans has raised questions about his power.

images.alt_text: “I told the European Union that they must make up their tremendous deficit with the US by the large scale purchase of our oil and gas. Otherwise, it is TARIFFS all the way!!!,” President-elect Donald Trump said on Truth Social.

site_title: Malaysia says Facebook, X, TikTok must get licences, NST reports
summary: Malaysia requires major social media platforms, including Facebook, X, and TikTok, to obtain licenses by next year to combat rising cybercrime cases. The platforms, which include WhatsApp and YouTube, have been identified due to having at least eight million users in the country. Failure to comply will result in legal action, with the government citing profits from the platforms and the significance of the Malaysian market. The move aims to combat online fraud, cyberbullying, and other crimes, despite resistance from some platforms citing concerns over stifling innovation.

site_title: China’s overseas investment adds to cash exodus weighing on renminbi
summary: China's overseas investment surged to almost $129 billion in the first 11 months of 2024, contributing to a gloomy outlook for the renminbi. This increase in direct overseas investment is driven by firms' desire to reduce tariffs and get closer to customers. Foreign firms have pulled out almost $13 billion in direct investment, while money has left financial markets, putting pressure on the Chinese currency. With the threat of new US tariffs and interest rate cuts, the renminbi is at risk of further losses, reaching its weakest level versus the US dollar in over a year.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after inflation data but close lower for the week
summary: US stocks rallied on Friday after a cooler-than-expected inflation report and comments from Federal Reserve officials eased concerns about interest rate hikes. The Dow and S&P 500 recorded their biggest daily percentage gains since November 6, with the Dow rising 1.2%, the S&P 500 gaining 1.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 1%. Despite the rally, the week ended lower, with the S&P 500 falling 2% and the Nasdaq declining 1.8%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 46 points, or 0.11 per cent, at the open to 42,296.26.

site_title: US markets embrace prospect of smaller government
summary: US investors are optimistic about a potential second Trump term, particularly deregulation and reduced government involvement in the economy. The S&P 500 has seen its best post-election day performance in decades, with investors welcoming a smaller government role. However, experts caution that a reduced government role may lead to increased cost pressures for businesses, potentially upending the performance dominance of passive investing. A look at historical data suggests that investors should consider the pathway of future earnings when making investment decisions.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, December 20, 2024
summary: SK Hynix completes a deal worth US$958 million for a US chips grant and loan. Indonesia is considering deep cuts to nickel mining to boost prices. China's hottest stock, Pop Mart, surged 370% due to craze for collectibles. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) fell 1.1% on regional declines.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares
SK Hynix is one of three makers of so-called high-bandwidth memory chips, which are essential components of computers used to create artificial intelligence software.
Nickel, which is used to make both stainless steel and EV batteries, has endured a two-year slump due to weak demand and booming Indonesian supplies.
Pop Mart is likely the first homegrown Chinese consumer brand to achieve significant global success by attracting consumers via intellectual property, design and products, rather than pricing.

site_title: IMF board approves US$1.1 billion disbursement for Ukraine
summary: The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) executive board approved a $1.1 billion disbursement to Ukraine on December 20, bringing the total disbursed under the program to around $9.8 billion since its signing in March 2023. The approval comes as Ukraine faces continued Russian attacks, and is part of a four-year, $15.5 billion loan program. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva stated that Russia's war in Ukraine continues to have a devastating social and economic impact.

images.alt_text: Much of von der Leyen’s 100-day planning will be influenced by shifting internal and external dynamics in Europe, and beyond.

site_title: Sias to take its Invest Singapore programme to the heartlands
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) plans to expand its Invest Singapore programme to the heartlands in 2025 to boost retail participation in local stocks. The initiative aims to educate investors and guide them in constructing portfolios to match their risk profiles. Despite a strong performance by the Singapore share market in 2024, the number of initial public offerings was limited, and the overall market is still missing a vibrant stock market. Sias hopes to see more high-quality listings and improved stock trading liquidity, with potential measures including an injection of capital and revised valuation multiples.

images.alt_text: David Gerald, Founder, President & CEO, SIAS delivering a speech at the launch of SIAS Corporate Governance Week 2024 on September 16, 2024

While experts believe that young investors are important to the vibrancy of an equities market, different headwinds stand in the way of making the Singapore Exchange more attractive to this cohort of investors.

site_title: Obscene prices, declining quality: Luxury is in a death spiral
summary: Luxury brands are facing a slowdown due to obscene prices, declining quality, and a growing realisation that many luxury houses have broken the principles that made them successful. High-end labels such as LVMH, Kering, Burberry, Richemont, and Capri Holdings reported losses this year, and management consulting company Bain predicted that 2024 would be the first year of luxury slowdown since the 2008 financial crisis. The industry's decline is attributed to factors such as the rise of "buy now, pay later" financing apps, social media-driven one-upmanship, and the proliferation of luxury goods, leading to a decrease in quality and an increase in prices.

images.alt_text: The partnership with Formula one, LVMH’s next major push into the sports world after it paid some 150 million euros (S$214 million) to be the premium sponsor of the Paris Olympics, starts in 2025.
Kering has remained largely dependent on Gucci, whose success in the cutthroat fashion industry has ebbed and flowed over the years.
LVMH’s sales in the region that includes China fell 16 per cent in the third quarter, more than its 14 per cent drop in the previous three months.

site_title: Oil steady as markets weigh Fed rate cut expectations, Chinese demand
summary: Oil prices were little changed at their settle on Friday as markets weighed Chinese demand and interest rate-cut expectations. Brent crude futures rose 6 US cents to $72.94 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 8 cents to $69.46 a barrel, both ending the week down about 2.5 percent. A weaker dollar makes oil cheaper for holders of other currencies, while rate cuts could spur economic growth and boost oil demand.

images.alt_text: View of two drilling rigs operated by Arrington Oil & Gas Operating LLC, an energy producer in Midland, Texas, U.S., October 8, 2024. REUTERS/Georgina McCartney

site_title: US: Wall Street falls at open on concerns over rate outlook
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Friday, December 20, 2024, due to concerns over high interest rates next year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 46 points, or 0.11%, to 42,296.26. The S&P 500 fell 25.1 points, or 0.43%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 182.7 points, or 0.94%. A cooler-than-expected inflation report for November partially stymied losses, but investors remained cautious about the impact of interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - DECEMBER 18: Traders work on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) floor on December 18, 2024 in New York City. site_title: Singapore stocks’ best year since 2017 masks downbeat outlook
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index is on track for its best annual performance since 2017, driven primarily by banks, with the trio of DBS, OCBC, and UOB making up over half of the benchmark's weighting. However, the rally is overshadowed by concerns about the market's stagnation, with delistings outnumbering new listings, and a lack of diversity in membership. The government has acknowledged the need to improve the situation and has formed a taskforce to create an action plan to revive the market by next summer, which may include initiatives to boost private sector participation and increase investment in local equities.

images.alt_text: Industry watchers are divided on the reasons for the underperformance of counters on the Catalist, the Singapore Exchange's junior board.

site_title: Trump-backed spending deal fails in House, shutdown approaches
summary: A spending bill backed by Donald Trump failed in the US House of Representatives, leaving Congress with no clear plan to avert a government shutdown that could disrupt Christmas travel. The bill, which would increase spending and clear the way for a plan to add trillions to the federal debt, failed by a vote of 174-235. The failure highlights fault lines within Trump's Republican Party and raises concerns about the country's debt and government spending.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump holds huge sway over Republicans, who currently control the House of Representatives and will also control the Senate when he returns to office on Jan 20.

site_title: Book review: The M&A Failure Trap
summary: A new book, "The M&A Failure Trap," by Baruch Lev and Feng Gu, reveals that the failure rate of mergers and acquisitions (M&A) is on the rise, with 70-75% of deals failing. The authors found that acquisition premiums have increased, goodwill write-offs have grown larger, and conglomerate acquisitions have made a comeback. They identified 43 factors that enhance or detract from the probability of success and developed a 10-factor model for investors to assess M&A prospects. The book highlights the role of flawed incentives, such as commission-hungry bankers and overconfident CEOs, in contributing to the high failure rate.

images.alt_text: Deals among larger regional firms could be possible, too – and would likely benefit Americans by providing better competition with the biggest lenders such as JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 20)
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) fined two interior-construction firms nearly S$10 million for bid-rigging in several tenders. Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 1.8% in November, below expectations. The Ministry of Health revoked MaNaDr Clinic's licence due to an "entrenched culture of disregard" for ethical and clinical standards. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry called for targeted measures to help SMEs in the 2025 Budget. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% on Friday, mirroring regional indices.

site_title: Indepay targets lower transaction costs for Indonesia’s MSMEs with zero-fee model
summary: Indonesian fintech company Indepay Networks is launching a zero-fee transaction model that connects mobile phones to bank accounts, aiming to improve the country's digital economy and bridge the gap for Indonesia's vast, underserved market. The company has partnered with Indosat Ooredoo Hutchison and 43 banks to reach 100 million customers and 50 million account holders. Indepay's goal is to reduce transaction costs for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises, which currently face high fees for online transactions, and make Indonesia one of the most promising untapped markets in the Asia-Pacific's digital financial sector.

site_title: China’s Xi urges bigger international role for gambling hub Macau
summary: China's President Xi Jinping urged Macau's new government to diversify the economy of the world's biggest gambling hub, calling for the development of new industries and connections with China's national development strategies. The move comes as Xi seeks to promote moderate economic diversification and reduce reliance on the casino industry, which contributes 80% of regional tax revenue. Xi also emphasized the importance of Macau's autonomy and encouraged the city to be more open and inclusive to international talent, with a focus on becoming a major player on the global stage.

images.alt_text: People walking underneath Macau and China flags at the Leal Senado Square in Macau, Dec 13, 2024.

site_title: Sentosa’s hidden histories in The Pineapple Room
summary: The Pineapple Room, a new bar at Capella Singapore, pays tribute to the island's history as a pineapple plantation in the 1880s. Located within the hotel, the intimate space features a nostalgic yet elegant atmosphere, with a dark teak bar and warm lighting. The bar's signature cocktail, the Triple P, is inspired by the area's history, and the menu features seven tropical cocktails with local fruits and botanicals. The bar aims to provide a tranquil escape for locals and a unique experience for travelers, with a bespoke card game and plans to extend the menu with classic drinks reinvented with local ingredients.

site_title: China lifts rock lobster ban, bringing end to Australian trade barriers
summary: China has lifted a ban on imports of Australian live rock lobsters, allowing exporters to resume trade worth US$500,000 a year. The move marks the end of a trade war between the two countries, with China previously imposing retaliatory tariffs on over US$12 billion worth of Australian exports. The lobster trade was the last major Australian export to remain under sanctions, following months of diplomatic efforts by the Australian government.

images.alt_text: Treasurer Jim Chalmers said that the challenges in the Chinese economy will impact Australia's budget, as reflected in Treasury’s forecasts.

site_title: Where to put your money in 2025
summary: Recession risks are expected to be low in 2025, with central banks expected to cut interest rates due to continued disinflation. Investors are advised to focus on maximising returns and minimising risk through diversification. Asia is poised to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, while productivity gains are key to unlocking wealth creation. De-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also emerging trends. Active management is crucial to optimally positioning portfolios for 2025, with a focus on the cheapest and most effective hedge available.

site_title: Competition watchdog fines two interior-construction firms nearly S$10 million for rigging tender bids
summary: Two Singaporean interior-construction firms, Flex Connect and Tarkus Interiors, have been fined nearly S$10 million by the Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) for colluding to rig tender bids over a five-year period. The firms affected 12 tenders worth S$34.1 million, with bid-rigging involving one party providing details to the other to increase their chances of winning. The CCCS found that the conduct eliminated competitive pressure and resulted in potential customers potentially overpaying for the tenders.

images.alt_text: The rigged bids relate to the supply of interior fit-out construction services for 12 non-residential properties in Singapore.

site_title: OUE Reit divests entire stake in Shanghai office property for 1.9 billion yuan
summary: OUE Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) is selling its entire stake in Shanghai office property Lippo Plaza for 1.9 billion yuan (S$357.4 million), with expected net proceeds of about S$318.2 million. The 36-storey building, valued at 1.7 billion yuan, will be sold to an unrelated entity. The divestment is part of OUE Reit's strategy to optimise portfolio composition, strengthen income resilience, and bring about sustainable returns. The sale will allow the manager to redeploy funds towards more strategic uses, including debt reduction and accretive acquisitions.

site_title: The business of nicknames
summary: Businesses and employees alike use nicknames, which can be either beneficial or hurtful. A study found that nicknames that genuinely reflect consumers' fondness for a brand can send a positive signal, but when used inauthentically, it can backfire. Workplace nicknames, while often meant as a mark of affection, can be unpleasant if given by a boss, whereas nicknames given by peers are more acceptable. Companies should allow nicknames to emerge organically, and managers should be cautious when using them, as they can affect employee well-being and perception of the company.

site_title: Trump threatens tariffs if EU doesn’t buy more US oil and gas
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump warned the European Union that it must significantly increase its purchases of US oil and gas to avoid US tariffs, citing a large trade deficit between the two. Trump tweeted that if the EU doesn't meet his demands, "it is TARIFFS all the way!!!". The EU has been preparing for a potential trade war, with officials discussing measures to counter coercive practices and exploring ways to reduce Russia's influence in energy markets. The bloc's euro strengthened against the US dollar following Trump's statement.
