site_title: Singapore’s bolttech, valued at US$2.1 billion, raises over US$100 million
summary: Singapore-based insurance technology company bolttech has raised over US$100 million in its latest funding round, valued at US$2.1 billion. The Series C funding will be used for global growth strategy. Global insurtech investment hit US$1.38 billion in the third quarter, the highest since 2023. Founded in 2020, bolttech operates in over 35 markets, and the latest funding round includes investors such as Dragon Fund, Liquidity Group, Baillie Gifford, and Lion River.

images.alt_text: V2Y's core insurtech business segment is mainly focused on the general insurance market and device protection in Singapore.

site_title: Malaysia to resume hunt for Flight MH370, 10 years after it vanished
summary: Malaysia has agreed to resume the search for the wreckage of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, 10 years after it vanished on March 8, 2014. The search will be conducted by exploration firm Ocean Infinity over an 18-month period in the southern Indian Ocean, covering 15,000 sq km. The firm will receive $70 million if wreckage is found. The decision comes after new data was assessed by multiple experts, and the government hopes to provide closure to the families of the 239 people on board.

images.alt_text: Izham Ismail who has been running Malaysia’s flagship airline since 2017, was initially due to retire at the end of 2024 when his current contract expires.
Malaysia Aviation Group - the parent company of Malaysia Airlines, decided to reduce network capacity by 20 per cent across its airlines this year amid a shortage of planes, labour and parts.
Kuala Lumpur International Airport, once a shining symbol of Malaysia’s aviation ambitions, has faced a dramatic fall from grace since its grand opening in 1998.

site_title: Top Glove swings back to black with RM5.5 million Q1 net profit
summary: Top Glove, a glove manufacturer, reported a net profit of RM5.5 million (S$1.7 million) for the first fiscal quarter ended November, reversing its net loss of RM57.7 million in the previous period. Higher sales volume, particularly from US orders ahead of a 50% tariff on glove imports from China, contributed to the improvement. Revenue rose 79.5% to RM885.9 million, and the company expects orders to continue flowing in, driven by increased health and hygiene awareness. Top Glove is optimistic about the recovery of the glove industry and is well-positioned to benefit from trade diversions.

images.alt_text: An employee monitors latex gloves on hand-shaped molds moving along an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020. The world’s biggest glovemaker got a vote of confidence from investors in the credit market, as the coronavirus fuels demand for the Malaysian company’s rubber products. The World Health Organization is taking an unprecedented step of negotiating directly with suppliers to improve access to gloves, face masks and other forms of protective equipment. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
In a call on Wednesday to discuss the company’s latest financial results, Top Glove’s managing director Lim Cheong Guan said it is “tough” to predict when the company will return to profitability.
Revenue for the fourth quarter was 75 per cent higher year on year at RM835.3 million, up from RM476 million in Q4 of FY2023.
Employees work on sewing machines at the Midnight Charm Garment lingerie factory in Guanyun county of Lianyungang, Jiangsu province, China, Nov 25, 2024.

site_title: SCCCI calls for Budget 2025 to help SMEs ease business costs, improve workforce productivity, build green capabilities
summary: The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) has released its Budget 2025 recommendations, focusing on easing business costs, improving workforce productivity, and building green capabilities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The SCCCI calls for targeted measures, including extending schemes to defray rising manpower costs, simplifying the application process, and providing tax rebates to cushion the impact of property tax increases. The chamber also recommends enhancing support for trade associations and chambers to drive internationalisation and upskilling among SMEs.

images.alt_text: To support senior workers, SNEF asked the government to extend the Senior Employment Credit beyond 2025.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 1.8% in November, below expectation
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 1.8% in November, below expectations, due to slower price growth of apparels and communication services. Core inflation remained steady at 1.8% for the third consecutive month. Analysts expect inflation to pick up next year due to policy changes, such as a wider sales and services tax coverage and increased minimum wages. Despite this, the Bank Negara is expected to keep the overnight policy rate unchanged at 3% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Economists surveyed by Reuters had expected the index to rise 2 per cent in August, matching the pace of the previous three months.
Malaysia’s industrial production growth in May was driven by higher manufacturing and electricity output, offsetting the declining mining production.

Asean's expected minimum wage growth bodes well for consumption spending but raises competitiveness considerations, cautioned OCBC Senior Asean economist Lavanya Venkateswaran in a Global Markets Research report on Thursday (Dec 12).

site_title: Indonesia anti-graft body raids office of Financial Services Authority
summary: Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) raided the office of the Financial Services Authority (FSA) on Thursday, days after a similar search at the central bank's headquarters. Investigators seized electronic evidence and documents, investigating alleged misuse of corporate social responsibility funds by financial regulators. The FSA has stated it respects and supports the investigation, and financial services to customers will not be disrupted. The central bank's governor has also cooperated with the investigation, stating that corporate social responsibility funds are distributed according to good governance principles.

site_title: MaNaDr Clinic loses licence, found to have ‘entrenched culture of disregard’ for ethical and clinical standards: MOH
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) has revoked MaNaDr Clinic's licence due to an "entrenched culture of disregard" for ethical and clinical standards. The clinic can no longer operate at its premises, temporary locations, or remotely via teleconsultation. Investigations found widespread inappropriate practices, including over 100,000 one-minute or shorter teleconsultations, and a lack of effective internal oversight. Patients are advised to seek alternative services, and MaNaDr's participation in MOH's financial schemes will be terminated. The clinic's licence revocation highlights the need for tighter telemedicine audits.

images.alt_text: Friday’s circular was issued by the Ministry of Health, Health Sciences Authority and  the Singapore Medical Council.
Telemedicine regulations remain valid, no review needed despite MaNaDr case: Ong Ye Kung
On Oct 24, MOH said it intended to revoke MaNaDr Clinic’s licence.
Telehealth abuse may go beyond MaNaDr clinic; more can be done to weed out errant doctors

site_title: South-east Asia startups missing out on region’s AI-fuelled tech boom
summary: South-east Asia's startups are missing out on the region's AI-fuelled tech boom, with investors wary of unproven entities. Despite the region's growing digital economy, venture investment in AI startups has reached just $1.7 billion this year, a fraction of the $20 billion invested in the Asia-Pacific region. The region's diverse cultural and economic landscape makes it challenging for local tech companies to compete globally. Governments are working to create a coordinated plan, but more cooperation between stakeholders is needed to prioritize moonshot innovation and build a competitive AI ecosystem.

images.alt_text: The absence of AI capabilities in the latest iPhones sold in China has become a major setback for Apple.
How businesses can survive the AI black hole

site_title: Italy probes CK Hutchison unit on tax in 3.4 billion euros asset sale
summary: Italy's finance police are investigating CK Hutchison's Italian telecommunications unit, Wind Tre, over alleged tax evasion in a 3.4 billion euros asset sale to Cellnex Telecom. The probe centers on whether Wind Tre failed to pay registration taxes on the sale of mobile phone masts, amounting to about 132 million euros for 2022. Wind Tre claims it implemented the transaction in full compliance with applicable tax laws and is cooperating with the tax authorities. This is part of Italy's increased scrutiny of global companies' taxes, following probes into Netflix and Meta Platforms.

images.alt_text: A exterior view of Cheung Kong Centre is seen in the Central district of Hong Kong, China, on Saturday, July 29, 2017. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

site_title: SK Hynix completes deal for US$958 million in US chips grant, loan
summary: SK Hynix has finalized a deal with the US government for up to $958 million in grants and loans to support an advanced chip packaging facility in Indiana, as part of the US efforts to build a domestic semiconductor supply chain. The $3.87 billion site will focus on packaging chips sent to the US from SK Hynix plants in South Korea. The deal is part of a pledge to invest $15 billion in US packaging and research projects, and marks a significant expansion for the South Korean company.

images.alt_text: SK Square, the holding company of SK Hynix, plans to cancel 100 billion won (S$96 million) worth of shares that it had bought back in April, while planning to repurchase another 100 billion won worth of shares within the next three months and cancel those shares.
SK Hynix has been leading a global race to meet an explosive demand for HBM chips that aid in the processing of vast amounts of data to train AI technology.
SK Hynix, the world’s second-biggest memory chipmaker, reported a 7 trillion won (S$6.7 billion) operating profit for the July-September quarter versus a 1.8 trillion won loss a year earlier.

site_title:
Elite UK Reit divesting property 
in England for £1.6 million
summary: Elite UK Reit is selling a 15,785-square-foot property in Chippenham, England, St Paul's House, for £1.6 million, representing an 18.5% premium above its valuation of £1.4 million. The sale is subject to conditions and will be used to repay debt. The proposed divestment is not expected to have a material impact on the Reit's net asset value and distribution per unit for the financial year ending December 31, 2024.

images.alt_text: The 15,785-square-foot St Paul's House, is on Marshfield Road in Chippenham, England.

site_title: Indonesia weighs deep cuts to nickel mining to boost prices
summary: Indonesia considers deep cuts to nickel mining quotas to boost slumping prices. The Energy and Mineral Resources Ministry is looking at lowering nickel ore mining to 150 million tonnes in 2025, a 45% decrease from this year. Any significant cut may be opposed by finance and investment ministries due to tax revenue impact and potential chilling effect on investment. Discussions are ongoing within the government, with the goal of boosting prices for the battery metal used in electric vehicle batteries and stainless steel production.

images.alt_text: Nickel, which is used to make both stainless steel and EV batteries, has endured a two-year slump due to weak demand and booming Indonesian supplies.
Indonesia produces nearly half of the world’s nickel with approximately 40.2 per cent of the world’s nickel production in 2023.

site_title: Intel shortlists suitors for programmable chip arm Altera
summary: Intel has shortlisted private equity firms Francisco Partners, Silver Lake Management, and Lattice Semiconductor, alongside Apollo Global Management and Bain Capital, to bid for its Altera unit, a programmable chip specialist. Intel, which acquired Altera in 2015 for $17 billion, is seeking a deal structure that could include acquiring a 20-30% stake or taking full control. Bidders have proposed valuations ranging from $9 billion to $12 billion. Intel's interim co-CEO David Zinsner has stated that the company is seeking another partner, similar to its IMS business sale to Bain Capital, as part of its efforts to engage with outside investors.

images.alt_text: Intel’s struggles to keep pace with rivals — along with its deteriorating financial condition — have spurred speculation that the next CEO will make dramatic changes.
Ayar Labs said it raised US$155 million from Nvidia, AMD Ventures and Intel Capital in a funding round led by Advent Global Opportunities and Light Street Capital.
Even after this year’s slump, Intel isn’t particularly cheap, trading at about 24 times forward earnings, roughly in-line with the chip index.
Intel has started evaluating a handful of outsiders, including former board member Lip-Bu Tan, for the role of CEO.

site_title: Nvidia’s Vietnam deal: a game changer or just noise?
summary: Nvidia has established its first R&D centre in Vietnam, acquiring VinBrain, a Vingroup-backed AI startup, for an undisclosed amount. The deal is seen as a significant move to strengthen ties with the Vietnamese government and the country's largest conglomerate. Despite speculation, Nvidia has not disclosed plans for the VinBrain team, details about the R&D centre's size, or the timeline for its operations. The move is expected to boost Vietnam's tech ecosystem, but concerns remain about the country's relatively lax data privacy regulations and limited scale of the domestic market.

images.alt_text: In a move likely seen as retaliatory against Washington’s recent curbs, Beijing has launched an investigation into AI bellwether Nvidia over suspected violations of China’s anti-monopoly law, further heightening tensions.
Nvidia Corp's offices in Shanghai, China, Dec 10, 2024. Nvidia is expanding its headcount globally as it works to fulfill runaway demand for its artificial intelligence chips.
Nvidia in 2020 agreed to pay US$5.5 million to settle related allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Ayar Labs said it raised US$155 million from Nvidia, AMD Ventures and Intel Capital in a funding round led by Advent Global Opportunities and Light Street Capital.

site_title: Showing extraordinary leadership in 2025 – mental health and the inclusive workplace
summary: Leaders in Singapore's workplace are failing to support mental health, with a recent Public Attitudes Study showing a decline in positive attitudes towards people with disabilities, particularly at work. Despite improved mental health literacy, many employees feel uncomfortable discussing mental health issues, and stigma remains a significant barrier. To address this, leaders can foster open conversations, provide mental health resources, and implement training and education programs. Investing in mental health support can also have economic benefits, including improved productivity and reduced healthcare costs, with a global economic return of $4 for every $1 invested in treatment and support.

images.alt_text: A recent casual question by Elmo on X about people's well-being elicited an unexpected torrent of responses.
Workplace mental health and psychological safety
Workers sweep excess rainwater off the Formula 1 track to ensure safe race conditions. Similar efforts are needed to ensure mental health at the workplace.
Kindness is a strength, a management tool.

site_title: Apollo says private credit may reach US$40 trillion by 2030
summary: Apollo Global Management predicts the private credit market will reach $40 trillion by 2030, exceeding its current estimate of $20 trillion. The asset-based market is expected to drive growth, particularly in investment-grade debt, such as data centers and energy infrastructure. Apollo believes private credit offers attractive risk-adjusted returns, but notes that it has been overlooked due to existing asset allocation frameworks. The company aims to expand its investor base, including retail accounts, and is exploring European opportunities in commercial real estate and asset-based finance.

images.alt_text: Landlord Canary Wharf Group (CWG) has faced challenging trading since the Covid-19 pandemic, as changing working patterns have driven out key office tenants from the east London business district including HSBC.
Apollo Global Management reported adjusted net income of US$1.13 billion, amounting to US$1.85 per share
Apollo manages about US$275 billion of investment-grade credit and its high-grade capital solutions business.
atlantic ocean, sunny isles beach, florida

site_title: Philippines may open 2025 with rate cut, central banker says
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) is considering a rate cut in 2025, with governor Eli Remolona stating the central bank is "still at the same trajectory as before" on monetary easing. Inflation remains on target, and economic growth slowed, supporting the case for further rate cuts. The BSP capped off the year with a third quarter-point rate cut and is watching the peso closely to prevent inflation. A measured pace of rate cuts is expected in 2025.

images.alt_text: Dennis Uy, chairman and president of Udenna Corporation.
The Philippines is moving to invigorate its tourism sector as arrivals from China remain tepid.
Philippines' consumer price index rose 2.5 per cent in November from 2.3 per cent the previous month as a slew of typhoons last month pushed food prices higher.

site_title: Worldcoin must delete all iris scan data, watchdog says
summary: A Spanish data protection watchdog, AEPD, has ordered Worldcoin, a company aiming to create a global identity system through iris scanning, to delete all collected iris scanning data due to a breach of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation. The decision comes after a temporary ban on the iris-scanning venture was upheld by Spain's High Court in March. Worldcoin, co-founded by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, has faced privacy concerns in several countries over its data collection practices. The company must delete the data by a specified deadline.

site_title: The face of courage
summary: Gisèle Pelicot, a 72-year-old French grandmother, has become a symbol of female strength after her ex-husband and 50 other men were found guilty of rape in a high-profile trial. Her unassuming appearance, with a simple haircut and sunglasses, has been used to convey a sense of empowerment and courage. Pelicot's decision to allow her trial to be public, rather than closed, has made her a visual shorthand for a collective turning point in the #MeToo movement, transcending her unique story to represent every woman who has experienced gender-based violence.

images.alt_text: Alibaba fires employee who accused former co-worker of sexual assault
New York Governor Cuomo resigns after sexual harassment findings

site_title: GIC’s senior VP of sustainability joins board committee of climate-focused investor group
summary: Wong De Rui, senior VP of sustainability at Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, will join the board committee of the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change (AIGCC). Wong leads research on sustainability-related themes, including climate change, at GIC and will collaborate with AIGCC to manage climate risks and opportunities. He emphasized the importance of discussing and sharing best practices to tackle climate change, given its significant impact on investors and the global community. This move is seen as a significant step for AIGCC, with Wong bringing his sustainability leadership expertise to the organization.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDLHT, Cromwell E-Reit, CLI, Clas, IReit Global, Elite UK Reit
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts acquired purpose-built student accommodation Benson Yard in Liverpool for £37.3 million (S$63.9 million), marking its entry into the student accommodation business. Cromwell E-Reit is divesting two Italian office assets for €20.9 million (S$29.6 million), expected to reduce its exposure to the Italian government. Stapled securities of CDLHT closed flat before the announcement, while Cromwell E-Reit's units ended 1.3% higher.

site_title: UK car manufacturing hits 44-year low in November, industry data shows
summary: The UK car manufacturing industry experienced its lowest November output in 44 years, with 64,216 units produced, a 30.1% drop from the previous year. The sector is under pressure due to the shift to zero-emission vehicles and rising costs. Despite a global shift towards electrification, production of electric vehicles fell 45.5% to 19,165 units in November, accounting for almost a third of total output. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) is urging the government to review the 'ZEV mandate' regulation, which could lead to £6 billion in discounts and compliance costs.

site_title: Gold set for weekly drop; market awaits more US data for economic cues
summary: Gold prices are poised for a weekly drop, flat at $2,594.59 per ounce, amid the Federal Reserve's slowdown in monetary policy-easing cuts. Investors await US Personal Consumption Expenditure data for further economic cues. Despite a faster-than-expected US economy growth and low jobless claims, the Fed's cautious approach to policy easing has kept gold at its lowest point since November 18. Gold futures and other precious metals are also expected to experience weekly losses.

images.alt_text: Markets now expect the Fed to leave its benchmark overnight rate unchanged at the Jan 28 to 29 policy meeting.

site_title: Bank of Japan bids final farewell to Kuroda’s radical policy experiment
summary: The Bank of Japan released a review of former governor Haruhiko Kuroda's radical monetary policies, concluding that his stimulus did not change consumer psychology as much as planned and may have longer-lasting negative effects. The review also warned that the BOJ's unconventional easing may have had unintended consequences, such as strain on the bond market. The findings reinforce the BOJ's resolve to normalize monetary policy and eliminate the remnants of Kuroda's era of unconventional easing. The review's results may mark a symbolic shift away from Kuroda's decade-long policy experiment, which aimed to directly influence public perceptions with monetary policy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bank of Japan (BOJ) Governor Haruhiko Kuroda leaves after his last news conference as Japan's central bank chief at the BOJ headquarters in Tokyo, Japan April 7, 2023.  Toru Kawata/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Inflation has become a key economic and political topic in Japan after years of falling prices.
BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.
The headline index measuring big manufacturers’ business confidence stood at +14 in December, up from +13 hit three months ago and marking the highest reading since March 2022.
BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda and his board are set to discuss whether they need to raise the benchmark rate from 0.25 per cent next week.
With the Federal Reserve’s policy outlook also uncertain, the wide rate differentials between Japan and other economies may keep the yen weak.
Toyoaki Nakamura, who is among the most dovish members of the board, said there was a chance inflation may miss the BOJ’s 2 per cent target from fiscal 2025 onward.
Japan is no longer in any kind of potential competition to become the world’s biggest economy.
Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda suggests the central bank will avoid rushing to rate hikes as President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.

site_title: IReit Global inks lease agreement with second hospitality company in less than a month
summary: IReit Global has signed a 20-year lease agreement with hospitality operator Stayery for approximately 10,600 square meters of gross floor area at its Berlin Campus office property in Berlin. The deal, which comes less than a month after a similar agreement with Premier Inn, is expected to start operating by mid-2027 and pay an initial annual rent of around 2.7 million euros, growing to about three million euros at the end of the three-year step-up period. The lease aligns with IReit's plans to reposition Berlin Campus into a multi-let and mixed-use asset.

images.alt_text: With Stoneweg’s recent proposed acquisition of Cromwell European business, Simon Garing, the CEO of CEReit’s manager, says investors will benefit from the incoming new sponsor in providing enhanced European resources and the pivot to logistics.
Chief executive of IRThe move is part of IReit Global's efforts to diversity the tenant base and reduce the risk of Berlin Campus, its largest asset.
Parc Cugat Green, an office building in Spain, is among IReit Global's assets.
About 1,200 sq m was vacated in the Parc Cugat Green office building in Barcelona, Spain in Q2 2024.
IReit Global's gross revenue for H1 is up by 28.8 per cent year-on-year.
The redevelopment of the Berlin Campus could unlock the asset's undervalued potential, says RHB Research.
Louis d’Estienne d’Orves will be stepping down as IReit Global CEO to assume a senior role in Tikehau Capital, one of IReit’s joint sponsors.

site_title: Beijing woos AstraZeneca for investment while probe continues
summary: Beijing's mayor, Yin Yong, has called on AstraZeneca to expand its research and development investment in the Chinese capital amid a probe into some executives. Despite the probe, Yin sought greater scientific collaborations between AstraZeneca and Beijing institutions. AstraZeneca has invested heavily in China, with Chinese sales accounting for up to 20% of its global revenue. The company has faced scrutiny over data privacy and illegal drug importation, with top leaders detained, but its business ties with Beijing remain unaffected, according to a virtual meeting between CEO Pascal Soriot and Yin.

images.alt_text: AstraZeneca reported core earnings per share (EPS) of US$2.08 on total revenue of US$13.57 billion for the quarter ended Sep 30.
Artist's impression of AstraZeneca's planned facility in Singapore, which targets to be operational by 2029.
The Anglo-Swedish company has for years had one of the strongest market positions among western drugmakers in China, the world’s No 2 pharmaceuticals market behind the United States.

site_title: As TikTok runs out of options, this billionaire has a plan to save it
summary: Billionaire Frank McCourt, a real estate mogul, is exploring a plan to save TikTok by purchasing the app and relocating its users and content to a different, American-made network of servers. Despite lacking the estimated $25 billion needed to buy the app, McCourt believes he can create a better system that gives users more control over their data and followers. The US Supreme Court has agreed to review TikTok's challenge to the law that would ban the app, and McCourt hopes to garner support from lawmakers and influencers to make his bid a reality.

images.alt_text: TikTok argues that the law, the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, violates its First Amendment free speech rights.
TikTok's CEO Shou Chew is one of many tech leaders choosing to meet US President-elect Donald Trump before his inauguration next month.
The potential ban could strain US-China relations just as Donald Trump prepares to take office on Jan 20.
FILE PHOTO: A view shows the office of TikTok in Culver City, California, March 13, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts ventures into student accommodation with £37.3 million UK deal
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts has acquired a purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) in Liverpool, UK, for £37.3 million, including vacant land adjacent to the asset. The deal, funded through debt financing, increases the trust's gearing ratio to 40.2%. The existing operator, Fresh Property, will continue to manage the Benson Yard PBSA, which has an occupancy of 95% and a 5.6% net property-income yield. The acquisition aligns with the trust's revised principal investment strategy to diversify into adjacent living assets, aiming for stable long-term growth and income resilience.

images.alt_text: Macquarie initiates coverage on S-Reits, positive on industrial and suburban retail sectors.

Various stakeholders have expressed broad support for its proposed changes, says MAS.
W Singapore at Sentosa Cove is one of CDLHT's properties. Revenue per available room for its Singapore hotels was down 10.3 per cent on the year.
Average monthly visitor arrivals to Singapore in Q3 grew 14 per cent compared to Q2. Chinese visitors rose by 56 per cent, contributing to around two-thirds of the increase in arrivals.
CDL Hospitality Trusts' on Tuesday announced the acquisition of a lifestyle boutique hotel in Exeter in the south west of England.

S-Reits that have debt due to be refinanced over the next 18 months also stand to benefit sooner from rate cuts, say analysts.
The stapled group’s interest coverage ratio stands at 2.73 times, and weighted average cost of debt is 4.3 per cent, as at the end of Q1.

site_title: Saudi Global Ports, co-owned by PSA, taps banks for up to US$1 billion IPO: sources
summary: Saudi Global Ports, a state-backed port operator co-owned by PSA International, has selected Goldman Sachs Group and HSBC Holdings to arrange a planned initial public offering (IPO) in Riyadh, potentially raising up to US$1 billion. The IPO could occur as early as next year, although no final decisions have been made on timing and size. Representatives for the companies involved declined to comment. Saudi Global Ports, formed in 2012, operates container terminals in King Abdulaziz Port on Saudi Arabia's east coast.

images.alt_text: The PSA Supply Chain Hub @ Tuas will also be able to handle sensitive goods and improve Tuas Port's competitiveness.
PSA International said the acquisition will allow it to enhance existing hinterland connections from its container terminal in Poland.

site_title: Japan’s inflation accelerates on energy as Bank of Japan seeks more data
summary: Japan's inflation accelerated to 2.7% in November, exceeding a consensus estimate, driven by higher energy costs. The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) key inflation gauge strengthened, supporting the view that inflation continues to develop in line with the BOJ's outlook, and a possible interest rate hike in January or March. The weakening impact of government energy subsidies will weigh on inflation data early next year, while the weak yen and inflation a little stronger than expected contribute to the likelihood of a rate hike.

images.alt_text: BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.
Japan's exports rose 3.8 per cent year-on-year in November, more than a median market forecast for a 2.8 per cent increase and following a 3.1 per cent rise in October.
The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) dropped at a slower pace to 49.5 in December from 49.0 in November.
The headline index measuring big manufacturers’ business confidence stood at +14 in December, up from +13 hit three months ago and marking the highest reading since March 2022.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit divests 2 office assets in Italy for 20.9 million euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit has sold two Italian office properties, valued at 20.9 million euros, reducing its exposure to the Italian government as a tenant from 3.1% to 2.2%. The divestments increase the Reit's exposure to the logistics and light industrial sector to 54.5%, up from 54.1%. The sales are part of the Reit's divestment program, designed to strengthen its balance sheet and recycle capital into asset enhancement initiatives.

images.alt_text: Simon Garing, CEO of Cromwell European REIT (CEREIT) [50 Collyer Quay, #07-02, OUE Bayfront, Singapore 049321]

site_title: How businesses can survive the AI black hole
summary: Businesses can survive the impact of generative AI (GenAI) by adopting a balanced approach. A survey of 68% of business leaders found that 65% of executives anticipate a significant impact from GenAI within the next few years. Companies can either delay tactics, adopting a "circumnavigation and delay strategy" to maximize profits, or take a rapid and aggressive approach, like Tesla, which has benefited from an early mover advantage. Alternatively, companies can adopt a flexible experimentation strategy, focusing on learning and adaptability, as seen in Elon Musk's Tesla Motors, which has developed real-world AI capabilities over a decade.

images.alt_text: Big Tech has provided us with electronic wonders that put much of the world’s knowledge at our fingertips. Likewise AI is also empowering regular workers by making it easier to find and present information, in effect, providing us all with our own research assistant.
Hui Li Lee, Managing Director, Microsoft Singapore.
OpenAI has unveiled a full roll-out of Sora, its video-generation tool, as well as Canvas, a writing and coding product.

site_title: China’s economic rebound hangs on the fate of its richest cities
summary: China's economic rebound is uncertain due to the economic slowdown affecting its richest cities. The central government plans to increase the headline budget deficit by 1% of GDP to expand spending, with reported payment delays for contractors in wealthy cities like Hangzhou and Suzhou. Construction company owner Alex Zhang faces difficulties in getting paid for finished projects, with middlemen preying on those with mounting bills. The situation highlights the desperation of local governments running out of cash, with many contractors facing years of unpaid bills, leading to fears of economic instability.

images.alt_text: The new deficit plan compares with an initial target of 3 per cent of GDP for 2024, and is in line with a “more proactive” fiscal policy.

Cross-border receipts of China portfolio investment totalled US$188.9 billion while payments totalled US$234.6 billion, resulting in the biggest monthly deficit under the item, according to forex regulator data released late on Monday.
Steps will prioritise increasing household income via fiscal spending, social security, job creation, wage growth, pensions, medical subsidies, and childbirth policies.
Staff at Chinese electric truck startup Windrose work on an electric truck at a factory in Suzhou, China, Nov 18. 2024.

site_title: Singapore shares mirror regional declines; STI down 1.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.1% on Friday, December 20, mirroring regional declines. The index closed at 3,719.93, with 308 decliners outnumbering advancers 204-0. The top gainer was Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, rising 0.8%. Total shares traded on Friday were 1.2 billion, worth S$1.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open

site_title: FedEx to spin off its freight trucking business
summary: FedEx announced the spinoff of its freight trucking division, FedEx Freight, which is the largest US provider of less-than-truckload services. The move is expected to unlock up to $20 billion in shareholder value and allow FedEx to focus on its core delivery business. Shares jumped 8% in after-hours trading, adding $5 billion to FedEx's market capitalization. Analysts believe the spinoff will create value for investors and provide an opportunity to expand and improve operations. FedEx Freight's revenue fell 11% to $2.17 billion during the fiscal second quarter.

images.alt_text: Signage is seen on a FedEx location in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
FedEx Singapore's Mercedes-Benz eVito 112 fully-electric delivery van can travel up to 321 kilometres on a full charge.
FedEx is in the process of integrating its Ground and Express delivery networks as part of a wider cost-cutting drive.

site_title: New Zealand’s declining imports help narrow annual trade deficit
summary: New Zealand's trade deficit narrowed to NZ$8.2 billion in the 12 months to November, the smallest since January 2022, as imports fell to NZ$78.3 billion due to a weak economy and high interest rates. Annual imports of plant and machinery and passenger vehicles declined 5% and 24% respectively. A modest improvement in exports, driven by a surge in fruit exports, helped close the trade deficit. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut interest rates further, aiming to revive domestic demand in 2025.

images.alt_text: A bugbear for some foreigners wanting to invest in New Zealand is an inability to buy a house in the country, the consequence of a ban imposed in 2018 on outsiders.
New Zealand no longer expects the government books to record a surplus in the five-year fiscal period ending June 2029. In May, it had expected a return to surplus in the year ending June 2028.
A bugbear for some foreigners wanting to invest in New Zealand is an inability to buy a house in the country, the consequence of a ban imposed in 2018 on outsiders.

site_title: Acra to remove NRIC numbers from Bizfile portal search; government apologises for lapse
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will remove National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers from its Bizfile portal search function when it is relaunched next week. Users can still purchase reports to access full NRIC numbers. The move comes after a misunderstanding between Acra and the Ministry of Digital Development and Information led to the full NRIC numbers being displayed in search results, causing anxiety among the public. The government apologizes for the lapse and will review the incident to find ways to address privacy concerns.

images.alt_text:
CMG20241214-ChanBK03/陈斌勤/李庚洧/经营: 身份证号码争议.

Tag - NRIC, IC, MDDI, ACRA, SINGPASS, security, cybersecurity, safety
A macro generic picture of an NRIC on Dec 14, 2024.
PDPC noted that it has previously taken action against organisations which have used NRIC numbers for authentication and breached their data protection obligations.
Acra's data policy states that the statutory board is exempted from the Personal Data Protection Act.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, December 19, 2024
summary: The US Federal Reserve lowered its interest rate by a quarter point, but signaled a slower pace of future cuts amid firmer inflation. The Bank of Japan maintained its interest rate at 0.25%. Asian currencies, including the Indian rupee, fell to record lows. Several major companies, such as Alibaba and BlackBerry, are selling assets at significantly lower valuations after spending billions to acquire them.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.
Asian markets fell on Thursday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Bangkok, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta all lower at midday.
BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.
Alibaba Group Holding announced on Tuesday that it’s going to sell the Chinese department-store chain Intime to a local apparel group for US$1 billion.

site_title: Oil drops as dour economic outlook adds to oversupply concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped 0.7% to $72.88 a barrel, as central bankers signaled caution over monetary policy easing, fueling concerns about weak economic activity and oversupply. The US Federal Reserve cut rates by a quarter percentage point, while the Bank of England held interest rates steady. Softening economic activity is expected to deepen a slowdown in oil demand growth next year, with Brent futures prices down 5% this year. Analysts predict an oil surplus next year, with supply outpacing demand by 1.2 million barrels per day.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled 20 cents, or 0.27 per cent, higher at US$73.39 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: US existing-home sales rise as buyers accept high mortgage rates
summary: US existing-home sales rose to a rate of 4.15 million in November, the highest in six months, as buyers accept mortgage rates above 6%. Job creation and increasing consumer comfort with current rate levels contributed to the growth. However, annual home sales are still expected to be lower than last year, and affordability remains a challenge due to high prices and mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: The combination of mortgage rate declines, firm consumer income growth and a bullish stock market have increased homebuyer demand in recent weeks.
Homebuyers are facing mortgage rates that have climbed in seven of the past eight weeks.

site_title: Nike results beat low expectations; CEO warns turnaround will be a slog
summary: Nike's quarterly earnings beat modest expectations, with revenue falling 7.7% to $12.35 billion, but its new CEO, Elliot Hill, warned of short-term pain as the company works to revive demand for its brands. Shares surged initially but then fell after Hill and CFO Matthew Friend reined in expectations, predicting double-digit revenue decline in the third quarter. Hill vowed to refocus the business on sport and premium prices, and prioritize rebuilding retail partnerships, innovation, and limiting discounts.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians carry Nike shopping bags in San Francisco, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Foot Locker predicted adjusted earnings of US$1.50 to US$1.70 a share for this fiscal year, falling short of analysts’ expectations.
RTFKT is setting up an updated website that showcases and preserves its design work throughout its history.
Outdoor gear is a crowded area, and Nike will be up against brands such as Patagonia, the North Face and Arc’teryx.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders digest Fed’s hawkish pivot
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday as investors digested the Federal Reserve's hawkish pivot and the potential impact of Donald Trump's presidency on the economy. Tokyo, Shanghai, Manila, and Jakarta edged up, while Hong Kong, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington, and Taipei sank. The US dollar maintained its gains against peers, reaching a five-month high near 158 yen, amid concerns about inflation and interest rate cuts. The Fed's preferred gauge of inflation, US personal consumption expenditure, is set to be released later in the day, with traders awaiting its impact on the markets.

images.alt_text: Asian markets fell on Thursday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Taipei, Bangkok, Singapore, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta all lower at midday.

site_title: US: Wall St jumps at open after selloff on Fed rate cut caution
summary: US stocks rose at the open on December 19, 2024, after a day of selloff due to Federal Reserve rate cut projections and inflation concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 137.3 points, or 0.32%, to 42,464.13, while the S&P 500 rose 40.6 points, or 0.69%, to 5,912.71. The Nasdaq Composite also rose 173.0 points, or 0.89%, to 19,565.664, despite lingering concerns about interest rate cuts and inflation.

site_title: Cosy comforts at Italian bakery-restaurant Atipico
summary: Atipico, a casual Italian bakery-restaurant in Singapore, offers hearty fare and warm comfort food rather than fine dining. Chef Matteo Pertoldi's passion for baking shines through in his creations, from crusty sourdough to decadent desserts. Standout dishes include lobster pepper choux, potato paves, and monkfish pasta in intense tomato sauce. While some dishes may be overly sauced, Pertoldi's attention to detail and commitment to quality shine through. With a rating of 7, Atipico is a solid choice for those seeking comforting Italian cuisine.

images.alt_text: The muted interiors of Anto.

site_title: US economy eyes strong finish ahead of heightened policy uncertainty in 2025
summary: The US economy is expected to end 2024 on a solid note, driven by strong consumer spending and labor market resilience, despite heightened policy uncertainty in 2025. The number of Americans filing new jobless benefits fell more than expected, while the economy grew faster than previously estimated in the third quarter, with consumer spending accounting for over two-thirds of economic activity. The Federal Reserve has cut interest rates, but projects only two rate reductions in 2025, citing the economy's continued resilience and elevated inflation. Economists warn of potential challenges from the incoming Trump administration's policies.

images.alt_text: News of the Federal Reserve rate cut decision flashes across the TV screen at the New York Stock Exchange, Dec 18, 2024. The Fed signalled less rate-cutting may be on the cards in 2025 but uncertainty reigns.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell  announced that the Federal Reserve is lowering interest rates by a quarter percentage point to a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent, Washington, US, Dec 18, 2024.
Manufacturing continues to tread water in the aftermath of the US central bank's aggressive monetary policy tightening.
Strong US retail sales add to warmer inflation readings in recent months in suggesting that the Federal Reserve could pause rate cuts in January.

site_title: Losses from crypto hacks jump to US$2.2 billion in 2024: report
summary: Cryptocurrency hacking losses surged to $2.2 billion in 2024, a 21% increase from the previous year, according to a report by Chainalysis. The number of incidents rose to 303, with hackers stealing $1.8 billion in 2023. The majority of stolen crypto was due to compromises on private keys, targeting centralized platforms. Notably, crypto hacking linked to North Korea more than doubled to a record high of $1.3 billion in 2024, allowing the country to circumvent international sanctions.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin hit a record US$103,800 on Dec 5 but subsequently struggled to stay above the six-figure level.

site_title: Asia dealmakers see more IPOs, convertible bonds in 2025
summary: Asia's IPO market is expected to see more listings and convertible bonds in 2025, driven by Chinese companies seeking capital amid economic woes and regulatory crackdowns. Mainland China's IPO market has underwhelmed, while Hong Kong's market has struggled, resulting in the lowest annual volume since 2013. In contrast, convertible bonds and follow-on stock offerings have filled the void, raising a record $29 billion this year. Experts predict continued growth in Chinese IPOs in 2025, with firms like Alibaba and Ping An Insurance leading the way.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong IPOs have raised about US$9 billion this year, a significant increase from 2023’s level of US$5.6 billion – which was the lowest since 2001.
Competition for IPOs in Asia is fierce with fees generated from ECM deals accounting for almost 40 per cent of the region’s investment banking wallet versus 25 per cent globally.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat as rebound effort losses steam
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising less than 0.04% to 42,342.24. Treasury bond yields surged above 4.5%, following a Federal Reserve decision that hinted at fewer interest rate cuts in 2025. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes declined 0.1% each, despite initial gains. Analysts attributed the lackluster recovery to concerns that good news has been priced into the market, waiting to see if it materializes.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 137.3 points, or 0.32 per cent, at the open to 42,464.13.

site_title: Dreaming of a greener Christmas
summary: Singaporeans are embracing a greener Christmas with eco-friendly traditions, reducing waste and excess. Eco-advocates like Eunice Yeo and Michelle Chow promote sustainable practices such as reusable decorations, locally sourced food, and experiential gifts. Artificial Christmas trees, plant-based menus, and elegant tableware are also popular alternatives to traditional decorations and gifts. With the rise of virtual Christmas gatherings and e-gifts, families can celebrate the festive season while minimizing their carbon footprint.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 19)
summary: Non-competitive bids for Singapore government securities reached S$2.3 billion, fully allotted. The cut-off yield on Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill increased to 3.02% on Dec 19, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Amazon workers strike at seven US facilities ahead of Christmas rush
summary: Amazon workers at seven US facilities went on strike on December 19, amid the holiday shopping rush, to pressure the retailer into contract talks with their union. The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing about 10,000 workers, had given Amazon a December 15 deadline to negotiate. Amazon does not expect the strike to disrupt operations, but the Teamsters claim the company ignored the deadline and refused to negotiate. The strike is the "largest" against Amazon, and the company's shares rose 1.5% before the market opened.

images.alt_text: Prime Air drone package deliveries, first launched in December 2022, are currently operational in a couple of US locations in Texas and Arizona.
Amazon joins another tech giant, Meta Platforms, in donating to the Jan 20 Trump inauguration. Meta will also give US$1 million, a company spokesperson said.

site_title: Disappointment over Spotify’s flat year-end wrap is a warning that AI is not everything
summary: Spotify's year-end wrap, a personalized summary of users' top streamed songs, artistes, and albums, received disappointing feedback from listeners, with many criticizing the use of artificial intelligence (AI) for generating the summaries. The AI-powered features, introduced after deep job cuts in 2023, were met with criticism for being impersonal and uncreative. The lack of human touch has led to concerns that Spotify may be prioritizing AI over user engagement, potentially affecting its subscriber base.

images.alt_text: The company is showing the benefits of workforce cuts taken late last year, along with the tailwind from continued growth.
Indonesia opened in 2022 its Jakarta International Stadium that can seat 82,000 people.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 clocks worst day in more than a month after Fed’s hawkish signal
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 1.5% on Thursday, its worst day in over a month, after the US Federal Reserve signaled a slower pace of interest rate cuts next year. Investors fled riskier assets, leading to a significant market reaction, a stronger US dollar, and a sharp increase in Treasury yields. The tech index dropped 2.4%, while chip stocks fell between 3.7% and 6.2%. The Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged, while the Bank of Sweden cut its key interest rate.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.15 per cent up at 514.43 points, snapping a four-day losing streak.

site_title: Indonesian arm of Malaysia’s Mr DIY climbs on market debut
summary: The Indonesian arm of Malaysia's Mr DIY Group, Daya Intiguna Yasa, listed on the Jakarta stock exchange, despite a weak market backdrop. The company's shares opened 6% lower than the IPO price, but later rose as much as 24.8% to 1,240 rupiah, indicating a successful market debut. The move follows the company's expansion to over 900 stores in Indonesia since its first opening in 2017.

images.alt_text: Mr DIY store in Jakarta
Mr DIY’s Indonesia business operates more than 800 stores in the country.

summary: CapitaLand Investment sold 4.9% stake in CapitaLand Ascott Trust for S$162 million, reducing its holdings to 24.04%. site_title: Asia: Stocks track Wall Street down after Fed forecast, BOJ hits yen
summary: Asian markets fell on Thursday, tracking a decline in US stocks after the Federal Reserve announced a "hawkish cut" in interest rates, halving its forecast for future rate cuts. The yen weakened against the dollar after the Bank of Japan decided not to hike rates for a third time this year. Investors were also concerned about the impact of US President-elect Donald Trump's plans on inflation and the economy, with the Fed indicating that the battle against inflation was key.

images.alt_text: BOJ policymakers hope regular pay, which has risen at a year-on-year pace of 2.5 per cent to 3 per cent recently, keeps increasing and supports consumption.

site_title: Sinopec forecasts China’s petroleum consumption will peak by 2027
summary: Sinopec forecasts China's petroleum consumption to peak by 2027 at 800 million metric tons. China's crude oil output is expected to reach 215 million metric tons in 2025 and oil refining capacity will reach 960-970 million tons per annum by 2025. Natural gas consumption is forecast to reach 570 billion cubic meters by 2030 and plateau at around 620 billion cubic meters by 2035-2040. These forecasts are part of Sinopec's outlook released in Beijing.

site_title: Fed’s hawkish tilt has emerging markets scurrying to save currencies
summary: The Federal Reserve's hawkish stance has sent emerging markets scrambling to defend their currencies, with the Brazilian real hitting a lifetime low. The Brazilian central bank sold dollars via a spot auction after the real sank overnight. The move was triggered by the Fed's indication that it may not cut interest rates much next year, unnerving investors. US Treasury yields rose, causing the dollar to surge against major rivals. Other emerging markets, including Indonesia, are also facing currency pressure as investors shift funds out of riskier assets.

site_title: Thailand faces uphill battle to revive growth momentum
summary: Thailand's economic growth is expected to remain subdued in 2025, with forecasted GDP growth of around 3% due to structural issues such as high household debt, an over-reliance on traditional industries, and a rapidly ageing population. The country's public debt has risen to 65% of GDP, and inflation remains low at 0.5%. Foreign direct investment (FDI) has been a bright spot, with a record $21.7 billion in investment applications in the first nine months of 2024. To reignite economic momentum, Thailand must implement bold structural reforms and address these challenges.

images.alt_text: Thailand extends battery electric vehicles production timeframe, offers hybrid EV incentives to support auto industry amid stagnant market and economic challenges.

“From our perspective, if it can be reduced, it’s good. We want it to be in line with inflation,” says Pichai Chunhavajira.

site_title: 100 Years of Solitude: Magic fades in TV adaptation
summary: Netflix's TV adaptation of Gabriel Garcia Marquez's "100 Years of Solitude" has received mixed reviews, with critics praising its faithfulness to the source material but criticizing its inability to capture the novel's magical realism and poetic prose. The show, which features Colombian actors and was produced in Colombia, has been released in eight episodes and is reportedly worth over $70 million to the country's economy. However, many feel that the adaptation falls short of the novel's original magic, and that readers are better off experiencing the story in its original form.

images.alt_text: For the sake of the planet, consider getting artificial Christmas trees, such as those offered by Masons Home Decor.
Glenn Yong wears a washed indigo sweatshirt by Coach.

site_title: Behind a potential Honda and Nissan tie-up, the existential threat posed by Chinese EVs
summary: Honda and Nissan are in talks to deepen ties, potentially leading to a merger, amid the existential threat posed by Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers. Both Japanese automakers have lost ground in China's massive market as domestic brands like BYD outperform them with innovative software-loaded EVs and hybrids. The proposed merger aims to slash costs and pool resources, but it remains to be seen if Japan's auto industry can sufficiently compete in the EV market. The move comes as Nissan plans to cut 9,000 jobs and manufacturing capacity by 20% due to slumping sales in China and the US.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, which has been investing heavily in factories to build electric vehicles, would be interested in the entirety of Nissan Motor – not just the Japanese firm’s plants and equipment.
After five years and a series of business plans, Nissan boss Makoto Uchida hasn’t been able to reverse the decline sparked by the 2018 arrest of Nissan’s former chairman, Carlos Ghosn.
The discussions between Honda and Nissan are focused on finding ways to bolster collaboration and include the possibility of setting up a holding company.
BYD has been on an extraordinary expansion this year, growing capacity and undertaking a massive hiring spree to turbocharge revenue.
To move towards electrification, Honda will reduce the production of petrol cars.

site_title: Scoot apologises after KL-bound flight took off 1½ hours earlier than scheduled on Nov 1
summary: Budget airline Scoot apologized for a Nov 1 flight that took off 1½ hours earlier than scheduled, leaving at least one passenger behind. The Scoot flight TR456 was originally set to depart at 4.50am but departed at 3.21am due to "operational reasons." Passengers who missed the flight were rerouted on Singapore Airlines flight SQ104, which departed at 7.04am. Scoot offered compensation of S$150 to the affected passenger, who had to buy additional tickets to continue his journey.

images.alt_text: The discounts will apply to selected Scoot flights from November to October 2025, as well as SIA flights from January to September 2025.
Scoot says the flight encountered turbulence as it was approaching Guangzhou, and that the aircraft landed uneventfully at 9.10 am local time.
Scoot will fly to Kertajati twice a week from Sept 28, and to Melaka five times each week from Oct 23.

site_title: Analysts optimistic on Asian equities, bonds even as  Fed signals fewer rate cuts
summary: The US Federal Reserve has signaled a slower pace of interest rate cuts for 2025, citing a relatively stable unemployment rate and little recent improvement in inflation. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic on the long-term outlook for Asian equities and bonds, particularly in Singapore's banking and manufacturing sectors. The slower rate cuts are expected to reduce volatility in the markets, benefiting bond investors and potentially narrowing the interest rate differential between Singapore and the US, which could affect banks' profitability.

images.alt_text: BHG Retail Reit was the largest decliner in terms of percentage as at 3.50 pm, shedding 11.1 per cent or S$0.05 at S$0.40.

site_title: Amazon delays return-to-office mandate for thousands of workers due to space
summary: Amazon is delaying its return-to-office mandate for thousands of employees due to insufficient space in its offices. The delay affects employees in at least seven cities, including Austin, Dallas, and Phoenix, with some being told their return dates will be pushed back four months. The company claims the delay is due to reconfigurations of buildings, but employees say it's an effort to thin the ranks and avoid layoffs. The move is the latest twist in Amazon's return-to-office saga, which has been met with widespread discontent among employees.

site_title: Rise of the unknown watch brands
summary: Luxury watch brands, often overlooked by new generations, are making a comeback. Brands like Vulcain, Czapek, Depancel, and Gerald Charles, founded in the 19th century, are reviving their production and creating unique timepieces. Vulcain's Nautical Legacy Messina LAB and Czapek's Antarctique "Artists & Artisans – Piece N Degree 1" showcase their expertise in watchmaking. Meanwhile, Depancel's Amida Digitrend and Cyrus's Klepcys Vertical Skeleton Tourbillon Malachite highlight innovative designs. These lesser-known brands aim to attract a new audience and reestablish their presence in the luxury watch market.

site_title: LVMH buys a 50 million euro villa in Cannes for brand events
summary: LVMH, the owner of Louis Vuitton, has acquired a historic 12-bedroom villa in Cannes, France for around 50 million euros, to host exclusive brand events and showcase its luxury brands during the city's high-profile festivals. The villa, which has had several high-profile owners, will be rented out during the summer months to attract top customers and create Instagrammable marketing opportunities. This latest acquisition is part of LVMH's record-breaking 2.45 billion euros in property purchases globally in 2023.

images.alt_text: New wealth generated by Bitcoin’s recent highs comes as the luxury industry faces its biggest slump in years and searches for new sources of growth.
Plans to ship cognac in containers and bottle it in China rather than France were discussed by industry body Maisons de Cognac.
Alexandre Arnault, 32, has held a position responsible for product and communications at Tiffany since 2021, when LVMH completed its takeover of the US jewellery brand.
Bernard Arnault’s fortune has been relegated to fifth place on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says rupiah fall due to impact of Fed outlook
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, attributed the rupiah's 1.12% fall to the US Federal Reserve's perceived hawkish policy outlook. The currency had reached its lowest level since August 2, at 16,265 per dollar. Despite holding interest rates steady, the bank expressed concern over global economic uncertainty and potential inflation. Governor Perry Warjiyo warned of slowing global growth and rising tensions, citing Donald Trump's planned tariffs. Bank Indonesia vowed to stabilize the currency against excessive volatility, with Director Fitra Jusdiman stating they would monitor and take measured actions to maintain stability.

site_title: Bank of England set to skip rate cut as stagflation looms
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% in 2025, with economists predicting a cautious tone due to inflation threats and the specter of stagflation. Governor Andrew Bailey and his colleagues may signal gradual rate cuts, but a vote split is likely, with only a small chance of a surprise reduction. The BOE may also tweak its growth forecast and comment on inflation, which has risen to an eight-month high.

site_title: Singapore’s residential rents climb in November against seasonal volume decline: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's residential rents rose in November, driven by a 0.8% increase in the Outside Central Region (OCR) and 0.4% growth in public housing rents. Condo rents increased 0.2%, while volumes fell 12.3% due to the year-end festive season. The private rental market is expected to persist into 2025, with projected growth ranging from 2 to 4%. HDB rents remain more affordable, with a 4% year-to-date increase, while condominium rental prices decreased 1.3% year-on-year. Experts predict a shift from a tenants' market to a landlords' market in 2025.

Having easy access to public transport was the top factor in attracting firms to industrial parks, says NUS.

site_title: Apple in talks with Tencent, ByteDance to roll out AI features in China: sources
summary: Apple is in talks with Tencent and ByteDance to integrate AI models into iPhones sold in China, following the absence of AI capabilities in the latest iPhones in the country. The move comes as Apple's market share in China is declining. Apple has rolled out OpenAI's ChatGPT into its devices globally, but it is not available in China due to regulatory requirements. The partnership aims to address the issue and provide AI features to users in China.

images.alt_text: Meta has made 15 interoperability requests thus far, more than any other company, for potentially far-reaching access to Apple’s technology stack, the latter said in a report.
The move is part of a broader shift in how Apple approaches payment services.
The AI features will be available on the latest iPhone series, as well as the Pro and Pro Max versions of the previous iPhone 15 line-up.

site_title: New year, same old you?
summary: A new year brings the opportunity for young adults to re-evaluate their goals and progress. Counsellor and executive coach Devendra Bisaria emphasizes the importance of self-awareness, encouraging individuals to assess their goals against the SMART framework (Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, Time) and avoid comparisons with others. By acknowledging limitations and embracing setbacks, individuals can create a more fulfilling journey and set realistic goals tailored to their capabilities.

site_title: S-Reits fall despite Fed’s 25-basis-point rate cut
summary: Singapore-listed S-Reits fell despite the US Federal Reserve's 25-basis-point interest rate cut, with retail and US office Reits leading the decline. BHG Retail Reit and Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust were the largest percentage decliners, shedding 11.1% and 5.6%, respectively. The Fed signaled it would slow the pace of rate cuts, citing stable unemployment and little recent inflation improvement, projecting just two quarter-percentage-point rate reductions by the end of 2025.

site_title: China banks raise mortgage rates for the first time since 2021
summary: Chinese banks have raised mortgage rates for the first time in three years, with the average rate increasing to 3.08% in November from a record low of 3.05% in October. The rate hike was unexpected given the ongoing property slump and slowing economy, and is seen as a move to boost banks' profitability and create a buffer for further rate reductions next year. The increase is expected to hit housing demand, but may not necessarily slow the early recovery in the property market.

images.alt_text: The new deficit plan compares with an initial target of 3 per cent of GDP for 2024, and is in line with a “more proactive” fiscal policy.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield inches up to 3.02%
summary: The Singapore six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) cut-off yield rose to 3.02%, higher than the 3% offered in the previous auction. The increase was within expectations, according to analysts, but they noted that market expectations on interest rates may not be in a straight line due to changing growth and inflation outlooks. The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter point, signaling a slower pace of rate cuts, and analysts expect some downward room for short-end Singapore dollar rates, although interim upticks cannot be ruled out.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell  announced that the Federal Reserve is lowering interest rates by a quarter percentage point to a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent, Washington, US, Dec 18, 2024.

site_title: The Fed is as clueless as markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve cut interest rates by 100 basis points to 4.25-4.5% on December 18, amid uncertainty surrounding inflation projections. The median forecaster projects inflation will slow in 2025, but 15 Fed board members now say risks to forecasts are weighted to the upside. The uncertainty is partly due to President-elect Donald Trump's agenda, which could increase price levels, and the wobbly nature of inflation data. Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the need to reassess the interest rate backdrop, with some members arguing the world has changed and policy rates may be close to neutral. The Fed's best option is to slow the pace of further adjustments, leaving the door open for rate cuts or suspension.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell said the "new phase", shifting from economic support to reining in inflation.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell  announced that the Federal Reserve is lowering interest rates by a quarter percentage point to a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent, Washington, US, Dec 18, 2024.

site_title: Merck snags Chinese obesity drug in nearly US$2 billion deal
summary: Merck has acquired a potential obesity medication, HS-10535, from Chinese drugmaker Hansoh Pharmaceutical Group for up to $2 billion. The oral drug targets GLP-1 receptors, a key component of injectable weight-loss medications like Ozempic. Merck will develop, manufacture, and commercialize the drug, with potential milestone payments of $1.9 billion. The deal comes as other biotechs developing weight-loss drugs saw their shares decline due to speculation of a possible deal being off the table.

images.alt_text: Merck headquarters in Rahway, New Jersey, US, on Tuesday, April 18, 2023. Merck & Co. will buy Prometheus Biosciences Inc. for about $10.8 billion to bolster its research pipeline and strengthen its portfolio of autoimmune drugs. Photographer: Christopher Occhicone/Bloomberg
Merck now expects total sales of up to US$64.1 billion for the year, US$300 million less than the top end of the guidance the company provided three months ago.
Merck narrowed expectations for its Life Science business, aiming for annual organic sales growth in a 7-to-9 per cent range from a previously anticipated 7 to 10 per cent.

site_title: Apple halts effort to build iPhone hardware subscription service
summary: Apple has halted work on its iPhone hardware subscription service, a project aimed at making owning an iPhone similar to subscribing to an app. The service, which would have allowed customers to pay monthly fees and swap out their iPhone for a new model each year, was overseen by Apple's Apple Pay group. The project was met with regulatory concerns, including stricter rules from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, and has been disbanded with the team reassigned to other projects.

images.alt_text: The AI features will be available on the latest iPhone series, as well as the Pro and Pro Max versions of the previous iPhone 15 line-up.
Apple’s AI chip is internally code-named Baltra and is expected to be ready for mass production by 2026, the report says.
Apple is looking to reinvigorate smartwatch sales with the new features after a slow stretch.
The recent gains come despite a tepid response to the latest iPhone model and a disappointing earnings report in late October.

site_title: HKMA cuts interest rate, tracking US Fed move
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) cut its base interest rate by 25 basis points to 4.75%, tracking the US Federal Reserve's decision. This move is expected to keep interest rates in Hong Kong at relatively high levels for some time due to uncertainty about future rate cuts. HKMA chief executive Eddie Yue noted that the pace of interest rate cuts remains uncertain, influenced by US inflation, labor market data, and economic policies. The decision aims to maintain market liquidity and stability, with the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remaining steady at 7.75-7.85 per US dollar.

images.alt_text: High interest rates and a weakening economy in China have spurred fire sales on some Hong Kong properties.
The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is reviewing Hong Kong brokers, representatives of US underwriters and investors backing the Nasdaq-listed companies in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is on track for its first annual gain since 2019, rising more than 18 per cent so far this year, boosted by a sharp rally in September.
Once synonymous with Hong Kong nightlife and in particular the city’s expat community, Lan Kwai Fong’s business mix is now changing to reflect what is becoming an increasingly Chinese city.

site_title: US central bank’s ‘new phase’ suggests the party is over for Wall Street
summary: The US Federal Reserve unexpectedly shifted from a focus on economic support to inflation-fighting mode, cutting interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to a range between 4.25 and 4.5%. Chairman Jerome Powell stated that the central bank is entering a "new phase" where it will move cautiously and look for progress on inflation, signaling a more hawkish stance. The decision marks a reversal of recent rate-cut euphoria, and investors are bracing for potential volatility amid uncertainty about the incoming Trump administration's economic and trade policies.

images.alt_text: All three major indices finished firmly lower on Wednesday after the Fed projected just two interest rate cuts next year, down from four.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell  announced that the Federal Reserve is lowering interest rates by a quarter percentage point to a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent, Washington, US, Dec 18, 2024.

site_title: Wife of Malaysia’s jailed ex-PM Najib acquitted in latest graft case
summary: Malaysia's Rosmah Mansor, the 73-year-old wife of jailed former PM Najib Razak, has been acquitted of 17 charges, including money laundering and income declaration failures, due to insufficient evidence. High Court judge K Muniandy struck out the charges, citing a lack of "probity, propriety and legality". The acquittal is a significant development in the ongoing corruption case against Najib and his associates.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

Najib asked the court to compel the government to confirm the royal decree’s existence and to implement its order.

The Kuala Lumpur High Court granted their bid for a discharge not amounting to an acquittal, due to procedural delays and the failure of the prosecution to disclose key documents, their lawyers said.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps interest rates steady, hawkish board member dissents
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept interest rates steady at 0.25% on December 19, as policymakers preferred to tread cautiously amid uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's economic plans. Despite hawkish board member Naoki Tamura's dissent, proposing a 0.5% rate hike, the BOJ maintained its cautious stance. Markets await BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda's press conference for clues on future rate hikes, with many expecting a hike in January or March to counter the declining yen's impact on inflation.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son, chairman and chief executive officer of SoftBank Group Corp., speaks during the SoftBank World event in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. SoftBank World, the company’s annual event for customers and suppliers, continues through Friday. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
The au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) dropped at a slower pace to 49.5 in December from 49.0 in November.

site_title: Funding Societies raises US$25 million from sovereign wealth fund Cool Japan Fund
summary: Funding Societies, a fintech firm, has secured US$25 million from Japan's Cool Japan Fund. The investment will be used to expand the company's small and medium enterprise (SME) financing business across five markets in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to strengthen ties between the region and Japan, fostering commercial relationships between SMEs and Japanese companies. The two parties will tap into the 15,000 business establishments set up by Japanese companies in the region, supporting business expansion and demand for Japanese products.

images.alt_text: Harish Venkatesan, head of corporates and business banking, HSBC Singapore (left) and Kelvin Teo, co-founder and group CEO, Funding Societies.
Funding Societies group chief executive and co-founder Kelvin Teo says that the tie-up will help extend credit access to businesses facing cash flow management challenges.

Funding Societies group chief executive and co-founder Kelvin Teo notes that MSMEs represent 97 per cent of business establishments in Malaysia and contribute 38 per cent to the gross domestic product.

site_title: Chinese students give boost to Hong Kong commercial property
summary: Hong Kong's commercial property market is experiencing a boost from the education sector, driven by a surge in Chinese students. Colleges and universities are snapping up offices to turn them into classrooms, while investors are piling into dormitories to capitalize on the demand. The sector is emerging as a bright spot in the market, which has seen leasing and sales plummet due to weak sentiment. The education industry accounted for 12% of new office leasing by floor area in the current quarter, and is expected to continue expanding in the short run.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is reviewing Hong Kong brokers, representatives of US underwriters and investors backing the Nasdaq-listed companies in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is on track for its first annual gain since 2019, rising more than 18 per cent so far this year, boosted by a sharp rally in September.
Once synonymous with Hong Kong nightlife and in particular the city’s expat community, Lan Kwai Fong’s business mix is now changing to reflect what is becoming an increasingly Chinese city.
High interest rates and a weakening economy in China have spurred fire sales on some Hong Kong properties.

site_title: Alibaba, BlackBerry among companies selling assets for peanuts after splurging billions buying them
summary: Companies that splurged billions on acquisitions during the boom times are now selling assets at significantly lower prices. Alibaba sold Chinese department store chain Intime to a local apparel group for $1 billion, a 30% discount from its valuation in 2017. BlackBerry also divested its Cylance endpoint security unit for $160 million, a 90% discount from its 2018 purchase price. The divestments reflect a shift towards a more cautious approach to M&A, with companies focusing on shoring up their main operations and cutting losses.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, which owns a 99 per cent stake in Intime, expects to record a loss of about 9.3 billion yuan on its initial investment in Intime, it said.

site_title: PBOC offers strongest yuan support since July after US dollar gains
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) has strengthened the yuan via its daily reference rate, the largest increase since July, amid growing US dollar gains and expectations of a weaker currency to mitigate the impact of US tariffs on China's exports. The move aims to counter external impacts and defend the currency, with the offshore yuan rising 0.2% to 7.3134 per US dollar. This comes as China's economy faces a prolonged property crisis and souring consumer sentiment, with authorities considering a weaker yuan to boost growth.

images.alt_text: The People’s Bank of China (PBOC) vowed zero tolerance for bond market “misbehaviors” and held meetings with some financial institutions involved in aggressive bond trading during the current rally.
The government will promote the recovery of the property market through measures such as increasing demand and controlling the supply of land for new development.
