August saw the closing of a mega S$1.6 billion acquisition by Lendlease and Warburg Pincus, who bought a portfolio of assets comprising business parks and high-tech industrial facilities.

site_title: Oil prices ease 1% to one-week low on weak Chinese, German economic data
summary: Oil prices dropped 1% to a one-week low on Tuesday, with Brent futures falling 72 cents to $73.19 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude slipping 63 cents to $70.08 a barrel. The decline was attributed to weak economic data from Germany and China, sparking demand worries. The drop also cut the premium of Brent over WTI to a 12-week low of $3.54 a barrel.

images.alt_text: One of the report’s standout findings is that GCC-China trade growth will continue to outstrip that with the West.
Brent crude futures settled at US$73.91 a barrel on Monday, down 58 cents, or 0.8 per cent lower, after settling on Friday at their highest since Nov 22.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: Is the era of remote work over?
summary: Singaporean employers must now establish formal processes for flexible work arrangement requests, which include combinations of flexi-load, flexi-time, and flexi-place, starting from December 1, 2024. Experts discuss the cultural shift sparked by the pandemic, emphasizing the need for a balance between flexible work and office culture. The tripartite guidelines, developed by the government, unions, and employers, aim to support Singaporeans in balancing work and personal commitments, while also addressing potential concerns and penalization of employees who request flexible work arrangements.

images.alt_text: Geoff Howie and Dr Joseph Liow explain the impact of a second Donald Trump administration on inflation, stock prices and elections in Singapore.

Co-chairs of the tripartite workgroup – (from left) SNEF honorary secretary, Edwin Ng; Minister of State for Manpower, Gan Siow Huang; and NTUC assistant secretary-general and director of U SME and U Women and Family, Yeo Wan Ling – at McDonald's Ridout Tea Garden, where they launched new guidelines for flexi-work arrangements.
Well-prepared employers should have full clarity of their flexible working arrangement policies before the effective date of the new guidelines.

site_title: Large car COE price up 5.8% at S$109,000 as most premiums rise
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for Singapore's large car category rose 5.8% to S$109,000, marking the first increase after four consecutive drops. Most COE categories saw price hikes, with Category E increasing by 4.8% and Category D rising 6.4%. Only Category C, for commercial vehicles, decreased by 0.6%. The price increase is attributed to dealers' pressure to register cars before the end of the year, as well as localized fluctuations due to the government's announcement of additional COEs for 2025.

images.alt_text: Private hire cars  currently use the same Certificates of Entitlement as passenger cars and have been blamed for driving premiums up.
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did not reveal specifics on the time frame of the additional COEs, nor on individual COE categories.
The COE premium for the large-car category, B, drops 2 per cent or S$2,071 to S$103,010.
Category B, for larger and more powerful cars, has a smaller fall of 2.7 per cent.
The Certificate of Entitlement quota for the mainstream car category increased 5.6 per cent.
Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in air travel growth at 5.1 per cent per year, with South-east Asia and India heading that expansion.
Gross profit margin remained relatively stable at 25.3 per cent, compared to 25.6 per cent in the previous corresponding period.

site_title: US CEO slaying suspect charged with murder as ‘act of terrorism’
summary: US authorities have charged Luigi Mangione, 26, with murder and terrorism for shooting and killing UnitedHealthcare chief executive Brian Thompson on a Manhattan street on December 4. Mangione faces up to life in prison without parole and is being held in Pennsylvania as he fights extradition to New York. The shooting, which occurred just over a week after the US Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, sparked widespread public anger towards the US healthcare system. A terrorism charge was added due to the intended evocation of terror, according to Manhattan district attorney Alvin Bragg.

images.alt_text: Luigi Mangione is escorted by police to his arraignment at the Blair County Courthouse in Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania, Dec 9, 2024.
Luigi Mangione was being held by officers in Altoona, Pennsylvania, after being found with a weapon that police described as a “ghost gun” capable of firing 9MM rounds and equipped with a suppressor.

site_title: AI startup Databricks raises US$10b from investors including GIC; hits US$62b valuation
summary: Databricks, a leading AI startup, has secured a record-breaking $10 billion in funding, valuing the company at $62 billion. The round, led by Thrive Capital, drew investments from elite firms including GIC and Andreessen Horowitz. The funding will be used to develop new AI products and acquisitions. Databricks expects to reach a $3 billion revenue run rate by January, competing with Snowflake, a company with a market capitalization of $57 billion.

images.alt_text: The newly public feature enables users to receive “fast, timely answers” with links to relevant web sources - information that previously required using a traditional search engine, OpenAI said.

Masayoshi Son, chairman and chief executive officer of SoftBank Group Corp., speaks during the SoftBank World event in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. SoftBank World, the company’s annual event for customers and suppliers, continues through Friday. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

site_title: German business sentiment tumbles in December amid ‘chronic’ weakness
summary: Germany's business sentiment plummeted in December, with its business climate index falling to 84.7 from 85.6 in November, according to a survey of 9,000 company managers. The expectations index dropped to 84.4, despite an improvement in current conditions. The decline is attributed to geopolitical uncertainty, an industrial slump, and companies' pessimistic views on the coming months. Economists predict a second consecutive year of contraction in 2024, with further challenges expected in 2025 due to a struggling industry and tumbling consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Exports to the United States, the top destination for “made in Germany” goods”, plunged 14.2 per cent to 12.2 billion euros.

site_title: One in 5 properties in England now at risk of flooding
summary: Around 6.3 million homes and businesses in England are at risk of flooding, a 15% increase from 2018. The Environment Agency warns that one in five properties may be at risk by the middle of the century due to climate change. The agency's models incorporate new data and climate projections, showing a 43% increase in flash flood risk and 2.4 million properties at risk from rivers and the sea. Coastal erosion risk is also on the rise, with 3,500 properties expected to be affected by 2055.

images.alt_text: The drop in asking prices - which followed a 1.4 per cent fall in November - was in line with the historic average decline for the end of the year, the company said.

site_title: Allianz pull-out ‘provides clarity’ on Income’s special position
summary: German insurer Allianz has withdrawn its pre-conditional offer to acquire a 51% stake in Singapore's Income Insurance, citing concerns about the company's social mission. Industry watchers say Allianz likely misjudged Income's unique role in Singapore, highlighting the importance of preserving its social mission. The government's intervention in the proposed acquisition underscores the significance of Income's social mission, according to experts.

images.alt_text: Income Insurance and Allianz's deal discussion is ongoing despite the government veto, with both parties considering the implications of the recent ministerial statement and amendment to Insurance Act.
Income Insurance has a special place in Singaporeans' hearts. This is evident in the outcry that Allianz's offer for Income and its proposed capital reduction plan evoked.
Allianz said it has withdrawn its offer to buy at least 51 per cent in Singapore's home-grown Income Insurance

site_title: US retail sales beat expectations in November
summary: US retail sales rose 0.7% in November, beating expectations and fueling concerns the Federal Reserve may pause rate cuts in January. This follows an upwardly revised 0.5% gain in October. The increase, driven by a surge in motor vehicle purchases, suggests strong underlying momentum in the economy as the year ends. The data adds to warmer inflation readings, increasing pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Sterling edges into positive territory on Tuesday after data showed regular UK pay rose more quickly than expected in the three months to October.

site_title: One of the toughest tables to book in Paris? It’s in Disneyland
summary: Bistrot Chez Rémy, a themed restaurant in Disneyland Paris, offers classic French cuisine with a twist, inspired by Pixar's Ratatouille. The restaurant's unique setting and clever design, including giant plates and fairy lights, create an immersive experience. However, the food, while decent, was a mixed bag, with some dishes, like the cod, falling short of expectations. Despite the high price point and limited availability, the restaurant's charm and ability to delight visitors make it worth a visit for its fantasy experience, rather than just its food.

images.alt_text: The restaurant features plenty of marble and a seafood market-like display.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after retail sales data; Fed awaited
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, December 17, as investors became cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 61 points, or 0.14%, to 43,656.47, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The strong retail sales data, which showed consumers' continued resilience, was seen as a factor in the cautious mood. The Fed's interest rate decision is expected later this week, and investors are watching for any signs of changes to monetary policy.

site_title: 2025 is the year to stay bullish on Japan
summary: Japan is poised for a strong 2025, driven by sustainable inflation, strengthening wages, and ongoing reforms. The Nikkei 225 Index has returned nearly 20% this year, fueled by positive earnings reports from megabanks. The Bank of Japan's monetary tightening has boosted banking sector earnings, while wage hikes and inflation are expected to drive consumer spending. Structural reforms aim to promote capital efficiency and shareholder returns, making Japanese equities more attractive. The yen may strengthen, but corporate earnings are expected to deliver double-digit growth, driven by global competitiveness and key megatrends.

images.alt_text: The headline index measuring big manufacturers’ business confidence stood at +14 in December, up from +13 hit three months ago and marking the highest reading since March 2022.

Speaking alongside US President-elect Donald Trump (right), SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son (left) confirmed the investment company’s financial commitment, adding that Trump’s victory had “tremendously increased” his confidence in the US economy.

site_title: How ‘the mother of all bubbles’ will pop
summary: The US stock market's exceptional performance over the past six months has led to a "bubble" that could pop, according to author Ruchir Sharma. Despite Wall Street analysts' predictions of continued outperformance, the bubble is at an advanced stage, fueled by supernormal profits of big tech firms and massive government spending. However, investors may eventually demand higher interest rates or fiscal discipline, leading to a temporary downturn in economic growth and corporate profits. The US's increasing addiction to government debt is a major concern, and the bubble's end could come unexpectedly, as it has in the past with the commodities boom and China's growth bubble.

images.alt_text: America’s share of global stock markets is far greater than its 27 per cent share of the global economy.
A critical driver of US strength is corporate America’s profit edge: S&P 500 company earnings are expected to rise 9.9 per cent this year and 14.2 per cent in 2025.
FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Capitol building is pictured on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., April 23, 2024. REUTERS/Julia Nikhinson/File Photo

site_title: Middle East economic ‘pivot’ to Asia to continue in 2025
summary: The Middle East is shifting its economic focus to Asia, driven by growing trade and investment ties between the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states and Asian nations. GCC-China trade is expected to continue outpacing that with the West, with GCC-China trade surpassing GCC-West trade in 2027. Despite some risks, including oil price volatility and political instability, the Middle East pivot to Asia is forecast to continue in 2025, driven by hydrocarbons and cooperation in areas such as artificial intelligence and infrastructure. European countries, including the UK and France, are also taking notice, with renewed interest in GCC economies and potential trade agreements.

images.alt_text: The Emir of the State of Qatar Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani gestures as he visits the Palace of Westminster and addresses the house in London, Britain, Dec 3, 2024.

Britain’s Trade secretary Jonathan Reynolds (pictured) and minister for trade policy Douglas Alexander will meet their counterparts from the Gulf Cooperation Council, which comprises Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
China has stepped up its diplomatic efforts in the Middle East in recent years.
The flags of the ten Asean member states.

site_title: Canada deputy PM quits in tariff rift with Trudeau
summary: Canada's Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland has resigned from her position, citing a grave challenge facing the country due to US President-elect Donald Trump's planned 25-per cent tariffs on Canadian imports. The move marks the first open dissent against Prime Minister Justin Trudeau from within his cabinet, potentially threatening his hold on power. Freeland had disagreed with Trudeau on the best path forward for Canada, and her resignation comes just hours before she was scheduled to provide an update on the nation's finances.

images.alt_text: When Trump began slashing business taxes in 2017, Trudeau’s government responded by allowing Canadian firms to write off certain assets more quickly, including machinery and equipment.

site_title: Trump vows to pursue more defamation claims after ABC News settlement
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump vowed to pursue defamation claims against news outlets, including suing social media influencers, after ABC News agreed to pay $15 million to settle a lawsuit over comments made by anchor George Stephanopoulos. Trump claimed the network was trying to "straighten out the press" and threatened to sue other outlets, including the Des Moines Register and CBS News, over alleged defamation and election interference. However, experts warn that Trump's actions may chill news coverage, as US law has strong protections for journalists covering public figures.

images.alt_text: With four years in Trump's final term as US president and only two years of assured Congressional majorities. Trump is expected to move quickly in 2025 to change the status quo.

site_title: Iconic Beijing mall put up for sale by real estate firm Parkview: sources
summary: Parkview Group, a Hong Kong-headquartered real estate firm, is putting up for sale its iconic Beijing mall, Parkview Green, amid China's prolonged real estate slump. The 200,000 square-meter mixed-use development includes a shopping mall, hotel, office towers, and an arts hub, but is struggling with high mortgage payments and low occupancy rates. A Chinese state-owned firm is interested in purchasing the asset, and no final decision has been made. The sale comes as China's commercial real estate faces a downturn, with Beijing's city-wide vacancies jumping to 20.6% in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: New home prices in China were down 0.1 per cent month-on-month after a 0.5 per cent dip in October, the slowest pace since June last year, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data.

Cross-border receipts of China portfolio investment totalled US$188.9 billion while payments totalled US$234.6 billion, resulting in the biggest monthly deficit under the item, according to forex regulator data released late on Monday.

site_title: Climate change is stealing weeks of winter, unnerving businesses
summary: Climate change is causing winter to feel less chilly, with the Northern Hemisphere experiencing a decline in days at or below 0°C. Over the past decade, more than one-third of countries lost one week's worth of freezing days, including most European nations and over half of US states. This trend threatens ecosystems, economies, and cultural traditions, as well as impacting businesses that rely on cold weather for income. Companies are adapting by investing in snow-making machines and other technologies to mitigate the effects of warmer temperatures.

images.alt_text: Current pledges and policies are insufficient to limit warming to 1.5 or even two deg C above the pre-industrial average, according to the UN.

site_title: Cosco Shipping begins building expanded logistics hub on Jurong Island
summary: Cosco Shipping International has begun construction on the second phase of its logistics hub on Jurong Island in Singapore. The expanded facility will have approximately 2.5 hectares of land and 62,500 square meters of built-up area, nearly doubling the current capacity. The hub aims to cater to the growing demand for specialized logistics services in the petrochemical and chemical sectors. When completed, the facility will integrate higher stacking and automation technologies to optimize operations and improve cost efficiency, aligning with Singapore's green transformation goals.

images.alt_text: Net income for the world’s major container carriers almost doubled from the first three months of the year and topped the US$8.88 billion haul from the second quarter of 2023, according to a report released on Saturday by industry veteran John McCown.

The memorandum of understanding includes exploring construction and deployment of green ammonia-fuelled vessels owned either by Cosco or jointly owned by both companies to transport iron ore and other minerals, to reduce carbon emissions in the China-Australia iron ore green shipping corridor.
Cosco's FY2022 results were affected by a non-cash impairment of goodwill from its acquisition of Cogent Holdings.
The board did not propose a dividend this year, just as was the case in FY22.

site_title: Silver lining in the scrapping of Allianz’s offer for Income Insurance
summary: Allianz has withdrawn its offer to acquire a majority stake in Singapore-based insurer Income Insurance, citing the need for more time to consult with regulators and renegotiate terms. The move comes after Income's special status as a cooperative insurer with a social mission was cemented by the passage of an urgent Bill in October. The Bill requires any potential acquirer to account for how Income's capital is deployed, weighing on the company's ability to attract a new owner. Income shares are now likely to face a liquidity and exit challenge, while the company will need to focus on gaining competitiveness in its core business.

images.alt_text: Allianz reported net profit attributable to shareholders of 2.47 billion euros (S$3.5 billion) in the three months through September.

Income Insurance and Allianz's deal discussion is ongoing despite the government veto, with both parties considering the implications of the recent ministerial statement and amendment to Insurance Act.
Allianz said it has withdrawn its offer to buy at least 51 per cent in Singapore's home-grown Income Insurance

site_title: 8 question sets shareholders should ask SingPost’s board over planned sale of Australian business
summary: SingPost is selling its Australian logistics business for A$1 billion (S$856.4 million) to mitigate the decline of its Singapore postal business. The sale will yield S$312.1 million in gains for shareholders and increase net tangible assets and earnings per share. However, the business has significant debt of A$362.1 million, and SingPost plans to use some of the sale proceeds to repay borrowings. Shareholders should ask the board about the strategic review, debt management, and potential alternatives to divestment, including the possibility of delisting the company.

images.alt_text: This divestment is at an enterprise value of A$1 billion (S$870 million) as part of the outcome of a strategic review.
S&P said on Thursday it has placed Singapore Post on credit watch negative, following news about the potential sale of its Australia business.

site_title: Indian banking liquidity deficit hits highest in six months
summary: India's banking system faces its highest liquidity deficit in six months, with a 1.5 trillion rupees (S$23.8 billion) cash shortfall as of December 16, mainly due to advance tax payments by companies and likely dollar sales by the central bank to curb rupee volatility. The rupee hit a new record low of 84.9337 per dollar, and experts warn that the liquidity deficit may widen further if the RBI intervenes in the currency market.

images.alt_text: A wholesale market in Bengaluru. India is one of the world's fastest-growing economies, supported by a resilient macro backdrop.

epa11770129 Newly-appointed Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Sanjay Malhotra poses for photographs before his first media conference at the RBI head office in Mumbai, India, 11 December 2024. Malhotra on 11 December assumed office as the 26th Governor of the RBI for a three-year term.  EPA-EFE/DIVYAKANT SOLANKI

site_title: Pocket novels for an agitated age
summary: Margaret Renkl advocates for short novels, or "pocket novels," as a solution to the problem of feeling overwhelmed by news and needing to maintain mental well-being. She suggests reading during the day and shorter works, such as novellas or short novels, in the evening, citing their ability to provide immersive storytelling without requiring a long time commitment. Renkl praises the form for its concision, emotional heft, and ability to tackle complex subjects like human evil and war, making it a valuable tool for coping with a chaotic world.

images.alt_text: epa11717442 British novelist Samantha Harvey, author of the book 'Orbital,' holds her trophy and a copy of her novel after winnig the 2024 Booker Prize at the 2024 Booker Prize ceremony in London, Britain, 12 November 2024.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Hot stock: Wee Hur falls by over 8% after exit from Australian student dorm business
summary: Wee Hur's shares fell 8.4% to S$0.435 after the company announced the sale of its Australian-focused purpose-built student accommodation portfolio to Greystar for A$1.6 billion. The sale, pending shareholder consent and regulatory approvals, is expected to be completed in the first half of 2025, with Wee Hur receiving S$320 million in proceeds. The transaction involves the trustee disposing 100% of the assets, with Wee Hur retaining an indirect stake through its Australia subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Wee Hur’s purpose-built student accommodation at 124 Waymouth Street in Adelaide. An Oct 15 Australian Financial Review report said that US multifamily fund Greystar was acquiring GIC’s PBSA business for A$1.6 billion (S$1.4 billion). It said Wee Hur, which sold GIC a 49.9 per cent stake in 2022, is expected to retain a stake as GIC transfers ownership of its holding to Greystar.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 17)
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk comments on Singapore's low birth rate, stating the country is "going extinct" due to the demographic and fertility problems. This issue has been a pressing concern for Singapore's policymakers for years, highlighting the need for solutions to the low birth rate and population decline.

site_title: Restoring Milan’s Duomo, one statue at a time
summary: A project to restore the Duomo in Milan is replacing damaged statues with replicas carved from the same Candoglia marble. The statues, damaged by weather, pollution, and World War II, are being painstakingly recreated by sculptor Giovanni Calderino. One of the damaged statues, a bearded man from the 19th century, has been restored with a new marble replica. The project aims to preserve the cathedral's original Gothic architecture and maintain its historical integrity.

images.alt_text: Laurent Ulrich, the archbishop of Paris, leading prayers for the consecration of the main altar, designed by French artist and designer Guillaume Bardet which replaces the old one that was destroyed in 2019, during a mass at the Notre-Dame cathedral on Dec 8, 2024.

site_title: China capital markets outflow hits record high in November after Trump election win
summary: China's capital markets experienced a record high outflow of $45.7 billion in November, largely due to Donald Trump's US presidential election win. The outflow, which widened from $25.8 billion in October, reflects weakening investor confidence amid a sluggish stock market rally and yuan slump against the US dollar. The largest monthly deficit on record resulted from a $188.9 billion in receipts and $234.6 billion in payments, with foreign institutions cutting holdings in Chinese onshore bonds for the third consecutive month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An investor stands in front of an electronic board showing stock information at a brokerage house in Shanghai, China, August 24, 2015. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Singapore investors flock to Bali’s new green SEZ, plan to build luxury resort and school
summary: Singaporean investors are flocking to Bali's Kura Kura Bali special economic zone (SEZ), with plans to develop luxury projects including a high-end resort and an international school. The Tsao Pao Chee Group, led by Chavalit Frederick Tsao, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Bali Turtle Island Development to build a luxury resort and wellness hub. The Singapore-based private school Anglo Chinese School (ACS) is also opening a new campus in Kura Kura, with plans to welcome students in 2025. The SEZ aims to diversify Bali's economy beyond traditional tourism, with a focus on eco-luxury tourism and sustainable development.

images.alt_text: Mr DIY store in Jakarta

site_title: Australia's Qantas to pay US$76 million to former employees
summary: Qantas Airways has agreed to pay US$76.2 million to former ground workers who were sacked in 2020. The airline will establish a compensation fund to distribute the funds to the individuals, with some of the amount going to the Transport Workers Union. A separate hearing in the Federal Court will determine whether Qantas will be penalized for its actions.

site_title: Trump likely to ‘move fast and break things’ to reshape the US and the world order
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is expected to "move fast and break things" in his second term, reshaping the US economy and world order. Key changes include a reduced likelihood of global tariffs in 2025, with a focus on pressuring Mexico and Canada, and a more wide-ranging tariff policy against China. China is also expected to accelerate its domestic transformation and strengthen its financial architecture. European defense spending will increase, but may face budgetary constraints. The new administration will prioritize fiscal sustainability and reallocation of government spending, potentially disrupting industries such as healthcare and finance.

images.alt_text: Cross-border receipts of China portfolio investment totalled US$188.9 billion while payments totalled US$234.6 billion, resulting in the biggest monthly deficit under the item, according to forex regulator data released late on Monday.
Spot gold ticked up 0.1 per cent to US$2,655.07 per ounce, as of 0335 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: Over 8,000 platform workers opt for increased CPF contributions
summary: Over 8,000 platform workers born before 1995 have opted in for increased Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions, with the goal of accumulating interest and boosting savings. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has been working with NTUC to encourage early participation, with mandatory contributions for younger workers born on or after Jan 1, 1995. The scheme aims to raise CPF contributions to 20% of platform workers' wages by 2029, with a gradual increase from 10.5% in 2025.

images.alt_text: The annual cost increase of around US$368 million (S$494.3 million) with CPF contributions to platform workers excludes other costs, such as workplace injury compensation insurance
The Central Provident Fund Board says it is a key pillar of Singapore’s social security system.

site_title: Sri Lanka economy expands 5.5% as debt overhaul nears conclusion
summary: Sri Lanka's economy expanded 5.5% in the last quarter, driven by debt restructuring efforts. The country is nearing the conclusion of its $12.6 billion debt overhaul, expected to be completed this month. This move is crucial for maintaining access to International Monetary Fund (IMF) aid, which will help stabilize the economy. The government, led by President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, will continue with the IMF loan program, prioritizing stability over big economic shocks. The central bank forecasts 4.5-5% economic growth this year and "well above" 3% in 2025.

images.alt_text: A general view of the main port in Colombo, Sri Lanka June 29, 2023. REUTERS/Dinuka Liyanawatte/File Photo

site_title: India equities offer resilience and promise
summary: India's economy remains resilient, despite concerns over a slowing growth pace and muted earnings results. The country's fast-growing economy is supported by long-term structural tailwinds, making it a good time to invest in quality companies. Equity valuations appear high, but the long-term investment potential remains promising, driven by India's favorable macro backdrop.

images.alt_text: State Bank of India will not stop lending to ongoing Adani projects that are nearing completion, but will exercise caution when disbursing loans to ensure all terms and conditions are being met.

site_title: Vietnam’s sweeping administrative cuts stir investors’ anticipation, worries
summary: Vietnam's new Communist Party leader To Lam has launched a massive overhaul of state bodies, slashing five ministries, four government agencies, and five state TV channels in an effort to reduce bottlenecks and red tape. The move aims to address investor discontent over delays in project approvals and regulatory reforms. While some investors expect short-term "paralysis," others anticipate long-term benefits, including simplified procedures for businesses. The reform is still in its preliminary stages and is subject to changes before being voted in parliament in February, with thousands of state employees likely to be affected.

images.alt_text: Talks with Keppel on the direct cable are in flux and no agreement has been reached yet, two sources with direct knowledge said.

The Vietnamese government is heightening scrutiny over local operators of foreign e-commerce platforms as well as eyeing additional taxes on duty-free imported goods enabled by the de minimis threshold.

site_title: China, Trump talk up prospects for US-China collaboration
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has spoken positively about his relationship with Chinese President Xi Jinping, calling him an "amazing guy" despite strained relations due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Trump has nominated China hardliners to key diplomatic and economic roles, signaling a potentially confrontational policy towards China. China's top diplomat, Wang Yi, hopes the new US administration will work with Beijing in a mutually beneficial manner, amid concerns over trade and investment tensions.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump has long opposed the criminal process brought against him after he paid a porn star for her silence over an alleged sexual encounter, and then covered up the payments in an effort to boost his chances in 2016’s election.
The new deficit plan compares with an initial target of 3 per cent of GDP for 2024, and is in line with a “more proactive” fiscal policy.
A pawnshop next to Casino Lisboa in Macau.  The city’s six casino operators managed to renew their licences in 2022 only after they pledged to invest in other sectors.

site_title: Clar to acquire and lease back DHL’s Indiana logistics property in S$150.3 million deal
summary: Capitaland Ascendas Reit has agreed to acquire and lease back DHL's Indiana logistics property in a S$150.3 million deal, set to complete in the first quarter of 2025. The acquisition will increase the Reit's US logistics portfolio value by 35.3% and add to its 5.1 million sq ft total estimated gross floor area. DHL will lease the 979,649 sq ft property for 11 years, with options to renew for two additional five-year terms, providing a long-term income stream for the Reit.

images.alt_text: The development of SummerVille Logistics Center (above) is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2025.
Clar's portfolio rental reversions rose to 14.4 per cent in the quarter, from 11.7 per cent a quarter ago.
Net proceeds from the divestment of 21 Jalan Buroh are estimated to be S$102.9 million.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Cromwell E-Reit, SIA
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit proposed buying DHL Indianapolis Logistics Center in Indianapolis for S$150.3 million, its first US sale-and-leaseback acquisition. Cromwell European Reit refinance office loans early with a higher interest rate facility, receiving €4 million from its sponsor to offset costs. Singapore Airlines reported 8.3% higher passenger traffic year-over-year in November 2024, with 3.3 million passengers carried, a 7.5% increase from the previous year.

site_title: First UK wage growth pickup in a year dampens rate-cut bets
summary: The UK's private sector wage growth accelerated to 5.4% in the three months through October, the first increase in over a year, prompting traders to scale back bets on Bank of England interest-rate cuts. This jump, driven by a surge in private-sector wages, led to a decrease in the implied chance of rate cuts in 2025 to around 55% from 90% before the report. The news also reinforces the Bank of England's concerns about lingering labor market pressures and inflation, which is forecast to rise to 2.6% in November.

images.alt_text: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves speaks during a press conference following her statement to the House of Commons on the findings of the Treasury audit into the state of the public finances, in London, Britain July 29, 2024. Lucy North/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Why ultraprocessed foods aren’t always bad
summary: An expert committee advising on federal dietary guidelines declined to strongly position against ultraprocessed foods due to a lack of reliable science. The category of ultraprocessed foods is too broad, encompassing both unhealthy and healthy options. Research suggests that energy density, rather than processing, contributes to overeating. While some additives in ultraprocessed foods may pose health risks, others are beneficial. The focus on ultraprocessed foods has been a distraction from addressing broader nutrition issues, such as excessive fast food and sugary drinks. Experts recommend better food policies, including taxes on unhealthy foods, to promote healthier diets.

images.alt_text: Ultra-processed foods are a symbol of peak capitalism, created by companies to maximise profits with scant regard for consumer health

site_title: Will the US and China equity markets diverge further in 2025?
summary: US equities have reached new highs, while China's markets have struggled, partly due to the implications of Donald Trump's presidential victory. China's equity performance has been lacklustre, with a remarkable turnaround in September followed by a divergence with US markets in the fourth quarter. Investors are advised to be patient for a re-rating of China equities, and the performance divergence may continue into 2025, with US equity outperformance potentially broadening.

images.alt_text: Cross-border receipts of China portfolio investment totalled US$188.9 billion while payments totalled US$234.6 billion, resulting in the biggest monthly deficit under the item, according to forex regulator data released late on Monday.
US earnings growth would not look so exceptional if not for the supernormal profits of its big tech firms, and massive government spending.
Brent crude futures settled at US$73.91 a barrel on Monday, down 58 cents, or 0.8 per cent lower, after settling on Friday at their highest since Nov 22.

site_title: China plans record budget deficit of 4% of GDP in 2025: sources
summary: China's leaders have agreed to a record budget deficit of 4% of GDP in 2025, the highest on record, while maintaining an economic growth target of around 5%. The additional 1.3 trillion yuan in spending will be funded through issuing off-budget special bonds. This decision aligns with a "more proactive" fiscal policy outlined by leading officials following a recent meeting. The move is seen as a response to China's economic challenges, with leaders aiming to stimulate growth despite deflationary price wars.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese flag and a stock graph are seen in this illustration picture taken April 30, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
People walk past a lane lined with restaurants, Shanghai, China, Sept 28, 2024.

Cross-border receipts of China portfolio investment totalled US$188.9 billion while payments totalled US$234.6 billion, resulting in the biggest monthly deficit under the item, according to forex regulator data released late on Monday.

Steps will prioritise increasing household income via fiscal spending, social security, job creation, wage growth, pensions, medical subsidies, and childbirth policies.

site_title: ChatGPT search opens to all users in challenge to Google
summary: OpenAI has made its ChatGPT-powered internet search feature available to all users, escalating its challenge to Google's dominance. The feature, previously available only to paying subscribers, enables users to receive fast, timely answers with links to relevant web sources. The upgrade allows ChatGPT to provide real-time information from across the web, similar to Google and other search engines. The move aims to increase OpenAI's computing needs and costs, but its CEO, Sam Altman, aims to make the company an internet powerhouse.

images.alt_text: China is trying to strike a balance between regulating the fast-growing AI sector and promoting its development, amid global concerns about safety and ethical implications.
The AI features will be available on the latest iPhone series, as well as the Pro and Pro Max versions of the previous iPhone 15 line-up.
The broader rollout of Gemini 2.0’s enhanced Search capabilities is scheduled for early 2025, with plans to expand AI Overviews to additional countries and languages throughout the year.
The ChatGPT maker currently offers consumers a US$20-per-month subscription tier as well as a newly launched US$200 monthly option for access to its most powerful new models.

Tech companies that compete with Microsoft in renting out cloud servers, such as Google and Amazon, also want to host OpenAI’s models so that their cloud customers don’t need to access Microsoft servers to get access to the startup’s technology, the report said.
The new version of the tool will be able to churn out videos up to 20 seconds in length and offer multiple variations of those clips.

site_title: DBS forecasts strong growth for suburban retail Reits in 2025, names its top picks
summary: DBS forecasts strong growth for Singapore's suburban retail Reits in 2025, despite a temporary risk of "retail leakage" from Singapore to Johor Bahru due to the RTS opening in 2026. The bank expects suburban malls to outperform centrally located ones, with demand surpassing supply and favourable demand-supply dynamics. Top picks include Frasers Centrepoint Trust and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, with yields of 6.1% forecast for FY2025 and an attractive price-to-book ratio of 0.85 times.

images.alt_text: While the capitalisation rates used to value Paragon are skinny, the asset might fetch a frothy price due to its premium quality and scarcity value.

site_title: China extends visa-free transit stays to 10 days: Xinhua
summary: China has extended its visa-free transit policy to 10 days for eligible foreign travelers, up from the original 72-144 hours, in an effort to attract more foreign visitors. The change, announced by the official Xinhua news agency, aims to boost tourism and economic growth.

site_title: Malaysia’s Mr DIY hammers down on growth in Indonesia with S$346 million IPO
summary: Malaysia-based Mr DIY, the largest household goods retailer in Indonesia by store count, is set to debut on the Indonesian market with a S$346 million initial public offering (IPO). The company aims to raise funds to pay off debt, open new stores, and boost operational working capital. Mr DIY has been aggressively expanding in Indonesia since 2017, opening over 500 new stores in the past two years. The IPO comes as Indonesia's non-grocery retail sector is expected to grow 8% annually until 2028, driven by stable economic growth and urbanization.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Axiata and Indonesia’s Sinar Mas will become joint controlling shareholders of the enlarged entity, with each holding a 34.8% stake.

site_title: Gold prices steady ahead of Fed policy meeting
summary: Gold prices remained steady ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, with spot gold increasing 0.1% to US$2,655.07 per ounce. The market awaits the Fed's outlook for interest rates in 2025, with a 96.3% chance of a quarter-point rate cut predicted. Non-yielding gold tends to shine in low-interest environments, and the Fed's decision could influence market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent to US$2,652.07 per ounce as of 0155 GMT on Monday.

site_title: Indonesia anti-graft body searches central bank’s headquarters
summary: Indonesian anti-graft investigators raided Bank Indonesia's Jakarta headquarters on Monday, searching for alleged mishandling of a corporate social responsibility program. Bank Indonesia confirmed the search and stated it respected the investigation, saying it would cooperate with the anti-graft agency. The probe's details have not been disclosed.

site_title: Massive earthquake jolts Vanuatu, damaging buildings
summary: A magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck near Vanuatu, causing significant damage to the US Embassy in Port Vila and knocking out most of the country's internet connectivity. The quake triggered small tsunami waves and affected communication systems in the Australian High Commission and other government agencies. The US Embassy sustained considerable damage and was closed until further notice. The epicenter was approximately 18 miles off the coast of Port Vila, and tsunami waves of up to 0.8 feet above normal tidal levels were recorded on the coastline.

site_title: Judge rules against Trump bid to throw out hush money conviction
summary: A New York judge ruled against Donald Trump's bid to dismiss his conviction for covering up hush money payments to a porn star, stating that a Supreme Court decision granting presidents immunity for official acts does not apply to unofficial conduct. The ruling denies Trump's motion to dismiss the indictment and vacate the jury verdict, raising the possibility that Trump could become the first president with a felony conviction. Trump had sought to have the case moved to federal court, where he could end the case himself, and had challenged the conviction on technical grounds.

images.alt_text: TikTok's CEO Shou Chew is one of many tech leaders choosing to meet US President-elect Donald Trump before his inauguration next month.
Employees work on sewing machines at the Midnight Charm Garment lingerie factory in Guanyun county of Lianyungang, Jiangsu province, China, Nov 25, 2024.

Speaking alongside US President-elect Donald Trump (right), SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son (left) confirmed the investment company’s financial commitment, adding that Trump’s victory had “tremendously increased” his confidence in the US economy.
The transition-team plan would redirect money now flowing to building charging stations and making EVs affordable into national-defence priorities.

site_title: Alibaba to sell department store chain Intime for 7.4 billion yuan
summary: Alibaba to sell its 99% stake in department store chain Intime to a consortium for 7.4 billion yuan, marking the tech giant's shift in focus from retail to e-commerce and cloud operations. The sale comes as Intime faces challenges due to declining Chinese consumer spending post-Covid-19, resulting in a potential loss of 9.3 billion yuan for Alibaba. This sale is part of Alibaba's restructuring efforts to exit underperforming assets and focus on core businesses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Alibaba Group is lit up at its office building in Beijing, China August 9, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Indian firms raise US$16 billion from large buyers via share sales
summary: Indian companies have raised a record-breaking $16 billion through share sales to large investors in 2024, with over 300 firms raising $18 billion from public listings. The funds are being used to repay debt and meet capital expenditure. This marks one of the busiest venues globally for first-time share sales this year, with robust offerings despite a typical seasonal lull.

site_title: Oil sags on soft Chinese spending, investor pause before US Fed rate move
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday, with Brent crude futures settling at $73.91 a barrel, down 58 cents or 0.8% from their highest level since November 22. The decline was attributed to weakness in Chinese consumer spending, the world's largest oil importer, and investors' pause in buying ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. US West Texas Intermediate crude also fell to $70.71 a barrel, down 58 cents or 0.8%. The decline marked a reversal from the previous day's gains.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell 21 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to US$74.28 a barrel by 0110 GMT after settling at their highest level since Nov 22 on Friday.

site_title: SNEF calls for more financial aid, extended wage credit schemes in Budget 2025 wish list
summary: The Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) has submitted a wish list for the 2025 budget, calling for financial aid and extended wage credit schemes to ease pressures on businesses from rising costs and evolving workforce needs. SNEF recommends extending the Senior Employment Credit beyond 2025, enhancing the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, and providing subsidies for AI-related training. The federation also requests financial support for training senior workers, increased absentee payroll, and temporary flexibility in work pass approvals.

images.alt_text: Individuals, organisations and businesses are invited to weigh in on themes such as SG60: Building Our Singapore Together, providing opportunities for skills upgrading and jobs for workers, and supporting Singaporeans across different life stages.

site_title: Economists weigh in after Tesla CEO Elon Musk says Singapore is ‘going extinct’ amid low birth rate
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk comments on Singapore's low birth rate, stating the country is "going extinct" due to a shrinking workforce. The resident total fertility rate has fallen to 0.97 births per female in 2023, down 6.7% from 2022. Economists weigh in, noting that automation and foreign labor can supplement the shrinking workforce, but may not replace humans entirely. They also emphasize the need for policymakers to strike a balance between addressing population issues and maintaining quality of life.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has added about US$218 billion to his net worth since the start of 2024, more than any other member of the group.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as STI falters, mirroring regional trend
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,799.93 points, mirroring regional declines. Local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS closed down 1.3%, 0.3%, and 0.2%, respectively. The US stock market surged ahead of the expected 25-bp rate cut, with the Nasdaq reaching its 36th record close of the year. This contrasts with the Asian market downturn, influenced by disappointing China data and unsettled economic developments.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit proposes to buy DHL Indianapolis Logistics Center in Whiteland, Indianapolis for S$150.3 million

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as Fed gears up for interest rate decision
summary: Asian markets are mixed as the Federal Reserve prepares to lower interest rates for the third meeting in a row, amid uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's policies. Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, and Taipei stocks rose, while Hong Kong, Singapore, Seoul, Manila, and Jakarta shares fell. Investors are keeping an eye on Beijing's economic measures and the Fed's statement for clues about next year's outlook. Despite concerns about sticky inflation and a strong labor market, many believe the US economy will achieve a "soft landing."

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.12 per cent lower at 515.83 points on Monday, trading near two-week lows.
The Nasdaq rose 1.2 per cent to 20,173.89 on Monday, just the second time the benchmark has closed above 20,000 points.
Across the broader market, decliners outnumber advancers 275 to 194, with 890.1 million shares worth S$1.1 billion changing hands.

site_title: Macau struggles to evolve beyond gaming
summary: Macau, a Chinese casino hub, is struggling to diversify its economy despite celebrating 25 years under Beijing rule. The city's reliance on gaming revenue has led to a disparity in economic growth, with residents like fashion boutique owner Suzanne Leong feeling the pinch. Macau's six casino operators have pledged to invest in other sectors, but the process has been slow, with critics arguing that the operators prioritize easy wins. To truly diversify, Macau needs to find new economic drivers, but experts warn it will be difficult to compete with other industries.

images.alt_text: Alejandro Tengco, chairman of Philippine's state-run gaming regulator, said a new integrated resort will open in Manila later this year, while up to eight more casino projects are being planned.
Dennis Uy, chairman and president of Udenna Corporation.
NBA would host two pre-season games annually for the next five years at casino operator Sands China’s Venetian arena in Macau.
Genting Singapore's weak performance recently was due mainly to reduced wagers at the RWS casino, as well as a lower “win rate”

site_title: The most memorable wines of 2024
summary:
Eric Asimov highlights 12 memorable wines of 2024, focusing on younger, more accessible bottles. The wines include:

- Kelley Fox's Dundee Hills Dux Vineyard Chardonnay 2022
- Bow & Arrow's Willamette Valley Chenin Blanc 2021
- Domaine de Cassiopee's Hautes-Cotes de Beaune Les Cotes 2020
- Martin Texier's Brezeme 2020

- Enric Soler's Catalonia Istiu 2020
- Pheasant's Tears' Kakheti Saperavi 2019
- Val Delle Corti's Chianti Classico Riserva 2019

- Felsina's Vin Santo del Chianti Classico 2015
- Chateau Durfort-Vivens' Margaux 2001
- Corison's Napa Valley 2001

These wines showcase a range of styles and regions, from Oregon chardonnay to Italian malvasia, and from Bordeaux to Napa Valley.

images.alt_text: This year saw many excellent wine books, but these five stood out, offering something special for every wine enthusiast.

site_title: Real estate leaders sue to stop New York City’s overhaul of broker fees
summary: Real estate leaders in New York City filed a lawsuit on Dec 16 to halt a new law that shifts expensive broker fees from renters to landlords. The law, passed by the City Council, prevents renters from being forced to pay broker fees that can cost thousands of dollars. The lawsuit, filed by the Real Estate Board of New York, argues that the law is unconstitutional and will lead to higher rents. The law went into effect after Mayor Eric Adams failed to sign or veto it within 30 days.

images.alt_text: New York City's market for luxury home deals in November was the strongest its been in three years.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, December 17, 2024
summary: Bitcoin surged past $107,000 on Tuesday, driven by US President Donald Trump's promise to strategically release reserves. Meanwhile, Malaysian home improvement retailer Mr DIY raised S$346 million in an Indonesian IPO, while Wee Hur's shares plummeted over 11% after exiting its Australian student accommodation business. The Singapore Stock Exchange also fell, mirroring regional trends.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Tuesday

site_title: Australian consumers fret over the economy in December: survey
summary: Australian consumer sentiment decreased 2.0% in December, driven by concerns over the economic outlook, despite an improvement in personal finances. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute index fell to 92.8, with pessimists outnumbering optimists for the first time in a year. The economic outlook index slid 9.6% and the 5-year outlook dropped 7.9%. Mortgage concerns, high borrowing rates, and affordability issues contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission said HSBC Australia’s failings were widespread and systemic.
Australia business Photographer: Lisa Maree Williams/Bloomberg

The move piles pressure on global tech giants such as Facebook-owner Meta Platforms and Alphabet’s Google to pay publishers for content or face the risk of paying millions to continue operations in Australia.

site_title: SoftBank’s Son to pledge US$100 billion in US investments
summary: Masayoshi Son, chairman and CEO of SoftBank Group, plans to invest $100 billion in the US over four years, focusing on AI and related infrastructure, creating 100,000 jobs. The pledge includes investments in data centers, semiconductors, and energy. Son joins other tech executives, including OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, in seeking to win favor from the incoming Trump administration, which promised to boost the US economy and speed permitting for large investments.

images.alt_text: The results show SoftBank’s more cautious approach to investment is bearing some fruit.

site_title: Dollar hovers near 3-week high before Fed meeting; bitcoin tops US$106,000
summary: The US dollar hovered near a three-week high against other major currencies ahead of a week of central bank meetings, where markets expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates but signal a measured pace of easing for 2025. Bitcoin surged above $106,000 for the first time, driven by potential strategic bitcoin reserve plans from President-elect Donald Trump. The euro declined 0.1% and the yen struggled to recover following its largest weekly slide since September.

images.alt_text: The greenback rose against the yen, after reports that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) could forgo a rate hike at its meeting next week.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit manager to refinance office loans early with higher all-in interest rate facility
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has refinanced its Netherlands office loans early with a higher all-in interest rate facility. The new five-year and one-month debt facility will provide more flexibility for managing redevelopment plans, and the higher interest rate will be offset by a 4 million euro payment from Cromwell Property Group, ensuring the Reit's distributable income remains unaffected. This refinancing is part of the divestment of Cromwell Property Group's stake in the Reit and its European fund management platform to Stoneweg Global Platform.

images.alt_text: With Stoneweg’s recent proposed acquisition of Cromwell European business, Simon Garing, the CEO of CEReit’s manager, says investors will benefit from the incoming new sponsor in providing enhanced European resources and the pivot to logistics.
Simon Garing, chief executive officer of the Reit manager, noted that distributable income for Q3 was up 4.1 per cent quarter-on-quarter, reflecting the “stabilisation” of the portfolio.

site_title: Singapore’s key exports rebound in November, buoyed by electronics
summary: Singapore's key exports rebounded in November, driven by a 23.2% year-on-year surge in electronic shipments, mainly due to integrated circuits and disk media products. Non-oil domestic exports grew 3.4% year-on-year, reversing the 4.7% contraction in October. The rebound was attributed to a front-loading of exports ahead of US president-elect Donald Trump's proposed tariffs. However, economists cautioned that Singapore's electronics exports growth may peak in the months ahead due to a potential down cycle in the electronics cycle in South Korea and Taiwan.

images.alt_text: NODX performance had spent a large part of H1 in negative territory and returning to positive growth in July. Since then however, it spent the next three months in decline.

site_title: Digital bank Tyme raises US$250 million, led by Brazilian peer Nubank
summary: Digital bank Tyme has raised $250 million in a Series D funding round led by Brazilian digital bank Nubank, valuing the company at $1.5 billion. The funds will be used to expand operations in Vietnam and enter Indonesia. Tyme plans to list on the NYSE and potentially list in Singapore and South Africa, with Co-founder and CEO Coen Jonker citing a strategic partnership with Nubank as key to accelerating learning in running a digital bank in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Tencent leads US$70m round in Singapore digibank firm
Digital banks are finding out that the unbanked potential in South-east Asia is a lot harder to tap than expected.

site_title: Dyna-Mac fires CEO following review of business after close of Hanwha’s exit offer
summary: Dyna-Mac, an offshore oil-and-gas contractor, has fired its CEO and executive chairman, Lim Ah Cheng, following a review of its business after Hanwha Ocean SG's acquisition. The board of directors aimed to identify areas for improvement in the company's strategic direction and operations. Lim's termination comes after four years at the helm, during which the company turned its financial situation around. The daily business operations will continue to be overseen by directors and the management team, with discussions ongoing about Lim's remaining salary.

images.alt_text: Dyna-Mac chief executive officer (CEO) Lim Ah Cheng – better known in the industry as AC Lim.
Dyna-Mac will lose its free float on the Singapore Exchange as Hanwha Ocean SG Holdings will make a compulsory acquisition of all its shares, the offeror said on Wednesday (Nov 20).
Hanwha's offer had previously turned unconditional on Nov 5 as to acceptances.
CCCS has approved Hanwha's proposed acquisition of Dyna-Mac.
Dyna-Mac main yard in Gul Road. Hanwha Ocean SG's offer for the company remains conditional on the CCCS green-lighting the deal.

site_title: China’s factories seek to Trump-proof business by going global
summary: China's factories are expanding globally and diversifying customer bases ahead of potential US tariffs under a Trump-led administration, aiming to "Trump-proof" their businesses. Key manufacturers, including metal castings and chemical product makers, are shifting production to reduce US exposure and capitalize on growing demand in Europe and South America. Despite acknowledging the risks of trade policies, factory bosses believe selling domestically may result in thinner margins, underscoring the complexity of navigating a second trade war with the US.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon given until Saturday to appear for questioning: Yonhap
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol has been given until Saturday to appear for questioning over his failed martial law bid, or face possible arrest. He is being investigated for alleged insurrection and faces life imprisonment or the death penalty if found guilty. The Constitutional Court has begun proceedings against Yoon, with a preliminary hearing scheduled for December 27. If his impeachment is upheld, fresh elections must be held within two months. Protests against Yoon continue in Seoul, with both supporters and opponents vowing to keep up the pressure.

images.alt_text: Protesters wave light sticks with placards reading "Arrest Insurrectionist Yoon Suk Yeol!" during a rally calling for the ouster of the South Korea president in downtown Seoul on December 16, 2024. South Korea's constitutional court kicked off proceedings on December 16, over the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol, who has been suspended from office over his failed bid to impose martial law. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

The constitutional court formally began proceedings at 10 am (GMT 0100) on Monday. Yoon Suk Yeol was removed by South Korea’s parliament on Saturday over his short-lived attempt to suspend civilian rule, which plunged the country into its worst political turmoil in years.
Bank of Korea said that following the impeachment vote, the predictability of the political process is expected to improve, and financial market volatility is anticipated to decrease.
Han Duck-soo (above) was elevated to acting president in accordance with the constitution while President Yoon’s case moves to the Constitutional Court.

site_title: Trump transition team plans sweeping rollback of Biden EV, emissions policies
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's transition team proposes sweeping changes to cut off support for electric vehicles and charging stations, redirecting funds to national-defense priorities. The plan includes imposing tariffs on all battery materials globally, negotiating individual exemptions with allies, and eliminating the $7,500 tax credit for consumer EV purchases. The recommendations aim to boost US production and protect domestic industries, but may harm US EV sales and production, as well as Tesla's sales.

images.alt_text: TikTok is now on track to be banned in the US the day before Trump takes office.
US President-elect Donald Trump said that Daylight Saving Time is inconvenient and very costly to the nation.

Amazon joins another tech giant, Meta Platforms, in donating to the Jan 20 Trump inauguration. Meta will also give US$1 million, a company spokesperson said.

site_title: SIA Group’s passenger traffic up 8.3% in November
summary: SIA Group's passenger traffic increased 8.3% in November, reaching 12.9 billion, with a 9.3% rise in passenger capacity to 14.9 billion. The group carried 3.3 million passengers, a 7.5% increase, with both SIA and Scoot contributing to the growth. Cargo load rose 10.3% year-over-year, but the cargo load factor decreased to 56.6%. Shares of SIA declined 0.2% following the update.

images.alt_text: Singapore is an important international market for China Eastern Airlines.
At the end of October 2024, the group’s passenger network covered 127 destinations in 36 countries and territories.

site_title: Microsoft makes push for AI adoption in Singapore in areas from firefighting to healthcare
summary: Microsoft is expanding its AI adoption in Singapore, partnering with organizations such as SingHealth and the Singapore Civil Defence Force to develop industry-specific solutions. The AI Pinnacle Programme aims to drive adoption in areas like healthcare, firefighting, and engineering. A generative AI tool called Note Buddy is being used by SingHealth staff to streamline administrative tasks, allowing doctors to focus more on patients. The program has received positive feedback and is being rolled out in phases, with Microsoft collaborating with existing IT vendors and consultancies to support its clients.

images.alt_text: Microsoft has moved fast in pushing generative AI technology to everyday users, largely using the models from its US$13 billion partnership with OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT.
Lee Hui Li of Microsoft uses her unique perspective to ascend the leadership ladder in the tech world – which, as it stands, is still dominated by men.

site_title: New Zealand expects to post budget deficits over five-year forecast period
summary: New Zealand's government no longer expects a return to surplus within its five-year forecast period, citing rising unemployment, slower economic growth, and a weaker balance sheet. The country now forecasts a budget deficit of NZ$17.31 billion for 2025, up from a previous deficit of NZ$13.37 billion. The government, led by Prime Minister Christopher Luxon, has introduced austerity measures, including cuts to public servant numbers and reduced budgets, to address the deficit. Net debt is expected to peak at 46.5% of GDP in 2027, two years later than previously forecast.

images.alt_text: A bugbear for some foreigners wanting to invest in New Zealand is an inability to buy a house in the country, the consequence of a ban imposed in 2018 on outsiders.
New Zealand is the world’s biggest dairy exporter and shipments of meat, wool, forest products, kiwifruit and seafood are also key drivers of economic growth.

site_title: TikTok asks Supreme Court to temporarily block looming US ban
summary: TikTok has asked the US Supreme Court to temporarily block a law requiring its Chinese owner ByteDance to sell or shut down the platform by January 19. The law, signed by President Joe Biden, aims to block TikTok from US app stores and web hosting services unless divested. TikTok seeks to halt the law while it challenges a lower court ruling that upheld the law, potentially with an appeal to the Supreme Court itself.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the office of TikTok in Culver City, California, March 13, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
TikTok is now on track to be banned in the US the day before Trump takes office.
Under the law, TikTok will be banned unless ByteDance divests it by Jan 19.
The US Justice Department said the court should not delay the law’s effective date arguing “continued Chinese control of the TikTok application poses a continuing threat to national security.”

site_title: Trump touts US$100 billion SoftBank investment, vowing 100,000 jobs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced a $100 billion investment by Japan's SoftBank Group, promising 100,000 new jobs. SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son expressed confidence in the US economy following Trump's victory, citing the investment as a demonstration of faith in America's future. The deal is set to focus on artificial intelligence, emerging technologies, and other industries, with Trump stating it will help create jobs and drive growth in the US.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son, chairman and chief executive officer of SoftBank Group Corp., speaks during the SoftBank World event in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Oct. 3, 2024. SoftBank World, the company’s annual event for customers and suppliers, continues through Friday. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
The results show SoftBank’s more cautious approach to investment is bearing some fruit.
A drop of around 10 per cent in the value of the US dollar versus the yen over the period is expected to boost SoftBank’s bottom line.

site_title: Australia’s prudential regulator finds gaps in super fund valuation, liquidity practices
summary: Australia's prudential regulator, APRA, found gaps in super fund valuation and liquidity practices. Despite improved trustee capability, a proportion of trustees still showed material weaknesses in areas such as board oversight, conflict of interest management, and fair value reporting. APRA urged immediate remediation to meet Prudential Standard SPS 530, which requires licensees to establish measurable investment objectives and conduct thorough due diligence. The regulator warned it will take further action to enforce compliance, including the responsibilities of accountable persons under the upcoming Financial Accountability Regime.

site_title: Shein weighs sale of less than 10% of company in London IPO: sources
summary: Shein, a Singapore-headquartered fast fashion retailer, is considering asking UK regulators to waive the 10% listing rule for its planned London IPO. The company is exploring this option to facilitate its listing, which would be the first of its kind in London. Shein was valued at US$66 billion in a fundraising round last year and is expected to raise US$6.6 billion if it lists at 10%. The company is waiting for China's securities regulator to approve its plans, and its revenues are expected to hit US$50 billion this year.

images.alt_text: The Vietnamese government is heightening scrutiny over local operators of foreign e-commerce platforms as well as eyeing additional taxes on duty-free imported goods enabled by the de minimis threshold.

Primark produces its garments in Asia and sells them cheaply in Europe, but ships them by boat rather than by plane, does not sell online, prepares its collections more than a year in advance and does not build up stock.
FILE PHOTO: Shein logo is seen inside the company's first pop-up store in Johannesburg, South Africa, August 2, 2024. REUTERS/Sisipho Skweyiya/File Photo
Fast-fashion retailer Shein has been selling into Vietnam for at least two years.

site_title: French central bank cuts 2025 growth forecast to 0.9%
summary: The Banque de France reduced its 2025 growth forecast to 0.9% due to increased uncertainty in the economic outlook. The central bank also lowered its forecast for 2026 to 1.3% and expects the same figure for 2027. This move follows Moody's downgrade of France's credit rating two days prior, citing months of political crisis and a budget standoff that led to a change of prime minister.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.12 per cent lower at 515.83 points on Monday, trading near two-week lows.
France new Prime Minister Francois Barnier had promised to bring the deficit down with tax rises for the wealthy and for big companies, as well as a curbs on the planned rise in pension payments.

Francois Bayrou (above) is the sixth prime minister of President Macron’s mandate after last week’s toppling of Barnier, who became France’s shortest-serving prime minister and lasted only three months.

site_title: TikTok’s true value
summary: TikTok's US parent company ByteDance faces a looming deadline to divest or ban the app due to national security concerns. Despite a record US$16 billion in revenue last year, potential buyers are hesitant to pay the estimated US$100 billion valuation, with some suggesting the app's worth is around US$30-40 billion. The Chinese government opposes any forced sale, and ByteDance may be willing to walk away from its 170 million US users and growth to maintain control. The outcome will reveal the true value of TikTok to Beijing and provide insight into competing motivations.

images.alt_text: Under the law, TikTok will be banned unless ByteDance divests it by Jan 19.
FILE PHOTO: Tik Tok logos are seen on smartphones in front of a displayed ByteDance logo in this illustration taken November 27, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: TikTok CEO Chew meets Trump at Mar-a-Lago ahead of US ban
summary: TikTok CEO Shou Chew met with US President-elect Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago on December 16, ahead of the app's expected ban in the US due to national security concerns. The meeting came after Trump suggested he would try to reverse the ban, citing a "warm spot" for TikTok. The ban is set for January 19 and is required under a law signed by President Joe Biden unless ByteDance agrees to sell the app to an American owner. Chew is one of several tech leaders meeting with Trump before his inauguration.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges higher at the open as investors await Fed
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 rising 12.7 points to 6063.79 and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 89.4 points to 20016.121, as investors await the anticipated Federal Reserve interest rate cut later in the week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average remained little changed at 43,825.76, after falling 2.3 points at the open.

site_title: Indonesia’s largest party expels Jokowi after he backed Prabowo
summary: Indonesia's largest party, PDI-P, has officially expelled former President Joko Widodo after he backed Prabowo Subianto's successful campaign in the February elections. The party, which supported Jokowi in two presidential campaigns, cited his alleged interference in a Constitutional Court ruling as the reason for the expulsion. Jokowi's eldest son and son-in-law were also dismissed. Analysts predict Jokowi may form his own party or join another group to build his family's support base and preserve his legacy.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps 1.2% to finish at fresh record
summary: The Nasdaq index surged 1.2% to a fresh record of 20,173.89 on Monday, driven by gains from tech companies such as Broadcom and Alphabet. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.3% and the S&P 500 advanced 0.4%. Analysts cited SoftBank's $100 billion investment in the US as supportive of tech shares, while others noted that the market may take a breather due to upcoming economic data releases.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.3 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 43825.76.

site_title: Eight CPF-related changes to take place in 2025
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board is implementing eight changes in 2025 to ensure the CPF system remains relevant and helps members build up savings for retirement, housing, and healthcare. Key changes include the closure of Special Accounts for members aged 55 and above, a higher Enhanced Retirement Sum, and increased quarterly Silver Support Scheme payments. The CPF monthly salary ceiling will also be raised to S$7,400, and contribution rates for senior workers will increase. Additionally, CPF contributions from platform workers will be mandatory, and the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme qualifying income cap will be raised to S$3,000.

The interest rate for the Central Provident Fund’s Special, MediSave and Retirement accounts will decrease to four per cent per annum, said the CPF, Housing and Development Board (HDB), and Ministry of Health on Wednesday (Dec 11).
Special, Medisave and Retirement accounts interest rate for Q4 is higher than the comparable rate for Q2.
Platform workers will become a distinct class of workers, alongside employees and self-employed persons.
The average CPF member age 60 to 65 had a balance of S$194,296. Women who generally earn less have less saved up.
CPF members earned a record S$21 billion in interest last year, 6 per cent higher than the year before.

site_title: Indonesia posts unexpectedly large US$4.4 billion trade surplus, boosted by strong exports and weak imports
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$4.4 billion in November, exceeding analyst forecasts, driven by a 9.1% year-on-year increase in exports to US$24 billion. Weak imports of US$19.6 billion, stagnant since March, also contributed to the surplus. The central bank is set to review this data in its monetary policy meeting, with analysts predicting no rate cuts due to concerns about exchange rate stability and weakening domestic demand.

images.alt_text: Airlangga Hartarto, Indonesia’s coordinating minister for economic affairs, says: “The VAT rate will increase to 12 per cent as scheduled, while maintaining the principle of fairness."

site_title: Asia-Pacific aviation growth to slow, profits squeezed on easing demand and supply chain issues
summary: Asia-Pacific aviation growth is expected to slow in 2025, with profits squeezed due to easing demand and supply chain issues. Despite this, the region, particularly South-east Asia and India, will continue to lead the world in air travel. The International Air Transport Association predicts a bumper year for air travel, with passenger numbers exceeding 5 billion and total industry revenues exceeding US$1 trillion. However, growth will slow to 9.1% in 2025, with demand easing from post-pandemic highs and airline profits expected to normalize. Supply chain issues, including delayed aircraft deliveries and maintenance, will also raise costs for airlines.

images.alt_text: Pixgeneric / Generic photo of travelers at the departure area in Changi Airport terminal 1 on June 24, 2024.

Singapore is an important international market for China Eastern Airlines.
Hong Kong has a lot riding on the project in its quest to stay abreast of Singapore as a key regional hub.

site_title: TransportBT: Aviation’s supply chain turbulence
summary: Aviation's supply chain is facing unprecedented challenges, with inefficiencies plaguing the industry. The Association of Asia Pacific Airlines' 69th Assembly in Brunei highlighted the issue, with a panel discussion criticizing supply chain woes. Experts emphasized the need for improvement to ensure the future of air travel. The discussion focused on the complexities of sourcing and logistics, highlighting the sector's vulnerability to disruptions. Supply chain inefficiencies are a major barrier to the aviation industry's growth and sustainability.

site_title: Perpetual-KKR deal not best for shareholders after tax bill surge, says board expert
summary: Perpetual, an Australian asset manager, is at risk of failing its deal to sell its wealth management and corporate trust business to KKR due to a tax bill blowout, higher liabilities, and lower shareholder returns. The estimated cash proceeds from the deal have reduced, from A$8.38 to A$9.82 per share to A$5.74 to A$6.42 per share. An independent expert has stated that the deal is not in the best interest of investors, citing unfavorable terms. Perpetual and KKR continue constructive engagement regarding the deal.
