site_title: Europe: Luxury and energy sectors weaken shares; French stocks fall 0.7%
summary: European stocks closed 0.12% lower on Monday, near two-week lows, due to weakness in luxury and energy sectors. Luxury firms, such as LVMH, fell over 1% after China's retail sales growth slowed. Energy shares dropped 1% due to lower crude oil prices. France's CAC 40 lost 0.7% after Moody's downgraded its rating to "Aa3". Germany's DAX closed 0.5% lower after parliament accepted Chancellor Olaf Scholz's invitation to withdraw confidence.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq rose 1.2 per cent to 20,173.89 on Monday, just the second time the benchmark has closed above 20,000 points.

site_title: Vincar to distribute Proton’s first electric vehicle in Singapore
summary: Proton has appointed car dealer Vincar to distribute its first electric vehicle, the Proton e.MAS 7, in Singapore, set to launch early next year. Vincar will establish a flagship showroom in Singapore's Leng Kee automotive belt and oversee after-sales services. The move aims to boost electric vehicle and hybrid-electric vehicle use in Singapore and gain a foothold in the global supply chain. The Proton e.MAS 7 was previously launched in Malaysia, where Proton is majority-owned by DRB-Hicom and 49.9% stake is held by Zhejiang Geely.

site_title: Wee Hur exits student accommodation business for A$1.6 billion
summary: Singaporean property company Wee Hur is selling its Australian-focused purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) portfolio to global real estate investor Greystar for A$1.6 billion (S$1.4 billion). The sale, which includes seven assets, will net Wee Hur about S$320 million. The transaction marks the company's successful exit from the PBSA sector, with Wee Hur retaining a 13% indirect stake in Greystar through its Australian subsidiary. The sale is expected to be completed in the first half of 2025.

images.alt_text: Goh Wee Ping (left, with his father Goh Yeow Lian) sees Wee Hur Holdings' diversification into fund management as a natural progression as it climbs the value chain.

site_title: US factory activity slumps further in December as tariffs loom
summary: US factory activity declined to 46 in December, the lowest level since May 2020, due to worries over higher tariffs that may raise prices of imported raw materials. The manufacturing PMI dropped to 48.3, below 50, indicating contraction. Despite concerns, the services sector flash PMI reached a 38-month high of 58.5, boosted by the election outcome. Businesses anticipate fewer regulations and tax cuts from the incoming Trump administration, but tariffs and potential inflation concerns weigh on the manufacturing sector.

images.alt_text: Fed chair Jerome Powell is likely to signal a pause in rate cuts.
The transition-team plan would redirect money now flowing to building charging stations and making EVs affordable into national-defence priorities.
The steps are the latest as US President Joe Biden races to tie off key files before a transfer of power that could reverse many of them.

The annual increase in inflation has slowed considerably from a peak of 9.1 per cent in June 2022.

site_title: The original rogue trader’s comment: Compliance is still an afterthought
summary: A rogue trader at Macquarie Group was able to book 426 fictitious trades to hide losses, costing the bank around $58 million, and was fined $13 million by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA). The incident highlights the need for improved compliance and risk management, despite the bank's significant resources and technology. The case echoes Nick Leeson's own rogue trading scandal at Barings 30 years ago, where he lost $1 billion in losses under the noses of management and compliance teams. The FCA's handling of the case has been criticized, with some accusing the regulator of being "incompetent at best, dishonest at worst."

site_title: Grab’s big quarter has some analysts seeing further stock gains
summary: Grab Holdings is expected to swing back to a US$6.5 million operating profit in the current quarter, according to analysts, as the ride-hailing and delivery firm benefits from scale and fends off competition. The company's stock price has surged 35% this quarter, with some analysts raising their price targets to US$8, implying a 56% upside. Grab's dominance in South-east Asia's ride-hailing and online food delivery sales has helped it ward off rival GoTo Group, and its scale advantage is expected to drive significant profitability in the long run.

images.alt_text: The profit is due to improvements in group-adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation.

site_title: Economic competitiveness challenges cut through EU domestic agenda
summary: EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's 100-day planning will be influenced by global competitiveness challenges. The EU has agreed to a trade deal with Mercosur, but its ratification is uncertain due to France's opposition. Von der Leyen aims to address economic and environmental issues through the Clean Industrial Deal, agriculture strategy, and expanded access to supercomputing resources for AI startups, with a focus on restoring the EU's economic vitality and industrial resurgence.

images.alt_text: European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen urgently needs to pursue a robust foreign policy that preserves and protects EU interests, says the writer.
With a political hill still to climb over a competitiveness deal, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is trying to build momentum by working with governments.

A worker standing at a construction site in Vienna. There is no denying that lists of the top global technology companies, the world’s top universities, or semiconductor manufacturing capacity, tend to show Europe falling behind.

site_title: With Assad gone, Syrian pound starts to recover
summary: The Syrian pound has begun to recover against the dollar after President Bashar al-Assad's ouster, with the exchange rate now ranging from 10,000 to 12,000 pounds to the dollar, compared to a record low of 30,000 pounds in December. The recovery is attributed to the influx of foreign currencies from rebel-held zones and the presence of foreign journalists and organizations. For the first time in years, the black market rate and official rate are now equal, as the absence of exchange offices has eliminated the need for fixed rates.

images.alt_text: Collapse of Syrian pound deals blow to struggling shops

site_title:
Young Founders Summit provides mentorship, 
resources to budding entrepreneurs
summary: The Young Founders Summit (YFS) Global, a six-month startup incubator program for budding entrepreneurs aged 15-20, kicked off in Singapore. About 80 participants from 10 countries attended a five-day in-person boot camp, followed by virtual mentorship and Demo Day in June next year, where they will pitch their startup ideas for potential funding. The program aims to empower youths to create innovative solutions to real-world problems, with a focus on customer-centricity and user validation.

images.alt_text: From left: Dr Daniel Lim, director at the Ministry of Trade and Industry; Ravi Menon, board chairman of ImpactSG; President Tharman Shanmugaratnam, who launched the initiative; Edmund Twohill, executive director and co-founder of ImpactSG; and Kwee Ker Fong, principal at Kwee Investment Office and co-founder of ImpactSG.

site_title: Scientists struggle to explain record surge in global heat
summary: Scientists struggle to explain the record surge in global heat over the past two years, with repeated temperature record shatters testing best-available predictions. Factors such as changes in cloud patterns, airborne pollution, and Earth's ability to store carbon are being considered, but a clearer picture is yet to emerge. The causes of this exceptional heat surge are still debated, with experts generally agreeing that burning fossil fuels has driven long-term global warming.

images.alt_text: Current pledges and policies are insufficient to limit warming to 1.5 or even two deg C above the pre-industrial average, according to the UN.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar appoints Thaksin as his adviser on Asean
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has appointed Thaksin Shinawatra, Thailand's billionaire and former premier, as his personal adviser for the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean) chairmanship next year. Thaksin, 75, will hold an informal role alongside advisers from several member states. Despite being barred from office due to corruption charges, Thaksin's influence is expected to shape the current Thai government, with his daughter, Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, a key player in the administration.

images.alt_text: Former Thailand Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra arrives at the Criminal court for a lese majeste case, also known as a royal insult case in Bangkok, Thailand, August 19, 2024. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: ECB's Lagarde flags more rate cuts if inflation continues to ease
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde signaled further interest rate cuts if inflation continues to ease towards the 2% target, citing weak economic growth and moderating price pressures. Lagarde stated that keeping rates "sufficiently restrictive" is no longer warranted, hinting at a potential move to the neutral level between 1.75% and 2.5%. Investors expect more rate cuts, with a greater than 50% chance of a move before the end of the year, potentially taking the key rate to the neutral range.

images.alt_text: View of the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building on December 11, 2024 one day before the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: China to deepen economic ties with Asean, focusing on high-growth sectors
summary: China is deepening its economic ties with ASEAN, focusing on high-growth sectors such as electric vehicles, semiconductors, and renewable energy. Amid US-China trade tensions, Chinese investments in ASEAN have surged, with total FDI reaching $17.6 billion in 2023. Key sectors expected to attract Chinese investors include EVs, semiconductors, and clean energy, with countries like Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia emerging as major hubs. The Asean-China free trade area is set to be upgraded in 2025, further enhancing cooperation in the digital economy and green economy.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump waves after arriving at Noi Bai airport for the US-DPRK summit in Hanoi on February 26, 2019.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.

site_title: Powell’s Fed appears headed for another collision with Trump
summary: The US Federal Reserve is bracing for another potential clash with the incoming Trump administration, with interest rates higher than they were during Trump's first term. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has expressed caution in cutting rates, citing strong economic growth and resilient labor markets, which could delay rate reductions. Trump's promised policies, including interest rate cuts and tariffs, may further stoke inflation and make it harder for the Fed to lower rates. Despite President Joe Biden reappointing Powell, Trump may try to replace him or make his job more difficult through public criticism, potentially eroding the Fed's favorability among voters and lawmakers.

site_title: Lamborghini delays first EV launch to 2029 as market not ready
summary: Lamborghini has delayed its first electric vehicle (EV) launch to 2029 due to a market not yet ripe for full electrification. The company's CEO, Stephan Winkelmann, cited a review of the European Union's ban on new internal combustion engine cars from 2035 as a factor in the delay. Lamborghini will continue to produce cars in Italy and has a hybrid three-model line-up, with the new Urus SE SUV, Revuelto sports car, and Temerario sports car. The company is not in a hurry to push for electrification and is instead waiting for a clearer regulatory outlook.

site_title: From 3G Sunset to 6G Dawn
summary: Singapore is redefining digital connectivity with its 6G strategy, aiming to position the nation as a global leader in next-generation technologies. The country's Digital Connectivity Blueprint focuses on enhancing international connectivity, establishing ultra-high domestic speeds, and supporting Low Earth Orbit satellite services. 6G has the potential to facilitate predictive, AI-driven healthcare models, autonomous transportation systems, and hyper-responsive manufacturing processes, transforming industries and urban living. However, its implementation requires careful management, including frequency allocation, energy efficiency, and regulatory compliance. Singapore's phased approach can serve as a model for balancing infrastructure needs with sustainability goals.

summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is proposing to sell a warehouse and office building in Singapore for S$12.3 million, a 35.2% premium over its latest valuation of S$9.1 million. The sale is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2025/2026 and is not expected to impact the trust's net asset value and net property income for the fiscal year. The divestment is part of the trust's efforts to rejuvenate its portfolio through selective asset divestments.

Ng, 59, is the brother of National Trades Union Congress secretary-general Ng Chee Meng. A former Air Force chief and civil servant, Ng has served in various roles, including permanent secretary at the Prime Ministers' Office and Ministry of Defence. He has opted to participate in an environmental, social, and governance programme for directors of listed companies.

site_title: Ahead of Fed’s final meeting of 2024, all eyes on the gifts that Powell might dole out
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates for a third consecutive meeting, with a 25-basis point reduction to a range of 4.25-4.5%, signaling a pause in rate cuts. Fed Chair Jerome Powell is likely to reinforce this stance, citing elevated inflation risks amid a recent uptick in staple prices and incoming US President Donald Trump's policy plans, which economists believe could be inflationary. The rate cut is seen as a response to inflation rising to 2.7% in November, the highest in 18 months, and Trump's plans for tax cuts, tariffs, and fiscal spending.

site_title: India’s economic activity expands in December, flash PMIs show
summary: India's economic activity expanded in December, according to a flash survey by HSBC Holdings, driven by improvements in demand for goods and services. The services purchasing managers' index rose to 60.8 from 58.4 in November, while the manufacturing purchasing managers' index improved to 57.4 in December from 56.5. The composite index reached 60.7, the highest since August, boosting business confidence and suggesting a pick-up in growth momentum. This marks the slowest pace of expansion in almost two years.

site_title: Beneficiaries take to the runway at APSN fashion fundraiser
summary: APSN's Charity Fashion Gala raised funds for its sheltered workshop, supporting vocational training, job coaching, and employment services for individuals with mild intellectual disabilities. Twenty-six beneficiaries walked the catwalk wearing upcycled outfits created by fashion-design students. The event, part of a larger fundraising campaign, has raised S$350,000, with proceeds going towards the APSN Centre for Adults' operations, including job coaching and pro bono employment support services.

site_title: Xi says ‘inevitable’ for ruling party to have internal conflicts
summary: China President Xi Jinping stated that internal divisions within the ruling Communist Party are inevitable, citing changes in the external environment and party membership as factors. He called for greater efforts to instill discipline and eliminate negative influences to ensure the party's vitality. This comes as part of his ongoing anti-corruption campaign, which has rooted out unscrupulous officials and eliminated political rivals since taking office in 2012. The remarks were made at an anti-graft meeting in January and were recently disclosed in the Communist Party journal Qiushi.

site_title:
China nibbles at dollar dominance and 
US’ control over global money flows
summary: China is challenging the US dollar's dominance in international currency usage, with the yuan accounting for 6% of global transactions, up from 2% in 2010. President-elect Donald Trump has threatened 100% tariffs on Brics countries if they create a new currency. China's Shanghai regulator is considering policy responses to stablecoins and cryptocurrencies. The yuan's growing influence is driven by China's Belt and Road Initiative and the increasing use of digital currencies. The shift could lead to a multipolar world order, altering global money flows and trade dynamics.

images.alt_text: The central bank also bought a net 200 billion yuan of sovereign bonds from dealers in November to ensure plentiful cash supply.

site_title: Decline in eurozone business activity eases in December, PMI shows
summary: The eurozone's business activity declined in December, but eased from November's contraction, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 49.5 from 48.3. The services sector bounced back to growth, while the manufacturing sector remained in contraction. Demand for goods decreased, with new orders and output indices falling to 43.0 and 44.5, respectively. Despite this, overall optimism improved with the future outlook index rising to a four-month high of 57.8.

images.alt_text: Eurozone household expenditure increased 0.7 per cent from the previous three months, while investments advanced by 2 per cent.

site_title: China to boost direct fiscal support to consumers
summary: China plans to boost direct fiscal support to consumers in 2025 by increasing funds from ultra-long special bonds to support industrial upgrades and consumer goods trade-in schemes. The government aims to promote stable growth in household income through increased fiscal spending on consumption, social security, job creation, and other policies. This comes as China seeks to spur growth despite weakness in the property sector, with policymakers considering expanding the trade-in scheme to include more products. The move is expected to support China's GDP growth, which is forecast to be around 5% this year.

images.alt_text: Staff at Chinese electric truck startup Windrose work on an electric truck at a factory in Suzhou, China, Nov 18. 2024.

New home prices in China were down 0.1 per cent month-on-month after a 0.5 per cent dip in October, the slowest pace since June last year, according to Reuters calculations based on National Bureau of Statistics data.
Sale signs adorn residential buildings under construction in Huizhou, Guangdong province, China, Oct 10, 2024.
China's policy push to develop manufacturing and high-tech goods led to increased production, but demand for the goods has been weak, forcing businesses to mark down prices.
The world’s second-largest economy is expected to contribute close to 30% of global growth.

China's consumer and business confidence remains sluggish, contributing to persistent deflation. Prices across the economy have been falling for six straight quarters, the longest streak this century.
At CEWC, Beijing sets targets for economic growth, the budget deficit, debt issuance and other variables for the year ahead.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand Investment
summary: UOB's Leong Yung Chee will replace Lee Wai Fai as chief financial officer on April 22, 2025. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Investment acquired Wingate Group's property and corporate credit investment management business in Australia for A$200 million. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering requested a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 16)
summary: Singapore's private home market saw a significant surge in November, with 2,891 units sold, exceeding expectations. This comes after consecutive project launches and strong demand, driven by rising consumer sentiment. Meanwhile, Perennial Holdings will operate China's first wholly foreign-owned tertiary general hospital in Tianjin. Allianz has withdrawn its offer to buy Income Insurance, citing a moderate rise in the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index, which suggests a cautious outlook for Q1 2025. The Straits Times Index closed up 0.3% on Monday.

images.alt_text: ACRA’s data policy indicates that the types of personal data publicly available include names, identification numbers and residential addresses, if no contact address is given.

site_title: Ministers to send letters of demand to Bloomberg, other media outlets over ‘libellous’ statements
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and Manpower Minister Tan See Leng will issue letters of demand to Bloomberg and other media outlets over 'libellous' statements in a Dec 12 Bloomberg article about good class bungalow transactions in Singapore. The article, which mentioned property transactions involving the ministers, is considered libellous and the ministers plan to take similar action against others who published similar statements. The ministers will take legal action after consulting with lawyers.

site_title: New roads to returns in 2025: Look to small-to-mid caps and dividend stocks
summary: Investors can expect a different market environment in 2025, driven by diverging policies, economic performance, and geopolitics. Opportunities include US domestic economic growth, policy support from the incoming US administration, and China's focus on weak domestic demand. Small-to-mid caps and quality dividend stocks are seen as attractive options, while equities and credit markets are expected to benefit from economic growth and policy support. Investors should be selective and focus on areas with higher dividends and government policy support. Diversification through US duration and higher-quality fixed income can also help mitigate risks.

images.alt_text: As general market sentiments improve, SGX is poised for heightened IPO activities next year, said observers.

site_title: Why smart companies do dumb things
summary: Big companies often make mistakes, even if they're large enough to get away with them. Examples include New Coke, Eastman Kodak, Polaroid, JCPenney, Borders, Blockbuster, and Lycos. Macy's is struggling, with activist investors calling for a real estate spin-off and financial restructuring. Walgreens could be a potential buyout target, while JetBlue remains on the ropes despite failed mergers. Netflix's recent offer of unlimited parental leave backfired, and the company's future is uncertain. On the other hand, companies like Robinhood, which has a large and growing customer base of younger users, are showing promise.

images.alt_text: In the 1990s, the Lego Group suffered a crisis as management diversified into clothes, watches, publications, TV, learning labs and theme parks, even as low-cost competitors attacked its core business of building blocks.

site_title: More property cooling measures? Locals buying their first homes could be hit
summary: Singapore may introduce additional property cooling measures, including a possible 5% ABSD for locals and 10% for PRs buying their first homes, with rates applying to transactions over S$1 million. The measure aims to curb the private housing market's momentum and reduce wealth inequality. The government may also consider applying ABSD to HDB resale flats and private homes, potentially affecting buyers of choice units and those using progressive payment schemes. The move could impact demand for investment homes and stabilize the market.

images.alt_text: The 846-unit Emerald of Katong project in the East Coast collected more than 3,600 cheques from interested buyers before sales bookings even started.

site_title: Thai finance minister seeks further rate cut
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Pichai Chunhavajira, urged the Bank of Thailand to consider a further interest rate cut to align with low inflation, which averaged 0.32% in the January-November period. The central bank is set to review its key rate this week, with economists expecting no change. Pichai discussed the matter with Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput and stated that a rate cut would be beneficial. The central bank unexpectedly cut its key rate by a quarter point in October, but Pichai remains optimistic about a potential rate cut.

images.alt_text: Pichai Chunhavajira, Thailand’s finance minister, speaks at a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Thailand unveiled detailed plans for a long-delayed distribution of cash to most adult citizens, the centerpiece of government efforts to revive growth and the fortunes of the ruling coalition. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

site_title: One in four Indonesia firms involved in tax evasion, World Bank says
summary: Indonesia's economy faces a tax evasion issue, with one in four firms involved in tax evasion, according to a World Bank survey. Tax evasion is more prevalent among exporters, and the survey suggests that a lack of trust in the tax system and administration may contribute to this issue. The Indonesian government has also conducted fewer audits per million population compared to other countries, highlighting an inefficiency in the system. The World Bank still expects Indonesia's economic growth of 5.1% in 2025 and 2026, despite risks from rising geopolitical tensions and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Airlangga Hartarto, Indonesia’s coordinating minister for economic affairs, says: “The VAT rate will increase to 12 per cent as scheduled, while maintaining the principle of fairness."

site_title: Allianz confirms withdrawal of offer for Income Insurance
summary: Allianz has withdrawn its offer to buy at least 51% of Income Insurance for 1.5 billion euros, citing the Singapore government's concerns over the proposed takeover and capital reduction exercise. Despite withdrawing the offer, Allianz remains committed to Singapore's insurance market and will continue to explore liquidation options for shareholders. Income Insurance will honour existing policies and explore liquidity options for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Income Insurance, which has around 1.7 million customers and offers life, health and property insurance, was founded in the 1970s to offer insurance to poorer parts of the population.

site_title: Perennial to operate China’s first wholly foreign-owned tertiary general hospital in Tianjin
summary: Perennial Holdings has announced the opening of China's first wholly foreign-owned tertiary general hospital, Perennial General Hospital Tianjin, in Tianjin. The 500-bed hospital, costing $185.3 million, has obtained a medical institution practice license after passing a hospital inspection by Tianjin's Municipal Health Commission. The hospital will utilize an asset-light co-medical space model, allowing doctors to use shared facilities provided by Perennial. The hospital aims to attract foreign patients and drive growth in Tianjin's medical tourism industry, with Perennial's CEO stating that it will "pave the way" for the country's medical industry to gain international standing.

images.alt_text: The S$1 billion project located in the Chinese municipality spans more than 3.5 million square feet, and integrates eldercare, medical and hospitality facilities.
Golden Mile Singapore is an integrated development which includes The Golden Mile and Aurea, a new residential tower.
IHH Healthcare's private hospital Gleneagles Kuala Lumpur will be expanded by 2027, with a new medical block adding 260 new beds.
IHH Healthcare's Mount Elizabeth Fertility Centre and Haematology and Stem Cell Transplant Centre are located near Mount Elizabeth Hospital.

Analysts are split on IHH Healthcare in the wake of its relatively flat third quarter earnings and news of its Singapore Mount Elizabeth Hospital 's accelerated upgrading works set to finish ahead of schedule.
Mount Elizabeth Hospital in Orchard is undergoing refurbishment, which was announced in January 2023.
Kenanga research analyst Raymond Choo said Island Hospital will be an integral part of IHH’s cluster strategy, with Penang already serving as the group’s second largest Malaysian cluster.

site_title: Indonesia rolls out fresh incentives to boost spending amid planned VAT hike
summary: Indonesia has introduced new fiscal incentives to boost consumer spending amid a planned 12% value-added tax (VAT) hike. The measures include tax breaks for electric vehicles, property, and automotive sectors, as well as a 50% electricity tariff cut for middle-income households. Workers earning less than 10 million rupiah per month will receive full income-tax exemptions. The government aims to stimulate economic growth of 5.2% in 2025, despite global economic turbulence and public opposition to the VAT hike.

With Prabowo’s agenda to ramp up spending for economic growth, tax revenue is seen as a vital tool for the president to fund his ambitious budget plans.

site_title: China’s Instagram-like Xiaohongshu making inroads with e-commerce sales
summary: China's social media platform Xiaohongshu, similar to Instagram, is gaining traction in e-commerce sales, particularly among financially independent urban Chinese women. The platform's focus on aspirational lifestyles has attracted less price-sensitive users, leading to increased sales for brands, especially those peddling niche and high-end products. Influencers on the platform are using a quieter tone to promote products, and brands are investing in partnerships and livestreams to reach their target audience. Experts predict triple-digit gains in Xiaohongshu's gross merchandise volume next year, with estimated sales revenue of over $100 billion by 2025.

images.alt_text: Over the past year, digital marketing agency Prizm Group has seen a 65 per cent increase in enquiries by Singapore brands about marketing on Xiaohongshu.

The Vietnamese government is heightening scrutiny over local operators of foreign e-commerce platforms as well as eyeing additional taxes on duty-free imported goods enabled by the de minimis threshold.

The new group brings together the Taobao and Tmall Group and the Alibaba International Digital Commerce (AIDC) Group – which operated platforms including cross-border player AliExpress and wholesale B2B site Alibaba.com, in addition to second-hand platform Xianyu.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity softens for sixth straight month: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity has shrunk for the sixth consecutive month due to lacklustre demand, according to the au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) which dropped to 49.5 in December. The service sector, however, showed gains, with businesses seeing the strongest rise in new orders in four months. This divergent trend highlights the economy's increasing reliance on services.

images.alt_text: The headline index measuring big manufacturers’ business confidence stood at +14 in December, up from +13 hit three months ago and marking the highest reading since March 2022.
Public day care is currently available to working parents in Japan, but the national government is planning to widen access to all households.

site_title: CLI to acquire Australian credit investment manager Wingate for A$200 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) is acquiring Australian credit investment manager Wingate Group for A$200 million, aiming to expand its private credit business and portfolio in the country. The acquisition will boost CLI's funds under management to S$115 billion, bolstering its private funds business and providing an additional engine of growth towards its S$200 billion target by 2028. Wingate will remain domiciled in Australia and CLI plans to maintain and grow the company's business under existing management.

For the nine months ended September, CLI's total revenue amounted to S$2.1 billion, up from S$2.09 billion in the year prior.
CapitaLand wants to reduce its exposure in the world’s second-largest economy to 10-20 per cent of its expected S$200 billion in funds under management by 2028.

site_title: US case against India's Gautam Adani appears strong but extradition unlikely
summary: US prosecutors have a strong case against Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, accused of bribing Indian officials to buy electricity from Adani Green Energy, but extradition is unlikely due to India's reluctance to cooperate. Documents, including "bribe notes" on Adani's nephew's phone, and emails show Adani's involvement in the alleged scheme. Adani faces securities fraud and conspiracy charges, punishable by up to 20 years in prison. Adani Group has denied the allegations, calling them "baseless."

images.alt_text: The founder of the port-to-power conglomerate is considered a close ally of the prime minister.
Indian billionaire Gautam Adani on Saturday blamed “a lot of the vested reporting” for spreading “negativity” about the nature of the US charges.

site_title: HSBC sued by Australian regulator for bank scam loss failures
summary: HSBC Australia is being sued by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission for failing to protect customers who lost approximately A$23 million (S$19.8 million) in scams between January 2020 and August 2024. The bank received around 950 reports of unauthorised transactions, with an average investigation time of 145 days. ASIC alleges that HSBC's failings were widespread and systemic, and the bank has cooperated with the investigation.

site_title: Gold edges higher with spotlight on Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to US$2,652.07 per ounce as investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision this week, with a potential 25 basis point cut expected. The focus shifts to the Fed's language on rate cuts next year, with a 93.4% chance of a quarter-point cut predicted. Meanwhile, Israeli strikes in Gaza killed at least 53 Palestinians, contributing to economic and geopolitical uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up about 0.1 per cent at US$2,719.79 per ounce.

site_title: India is booming. Will it blow up in your face?
summary: India's stock market is experiencing a boom, with its benchmark index on track for a ninth consecutive annual gain. The country's favorable demographics and lower tariff risks have drawn investors, including heavyweight listings and oversubscribed IPOs. However, analysts warn that overvaluation is a ticking time bomb, and corporate scandals could blow up in investors' faces. Despite this, some experts remain bullish on India as a secular growth story, while others advise caution and diversification. The country's economy is expected to surpass Japan's by 2025, becoming the fourth-largest globally.

South-east Asia’s e-commerce firms have something to show for all that financial sobriety, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
Beyond the knee-jerk US equity euphoria, there is disquiet as election uncertainty is replaced by uncertainty about everything else, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust unit to sell one vessel
summary: FIRST Ship Lease (FSL) Trust announced that its subsidiary, FSL-1, will sell the 12,921 deadweight-ton product tanker Cumbrian Fisher to an unaffiliated third party. The vessel, built in 2004, has been employed under bareboat charter. A memorandum of understanding has been signed, with a 10% deposit in escrow. The sale is a result of FSL-1's efforts to optimize its fleet.

site_title: German Chancellor Scholz to ask parliament to clear way for new elections
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz will ask parliament to declare no confidence in him, paving the way for early elections. The move comes after the collapse of his government due to the departure of the Free Democrats, leaving him without a parliamentary majority. If the vote passes, Scholz and his ministers will remain in office until a new government is formed, potentially taking months. Early elections are set for February 23, with Scholz proposing measures to address Germany's economic crisis, including tax cuts and subsidies.

images.alt_text: Recent worse-than-expected data had fuelled speculation the ECB could deliver a hefty, half-percentage-point cut for the first time in its easing cycle.

site_title: STI inches up 0.3% on Monday, bucking regional trend
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% on Monday, bucking a regional trend, with OCBC being the top gainer and closing up 1.4%. DBS followed, rising 1.3%. The broader market saw decliners outnumber advancers 333 to 183, with 866.9 million shares worth S$1.1 billion changing hands. Across the region, major indices declined, with South Korea's Kospi falling 0.2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 0.9%.

site_title: US finalises US$9.63 billion loan for Ford, SK On joint battery venture
summary: The US Energy Department has finalized a $9.63 billion loan to Ford's joint venture with SK On to build battery manufacturing facilities in Kentucky and Tennessee, enabling over 120 gigawatt hours of US battery production annually. The loan is the largest ever from the Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing loan programme, aimed at boosting electric vehicle production before President-elect Donald Trump takes office. The joint venture has invested over $11 billion in construction and plans to begin production in 2025.

site_title: KidZania Singapore operator Sim Leisure dreams of creating Asia’s theme parks of tomorrow
summary: Sim Leisure Group, the operator of KidZania Singapore, aims to become Asia's most successful theme park operator in terms of efficiency and profitability. The company, led by founder and executive chairman Sim Choo Kheng, acquired KidZania Singapore in 2023 for a discounted price and has since turned the park profitable. Sim Leisure plans to replicate this success with KidZania Singapore, which reopened in May this year. The company also operates Escape, an outdoor adventure park brand, and is exploring franchising opportunities in South-east Asia and China.

site_title: ‘Moana 2’ surfs to third weekend lead in North American theatres
summary: "Moana 2" tops the North American box office for the third weekend, earning US$26.6 million and pushing domestic earnings to US$337.5 million. The animated film, which follows Moana's seafaring adventures, surpasses US$700 million in overall earnings. Universal's "Wicked" takes second place with US$22.5 million, while "Kraven the Hunter" and "Gladiator II" follow in third and fourth place.

site_title: China’s factory output quickens in November but consumption still a drag
summary: China's industrial output grew 5.4% in November, beating expectations, but retail sales disappointed with a 3.3% increase, down from October's 4.8%. Fixed asset investment rose 3.3% for the January-November period. Despite a pledge to boost consumption, China's economy remains fragile as it prepares for potential US trade tariffs under a second Trump administration, with growth forecasts potentially shaved off due to new tariffs.

site_title: Top South Korean court begins Yoon impeachment trial
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court has begun proceedings on the impeachment of President Yoon Suk-yeol, who was removed by parliament on Saturday over his attempt to suspend civilian rule. Yoon's suspension plunged the country into its worst political turmoil in years. The court has six months to determine whether to uphold the impeachment, with fresh elections set to be held within two months if he is removed. Yoon remains under a travel ban and has refused to comply with a summons for questioning, with prosecutors seeking a second summons.

site_title: UK property asking prices fall, headwinds remain for 2025: Rightmove
summary: UK property asking prices fell 1.7% in December, in line with the historic average decline for the end of the year, according to Rightmove. This follows a 1.4% drop in November. Despite this, activity was robust, with agreed sales 22% higher and new buyer demand 13% higher than a year earlier. The drop in asking prices is partly due to uncertainty over the upcoming increase in stamp duty tax in April, which may impact market activity in 2025.

site_title: Asia’s tourism arrivals forecast to return to pre-Covid levels in 2025: report
summary: Asia's tourism arrivals are forecast to recover to pre-Covid levels in 2025, rising 4.7% from 2019, according to a report by BMI. This is slower than Western Europe and Latin America's 16.3% and 13.9% growth, respectively. Mainland China, a key source market for Asia, reopened in 2023 and is expected to contribute to the region's recovery. The Middle East and North Africa (Mena) region is forecast to see the highest growth, at 34.4% above pre-Covid-19 levels.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in air travel growth at 5.1 per cent per year, with South-east Asia and India heading that expansion.

site_title: Zakir Hussain, peerless Indian tabla player, dies at 73
summary: Zakir Hussain, a renowned Indian tabla player, died at 73 due to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis in San Francisco. A four-time Grammy Award winner, Hussain collaborated with artists like Yo-Yo Ma and George Harrison, elevating the status of the tabla. Born in 1951, he began performing at 7 and toured by 12, becoming a child prodigy. His father, a tabla master, was also known as Ustad, and together they helped transform the instrument's reputation. Hussain is survived by his family, including his wife and three daughters.

site_title: Hong Kong Urban Renewal Authority to sign US$1.7 billion loan
summary: Hong Kong's Urban Renewal Authority is set to sign a $1.7 billion, five-year loan with a group of banks, marking its first syndicated facility in over a decade. The loan pays 68 basis points over the risk-free Hong Kong interbank offered rate and comes amid the city's prolonged property slump, where home prices have declined over 6% this year. The entity's latest loan, which could be signed as early as this week, will push its total borrowing to at least $25 billion this year.

site_title: Singapore business confidence remains mixed for Q1 2025
summary: Singapore business confidence remains mixed for Q1 2025, with the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau's Business Optimism Index (BOI) climbing to +5.45 percentage points, a sixth consecutive quarter. Sentiments for construction, transportation, and financial sectors were the most optimistic, with at least four indicators in positive territory. Manufacturing sector sentiment improved visibly, while wholesale trade sentiment moderated. SCCB chief Audrey Chia attributed the mixed sentiment to global trade uncertainties and cautioned that the outlook remains cautiously optimistic for the new year.

site_title: Singapore’s new home sales more than treble in November as six projects hit the market
summary: Singapore's private home market experienced a surge in November, with 2,557 units sold, more than tripling from the previous year. This marks the highest sales figure in over a decade, with a total of 6,344 new homes sold between January and November. The increase was driven by six new projects launched in November, including executive condominiums, which sold at median prices of S$2,627 and S$2,586 per square foot. Analysts predict that new home sales may reach 6,500 to 7,000 units for 2024, with prices growing by up to 5%.

site_title: Price seen softening further for key semiconductor index
summary: The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (SOX) has pulled back 15% since peaking in mid-July, underperforming the S&P 500. The decline is attributed to the US-China chip war, with stricter export curbs imposed on China-bound shipments of high-bandwidth memory chips. Beijing has launched an investigation into Nvidia Corp, suspected of violating China's anti-monopoly law, further heightening tensions. The SOX is expected to continue its downtrend, with the current negative market sentiment in the sector.

site_title: China’s new home prices fall at slowest pace in 17 months in November
summary: China's new home prices fell 0.1% month-on-month in November, the slowest pace in 17 months, according to Reuters calculations. This marks a 0.5% dip from October, the previous month. In annual terms, new home prices dropped 5.7% after a 5.9% decline the previous month. The government has scaled up stimulus measures to lift the crisis-hit property sector, indicating efforts to stabilize the market.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle after more weak China data
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday after weak China retail sales data reinforced economic concerns, despite Tokyo, Singapore, and Taipei rising. The disappointing data, combined with Beijing's stimulus pledges, added to market woes. Key monetary policy decisions by the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan are also on the horizon, further complicating the market.

site_title: UK approves Daniel Kretinsky’s £5.3 billion bid for Royal Mail parent, FT reports
summary: The UK government has approved Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky's £5.3 billion bid to acquire Royal Mail owner International Distribution Services. The approval is expected to be announced Monday morning. As part of the deal, the UK government will retain a "golden share" in the postal service, giving it special governance rights. Royal Mail has struggled with labour strikes, competition, and market share loss, including a recent £10.5 million fine for failing to meet delivery targets. The takeover is seen as a significant development for the postal service.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A Royal Mail sign is pictured outside a delivery office in north London on September 8, 2022. site_title: BT Money Hacks: Fractional jobs: The modern day side hustle?
summary: Singapore has recognized and adapted to the shift towards fractional jobs, with a landmark bill creating a distinct legal category for gig economy workers, offering better protection. These jobs, where professionals work part-time or on a project basis, provide companies with flexibility while maintaining a work-life balance. However, they also come with challenges, such as accessing financial products and managing finances effectively. Experts emphasize the importance of financial literacy and prudent money management for gig and fractional workers, who can benefit from building a robust credit history over time.

site_title: UK factories take fright as budget adds to cost pressures: survey
summary: British manufacturers reported a sharp loss of confidence due to higher costs, including tax increases by the new government. The Make UK survey showed a 5.8 confidence level in the fourth quarter of 2024, down from 6.8 three months earlier. The sector cut its forecast for manufacturing output in 2024 to a 0.2% shrink, down from 0.5% growth. Despite positive output and orders, recruitment and investment intentions remained stable, with the sector expected to expand by 0.7% in 2025.

site_title: The changing landscape of petrol stations in Singapore: What lies ahead?
summary: Singapore's petrol stations landscape is undergoing changes due to declining petrol demand as more drivers shift to electric vehicles (EVs). The country has around 180 petrol stations, with ExxonMobil being the largest player with 59 stations. Approximately 2 million sq ft of land could be repurposed as EV charging stations, with some sites potentially being rezoned and redeveloped for alternative uses. The government aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, and subsidies and expanded EV infrastructure are encouraging EV adoption. Repurposing sites could enhance practical use and economic value, and could be converted into mixed-use developments or repurposed using shipping containers or double-decker buses.

site_title: Bitcoin powers above US$106,000 for first time
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record high above US$106,000 on Monday after President-elect Donald Trump suggested he plans to create a US bitcoin strategic reserve, sparking enthusiasm among crypto bulls. The price rose 3.1% to US$104,493, with smaller crypto ether rising 1.2% to $3,952. This surge marks a 50% increase since Trump's election on November 5. Trump's comments have boosted the cryptocurrency industry, with over US$119 million spent backing pro-crypto US congressional candidates.

images.alt_text: The digital asset rose nearly 5 per cent on Wednesday in the US, the most in two weeks.
Bitcoin hit a record US$103,800 on Dec 5 but subsequently struggled to stay above the six-figure level.
As Bitcoin sceptics and Bitcoin maximalists talk over each other, a third group – the opportunists – have bought and sold the stuff many times over.
The token’s six-week streak of gains through Sunday is the longest such run since the crypto frenzy of 2021.

site_title: Oil eases from highest in weeks, investors eye Fed rate cuts
summary: Oil prices eased from their highest levels in weeks, with Brent crude futures falling 21 cents to $74.28 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude dropping 30 cents to $70.99 a barrel. Investors await a Federal Reserve meeting for indications of further rate cuts, but supply disruptions concerns limited falls, particularly if the US imposes more sanctions on Russia and Iran. The Fed is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, which could boost economic growth and demand for oil.

images.alt_text: The price of crude sold to China from Iran, another Opec member, rose to the highest in years as US sanctions have tightened shipping capacity and boosted logistics costs.
Brent crude futures settled 11 cents, or 0.15 per cent, lower at US$73.41 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Boeing’s year of crisis leaves investors wary of beaten-up stock
summary: Boeing's stock has plummeted 35% this year, becoming one of the 20 biggest decliners in the S&P 500 Index. The company's struggles began in January after a door plug blew off during an Alaska Air flight, followed by a series of crises including a management overhaul, labour strike, and allegations from whistle-blowers. Analysts now expect a loss of $15.89 per share for 2024, and estimates for 2025 and beyond have collapsed by 50% or more. The company's shares may only recover modestly in 2025, with a potential 7% gain from current levels, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Boeing announced the US$1 billion investment in its non-union facilities in North Charleston, where it said 500 jobs would be created over the next five years.
Boeing said it restarted 737 MAX production, loading fresh fuselages into its Seattle-area Renton factory, after weeks of methodical preparation.
The aerospace industry says it is gradually returning to normal but has warned of supply pressures well into 2025.

site_title: HDB starts work on flats not announced for sale yet in Clementi, Toa Payoh and Bukit Merah
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has begun construction on new Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in Clementi, Toa Payoh, and Bukit Merah, despite not having announced them for sale yet. The projects include 753 units in Clementi, 741 units in Toa Payoh, and 498 units in Bukit Merah. The flats are expected to be completed by 2029 and will feature various amenities, including childcare centers, eating houses, and precinct pavilions. Experts predict that the flats will fall under the Plus category, which may require significant subsidies due to their locational attributes.

images.alt_text: BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee asks: While homebuyers here should be mindful of the economic impact of a new Trump presidency, are many Trump voters who are hoping for lower inflation wrong?
PHOTO: URA

site_title: Singapore’s logistics sector grows at slightly slower pace in November
summary: Singapore's logistics sector experienced a slower expansion in November, with the Logistics Growth Index (LGI) dropping to 51.9 points from 52.2 points in the previous month. The Asia-Pacific region saw a faster growth rate, with the LGI increasing to 51.8 points. The slowdown was attributed to declining business volumes, transportation, and warehousing. Despite this, the sector remains in expansionary mode for the 50th consecutive month, driven by technological innovation and demand for air and ocean freight.

images.alt_text: The commissioning of new berths in Tuas is one of the measures Singapore is taking to mitigate port congestion.

site_title:
Microgrids can help with energy bottlenecks 
as Singapore scales EV population
summary: Singapore plans to scale up its electric vehicle (EV) population, which would require 3.1 terrawatt hours of energy, equivalent to 6.9% of the country's electricity consumption. To address potential power bottlenecks, microgrids could help smooth generation and demand across the island. Microgrids, small-scale power systems that operate outside a national grid, could enable consumers to become prosumers, producing electricity for the grid when it makes sense. Singapore aims to have half its public bus fleet electric by 2030 and is already providing an EV infrastructure, with 13,800 registered charging points.

images.alt_text: The acquisition brings the total charging points that Charge+ has in Singapore to around 2,500.

site_title: No rush for MAS to ease monetary policy early in 2025, as uncertainty over Trump lingers
summary: Singapore's central bank is expected to start easing monetary policy in 2025, but most economists predict it will occur in April rather than January due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs. Despite core inflation cooling to under 2% by end-2024, MAS will wait to see how Trump's policies impact the economy. Economists expect core inflation to fall further in 2025, but MAS may hold back on easing prematurely to prevent the economy from overheating, especially if Trump's tariffs worsen growth risks.

images.alt_text: Their median forecasts for inflation in 2024 have slipped.
Food inflation was unchanged at 2.6 per cent, as the prices of non-cooked food and food services rose at a similar pace in September and October.

site_title: France’s Macron has a new prime minister but the same old problems
summary: France's new Prime Minister Francois Bayrou faces significant challenges in passing a 2025 budget, which must cut the 2024 deficit from 6.1% while managing unions, the military, and industry. Bayrou, a centrist, has a fractured parliament and must navigate opposition from far-right and left-wing parties, who may try to block his budget plans. The government must also address rising debt, pension reform, and industrial sector support, all while keeping the peace with trade unions and powerful vested interests.

site_title: As agencies apologise over NRIC confusion, concerns over scam risk and privacy loss remain
summary: The Singapore government's revised stance on the sensitivity of National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers has sparked concerns over data breaches and loss of privacy. Despite the government's apology, many citizens remain worried that easy availability of full NRIC numbers will lead to identity theft. Concrete measures to mitigate the impact, such as authentication measures for critical sectors, are needed, and the public should be reassured of the government's plan to address these concerns.

site_title: China’s housing regulator sees stabilisation signs: report
summary: China's housing regulator sees signs of stabilisation and improved sentiment in the real estate market due to government stimulus measures, according to a report. The regulator will continue to boost demand and control land supply for new development. The housing market collapse over the past three years has dragged down economic activity, but the government pledged to stabilise the stock market and property sector at its December meeting. Vice-minister Dong Jianguo attributed the stabilisation signs to the government's efforts. The regulator aims to promote the recovery of the property market.

site_title: Australia’s economy under pressure amid China’s slowdown: Treasurer Chalmers
summary: Australia's economy is under pressure due to China's slowdown, with weaker domestic growth and increased spending in some areas. Treasurer Jim Chalmers stated that challenges in the Chinese economy will impact Australia's budget, as reflected in Treasury's forecasts. The country's gross domestic product rose 0.8% last quarter, the weakest reading since 1991. Earnings from iron ore are forecast to decline by A$100 billion over the four years to 2027-2028, and company tax receipts will be revised down by A$8.5 billion.

site_title: ‘I’m not good enough’, says Guardiola as Man City continues slump with 2-1 loss to Man United
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola admitted he didn't see his team's collapse coming, as they lost 2-1 to Manchester United in a Premier League match. City have won just once in 11 games, including eight defeats, and trail leaders Liverpool by nine points. site_title: Office property meltdown is starting to surface at US banks
summary: US banks, especially smaller ones, are modifying 0.32% of commercial real estate loans due to declining office property values. This is a significant increase from the first half of 2024, when modifications were just 0.1%. Larger banks have modified around 1.93% and 0.79% of their CRE loans, respectively. Smaller lenders have been slower to confront declining property prices, likely contributing to the difference in modification rates. This trend is rippling through US banks, impacting their commercial real estate books.

site_title: Volatility to surge in agri-commodity markets amid trade tensions
summary: Agri-commodity markets are expected to experience significant volatility in 2025 due to escalating trade tensions and shifting currency dynamics. Tree crop commodities like crude palm oil, cocoa, and coffee are expected to sustain elevated prices, while ringgit-denominated palm oil may see further gains. However, US food and agriculture exports, particularly soybeans, face notable risks if trade relations sour between China and the US under Donald Trump's administration. Analysts predict that US farmers may scale down production, impacting global prices for key crops like corn, soybeans, and wheat.

site_title: What China’s persistent deflation means for the world
summary: China's economy has slipped into a six-quarter deflationary streak, with prices falling due to weak demand for goods produced during a policy push to develop manufacturing and high-tech goods. Policymakers have pledged to ease price declines, but the situation is challenging to fix due to a cautious approach to stimulus measures and a shift towards advanced technologies. The US's potential trade war with China, led by President-elect Donald Trump, poses a significant threat to China's export growth, further exacerbating deflation. China's GDP growth is expected to be around 5% this year, and the country is struggling to reverse the downward trend in prices, which could have broader implications for the global economy.

site_title: UBS Wealth calls out ‘overblown’ ESG investor angst over Trump
summary: UBS Wealth Management has downplayed concerns that the return of Donald Trump to the White House will undermine the case for Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing. Despite a recent sell-off in traditional ESG stocks, long-term demand for investment in renewable infrastructure and electrification is expected to remain strong, according to UBS strategists. They argue that politics and geopolitics aside, the economic case for renewable energy and electrification is attractive, with long-term demand visibility.

site_title: Catalist-listed SIAMH may have gone public before it was ready – MAS review group should figure out why
summary: The Singapore-listed company SIAMH's shares have collapsed to S$0.06 since its initial public offering (IPO) in February 2024, despite its promising technology and business model. The company's financial performance has been weak, with a loss of S$37.4 million for the financial year to June 30, and revenue increased only 2.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's review group should investigate how the enablers of public listings can be incentivized to ensure companies are prepared to engage with investors and deliver a credible growth story before listing.

site_title: Doing good to do well
summary: Standard Chartered Bank emphasizes its corporate purpose as guiding decisions to create positive impact, focusing on society's prosperity and sustainable economic growth. The bank supports various initiatives, including empowering seniors through digital literacy programs, helping women from underprivileged backgrounds through entrepreneurship initiatives, and promoting disability inclusion through sports. Employees are encouraged to volunteer, with over 40% of 9,000 staff members contributing over 31,000 hours of service in 2024. The bank has received recognition for its commitment to corporate giving, including being named Singapore's Best Bank in Corporate Responsibility.

site_title: Chasing chip talent to keep the semiconductor boom alive
summary: China has built a sizable talent pool in the semiconductor industry over the past two decades, driven by government policies, but still faces a shortage of skilled employees in high-level strategic roles. The global semiconductor industry is expected to reach a staggering $1 trillion by 2030, driven by the rise of generative AI. Countries like the US, Malaysia, and Singapore are competing for chip industry talent, with China offering higher salaries to attract professionals. The Malaysian government has launched a National Semiconductor Strategy to drive growth and attract foreign tech companies, while China continues to invest in its industry, but still needs to close the experience gap.

site_title: Open global trade is only way to feed the world: WTO chief
summary: World Trade Organization (WTO) director-general Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala emphasized the importance of maintaining a stable, free, open, and predictable trading system to feed the world. She warned that global poverty will increase if the world doesn't work to maintain this system, citing that one in four calories consumed globally is traded. Okonjo-Iweala faces challenges in championing free trade, particularly with the US's protectionist stance, but highlights opportunities in services and green trade, worth $4.25 trillion and $2 trillion respectively.

images.alt_text: Okonjo-Iweala, a former Nigerian finance minister who made history in 2021 by becoming the body’s first female and first African director-general, has broad backing among WTO members.

site_title: The 24 hours of rate cuts that end year of global central-bank easing
summary: Central banks worldwide are set to announce a 24-hour flurry of decisions, with the US Federal Reserve leading the way on December 18, followed by peers in Japan, the Nordics, and the UK. The Fed is expected to deliver a quarter-point rate cut, while the Bank of England is anticipated to keep borrowing costs on hold. The Bank of Japan, meanwhile, is likely to hold off on rate hikes until 2025. The decisions come as policymakers weigh the impact of inflation, economic growth, and the prospect of inflationary import tariffs from the incoming Trump administration.

site_title: Data protection guidelines on NRIC numbers will be updated after public consultation: PDPC
summary: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) in Singapore plans to update its guidelines on the use of National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers after public consultation. Despite the government's change in stance, NRIC numbers are still considered sensitive information and must be protected. Organisations must obtain valid consent and comply with reasonable use and protection requirements when collecting and using NRIC data. The new guidelines will not change the fact that NRIC numbers are subject to data protection obligations, and organisations must continue to ensure protection and secure authentication methods.

site_title: S-Reits’ secondary fundraising rebounds in 2024; more may tap capital markets next year
summary: At least six Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have raised over S$2.8 billion through equity fundraising (EFR) in 2024, exceeding last year's nearly S$1.9 billion. This rebound in EFR activity is attributed to healthy investor interest, with subscription levels in most issuances. S-Reits have also been able to raise larger amounts of capital this year, with two S-Reits launching EFR exercises that raised over S$1 billion. Analysts predict that more S-Reits will tap capital markets to fund acquisitions in 2025, particularly in the industrial and data-centre spaces.

site_title: China’s regulators vow to stabilise property, stock markets
summary: China's regulators vowed to stabilize the property and stock markets through measures such as increasing demand and controlling land supply. The China Securities Regulatory Commission will enhance market monitoring and strengthen supervision of margin trading. The government also plans to implement more effective fiscal policies, including increasing local government special bond issuance. China's struggling economy has shown modest improvement in recent weeks, but overall confidence remains fragile. The central bank is expected to cut interest rates and reserve requirement ratio next year to boost credit growth.

images.alt_text: The world’s second-largest economy is expected to contribute close to 30% of global growth.

China's outbound shipments grew just 6.7 per cent last month, customs data showed on Tuesday, missing an 8.5 per cent increase in a Reuters poll of economists and a 12.7 per cent rise in October.
China's CPI rose 0.2 per cent last month from a year earlier, cooling from a 0.3 per cent increase in October, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed on Monday.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending December 13, 2024, highlights a challenging market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. Key points include:

- Capesize rates declined across both the Pacific and Atlantic basins, with the BCI 5TC index falling to $10,474.
- The Panamax market remained stable, with Trans-Atlantic demand driving rates, but Asia struggled to gain momentum due to growing tonnage lists and subdued demand.
- Ultramax and Supramax vessels faced a difficult week, with limited activity and low rates in the South Atlantic and Asian arenas.
- Handysize vessels saw limited activity, with the U.S. Gulf market remaining slow.
- Clean and dirty bulk cargo markets also experienced declines, with LR2 rates making small gains mid-week before recorrecting.
- The Suezmax market saw charterers regain control, with rates declining in the Middle East and West Africa.
- Aframax rates rose slightly in the North Sea, but eased in the Mediterranean.
- The LNG market remained bearish, with weak fundamentals and size constraints on cargoes.
- LPG rates experienced a noticeable uptick, driven by increased demand and a tighter tonnage list.

images.alt_text: The LNG spot market continued to stagnate this week, with rates remaining relatively flat amid limited activity.

site_title: Trump vows to eliminate ‘inconvenient’ Daylight Saving Time
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has vowed to eliminate "inconvenient" Daylight Saving Time, calling it "costly" to the nation. Trump's stance is not new, as he previously expressed support for making the time change permanent in 2019. Trump's pick for Secretary of State, Marco Rubio, has introduced a bipartisan bill to make the time change permanent, which has gained support from Tesla CEO Elon Musk and biotech entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy.

Amazon joins another tech giant, Meta Platforms, in donating to the Jan 20 Trump inauguration. Meta will also give US$1 million, a company spokesperson said.

Trump advisers and officials from the newly established Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) have inquired about the possibility of the president-elect abolishing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, the Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

US President-elect Donald Trump rings the opening bell on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Dec 12. Trump was invited to the Exchange after being named TIME’s “Person of the Year” for the second time.

site_title: LHN optimises Coliwoo’s co-living spaces to give back to the community
summary: LHN, a property player, has optimised its co-living space at Coliwoo Boon Lay in Singapore to give back to the community. The space, previously underutilised, now hosts academic coaching and activities for 15-20 children aged 5-14 from lower-income or single-parent families, including those from Touch Young Arrows. The initiative, launched in July, aims to promote cognitive development and values such as teamwork. LHN's chief strategy officer, Darren Loh, sees this as part of the company's efforts to serve the community and incorporate social good into its spaces.

images.alt_text: UOB volunteers at a Christmas carolling session, which was organised as part of its Christmas charity pop-up event.

site_title: South Korea’s central bank vows to stabilise markets amid political turmoil
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has vowed to stabilize financial markets amid the country's political turmoil following the impeachment of President Yoon Suk-yeol. The bank stated that the predictability of the political process is expected to improve, leading to a decrease in financial market volatility. The central bank aims to utilize all available policy instruments to respond to and avert an escalation of volatility in financial and foreign exchange markets.

images.alt_text: Han Duck-soo (above) was elevated to acting president in accordance with the constitution while President Yoon’s case moves to the Constitutional Court.

Protesters in Seoul celebrate after the result of the second martial law impeachment vote was announced on Saturday. Lawmakers successfully voted to remove Yoon from office for his failed attempt to impose martial law.
A man wearing a fat suit and a mask depicting South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol dances during a protest calling for Yoon's ouster outside the National Assembly in Seoul.

Demonstrators call for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 7, 2024.

site_title: NRIC numbers may not be secure enough for authentication purposes, but how will companies adapt?
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Digital Development and Information announced that National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers will be viewed as public information, making them publicly available. This move aims to reduce the false sense of security provided by masking NRIC numbers. However, banks and regulated sectors are questioning how they will treat NRIC numbers, citing concerns over data breaches and inconsistent treatment of local and foreign data. Experts suggest that the move could lead to the adoption of biometric or in-app verification methods to enhance security.

images.alt_text: PDPC noted that it has previously taken action against organisations which have used NRIC numbers for authentication and breached their data protection obligations.
Acra's data policy states that the statutory board is exempted from the Personal Data Protection Act.
ACRA’s data policy indicates that the types of personal data publicly available include names, identification numbers and residential addresses, if no contact address is given.

site_title: Broadcom valuation soars past US$1 trillion on AI sales boom
summary: Broadcom's stock surged 24% to $224.80 on Dec 13, its largest one-day rally since 2009, after the chip supplier predicted a 65% increase in AI sales in the first quarter, driven by demand for its AI chips. The company's valuation soared past $1 trillion, fueled by its strong AI revenue growth, which reached $12.2 billion in the last fiscal year. Broadcom's CEO Hock Tan also announced the company's plans to expand its software unit and win new customers, positioning the company for long-term growth.

images.alt_text: SAN JOSE, CALIFORNIA - DECEMBER 12: A sign is posted in front of a Broadcom office on December 12, 2024 in San Jose, California. Shares of Broadcom surged 13 percent after reporting better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings with net income of $4.32 billion, compared to $3.52 billion one year ago.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Profit was US$1.42 a share in the period, excluding some items, Broadcom said in a statement on Thursday.

site_title: US tech firms battle to keep selling to China
summary: The US government has rejected a plea from semiconductor equipment companies to cut off sales to three Chinese companies linked to Huawei, citing national security concerns. Applied Materials, KLA, and Lam Research, which make equipment used to manufacture semiconductors, argued that the sales were a major source of revenue, earning $6 billion. The companies claimed that US industry should not be singled out for restrictions, as Japan and the Netherlands also supply technology to China. The US government ultimately issued new regulations banning certain chips and equipment from being shipped to China, but some officials believe loopholes will be exploited.

images.alt_text: The lack of major changes ran counter to rumours that the Huawei Mate 70 phone would contain a chipset made on a more advanced 5nm process.
Earlier this year, the US revoked some licenses including those belonging to Intel and Qualcomm for doing business with Huawei.

site_title: Allianz scraps proposed acquisition of Singapore’s Income Insurance: source
summary: Allianz has scrapped its proposed 1.5 billion euro acquisition of a 51% stake in Singaporean firm Income Insurance due to public opposition. The deal, valued at S$2.1 billion, would have lifted Allianz to the fourth-largest composite insurer in Asia, but sparked concerns that it would detract from Income Insurance's mission to provide affordable insurance for lower-income workers. Singapore's prime minister had previously stated that the city-state would block the deal, but remained open to a new proposal if concerns were addressed.

site_title: US foreign investment panel split on Nippon-US Steel deal: FT
summary: The US Treasury has informed Japan's Nippon Steel that a panel reviewing its proposed $14.9 billion purchase of US Steel has not reached a consensus on addressing security concerns. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS) has until December 22 to make a decision on whether to approve, block, or extend the timeline for the deal's review. The acquisition has faced opposition from US officials, including President Joe Biden and his successor Donald Trump, citing potential national security risks. The deadline for a recommendation is looming, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: TikTok hawks tapped for jobs contrast with Trump’s murky stance
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has announced key appointments that could lead to a ban on TikTok in the US, despite his recent softened stance on the issue. Senator Marco Rubio will be secretary of state, while Jacob Helberg, a China hawk, will be under secretary for economic and tech-related issues. Brendan Carr, a long-time opponent of TikTok, will lead the Federal Communications Commission. These appointments may create a conflict between Trump and his chosen diplomats, who are likely to press for a ban on the Chinese-owned app.

images.alt_text: Under the law, TikTok will be banned unless ByteDance divests it by Jan 19.
The US Justice Department said the court should not delay the law’s effective date arguing “continued Chinese control of the TikTok application poses a continuing threat to national security.”

TikTok Shop – which combines video with impulse buying in visual fashion – is the app’s biggest growth engine after advertising.

The companies also noted President-elect Donald Trump has vowed to prevent a ban, arguing the delay “will give the incoming administration time to determine its position – which could moot both the impending harms and the need for Supreme Court review.”
The court's decision is a complete win for the Justice Department and opponents of TikTok and a devastating blow to ByteDance.

site_title: Tech trends and trust: Making South-east Asia’s digital economy work for all
summary: South-east Asia's digital economy is expected to exceed US$1 trillion in 2025, driven by the growing use of generative artificial intelligence (AI) and alternative payment methods. However, implementing these innovations responsibly and building consumer trust will be crucial. Key trends include the rise of AI in banking, demand from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) for accessible payment solutions and credit options, and the increasing need for advanced cybersecurity measures. To unlock the full potential of these innovations, a balance must be struck between user experience, privacy, and security, with trust playing a pivotal role in their adoption.

images.alt_text: The broader rollout of Gemini 2.0’s enhanced Search capabilities is scheduled for early 2025, with plans to expand AI Overviews to additional countries and languages throughout the year.
Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.

The pressure is on for data centres to be greener and smarter. Businesses and operators have been announcing carbon targets and initiatives to reduce their footprint even before AI dominated headlines.

site_title: China’s CNOOC sells US assets to Britain’s Ineos
summary: China's CNOOC Energy Holdings USA has sold its US upstream oil and gas assets in the Gulf of Mexico to Ineos, a British chemicals group, for approximately $2 billion. The deal includes non-operator interests in projects such as the Appomattox and Stampede fields. CNOOC aims to optimize its global asset portfolio and will work with Ineos to ensure a smooth transition. The sale is part of CNOOC's efforts to exit Western assets due to concerns about potential sanctions from China's relations with Russia.

images.alt_text: The Chinese offshore driller’s net income declined 8.1 per cent to US$4.64 billion from the same period last year.
Cnooc said net income rose to 36.9 billion yuan (S$6.8 billion), from 33.9 billion yuan last year.
