site_title: US dollar set for best week in a month on cautious Fed outlook for 2025
summary: The US dollar is set for its best weekly performance in a month, rising 0.69% to 153.695 yen, following reports that the Bank of Japan may forgo a rate hike next week. Investors are pricing in a slower pace of Federal Reserve rate cuts in 2025, with a 24% chance of another rate cut in January and a 23% chance of a quarter-point hike by the BOJ on December 19. The dollar index is up 0.037% at 107, its highest since late November.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the currency against a basket of six others, was little changed at 106.58, a day after a US inflation reading cemented bets for a rate cut from the Federal Reserve next week.

site_title: Agri-food sector investing amid a looming food crisis
summary: Asia's agri-food sector faces a looming food crisis, with the global population expected to reach 10 billion by 2050. The region already struggles with resource constraints, and disruptions to the global food supply chain have exacerbated the issue. To address these challenges, an estimated US$800 billion will need to be invested in the next decade, primarily in Asia, to drive efficiency and innovation. Traditional agri-food corporates have been slow to invest in innovation, prompting the emergence of agri-food tech startups, which have attracted significant investment in recent years.

images.alt_text: Workers harvesting rice in Thailand using their sickles, before the threshing and winnowing. With climate change, rising sea levels are threatening rice fields and the region’s supply of the grain will come under more pressure.
Oxford Economics expects international soybean prices to take a direct hit from the upcoming Trump presidency and ensuing trade war with China.

site_title: South-east Asia ESG funds record net inflows in Q3 2024, reversing two quarters of outflows
summary: South-east Asia's ESG funds recorded net inflows in Q3 2024, reversing two quarters of outflows. Despite geopolitical uncertainties, investors are shifting towards large-cap index stocks and fixed income funds, which do not typically come with an ESG label. ESG funds still outperformed non-ESG funds, with average quarterly returns of 16.96% compared to 14.74%. Despite concerns over US President Donald Trump's climate policies, fund managers expect continued investor interest in ESG investing, citing global initiatives to address climate change and growing demand for sustainable practices.

images.alt_text: Whether you like or believe in them or not, both climate change and the clean-energy transition create risks and opportunities for companies. It’s bad business to ignore them.
COP29 saw 150 countries pledge to collectively deploy 1,500 gigawatts of energy storage by 2030, six times the level of 2022.
Lush forests seen at the Southern Cardamom project, which protects 497,000 ha of tropical rainforest in South-west Cambodia.

The huge shortfall in climate finance at COP29, coupled with unfinished details on how the rest of the money is to be mobilised, leaves emerging markets, many of which are in Asia, facing the daunting task of having to undertake system-wide energy transition efforts, implement climate adaptation projects and cope with natural disasters all on a tight budget.

site_title: Stamford Tyres H1 profit tumbles 75.1% to S$401,000 on increased expenses
summary: Stamford Tyres reported a 75.1% decrease in net profit to S$401,000 for the half-year ended Oct 31, primarily due to a 1.2% decline in revenue to S$94.5 million. The company's gross profit margin remained stable at 25.3%, while other operating expenses increased 89.6% to S$2.9 million. Stamford Tyres attributed the decline to lower sales in the South-east Asia market and increased costs.

images.alt_text: Stamford Tyres' executive director Dawn Wee Wai Ying becomes executive chairman
For over 50 years, Wee was at the helm of Stamford Tyres, which grew from a family-run business to a multinational operating in 11 countries.

site_title: South Korea’s acting president moves to reassure allies, calm markets after impeachment
summary: South Korea's acting President Han Duck-soo reassured allies and calmed markets after President Yoon Suk-yeol was impeached and suspended over a martial law attempt. Han spoke with US President Joe Biden, affirming the US-South Korea alliance and pledging to maintain military readiness. The main opposition party announced it would not seek to impeach Han, citing the need for stability. Han vowed to exercise minimum power as acting president and convened a meeting with his Cabinet and National Security Council. The Constitutional Court has up to six months to decide on Yoon's fate, leading to uncertainty over South Korea's leadership.

images.alt_text: Protesters in Seoul celebrate after the result of the second martial law impeachment vote was announced on Saturday. Lawmakers successfully voted to remove Yoon from office for his failed attempt to impose martial law.

Demonstrators call for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 7, 2024.

site_title: The message: Impeach South Korea’s president. The tune: Feliz Navidad
summary: Tens of thousands of South Korean protesters danced to traditional percussion, sang a pop genre called trot, and blasted the song "Whiplash" by girl group Aespa, calling for President Yoon Suk-yeol's removal. The protest anthem, "Feliz Navidad," was created by musician Baek Jae-gil, who has been protesting for decades. The song's repeated opening verse says "Impeachment is the answer." The adaptation has spread on social media, with a recording receiving nine million views on X. Protests have become more peaceful and the mood has lightened since Baek's first rally in 1989, a time of brutal suppression.

images.alt_text: Protesters attending a candlelight vigil demanding the impeachment of South Korea President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 13.

site_title: China’s GDP growth expected around 5% this year, senior official says
summary: China's GDP growth is expected to reach around 5% this year, contributing approximately 30% of global growth, according to a senior official. Deputy director Han Wenxiu emphasized the need to boost consumption and view domestic demand expansion as a long-term strategic move to drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: epa11774533 Costumers look on in the booth selling toys, Christmas and New Year decorations on the Arts & Crafts Market in Yiwu, Zhejiang Province, China, 13 December 2024. The 'Christmas Village' in Yiwu, China, is renowned among international traders as the global epicenter of festive decorations, located in International Trade City, spanning on 340,000 square meters and features over 9,000 booths with 10,500 business operators, which according to government data, 60 percent of all Christmas decorations sold worldwide are produced in one of the 600 factories within the village.  EPA-EFE/ALEX PLAVEVSKI

China's consumer and business confidence remains sluggish, contributing to persistent deflation. Prices across the economy have been falling for six straight quarters, the longest streak this century.

Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.

site_title: Malaysian veteran dives water hazards for sunken golf treasure
summary: Veteran Malaysian diver Sumadi Ibrahim, 51, has retired from the navy and now makes a living by diving water hazards at a golf course in Selangor state, collecting between 500-600 golf balls per expedition. He uses his specialized skills to identify balls and collects them by hand, selling them back to golfers. His work, which he started in 2012, earns him up to RM8,000 per month, nearly three times the median monthly salary of formally employed Malaysians. Sumadi sees his work as a small contribution to sustainability, as he removes plastic and rubber golf balls from the ecosystem.

site_title: Staff at UK luxury store Harrods vote to strike
summary: Staff at UK luxury store Harrods have voted to strike on Dec 21-22 and Dec 26, targeting busy retail days, in a dispute over pay and working conditions. The United Voices of the World UVW union said management's refusal to recognize or engage with the union led to the decision. The strike coincides with traditionally busy end-of-year sales, including Boxing Day.

images.alt_text: Al Fayed controlled far-flung enterprises in oil, shipping, banking and real estate, including the palatial Ritz Hotel in Paris and, for 25 years, the storied London retail emporium Harrods.

The new club, called The Residence, will open at the end of this year on the second floor of Cha House, a central Shanghai heritage building where a Harrods tea room and bar, which are open to public, are already located.

site_title: Can you buy too much health insurance for your own good?
summary: Singaporeans and permanent residents may be overinsuring themselves, paying costly premiums for health insurance policies with overlapping coverage. Data from the CPF Board shows 57% of those with higher coverage opted for subsidized wards, despite having multiple policies. Experts warn that individuals should carefully select and utilize their policies, focusing on protection rather than investments, and not be tied to high financial commitments. A balanced approach, allocating 10-15% of income for insurance, is recommended, and individuals should assess their needs and assets before committing to insurance plans.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical companies charge different prices in different countries for the same drugs. Income level and negotiating power are key factors. But in these aspects, Singapore is at a disadvantage because of its small population and relatively high GDP per capita.
By taking control of your medical insurance, you can navigate the complexities of health coverage while safeguarding your financial well-being.
As we live longer, keeping physically fit and economically active become more important.
The latest review, conducted by the 11-member MediShield Life Council, is chaired by former Nominated Member of Parliament Fang Ai Lian.

site_title: Britain joins trans-Pacific pact in biggest post-Brexit trade deal
summary: Britain officially joined the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) on December 15, 2024, becoming the 12th member of the pact. The agreement allows Britain to apply CPTPP trade rules and lower tariffs with eight existing members, including Japan, Australia, and Canada, from December 15. The pact is worth £2 billion (S$3.4 billion) a year to Britain and gives the country influence over potential future applicants, including China and Taiwan.

images.alt_text: UK Conservative Party leader Kemi Badenoch is optimistic about the CPTPP, and helped promote the deal as a former UK trade and business secretary.
Chan Chun Sing (seated) signing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) FTA on Nov 15, 2020. The RCEP represents the pinnacle of existing FTAs between Asean and China.

site_title: Would you buy a perfume you had never smelled?
summary: Ffern, a luxury perfume subscription service, has gained a large following for its unique approach to fragrance. Founded in 2016 by Owen Mears and his sister Emily Cameron, the company releases four new scents per year, each handmade in small batches from natural ingredients. The perfumes come with evocative backstories and artwork, and customers can try a small sample before committing to a full-size bottle. With a wait list of 500,000 people, Ffern has become a coveted experience for perfume enthusiasts, who appreciate the ritual and storytelling behind each scent.

images.alt_text: A scientist preparing salted egg CulinaPlant chunks at dsm-firmenich's new facility FutureBites, which was launched on Sep 18.
Saudi Arabia’s equity capital markets have been busy this year, with a number of IPOs.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat as Nasdaq extends weekly gains, S&P 500 and Dow dip
summary: US stocks ended flat on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Dow posting weekly declines, while the Nasdaq secured its fourth consecutive week of gains. Broadcom's optimistic forecast of robust growth in demand for its AI chips boosted its shares, pushing its market capitalization past $1 trillion. The Nasdaq surpassed 20,000 for the first time, driven by technology stocks and a solid inflation report that solidified expectations of a 25-basis-point interest rate cut from the US Federal Reserve next week.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street sign in front of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, Dec. 12, 2024. Donald Trump rang the New York Stock Exchange’s opening bell Thursday, a celebratory moment for the president-elect who was returned to the White House in an election in which the US economy took center stage. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 10, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: South Korean lawmakers impeach Yoon over failed martial law bid
summary: South Korean lawmakers have impeached President Yoon Suk-yeol over his failed attempt to impose martial law, with 204 lawmakers voting to remove him and 85 voting against. The opposition declared a "victory of the people" as hundreds of thousands protested in support of removing Yoon. The Constitutional Court has 180 days to rule on Yoon's future, with Prime Minister Han Duck-soo taking over as interim leader. Yoon has vowed to fight on, despite his approval rating plummeting to 11% and 75% of the public supporting his impeachment.

images.alt_text: A man wearing a fat suit and a mask depicting South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol dances during a protest calling for Yoon's ouster outside the National Assembly in Seoul.

site_title: Tuan Sing CEO and director add to stakes
summary: Institutions sold Singapore stocks, resulting in a net institutional outflow of S$104 million from Dec 6 to 12, reversing a S$418 million net inflow in the preceding sessions. The sectors that booked the most net institutional inflow were industrials and utilities, while real estate investment trusts and financial services experienced the most net institutional outflow. Notable director and CEO transactions included William Liem and Michelle Liem increasing their interests in Tuan Sing Holdings, and Ang Yee Lim increasing his stake in ABR Holdings.

images.alt_text: Over the five trading sessions from Nov 29 to Dec 5, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, leading to a net institutional inflow of S$418 million.

site_title: Biden plans measures on AI, clemency and lands in final stretch
summary: US President Joe Biden is racing to finalize key files before a transfer of power that could reverse many of his initiatives. In his final weeks, Biden plans to take action on land protections, clemency, and artificial intelligence, as outlined in a memo to allies. The efforts, which include codifying his legacy, are expected to have long-term impacts, according to White House communications director Ben LaBolt. The moves aim to secure Biden's legacy before Donald Trump's inauguration, which could potentially reverse many of Biden's accomplishments.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden said Donald Trump’s threats to slap huge tariffs on imports were a “major mistake” and challenged Trump to build on what he said were the successes of his own administration.

Donald Trump was found guilty in May of 34 counts of falsifying business records from covering up the payment of US$130,000 to pornographic film actress Stormy Daniels to silence her from coming forward about an alleged extramarital affair during the final stretch of the 2016 election campaign.
(Right) Hunter Biden's case has long been a thorn in the Biden family’s side, particularly during this election year when Republicans have charged that Hunter was being treated too leniently.

site_title: Selena Gomez’s engagement ring has people talking
summary: Selena Gomez has announced her engagement to record producer Benny Blanco, showcasing a marquise diamond engagement ring. The ring, which Gomez has worn in the past, is a nod to her 2015 song "Good for You," in which she sings about being a marquise diamond. The ring's unique shape, dating back to 18th century France, is said to evoke romantic folklore. Estimated to be worth $150,000 to $200,000, the ring reflects Blanco's thoughtfulness and personal touch in choosing a one-of-a-kind piece.

images.alt_text: The pair’s connection dates to at least 2015, when Blanco produced songs for Gomez’s album Revival. They have since worked together on other projects, including Single Soon, a song released by Gomez last year.

site_title: Schools targeted with AI learning apps despite experts' doubts
summary: Experts doubt the effectiveness of artificial intelligence (AI) learning apps in schools, citing concerns over biased algorithms, commercial data use, and limited educational outcomes. Despite the rapid adoption of AI in education, the UN's Unesco has warned of a "tragedy" of increased inequality and worsened learning outcomes. Many educators, including Unesco's Manos Antoninis, argue that AI is not a panacea and that technology should be used as a tool to support human teachers, rather than replace them.

images.alt_text: OpenAI has unveiled a full roll-out of Sora, its video-generation tool, as well as Canvas, a writing and coding product.

site_title: US court rejects Tiktok request to temporarily halt pending US ban
summary: A US appeals court rejected an emergency bid by TikTok to temporarily block a law requiring its Chinese parent company ByteDance to divest the short-video app by January 19 or face a ban. The court's decision means TikTok must quickly move to the US Supreme Court to halt the pending ban, which could shut down the app for its 170 million domestic monthly users. The ban is set to take effect unless ByteDance divests TikTok by the deadline.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tik Tok logos are seen on smartphones in front of a displayed ByteDance logo in this illustration taken November 27, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The US Justice Department said the court should not delay the law’s effective date arguing “continued Chinese control of the TikTok application poses a continuing threat to national security.”
TikTok Shop – which combines video with impulse buying in visual fashion – is the app’s biggest growth engine after advertising.

site_title: Databricks nears record US$9.5 billion VC raise, eyes extra US$4.5 billion debt
summary: Databricks is nearing a record-breaking US$9.5 billion venture capital raise, with investors including Thrive Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, Insight Partners, and GIC. The round is expected to value the company at over US$60 billion, with a price of US$92.50 per share. In conjunction with the equity raise, Databricks is also seeking US$4.5 billion in debt financing. The deal would be one of the largest venture capital funding rounds in history and marks a significant jump in valuation for the 11-year-old company.

images.alt_text: Databricks’ new tool will continuously learn from individual customer data to better understand queries, says chief executive officer Ali Ghodsi.

site_title: NRIC should not be treated as sensitive unique identifiers: MDDI
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Digital Development and Information (MDDI) says National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers should not be treated as sensitive information, but rather as full names. This comes after public concern over the availability of full NRIC numbers on the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority's (Acra) Bizfile online portal. The portal has been temporarily disabled due to public anxiety, and MDDI and the Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) will conduct public education efforts to help Singaporeans adjust to the new approach.

images.alt_text: ACRA’s data policy indicates that the types of personal data publicly available include names, identification numbers and residential addresses, if no contact address is given.

site_title: The troubled history of South Korean presidents
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol faces a second impeachment vote after declaring martial law last week. He is not the first South Korean president to face impeachment and scandal, following in the footsteps of Park Geun-hye, who was impeached and jailed for corruption in 2016-2017, and Lee Myung-bak, who was sentenced to 15 years in prison for corruption in 2018. Other past presidents, including Roh Moo-hyun, who died by suicide in 2009, and Chun Doo-hwan, who was pardoned after serving just two years in jail, have also faced controversy and scandal, highlighting a troubled history of South Korean presidents.

images.alt_text: South Korea Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (bottom right) highlighted growing downside risks and efforts to stabilise foreign exchange markets using common smoothing operations.

FILE Ñ President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea in Seoul on Sept. 14, 2022. Yoon, who briefly declared martial law on Dec. 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.  (Woohae Cho/The New York Times)

site_title: The New York luxury housing market is back
summary: New York City's luxury housing market is experiencing a resurgence, with prices easing, new developments offering options, and borrowing costs stabilizing. In November, the market saw its strongest performance in three years, with 90 luxury home deals worth over $5 million signed. Buyers, such as Rajiv Khanna, took advantage of the moment when rates remained high and prices were dropping. Developers like Naftali Group and Related Cos. cut prices at luxury projects, and sales at new developments climbed 12% in November. The market is expected to continue growing, with top brokers predicting a return to the 1980s era of ostentatious wealth and conspicuous consumption.

images.alt_text: seattle, space needle, skyline
Pending home sales rose 5.4 per cent from a year earlier and all four regions saw month-over-month and year-over-year increases.
New home sales plunged 17.3 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 610,000 units last month, the lowest level since December 2022.
House prices jumped 0.7 per cent on a month-on-month basis after an upwardly revised 0.4 per cent rise in August.

site_title: Manchester City crisis puts rivals United’s malaise in the shade ahead of Sunday derby
summary: Manchester City's dismal 2-0 defeat by Juventus has raised concerns about manager Pep Guardiola's golden era, with pundits declaring the end of his era. City have won just once in their last 10 matches and sit fourth in the EPL standings, eight points behind leaders Liverpool. Meanwhile, Manchester United, who sacked Erik ten Hag in October, are struggling under new manager Ruben Amorim, sitting 13th in the table. The two teams face off in Sunday's derby, with City's fragility and United's malaise making it an intriguing matchup.

images.alt_text: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola gestures towards fans after the English Premier League match between Liverpool and Manchester City in Liverpool, England, Dec 1, 2024.

site_title: Issue 129: LReit’s new debt sticks to sustainability-linked structure; Oxford Economics weighs food cost of net zero
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (LReit) has secured up to S$760 million of sustainable-linked debt facilities, with 85% of its committed debt linked to sustainability performance indicators. The new facilities aim to tie financial performance to sustainability outcomes, aligning shareholders with the company's other stakeholder groups. However, the exact sustainability-linked structures and interest increments are unknown, and LReit's interim targets and KPIs need to be credible to make the sustainability-linked loans meaningful. A report by Oxford Economics estimates that net-zero policy measures could raise food production costs in South-east Asia by 30.8% to 58.9% by 2050.

The accord comes as China’s solar industry contends with overcapacity, heightened geopolitical tensions and slowing demand.
Iata director general Willie Walsh pointed to a lack of biorefineries under construction which could produce the green jet fuel, many of which require extensive capital expenditure to get built.
Goldman Sachs' decision comes against a backdrop of pressure from some Republican politicians who have suggested that membership of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA) could breach anti-trust rules.

site_title: Skoda Kodiaq and Enyaq RS review: Czech out this dynamic duo
summary: Skoda's new Kodiaq and Enyaq RS models have been reviewed, showcasing the brand's versatility and attention to detail. The Kodiaq, a seven-seat SUV, boasts a sculptural new face and a spacious cabin, making it ideal for family use. Its 1.5-litre engine provides a comfortable drive, despite not being a thrill-seeker. In contrast, the Enyaq RS, an electric SUV, feels too big and heavy to be truly sporty, but its interior is premium and feature-rich. The Enyaq RS is available in a more affordable Sportline variant, making it a worth considering option.

images.alt_text: As the brand’s new flagship, the Revuelto takes the torch from the boisterous Aventador and carries it with characteristic Lamborghini brazenness.

site_title: Heavy rains to hit Malaysian palm oil output again in December
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production is expected to decline for the fourth consecutive month in December due to heavy rainfall, with a potential reduction of 5-20% in crude palm oil production. The country's palm oil production in November fell 9.8% to 1.62 million metric tons, the lowest since 2020. Heavy rainfall has caused floods in Peninsular Malaysia and southern Thailand, damaging homes, transport links, and crops. The decline in production could curb inventories and boost benchmark futures, which are near their highest levels in 2.5 years.

images.alt_text: Malaysia, the world’s second-largest palm oil producer, is in a strategic position to become one of the world’s leading SAF producers.
Above: Harvested palm oil fruit. The company says crude palm oil prices will continue to be influenced by shifts in supply and demand, and currency and financial market uncertainty.

site_title: Oil up 2%, settles at 3-week high as more sanctions loom on Russia, Iran
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday, settling at a three-week high, due to expectations of tighter sanctions on Russia and Iran, as well as lower interest rates in Europe and the US boosting fuel demand. Brent futures rose $1.08 to $74.49 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $1.27 to $71.29 a barrel. The International Energy Agency forecast a 1.1 million barrel-per-day increase in global oil demand growth in 2025, citing China's stimulus measures, while US sanctions on Iran are expected to tighten supplies and boost logistics costs.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 11 cents, or 0.15 per cent, lower at US$73.41 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Currencies drop as China disappointment rattles emerging markets
summary: Emerging-market currencies declined as China's Central Economic Work Conference ended without policy details on fiscal stimulus, despite authorities' pledge to boost consumption. The MSCI EM equity index fell 0.5% to pare weekly gains, while Chinese equities declined, driving benchmark EM indices lower. Analysts attribute the downturn to China's weak growth signals and skepticism around official statistics, exacerbating pessimism about emerging markets and the US dollar's potential impact.

images.alt_text: Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.
Generic photo for stories regarding Green Buildings and Sustainable Buildings. Part of Singapore Green Plan 2030 to change the way people live, work, study and play
The International Finance Corporation and HSBC Holding's new partnership aims to help banks in emerging markets increase lending for trade.

FILE PHOTO: Former U.S. President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and U.S. Representative Elise Stefanik (R-NY) attend a rally ahead of the New Hampshire primary election in Concord, New Hampshire, U.S. January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Elizabeth Frantz/File Photo

Investors are still trying the gauge paths for global interest rates and the dollar under a new Trump administration. Trump's tariff plans are likely to take a disproportionate toll on some larger emerging markets, such as Mexico and China.
Analysts predict Beijing could announce as much as 2 trillion yuan (S$369.4 billion) in new fiscal support on Saturday.

site_title: Vibrant Group returns to black with S$3.3 million H1 profit
summary: Vibrant Group, a logistics company, has posted a net profit of S$3.3 million for the half-year ended Oct 31, reversing from a loss of S$3.2 million in the previous period. The company attributes its performance to improved shipping revenue, increased other income, and finance income. Revenue rose 12.4% to S$78.7 million, driven by higher sea freight rates and increased cargo volumes. Earnings per share for H1 stood at S$0.0049, compared to a loss per share of S$0.0047 previously.

images.alt_text: Singapore on Wednesday unveiled a slew of initiatives to cut shipping emissions at its port.

site_title: HSBC sent fintech Stenn into administration over fears about client list
summary: HSBC triggered the administration of fintech firm Stenn Technologies due to concerns over the legitimacy of its relationships with large customers in Taiwan and Japan. The bank suspected that Stenn may have received funds from entities impersonating these clients, leading to the forced administration of two of Stenn's UK companies, resulting in job losses for most employees. Stenn had claimed to provide billions of US dollars in trade finance to its customers, but the true nature of its relationships remains unclear.

images.alt_text: Stenn Technologies' UK units entered administration after HSBC flagged potential irregularities in some of the company's transactions.

site_title: France’s Macron names centrist ally Bayrou as new prime minister
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron named centrist leader Francois Bayrou as prime minister, tasked with forming a government after the toppling of Michel Barnier's government in a historic no-confidence vote. Bayrou, the sixth prime minister of Macron's mandate, faces an immediate challenge to form a Cabinet that can survive a no-confidence vote and thrash out a 2025 budget to limit economic turmoil. His appointment sparked criticism from hard-left France Unbowed and the Greens, who threaten to back a new motion of censure.

images.alt_text: Macron has more than two years of his presidential term left, but some opponents are calling on him to resign.
French Prime Minister Michel Barnier will be the shortest-serving prime minister in modern French history after he hands in his resignation.

A screen shows the result of the no-confidence vote against the French prime minister and his government at the National Assembly, Paris, France, Dec 4, 2024. The government lost the no-confidence vote after a total of 331 members of the parliament voted in favour of the motion.

site_title: Seattle developer Selig expects to default on more office debt
summary: Seattle developer Martin Selig Real Estate is expected to default on a US$379 million loan tied to nine office properties in downtown Seattle by April due to high vacancy rates, which average 33% across the buildings. The company has already received a 60-day forbearance on a US$239 million loan and is trying to modify the loan before the end of the year. This comes as the urban commercial real estate sector faces challenges from post-pandemic work patterns, high interest rates, and depressed downtowns.

images.alt_text: In Seattle, roughly 25 per cent of downtown office space was vacant in the third quarter, according to data from brokerage CBRE Group.

site_title: Tight supply expected to provide support for cocoa, coffee prices in 2025
summary: Cocoa and coffee prices are expected to ease from historical highs in 2025, but remain elevated due to supply disruptions caused by the severe El Nino phenomenon in 2024. The Ivory Coast and Ghana, which account for 60% of global cocoa supply, oversold their production, and aggressive hedge-fund buying and increased margin requirements have driven up prices. Forecasters expect cocoa prices to average around $7,200 in 2024 and $5,900 in 2025, while Arabica coffee prices are expected to ease from their current high base, averaging around $2.15 per pound in 2025.

images.alt_text: Founded in the late 19th century, Hershey is known for its chocolate and candy brands including Hershey’s Kisses, Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups and PayDay.
Mondelez makes Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies as well as Toblerone chocolate bars.
Ponteh roast turkey from Fullerton Hotel Singapore.
Jollibee tends to grow its presence in countries with a large number of Philippine expats, analysts say.
Global coffee supplies are tightening after several years of disappointing crops in the South American nation.

site_title: US import prices rise marginally in November
summary: US import prices rose 0.1% in November, edging up from a 0.1% decline in October, as a strong US dollar partially offset increases in food and fuel costs. Despite a 1.3% year-over-year increase in import prices, the improvement in inflation has stalled, with no noticeable deterioration. The US central bank's benchmark interest rate remains in the 4.5-4.75% range, with economists anticipating a 25 basis point interest rate cut next Wednesday, and potentially fewer rate cuts next year due to President-elect Donald Trump's plans to increase tariffs.

images.alt_text: The wholesale inflation data follow the more closely watched consumer price index, which showed on Wednesday that underlying inflation remained firm for a fourth month.
Claims are likely to remain volatile in the weeks ahead, which could make it difficult to get a clear read on the labour market.
The annual increase in inflation has slowed considerably from a peak of 9.1 per cent in June 2022.
US President Joe Biden said Donald Trump’s threats to slap huge tariffs on imports were a “major mistake” and challenged Trump to build on what he said were the successes of his own administration.
The so-called core consumer price index (CPI)  that excludes food and energy is seen rising 0.3 per cent in November from a month before.

site_title: Boeing invests US$1 billion to boost 787 production
summary: Boeing invests $1 billion to boost 787 Dreamliner production to 10 aircraft per month by 2026, creating 500 jobs in South Carolina. The investment aims to address production quality issues and follows a recent strike that paralyzed two factories. Boeing has also announced plans to reduce its global workforce by 10% and has resumed production of the 737 and 777 models. The company's order book stands at over 6,200 aircraft, with 33,000 US workers previously striking over production quality concerns.

images.alt_text: Boeing said it restarted 737 MAX production, loading fresh fuselages into its Seattle-area Renton factory, after weeks of methodical preparation.

site_title: Indonesia’s central bank conducts intervention to support rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank intervened in the foreign exchange market to support the rupiah, which fell to a four-month low against the dollar due to a resilient US economy and growing geopolitical tensions between China and Taiwan. The rupiah dropped 0.44% to 15,990 a dollar. The intervention aims to maintain confidence in the currency.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 snaps three-week winning streak
summary: European stocks snapped a three-week winning streak, with the Stoxx 600 index losing 0.5% to hit a more-than one-week low. The decline came amid concerns over slowing economic growth and a potential trade war. The pan-European index ended the week about 0.8% lower. Despite a struggling economy, the DAX is near an all-time high due to most companies not being heavily exposed to domestic factors.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, December 13, 2024.    REUTERS/Staff
The Stoxx 600 index closed Thursday's choppy session at 519.20 points, down 0.14 per cent, although rate-sensitive eurozone bank shares edged up 0.3 per cent.

site_title: India's rice stocks surge to record high, boosting export prospects
summary: India's rice stocks surged to a record high of 44.1 million metric tons as of December 1, exceeding the government's target of 7.6 million tons. This surplus could boost overseas shipments without jeopardizing domestic supplies, allowing India to remove export curbs on all rice grades except broken rice. The country's summer rice crop of 120 million tons accounts for nearly 85% of its total rice output, with the Food Corporation of India expected to buy 48.5 million metric tons of new rice in the marketing year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A farmer harvests rice on a rice paddy field outside Hanoi, Vietnam, June 7, 2018. REUTERS/KhamÊ/File Photo

site_title: Bolder biotech investments, not less, is key to better health outcomes for all
summary: Large pharma companies have clear mandates and resources for cutting-edge R&D, particularly in AI and biologics, to improve health outcomes. Despite rising healthcare costs globally, driven by ageing populations and inflation, the evidence of an association between costs and quality outcomes is inconsistent. To address this, the focus should be on expanding access to treatments and increasing the types of patients that can benefit from them, rather than reducing investment. This will help to drive better health outcomes for all, rather than just a select few.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Eli Lilly logo is shown on one of the company's offices in San Diego, California, U.S., September 17, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

Oxford Nanopore's CEO Gordon Sanghera said: "You can take these science breakthroughs and turn them into real-world applications, whether that is diagnostics, healthcare, food industry contamination or biopharmaceuticals."

site_title: Worker shortages raise doubts over Britain’s plan to build for growth
summary: The UK's construction sector faces significant worker shortages, with skilled workers nearing retirement age and a lack of young people entering the workforce. The government aims to build 1.5 million homes by 2029, but experts say this goal is unachievable without addressing worker and skills shortages. Industry experts point to a need for better training and a more diverse workforce, and some suggest revising the post-Brexit immigration system to meet the sector's needs. The government has announced plans to increase apprenticeships, but critics argue that the process for sponsoring foreign workers is too complex and costly.

site_title: The ‘Christmas’ of the year’s financial highlights
summary: Key financial highlights of 2024 include the closure of Singapore's Special Account (SA) for those aged 55 and above, with balances to be transferred to the Retirement Account (RA) and Ordinary Account (OA). The Enhanced Retirement Sum will be further increased to four times the Basic Retirement Sum or S$426,000. New HDB framework classifies Build-To-Order flats as Prime, Plus, or Standard, with Prime flats subject to tighter conditions. The average life expectancy in Singapore is projected to reach 83 years by 2026, highlighting the importance of retirement savings. Scammers have made record wins in 2022, with a staggering S$660.7 million lost across 31,728 cases. Meanwhile, Treasury bills (T-bills) are losing their lustre due to a falling interest rate environment.

Good money habits empower you to make informed decisions, better handle emergencies, and help you to work towards your financial goals and achieve sustainable financial wellness.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, December 13, 2024
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, December 13, 2024, following China's pledge to reform its economy, which failed to spark excitement. DigiCo REIT shares plummeted 9% after Australia's largest IPO since 2018. Thailand expects to collect the global minimum corporate tax starting January 2025. In contrast, Xiaomi's stock surged 103% this year due to strong electric vehicle sales.

images.alt_text: Shares fell in Tokyo even as the Bank of Japan’s closely watched Tankan survey indicated a slight increase in confidence among Japan’s major manufacturers.

Pichai Chunhavajira, Thailand’s finance minister, speaks at a news conference in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. site_title: Macquarie said to bid for Axiata’s telecom infrastructure arm
summary: Macquarie has submitted a bid to acquire Axiata Group's telecom infrastructure unit, edotco Group, valued at approximately US$3.5 billion. Axiata, Malaysia's largest cellular firm, owns about 63% of edotco. The bid follows Innovation Network Corp of Japan's (INCJ) decision to sell its 21% stake in edotco, which must be unloaded by the end of March. Axiata has yet to make a decision on the offer, and edotco may also receive other bids.

images.alt_text: Beyond Japan, Macquarie has been actively investing across Asia-Pacific with more than US$16 billion managed under its infrastructure fund series.

site_title: China sets up AI standards committee as global tech race intensifies
summary: China establishes an artificial intelligence standards committee to balance regulation and development, amid global concerns over safety and ethics. The 41-member committee, including Baidu and Peking University, will focus on large language models and AI risk assessment. China's proactive regulatory stance on AI follows its earlier hands-off approach to mobile Internet and e-commerce. The move aims to position China as a standard-setter in the AI field, as global competition intensifies.

images.alt_text: OpenAI has unveiled a full roll-out of Sora, its video-generation tool, as well as Canvas, a writing and coding product.
Profit was US$1.42 a share in the period, excluding some items, Broadcom said in a statement on Thursday.
Google this week announced the launch of Gemini 2.0, its most advanced artificial intelligence model to date, as the world’s tech giants race to take the lead in the fast-developing technology.
In a Florida lawsuit filed in October, a mother claimed the platform bears responsibility for her 14-year-old son’s suicide.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (second from left) and Minister of Digital Gobind Singh Deo at the launch of National AI Office on Thursday (Dec 12) in Kuala Lumpur.
Nvidia Corp's offices in Shanghai, China, Dec 10, 2024. Nvidia is expanding its headcount globally as it works to fulfill runaway demand for its artificial intelligence chips.

site_title:
UOB names its corporate banking head 
Leong Yung Chee as new group CFO
summary: UOB appoints Leong Yung Chee as its new group CFO, effective April 22, 2025, replacing Lee Wai Fai after 20 years. Leong, current head of group corporate banking, brings 25 years of experience in financial services to the role. He will oversee key functions including finance, treasury, and data management. Leong will work closely with Lee as CFO-designate until his official start.

images.alt_text: Current UOB head of group retail Eddie Khoo (right) will retire from the role, with  head of group technology and operations Susan Hwee succeeding him.
Singapore shares end flat amid mixed Asia markets as investors digest China’s monetary easing plans
Wee receiving the Distinguished Service Order Medal from then president Tony Tan at the National Day awards in 2011.
The loan will be used to refinance an existing S$4 billion seven-year borrowing from August 2019, sources said.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after Broadcom’s upbeat forecast
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday after Broadcom's upbeat forecast boosted chip stocks and kept the euphoria around artificial intelligence alive. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 15.0 points, or 0.03%, to 43,929.15, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, rising 16.9 and 92.3 points, respectively, at the open.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 13)
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Dec 13 amid mixed Asia markets, as investors digested China's monetary easing plans. Meanwhile, UOB appointed Leong Yung Chee as its new group CFO, while a quartet of freehold conservation shophouses in District 7 were put up for sale at S$37 million. The search function on online portal Bizfile raised concerns over citizens' privacy, allowing users to search for NRIC numbers of some citizens. A full takeover of Bank Pan Indonesia could add 2-3% to DBS or OCBC's profit, according to RHB.

site_title: Construction sector fatalities trebled in second half of 2024: MOM
summary: Singapore's construction sector has seen a significant increase in fatalities, tripling to 15 in the second half of 2024, according to the Ministry of Manpower. The majority of incidents were caused by a lack of basic safety measures or non-compliance with established regulations, leading to a sense of complacency among companies. In response, the ministry has stepped up safety enforcement efforts, issuing over 400 inspections and fines totaling S$300,000. The ministry warns that further non-compliance will result in stronger actions against violators, emphasizing its "zero tolerance" for workplace safety and health regulations.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong

site_title: Manchester City announce record revenue for 2023-24 season
summary: Manchester City reported a record revenue of £715 million for the 2023-24 season, driven by increased matchday and commercial revenue but weighed down by a decrease in broadcasting revenue due to the Champions League quarter-final exit. The club also made a record profit of £139 million on player sales. Despite this, the club's overall pre-tax profit decreased by 8% to £73.8 million. Manchester City chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak attributed the success to the club's "constant ambition" and "deliberate and detailed planning."

images.alt_text: Manchester City's Portuguese midfielder Bernardo Silva (left) and Juventus' Brazilian defender Danilo in action   during the Champions League, league match at the Allianz stadium in Turin on Wednesday.
Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola reacts after his team's 2-0 Champions League defeat to Juventus, Turin, Italy, Dec 11, 2024.

site_title: Schroders seeks buyers for Indonesia unit with US$4 billion in assets: sources
summary: Schroders is seeking buyers for its Indonesian unit, which manages approximately US$4 billion in assets. The move is part of a broader strategy shift under new CEO Richard Oldfield, who aims to trim underperforming units. At least four firms, including HSBC, Allianz, and Indonesia's BNI, are reportedly interested in acquiring the business. This comes after a three-decade struggle to grow its business in Indonesia, with the company's shares hitting an 11-year low.

images.alt_text: Beyond Japan, Macquarie has been actively investing across Asia-Pacific with more than US$16 billion managed under its infrastructure fund series.
Leong Yung Chee takes over as UOB CFO on Apr 22, 2025.

site_title: Securing the future: How Web3 empowers privacy in green cars
summary: Web3 technologies are transforming the security and privacy of green cars, empowering them to become secure, efficient mobile forts. Advanced sensors in these vehicles collect vast data, raising concerns about privacy breaches. However, the adoption of Web3 technologies addresses these concerns by embodying the cypherpunk ethos, ensuring personal data protection while maintaining transparency about data usage. Technologies such as federated computing, Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs), Zero Knowledge Proofs, and Multi-party Computation are being applied to boost privacy and security in green cars, including secure payment processing, predictive maintenance, and navigation capabilities.

images.alt_text: Despite the substantial market demand for charging stations, the upfront costs of investing in and constructing the infrastructure are considerable, making them inaccessible to retail investors.

site_title: Indonesia president suggests scrapping regional elections to cut costs
summary: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto suggested scrapping the country's second nationwide election to cut costs, proposing a model similar to the authoritarian rule of the past three decades. Under this plan, regional legislatures would choose mayors and governors instead, freeing up funds for school upgrades and meals. Critics, including a political analyst, have expressed concerns that this move could undermine democracy and accountability.

images.alt_text: Indonesian parliament members sit as President Joko Widodo delivers a speech ahead of Independence Day, at the parliament building in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 16, 2019. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: Global M&A deal value will hit ‘middling’ US$3.5 trillion by end-2024: Bain
summary: Bain & Company projects the global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) market to reach a "middling" US$3.5 trillion in value by the end of 2024, with a 7% increase in transaction volume. Despite macroeconomic tailwinds, dealmakers failed to achieve expected positive momentum due to high interest rates, low seller willingness to exit, and regulatory scrutiny. The most effective dealmakers adapted quickly to market realities and leveraged revenue and cost synergies, while early adopters of generative AI reported reduced manual effort and faster timelines.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index is on track for its first annual gain since 2019, rising more than 18 per cent so far this year, boosted by a sharp rally in September.

site_title: China bank lending rises far less expected in November
summary: China's bank lending rose less than expected in November, with new yuan loans totaling 580 billion yuan, missing analysts' forecast of 990 billion yuan. This weak credit demand highlights the economy's struggles, prompting policymakers to pledge more stimulus measures, including increasing the budget deficit and cutting interest rates. The government has already launched a debt package and tax incentives to spur demand and ease financial burdens. The central bank's growth target for this year remains at around 5%, and policymakers aim to maintain this target for next year.

images.alt_text: Monetary policy support will be critical to China’s economy next year as the US president-elect has vowed to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: Australian immigration falls for first time in two years
summary: Australia's net overseas migration fell to 446,000 in the year ended June 2024, down from 536,000 a year earlier, marking the first decline in two years. The drop was largely attributed to a 25% decrease in international student arrivals, with the number of student visa holders falling to 207,000. This move was part of the government's crackdown on international student visas, including higher fees and a proposed cap, which negatively impacted the country's global reputation for tertiary education.

site_title: Ability to search for citizens’ IC numbers on Acra’s Bizfile raises privacy concerns
summary: Singapore's Bizfile portal has raised privacy concerns after allowing users to search for citizens' National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers, which are likely to be shareholders or directors of private companies. The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) manages the portal, exempted from the Personal Data Protection Act, citing that holders of personal data are responsible for complying with the law. The issue sparked concerns after veteran journalist Bertha Henson highlighted it on Facebook, with some users able to search for current politicians and deceased persons' NRIC numbers.

images.alt_text: There are currently 2,900 corporate service providers are registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority.
Second Finance Minister Indranee Rajah also fielded questions from MPs, as several sought clarifications on the requirement for CSPs to arrange for nominee directors to be fit and proper.

site_title: German exports fall more than expected in October
summary: Germany's exports fell 2.8% in October to 124.6 billion euros, exceeding expectations of a 2% decline. Exports to the US plummeted 14.2% to 12.2 billion euros, while those to China dropped 3.8% to 6.9 billion euros. The trade surplus narrowed to 13.4 billion euros. Weak demand for key exports has driven a slowdown in Europe's largest economy, which contracted last year and is expected to contract again in 2024 before a modest recovery in 2025.

images.alt_text: The government will cap the costs of electricity transmission at 3 US cents per kilowatt-hour, partly finance the costs of the transmission grids and ensure that transmission grid fees do not increase in 2025.

site_title: Sotheby’s lays off more than 100 staffers globally as auction sales slump
summary: Sotheby's has laid off over 100 staff members globally, accounting for 6% of its workforce, amid shrinking auction revenue. The cutbacks come after the company received a $1 billion cash infusion from Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund. The layoffs affect junior employees, client services executives, and long-serving specialists, with no previously scheduled sales cancelled. The move follows a 25% decline in auction sales in the first half of 2024, attributed to reduced interest rates, a volatile Chinese economy, and a shrinking supply of top-quality artworks.

images.alt_text: A staff member stands in one of the salons at Sotheby's Maison, the new Asia flagship, during a media tour ahead of its opening in Hong Kong on Jul 27.

The settlement resolves claims that Sotheby’s let at least eight clients cheat New York state from 2010 to 2020 by using “resale certificates” that falsely portrayed them as art dealers entitled to tax exemptions, instead of art collectors.

site_title:
iFast launches dedicated China desk 
to tap Chinese investor needs
summary: Wealth management platform iFast has launched a dedicated China desk in Singapore and Hong Kong to cater to the needs of Chinese investors for offshore wealth allocation. The new desk will help non-Chinese institutions and customers invest in China, with a focus on identifying potential clients and business opportunities. The move aims to deepen connections between iFast's global offices and Chinese clients, while strengthening partnerships and unlocking new opportunities for international business. The desk will be staffed by longstanding iFast China employees with expertise in research, investment advisory, and business development.

images.alt_text: Lim Chung Chun, CEO of iFast Corporation, says that the the company's banking business will be kept "simple".
Shares of iFast were heavily traded, in terms of value, as at 9.31 am on Monday.
The increase in profitability was driven by contributions from its ePension division, as well as improvements across its core wealth management platform business, iFast said.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat amid mixed Asia markets as investors digest China’s monetary easing plans
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat at 3,810.35, with 793.5 million securities worth S$910.2 million changing hands. China pledged further monetary easing to prepare for increased trade tensions with the US, causing Asian markets to be mixed. Banking stocks were varied, with UOB rising 0.3% and OCBC declining 0.2%. Other Asia-Pacific markets, such as Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi Composite Index, also experienced declines.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit's Guangdong Data Centre in China. The trust's manager says its non-renounceable preferential offering is about 159.9 per cent subscribed.

site_title: CEA considering minimum transaction condition for property agents to renew licence
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) is considering requiring property agents to facilitate a minimum number of transactions to renew their licence. This move aims to ensure high-quality service and professional advice for clients, as agents who do not facilitate transactions regularly may be less familiar with market trends and regulations. From 2021 to 2023, an average of 40% of property agents did not close at least one residential property transaction each year, prompting the review. The CEA will engage industry stakeholders to explore the implementation of such a requirement.

images.alt_text: Ocean Metro Mall is one of four malls whose commercial and property management agreements will not be renewed upon their expiry this month.
While cost savings are important, relocation or right-sizing must make strategic sense for industrialists, says CBRE's Song.
Rents at suburbs business park space, such as the Punggol Digital District, saw a gross effective rent of S$3.46 per square foot per month during Q3, says Cushman & Wakefield.
The warehouse located in the Toh Tuck Industrial Estate has a total gross floor area of 12,492.4 square metres.
Golden Mile Singapore is an integrated development which includes The Golden Mile and Aurea, a new residential tower.

site_title: Facing teen suicide lawsuits, Character.AI rolls out safety measures
summary: Character.AI, a popular AI chatbot platform, has rolled out safety measures in response to lawsuits alleging its chatbots contributed to youth suicide and self-harm. The company, founded by former Google engineers, has developed a separate AI model for users under 18 with stricter content filters and more conservative responses. The platform will now automatically flag suicide-related content and direct users to the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline. Character.AI also plans to introduce parental controls and mandatory break notifications, with the goal of providing a safe space for users.

images.alt_text: The AI features will be available on the latest iPhone series, as well as the Pro and Pro Max versions of the previous iPhone 15 line-up.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (second from left) and Minister of Digital Gobind Singh Deo at the launch of National AI Office on Thursday (Dec 12) in Kuala Lumpur.
Nvidia Corp's offices in Shanghai, China, Dec 10, 2024. Nvidia is expanding its headcount globally as it works to fulfill runaway demand for its artificial intelligence chips.
The broader rollout of Gemini 2.0’s enhanced Search capabilities is scheduled for early 2025, with plans to expand AI Overviews to additional countries and languages throughout the year.

site_title: Thailand expects to collect global minimum corporate tax from Jan 2025
summary: Thailand plans to implement a global minimum corporate tax of 15% starting January 2025, targeting multinational companies with an annual global turnover of over $1.1 billion. The move follows similar actions by other Southeast Asian countries, including Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira stated that the government will urgently issue a law on the tax collection. This marks a significant shift for Thailand's corporate tax, which is currently set at 20%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a press conference after a special cabinet meeting at the Government house in Bangkok, Thailand, September 7, 2024. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: A tale of two cities: Lessons from a US tech hub as Singapore revs up digital economy ambitions
summary: Singapore is seeking to boost its digital economy ambitions by learning from Seattle, a US tech hub. The two cities have strong trade and investment ties, with Singapore receiving a third of Greater Seattle's exports to South-east Asia. Exports to Singapore have nearly doubled, reaching US$1.4 billion in 2023, and 912 jobs have been created in Seattle by companies from South-east Asia, including Grab and Microsoft. Seattle is also attracting tech companies to designate Singapore as a base for their Asia-Pacific operations. Both cities are investing in artificial intelligence, and Singapore aims to become a global leader in AI development.

images.alt_text: Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.

site_title: Four North Bridge Road shophouses up for sale at S$37 million guide price
summary: Four freehold conservation shophouses in District 7, Singapore, are up for sale via an EOI exercise at a guide price of S$37 million. The properties, totaling 5,765 sq ft, are zoned for commercial use and one is approved for a massage-spa establishment. Located 100m from Sultan Mosque and 10 minutes from Bugis MRT, the shophouses offer excellent exposure for businesses. The EOI exercise closes on January 10, 2025, with the potential for buyers to extend the second level to increase outdoor terrace area.

images.alt_text: Total transaction value for shophouses sold in 9M 2024 is up 48.5 per cent from the corresponding period last year at S$519 million.

HDB shophouse rents have been trending upwards as major retaliers start taking over commercial spaces that were previous occupied by traditional mom-and-pop shops, said Clemence Lee, CBRE's capital markets executive director for Singapore.

site_title: Selena Gomez and Benny Blanco are engaged; the Internet rejoices
summary: Selena Gomez and record producer Benny Blanco announced their engagement on social media, with Gomez sharing a stack of pictures of her marquise-cut diamond ring and a video saying "yes" to the proposal. The engagement post received over 15 million likes and comments from Gomez's friend group, including congratulations from celebrities like Taylor Swift, Jennifer Aniston, and Lil Nas X. The pair's relationship dates back to at least 2015, and they have worked together on several projects.

images.alt_text: Cast member Selena Gomez attends a premiere a premiere for season 4 of the television series "Only Murders in the Building" at Paramount Studios in Los Angeles, California, U.S., August 22, 2024. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni

site_title: Panin Bank acquisition could add 2-3% to DBS or OCBC profit: RHB
summary: DBS and OCBC may see a 2-3% profit increase from acquiring Panin Bank, according to RHB. The Jakarta-listed bank's sale is considered attractive due to its scarcity and mid-sized assets of S$19.4 billion. Several Asian banks, including CIMB, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, are reportedly interested in buying Panin Bank, with the Gunawan family also open to joining a sale. However, the impact on DBS and OCBC's profit could be smaller due to uncertainties surrounding the Gunawan family's plans.

images.alt_text: Panin Bank has also drawn interest from other Asian financial institutions, the sources say.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US decrease for third week, falling to 6.6%
summary: US mortgage rates have fallen for a third consecutive week, dropping to 6.6% for a 30-year fixed loan, according to Freddie Mac. This decrease has led to a 4.1% increase in homebuying contracts compared to the same period last year. Despite this, affordability remains a challenge, with the median sale price up 6% and mortgage rates still high. Experts attribute the increase in demand to a combination of declining mortgage rates, strong consumer income growth, and a bullish stock market, but note that affordability headwinds continue to limit the housing market's improvement.

images.alt_text: Extreme weather has driven up insurance costs nationwide. Recent research has found that those rising costs can drive homeowners into delinquency, even if the house avoids damage.

site_title: Trump advisers seek to shrink or eliminate bank regulators: WSJ
summary: US President-elect Trump's transition team is exploring ways to significantly reduce or eliminate top bank regulators, including the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. Advisers have inquired about absorbing deposit insurance into the Treasury Department and merging or restructuring federal bank regulators. Any proposal would require congressional action, and significant job cuts are expected. Trump's task force, led by entrepreneurs Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy, plans a sweeping overhaul of the US government, which has spent $6.8 trillion in the most recent fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Claims are likely to remain volatile in the weeks ahead, which could make it difficult to get a clear read on the labour market.
FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Federal Reserve building is pictured in Washington, March 18, 2008. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo
Recent worse-than-expected data had fuelled speculation the ECB could deliver a hefty, half-percentage-point cut for the first time in its easing cycle.
Bank of America offered foreign-exchange and fixed-income services in the Philippines until early 2000s.

site_title: Former China men’s football coach jailed 20 years for corruption
summary: Former China men's football coach Li Tie was jailed for 20 years for accepting over $10 million in bribes. Li, 47, pleaded guilty earlier this year and was one of China's most recognizable former footballers. The conviction is part of a sweeping crackdown on corruption by Chinese President Xi Jinping, who has also jailed several other former football administrators. The move aims to promote clean governance, but critics say it also serves as a means for Xi to purge political rivals.

images.alt_text: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola reacts after his team's 2-0 Champions League defeat to Juventus, Turin, Italy, Dec 11, 2024.
The combined proposal from Morocco, Spain and Portugal will see the 2030 World Cup take place across three continents and six nations.
Fifa is also set to confirm the hosts of the 2030 and 2034 men’s World Cups on Wednesday.

site_title: UK economy in October suffers first back-to-back declines since 2020
summary: The UK economy contracted by 0.1% in October, marking the first back-to-back decline since the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020. The services sector flatlined, while manufacturing and construction output declined. Finance Minister Rachel Reeves described the data as "disappointing," but vowed to deliver long-term economic growth. Economists expect the government's Budget to boost public investment and spending, leading to faster growth in 2025. Sterling fell against the US dollar, and investors anticipate a possible interest rate cut by the Bank of England in 2025.

images.alt_text: The monthly consumer confidence index from market research firm GfK rose to -17 in December from -18 in November, the highest reading since August.

FILE PHOTO: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves attends a conversation with U.K. CEO of GroupM Karen Blackett, at a fringe meeting during the Labour Party conference in Liverpool, Britain, September 23, 2024. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel DC Reit, Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine
summary: Keppel DC Reit's non-renounceable preferential offering is 159.9% subscribed, with 148.4 million units to be issued at S$2.03 each to raise S$301.3 million. Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine set up a strategic review committee to improve performance and address funding requirements after its auditor issued a disclaimer of opinion on its financial year-end results.

site_title: Singapore, Vietnam firms in talks for new undersea cables: sources
summary: Singaporean asset manager Keppel and Vietnamese conglomerate Sovico Group are in talks for new undersea fiber-optic cables to boost the region's data centre industry. The planned direct cable would link Vietnam to Singapore, costing $150 million, but talks with Keppel are in flux. Vietnam aims to have 10 new submarine cables by 2030 to meet booming demand for AI services and data centers, amid the US-China tech war.

images.alt_text: While cost savings are important, relocation or right-sizing must make strategic sense for industrialists, says CBRE's Song.
Google’s plan is to build the data centres and new power supplies so they connect to the same substation within a state or regional grid, which should help speed up the process to get them online.

site_title: What do the gods of generative AI have in store for 2025?
summary: Artificial intelligence companies OpenAI and Google have unveiled new products, marking a shift from focusing on generative models to developing user-centric tools. OpenAI's Sora video-generation tool and Canvas writing and coding product have been rolled out, while Google's Gemini 2.0 model has been used to power agentic AI products Astra and Mariner. These products, which can take actions on behalf of users, are seen as a significant step forward in AI development, but are also marred by glitches and technical issues. The industry expects agentic AI to be a major breakthrough in 2025, with potential applications in areas such as customer service and workplace automation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: OpenAI logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Gemini logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The new version of the tool will be able to churn out videos up to 20 seconds in length and offer multiple variations of those clips.
Meta said that movie Gen also can generate background music and sound effects synced to the content of the videos.

site_title: 5 Asian business titans who died in 2024, and their giant legacies
summary: Five Asian business titans who died in 2024, leaving giant legacies in various industries, include Wee Cho Yaw, Ananda Krishnan, Ratan Tata, Hirotake Yano, and Zong Qinghou. Wee, a Singaporean banker, expanded UOB's global network and assets, while Ananda built Malaysia's second-largest telco and held significant stakes in oilfield services. Ratan Tata transformed Tata Group into an international enterprise, while Yano pioneered the dollar-shop business model with Daiso Industries. Zong Qinghou, founder of Wahaha Group, rose from poverty to become China's richest man.

images.alt_text: Wee receiving the Distinguished Service Order Medal from then president Tony Tan at the National Day awards in 2011.

site_title: Bain offers to buy Australia’s Insignia in A$2.7 billion deal
summary: US private equity firm Bain Capital has made a non-binding and indicative offer to buy Australian financial services firm Insignia Financial for approximately A$2.7 billion (S$2.3 billion). The proposal, valued at A$4 cash per share, represents a more than 30% premium to the company's shares. Insignia will consider the offer, which comes as Australian listed wealth managers become attractive takeover targets for foreign investors. The deal, if accepted, would value Insignia at A$319.6 billion, a significant portion of which is managed by the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Bain Capital is displayed on the screen during a news conference in Tokyo, Japan October 5, 2017. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
The world’s No 3 Nand maker is listing at a time when Japan’s IPO market is seeing the largest volume since 2018.
With exits, capital can be returned to investors to be recycled back into VCs, which in turn provides funding for startups.
South-east Asia’s data consumption and computing growth will require investments of as much as US$60 billion in infrastructure.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat as China pledges fail to spark excitement
summary: Asian markets retreated on Friday as China's latest economic stimulus efforts failed to boost sentiment, with shares falling in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other cities. China pledged to implement a "moderately loose" monetary policy, increase social financing, and reduce interest rates, but the announcement was met with skepticism, with analysts predicting a near-term stimulus bounce but a potential slowdown next year. The Bank of Japan's Tankan survey showed a slight increase in confidence among major manufacturers, but overall, markets were subdued ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting next week.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares end flat amid mixed Asia markets as investors digest China’s monetary easing plans
The Stoxx 600 index closed Thursday's choppy session at 519.20 points, down 0.14 per cent, although rate-sensitive eurozone bank shares edged up 0.3 per cent.

US President-elect Donald Trump and Melania Trump take a selfie with Jeff Sprecher, the chief executive of the Intercontinental Exchange as Trump takes part in the Wall Street bell ringing in Manhattan, New York, Dec 12, 2024.

site_title: Amazon donating US$1 million to Trump inaugural fund, to air event on Prime Video
summary: Amazon is donating $1 million to President-elect Donald Trump's inaugural fund and will air the event on its Prime Video service, valued at another $1 million. This marks the second tech giant to donate, following Meta Platforms' $1 million contribution. The donations were first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

images.alt_text: Trump advisers and officials from the newly established Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) have inquired about the possibility of the president-elect abolishing the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp, the Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

US President-elect Donald Trump rings the opening bell on the trading floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on Dec 12. Trump was invited to the Exchange after being named TIME’s “Person of the Year” for the second time.
Trump also received the title in 2016, after his first presidential election victory, and now joins a select group of people who have been chosen twice.
Allowing the yuan to depreciate next year would deviate from the usual practice of keeping the foreign exchange rate stable.
Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.

site_title: Global EV sales hit third consecutive record high
summary: Global electric vehicle sales reached a third consecutive record high in November, with a 32.3% year-over-year increase to 1.83 million vehicles. China led sales growth, accounting for 70% of total EV sales, with a 50% increase to 1.27 million vehicles. In contrast, European EV sales declined marginally, while US and Canadian sales rose 16.8% to 0.17 million vehicles. This trend is attributed to China's government incentives, which have pushed EV penetration to around 50% and are expected to exceed global annual sales goals.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s Hyundai and BAIC subsidiary BAIC Investment will each inject about US$548 million into their equally owned venture Beijing Hyundai Motor.
Chinese EV manufacturer BYD has already made significant ventures into Thailand. The EV sector is expected to be of interest to Chinese investors.
Tesla’s Model Y has been the best-selling passenger vehicle in China over the past year with 556,000 units in sales.
Hybrids will be “at the core of BYD strategy in Europe.
China has invested heavily for more than 15 years in developing electric cars, to limit its dependence on imported oil.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rise
summary: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rose 17,000 to 242,000 for the week ended Dec 7, exceeding economists' forecasts. The increase likely reflects volatility after the Thanksgiving holiday. Despite a slowdown in labor demand, the unemployment rate ticked up to 4.2% in November. The elevated continued claims and longest duration of unemployment spells in nearly three years suggest some laid-off individuals are experiencing longer bouts of unemployment, potentially impacting consumer spending.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Federal Reserve building is pictured in Washington, March 18, 2008. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: Japan’s business sentiment improves slightly: BOJ tankan
summary: Japan's business sentiment improved slightly in the three months to December, according to the Bank of Japan's "tankan" quarterly survey, with the headline index measuring big manufacturers' business confidence at +14, the highest reading since March 2022. This slight improvement bodes well for the central bank's plans to gradually raise interest rates from near-zero levels ahead of its two-day policy meeting next week. The BOJ will debate whether to lift rates from 0.25% to address the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: The scramble for Seven & i gives a taste of how deals are likely to develop in the years to come, industry experts say, as changes in Japan Inc’s corporate governance standards make delisting an increasingly compelling option.
BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda and his board are set to discuss whether they need to raise the benchmark rate from 0.25 per cent next week.

The rise in the corporate goods price index, which measures the price companies charge each other for their goods and services, was faster than a median market forecast for a 3.4 per cent increase and followed a 3.6 per cent gain in October.

site_title: From fund access to matchmaking, ex-F1 champ Nico Rosberg looks to drive value for investors and startups
summary: Nico Rosberg, a former Formula 1 world champion, has launched Rosberg Ventures, a fund-of-funds model providing access to top US venture capital funds for limited partners to invest into. He initially focused on mobility startups but shifted to a diversified approach, inspired by Yale University's endowment model, to gain exposure to top VC funds. Rosberg Ventures has recently closed a $100 million fund, with plans to raise another $100 million next year through direct investing in partnership with US VC funds.

images.alt_text: From L-R: Intudo founding partners Patrick Yip and Eddy Chan.
Koh Xue, son of Koh Boon Hwee and investment head at his father's family office, Black Kite Capital, joins Wavemaker Growth as a founding partner.

site_title: UK consumer confidence touches 4-month high in December: GfK survey
summary: UK consumer confidence reached a 4-month high in December, with the monthly consumer confidence index rising to -17 from -18 in November, according to a GfK survey. This marks the highest reading since August. Despite this, consumers remain uncertain about making big-ticket purchases and have relatively weak confidence in the overall economy. The news comes as finance minister Rachel Reeves' budget imposed sharp tax increases on employers, which may have contributed to the dip in business confidence. Most forecasters expect the budget to temporarily improve Britain's economic growth rate next year.
