images.alt_text: UK Conservative Party leader Kemi Badenoch is optimistic about the CPTPP, and helped promote the deal as a former UK trade and business secretary.
Under the government’s plans, online marketplaces will have to register with the Environment Agency and report data on UK sales of their overseas sellers.
The Recruitment and Employment Confederation trade body and accountants KPMG said their index of demand for staff slid to 43.9, the lowest reading since August 2020, from October’s 46.1.
Just nine of the FTSE 100 bosses are women, down from a peak of 11 the index reached earlier this year.

site_title: China vows bigger fiscal spending to boost consumption in 2025
summary: China has pledged to increase fiscal spending in 2025 to boost consumption, following six consecutive quarters of deflation and sluggish consumer and business confidence. The government aims to raise its fiscal deficit target and implement targeted subsidies for consumer goods purchases and aid for vulnerable groups. This shift in policy focus comes as looming US tariffs threaten China's exports, with top officials led by President Xi Jinping prioritizing "lifting consumption vigorously" and stimulating domestic demand.

images.alt_text: A tourist rides a camel at Jiayu Pass, a strategic point of the Great Wall of the Ming Dynasty along the ancient "Silk Road", in Jiayuguan, Gansu province, China, Oct 28, 2024. An increasing number of young Chinese holding university degrees are getting certified to become tour guides.
At CEWC, Beijing sets targets for economic growth, the budget deficit, debt issuance and other variables for the year ahead.
Once synonymous with Hong Kong nightlife and in particular the city’s expat community, Lan Kwai Fong’s business mix is now changing to reflect what is becoming an increasingly Chinese city.
Janet Yellen and her Chinese counterparts established two working groups last year after her first visit to the Asian nation since assuming her current role.
Chinese companies invested in South Africa include Huawei Technologies, Hisense South Africa, Zijin Mining Group and ZTE.

site_title: Broadcom earnings top estimates after AI fuels sales growth
summary: Broadcom reported better-than-expected profit in the fourth quarter, driven by strong sales growth fueled by artificial intelligence demand. The company's profit per share was $1.42, exceeding estimates, and revenue rose to nearly $14.1 billion. Broadcom's AI revenue grew 220% in the year, driven by demand for AI processors and networking components. The company's stock rose 4% in extended trading, with sales expected to reach $14.6 billion in the first fiscal quarter.

images.alt_text: Apple’s AI chip is internally code-named Baltra and is expected to be ready for mass production by 2026, the report says.
There are five products in development that use the new tech, with production shipments starting in February 2026, Broadcom says.
DPM Gan Kim Yong (right) launching the initiative with Dr Prabu Raja, president of the semiconductor products group at Applied Materials.

site_title: OCBC sets up teams to help regional SMEs make foray into Johor-Singapore SEZ
summary: OCBC has launched teams in Singapore and Malaysia to advise small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) on entering the upcoming Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). The bank, with 25 bankers, aims to support SMEs from its key markets and expects to assist 260 new mid-sized enterprises by the end of 2024, with a 20% increase in 2025. Despite unclear incentives, Singapore-based business leaders express optimism about potential cost savings from offshoring operations to Johor.

images.alt_text: PM Lawrence Wong said on Dec 3 that he was self-isolating at home after testing positive for Covid-19 for the first time.
The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.

site_title: Intel says the idea of splitting up company is an open question
summary: Intel's interim co-CEO Dave Zinsner says the possibility of splitting the company's factory and product-development divisions is an open question that will be decided by the next CEO. The two units are already separated operationally, but Zinsner acknowledged that the idea has been discussed. Intel's financial struggles and deteriorating condition have sparked speculation about dramatic changes, including a split. The company's shares gained 1.9% following the statement.

site_title: Euro, US dollar steady before ECB decision, Swiss franc falls on large rate cut
summary: The US dollar remained steady against the euro and Swiss franc on Thursday, ahead of the European Central Bank's decision to cut interest rates, with a quarter-point rate cut widely expected. The Swiss franc fell 50 basis points after the central bank's larger-than-expected rate cut. The Australian dollar surged after domestic employment data beat forecasts, while the euro rose 0.1% against the dollar. Markets are now pricing a 25 basis point cut at the Federal Reserve's next meeting, with the ECB likely to signal further easing.

images.alt_text: Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed the jobless rate dropped to 3.9 per cent in November from 4.1 per cent in October, confounding analysts who had looked for a rise to 4.2 per cent.
At CEWC, Beijing sets targets for economic growth, the budget deficit, debt issuance and other variables for the year ahead.

site_title: China pledges more debt, rate cuts to counter Trump’s tariff threats
summary: China's top leaders have pledged to increase the budget deficit, issue more debt, and loosen monetary policy to maintain economic growth amid US trade tensions. The Central Economic Work Conference (CEWC) has set targets for a stable yuan, higher debt issuance, and a 5% growth rate, prioritizing growth over financial risks. This dovish shift comes as the country prepares for higher US tariffs, which could further shrink profits and hurt jobs, investment, and growth.

images.alt_text: China's outbound shipments grew just 6.7 per cent last month, customs data showed on Tuesday, missing an 8.5 per cent increase in a Reuters poll of economists and a 12.7 per cent rise in October.
Falling prices have undercut the economy’s 4.8 per cent growth so far this year, eating into corporate profits and pushing companies to cut investment as well as wages.
China's CPI rose 0.2 per cent last month from a year earlier, cooling from a 0.3 per cent increase in October, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed on Monday.
China has invested heavily for more than 15 years in developing electric cars, to limit its dependence on imported oil.

Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.

site_title: Virgin Galactic eyes possible expansion into Italy
summary: Virgin Galactic is exploring the possibility of opening a new base in Italy, potentially bringing suborbital flights to tourists in Europe for the first time. The company has signed an agreement with Italy's ENAC civil aviation authority to study the feasibility of operating missions from Grottaglie Spaceport in southern Italy. Phase one of the study will be completed in 2025 to assess airspace compatibility, while phase two will consider regional workforce requirements and economic benefits. Operations could commence four to five years from now, with Virgin Galactic's first commercial flight in Italy potentially featuring members of the Italian Air Force and the National Research Council of Italy.

images.alt_text: Virgin Galactic spaceflights are flown by two expert pilots, and every seat on board is a window seat.
The round-trip mission is part of a step-by-step plan to land humans back on the moon at some point this decade.

site_title: Singapore port authority seeks proposals on scaling up LNG bunker supply
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has launched an expression of interest to gather proposals for scaling up liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering or ship refuelling. The EOI focuses on three areas: sea-based reloading operations, LNG alternatives like liquefied bio-methane, and floating platform concepts. Proposals should address methane slip and include trial operations in Singapore. The selected companies will contribute to MPA's review of the LNG licensing framework, supporting the expected rise in LNG demand for marine fuel.

images.alt_text: Singapore's ports are expected to break records for cargo throughput and bunkering in 2024, following 2023's performance.
The Singapore LNG Corporation will charter a new floating storage and regasification facility unit as part of its development of the second LNG terminal.

site_title: US producer prices jump on eggs, but Fed categories come in soft
summary: US producer prices rose 0.4% in November, the largest gain since June, driven by a 55% surge in egg prices, largely due to bird flu. This follows the consumer price index's report that underlying inflation remained firm for a fourth month. The increase in the producer price index, excluding food and energy, was 0.2% on the month and 3.4% from a year earlier. The data follows a rapid moderation earlier in 2024, adding to uncertainty over the trajectory for prices and interest rates as the incoming Trump administration threatens higher tariffs.

images.alt_text: The annual increase in inflation has slowed considerably from a peak of 9.1 per cent in June 2022.

site_title: South Korean leader’s support hits record low after martial law
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol's approval rating has reached a record low of 11% after his declaration of martial law, according to a Gallup Korea poll. The opposition has filed a second impeachment motion against Yoon, with a majority of lawmakers from his own party indicating support. A successful impeachment would result in Yoon's suspension and potentially his removal from office. The opposition needs 200 votes in parliament to pass the motion, which they plan to report at a plenary session on Friday.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators call for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol outside the National Assembly in Seoul, Dec. 7, 2024. The President’s attempt to suspend the democratic system has given rise to a new group of politically active South Koreans. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

FILE Ñ President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea in Seoul on Sept. 14, 2022. Yoon, who briefly declared martial law on Dec. 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.  (Woohae Cho/The New York Times)

South Korea's opposition Rebuilding Korea Party leader Cho Kuk (centre) was at the forefront of efforts to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol in the wake of his short-lived imposition of martial law last week.
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol  on Thursday said he would “not avoid legal and political responsibility regarding the declaration of martial law”.
South Korea Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (bottom right) highlighted growing downside risks and efforts to stabilise foreign exchange markets using common smoothing operations.

During a parliamentary hearing, the commissioner general of the Korea Correctional Service said former defence minister Kim Yong Hyun (pictured) tried to kill himself minutes before his arrest was announced.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Nasdaq retreats from record
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nasdaq retreating below 20,000 points following a US inflation report that topped expectations. Wholesale inflation rose to 0.4% seasonally adjusted, higher than projected. Despite this, markets expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates later this month. The Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.7% to 19,902.84, while the Dow Jones and S&P 500 declined 0.5% each. Individual stocks like Adobe fell 13.7% and Warner Bros Discovery surged 15.4% after announcing a reorganisation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 20.1 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 44,168.66.

site_title: Google renews push into mixed reality headgear
summary: Google has launched Gemini 2.0, its most advanced artificial intelligence model, to power augmented and virtual reality experiences. The company is also developing Android XR, an operating system for smart glasses and headgear, in collaboration with Samsung. Android XR will enable digital assistants to understand users' surroundings, make decisions, and take actions. Google plans to test prototype Android XR-powered glasses with a small group of users and adapt popular apps for immersive experiences. The company aims to create a seamless transition between virtual and real-world environments with its AI-powered smart glasses.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (second from left) and Minister of Digital Gobind Singh Deo at the launch of National AI Office on Thursday (Dec 12) in Kuala Lumpur.
Apple’s AI chip is internally code-named Baltra and is expected to be ready for mass production by 2026, the report says.
The broader rollout of Gemini 2.0’s enhanced Search capabilities is scheduled for early 2025, with plans to expand AI Overviews to additional countries and languages throughout the year.
The lack of major changes ran counter to rumours that the Huawei Mate 70 phone would contain a chipset made on a more advanced 5nm process.

site_title: Europe: Stocks settle lower after ECB trims interest rates as expected
summary: European stocks settled lower on Thursday, closing at 519.20 points, down 0.14%, after the European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates by 25 basis points as expected. The decision aims to support a struggling economy amid heightened political risks. Despite the rate cut, investors remain cautious due to ongoing inflation concerns and the risk of a trade war with the US. Market participants now expect around 120 basis points of interest rate cuts by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump and Melania Trump take a selfie with Jeff Sprecher, the chief executive of the Intercontinental Exchange as Trump takes part in the Wall Street bell ringing in Manhattan, New York, Dec 12, 2024.

site_title: Trump woos Wall Street with corporate tax cuts at NYSE visit
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has made fresh pledges to cut taxes, vowing to lower the corporate rate to 15% from 21% and cutting levies on capital gains and dividends. Trump also promised to "do something great with crypto" and slash federal rules, sparking a market bump. The event, where Trump rang the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange, was attended by his Cabinet nominees and marked his being named Time Magazine's "Person of the Year." Trump's populist economic agenda, which includes tax cuts and deregulation, has been well-received by Wall Street and business leaders.

images.alt_text: Trump also received the title in 2016, after his first presidential election victory, and now joins a select group of people who have been chosen twice.

Wall Street executives have so far cheered the prospect of business-friendly regulations and are anticipating a burst of deals next year, as Donald Trump’s return to the White House is likely to significantly ease some regulatory pressures that dealmakers faced under the Biden administration.
US President Joe Biden said Donald Trump’s threats to slap huge tariffs on imports were a “major mistake” and challenged Trump to build on what he said were the successes of his own administration.

site_title: ECB cuts rates again, keeps door open to further cuts
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates for the fourth time this year, lowering its deposit rate to 3% from 3.25%, as the eurozone economy faces "losing momentum" due to political instability and trade risks. The ECB expects inflation to return to its 2% target in early 2025 and growth to remain sluggish. The decision signals a return to a neutral policy setting, but economists expect further rate cuts to support the stagnant economy.

images.alt_text: View of the Euro currency sign in front of the former European Central Bank (ECB) building on December 11, 2024 one day before the meeting of the governing council of the ECB in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Job prospects 2025: Stable with a chance of shifting demands
summary: The 2025 job market in Singapore is expected to present both opportunities and challenges, with a stable overall outlook. Despite a slight slowdown in hiring intentions, the local labour market remains resilient, driven by sectors such as artificial intelligence, healthcare, and financial services. Workers are advised to stay competitive and skilled to seize emerging opportunities, while employers are encouraged to invest in training programs and career development initiatives to foster resilience.

images.alt_text: Pay increments may be preferred, but alternatives such as flexible work arrangements aren't bad options either.
For all the talk about prioritising workers’ well-being, the situation seems pretty dire.
A woman on her laptop working from home.

site_title: Oil settles flat; markets weigh IEA surplus forecast, rate cut optimism
summary: Oil prices settled flat on Thursday, influenced by a forecast for ample supply and rising expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. Brent crude futures fell 11 cents, or 0.15%, to $73.41 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 27 cents, or 0.38%, to $70.02. The International Energy Agency slightly revised its demand outlook for next year, still expecting the oil market to be comfortably supplied.

images.alt_text: The deadlock had sparked some industry worries due to uncertainty over the potential impact on Petronas.
Brent crude futures settled US$1.33, or 1.84 per cent, higher at US$73.52 a barrel on Wednesday.
FILE PHOTO: An OPEC flag is seen on the day of OPEC+ meeting in Vienna  in Vienna, Austria October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Leutner//File Photo

site_title: Venture capitalists eye exits to improve sentiment in 2025 as funding winter shows signs of easing
summary: Venture capital activity is showing signs of easing in 2025, with fundraising announcements and exits increasing in the second half of 2024. Despite a disappointing year for venture capitalists, market watchers believe the funding winter is starting to thaw due to easing interest rates and the need to deploy dry powder. However, exits remain key, and transaction levels are still soft, with investors looking to reallocate funds out of the asset class. To support growth in Southeast Asian startup ecosystems, corporates are needed to provide exits and incentivize talent, with success stories needed to show that it is possible.

images.alt_text: Koh Xue, son of Koh Boon Hwee and investment head at his father's family office, Black Kite Capital, joins Wavemaker Growth as a founding partner.

From left to right: ⁠Anqi Chen, investment associate, Qualgro VC, ⁠Heang Chhor, managing partner, Qualgro VC, ⁠Adrian Li, managing partner, AC Ventures, ⁠Joan Ong, co-founder and chief strategy officer, Supermom, ⁠Rebecca Koh, co-Founder and chief of staff, Supermom, ⁠Luke Lim, co-founder and CEO, Supermom, Yinghui Kuang, investment principal, Granite Asia, Jenny Lee, managing partner, Granite Asia
From top left: Pandu Sjahrir, founding partner, Adrian Li, founder and managing partner, Michael Soerijadji, founder and managing partner, Helen Wong, managing partner, AC Ventures.

site_title: Why I still send holiday cards – and perhaps you should, too
summary: Sending holiday cards preserves weak social ties, exposing individuals to new ideas and facts, according to sociologist Mark Granovetter's 1973 paper "The Strength of Weak Ties." These ties, often with acquaintances, can facilitate connections between isolated social circles and provide access to diverse information. The annual card-sending ritual allows people to maintain relationships with those they may not see regularly, fostering a sense of community and connection, especially in polarized times.

images.alt_text: To gift or not to gift?

site_title: A fusion of creative forces
summary: Luxury watch brands are collaborating with like-minded artists and racing teams to create unique timepieces. TAG Heuer's limited-edition Formula 1 Chronograph x Oracle Red Bull Racing celebrates 20 years of high-speed triumphs, while Louis Erard x Vianney Halter's Le Regulateur II blends steampunk aesthetics with exceptional craftsmanship. Hublot's Big Bang Tourbillon Carbon SR_A, unveiled at Miami Art Week, combines cutting-edge materials with bold design language, exemplifying the "Art of Fusion" motto. These collaborations showcase the fusion of creative forces in the world of haute horlogerie.

images.alt_text: Grand Seiko celebrates Japanese elegance and beauty with the limited edition SBGJ285.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat to lower after hot economic data
summary: US stocks opened flat to lower on December 12, 2024, after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq ended the previous session on a positive note. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 20.1 points, or 0.05%, to 44,168.66, while the S&P 500 fell 9.9 points, or 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 87.6 points, or 0.44%. Investors were cautious ahead of the Federal Reserve's meeting and amid hot economic data.

site_title: Educated young Chinese turn to tour guiding as job market wavers
summary: Young Chinese with university degrees are turning to tour guiding as a job market waver due to economic instability and high youth unemployment. Over 320,000 have signed up for the country's annual tour guide certification exam, with a 45% increase from 2023. Many candidates hold foreign language majors, and tour guiding offers a lucrative option, with English-speaking guides earning up to 1,000 yuan per day. The industry's growth is driven by China's domestic vacation boom and the post-pandemic recovery of foreign tourism, with many young graduates seeking alternative income sources.

images.alt_text: At CEWC, Beijing sets targets for economic growth, the budget deficit, debt issuance and other variables for the year ahead.
Janet Yellen and her Chinese counterparts established two working groups last year after her first visit to the Asian nation since assuming her current role.
Allowing the yuan to depreciate next year would deviate from the usual practice of keeping the foreign exchange rate stable.

The vehicle trade-in policy, which offered a subsidy payment as high as 20,000 yuan (S$3,700), was credited for record high auto production and sales in November, with many consumers rushing to buy cars before the policy ends this month.
Chinese EV manufacturer BYD has already made significant ventures into Thailand. The EV sector is expected to be of interest to Chinese investors.
Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.

site_title: Deadline for Design AI and Tech Awards submissions extended, Design AI and Tech Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: FedEx has partnered with Singapore-based startup QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. The partnership aims to increase efficiency and reduce labor costs. QuikBot's robots, designed for indoor use, will navigate through corridors and deliver packages to customers. The service is expected to launch in Singapore and potentially expand to other cities. FedEx hopes to leverage QuikBot's technology to improve its last-mile delivery capabilities and enhance the customer experience. The partnership is a significant step towards the widespread adoption of autonomous delivery robots in commercial settings.

site_title: Blackstone to buy Tokyo complex from Seibu for 400 billion yen
summary: Blackstone is acquiring Tokyo Garden Terrace Kioicho, a mixed-use complex in Tokyo, from Seibu Holdings for approximately 400 billion yen (S$3.5 billion), marking the largest real estate buy by a foreign fund in Japanese history. This deal underscores the growing interest of global investors in the Japanese property market, driven by the country's cheap yen, low borrowing costs, and strong property performance in metropolitan areas.

images.alt_text: A sale to Blackstone would be the US asset manager’s biggest real estate deal in Japan and likely the largest purchase by a foreign fund.
Japan’s property prices have soared, especially in metropolitan areas.
Higher mortgage rates may pressure the housing market.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, December 12, 2024
summary: Chinese consumer stocks surged ahead of a key policy meeting conclusion, while Korean Air completed its takeover of Asiana to form one of Asia's biggest airlines. Indonesian third-party logistics players called for more action to rein in Shopee's dominance, citing an antitrust fix as insufficient. Market updates also showed Singapore stocks rising amid Fed rate-cut hopes, with the STI up 0.4%.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.
Singapore stocks open in the green, buoyed by expectations the US Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next week following mild inflation data
Shares in Seoul rose again as lawmakers prepare for a second impeachment vote on Yoon at the weekend, after the first fell short on Saturday.
Korean Air acquired 131,578,947 newly issued shares in Asiana on Thursday, for a stake of 63.88 per cent stake in the airline, which becomes a subsidiary.
Shopee even faced allegations of monopolistic behaviour in the country, being accused of prioritising its logistics service SPX Express over 3PL players on its platform.

site_title: South Korea’s opposition files second motion to impeach Yoon
summary: South Korea's opposition has filed a second impeachment motion against President Yoon Suk Yeol, requiring at least eight ruling party votes to pass. Seven members of the ruling party have hinted at supporting the motion, increasing the likelihood of its passage. The opposition needs 200 votes in parliament to pass the motion, which would lead to a Constitutional Court case lasting up to 180 days if Yoon is ruled against. The motion comes after Yoon's defiant speech defending his shock martial law declaration, which sparked public outrage and financial market concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea in Seoul on Sept. 14, 2022. Yoon, who briefly declared martial law on Dec. 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.  (Woohae Cho/The New York Times)
South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol  on Thursday said he would “not avoid legal and political responsibility regarding the declaration of martial law”.
South Korea Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (bottom right) highlighted growing downside risks and efforts to stabilise foreign exchange markets using common smoothing operations.

site_title: Donald Trump is Time magazine’s Person of the Year
summary: Donald Trump has been named Time magazine's Person of the Year for the second time, joining a select group of individuals who have been chosen twice, including Bill Clinton, George W Bush, and Barack Obama. Trump previously received the title in 2016, following his first presidential election victory. This marks the first time a president has been named Person of the Year twice.

site_title: New Zealand plans ‘golden visa’ changes to lure wealthy migrants
summary: New Zealand's government plans to reform its "golden visa" program to attract more wealthy immigrants, aiming to reverse a decline in investor applications since 2022. The changes, expected to be announced in the coming weeks, will include reforms to speed up overseas investment applications and emphasize the nation's need for foreign capital. The reforms may also include removing the English-language test and potentially allowing foreigners to buy houses valued at NZ$2 million or more, a policy proposed by the National Party before the 2023 general election.

images.alt_text: New Zealand is the world’s biggest dairy exporter and shipments of meat, wool, forest products, kiwifruit and seafood are also key drivers of economic growth.
New Zealand, along with the US, Ireland, Australia and Britain, is one of only five countries where commercial greyhound racing is still allowed.

Houses in the Lyall Bay suburb of Wellington, New Zealand, on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020. A housing frenzy at the bottom of the world is laying bare the perils of ultra-low interest rates. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: India's Gukesh beats China's Ding to become youngest chess world champion
summary: India's Gukesh Dommaraju, 18, became the youngest chess world champion by defeating China's Ding Liren 7.5-6.5 in a 14-game match in Singapore. This victory is four years younger than Garry Kasparov's record. Gukesh won the decisive game with the black pieces after Ding's blunders, ending his 14-game winning streak. Ding's form had declined since his 2023 championship win, and he largely avoided top events to improve. Gukesh qualified for the match by winning the Candidates tournament in April.

site_title: IEA expects comfortably supplied oil market in 2025 despite demand hike
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) expects the world oil market to be comfortably supplied in 2025, despite a 1.1 million barrel per day (bpd) increase in global demand forecast for the year. This growth is largely driven by Asian countries, particularly China, following recent stimulus measures. Opec+ is planning to revive output in 2025 after years of cuts, aiming to address the expected headwinds. The outlook suggests a continued impact of economic challenges and electric vehicle growth on oil demand.

images.alt_text: Energy security and affordability remains top priorities for South-east Asia, with the recent global energy crisis highlighting the region’s vulnerability to fuel price shocks.

South-east Asia as a whole attracts only 2 per cent of global clean energy investment despite accounting for 6 per cent of global GDP, 5 per cent of global energy demand and being home to 9 per cent of the world’s population, according to IEA's report.

site_title: India’s November retail inflation eases, boosts rate cut hopes
summary: India's retail inflation eased to 5.48% in November, lower than 6.21% in the previous month, due to moderating vegetable prices. This decline, combined with a slowdown in growth in the July to September quarter, boosts expectations of an interest rate cut by the central bank in February. Economists expect a 25-basis-point cut, citing a deflationary trend in food prices and softening demand. The Reserve Bank of India left interest rates unchanged earlier this month but reduced the cash reserve ratio to ease monetary conditions and support growth.

site_title: Climate Impact X to offer contracts to airlines looking to offset carbon emissions
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX) launched the world's first standardized contracts for carbon credits aligned with the International Civil Aviation Organization's (ICAO) Corsia scheme, requiring airlines to offset carbon emissions above 85% of 2019 levels. The contracts, designed to meet growing demand, will accept credits from all fully approved ICAO registries and provide a transparent pricing mechanism. This move is expected to unlock new opportunities for airlines and market participants to trade emissions reductions, with demand projected to increase exponentially by 2026.

images.alt_text: Heightened scrutiny over the environmental integrity of carbon markets and fears of “greenshaming” have stunted the growth of the voluntary carbon market.
A Finnair plane being fueled with sustainable aviation fuel at Helsinki Vaanta Airport in Finland.
Airline chiefs want government aid to reduce carbon emissions

site_title: Temasek firm’s deal values Malaysia 5G winner at RM7.5 billion: sources
summary: A Temasek Holdings firm, Straits Mobile Investments, is selling its majority stake in U Mobile, Malaysia's 5G network developer, to a company owned by tycoon Vincent Tan and the Malaysian king's daughter for approximately RM7.5 billion (S$2.3 billion). The sale values U Mobile at nearly four times the RM625 million it was valued at in 2010 when Straits Mobile Investments first acquired a 33% stake. U Mobile plans to fund the 5G network rollout on its own, without taxpayer cost. The deal, which includes a deferral of payment for up to a year, surprised analysts due to U Mobile's smaller player status and large foreign ownership.

site_title: Indonesian third-party logistics players say Shopee antitrust fix falls short, urge action
summary: Indonesian third-party logistics (3PL) players are urging the government to set a price floor for courier services on e-commerce platforms to protect them from "unhealthy" price wars. The rise of in-house logistics services has eroded shipment volumes for 3PL companies, with many facing financial difficulties and layoffs. The industry is calling for a minimum price regulation to eliminate predatory pricing and ensure fair competition. However, the government's response remains uncertain, and some experts argue that mergers and acquisitions (M&A) might become the best option for 3PL companies to survive.

images.alt_text: Chinese e-commerce giants were similarly coy about actual sales. Both Alibaba Group and JD.com did not disclose sales figures for this year's Singles' Day shopping season.

site_title: UK’s biggest post-Brexit economic opportunity dawns
summary: The UK is set to join the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) on December 15, marking a significant long-term economic opportunity. The bloc's combined GDP will increase to around £12 trillion, with the UK's accession expected to bring in 0.08% of GDP growth over the next decade. Key sectors, such as food and agriculture, metals, and data flows, are expected to benefit from the deal. The UK's accession also paves the way for stronger ties with Asia-Pacific and the Americas, with Malaysia being a potential early beneficiary of the deal.

images.alt_text: A handout photograph, released by the UK Parliament, shows Britain's main opposition Conservative Party leader Kemi Badenoch speaking during Prime Minister's Questions (PMQ) session, in the House of Commons, in central London, on November 13, 2024. (Photo by UK PARLIAMENT / AFP) / RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - NO USE FOR ENTERTAINMENT, SATIRICAL, ADVERTISING PURPOSES - MANDATORY CREDIT " AFP PHOTO / Handout/ UK Parliament"
South Korean Foreign Minister Cho Tae-yul (2-L) and Britain’s Foreign Secretary David Lammy (R), hold strategic talks at the foreign ministry in Seoul, South Korea, Oct 21.

site_title: Apple adds ChatGPT to iPhone in latest iOS update
summary: Apple has integrated OpenAI's ChatGPT into its latest iPhone series, including iPhone 15 Pro and Pro Max, and iPads with A17 Pro or M1 chips, as part of its iOS update. The integration allows Siri to access ChatGPT's expertise on user queries and create written content in any app that supports the Writing Tools feature. The move aims to boost iPhone sales during the peak holiday shopping season, which has seen concerns about the strength of the iPhone 16 sales cycle.

site_title: Australia to charge tech companies for news content if they do not pay
summary: Australia's centre-left government plans to charge big tech firms millions of dollars if they don't pay Australian media companies for news hosted on their platforms. The charge, offset for voluntary commercial agreements, targets significant social media platforms and search engines with Australian revenue exceeding $250 million. Tech companies, including Meta Platforms and Alphabet's Google, have condemned the plan, citing the realities of how their platforms work. The move aims to create a financial incentive for agreement-making between digital platforms and news media businesses.

images.alt_text: A competition commission report on digital platform services in 2022 showed Google controlled 93 per cent to 95 per cent of online search services in Australia, while Apple’s App Store accounted for about 60 per cent of app downloads and Google Play Store 40 per cent.
Australia this week approved a landmark law banning social media for children under 16.

site_title: NVPC, Essec Business School ink MOU to ramp up corporate volunteering efforts
summary: Essec Business School and the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) have signed a memorandum of understanding to ramp up corporate volunteering efforts in Singapore. Under the partnership, Essec will commit to at least 2,000 hours of service and skills-based volunteering, involving over 500 students, alumni, faculty, and staff. The business school will collaborate with non-profit organizations, such as FaithActs, to offer service-based and skills-based volunteering opportunities, with a focus on nurturing the next generation of leaders to make a positive impact on the community.

images.alt_text: Tony Soh, chief executive of NVPC, says the COG Recognition System has been revised to be "more inclusive and progressive".
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (centre in red) and Jane Ittogi (centre in green) with the PVPA winners on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia’s billionaire boom: record wealth, new entrants and rising fortunes
summary: Indonesia's collective wealth of its top tycoons has reached a record-breaking $263 billion, up $11 billion from last year. The top five billionaires are the Hartono brothers ($50.3 billion), Prajogo Pangestu ($32.5 billion), Low Tuck Kwong ($27 billion), the Widjaja family ($18.9 billion), and Anthoni Salim ($20.5 billion). The surge in wealth is driven by booming sectors such as mining, agribusiness, and digital ventures, particularly data centers. The minimum wealth requirement to make the list has crossed the $1 billion mark, reflecting Indonesia's growing economic dynamism.

images.alt_text: The late tycoon Ananda Krishnan attends the Allen & Co Media Conference in the United States in 2012. The 86-year-old billionaire passed away on Nov 28, 2024.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 12)
summary: Temu, a Chinese e-commerce firm, has put a notice on its app stating it is working with Vietnamese authorities to register its e-commerce services in the country. This move may force Temu to consider a pivot and compete directly with Shopee, or register more Vietnam-registered businesses. Meanwhile, Malaysia has launched a national AI office to boost its digital economy development, aiming to become a regional hub for AI development. ESR has secured a US$2.5 billion syndicated sustainability-linked loan, and IFC and HSBC have inked a US$1 billion risk-sharing facility to boost trade financing in emerging markets.

site_title: Hermes family in talks to invest in French insurer Albingia
summary: A family office backed by the Hermes fortune, estimated at $171 billion, is in talks to buy French insurer Albingia from asset manager Eurazeo. The deal, led by the Chamoin family and Canadian insurer Fairfax Financial Holdings, is expected to bring in €289 million (S$408 million) in sale revenue. The investment signals a diversification of the Hermes family's wealth away from luxury goods, with Krefeld Invest, the family office, announcing its first public investment since its creation in 2022.

images.alt_text: An Hermes luxury boutique in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024. Hermes has held steady as its leather-goods unit benefits from long waiting lists and price increases, according to Exane, and has had a neutral rating since 2018. Photographer: Benjamin Girette/Bloomberg
The company is experiencing softer demand for its more affordable goods such as silk scarves, reflecting a curb in spending by aspirational customers, Dumas says.

site_title: South Korea’s top court upholds two-year sentence for prominent opposition leader
summary: South Korea's Supreme Court upheld a two-year jail sentence for opposition leader Cho Kuk, who was found guilty of forging academic documents to secure his children's admission to prestigious schools. Cho, a former high-profile academic and aide to ex-president Moon Jae In, was also at the forefront of efforts to impeach President Yoon Suk Yeol, who recently imposed martial law. The court's decision will see Cho lose his parliamentary seat, effectively ending his presidential ambitions. Cho is expected to report to a correctional facility to begin his sentence.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol  on Thursday said he would “not avoid legal and political responsibility regarding the declaration of martial law”.
South Korea Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (bottom right) highlighted growing downside risks and efforts to stabilise foreign exchange markets using common smoothing operations.
Half-empty pubs and bars now dominate South Korea's neon-lit streets, reflecting a cultural shift as corporate Korea reduces hoesik, or after-work drinking bouts.

During a parliamentary hearing, the commissioner general of the Korea Correctional Service said former defence minister Kim Yong Hyun (pictured) tried to kill himself minutes before his arrest was announced.
Former South Korean defence minister Kim Yong Hyun was arrested on charges including “engaging in critical duties during an insurrection” and “abuse of authority to obstruct the exercise of rights”.
A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon

site_title: OCBC tightens scrutiny of international clients
summary: OCBC, Singapore's second-largest lender, has given international clients a deadline to confirm their Singapore residency with verified addresses to avoid account closures. This move comes as the bank is among several institutions caught in Singapore's largest money-laundering case, where over $3 billion in assets were seized. Local authorities are bolstering measures to combat illicit flows, and OCBC's actions signal heightened scrutiny. Clients have until Dec 15 or Dec 31 to comply, or risk having their accounts shut.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere lays off 8.1% of workforce across Singapore and South-east Asia
summary: Doctor Anywhere, a Singapore-based telehealth platform, is laying off 8.1% of its workforce across Singapore and South-east Asia, affecting 45 employees. The move is part of the company's effort to become more self-sustainable, with the goal of streamlining operations and restructuring its tech team. The layoffs do not impact medical doctors or other healthcare professionals, and the company remains one of Singapore's largest telehealth platforms, serving over 1 million users annually.

site_title: Nordic Group bags S$22.9 million worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group secured contracts worth around S$22.9 million, primarily from its system integration and cleanroom divisions. The contracts are with new and repeat customers in the marine, offshore oil and gas, petrochemical, semiconductor, infrastructure, and security sectors. The system integration division secured S$6.7 million, while the cleanroom division bagged S$7 million. The contracts are expected to have a minimal impact on Nordic Group's consolidated net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year. Shares traded flat at S$0.36 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: In its outlook, the group said it remains positive over the long-term prospects in the marine, offshore oil and gas industries, petrochemical, pharmaceutical, infrastructure, semiconductor and security services sectors.

site_title: Inflation gives Fed green light for rate cut in December
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to cut interest rates by a quarter percentage point in December, despite inflation rising in November in line with expectations. However, concerns over persistent price pressures may prompt officials to reduce the number of rate cuts in 2025. Policymakers will release new forecasts and rate projections at the conclusion of their Dec 17-18 meeting. Investors expect a December cut followed by two to three additional cuts next year, but some analysts predict a shallower path.

images.alt_text: The annual increase in inflation has slowed considerably from a peak of 9.1 per cent in June 2022.

site_title: Alternatives to pay rises becoming increasingly viable
summary: A survey by ADP found that 71% of Singaporean workers consider salary as the most important factor in a job, surpassing the global average of 55%. While pay rises may be preferred, alternatives such as flexible work arrangements are also gaining viability, offering employees a sense of meaning and work-life balance. The survey suggests that Singaporean employees value financial rewards, but also prioritize non-monetary benefits in their careers.

site_title: Art and Art Deco
summary: A Singaporean family's home features a colorful mural and Art Deco elements that capture their memories and aesthetic tastes. The mural, painted by Ripple Root, depicts family members and places they've lived, while the interior design firm Haus Atelier incorporated Art Deco style into the home's various spaces, including a bar, music room, and gym. The house also includes plenty of storage space, a lift for easy movement, and artwork by other artists. The homeowners' love for the arts is reflected in the home's design, which balances traditional and modern elements.

images.alt_text: London-based Singaporean interior designer Sacha Leong.

site_title: Temasek leads US$210 million fund-raising round for India’s Rebel Foods ahead of planned IPO
summary: Rebel Foods, an Indian online-only restaurant startup, has secured a $210 million funding round led by Singapore's Temasek Holdings ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO) by 2026. The company, valued at $1.4 billion, plans to expand overseas and leverage AI technologies to boost operations. Rebel Foods operates in 75 Indian cities and 3 international locations, serving customers from 450 dark kitchens. The new funding will support the company's expansion plans, including a growth to 800 dark kitchens and 200 cities by 2029.

images.alt_text: Temasek owns a S$389 billion total portfolio as at Mar 31, and has focused on long-term investments with themes such as digitisation and sustainability.
Temasek Trust receives its funding primarily from Temasek Holdings.
CMG20231025-HengYY03 / 王彦燕 / 淡马锡 Temasek International office at Orchard Road [Temasek International Pte. Ltd. 60B Orchard Road #06-18 Tower 2. The Atrium@Orchard Singapore 238891]
U Mobile’s selection to develop the 5G network surprised analysts because it’s a smaller player in Malaysia’s telecommunications industry and has a large foreign ownership.

site_title: Malaysia to export first 200 tons of sustainably certified rubber to EU
summary: Malaysia is exporting its first 200 tons of sustainably certified rubber to the European Union, meeting conditions ahead of new anti-deforestation rules. The export, via two Malaysian firms to Slovakia and the Netherlands, demonstrates Malaysia's commitment to international sustainability practices. The move comes after the EU delayed the rollout of the rules by a year, allowing time for supply chains to comply. This is a response to EU legislation banning commodities linked to deforestation, with Malaysia and Indonesia opposing the implementation rules as discriminatory.

images.alt_text: Sri Trang Gloves says it will continue to reduce production costs through automation to eliminate redundancies and achieve economies of scale.
The company posts a net profit of 517.3 million baht for Q3, up from a loss of 410.2 million baht in the same period last year.

site_title: 🌠 Are you working to find or fund your dreams?
summary: A panel discussion at Thrive's fireside chat featured three guest speakers: Amanda Chong, Dione Song, and Khairul Mohd Khair, discussing career choices, finding meaning at work, and advice for young adults. Panelists advise against making work their entire identity, emphasizing the importance of work-life balance and finding meaning in interpersonal connections. They also stress the need to take calculated risks, seize opportunities, and be open to growth and change, noting that sometimes work is just a means to fund one's life's meaning.

images.alt_text: BT
(FROM LEFT) Daryl Choo, BT young audience journalist, Emelia Tan, director of research and FinLit of SGX and Timothy Phillips, trainer at SGX Academy on the panel of the fireside chat
Participants filming a mock street interview during a Thrive workshop at the World X 2023 career fair on July 22, 2023.

From right: Khairul Mohd Khair, head of people and organisational development at Stroke Support Station; Dione Song, chief executive of Love, Bonito; lawyer, poet and playwright Amanda Chong; and BT young audience editor Vivien Shiao speak at a thrive panel discussion.

site_title: South Korea to safeguard competition after Korean Air, Asiana merger
summary: South Korea's transport ministry has unveiled measures to boost competition in the domestic aviation industry following the merger of Korean Air and Asiana Airlines. The merger, valued at 1.8 trillion won, creates one of Asia's largest carriers and the world's 12th-largest airline. The Fair Trade Commission will monitor Korean Air's compliance with conditions attached to the merger's approval, including not reducing seat numbers on key routes. The deal aims to strengthen Korean Air's competitive position globally and boost the capabilities of Incheon International Airport.

images.alt_text: Alaska Airlines expects to earn at least US$10 per share in 2027, more than double the US$4.25 to US$4.50 estimated for 2024. It forecast a pretax margin of between 11 per cent and 13 per cent.
Boeing said it restarted 737 MAX production, loading fresh fuselages into its Seattle-area Renton factory, after weeks of methodical preparation.
The aerospace industry says it is gradually returning to normal but has warned of supply pressures well into 2025.
Iata director general Willie Walsh pointed to a lack of biorefineries under construction which could produce the green jet fuel, many of which require extensive capital expenditure to get built.
A model of Comac's C919 plane on display at the 2nd China International Supply Chain Expo in Beijing on Nov 28, 2024.

site_title: Gold rises for fifth day as US data lifts Fed rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices rose for a fifth consecutive day, reaching near a two-week peak, as US inflation data supported interest rate cut bets from the Federal Reserve. Spot gold increased 0.1% to $2,719.79 per ounce, while traders predict a 98.6% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut at the Fed's Dec 17-18 meeting. The European Central Bank is also expected to cut interest rates, and the gold market is seen as a safe investment during economic turmoil.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: Thai PM vows to end business monopoly, plans more cash stimulus
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra has vowed to end business monopolies, aiming to lower costs for people and stimulate the economy. Outdated laws will be amended to increase competition in areas like rice exports and liquor production, benefiting small and medium enterprises. Paetongtarn also plans to launch cash handouts, a digital wallet scheme, and affordable housing programs to support economic growth and lower the cost of living. The government will also focus on restructuring the power industry, curbing drug-trafficking, and addressing air pollution.

images.alt_text: The head office of Thailand's Bangkok Bank is pictured in front of the city skyline in Bangkok on September 5, 2024. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: Philippine fast-food chain Jollibee hits 200 stores in Vietnam, forecasts faster growth in 2025
summary: Jollibee, a Philippine fast-food chain, has reached 200 stores in Vietnam, its largest international market, with plans to expand its network more quickly in 2025. The chain, which previously took seven years to grow from 100 to 200 outlets, expects "two-digit" growth in profit and sales this year. Jollibee's success in Vietnam stems from its willingness to expand to second and third-tier cities, and its similarity in demographics and culture to the Philippines, where the chain is extremely popular.

images.alt_text: Jollibee expects to add 750 to 820 stores this year given the consolidation of South Korea’s Compose Coffee which it acquired in July.
Jollibee’s unit Jollibee Worldwide will acquire 70 per cent of Compose Coffee and its majority-owned Titan Fund will take 5 per cent, the fast-food firm said in a disclosure.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate after Wall Street record; eyes on China
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Thursday, following a record day on Wall Street, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The US consumer price index rose in line with expectations, bolstering hopes for a rate cut next week. In Asia, Seoul's Kospi rose for a third straight day, while Hong Kong and Shanghai edged up amid hopes for more economic stimulus in China. However, analysts warned that the outlook for 2025 was uncertain, citing concerns about inflation and the presidency of Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite Index was the day’s big winner, jumping 1.8 per cent to close at a new record of 20,34.89 on Wednesday.
Singapore stocks open in the green, buoyed by expectations the US Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next week following mild inflation data

site_title: Australia’s jobless rate unexpectedly drops as labour market remains tight
summary: Australia's jobless rate unexpectedly dropped to 3.9% in November, the lowest in eight months, with employment rising more than forecast. The rate was below expectations of a rise to 4.2%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to leave interest rates steady has led to a shift in market expectations, with a rate cut in February now seen as more likely. The Australian dollar rose, while bond futures fell, implying a 55% chance of a rate cut in February.

images.alt_text: In Spain, annual GDP growth is on track to exceed 3 per cent, driven by a strong labour market and high levels of immigration, which mechanically lifts economic output.
Wrapping up its December policy meeting, the Reserve Bank of Australia, led by Governor Michele Bullock, kept the cash rate unchanged at 4.35 per cent where it has been all year.
Activity fell across all industries with retail and manufacturing reporting the worst conditions.

site_title: Microsoft expects US$800 million impairment charge in Q2 2025 over General Motors’ Cruise exit
summary: Microsoft expects a US$800 million impairment charge in Q2 2025 due to General Motors' exit from the Cruise autonomous driving business. The charge results from Microsoft's minority stake in Cruise, which GM is ending after investing over US$10 billion since 2016. The impairment charge will negatively impact Microsoft's second-quarter earnings per share by about nine US cents.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar says Petronas, Petros finalising deal on gas distribution in Sarawak
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said that Petronas and Petroleum Sarawak Berhad (Petros) are finalizing a deal on gas distribution in Sarawak, resolving a months-long impasse. The agreement, which will see Petros take control of natural gas activities in the state, was initially set for July but negotiations were delayed. Anwar stated that "clear decisions" had been made, but finer details and legal implications are still being discussed. The deal is expected to be announced by Anwar soon, addressing concerns over the potential impact on Petronas and energy activities in Sarawak.

images.alt_text: Adnoc handed Shell, BP, TotalEnergies and Japan’s Mitsui each a 10 per cent stake in the project, which will is expected to start production in late 2028.
Petronas is crucial to the state budget. The oil and gas giant is expected to pay RM32 billion to the government in 2024, roughly 10 per cent of Malaysia’s overall revenue for the year.
Malaysian Transport Minister Anthony Loke said only 0.2 per cent of registered motor vehicles in the country were fuelled by NGV, with many considered in ageing condition and spare parts unavailable.
Petronas plans significant expansion in Indonesia, country head says

site_title: Musk and Milei belong to the same cult of disruption
summary: The "cult of disruption" in the public sector is gaining momentum, with leaders such as Argentina's President Javier Milei and US President-elect Donald Trump embracing the idea of slashing government spending and streamlining bureaucracy. However, critics argue that this approach can be counterproductive, disrupting essential public services and failing to address deeper issues. Experts suggest that a more nuanced approach, combining long-term reforms with controlled disruption, may be more effective in modernizing the public sector. Ultimately, the real challenge lies in adjusting public expectations, as the public sector must endure to pick up the pieces left behind by private-sector failures.

images.alt_text: As Musk (centre) and Ramaswamy (right) wield their axes, it may be hard to tell whether they are aimed at red tape or more like DIY home renovators taking a swing at a load-bearing wall.
Creative destruction? Once upon a time, venture capitalists refused to fund anybody who didnt promise to break things.

site_title: Minimum wages set to rise in parts of Asean, outpacing expected increase in inflation: report
summary: Asean countries are set to increase minimum wages in 2025, with growth expected to surpass inflation, according to a report by OCBC's Global Markets Research. Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia have already announced wage hikes, while Vietnam and the Philippines will maintain wages until 2025. This could boost consumption expenditure, but also raises concerns about competitiveness and labour productivity. OCBC economist Lavanya Venkateswaran notes that real wages are likely to rise, supporting income growth and consumption, but warns that productivity gains must keep pace with wage increases to maintain competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Workers harvesting rice in Thailand using their sickles, before the threshing and winnowing. With climate change, rising sea levels are threatening rice fields and the region’s supply of the grain will come under more pressure.

site_title: Michael Jordan sells suburban Chicago mansion for 67% price cut
summary: Michael Jordan has sold his 2.8-hectare Chicago-area mansion for $9.5 million, a 67% reduction from the initial asking price of $29 million. The 32,000-square-foot home features nine bedrooms, 19 bathrooms, and a regulation-sized basketball court, built during Jordan's championship years with the Chicago Bulls. The sale price marks a significant price cut in high-end Chicago real estate, following recent sales of properties at below market value. The identity of the buyer remains undisclosed.

images.alt_text: Built in 1995, during the height of Jordan’s time on the National Basketball Association’s Chicago Bulls, the home is on a seven-acre lot and has nine bedrooms and 19 bathrooms.

site_title: Malaysia launches national AI office to boost adoption and attract investments
summary: Malaysia launched its National Artificial Intelligence Office (NAIO) to boost AI adoption and attract high-value investments, aiming to enhance its digital economy development. The country is looking to increase its digital economy contribution to 25.5% of GDP by 2030, with a target of RM120 billion. Strategic partnerships with tech giants, including Toshiba, Amazon Web Services, Microsoft, and Google, were announced. The NAIO aims to promote innovation, enable cross-sector collaboration, and develop AI policies, with a budget of RM10 million allocated to drive AI adoption.

images.alt_text: Malaysia joins efforts by governments across Asia to clamp down on online platforms and hold Big Tech firms accountable for illegal content.
Malaysia deputy investment, trade and industry minister Liew Chin Tong said that it is time for data centre players to form a trade association.
Brain drain is a major issue for Johor and Malaysia, with many young professionals leaving the country for higher-paying jobs abroad.
A data centre project that Nvidia is building with the energy subsidiary of one of Malaysia's biggest conglomerates in Johor.

site_title: Amid weak eurozone and political turmoil, ECB to cut rates again
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to cut interest rates for the third consecutive time, with a quarter-point reduction expected to take the key deposit rate to 3%. The decision comes amid weak economic data, political turmoil in the eurozone, and renewed trade tensions with the US. Inflation pressures remain a concern, but analysts expect the ECB to maintain its cautious approach and avoid a more significant cut. The decision is seen as a response to the growing economic slowdown and the potential impact of US economic policies under a potential Trump presidency.

images.alt_text: The BOE remains on alert about price pressures in Britain’s jobs market that have subsided more clearly elsewhere.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5 per cent lower at 518.49 points, with France’s CAC 40 off 1.1 per cent, falling the most among major European economies.
Some policymakers urge rapid cuts to encourage consumers to spend and businesses to invest.

site_title: US asks court to reject delay to law that would ban TikTok
summary: The US Justice Department asked a US appeals court to reject TikTok's emergency bid to delay a law requiring its Chinese parent company ByteDance to divest the app by January 19 or face a ban. TikTok warned that the law would "shut down" the app for its 170 million domestic users. The Justice Department argued that "continued Chinese control of the TikTok application poses a continuing threat to national security."

site_title: Elon Musk’s net worth tops US$400 billion, a historic first
summary: Elon Musk has surpassed $400 billion in net worth, a historic milestone, with a $218 billion increase since January 2024, more than any other member of the world's richest 500. Musk's wealth jumped $62.8 billion in a single day, the largest on record, driven by SpaceX's insider share sale and Tesla's all-time high. Musk's combined fortune is now over $10 trillion, comparable in size to the combined GDP of Germany, Japan, and Australia.

images.alt_text: Musk has been an ever-present sidekick for Trump since his election victory in November, inviting him to watch a rocket launch in Texas by his SpaceX company.
Elon Musk has alleged that OpenAI bars its investors from making investments in rivals – which would put his own startup at a disadvantage in a sector where billions of dollars are at stake.
While Donald Trump and Elon Musk have claimed that US$2 trillion could potentially be saved, most experts believe this is not realistic without cuts to crucial services or benefits.

site_title: ESR inks largest syndicated sustainability-linked loan for US$2.5 billion
summary: ESR Group, a Hong Kong-listed real asset manager, has secured a $2.5 billion five-year syndicated sustainability-linked term loan and revolving credit facilities. This is the group's largest sustainability-linked loan to date, bringing the total to $7 billion. The loan is expected to enable ESR to achieve lower borrowing costs, supporting its sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong-listed real estate fund manager ESR Group has received a privatisation offer valued at HK$55.2 billion, the largest on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2021.
ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.
Since the offer, the shares of the company are up 14.4 per cent from the closing price on the last trading day before the first take-private announcement on May 14.

site_title: Hong Kong’s expat nightlife hub reshaped by Chinese influx
summary: Hong Kong's nightlife hub, Lan Kwai Fong, is undergoing a transformation as the city's population shifts towards a more Chinese demographic. Legacy nightclubs and bars are giving way to hot pot and karaoke joints catering to mainland Chinese customers. The area's business mix is changing, with sales from mainland Chinese tourists and residents becoming increasingly important to Hong Kong's businesses. The shift is driven by a decline in local residents' wealth and a rise in Chinese visitors, with many opting for cheaper social media-driven activities.

images.alt_text: Generic photos of Singapore city skyline for stories related to Singapore economy or economic growth.
The wider project is set to transform 30,000 hectares of land along the border, about a third of Hong Kong’s territory.

site_title: Malaysia drops appeal over Deputy PM Zahid’s graft acquittal
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Zahid Hamidi has secured a fresh legal victory as prosecutors dropped their challenge against his graft acquittal. The Court of Appeal in Putrajaya cancelled the appeals after prosecutors withdrew, citing lack of evidence. Zahid was acquitted in September 2022 for receiving bribes in exchange for awarding contracts. The decision erodes public trust in Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's government, which relies on Zahid's United Malays National Organisation to stay in power. The move comes after Zahid was discharged mid-trial from 47 graft charges in a separate case.

site_title: Legal pressures in Vietnam may push Temu to mull a pivot, compete directly with Shopee
summary: Temu, a Chinese cross-border shopping platform, may pivot to a marketplace model in Vietnam to comply with regulatory hurdles and backlash from local sellers. The platform's direct-from-China supply chain model has been criticized for potential sale of counterfeit items and unfair competition. Temu's operations in Vietnam were suspended a month after its debut in October due to registration issues. The company may need to onboard Vietnam-registered businesses to sell their goods on its platform, potentially putting it in direct competition with Shopee, the leading e-commerce player in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, Vietnamese language options had been removed from Temu’s website when it was accessed from Vietnam.
Fast-fashion retailer Shein has been selling into Vietnam for at least two years.
Thanks to e-commerce giants, which have lowered entry barriers for South-east Asian sellers, small businesses in the region have been able to internationalise closer to home.

site_title: Blackstone’s iQ buys defaulted London office for dorms
summary: Blackstone's iQ Student Accommodation has acquired a 0.6-hectare plot in Southwark, London, previously intended for an office development, for a significant discount to the outstanding debt of £70 million. The site, valued at £50 million, will be redeveloped into 430,000 square feet of student dorms, addressing London's accommodation crunch, which affects 105,000 full-time students. This deal is part of a trend of office projects being repurposed for alternative uses, driven by the shift in demand for office space and the increasing attractiveness of hotels and student accommodation.

images.alt_text: Blackstone will continue to be Resolution’s investment manager across private credit and other areas after Nippon completes the acquisition.
Blackstone and Nuveen failed to agree on a price for 70 St Mary’s Axe, nicknamed 'Can of Ham', potentially one of Europe’s largest real estate deals.
New York City’s housing agency is issuing the bonds as fixed-rate debt with multiple classes, similar to the way commercial mortgage backed securities are structured.

site_title: Nvidia steps up hiring in China to focus on AI-driven cars
summary: Nvidia has added hundreds of staff in China, expanding its research capabilities and focusing on autonomous driving technologies. The company, which has around 4,000 employees globally, has hired about 200 researchers in Beijing to work on self-driving technologies. This move comes as Nvidia seeks to fulfill demand for its artificial intelligence chips, despite US trade curbs in China. The company's expansion in China, a key research hub, may be seen as a response to the US-China trade dispute, with Beijing's support for domestic electric vehicle makers and its leading position in EV technologies.

images.alt_text: Nvidia Corp.'s offices, right, in Shanghai, China, on Tuesday, Dec. 10, 2024. China has opened a probe into Nvidia over suspicions that the US chipmaker broke anti-monopoly laws around a 2020 deal, taking aim at the AI heavyweight as Washington ramps up sanctions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.5 per cent lower at 44,401.93 on Monday.
The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) said Nvidia is suspected of violating commitments it made during its acquisition of Mellanox Technologies.

site_title: The best wine books of 2024
summary: This year's top wine books offer something for every wine enthusiast. Five standout titles include "One Thousand Vines: A New Way to Understand Wine" by Pascaline Lepeltier, which provides a comprehensive synthesis of wine's various aspects; "A Season for That: Lost and Found in the Other Southern France" by Steve Hoffman, a heartwarming tale of discovery in the French countryside; "Who's Afraid of Romanée-Conti? A Shortcut to Drinking Great Wines" by Dan Keeling, a collection of essays on wine and its culture; "Wine Confident: There's No Wrong Way to Enjoy Wine" by Kelli A. White, a beginner's guide that emphasizes confidence and self-expression; and "On Tuscany: From Brunello to Bolgheri, Wine Tales From the Heart of Italy," a compilation of essays on Tuscan wine by various writers.

images.alt_text: LVMH’s Cognac brand Hennessy has increased consignments to the US following Trump’s victory last month, while its label Moët & Chandon is among the Champagne makers that intend to do the same.
Only 400 bottles of Hibiki 40 Years Old are available globally.
Output in France, the biggest wine producer last year, is set to sink by 23 per cent, the largest drop in the sector.
While demand for zero-alcohol beer has surged, the Carl Jung family business is betting on similar growth in the wine sector, using a technique it pioneered more than a century ago.

A wine harvest in Georgia's Kakheti region. Some vintners in the former Soviet republic are seeking to break a politically risky dependence on Russia and focus more on high-value European and American markets.

Higher tariffs could harm businesses throughout the wine industry, from farmers, producers, importers, distributors, shops and restaurants to warehouses, transport companies and label and bottle manufacturers.

site_title: Bitcoin lifted above US$100,000 on firming expectations of Fed cut
summary: Bitcoin surged nearly 5% on Wednesday, its largest gain in two weeks, after US inflation data bolstered expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The digital asset rose to a record high of $103,800 on December 5, but has since struggled to stay above $100,000. The prospect of looser monetary conditions boosted investor sentiment, sending the Nasdaq 100 to a record high. Bitcoin's gain was partly attributed to President-elect Donald Trump's moves to undo a Biden administration crypto crackdown and his son Eric Trump's comments that his father will be an "unbelievable ally" to the industry.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin hit a record US$103,800 on Dec 5 but subsequently struggled to stay above the six-figure level.
As Bitcoin sceptics and Bitcoin maximalists talk over each other, a third group – the opportunists – have bought and sold the stuff many times over.
The token’s six-week streak of gains through Sunday is the longest such run since the crypto frenzy of 2021.

site_title: UK house price indicator hits highest in over two years
summary: A closely watched UK house price indicator reached its highest in over two years in November, jumping to 25 from 16 in October, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). The increase was driven by a Bank of England interest-rate cut and an end to uncertainty over Labour's first budget, with gains across almost every region. Economists expect the housing market to gather momentum, but warn that rising mortgage interest rates may curtail the recovery.

images.alt_text: The deal is the latest in a string of transactions that have seen planned office projects ditched in favour of alternative uses including hotels and student accommodation.
Blackstone and Nuveen failed to agree on a price for 70 St Mary’s Axe, nicknamed 'Can of Ham', potentially one of Europe’s largest real estate deals.

Rutland Gate has planning permission to be redeveloped as a luxury home, removing a major paperwork headache for certain potential buyers.

site_title: Apple working with Broadcom to develop AI chip: report
summary: Apple is reportedly working with Broadcom to develop its first server chip specifically designed for artificial intelligence (AI) processing, internally code-named Baltra. The AI chip is expected to be ready for mass production by 2026, aligning with other major tech companies in reducing reliance on Nvidia's pricey processors. This move is part of Apple's efforts to power its compute-heavy AI services and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: Apple is looking to reinvigorate smartwatch sales with the new features after a slow stretch.
The recent gains come despite a tepid response to the latest iPhone model and a disappointing earnings report in late October.
For years, Apple engineers and designers complained that the Qualcomm modem and related parts took up too much space in the iPhone.
Apple has spent years trying to replace the Qualcomm modem chip in its iPhones.

site_title: US-China economy talks resume as Janet Yellen urges maintaining links
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged the next administration to maintain dialogue channels with China, citing the importance of open communication between the world's two largest economies. She established working groups with Chinese counterparts last year to discuss shared interests, such as combating the pandemic and climate change, and to address concerns about Russia's economic policies and China's macroeconomic imbalances. The next round of talks, scheduled for December 12 and 15, will focus on topics including macroeconomic stability and cross-border data.

images.alt_text: Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon vows to fight ‘until the very last minute’
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol has vowed to fight "until the very last minute" as a probe into his imposition of martial law and deployment of troops to the parliament gains pace. The probe is linked to an "insurrection" probe into Yoon's inner circle. Yoon accused the opposition of pushing the country into a "national crisis" and stated he would not avoid "legal and political responsibility" for the declaration. The opposition has warned it will file legal complaints against the presidential staff and security if they continue to obstruct law enforcement.

images.alt_text: South Korea Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (bottom right) highlighted growing downside risks and efforts to stabilise foreign exchange markets using common smoothing operations.

During a parliamentary hearing, the commissioner general of the Korea Correctional Service said former defence minister Kim Yong Hyun (pictured) tried to kill himself minutes before his arrest was announced.
Former South Korean defence minister Kim Yong Hyun was arrested on charges including “engaging in critical duties during an insurrection” and “abuse of authority to obstruct the exercise of rights”.
A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon

site_title: Blackstone keen to boost Nippon Life ties after Resolution deal
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, is eager to strengthen its ties with Nippon Life Insurance following its acquisition of Resolution Life Group Holdings for US$8.2 billion. Blackstone will continue to manage Resolution's private credit and other assets after the acquisition. Nippon Life's deal marks a significant expansion globally for the Japanese insurer. Blackstone President Jon Gray expressed enthusiasm for doing more business with Nippon Life, citing the potential for future collaborations and investments in Japan, where Blackstone aims to make around US$20 billion in real estate and corporate investments over the next three years.

images.alt_text: Nippon Life, Japan's largest insurer by assets, is trying to diversify its profit drivers as the local market faces demographic challenges that are hindering growth prospects.
Nippon Life will buy remaining shares in Resolution Life from Blackstone and others, making it a subsidiary in 2025.

site_title: Analysts place ‘buy’ call on Oiltek on strong order book, growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and Lim and Tan Securities have issued a "buy" call on Oiltek, citing a strong order book and growing demand for sustainable aviation fuel. The company's record order book of RM401 million for the third quarter has led to earnings growth expectations of 39% and 15% in 2024 and 2025, respectively. Oiltek's trading at a 25% discount to its peers, making it a "high-potential market" for sustainable aviation fuel production.

images.alt_text: Oiltek unit bags RM19.5 million in new contracts

site_title: Hong Kong’s US$38 billion year for M&A sparks rare bidding wars
summary: Hong Kong is poised for its busiest year for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in nearly a decade, with over $38 billion in deals targeting local firms. Bidding wars are intensifying as companies jostle for assets, with China's largest brokerage set to be created through the combination of Guotai Junan Securities and Haitong Securities. The uptick in M&A activity is also driving take-private deals, with several firms trading at a discount to elsewhere, as investors capitalize on low market valuations to acquire companies.

images.alt_text: Once synonymous with Hong Kong nightlife and in particular the city’s expat community, Lan Kwai Fong’s business mix is now changing to reflect what is becoming an increasingly Chinese city.
