site_title: Meta’s Instagram says services back up after outages
summary: Meta's Instagram services have been restored after experiencing technical issues, with over 100,000 incidents reported on Facebook and nearly 70,000 on Instagram at the peak of the outage. The outage, which began around 12:50 pm ET, affected thousands of users worldwide, but the number of reports has significantly decreased to over 1,000 as of 6 pm ET.

images.alt_text: TikTok Shop – which combines video with impulse buying in visual fashion – is the app’s biggest growth engine after advertising.

Australia this week approved a landmark law banning social media for children under 16.

site_title: Volatility could roil base metal markets in 2025; analysts favour copper, tin amid energy transition
summary: Base metal prices are expected to experience volatility in 2025 due to a stronger US dollar, escalating trade tensions, and China's economic momentum. Analysts favor copper and tin, citing their roles in the green transition and increasing demand from emerging markets. Copper is expected to perform well due to its widespread application in various industries, while tin's fundamentals are seen as "arguably the best" among base metals, with rising demand and a forecasted record deficit by 2030.

site_title: Tough 2024 for suburban business parks with rising vacancies; muted growth for industrial rents in 2025
summary: Suburban business parks in Singapore face challenges in 2024, with rising vacancies and muted growth. Industrial rents are expected to grow 2-3% in most submarkets, but suburban business parks are forecast to record flat growth due to the surge in new supply. City-fringe business parks, on the other hand, are expected to see a 2% year-on-year growth in rents. The decline in demand for industrial space, combined with increased supply, is expected to temper growth in rentals for the year ahead.

site_title: IFC, HSBC ink US$1 billion risk-sharing facility to boost trade financing in emerging markets
summary: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) and HSBC Holdings have signed a US$1 billion risk-sharing facility to boost trade financing in emerging markets. The partnership will equally share the risk on a portfolio of trade-related assets held by emerging-market banks in 20 countries across Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East. The facility aims to promote capital and trade flows in emerging markets and reduce the trade finance gap, supporting job creation and economic growth in the region.

site_title: US appeals court tosses Nasdaq board diversity rules
summary: A US appeals court has ruled that Nasdaq's board diversity rules, requiring companies to have women and minority directors, are invalid under federal securities law. The 9-8 decision, made by a conservative-majority court, sided with two advocacy groups that challenged the rules. The SEC had approved the rules in 2021, but the full court opted to reconsider the matter. The ruling could impact companies' diversity efforts and may lead to changes in corporate governance practices.

site_title: Singapore can support emerging market companies in their ESG ambitions
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to support emerging market companies in achieving environmental, social, and governance (ESG) ambitions due to its large pool of seasoned executives and accredited non-executive directors. The city-state offers diverse markets, resources, and sophisticated investors who prioritize impact, sustainability, and good corporate governance. The Singapore Institute of Directors has also established an accreditation framework to uplift director competencies. International Finance Corporation is ramping up its equity commitments to support ESG compliance in emerging markets, including through partnerships with Singapore investors and tapping into their pool of highly qualified directors.

images.alt_text: Whether you like or believe in them or not, both climate change and the clean-energy transition create risks and opportunities for companies. It’s bad business to ignore them.

site_title: Commerzbank to assign more employees to branches in revamp
summary: Commerzbank is revamping its 400 retail branches by assigning more employees to work in the branches, aiming to boost business with clients and avoid shutdowns. The bank will have at least one banker per branch to advise on mortgages and financial investments, and regroup customers into new segments based on their investment levels. This move follows employee shortages due to illness, which have occasionally forced higher-paid staff to assist with standard retail banking services. The changes are set to come into effect later next year.

images.alt_text: A Commerzbank AG bank branch in Frankfurt, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Bank of America promotes 387 employees to managing director: source
summary: Bank of America has promoted 387 employees to managing director roles in 2024, a 16% increase from last year. The promotions include over half women and people of color for the fifth consecutive year, as the bank seeks to diversify its workforce. Banking executives expect a lighter regulatory touch under President-elect Donald Trump and lower interest rates to spur dealmaking. BOA CEO Brian Moynihan also predicted a 25% rise in investment banking fees in the fourth quarter and a resilient US consumer market in 2025.

images.alt_text: Bank of America dropped down to category two from three previously.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise amid Fed rate-cut hopes; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to 3,809.27, driven by hopes of a Federal Reserve interest-rate cut this month, following mild US inflation data. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the top gainer, up 2.2%. Local banks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, also rebounded, while Sats lost 1.6%. Analysts are bullish on Oiltek, citing a strong order book and demand for sustainable aviation fuel. Markets across the Asia-Pacific region closed mostly in the green, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi up 1.2% and 1.6%, respectively.

site_title: Will Singapore’s ‘novel food’ dreams be ultra-processed?
summary: Singapore's "novel food" efforts may inadvertently promote ultra-processed foods, despite warnings about their health risks. Ultra-processed foods, engineered to be highly addictive, are linked to 32 health problems, including heart disease, cancer, and death. The Singapore Food Agency seeks proposals to develop novel foods, but caution is warranted due to the lack of long-term data on their health risks and the potential for adverse outcomes in a fast-ageing society.

site_title: Offshoring lures cost-conscious industrialists, but Singapore remains attractive: market watchers
summary: Singapore remains an attractive destination for cost-conscious industrialists despite high operating costs, thanks to its political stability, skilled workforce, and legal protections. While some companies are relocating to lower-cost markets, market experts say this trend is not widespread and that Singapore is poised to draw investments from firms in growth sectors like semiconductors and advanced manufacturing. Opportunities for redevelopment and repurposing of industrial spaces are emerging, particularly for high-value industries, and sustainability is becoming a key factor in industrial property decisions.

site_title: US brothers charged in luxury real estate sex-trafficking scheme
summary: US brothers Oren, Tal, and Alon Alexander have been charged with sex trafficking by federal prosecutors in New York. The brothers, founders of luxury real estate firm Official, allegedly used deception, fraud, and coercion to engage in sex trafficking, drugging, and assaulting dozens of women from 2010 to 2021. The charges carry a maximum sentence of life in prison, and the brothers' high-profile connections in the luxury real estate world are believed to have facilitated their crimes.

site_title: 7-Eleven battle shows resilience of Japan Inc’s family ties
summary: A US$58 billion takeover bid from the Ito dynasty, a founding family of 7-Eleven's parent company, has sparked a management buyout offer from Junro Ito, the vice-president of Seven & i Holdings. This bid is seen as a response to a rival bid from Canada's Alimentation Couche-Tard. The move is part of a trend of Japanese companies being taken private as the country's corporate governance standards change, making delisting an increasingly attractive option. Industry experts predict more management buyouts, citing the government's guidelines on giving consideration to credible buyout offers and the unwinding of cross shareholdings.

Bloomberg News reported on Wednesday that Seven & i was considering a management buyout, or MBO, worth up to nine trillion yen - above its market cap of 5.7 trillion yen.

site_title: Insurer Income sets up new financial advisory unit and is ‘actively recruiting’: sources
summary: Income Insurance is launching a new financial advisory unit, Income Advisory Group Holdings (IAG), to partner with individuals seeking to start their own financial advisory firms. IAG, led by Grace Tng, will hold a stake in the new firms and provide support through shared services. The move aims to expand Income's distribution abilities and complement its omni-channel distribution strategy. Industry players have raised concerns about the sustainability of this model, citing concerns over high buyout packages and potential industry-wide impact.

site_title: New Zealand primary exports tipped to recover despite trade risk
summary: New Zealand's primary exports are forecast to rebound 6.8% to NZ$56.9 billion in the 12 months to June 2025, after a 7.1% decline in the previous year. The country's reliance on China, its largest market, poses risks, but increased supplies and higher prices for dairy, beef, and seafood are expected to offset these. However, uncertainty remains due to potential shifts in trade and fiscal policy, geopolitical tensions, and US economic weakness, which could impact demand for New Zealand exports.

site_title: Man City crisis deepens with Champions League defeat at Juventus
summary: Manchester City suffered a 2-0 defeat to Juventus in the Champions League, deepening their crisis and putting their last 16 chances in jeopardy. The defeat, Manchester City's seventh in 10 matches, leaves them in 22nd place in Europe's top club competition with just eight points from six matches. The loss, coupled with their struggles in the Premier League, has City just one point above the bottom 12 places and elimination.

site_title: Stability, rich talent pool in South-east Asia drive double-digit growth for Citi across inter-Asean trade corridors
summary: Citi has reported double-digit growth in client activity across inter-Asean trade corridors, driven by the region's stability, talent pool, and geographic location. The bank's co-head of corporate banking, Jason Rekate, attributes this growth to the desire of multinational corporations to diversify their supply chains and manufacturing due to global tensions. Key growth corridors include Taiwan-Asean, India-Asean, and Japan-Asean, with Singapore emerging as a prime spot for multinationals to set up regional headquarters due to its strong regulatory environment and talent pool.

site_title: Dealmakers see return of more, bigger megadeals in 2025
summary: Wall Street executives expect a surge in megadeals in 2025 due to business-friendly regulations under the incoming Trump administration. The Federal Trade Commission, led by Andrew Ferguson, is expected to ease up on policing large mergers and acquisitions. This is anticipated to revive deals above $40 billion, which have been scarce in 2024. Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon is optimistic about dealmaking in equities and M&A, with some predicting a 10-year average. However, policy uncertainty and protectionism under Trump may pose headwinds for corporate dealmaking.

site_title: ServiceNow restructures RiseUp workforce training programme, cuts staff
summary: ServiceNow is restructuring its workforce training program RiseUp amid low job placement rates and corporate backlash to diversity-focused initiatives. The company has let go multiple workers, key leaders, and contractors, and is rebranding the program as ServiceNow University. Despite its initial goal of training one million people by 2024, ServiceNow has since softened its target to "skilling" three million people by 2027. The move comes as companies like Walmart and Zoom Communications have pulled back from diversity-oriented programs following the Supreme Court's ruling on affirmative action.

site_title: Nvidia challenge to investor suit spurned by Supreme Court
summary: The US Supreme Court dismissed Nvidia's appeal, allowing a lawsuit to proceed against the chipmaker for allegedly misleading shareholders about its reliance on crypto-mining revenue. The shareholders claim that CEO Jensen Huang hid the fact that record revenue growth was driven by mining-related sales, rather than gaming sales, in the run-up to a market crash in 2018. The dismissal is seen as a "big win for corporate accountability," ensuring that investors can seek justice and preserving fairness and transparency in the markets.

site_title: China is urging EV firms to invest in South Africa, official says
summary: China is urging its electric vehicle manufacturers to invest in South Africa, with the Asian nation's ambassador, Wu Peng, stating that Chinese companies should consider moving assembly lines or value-added production to the country. China is South Africa's biggest trading partner and the world's leader in EVs, with South Africa seeking to grow its EV industry. The South African government has announced plans to allow automakers to claim a 150% tax deduction on investment in EV facilities, but details have yet to be released.

site_title: Hershey’s main owner rejects Mondelez’s offer as too low
summary: Hershey's main owner, the Hershey Trust, rejected a preliminary takeover offer from Mondelez International, citing the offer as too low. The bid, valued at over $40 billion, including debt, would have created a food giant with combined sales of almost $50 billion. The trust's rejection ends a fresh pursuit that was sparked after Hershey reported third-quarter earnings that missed analyst expectations. Mondelez had approved a stock repurchase authorisation of up to $9 billion and remains committed to its capital allocation priorities.

images.alt_text: Mondelez makes Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies as well as Toblerone chocolate bars.

site_title: Adobe forecasts fiscal 2025 revenue below estimates on slower subscription spending
summary: Adobe forecasts fiscal 2025 revenue between US$23.3 billion and US$23.55 billion, below Wall Street estimates, due to foreign exchange volatility and subscription spending headwinds. The company expects a US$200 million headwind and has struggled to monetize its AI push. Shares fell over 8% in extended trading. Despite projecting strong growth for the second half of the year, Adobe's forecast indicates the company is taking longer to see the benefits of its AI investments.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed, Nasdaq closes above 20,000 for first time
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed session on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a new record of 20,34.89, closing 1.8% higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2% to 44,148.56, while the S&P 500 rose 0.8% to 6,084.19. The Nasdaq's gain was driven by Alphabet's breakthrough in quantum computing, despite US-EU tariff threats.

site_title: Dollar gains ahead of CPI, yuan falls as China considers allowing currency to weaken
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% against the offshore yuan and 0.14% against the onshore yuan, ahead of the US inflation data, as China considers allowing its currency to weaken in 2025 to counter higher US tariffs. The euro and pound also fell, while Asian currencies, including the Aussie and kiwi, dropped due to China's economic stimulus plans. Economists expect a 0.3% increase in US inflation, which could lead to a quarter-point rate cut by the Fed, supporting the dollar.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures the currency against the yen and five other major peers, rose 0.2 per cent to 106.34.

site_title: Oil settles up US$1 as EU agrees further sanctions threatening Russian oil flows
summary: The European Union agreed on a 15th package of sanctions on Russia, threatening its oil flows, and led to a rise in oil prices. Brent crude futures settled US$1.33 higher, or 1.84%, at US$73.52 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose US$1.70, or 2.48%, to US$70.29. This move is expected to tighten global crude supplies, contributing to the price increase.

site_title: Huawei’s New Mate 70 phone shows its chip advances are stalling
summary: Huawei's new Mate 70 phone, a flagship smartphone, is powered by a chip similar to the one from last year, despite rumors of a more advanced 5nm process. The Kirin 9020 chip is fabricated on a 7nm process node, indicating a slowdown in the company's tech advances. This means Huawei is still about five years behind industry leader Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) in terms of technology. The company's push for breakthroughs is hindered by challenges in chipmaking, including poor yield and reliability issues with its current technology.

site_title: ExxonMobil plan aims to accelerate oil production, earnings
summary: ExxonMobil plans to increase earnings by $20 billion and cash flow by $30 billion through 2030, with annual project spending rising to $28-33 billion. The company aims to more than triple its Permian production to 2.3 million barrels per day and increase output from its Guyana operations to 1.3 million barrels per day. This expansion is driven by its acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources and is expected to drive shareholder returns. Exxon's share price has risen 12.7% year-to-date, outperforming the energy sector.

site_title: Google unveils latest AI model, Gemini 2.0
summary: Google has unveiled Gemini 2.0, its most advanced AI model, marking a "new agentic era" in AI development. Gemini 2.0 is designed to understand context, think ahead, and take supervised actions, with enhanced Search capabilities set to roll out in early 2025. The model is powered by Google's sixth-generation TPU hardware, Trillium, and has been integrated into seven Google products, serving over two billion users. The tech giant promises AI agents will revolutionize the industry, following the success of ChatGPT.

site_title: Morocco, Spain and Portugal confirmed as 2030 World Cup hosts, 2034 edition awarded to Saudi Arabia
summary: FIFA has confirmed Morocco, Spain, and Portugal as the 2030 World Cup hosts, with the tournament to take place across three continents and six nations. The 2034 edition will be held in Saudi Arabia, marking the second Middle Eastern nation to host the quadrennial tournament. The decision was made by FIFA president Gianni Infantino following a virtual extraordinary Congress, with no bids contested in 2023. The 2030 tournament will include celebratory games in Uruguay, Argentina, and Paraguay to mark the tournament's centenary.

site_title: Europe: French blue-chips hit three-month low on budget angst
summary: French blue-chips hit a three-month low as investors fretted over the government's ability to pass its budget and concerns over potential US tariffs on European automobiles. The Stoxx 600 closed 0.28% higher, while France's main stock index dropped 1% to its lowest since August. French bonds saw a significant increase in borrowing costs, and the technology sector led declines in the Stoxx 600. The concerns over the budget and US tariffs kept European stocks under pressure, despite a 1.7% gain in rate-sensitive real estate stocks.

site_title: To define who we are and our values, a personal brand identity is what matters
summary: Developing a personal brand identity is crucial to defining one's values and individuality, separate from a job or organization. Gathering feedback from trusted individuals can help identify how others perceive you, and making intentional changes can shape your personal brand. By being aware of your listening skills and adopting a more patient approach, you can change perceptions and rebrand yourself. Effective personal branding can lead to increased self-worth, improved communication, and a stronger sense of identity.

summary: Ron Sim and Osim International have sent a legal letter of demand to Trek 2000 International's current and former chairmen, Wayne Tan and Henn Tan, alleging fraudulent misrepresentations made by Henn Tan before Sim acquired shares of Trek in 2015. Henn Tan, the founder and ex-chairman of Trek 2000 International, is accused of making false representations that Sim and Osim relied on when purchasing stock in the company. site_title: Up to 10,000 Bosch jobs at risk in Germany, deputy chairman says
summary: Up to 10,000 jobs at Bosch in Germany are at risk due to staff reduction schemes, according to the company's deputy supervisory board chairman Frank Sell. The cuts, part of a larger effort to ensure competitiveness, will be implemented in a socially responsible manner but may lead to strikes, Sell said. Bosch, the world's top auto supplier, employs around 135,000 staff in Germany, with the company's supervisory board set to convene on Friday to discuss the plans.

site_title: HSBC’s CEO eyes US$3 billion in potential savings from overhaul
summary: HSBC is planning a US$3 billion cost-cutting overhaul, expected to take until June 2025 to complete, representing a 10% reduction in its estimated US$32.6 billion expense bill. The bank's new CEO, Georges Elhedery, has already made significant changes, including reducing the size of his executive committee and cutting the number of top managers by about 40%. The restructuring aims to create four new divisions, including a premier banking and wealth unit, with the goal of providing a "clear competitive advantage and the greatest opportunity to grow."

site_title: Vestas to cut 300 jobs at British wind turbine plant
summary: Vestas to cut 300 jobs at its British wind turbine plant on the Isle of Wight as it transitions to manufacturing blades for onshore rather than offshore wind power. The restructuring is due to declining demand and site constraints, with around 300 jobs sustained and the company offering opportunities in other areas. The UK government supports the move, seeing it as essential for its clean energy mission and securing work for a major employer. Vestas will still employ over 1,500 people in Britain across onshore and offshore activities.

site_title: Reckoning with an era of slow growth
summary: The UK and European high-income countries have experienced stagnant economic growth since the post-World War II era, with the US, France, Germany, and Japan outpacing the UK in terms of real GDP per head. The era of rapid growth, driven by post-war reconstruction, mass consumption, and trade liberalization, is considered a one-off. Opportunities exist for the UK to catch up with the US, raise incomes in "left behind" regions, or return to the EU's customs union and single market. However, policymakers must focus on economic reforms, managing public spending, promoting competition, innovation, and investment, and encouraging immigration by skilled people to ensure sustainable growth.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after inflation data solidifies rate-cut bets
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, December 11, 2024, after an in-line inflation reading solidified rate-cut bets from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 52.6 points, or 0.12%, to 44,300.41. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with gains of 25.2 and 145.7 points, respectively, at the opening bell. The inflation data reinforced expectations of a potential interest rate cut later this month, contributing to the market's positive tone.

site_title: Hyundai to help tip US$1.1 billion into China unit as sales crater
summary: Hyundai and its sister brand Kia are injecting US$1.1 billion into their China joint venture, Beijing Hyundai Motor, in an effort to boost sales and exports. The capital injection aims to support the company's transition to electric vehicles and expand its product offerings in the Chinese market. Despite the move, Hyundai's sales in China have cratered, with a 41% decline in vehicle sales from the same period in 2023. The company's Beijing Hyundai unit is also loss-making, with a deficit of 2.6 billion yuan as of September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers assemble cars inside the Hyundai Motor India Ltd. plant at Kancheepuram district in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu October 4, 2012. REUTERS/Babu/File Photo

site_title: Net-zero policies in Asean may cause food production costs to jump 60% by 2050: report
summary: A report by Oxford Economics warns that implementing net-zero policies in Southeast Asia's food production sector could lead to a 30.8-58.9% increase in food production costs by 2050. The region's reliance on fossil fuels and climate change will drive up energy and labor costs, affecting food prices. Indonesia is expected to bear the brunt, with a 58.9% increase, followed by Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines. New foreign direct investment is key to driving transformation and mitigating these risks, with development partners providing financial assistance and technical expertise.

images.alt_text: PM Wong shakes hands with Thailand's prime minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra during a signing ceremony and press conference at the Government House in Bangkok.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas has delivered two quarter-point cuts since August to bring its key interest rate to 6 per cent.
Production of the vegetable oil in Indonesia has stagnated in recent years due to ageing trees.

site_title: Europe’s loan bankers pin hopes on M&A revival to boost volumes
summary: European loan bankers are optimistic about a M&A revival in 2025, driven by lower interest rates, tight bond spreads, and a favorable US economic environment. M&A transactions reached $40 billion globally on Monday, with Mondelez International exploring an acquisition of Hershey. EMEA investment-grade loans' volumes increased by 8% in 2024, but still lag behind 2022 levels. To boost volumes, banks are relying on close relationships and refinancing existing loan facilities. However, fierce competition from the bond market and stricter regulation may limit loan growth, with some firms opting for bond financing instead.

images.alt_text: Nippon Life, Japan's largest insurer by assets, is trying to diversify its profit drivers as the local market faces demographic challenges that are hindering growth prospects.
Club Med is known for its all-inclusive resorts offering a range of leisure activities from fine dining and massages to yoga, scuba diving, and baby gym classes.
Alaska Airlines expects to earn at least US$10 per share in 2027, more than double the US$4.25 to US$4.50 estimated for 2024. It forecast a pretax margin of between 11 per cent and 13 per cent.
A judge's suspension deals a significant blow to what would have been one of the largest retail grocery deals in US history.
Prudential is working with a financial adviser on a review of Eastspring, which could be valued at about US$3 billion in a potential stake sale.

site_title: Verdict on Swiss handling of Credit Suisse meltdown to set tone for UBS
summary: A long-awaited report on Switzerland's handling of Credit Suisse's 2023 collapse is set to be published, potentially influencing new regulations for UBS, the bank's new owner. The report is expected to criticize the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority (Finma) for its response to the crisis, which Swiss officials have blamed on Credit Suisse's management. The report's findings may set the tone for stricter oversight of systemically important banks, with a focus on increasing capital requirements, although the parliamentary committee will not recommend this.

images.alt_text: UBS said in a statement that it “welcomes the court’s decision to acquit the bank in connection with a legacy matter related to Credit Suisse.”
The exits include two Singapore-based bankers and two more junior bankers based in Hong Kong.

site_title: Alternatives to a pay rise
summary: Companies are exploring alternative solutions to pay rises, such as one-off bonuses, upskilling opportunities, and enhanced wellbeing benefits, to keep employees satisfied and incentivize productivity without straining finances. Experts say that money isn't always everything, especially for those seeking meaning in their work. These cost-effective alternatives are gaining acceptance globally, offering employees a more holistic approach to compensation and work-life balance.

site_title: US CPI rises 0.3% in November, the largest gain in seven months
summary: The US consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.3% in November, the largest gain in seven months, but the annual increase in inflation has slowed considerably from a peak of 9.1% in June 2022. Despite this, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates for a third time next week due to a cooling labor market. The Fed is now more focused on the labor market, with the unemployment rate ticking up to 4.2% in November. Economists expect fewer rate cuts next year amid moderating inflation and rising labor market slack.

images.alt_text: SUNRISE, FLORIDA - JUNE 26: Elizabeth Brunner (L) and Hope Johnson (R), recruiters for the City of Pompano Beach, speak to job seekers during the JobNewsUSA.com South Florida Job Fair held at the Amerant Bank Arena on June 26, 2024, in Sunrise, Florida. More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives. site_title: Del Monte Q2 net loss widens to US$22.2 million on subsidiary’s lower profit, higher interest expense
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$22.2 million for the second quarter, widening from a US$8.5 million loss in the previous quarter, due to lower profit and higher interest expenses from its US subsidiary, Del Monte Foods. The company's gross profit fell to US$78.5 million, and revenue rose 4% to US$694 million. The group expects to incur a net loss in FY2025, but aims to "actively restore" gross margins and achieve gradual improvement in FY2026 and FY2027.

images.alt_text: Canned food brand Del Monte Pacific's gross profit falls by 19.1 per cent to US87.6 million for Q1.
Del Monte Pacific is not paying a dividend for FY2024 because of the net loss, whereas shareholders were rewarded US$0.0013 per share as final dividend in FY2023.

Organic strawberries from Harry’s Berries, grown in Oxnard, Calif., which sell for $15-20 a pound, at Melissa’s Produce in Los Angeles, May 22, 2024. Luxury fruits, which have a long history in parts of Asia, especially as gifts, are catching on in the U.S. with Americans who desire the flawless berries and melons they may have tried overseas. site_title: Opec makes deepest cut yet to 2024 world oil demand forecast
summary: OPEC has cut its 2024 oil demand forecast by 210,000 barrels a day to 1.6 million barrels a day, marking its deepest reduction yet. The cartel has also slashed its projections by 27% since July, recognizing a deteriorating market picture. This is the fifth straight month OPEC has reduced its forecast, following an agreement to extend supply curbs and delay plans to restart halted crude production. The move comes as oil prices have declined 17% since early July.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$72.19 a barrel, up 5 cents or 0.07 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: India's newly-appointed central bank chief commits to policy continuity
summary: India's newly-appointed central bank governor Sanjay Malhotra has committed to policy continuity, emphasizing the need for stability over short-term changes. In his first press conference, Malhotra stated that businesses and people require stability in policymaking, rather than day-to-day adjustments. This stance may ease market uncertainty following the surprise appointment. Malhotra's three-year term aims to uphold stability, which differs from the approach of his predecessor, Shaktikanta Das.

site_title: Which economy did best in 2024?
summary: The world economy delivered a strong performance in 2024, with global GDP rising by 3.2%, according to the International Monetary Fund. Spain topped the ranking of 37 mostly rich countries, followed by Greece, Italy, Ireland, and Denmark. The Mediterranean region's economic recovery continued, while northern European heavyweights such as Britain and Germany underperformed. The ranking varied across five economic and financial indicators: real GDP growth, stock market returns, core inflation, unemployment, and fiscal balances. Despite some challenges ahead, countries like Spain, Greece, and Italy can celebrate their economic resurgence.

images.alt_text: The BOK has stepped up its measures to stabilise markets since the martial-law row erupted and pledged “unlimited liquidity” if necessary in coordination with the government.
The IMF’s latest World Economic Outlook forecasts global economic growth at 3.2% for both 2024 and 2025, weaker than its more optimistic projections for Asia.

site_title: An Opec for solar power isn’t going to work
summary: China's solar power producers sign an Opec-style agreement, allocating quotas based on existing capacity and forecasts. Over 30 producers joined, aiming to stabilize prices after a year of excess production driving prices below costs, resulting in losses of 7.7 billion yuan for the big four panelmakers. The move is seen as an attempt to address the crisis, but the industry's reliance on technological advancements raises concerns about obsolescence.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A worker checks solar photovoltaic modules used for solar panels at a factory in Suqian in China's eastern Jiangsu province on May 9, 2023. Strong state support and huge private investment have made China's solar industry a global powerhouse but it faces new headwinds, from punitive tariffs abroad to a brutal price war at home. (Photo by AFP) / - China OUT / To go with 'CLIMATE-COP29-UN-CHINA-SOLAR, FOCUS' by Oliver HOTHAM

site_title: New York to close giant family shelter to protect migrants from Trump
summary: New York City officials announced the closure of a giant tent complex in Brooklyn housing 2,000 migrants, citing a decline in arrivals and concerns about potential Trump administration raids. The shelter, on federal land, will shut down by March, with families relocated by January 15. The move is part of a city-wide effort to consolidate and close 25 shelters, which have seen a 25% decline in migrant arrivals over the past five months.

images.alt_text: The interview on NBC’s "Meet the Press with Kristen Welker" was taped on Friday but aired on Sunday, following Trump’s meetings with the presidents of France and Ukraine over the weekend - his first foreign trip since winning the November election against Vice-President Kamala Harris.
FILE PHOTO: A view of East Hastings street in Downtown Eastside of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada January 31, 2023. REUTERS/Jennifer Gauthier/File Photo

site_title: BOJ sees little cost to waiting for next rate hike
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is considering waiting to raise interest rates next week, despite signs of low inflation risk, according to officials familiar with the matter. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda and his board will assess data and financial markets before making a decision on the benchmark rate, which is currently at 0.25%. The decision comes as the yen shows no strong momentum toward weakness, reducing the risk of inflation. Officials will closely watch US CPI data, the quarterly Tankan business sentiment survey, and the Federal Reserve meeting before delivering the policy decision on December 19.

site_title: Bank of England set to stay in central bank slow lane and keep rates on hold
summary: The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% next week, following a recent slowdown in price growth, but remains on alert about price pressures in Britain's jobs market. The BOE has cut rates only twice in 16 years, and investors see a one-in-10 chance of a rate cut on December 19. The European Central Bank, US Federal Reserve, and other central banks are expected to lower borrowing costs in the coming days, but the BOE is moving more slowly to cut rates.

images.alt_text: The collapse in standards has come at an inconvenient moment. A misleading dip in growth or a questionable jobs report could provoke a financial markets response with nasty consequences for borrowing costs.
The UK’s Office for National Statistics has been struggling to collect sufficient and accurate data on employment trends, leading to severe criticism from central bankers and politicians.

FILE PHOTO: Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, gestures as he addresses the media during a press conference at the Bank of England in London, Britain, August 1, 2024. Alberto Pezzali/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Nvidia, AMD and Intel invest in startup bringing light to chips
summary: Ayar Labs, a startup that uses light to transfer data between chips, raised US$155 million from Nvidia, AMD Ventures, and Intel Capital in a funding round led by Advent Global Opportunities and Light Street Capital. The investment valued the company at over US$1 billion. This funding aims to address the power and heat challenges in AI processing, which relies on rapid data transmission.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tik Tok logos are seen on smartphones in front of a displayed ByteDance logo in this illustration taken November 27, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) said Nvidia is suspected of violating commitments it made during its acquisition of Mellanox Technologies.

Jensen Huang, CEO and founder of Nvidia, said that the data stored on Thailand’s sovereign cloud server could be used to power a local “AI ecosystem”, such as a generative AI chatbot fed by Thai data.
CEO and founder of Nvidia Jensen Huang met with Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra while on a visit to Bangkok, and the two agreed to deepen cooperation on artificial intelligence.

site_title: South Korea flags economic risks as political turmoil rumbles on
summary: South Korea is facing growing economic risks amid political turmoil, with Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok highlighting downside risks and efforts to stabilize foreign exchange markets. The country's currency depreciated to its worst level against the US dollar since 2009 following a bungled martial-law attempt by President Yoon Suk-yeol. Despite a parliamentary vote to nullify the decree, stock markets struggle to recover, and policymakers are working to mitigate the impact through common smoothing operations.

images.alt_text: A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
