Taiwan’s equity-market outperformance has a lot to do with this year’s 80 per cent surge in the shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, the world’s top advanced chipmaker that accounts for 37 per cent of the benchmark’s weighting.

site_title: Chinese authorities are considering a weaker yuan as Trump trade risks loom: sources
summary: Chinese authorities are considering allowing the yuan to weaken in 2025 as US trade tariffs under Donald Trump's presidency loom. The move would deviate from the usual practice of keeping the foreign exchange rate stable and could make Chinese exports cheaper. China's central bank has pledged to adopt a "basically loose" monetary policy next year, and analysts suggest temporarily switching the yuan's anchor from the US dollar to a basket of non-US dollar currencies. A weaker yuan could help China's economy, but risks a tariff cascade and backlash from other trading partners.

images.alt_text: Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.
Beijing has pushed for technology self-reliance in the face of growing curbs from the US.
The anomaly has appeared in global trade data from early 2020, when China started to say it was selling more goods to the US than America reported buying from the Asian manufacturing behemoth.
The dollar index, which measures the currency against the yen and five other major peers, rose 0.2 per cent to 106.34.
The yuan has weakened as traders grew disappointed over China’s stimulus measures

site_title: From TikTok to Nvidia, the tech war is getting uglier
summary: A US federal appeals court has upheld a law forcing TikTok to divest from its Chinese parent ByteDance or face a ban, further escalating the US-China tech war. China's market regulators are targeting Nvidia Corp in a probe over a deal approved years ago, while Beijing has cut off drone supplies to the US and Europe. The ruling sends a chilling message to Chinese tech firms, warning them against expanding too big in the US, and is likely to lead to more retaliatory measures from Beijing.

images.alt_text: ByteDance has diversified to domestic suppliers of chips used in AI and accelerated development of its own since the US in 2022 started restricting exports of advanced AI chips.
Singapore is emerging as a favourite destination for Chinese AI startups seeking to go global.

site_title: A US$319 billion corner of ESG bond market faces ‘slow demise’
summary: The US$319 billion sustainability-linked bond (SLB) market is experiencing a "slow demise" due to greenwashing claims, difficulties in tracking sustainable goals, and tougher regulations. SLB issuance in the US has fallen 46% in 2024 compared to 2023, with no deals issued so far this year. Companies are instead opting for green bonds or sustainability-linked loans, which are less scrutinized by markets. Despite this, issuance of all sustainable debt has risen above $1.49 trillion this year, with green bonds on track to raise $685 billion.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024
This issuance will be consolidated with OUE’s existing S$150 million in green notes, which were issued on Oct 8, 2024, to form a single series.
MSCI's glidepath indexes help managers of corporate bond portfolios to slowly shift their holdings towards more sustainable issuers.
ST Telemedia Global Data Centres will look into applying for green building certifications for existing data centres, such as STT Singapore 6 (above).

site_title: World Bank sees Myanmar economy shrinking as civil war rages on
summary: The World Bank forecasts Myanmar's economy to contract by 1% in the current fiscal year and shrink by 11% since 2019 due to the ongoing civil war, elevated inflation, and a weak currency. The country's military junta predicts 3.8% growth, but the World Bank warns of a further escalation in conflict, potential natural disasters, and longer disruptions that could plunge households deeper into poverty. Inflation is expected to remain high at 26% and shortages of electricity and imported raw materials continue to disrupt sectors.

images.alt_text: Thailand's national flag flies over the city skyline in Bangkok on October 28, 2024. (Photo by Alex OGLE / AFP)

site_title: The Philippines probe to go ahead as Duterte skips questioning
summary: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte will proceed with a probe into her alleged assassination threat against President Ferdinand Marcos Jr after failing to appear for questioning for a second time. Duterte has vehemently denied making any threat, citing the content and context of a November 23 online briefing. The National Bureau of Investigation will submit its recommendation to the Department of Justice by early January, amid two impeachment complaints filed against her. The probe follows a public feud between Duterte and Marcos over policy disagreements, which risks causing political instability in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: The complaint adds to Duterte’s legal woes as she faces a probe into her alleged death threat against President Ferdinand Marcos and another inquiry into her use of government funds.

Sara Duterte (top) appeared to walk those comments back on Tuesday, describing them as an expression of “consternation” at the Marcos administration’s “failure to serve the Filipinos while it masterfully persecutes political enemies”.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 11)
summary: Official estimates indicate 2024 full-year growth at 3.5%. Private-sector economists' forecast for 2024 growth increased, but only slightly for 2025. The interest rate for CPF Special, MediSave, and Retirement Accounts will drop to 4% per annum from Jan 1 to Mar 31, 2025. Charge+ acquired 140 EV chargers from companies that have ceased commercial charging services in Singapore. Singapore stocks fell, with Hongkong Land leading losses, resulting in a 0.5% decline in the STI index.

site_title: China auto body seeks subsidy extension as EV exports take hit
summary: China's largest auto industry group is urging the government to extend a vehicle trade-in policy that offers a 20,000 yuan subsidy to boost domestic car sales amid declining electric vehicle exports. The policy, set to end this month, contributed to record high auto production and sales in November. Industry officials cited unstable international markets and changing trade policies as reasons for the request. China's domestic auto wholesales rose 11.7% to a record 3.3 million units in November, with new energy vehicles surging 47.4%.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, December 11, 2024
summary: The Bank of England is set to keep interest rates on hold, while Axiata and Sinar Mas are forming a $6.5 billion telco giant in Indonesia to drive 5G expansion. The rupee has slipped to a record low. Dasin Retail Trust is terminating its remaining mall management agreements, leading to market volatility in Singapore, with the STI down 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Declines in the local stocks were despite positive sentiment regarding Singapore’s full-year growth for 2024, which economists predict will climb significantly.
Shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai rose in early trade, while there were also gains in Wellington and Jakarta.
Malaysia’s Axiata and Indonesia’s Sinar Mas will become joint controlling shareholders of the enlarged entity, with each holding a 34.8% stake.
Ocean Metro Mall is one of four malls whose commercial and property management agreements will not be renewed upon their expiry this month.

site_title: Japan to propose defence spending tax increases starting in 2026
summary: Japan's coalition government plans to propose a 4% corporate tax surtax and a 1% income tax surtax starting in 2026 to fund increased defence spending. The goal is to double the defence budget to 2% of GDP by 2027. The proposal comes after years of delays due to opposition from lawmakers. The government faces challenges in securing funding for the planned 43 trillion yen defence spending over five years, which could impact its aim to balance the budget by 2025.

site_title: London’s Canary Wharf borrows £610 million from Apollo in refinancing deal
summary: London's Canary Wharf district has borrowed £610 million from US investment giant Apollo to repay bonds due in 2025 and 2026, reducing near-term refinancing risks and increasing funding costs. The loan, secured with clients and funds managed by Apollo, will repay bonds taken out at lower interest rates. The deal eases pressure on landlord Canary Wharf Group, which has faced challenging trading since the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Rutland Gate has planning permission to be redeveloped as a luxury home, removing a major paperwork headache for certain potential buyers.

A new residential property development in an area of green belt land in Crowthorne, UK, on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024. UK property surveyors expect a jump in home sales in the coming months after the Bank of England cut interest rates for the first time in more than four years. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg
Banks and building societies approved 68,300 home loans in October, an increase from 66,100 the previous month.
Nationwide said the £2.3 billion gain from the Virgin deal was more than the £1.5 billion it had previously forecast earlier this year.

site_title: South Korea’s fading nightlife signals shift in hard-drinking culture
summary: South Korea's nightlife is fading due to a shift in the country's hard-drinking culture, driven by corporate Korea's slowdown on after-work drinking bouts, the emergence of a more health-conscious younger generation, and rising interest rates. The decline has dealt a major blow to popular drinking establishments and reflects a broader slowdown in domestic demand. With alcohol consumption dropping 12% from 2015, the country's economy faces challenges in addressing a disparity between solid exports and weak domestic consumption.

images.alt_text: LVMH’s Cognac brand Hennessy has increased consignments to the US following Trump’s victory last month, while its label Moët & Chandon is among the Champagne makers that intend to do the same.
Only 400 bottles of Hibiki 40 Years Old are available globally.
Output in France, the biggest wine producer last year, is set to sink by 23 per cent, the largest drop in the sector.

site_title: Club Med owner shares jump 83% after Hong Kong take-private offer
summary: Club Med's owner, Fosun Tourism Group, has made a 95% premium offer to buy back minority shares, resulting in a 83% surge in its Hong Kong shares. The move aims to boost growth as a private company, allowing the company to focus on core businesses and transition into an asset-light operation. Fosun Tourism's shares have declined 31% this year, and the company's first-half profit from operations fell 23% from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Club Med is known for its all-inclusive resorts offering a range of leisure activities from fine dining and massages to yoga, scuba diving, and baby gym classes.

site_title: Hong Kong’s New World sells Kowloon industrial tower for US$80 million: report
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development sold a 22-storey industrial tower, Artisan Lab, in Kowloon for US$80 million. The sale is part of the company's plan to offload non-core assets amid a liquidity crunch and recent management changes, including the replacement of its CEO. This sale follows New World's decision to sell China property assets, as the company seeks to alleviate its financial struggles.

site_title: Zara owner Inditex’s sales growth slows as holiday shopping begins
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported slower sales growth at the start of the holiday shopping season, with revenue growth of 9% in the five weeks to Dec 9, compared to 14% a year earlier. This is slower than the 10.5% sales growth achieved in the nine months to October. The company's tightly managed supply chain allows it to stay agile on fashion trends and potential headwinds, but unseasonably warm weather and weak demand in key markets have affected rivals.

images.alt_text: Zara owner Inditex said its sales between Aug 1 and Sep 8 saw an 11 per cent boost in constant currency compared with a year ago.

Zara owner Inditex reported a 7 per cent rise in sales for its first quarter to the end of April, an expected slowdown from a year earlier when the company benefited from a post-pandemic shopping spree.

site_title: ADB trims developing Asia’s growth forecast, flags US policy risks
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has trimmed its growth forecast for developing Asia, citing US policy risks that could slow growth and drive inflation higher. The bank now projects a 4.9% growth rate for this year and 4.8% for next year, down from previous forecasts of 5% and 4.9%. Changes to US trade, fiscal, and immigration policies could impact developing Asia's growth, with the US president-elect's swift changes to US trade policy posing a significant risk.

images.alt_text: In his new role that begins next year, Kanda will be tasked to navigate the ADB through fresh challenges such as helping Asia reduce poverty and mitigate risks from climate change.
Philippines topped the 2022 to 2024 World Risk Index which assesses populations most at risk from earthquakes, cyclones, floods, droughts and sea-level rise.
The ADB has set a long-term cumulative climate finance lending target of US$100 billion between 2019 and 2030.
The bank cut its 2024 inflation forecast for Thailand as ample market supply translated into lower food prices, which are, however, expected to creep up through the year.

site_title: Charge+ buys 140 EV chargers from 3 companies that have ceased commercial charging services in Singapore
summary: Charge+, an EV charging point operator in Singapore, has acquired 140 public and shared EV chargers from three companies, eChargz, PaC Components, and Quickcharge.sg, which have ceased commercial charging services. This acquisition brings Charge+'s total charging points to around 2,500. Charge+ CEO Goh Chee Kiong believes this move signals a consolidation phase of the EV charging point industry.

images.alt_text: The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.
Senior Minister of State for Sustainability and the Environment Amy Khor says that high-mileage drivers in particular need fast chargers.
ComfortDelGro Engie is one of two electric vehicle (EV) charger operators to be awarded public EV charger deployment contracts by EV-Electric Charging.
A charging plug on an electric vehicle in Guangzhou, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The sale of Bukom assets and the acquisition of Pavilion Energy is part of the global direction and strategy said Aw Kah Peng, Chairperson, Shell Singapore

site_title: CPF Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts’ interest rate falls to 4% for Q1 2025
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) has announced that interest rates for its Special, MediSave, and Retirement Accounts will fall to 4% per annum from January 1 to March 31, 2025, due to lower 10-year Singapore Government Securities yields. The Ordinary Account interest rate remains unchanged at 2.5%, while HDB housing loan interest rates remain the same. All CPF members will earn extra interest on their savings, with capped rates for OAs. The Basic Healthcare Sum for 2025 is also raised to $75,500 for members under 65.

images.alt_text: The annual cost increase of around US$368 million (S$494.3 million) with CPF contributions to platform workers excludes other costs, such as workplace injury compensation insurance

site_title: Thailand unveils debt-relief measures to cover US$26 billion loans
summary: Thailand has introduced debt-relief measures to cover US$26 billion loans, benefiting 1.9 million borrowers with household debt estimated at US$500 billion. The measures include interest suspension for three years and a reduction in instalments of principal for retail borrowers and small businesses. Eligible borrowers will also have the option to pay 10% of their dues and close their loans. The debt relief aims to ease the overall debt burden and tackle the nation's high household debt, which has weighed on the economy.

images.alt_text: The clarification came days after Pichai mooted the idea of hiking the consumption tax to 15 per cent from the current 7 per cent to address income inequality and mobilise funds for public investment to boost a sluggish economy.

site_title: Tesla sells 21,900 EVs in China in first week of December, the highest in Q4
summary: Tesla sold 21,900 electric vehicles in China in the first week of December, the highest weekly sales in Q4 2024, according to Tesla China. This follows a record-breaking November sales of over 73,000 units. The Model Y remains the best-selling passenger vehicle in China, with 556,000 units sold in the past year. Tesla offered a 10,000 yuan discount on outstanding loans for the Model Y to boost year-end sales amid increased competition from BYD.

site_title: Landmark London office tower sale falls through on pricing deadlock: sources
summary: Blackstone has pulled out of talks to buy the landmark office property "Can of Ham" in London's City of London after its owner Nuveen refused an offer of around £300 million. The 516,000 square foot property, let to several tenants, remains on the market. The deal would have been one of the largest transactions in European real estate this year, but a pricing deadlock prevented a sale. The failure highlights the challenges in the UK property market, which has been struggling with declining occupancy and market values due to the post-pandemic malaise.

images.alt_text: A view of 70 St Mary Axe, nicknamed the 'Can of Ham', in London, Britain, October 18, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams

site_title: Could Paragon soon change hands?
summary: Paragon Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, may be sold or wound down by its parent company, Cuscaden Peak, which owns 61% of the trust. Cuscaden Peak has been divesting properties, including the sale of The Rail Mall for S$78.5 million and The Woodleigh Mall for S$800 million. The trust's portfolio is expected to shrink, potentially resulting in a significant payout to unitholders. Despite its premium quality and scarcity value, Paragon's assets may fetch a good price due to the current low capitalisation rates.

images.alt_text: The property, Figtree Grove, is a shopping centre in Wollongong, a coastal city in Australia.
The Woodleigh Mall at Bidadari estate.
The acquisition brings Mapletree’s overall student housing portfolio to a total of 33,000 beds across 47 cities.

site_title: Former bank employee implicated in $3b money laundering saga to plead guilty
summary: A former Citibank relationship manager, Wang Qiming, will plead guilty to 10 charges, including money laundering and forgery, related to Singapore's largest money laundering case. Wang, 27, had facilitated offences involving two convicted money launderers and allegedly possessed $481,678 in cash linked to their crimes. He faces up to 14 years in prison and will return to court on January 8, 2025.

site_title: Xi readies bargaining chips for US trade war after Biden curbs
summary: China has taken retaliatory measures against the US in response to the Biden administration's curbs on China's access to AI chip components. President Xi Jinping has opened an investigation into Nvidia and banned the export of rare materials with military applications. Beijing has also limited sales to the US and Europe of key components used to build drones. The move appears to be a calculated response to threaten the US without causing significant economic damage to China. China's Politburo has vowed to provide bolder economic support in 2025, easing monetary policy stance, and has prepared a range of tools to retaliate against US actions.

images.alt_text: Beijing has pushed for technology self-reliance in the face of growing curbs from the US.
The anomaly has appeared in global trade data from early 2020, when China started to say it was selling more goods to the US than America reported buying from the Asian manufacturing behemoth.
The president-elect has threatened to impose 60 per cent tariffs on all Chinese imports, which would likely spur retaliatory action from Beijing.
Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust to terminate remaining mall management agreements
summary: Dasin Retail Trust will terminate the remaining mall management agreements for four properties, including Shiqi Metro Mall, Xiaolan Metro Mall, Ocean Metro Mall, and Dasin E-Colour, upon their expiry on Dec 31, 2024. The decision was made despite two minority directors not voting on the resolutions, as the trustee-manager believed they were "conflicted" due to outstanding receivables. The trust's current trade payables to related parties stood at S$2.8 million as of June 2023, down from S$3.8 million at end-December 2022.

images.alt_text: The trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust says the announcement represents the view of most of the board.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust's initial portfolio.  Its unitholders rejected the resolutions at an EGM on Sep 9.
The trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust demands that both minority directors stop obstructing the trust's restructuring efforts.
Amendments to the trust deed requires the approval of the bourse operator, said the trustee-manager of Dasin Retail Trust.
Ocean Metro Mall, one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust's initial portfolio. The trustee-manager aims to convene the EGM by end-September.

Ocean Metro Mall is one of three malls in Dasin Retail Trust’s initial portfolio. The trustee-manager said it has received a letter of demand from GSUM-Titanland Capital for an alleged outstanding sum of S$214,000.

site_title: Women’s World Cup 2027 to kick off on Jun 24: Fifa
summary: The 2027 Women's World Cup, set to take place in Brazil from June 24 to July 25, will feature 32 teams and follow the same confederation slot allocation as the 2023 editions. The tournament will have 11 direct European slots, six direct Asian slots, four each from Africa and North America, and three from South America, with the remaining three slots determined through a 10-team playoff tournament. This will be the first edition of the women's world championship to be held in South America.

images.alt_text: “Fifa is taking the concept of a legacy fund to the next level in terms of reach and impact by tackling key priorities such as refugees, occupational health, education, and football development,” says Fifa President Gianni Infantino.
“We are delighted to welcome Hisense, a global market-leading brand, as an official partner of the Fifa Club World Cup 2025,” Fifa president Gianni Infantino said.
FIFA will begin a global dialogue with key stakeholders to decide on the conclusions to be drawn from the Diarra decision and determine the most appropriate changes.

site_title: SpaceX share sale values company at about US$350 billion
summary: SpaceX has agreed to purchase up to $1.25 billion of insider shares, valuing the company at approximately $350 billion. The per-share price of $185 is a significant increase from the prior valuation of $112. This transaction cements SpaceX's status as the most valuable private startup in the world. The valuation reflects the post-election gains across Elon Musk's business empire, with Musk's own wealth soaring to about $384 billion. The company is offering to purchase up to $500 million worth of common stock.

images.alt_text: The use of Starlink in conflict has gained the attention of China, another US adversary.
The potential valuation surge underscores the enormous gains that Elon Musk’s empire has seen since the US presidential election.
Elon Musk speaks with US President-elect Donald Trump and guests at a viewing of the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship, Brownsville, Texas, Nov 19, 2024.

site_title: Malaysia court bars PetroSaudi from 1MDB-linked funds
summary: A Malaysian court approved the government's application to bar PetroSaudi International and its CEO from accessing $340 million linked to the 1MDB scandal. The money was deemed connected to money-laundering activities. The court's decision effectively bars the company and its CEO from accessing the funds. This move follows a series of investigations into the scandal, which has led to criminal investigations in the US, Switzerland, and Singapore.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim presenting the 2025 national budget document at Parliament.

FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers as the jailed politician left the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.
The Kuala Lumpur High Court granted their bid for a discharge not amounting to an acquittal, due to procedural delays and the failure of the prosecution to disclose key documents, their lawyers said.
Prabowo’s push to create Danantara is seen as a shrewd strategy to better manage the nation’s investment assets.
Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak issued a rare apology last week for his role in mishandling the scandal, which occurred during his tenure as prime minister and finance minister.

FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers, waves to photographers as the jailed politician leaves the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: BlackRock sees investor shift from cash after even ‘modest’ rate cuts
summary: BlackRock's CFO, Martin Small, expects investors to shift from cash to stocks and bonds after modest Federal Reserve interest rate cuts, despite high borrowing costs. Despite a rise in US money market assets to $6.77 trillion, investors are not abandoning cash due to ongoing economic uncertainty. Small notes that investors who favor cash are underperforming traditional portfolios, and the fear of missing out is driving re-risking.

images.alt_text: BlackRock has also developed artificial intelligence tools that show economic activity by county or zip code, and the impact of extreme weather on credits.
FILE PHOTO: The BlackRock logo is pictured outside its headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., May 25, 2021.  REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo
Blackrock Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: TikTok Shop goes live for Spain, Ireland in Europe rollout
summary: TikTok has launched its in-app shopping feature, TikTok Shop, in Spain and Ireland, marking its expansion across Europe. The platform allows creators to set up digital stores and sell products, including beauty and home appliances, with prices ranging from €3 to €60. This move follows a potential US shutout, as a federal appeals court upheld the Biden administration's divest-or-ban law citing national security concerns. TikTok Shop aims to compete with rivals like Amazon and set itself apart with its unique combination of video content and impulse buying.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tik Tok logos are seen on smartphones in front of a displayed ByteDance logo in this illustration taken November 27, 2019. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The video-sharing platform has more than 14 million monthly users in Canada – a third of the country’s roughly 42 million people.
Users can earn US$50 for recruiting first-timers to sign up for TikTok and unlock an additional US$350 in bonuses if they bring in more

site_title: Preqin reports soft exits and fundraising in 2024, but expects improvement from next year
summary: Preqin reports a slowdown in venture capital (VC) exits globally, with Asia-Pacific experiencing the largest drop in the first three quarters of 2024, from 389 to 142 exits, and a corresponding decline in exit value from $38.2 billion to $20.6 billion. This lack of exits has hindered fundraising for VC, as investors' capital is locked up and unable to be recycled, affecting distributions to limited partners. Preqin expects improvement from next year.

images.alt_text: In Japan, central bank action has re-energised the private capital markets and boosted deal activity.
Much like a fine wine, a private equity investment improves over time and under a skilled hand.

site_title: South Korean ex-defence minister tried to kill himself: prisons official
summary: South Korea's former defense minister Kim Yong Hyun attempted suicide minutes before his arrest on Tuesday for his role in the martial law operation. The attempt was thwarted by a control room staff member, and Kim is now under protection in a secure cell and in good health. Kim had apologized for the situation, stating that all responsibility lies solely with him, and that his subordinates were following his orders. He faces charges including "engaging in critical duties during an insurrection" and "abuse of authority to obstruct the exercise of rights."

images.alt_text: Former South Korean defence minister Kim Yong Hyun was arrested on charges including “engaging in critical duties during an insurrection” and “abuse of authority to obstruct the exercise of rights”.
A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
A protestor wears a face mask of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol in a rally calling for his impeachment. Yoon is the first sitting South Korean president to be banned from leaving the country.
Protesters hold placards calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 7, 2024.
Protesters attend a rally calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the headquarters of the ruling People Power Party in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 9, 2024.

site_title:
Axiata and Sinar Mas to forge US$6.5b telco giant 
in Indonesia to drive 5G expansion
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group and Indonesia's Sinar Mas Group announced a $6.5 billion merger to form XLSmart, a telecom giant in Indonesia. The merger, pending regulatory and shareholder approvals, will create a 94.5 million-subscriber base and 27% market share, with projected annual pre-tax savings of $300-$400 million. The combined entity aims to drive 5G expansion, boost AI, and enhance network quality, with Axiata and Sinar Mas holding 34.8% stakes each. The merger is seen as a pivotal step towards building a strong digital economy in Indonesia and the region.

images.alt_text: Beyond conventional telco business, Axiata Group is expanding its digital businesses to transform into a “techco”.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of US inflation data, eyes on China
summary: Asian markets are mixed ahead of US inflation data, with shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai rising, while Wellington and Jakarta also gained. Seoul's rebound rally continues despite political uncertainty, while Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, and Manila fell. Beijing is expected to announce economic support measures, with a focus on rate cuts and more lending. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to cut interest rates for a third straight meeting next week, despite fears of inflation reigniting due to Trump's planned tax cuts and deregulation.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.5 per cent lower at 518.49 points, with France’s CAC 40 off 1.1 per cent, falling the most among major European economies.
Alaska Air Group surged 13.2 per cent as it unveiled a medium-term outlook that promised “at least” US$10 earnings per share in 2027. In 2023, the airline company earned US$1.83 per share.
Declines in the local stocks were despite positive sentiment regarding Singapore’s full-year growth for 2024, which economists predict will climb significantly.

site_title: Apple’s next Ultra smartwatch will be able to send texts via satellite
summary: Apple is set to introduce satellite connectivity to its next-generation Ultra smartwatch in 2025, allowing users to send texts via satellite when off-grid. The feature is expected to be part of the Apple Watch Ultra, the company's top-of-the-line model, and will work in conjunction with Globalstar's satellite network. Additionally, Apple is working on a blood-pressure monitoring feature, which may arrive as soon as 2025, and is also developing a 5G modem component for the iPhone. The satellite feature is expected to revitalize smartwatch sales, particularly for the Ultra model, which costs $799.

images.alt_text: The recent gains come despite a tepid response to the latest iPhone model and a disappointing earnings report in late October.
For years, Apple engineers and designers complained that the Qualcomm modem and related parts took up too much space in the iPhone.
Apple has spent years trying to replace the Qualcomm modem chip in its iPhones.
Apple’s long-awaited iPhone 16 launch in September had drawn scorn in China for its lack of artificial intelligence features.

site_title: South Korea ex-defence minister formally arrested for insurrection
summary: Former South Korean Defense Minister Kim Yong Hyun was formally arrested on insurrection charges related to President Yoon Suk Yeol's brief declaration of martial law, which plunged the country into chaos. Kim faces charges of "engaging in critical duties during an insurrection" and "abuse of authority to obstruct the exercise of rights." Two top police officials were also taken into custody. The arrest comes amid concerns that evidence may be destroyed, and lawmakers have appointed a special counsel to investigate the martial law case.

images.alt_text: A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
A protestor wears a face mask of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol in a rally calling for his impeachment. Yoon is the first sitting South Korean president to be banned from leaving the country.
Protesters hold placards calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 7, 2024.
Protesters attend a rally calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the headquarters of the ruling People Power Party in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 9, 2024.
Thousands of people rallied in front of the parliament in Seoul on Sunday, calling for the impeachment and arrest of Yoon and the disbandment of his ruling party.

site_title: Nippon Life to buy Resolution in largest Japan insurance deal
summary: Nippon Life, Japan's largest insurer by assets, agreed to buy Resolution Life Group for approximately US$8.2 billion, the largest takeover by a Japanese insurer. The deal aims to diversify Nippon Life's profit drivers and grow beyond the domestic market, as the local market faces demographic challenges. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the second half of 2025, pending regulatory approvals, and will also purchase a 20% stake in MLC, an Australian unit.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians carry shopping bags in the Harajuku district of Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Dec. 6, 2024. Base salaries for regular workers in Japan rose by a record, a further indication of progress toward a positive economic cycle that will support market speculation of a near-term rate hike by the central bank. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

site_title: Alaska Airlines sees US$1 billion jump in profit after merger with Hawaiian Airlines
summary: Alaska Airlines has reported a $1 billion increase in profit after its merger with Hawaiian Airlines, with the company forecasting $10 per share in earnings by 2027. The airline expects to expand its global presence with new flights to Tokyo and Seoul, and plans to serve 12 international destinations from Seattle by 2030. Alaska also expects to capitalize on the growing demand for premium travel, with investments in higher-margin seats and a new premium credit card forecast to produce $100 million in additional profit.

images.alt_text: Boeing said it restarted 737 MAX production, loading fresh fuselages into its Seattle-area Renton factory, after weeks of methodical preparation.
US District Judge Reed O’Connor blocked Boeing’s guilty plea under a deferred prosecution agreement in the case which dates back to two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019 that killed 346 people.
The airline rankings methodology takes into account customer claims processed worldwide.
Negotiations at Alaska are being closely watched because one airline’s contract tends to become an industry benchmark.
Boeing has been implementing a quality plan it submitted to the FAA in May as it seeks approval to boost 737 MAX production.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall, with Hongkong Land leading losses; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,792.82, as declines in banking stocks led the losses. Hongkong Land was the biggest loser. Despite positive sentiment on Singapore's full-year growth for 2024, economists predict a significant climb. The three local banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - closed lower, with DBS declining 0.7%, OCBC down 0.6%, and UOB losing 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Aims Apac Reit is divesting its warehouse at 3 Toh Tuck Link for S$24.4 million.

site_title: Gold hits two-week high with spotlight on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-week high, reaching $2,696.82 per ounce, due to escalating geopolitical tensions and expectations of a US interest rate cut. The US Consumer Price Index (CPI) report later in the day and the Producer Price Index (PPI) on Thursday will influence monetary policy expectations. Investors predict an 86% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut at the Federal Reserve's Dec 17-18 meeting, with most economists expecting a pause in late-January amid inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Gold bars at the Austrian Gold and Silver Separating Plant 'Oegussa' in Vienna, Austria, March 18, 2016.   REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger/File Photo

site_title: US inflation data to show fourth consecutive month of firm gains
summary: US inflation data is expected to show a fourth consecutive month of firm gains, with the core consumer price index (CPI) rising 0.3% in November from the previous month. The Federal Reserve is closely monitoring inflation data ahead of its policy meeting next week, with some economists expecting the Fed to slow the pace of interest rate cuts due to strong inflation readings. Policymakers aim to strike a balance between controlling inflation and maintaining a healthy economy and labor market.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden said Donald Trump’s threats to slap huge tariffs on imports were a “major mistake” and challenged Trump to build on what he said were the successes of his own administration.

SUNRISE, FLORIDA - JUNE 26: Elizabeth Brunner (L) and Hope Johnson (R), recruiters for the City of Pompano Beach, speak to job seekers during the JobNewsUSA.com South Florida Job Fair held at the Amerant Bank Arena on June 26, 2024, in Sunrise, Florida. More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

“Year-ahead expectations about households’ financial situations improved considerably in November,” the New York Fed wrote in a statement.

site_title: Maybank downgrades rating on Malaysia property to ‘neutral’ on JS-SEZ delay, lack of new drivers
summary: Maybank Securities downgrades its rating on Malaysian property developers to "neutral" from "positive" due to the delay in details about the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) and lack of new drivers. Analyst Wong Wei Sum expects sector themes to focus on Johor, data centre developments, and corporate exercises in the next year. The JS-SEZ delay has likely been priced into property demand expectations, and investors are seeking to monetise from such expectations. Maybank maintains a positive outlook on Sime Darby Property and SP Setia, upgrading its call on Sime Darby to "buy".

images.alt_text: EcoSpring in the Tebrau Corridor is within easy reach of major highways such as the Eastern Dispersal Link (EDL) Expressway, the North-South Highway and the Pasir Gudang Highway.

site_title: Tom Brady’s watches and sports memorabilia sell for US$9 million
summary: Tom Brady's sports memorabilia and watches sold for a total of US$9 million in an auction at Sotheby's New York. The sale exceeded the presale estimate of US$5.2 million to US$8.9 million. Notable items included a football used to break the NFL all-time passing yards record, selling for US$216,000, and a Rolex Daytona Paul Newman watch, selling for US$1.14 million. The auction drew a crowd of 800 registered bidders, with 34% being first-time participants, mostly millennials and Gen Z. Brady was present at the auction and praised the sale, saying it was a "fair representation" of his collection.

images.alt_text: Sotheby’s will sell just over 700 lots for a total presale estimate of roughly US$479 million to US$659 million.

The settlement resolves claims that Sotheby’s let at least eight clients cheat New York state from 2010 to 2020 by using “resale certificates” that falsely portrayed them as art dealers entitled to tax exemptions, instead of art collectors.

site_title: Economists’ Singapore growth forecast jumps for 2024, but only edges up for 2025: survey
summary: Economists' median forecast for Singapore's 2024 growth has jumped to 3.6% from 2.6%, with manufacturing expectations strengthening significantly. However, 2025 growth is expected to remain at 2.6%, with inflation predictions lowered for both years. Geopolitical tensions, including higher tariffs, are seen as a downside risk to the domestic outlook, with 100% of respondents citing it as a risk. Monetary policy is expected to stay unchanged in January, with 33.3% of respondents predicting no change.

images.alt_text: The Q3 figure brings GDP growth for the first nine months of 2024 to a “better-than-expected” 3.8 per cent, said the Ministry of Trade and Industry.
The latest expectations remain in line with official forecasts.

site_title: US mulls new Russia oil sanctions to weaken Putin ahead of Trump
summary: The US is considering new, harsher sanctions against Russia's lucrative oil trade, targeting some Russian oil exports, to weaken President Vladimir Putin ahead of Donald Trump's return to the White House. The Biden administration is weighing restrictions that could upend over two years of policy and limit the revenue Russia earns from buyers. The European Union is also planning similar measures on Russia's shadow fleet before the end of the year. The move aims to give Ukraine leverage in negotiations to end its nearly three-year-old war and could lead to a spike in oil prices.

images.alt_text: The EU is also proposing a derogation mechanism to allow EU central securities depositories to unfreeze some of the cash they hold in the face of increased litigation in Russia.

The move is the latest step in a so-far unsuccessful push to clamp down on the flow of microchips, machine tools and advanced electronics via third countries that continue to supply Russia’s defense-industrial base.

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen speaks at Wake Tech Community College East Campus September 5, 2024, in Wendell, North Carolina. Yellen is in North Carolina to higlight how the Biden administration is lowering energy costs for families and spurring investment in advanced manufacturing through the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). (Photo by Allison Joyce / AFP)

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation rises in November
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation rose 3.7% in November from a year earlier, exceeding a 3.4% forecast and following a 3.6% increase in October. The corporate goods price index, which measures prices companies charge each other, accelerated due to pressure from rising raw material costs. In contrast, the yen-based import price index fell 1.2% from a year earlier. This marks a slight acceleration from the previous month's decline.

site_title: Covid-19 a boost for claw machine operators
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic led to an unexpected boom in sales for claw machine operators, with many businesses experiencing significant growth. Fun Claw, a claw machine store, expanded from 17 to 25 stores, while ClawGey, another operator, saw sales of around S$100,000 per month. The surge in sales can be attributed to people staying at home and seeking entertainment, with Bryan Ong, co-founder of ClawGey, stating that "people couldn't travel abroad, so to kill time, they would come and play on the claw machines."

images.alt_text: Timezone Singapore's largest store, at Orchard Xchange, sees around 500 guests on busy days.

site_title: OpenAI CFO thinks business users will pay thousands monthly for AI tools
summary: OpenAI's CFO, Sarah Friar, suggests charging business users thousands of dollars a month for AI tools to reflect their value to companies. Currently, the company offers a $20 monthly subscription for consumers and a $200 monthly option for its most powerful models. Friar believes a value-based pricing model could help offset AI development costs and provide a fair price for tools that automate roles, potentially saving companies money by reducing the need to hire more people.

site_title: Google asks FTC to break up Microsoft’s cloud deal with OpenAI, the Information says
summary: Google has asked the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to break up Microsoft's exclusive agreement to host OpenAI's technology on its cloud servers, citing concerns that it could harm customers and stifle competition. The move comes as tech companies like Google and Amazon want to host OpenAI's models to provide their cloud customers with access to the startup's technology without relying on Microsoft servers. The FTC is investigating Microsoft's business practices, and Google's request is part of this broader inquiry.

site_title: Trump’s unorthodox cabinet picks test party loyalty
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has assembled a cabinet of staggering wealth and controversy, with an estimated total value of $340 billion. The team includes nominees with financial controversies, such as Defence Secretary nominee Pete Hegseth's allegations of alcohol abuse and sexual misconduct. Trump's allies argue that the nominees are "change agents" to deliver on his promises, but critics voice skepticism over their fitness for office and conflicts of interest. The Republican-led Senate can afford to lose only three votes from their own side, but the nominations face uphill climbs to confirmation.

images.alt_text: The European Union is planning similar measures on Russia’s shadow fleet before the end of the year.
US President Joe Biden said Donald Trump’s threats to slap huge tariffs on imports were a “major mistake” and challenged Trump to build on what he said were the successes of his own administration.
Judge Juan Merchan indefinitely postponed Donald Trump’s sentencing at a hearing on Nov 22, given his win in the Nov 5 presidential election.

site_title: Labubu, co-op games, VR: How arcades are keeping patrons hooked
summary: Singapore's arcades and gaming venues are adapting to stay relevant by offering original plushie prizes, cooperative games, and tie-ups with popular franchises. Timezone Singapore's largest store attracts 500 guests on busy days, while smaller players like ClawGey rely on returning customers. The shop's efforts to keep up with customers' tastes and preferences have led to a 30-40% rise in monthly customer traffic since 2019. However, the industry faces pressure to continually refresh offerings, with costs ranging from US$2,000 to US$100,000 for arcade machines and VR equipment. Operators expect consolidation ahead, with only two traditional arcade operators still expanding.

images.alt_text: Fun Claw has grown to 25 stores today, from 17 before Covid-19, thanks to the "unique growth opportunity" brought about by the pandemic.

Blind boxes have enabled companies to step up their marketing game as it raises consumer engagement with the brand. Yet, the market is also linked to impulsive buying behaviour, which puts it at risk of further regulations.

site_title: Boeing jet deliveries fall to 13 in November after strike ends
summary: Boeing delivered 13 commercial jets in November, a fraction of the 56 delivered in November 2023, after a seven-week strike by 33,000 factory workers ended on November 5. The company restarted 737 MAX production in its Seattle-area Renton factory after weeks of preparation. Boeing aims to increase 737 production to 38 a month to generate revenue, while also resuming production of its 767, 777, and 777X in Everett. Deliveries were lower than expected, with just two 787 jets delivered, due to supply chain snags.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The Boeing Co. logo is displayed on top of company offices near Los Angeles International Airport (LAX) in El Segundo, California on January 18, 2024. Boeing on October 28, 2024,  announced a stock offering expected to raise up to USD19 billion, saying proceeds will go towards repaying debt and investing in its subsidiaries. The aviation giant, which last week reported a whopping $6.2 billion quarterly loss, has been suffering from a strike by some 33,000 US workers that has paralyzed two major plants since mid-September. (Photo by Patrick T. Fallon / AFP)

site_title: GM to wind down robotaxi operations championed by CEO Barra
summary: GM's Cruise self-driving car unit is exiting the robotaxi business due to costly and reputational pitfalls. The company will combine its technical teams to focus on developing autonomous technology for future GM models. GM cited the competitive robotaxi market and the need for significant resources as reasons for the retreat. This move comes as Alphabet's Waymo expands into more cities and Tesla plans to start its robotaxi business in 2026.

images.alt_text: GM expects to write down the value of its joint-venture operations in China by as much US$2.9 billion.
GM still has 50 per cent ownership along with LG in Ultium Cells, which owns the existing two battery plants in Ohio and Tennessee.
GM has one of its four North American plants making large pickup trucks in Silao, Mexico, with much of its production coming to the US.
FILE PHOTO: The new GM logo is seen on the facade of the General Motors headquarters in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., March 16, 2021. .  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: Party City mulls second bankruptcy, just over a year after first
summary: Party City Holdco, the parent company of Party City, is considering options including a sale or potential bankruptcy filing, just over a year after emerging from Chapter 11. The New Jersey-based retailer, which sells party supplies, is struggling due to years of lagging sales and a sizeable debt load of around $1.8 billion. The company is behind on rent at some locations and running out of cash to maintain operations, prompting a potential return to bankruptcy.

site_title: New York appeals dismissed PepsiCo plastic pollution suit
summary: New York State has appealed a Supreme Court ruling dismissing a lawsuit against PepsiCo, citing the company's single-use plastic packaging as a major contributor to Buffalo River pollution. The lawsuit, filed by Attorney General Letitia James, alleged PepsiCo's packaging posed health and environmental threats. A survey found PepsiCo's packaging was 3 times more abundant in the river than McDonald's, and the company had misled the public about recycling effectiveness. The appeal comes amid a failed global treaty to limit plastic waste.

images.alt_text: Plastics became indispensable because of low production costs, relatively easy and well-researched manufacturing processes, and availability of raw material from by-products of the oil and gas industry.
Aerial view of a garbage dump filled with plastics in Rodriguez, Rizal province, Philippines, Nov 2024.

INC-5 Chair Luis Vayas Valdivieso brings down a gavel, made with recycled plastic bottle tops from the Dandora landfill in Nairobi, to mark an agreement that talks will resume at a later date, during the UN Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution (INC-5) in Busan, South Korea, Dec 2, 2024. Negotiators have failed to reach agreement on a landmark treaty to curb plastic pollution.
Plastic fishing floats and other debris are being washed up along the shore of the Miaodao Archipelago in Yantai, in eastern China's Shandong province.

site_title: Is China ready to take on Airbus and Boeing? Not just yet
summary: China's Commercial Aircraft Corporation (Comac) is making strides in the commercial aerospace industry, with its C919 jetliner garnering over 300 orders from Chinese airlines and being designed with environmental sustainability in mind. Comac's C929 and a wide-body jet in development could potentially challenge Airbus and Boeing's dominance. However, regulatory approval in the EU and US remains uncertain, and the US market is considered difficult to break into. Despite these challenges, increased competition could lead to improved safety, fuel efficiency, and environmental sustainability in the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Comac has said the C929 will have 280 to 400 seats and a range of 12,000 km, which is in the same category as Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner.
The moves are a step toward convincing foreign airlines to buy Comac’s C919 – a jet that competes directly with Airbus’s A320 and Boeing’s 737 aircraft.

site_title: Citigroup cuts ESG analyst jobs as research group trimmed
summary: Citigroup has cut approximately five ESG analyst jobs, leaving the bank's ESG research team reduced, despite a commitment to supporting clients in their sustainability journeys and reaching the firm's net-zero and sustainable financing goals. The analysts who left had published reports on topics such as climate, renewable energy, and carbon markets. This move comes as a second term with Donald Trump as US president poses a threat to ESG financial strategies, with the Republican Party stepping up attacks on green subsidies and environmental protections.

images.alt_text: The tribulations for Citigroup underscore the risks of handling large stock sales in a fiercely competitive part of the Asia Pacific.
Former BlackRock fund manager Kate Moore (pictured here in 2017) will become Citigroup's chief investment officer for its wealth division in February 2025.
Managers have been told that as many as 2,000 Citi employees could get promotions, with pay hikes limited to 15 per cent, in the next month.

site_title: Oil prices rise on China stimulus, possible tight supply in Europe
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$72.19 a barrel, up 5 cents or 0.07%. The increase was driven by rising demand in China, the world's largest buyer, and concerns about tight supply in Europe this winter. Additionally, reports suggested China would adopt "appropriately loose" monetary policy in 2025 to spur economic growth, providing further support to oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$1.02, or 1.4 per cent, higher at US$72.14 per barrel on Monday.

site_title: TikTok files legal challenge against Canada unit shutdown order
summary: TikTok is filing a judicial review to challenge Canada's order to shut down its subsidiary, citing national security risks as disproportionate and procedurally unfair. The company argues that Canadian officials were not adequately informed about addressing concerns before the closure order was issued. TikTok has over 14 million monthly users in Canada, a third of the country's population, and had worked with Canadian election officials in 2021. The Canadian government claims its decision was informed by a thorough national security review, but stands by its decision.

images.alt_text: Users can earn US$50 for recruiting first-timers to sign up for TikTok and unlock an additional US$350 in bonuses if they bring in more

The companies also noted President-elect Donald Trump has vowed to prevent a ban, arguing the delay “will give the incoming administration time to determine its position – which could moot both the impending harms and the need for Supreme Court review.”
The court's decision is a complete win for the Justice Department and opponents of TikTok and a devastating blow to ByteDance.
ByteDance set out to increase TikTok’s US e-commerce arm 10-fold this year, to as much as US$17.5 billion.

site_title: US Steel drops as Biden plans to block sale to Nippon Steel
summary: US Steel shares plummet 9.7% after President Joe Biden plans to block the $14.1 billion sale to Nippon Steel on national security grounds. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the US has referred the deal to Biden, who has signaled opposition to the sale, citing the need for US Steel to remain domestically owned. The decision is seen as a significant blow to the struggling steelmaker, which has warned it may move its headquarters out of Pennsylvania and shutter operations if the merger collapses.

images.alt_text: After meeting with United Steelworkers leaders, Nippon Steel said it made new commitments with regards to where and when a previously announced US$1.4 billion would be spent.
Through the partnership, Nippon Steel is also looking to grow its sales across a range of products and expand its reach in high-performance offerings.

A number of US business groups have sounded the alarm that the Biden administration’s national security review of Nippon Steel’s planned US$14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel is being unduly influenced by political pressure.

site_title: GameStop reports third-quarter profit on spending cuts
summary: GameStop reported a third-quarter profit of US$17.4 million, despite a 20% decline in revenue to US$860 million. The company has been struggling to ramp up sales of videogame hardware and collectibles, and faces stiff competition from online retailers. CEO Ryan Cohen has implemented cost-saving efforts, including store closures and the sale of higher-margin goods. Analysts, however, remain skeptical about the company's turnaround prospects, with Wedbush Securities' Michael Pachter stating that the "core business is salvageable."

images.alt_text: GameStop has been struggling with declining sales in its primary business of selling new and used video game discs due to a shift towards digital downloads and game streaming.
The meme stock mania was fuelled in part by investors stuck at home during the pandemic.
GameStop shares were down 11.6 per cent at US$25.38 on Monday afternoon after the annual general shareholder meeting, which lasted about 20 minutes.
The company’s last shareholder meeting in June 2023 took less than 15 minutes and included a brief statement from CEO Ryan Cohen.

site_title: UBS reorganises US wealth management unit in growth push
summary: UBS has reorganized its US wealth management unit into four regional units and an international clients team, as part of its strategy to boost profitability and growth. The move aims to expand services for its wealthiest clients, including a new Ultra-High Net Worth Plus segment for clients with assets over $50 million. UBS is also seeking a broader banking license in the US, with CEO Sergio Ermotti citing expansion as a key part of his strategy. The changes are part of UBS's efforts to increase its presence in the US market and attract high-net-worth clients.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Aims Apac Reit, Keong Hong
summary: Aims Apac Reit is divesting its warehouse at 3 Toh Tuck Link for S$24.4 million, a 32.5% premium over the property's valuation. The Reit plans to reinvest the proceeds in growth initiatives. Meanwhile, Keong Hong Holdings' subsidiary sold a 20% stake in Katong Holdings for S$34.5 million, which will be used for working capital and potential business opportunities. The divestments may impact the trading of their securities.

site_title: Chinese cybersecurity firm sanctioned, employee charged by US
summary: The US Treasury Department sanctioned Chinese cybersecurity firm Sichuan Silence Information Technology Company, Limited, and charged one of its employees, Guan Tianfeng, with hacking into thousands of businesses, including American critical infrastructure firms. Guan allegedly broke into over 80,000 firewalls in 2020 to steal company data and install ransomware. The sanctions and indictment aim to disrupt Chinese government intelligence operations and hold individuals accountable for cybercrimes. The US authorities view Sichuan Silence as providing Chinese government intelligence officials with hacking and cybersecurity services.

images.alt_text: Salt Typhoon has collected intelligence and targeted phones belonging to president-elect Donald Trump and vice-president-elect JD Vance, among others.

site_title: Google invests in venture to build energy parks for data centres
summary: Google has invested in Intersect Power, a venture to build energy parks for its data centers. The investment, valued at over $800 million, aims to generate renewable power and support multiple gigawatts of data centers. Google plans to connect its data centers to existing state or regional grids, reducing the time needed to get them online. The energy parks will provide a reliable source of power as ageing US grids struggle to meet demand from AI and electrification.

images.alt_text: Microsoft’s existing data centres will continue to use a mix of older technologies, but new projects will begin using the zero-water designs in 2026.
Digital Core Reit’s data centre in northern Virginia. The Reit now owns a 49.9% stake in the data centre in Frankfurt
NTT DATA announces a proposed land acquisition in Johor Bahru to build a data centre
AWS chief executive Matt Garman (left) and Keppel chief executive Loh Chin Hua at the ceremonial signing event in Las Vegas, US.
Schneider’s designs will be used in data centres that use Nvidia’s flagship server containing 72 of its most powerful AI chips.

site_title: South-east Asia’s renewable energy future faces hurdles, but financing momentum is growing
summary: South-east Asia's renewable energy sector faces challenges such as regulatory uncertainties and infrastructure bottlenecks, despite the region's abundant sunshine and advancements in solar technology. However, innovative financing solutions, including blended financing, green bonds, and the expanding carbon credit market, are gaining momentum, highlighting the region's commitment to achieving its clean energy goals. Key players like Standard Chartered are investing in sustainable finance, with a goal of channeling US$300 billion by 2030, and are fostering public-private collaborations to mitigate risks and unlock the region's green energy potential.

images.alt_text: What is often less visible is that, like the EU, Asean is actively working as an organisation to remove barriers to intra-regional trade.

The huge shortfall in climate finance at COP29, coupled with unfinished details on how the rest of the money is to be mobilised, leaves emerging markets, many of which are in Asia, facing the daunting task of having to undertake system-wide energy transition efforts, implement climate adaptation projects and cope with natural disasters all on a tight budget.

site_title: TikTok pays its users to shop if they boost app downloads
summary: TikTok is offering US users hundreds of dollars to spend time in the app, invite friends, and shop on TikTok Shop, in an effort to expand before a possible ban in the US. Users can earn US$50 for recruiting first-timers, an additional US$350 for bringing in more users, and US$80 in coupons for purchasing on TikTok Shop. The app aims to increase merchandise sales to US$17.5 billion and has already tripled its US sales to over US$100 million. A court ruling upheld a law that could ban TikTok nationwide as soon as January.

site_title: Japanese electric-truck maker Zo Motors to debut at Singapore Motorshow
summary: Japanese electric-truck maker Zo Motors will debut at the Singapore Motorshow in January 2025, marking its local expansion into South-east Asia. Founded in 2023, the company has partnered Chinese manufacturers and aims to sell its fully electric commercial vehicles in Singapore. The company's models, including the ZM6 and ZM8, are road-legal in Singapore and are expected to be classified as heavy-goods vehicles under Land Transport Authority regulations. Zo Motors has begun sales in Japan, the US, and Canada, with plans to expand into South America, South-east Asia, and the Middle East.

images.alt_text: China has invested heavily for more than 15 years in developing electric cars, to limit its dependence on imported oil.
Nissan had an average of 109 days’ supply in October, well above the industry average of 85 days and Toyota Motor’s 35 days, according to market researcher Cox Automotive.
BYD’s rollout of the Shark 6 hybrid is a potential turning point.
Europe has been hoping that Northvolt would reduce Western car makers’ reliance on Chinese rivals such as battery maker CATL and EV and battery maker BYD.

site_title: US court blocks Kroger’s US$25 billion supermarket mega-merger
summary: A US judge has blocked Kroger's planned $24.6 billion acquisition of Albertsons, citing concerns that the deal would harm consumers and lead to higher prices for groceries. The Federal Trade Commission had argued that the merger would reduce competition in the grocery market. The temporary block, which delays the deal, is a win for the FTC, which claims the merger would generate higher prices for millions of Americans. The judge rejected Kroger's arguments that the merger would lead to cost savings and lower prices.

images.alt_text: DFI, a multi-format retailer that counts CS Fresh, Giant and Guardian under its brands, also operates 7-Eleven stores in Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau and China’s Guangdong province.

Sales volumes in Britain dropped by 3.3 per cent in the 12 months to November, the weakest reading since April when they fell 4.0 per cent, and below an increase of 0.6 per cent in the year to October, the British Retail Consortium said.

The two supermarkets, Woolworths and Coles stand accused of misleading discount claims on everyday products.

site_title: Biden says Trump economic plan will be ‘a disaster’
summary: US President Joe Biden criticized Donald Trump's economic plan, calling it a "disaster" and labeling Trump's threats to impose huge tariffs on imports as a "major mistake." Biden challenged Trump to build on the successes of his own administration, citing his own economic achievements, including the US economy's recovery from the Covid pandemic. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that Trump's tariffs could derail progress on inflation and have adverse consequences on growth. Biden's comments come as Trump prepares to take office in January, despite Biden's relatively low profile in the final weeks of his term.

images.alt_text: Judge Juan Merchan indefinitely postponed Donald Trump’s sentencing at a hearing on Nov 22, given his win in the Nov 5 presidential election.
President-elect Donal Trump's return to the White House sets the stage for resets in globalisation, multilateralism and economic blocs.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr (right), a nephew of assassinated US president John F. Kennedy Jr, made his own White House run earlier this year before throwing his support behind Donald Trump (left).

US President-elect Donald Trump greets Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky inside Notre-Dame Cathedral ahead of a ceremony to mark the re-opening of the landmark cathedral. Together with French President Emmanuel Macron, they discussed ending the war in Ukraine.

site_title: HSBC raised fraud alarm that sparked collapse of fintech Stenn
summary: HSBC raised concerns about potential fraud in Stenn Technologies' transactions, leading to the collapse of the UK-based fintech firm. Stenn's UK units entered administration on December 4 after the bank discovered irregularities in the company's transactions. The company, valued at $900 million in 2022, had attracted investors such as Centerbridge Partners and had worked with major banks including Citigroup and Barclays. Stenn's founder and CEO, Greg Karpovsky, left the country and the company's administrators were appointed by Interpath.

images.alt_text: Georges Elhedery (pictured) will take over on Sep 2 from current CEO Noel Quinn.
The leadership transition coincides with HSBC navigating global macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical tensions.
Chinese consumers have tightened spending in a slowing economy, shrinking the credit card market further.
FILE PHOTO: The HSBC building in Canary Wharf in London, October 8, 2008.    REUTERS/Kevin Coombs/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 ends eight-day winning streak; ECB decision in focus
summary: The Stoxx 600 index ended an eight-day winning streak, closing 0.5% lower at 518.49 points. Luxury stocks declined 2.5% and 2.2% after weak Chinese trade data. The CAC 40 in France fell 1.1%, its largest decline among major European economies. The European Central Bank's decision on Thursday is expected to influence markets, with a 25 basis point interest rate cut predicted by 85%.

images.alt_text: Alaska Air Group surged 13.2 per cent as it unveiled a medium-term outlook that promised “at least” US$10 earnings per share in 2027. In 2023, the airline company earned US$1.83 per share.

site_title: Prosecutor fights Trump bid to throw out hush money conviction
summary: Prosecutors continue to oppose Donald Trump's efforts to dismiss his hush money conviction, despite his presidential win. Judge Juan Merchan postponed Trump's sentencing indefinitely on November 22, citing the election. Prosecutors agreed to pause the case while Trump is president, but expressed continued opposition to his bid to quash the conviction. Trump has long opposed the case, which stems from his payment to a porn star and cover-up of the payments in 2016.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin hit a record US$103,800 on Dec 5 but subsequently struggled to stay above the six-figure level.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr (right), a nephew of assassinated US president John F. Kennedy Jr, made his own White House run earlier this year before throwing his support behind Donald Trump (left).

US President-elect Donald Trump greets Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky inside Notre-Dame Cathedral ahead of a ceremony to mark the re-opening of the landmark cathedral. Together with French President Emmanuel Macron, they discussed ending the war in Ukraine.
China's President Xi Jinping looks on during the second session of the G20 Leaders' Meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on November 18, 2024. (Photo by Pablo PORCIUNCULA / AFP)

The interview on NBC’s "Meet the Press with Kristen Welker" was taped on Friday but aired on Sunday, following Trump’s meetings with the presidents of France and Ukraine over the weekend - his first foreign trip since winning the November election against Vice-President Kamala Harris.
President-elect Donald Trump’s vow to implement across-the-board tariffs could also complicate the Fed’s efforts to keep inflation in check.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s US$1 trillion fund seeks more innovation in private credit
summary: Abu Dhabi's US$1 trillion sovereign investor, Adia, is seeking more innovative products in the private credit market, including exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Executive director Dhaen Al Hameli stated that there are "a lot of opportunities" in the asset class and wants to see more innovation, citing ETFs as an exciting example. This comes after the first two private credit ETFs began trading, and Adia has been rapidly increasing its exposure to the sector, committing billions to various real estate and private credit funds.

site_title: Nippon Life in talks to buy Resolution Life in deal worth US$8.2 billion
summary: Nippon Life Insurance is in talks to acquire US-based Resolution Life Group Holdings for $8.2 billion, making it a subsidiary in 2025. This deal would be the largest foreign acquisition by a Japanese insurer and highlights Japanese insurers' hunt for growth in the US market. Nippon Life has built up a 23% stake in Resolution Life since 2019 and plans to purchase the remaining shares from Blackstone and others using cash. The acquisition is part of Japanese insurers' efforts to expand abroad due to limited growth opportunities at home.

images.alt_text: Hopes that Japan's companies may manage their capital better have propelled Japanese stock prices to rise above their 1989 peak earlier this year.

site_title: US: Stocks fall but Alphabet jumps on Google announcement
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, pausing a post-election rally, while Alphabet surged 5.3% after Google's "major" technology announcement, including a new quantum computing chip. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 declined 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Individual companies also saw significant gains, including Alaska Air Group's 13.2% surge and Walgreens Boots Alliance's 17.7% rise, ahead of Thursday's consumer price index data and potential interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: A banner announcing Alaska Air Group's acquisition of Hawaiian Airlines hangs on the facade of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 10, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Adidas headquarters raided in years-long tax investigation, company says
summary: German authorities raided Adidas' headquarters as part of a years-long tax investigation into compliance with customs and tax regulations. The investigation, covering 2019-2024, is related to the import of products into Germany. Adidas is cooperating with authorities and claims not to expect a significant financial impact. The company has been in contact with customs authorities for several years and is providing them with documents and information to clarify questions about German and European law.

site_title: Singapore’s new family office framework will give clarity, but may not be enough to attract more super rich
summary: Singapore's new family office framework, set to provide greater clarity and certainty, may attract ultra-wealthy families seeking transparency, but may not be enough to attract more super-rich due to higher disclosure requirements and compliance costs. The framework introduces new notification and reporting requirements and strengthens protections against money-laundering risks, but may push wealthy families to lighter-touch jurisdictions like Dubai. Higher spending thresholds and tax-incentive schemes in Singapore may deter families, while Dubai's nearly tax-free environment and simpler tax compliance may draw them in.

images.alt_text: Dubai – and the rest of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) – has become a strong magnet for private wealth and talent in recent years.
The Jumeirah Hotel in London hosted an event to attract non-doms from the UK to Abu Dhabi.

The number of single family offices (SFOs) added in 2024 will likely surpass the 300 added in the whole of 2023, says Chee Hong Tat, Second Minister for Finance and deputy chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).
The DIFC is home to over 120 families and 800 family-related structures and entities who manage more than US$1.2 trillion in assets.
Hong Kong has been seeking to bring money and rich families to the financial hub through tax concessions and talent programmes, after strong outflows during the pandemics.

site_title: South Korea's ruling party discusses Yoon resigning in Feb before snap election
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol's ruling party is discussing his potential resignation in February following a botched martial law attempt, which led to a snap election in April or May. Yoon has apologized for the declaration and pledged to leave his fate to the People Power Party, but has not resigned. He faces criminal investigations over insurrection charges, a second impeachment vote, and a ban from leaving the country. The ruling party's proposal is met with criticism from the opposition Democratic Party, which argues it is unconstitutional and seeks to impeach Yoon instead.

images.alt_text: A protestor wears a face mask of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol in a rally calling for his impeachment. Yoon is the first sitting South Korean president to be banned from leaving the country.
Protesters hold placards calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 7, 2024.
Protesters attend a rally calling for the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol in front of the headquarters of the ruling People Power Party in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 9, 2024.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, December 10, 2024
summary: The India rupee hit a record low, dipping due to speculation about a potential rate cut by the RBI following the change in guard. Bond yields also dropped, as investors bet on a decrease in interest rates. Meanwhile, Singapore's STI index rose 0.5% driven by bank stocks, and the Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine was flagged for uncertainty over its financial stability. China's Mao Geping, a makeup mogul, is nearing billionaire status after a successful Hong Kong IPO.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers at 92 to 59.
FILE PHOTO: Indian twenty rupee currency notes are displayed at a roadside currency exchange stall in New Delhi, India, May 24, 2024. REUTERS/Priyanshu Singh/File Photo
