Mao Geping Cosmetics keeps prices closer to those of premium international labels.

site_title: Apple shares are on a tear despite sluggish growth, tariff risks
summary: Apple shares have surged nearly 10% in the past month, defying sluggish growth and a disappointing earnings report in October, despite a tepid response to the latest iPhone model. The stock is one of the best performers in the "Magnificent 7" after Tesla, with investors showing remarkable calm about headwinds such as China's economic state and US-China tensions.

images.alt_text: For years, Apple engineers and designers complained that the Qualcomm modem and related parts took up too much space in the iPhone.
Apple has spent years trying to replace the Qualcomm modem chip in its iPhones.
Apple’s long-awaited iPhone 16 launch in September had drawn scorn in China for its lack of artificial intelligence features.

site_title: UK pledges to cut government spending waste
summary: UK Finance Minister Rachel Reeves vows to cut government spending waste, aiming for efficiency savings of 5% across public departments. The move comes as part of a review of public spending launched by Prime Minister Keir Starmer, with findings due in June. Reeves promises a "line-by-line review" of every government pound, and warned that spending not contributing to priority areas will be stopped. The goal is to mend UK public finances and fix crumbling public services following Labour's return to power.

images.alt_text: The UK economy is projected to grow at 1.6 per cent in 2025, the Confederation of British Industry said, down from a projection of 1.9 per cent made in June.
Business investment is forecast to grow by just 0.9 per cent next year, compared to a previous forecast of 1.4 per cent growth.

site_title: US labour costs revised down in sign of easing inflation pressure
summary: US labour costs rose at a 0.8% annualised rate from July to September, following a revised 1.1% decrease in the prior period. This downward revision adds to evidence that the job market is easing inflationary pressure. Productivity increased at a 2.2% annualised rate, while hourly worker compensation rose 3.1% unadjusted for inflation. These figures suggest that productivity-enhancing efforts are helping alleviate operating costs, reducing pressure on companies to raise prices, and providing a comforting development for Federal Reserve policymakers.

images.alt_text: SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 12: A customer shops for food at a grocery store on March 12, 2024 in San Rafael, California. According to a report by the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, inflation rose by 3.2 percent for the 12 months ended in February, up slightly from January’s annual reading of 3.1 percent. site_title: A US$31b ad deal shows the Mad Men are scared
summary: Omnicom Group is acquiring Interpublic Group of Companies in a $31 billion deal, creating a new world No 1 in advertising. The all-stock terms offer Interpublic investors a premium exceeding 20% and will enable Omnicom to pursue a deal from a position of strength. The deal has a defensive feel, as Omnicom chairman and CEO John Wren acknowledges the challenges of an "AI-driven future" requiring significant technology spending. However, the deal faces risks, including antitrust scrutiny and potential client and talent retention issues, which could offset the benefits and reduce the transaction to a simple transfer of value.

images.alt_text: The 2024 estimate does not include political advertising in the US, which surged this year due to the presidential election.
Ad agencies' new challengers expose lack of tech wizardry

site_title: ESG is in its flop era
summary: Investors and business leaders are reevaluating their stance on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing despite a backlash from right-wing politicians. Despite a grim year for green investments, with $24 billion pulled from climate-related funds in the first three quarters of 2024, assets in climate-related funds still rose 6% from last year due to rising prices. Companies that make green pledges see significant and persistent gains in stock prices, with emissions reductions averaging 12% five years later. As the ESG backlash may be short-lived, investors are advised to be greedy when others are fearful, and companies are encouraged to take action to meet the Paris Agreement goal of keeping global heating below 2°C.

images.alt_text: After more than 3 years of inflows, investors are now pulling cash out of US equity exchange-traded funds with higher environmental, social and governance standards.
Goldman Sachs' decision comes against a backdrop of pressure from some Republican politicians who have suggested that membership of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA) could breach anti-trust rules.

site_title: Amazon to make films, series based on Warhammer game
summary: Amazon has agreed to develop films and TV series based on the tabletop game Warhammer 40,000, giving the US e-commerce giant exclusive rights to the futuristic fantasy universe. The deal also grants merchandising rights and the option to develop Games Workshop's other Warhammer universes, including medieval-themed ones. The partnership comes after Games Workshop's value soared 40% this year, making it worth around £4.7 billion. The deal could be "extremely lucrative" for the brand, according to research director Kathleen Brooks, citing the global interest in fantasy shows and Warhammer's popularity.

images.alt_text: Prime Air drone package deliveries, first launched in December 2022, are currently operational in a couple of US locations in Texas and Arizona.
AWS chief executive Matt Garman (left) and Keppel chief executive Loh Chin Hua at the ceremonial signing event in Las Vegas, US.
The announcements mark Amazon’s biggest step towards combating a reputation that it had been caught flat-footed in developing AI applications as competitors sped ahead.

site_title: The hunt for sustainable plastic solutions
summary: The world is facing a plastic pollution crisis, with over 300 million tonnes of plastics produced annually, 97% of which are non-biodegradable. This has led to 2,000 garbage trucks full of plastics entering oceans, rivers, and lakes daily, disrupting marine life and threatening human health. Biopolymers, such as bamboo and jute, offer sustainable alternatives, but their production costs are high. Research on biodegradable plastics, like polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA), shows promise, but it also has limitations. International cooperation and policies are needed to address the issue, with some startups and governments already working on bioplastics solutions.

INC-5 Chair Luis Vayas Valdivieso brings down a gavel, made with recycled plastic bottle tops from the Dandora landfill in Nairobi, to mark an agreement that talks will resume at a later date, during the UN Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution (INC-5) in Busan, South Korea, Dec 2, 2024. Negotiators have failed to reach agreement on a landmark treaty to curb plastic pollution.

Sacks of untreated and shredded plastic waste, which is left unattended, are piled at an inoperational recycling site in Asan, South Korea, Nov 19, 2024.

site_title: Trump’s big promise to reach peace deal with Putin to end Ukraine war is questionable
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has declared that he can end the Ukraine war "in 24 hours" after taking office in January, sparking concerns in Ukraine that major territorial concessions may be necessary for peace. However, analysts question the feasibility of such a deal, citing the need for Ukraine's sovereignty and European support. The World Bank estimates the reconstruction cost of Ukraine at $486 billion over the next decade, with frozen Russian assets potentially financing the effort. A peace deal could also impact global commodities markets, with some analysts suggesting that a settlement may pressure Putin into agreeing to a peace deal.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump greets Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky inside Notre-Dame Cathedral ahead of a ceremony to mark the re-opening of the landmark cathedral. Together with French President Emmanuel Macron, they discussed ending the war in Ukraine.

The interview on NBC’s "Meet the Press with Kristen Welker" was taped on Friday but aired on Sunday, following Trump’s meetings with the presidents of France and Ukraine over the weekend - his first foreign trip since winning the November election against Vice-President Kamala Harris.
FILE PHOTO: An OPEC flag is seen on the day of OPEC+ meeting in Vienna  in Vienna, Austria October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Leutner//File Photo

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar deflects questions on house arrest for Najib
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim refused to answer questions on a royal decree allegedly allowing former Prime Minister Najib Razak to serve his prison sentence at home. Najib, convicted of corruption in 2022, had his sentence halved by a pardons' board chaired by former King Al-Sultan Abdullah. Anwar cited parliamentary rules on matters decided by courts and referred the matter to the current king, Sultan Ibrahim, for further deliberation. A court hearing on Najib's request for a house arrest is set for January 6, 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers as the jailed politician left the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

site_title: US small business sentiment nears 3½ year high in November
summary: US small business sentiment reached its highest level in nearly 3½ years in November, with the National Federation of Independent Business's Small Business Optimism Index jumping 8.0 points to 101.7. The share of small business owners expecting the economy to improve soared 41 points to 36%, the largest since June 2020, amid post-election euphoria following Donald Trump's Republican Party win. Labor remains scarce, but owners reported raising compensation and planning price hikes.

images.alt_text: SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 12: A customer shops for food at a grocery store on March 12, 2024 in San Rafael, California. According to a report by the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, inflation rose by 3.2 percent for the 12 months ended in February, up slightly from January’s annual reading of 3.1 percent.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
While rising incomes have allowed many consumers to manage the high cost of borrowing, many lower-income Americans are experiencing greater financial strain.

site_title: Global airlines forecast US$1 trillion 2025 revenue despite plane shortage
summary: Global airlines forecast a record-breaking $1.007 trillion in revenue for 2025, with industry-wide net profit expected to reach $36.6 billion, up from $31.5 billion in 2024. Despite supply chain issues and delays in jet deliveries, airlines are anticipating a gradual return to normalcy, with record 5.2 billion passengers expected to fly. The industry is also expecting lower jet fuel prices, which will help offset the costs of newer, more efficient planes.

images.alt_text: Iata director general Willie Walsh pointed to a lack of biorefineries under construction which could produce the green jet fuel, many of which require extensive capital expenditure to get built.

site_title: US dollar steadies, Aussie drops after RBA, Chinese trade data
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% to 106.34 on the dollar index, ahead of US inflation data that may influence the Federal Reserve's monetary easing path. The Australian dollar dropped 0.68% to 0.6397 after the Reserve Bank of Australia softened its tone on inflation outlook. Chinese trade data showed slower exports and unexpected imports, affecting expectations for the Australian economy. Analysts predict a 25 basis point rate cut by the US Federal Reserve next week, with the ECB expected to cut rates by a quarter-point.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar and Euro notes are seen in this November 7, 2016 picture illustration. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Sanjay Malhotra, is currently serving as the revenue secretary at the Ministry of Finance, and will take charge of the Reserve Bank of India for a three-year term from Dec 11.
South Korean stocks' retreat came on a broadly upbeat day for Asian markets.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed, focus remains on inflation data
summary: The US stock market opened mixed on December 10, 2024, ahead of a key inflation report that may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones fell 110.4 points, or 0.25%, to 44,291.57, while the S&P 500 rose 4.7 points, or 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 59.7 points, or 0.30%. The mixed opening is a result of investors weighing the market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: US finalises more than US$6.1 billion chips subsidy for Micron Technology
summary: The US Department of Commerce finalized a $6.1 billion subsidy for Micron Technology to support the construction of domestic semiconductor facilities in New York and Idaho, creating at least 20,000 jobs by the end of the decade. This investment, unchanged from the original April announcement, is part of the US CHIPS and Science Act, aimed at reducing reliance on China and Taiwan. The subsidy also includes an additional $275 million investment to expand Micron's facility in Virginia, supporting the domestic semiconductor industry and national security.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the Micron Technology Inc. offices in Shanghai, China May 25, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Philippine gambling revenue to hit record US$6 billion this year
summary: The Philippine gambling industry is projected to reach a record US$6.03 billion in revenue this year, driven by growth in electronic gaming. The Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp (Pagcor) forecasts gross gaming revenue (GGR) of over 350 billion pesos. The industry's growth is attributed to high rollers from China, Japan, and other countries. Pagcor plans to revoke licenses of offshore gambling firms by year-end, following President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s directive to ban the industry due to reports of POGO-related crimes. This move is expected to boost the national budget.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr orders the gaming regulator to wind down and cease such offshore gaming operations by the end of the year.

site_title: Anger at plan to turn Nazi tunnels into bunker for super rich
summary: A German property developer, Peter Karl Jugl, has sparked outrage with a plan to turn a World War II tunnel system into a luxury bunker for rich survivalists. The tunnel system, constructed by prisoners held in the Buchenwald concentration camp, is currently a memorial site honoring the victims. The proposed bunker, offering nuclear-proof facilities and amenities, will be sold as entry tokens using a crypto-currency called "BunkerCoin". Relatives of the prisoners and local officials have criticized the plan, with some suspecting it's an attempt to embarrass German authorities and raise the price for the site's eventual re-sale.

images.alt_text: Logistics and residential properties are increasingly drawing interest from investors.
The average German family would have to shell out 40 per cent of its income to buy a house, down from a high of 45 per cent in 2022.
The impact in Germany has been particularly severe because of the amount of capital that was invested in a market long considered one of the safest in Europe.

Prices for apartments and single-family houses in the period ended Jun 30 gained 2.4 per cent and 2 per cent respectively compared with the previous three months, according to the German Real Estate Index.

site_title: Award-winning US poet Nikki Giovanni dies aged 81
summary: Award-winning US poet Nikki Giovanni, a key figure in the Black Arts Movement, has died at 81 after a long battle with cancer. Giovanni, known for her work on civil rights, gender, and race issues, received numerous awards and a Grammy nomination. Her most famous poems included "Knoxville, Tennessee" and "Nikki-Rosa." Giovanni died peacefully on December 9, 2024, with her life-long partner by her side. She inspired generations of artists, activists, and scholars, and her legacy continues to be celebrated.

images.alt_text: Krishnan is also known for his philanthropic efforts, having established the Yu Cai Foundation to support education among ethnic Chinese communities in Malaysia.
“Her sons Alain and Gerard, as well as the son from her second marriage Charles Gregoire, owe her everything” says Yann Kerlau in his book The Dynasties of Luxury.

The former US Army soldier, whose business began with The GI’s Guide to Travelling in Europe at 50 US cents apiece in the mid-1950s, became a household name for any vacationer seeking an affordable trip abroad.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value rises 51% in November; volume up 12%
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 51% year-on-year increase in securities market turnover value to S$30.2 billion in November, with a 12% rise in market volume. The Straits Times Index, Singapore's stock benchmark, reached a 17-year high, fueled by a rally of banking stocks. The bourse operator also welcomed several new listings, including PC Partner Group's secondary listing on its mainboard. Derivatives volume advanced 17% year-on-year, while FX futures traded volume reached an all-time high.

images.alt_text: Singapore stock market is resilient against a backdrop of softer regional growth, says the exchange in a monthly market update.

site_title: ECB officials to lock horns over how much cuts can boost economy
summary: European Central Bank officials are divided over how much interest rate cuts are needed to boost the economy, with some policymakers urging rapid cuts to encourage spending and investment. Others are more cautious, citing structural issues such as high energy costs and a lack of skilled workers. The ECB is set to deliver a fourth quarter-point reduction in the deposit rate on December 12, but the outcome will depend on how policymakers weigh the cyclical and structural challenges facing the economy. Economists expect borrowing costs to settle at 2% and some officials have hinted at taking the deposit rate below neutral.

images.alt_text: The ECB has for a long time been stressing that its decisions will be guided by incoming data and Lagarde insists she will not commit to any particular rate path.
The ECB requires banks to submit information on their planned SRTs as part of the regulatory process to allow them to obtain such capital relief.

site_title: VW to resume protracted cost-cutting talks with unionists next week
summary: Volkswagen's management and labor leaders will resume cost-cutting talks next week, with no breakthrough in sight. The negotiations, the fifth round, come as the company faces declining demand for electric vehicles, higher operation costs, and increased competition from Chinese manufacturers. Management has proposed shuttering three German factories and laying off thousands of workers, while union representatives want to keep plants open. The talks are expected to continue despite union threats to escalate walkouts if no agreement is reached before the Christmas period.

site_title: Far East-Perennial JV to launch sale of strata-titled offices and medical suites at The Golden Mile
summary: The developer GMC Property, a joint venture between Perennial Holdings and Far East Organization, will launch 156 strata-titled office units and 19 medical suites at The Golden Mile in Singapore this month. The offices range from 66 to 501 sq m, while medical suites span 47 to 228 sq m. Pricing has not been announced. The development will also feature retail units, an architecture centre, and an open event space, and is part of the Golden Mile Singapore integrated development, which includes a new residential tower.

images.alt_text: URA granted developer GMC Property permission to add four storeys of office space to the conserved Golden Mile Complex.
Far East, Perennial offer to buy Golden Mile Complex for S$700m

site_title: Aims Apac Reit to divest warehouse in Singapore for S$24.4 million
summary: AIMS Apac Real Estate Investment Trust (AA Reit) is divesting a warehouse in Singapore for S$24.4 million, a 32.5% premium to its valuation as of March 31, 2024. The warehouse, located in the Toh Tuck Industrial Estate, will be sold to Crown Worldwide, a Hong Kong-headquartered logistics company. The divestment is expected to complete by the first half of next year, with net proceeds potentially re-invested in AA Reit's growth initiatives.

images.alt_text: Russell Ng, CEO of the manager of Aims Apac Reit, at its flagship property at 20 Gul Way.
Aims Apac Reit's property at 1 Bukit Batok Street 22. The Reit's portfolio occupancy as at end-September 2024 stood at 95 per cent.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 10)
summary: The Golden Mile Singapore consortium is launching 156 strata-titled office units and 19 medical suites for sale in December. Keong Hong Construction sold a 20% stake in Katong Holdings for $34.5 million. Fitch Ratings upgraded Astrea VI Class A-2 bonds, while the Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine received a disclaimer of opinion on its financial results. Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in local banks, marking a positive close for the market.

site_title: DBS, Japan’s top lenders said to be among bidders for Panin Bank
summary: Asian lenders DBS Group Holdings, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group are among potential suitors for Bank Pan Indonesia, also known as Panin Bank. The three lenders have submitted preliminary proposals to buy the Jakarta-listed bank, which has seen a 57% share price rise this year. The Gunawan family, controlling 46% of Panin Bank, is open to selling if the price is right. No final decisions have been made, and the process is ongoing.

images.alt_text: ANZ has been attempting to exit its stake in Panin Bank since 2013, but valuation concerns had hampered its efforts.

site_title: Keong Hong unit to sell stake in Katong Holdings for S$34.5 million
summary: Keong Hong Construction, a subsidiary of Keong Hong Holdings, has agreed to sell 20% of Katong Holdings to MCSK for S$34.5 million, with estimated net proceeds of S$34.3 million. The sale will be used for working capital requirements and potential business opportunities. The company has reported significant losses in recent years and its market capitalization is around S$18.8 million.

images.alt_text: SGX conducts quarterly reviews to identify issuers to be included on the watch list.

site_title: Stellantis, China’s CATL to invest 4.1 billion euros in EV battery factory in Spain
summary: Stellantis and Chinese battery maker CATL have agreed to invest 4.1 billion euros in a 50-50 joint venture to build a large electric vehicle battery factory in Zaragoza, Spain. The factory, which is expected to start production by the end of 2026, will have a capacity of 50 gigawatt hours and power an average of 700,000 cars per day. The project aims to attract EV battery makers to Europe, where carmakers have struggled with high costs and stiff competition from Chinese rivals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People stand at the booth of battery maker CATL during the first China International Supply Chain Expo (CISCE) in Beijing, China November 28, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
The battery, known as Freevoy, is the world’s first hybrid battery with a range of over 400 km, according to CATL.
CATL made a net profit of 13.14 billion yuan (S$2.4 billion) in July-to-September quarter, while its revenue fell 12.5 per cent year on year to 92.3 billion yuan.

site_title: San Francisco, Paris named best cities for urban transportation
summary: San Francisco and Paris have been named the best cities for urban transportation, according to a ranking of 70 global cities by the Oliver Wyman Forum and the University of California, Berkeley. San Francisco topped the list due to its adoption of electric vehicles and high-tech innovations, while Singapore ranked third and first in public transit. The Urban Mobility Readiness Index analyzed factors such as walkability, air quality, and zero-emission buses to determine the cities' readiness for future urban mobility.

images.alt_text: The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.

site_title: Invest smarter – escape the benchmark trap
summary: Investors are increasingly fixated on beating benchmarks, distorting incentives and leading to irrational decision-making. This phenomenon, known as "benchmarkism," encourages risk-taking and diverts attention away from fundamental principles of investing, such as preserving capital and achieving long-term wealth growth. To escape the benchmark trap, investors must focus on stable long-term wealth growth by emphasizing fundamentals and essential risks, rather than relative performance. By doing so, they can unlock hidden value and achieve long-term performance, even outperforming the benchmark.

images.alt_text: Taiwan’s equity-market outperformance has a lot to do with this year’s 80 per cent surge in the shares of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, the world’s top advanced chipmaker that accounts for 37 per cent of the benchmark’s weighting.

site_title: Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine flagged over uncertainties about staying afloat
summary: Singapore Institute of Advanced Medicine (SAM) has faced uncertainties about its ability to continue as a going concern due to material uncertainties noted by external auditors. The group reported a loss after tax of S$37.4 million for FY2024, with current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$7.9 million. The company relies on a cash-generating unit, which reported a loss after tax of S$21.1 million for FY2024, casting significant doubt on SAM's ability to continue as a going concern.

images.alt_text: Incorporated in 2011 and founded by Dr Djeng Shih Kien, SIAMH focuses on diagnosing and treating various diseases and health conditions.

site_title: Prudential is said to consider selling stake in Eastspring
summary: Prudential is exploring options, including selling a 30% stake in Eastspring Investments, valued at around $3 billion, to broaden its business and diversify. The insurer is working with a financial adviser on the review, and a potential sale could give it room to boost its total return yield. Eastspring, a Singapore-based asset manager, has $271 billion in funds under management and a presence in 11 Asian markets. The move comes as rising costs and pressure on fees prompt asset managers to seek greater scale.

images.alt_text: Prudential's annual premium equivalent (APE) sales came in at US$4.64 billion for the first nine months of fiscal 2024, up 7 per cent on a constant exchange rate basis.
Prudential Thailand, TMB Bank in bancassurance tie-up
China’s National Financial Regulatory Administration (NFRA) has approved the creation of a joint venture between BNP Paribas and Volkswagen Financial Services.
“With rising longevity, it is essential that we take  proactive measures to remain healthier and be financially prepared for a longer life,” said Dennis Tan, chief executive of Prudential Singapore.
Prudential attributes the lower net profit to changes in short-term fluctuations from movements in interest rates.

site_title: Australia’s central bank ends 2024 with dovish pivot, Aussie dollar dives
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) kept its cash rate unchanged at 4.35% in its December policy meeting, but signaled a dovish pivot by acknowledging growing confidence that inflation is moving towards its target band. The Australian dollar fell 0.8% and bond futures rallied. The RBA omitted a previous statement that hinted at a potential rate cut, paving the way for a possible rate cut in February. This move is seen as a softening of the central bank's hawkish tone, but core inflation remains stubborn at 3.5%.

images.alt_text: Activity fell across all industries with retail and manufacturing reporting the worst conditions.
The Australian dollar bounced 0.2 per cent to US$0.6400, having tumbled 2 per cent last week to as low as US$0.6373.
ATI bonds were introduced in the aftermath of the global financial crisis to prevent taxpayers from picking up the cost for a bank’s failure.

site_title: Global airlines could miss sustainable fuel targets: Iata’s chief
summary: Global airlines are struggling to meet their sustainable fuel targets, with only 0.3% of jet fuel usage being sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) as of 2024. IATA's chief Willie Walsh attributes the slow progress to a lack of biorefineries under construction, requiring significant capital investment. The industry aims for net zero emissions by 2050, but current production rates of 1 million tonnes in 2024 fall short of projections. Walsh notes that Europe's lack of incentives for biorefineries is a major obstacle, and the impact of the incoming Trump administration's policies on SAF production is uncertain.

images.alt_text: With no policing powers, ICAO uses consensus to set standards on everything from runways to seat belts.
Malaysia, the world’s second-largest palm oil producer, is in a strategic position to become one of the world’s leading SAF producers.

site_title: How to invest without relying on target prices
summary: Investors are drawn to target prices, but their accuracy is uncertain due to underlying assumptions that can be influenced by emotions. Analysts input optimistic or pessimistic assumptions into mathematical formulas, which can result in incorrect predictions. History shows that even reputable firms can make incorrect projections, such as McKinsey's 2000 estimate of 900,000 cell phone sales. Instead of focusing on target prices, investors should prioritize valuing stocks by comparing current valuations to historical trading ranges, and managing risk by identifying high-quality businesses and adjusting investment strategies accordingly.

images.alt_text: AWS chief executive Matt Garman (left) and Keppel chief executive Loh Chin Hua at the ceremonial signing event in Las Vegas, US.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 197.

site_title: Asian economies resilient enough to endure turbulence: IMF
summary: Asian economies remain resilient in the face of turbulence, according to the IMF, despite internal risks and uncertainties. The region's growth potential remains high, with IMF economists highlighting the brevity of market turmoil in August and the resilience of Asian central banks. The IMF's Alasdair Scott and Johannes Wiegand visited Seoul to discuss Trump's return to the White House and the global economic outlook, while the Bank of Korea has pledged "unlimited liquidity" to stabilize markets amid the martial-law row in South Korea.

images.alt_text: China’s factory activity expanded at the fastest pace in five months in November as new orders.

site_title: Sembcorp receives court judgment validating its South African water asset divestments
summary: Sembcorp Industries received a court judgment validating its 2018 divestments of its South African water assets to South African Water Works for 718 million rand (S$70 million). The judgment, made by the South African Supreme Court of Appeal, affirms that the divestments were "valid and enforceable". The decision is not expected to impact the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2024.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp joins legal proceedings involving divested South African water assets

site_title: US households’ views of finances are brightest since early 2020
summary: US households' year-ahead financial expectations improved in November, reaching the highest level since early 2020. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, nearly 38% of consumers foresee being somewhat or much better off, while 42% expect conditions to remain roughly the same. This marks a significant increase from the previous year and the lowest level of people anticipating a worse financial situation since May 2021.

site_title: Malaysia’s industrial production rose 2.1% in October, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production rose 2.1% in October, below forecast expectations of 2.5%. The growth was driven by improved manufacturing output, but mining production declined 2.8% for the fourth consecutive month. Manufacturing output grew 3.3% year-on-year, supported by sectors such as food, beverages, and electronics. The decline in mining production was attributed to reduced crude oil and condensate output. Economists remain cautious due to potential impacts of US protectionist policies, but expect minimal direct impact on Malaysia's export-oriented sectors.

images.alt_text: Workers inspects low-density polyethylene plastic products at a plastic factory in Klang, Malaysia's Selangor state on October 9, 2024. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: India rupee hits record low, bond yields dip as change of guard at RBI spurs rate cut bets
summary: India's rupee fell to a record low of 84.85 per US dollar, surpassing its previous all-time low of 84.7575, while the 10-year bond yield fell 2 basis points to 6.6954 per cent, amid speculation of a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) following the appointment of career bureaucrat Sanjay Malhotra as the next governor.

images.alt_text: Sanjay Malhotra, is currently serving as the revenue secretary at the Ministry of Finance, and will take charge of the Reserve Bank of India for a three-year term from Dec 11.
India’s annual retail inflation rose to 6.21 per cent in October, breaching the central bank’s tolerance band for the first time in more than a year.

site_title: Mahathir denies treachery allegations amid calls for criminal probe
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad denied allegations of treachery, saying the decision to drop claims on disputed islets was made by the then Cabinet on legal advice. A royal commission of inquiry recommended a 99-year-old Mahathir face investigation for the decision, which led to his government's withdrawal of Malaysia's bid to overturn a World Court ruling. Mahathir questioned why his cabinet colleagues weren't called as witnesses, and described the inquiry as politically motivated aimed at destroying his reputation.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Malaysia's former prime minister Mahathir Mohamad leaves the Nikkei Forum "Future of Asia" in Tokyo on May 26, 2023. Malaysia's nearly 100-year-old former prime minister Mahathir Mohamad has been hospitalised for "continuous coughing", his aide told AFP on July 18, 2024. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Global ad sales to top US$1 trillion in 2024, thanks to digital growth
summary: Global ad sales are projected to reach US$1 trillion in 2024, a 9.5% increase, driven by online advertising. This milestone marks the first time ad revenue has surpassed US$1 trillion. Online giants such as Google, Meta, and Amazon account for 41% of global ad revenue. Despite this, the estimate excludes US political advertising, which surged due to the presidential election. Industry growth is expected to slow to 7.7% in 2025.

images.alt_text: Over the past decade, the value of storytelling and entertainment has been undermined. We have built channels and platforms where content is entirely transactional, designed to deliver quick dopamine hits but easily forgotten.

site_title: Earning 3% from Singapore T-bills may not last or be enough
summary: Earning a 3% annual return from Singapore's risk-free T-bills or fixed deposits may not be enough for retirees, especially if inflation exceeds 3%. A couple with a monthly income of S$9,730 may experience negative annual net cash flow after eight years and a capital sum below S$2 million after 15 years. To mitigate this risk, investors may consider allocating capital to high-quality equities and bonds, such as Singapore dollar bonds or listed stocks with a 5% annual dividend yield, which can provide recurrent income that possibly grows over time.

images.alt_text: The latest tranche offers a first-year interest rate of 2.66 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 2.81 per cent.

site_title: Telco consolidation may not necessarily lead to recovery in mobile revenues
summary: Singapore's telcos, including Singtel, StarHub, and M1, face intense competition for mobile revenues, with prices for mobile plans yet to find a bottom. Despite potential consolidation between StarHub and M1, which could lead to more rational price competition, investors may be disappointed as Simba, a smaller telco, continues to offer low-cost SIM-only plans, potentially competing towards a price floor of S$10. To recover, telcos will need to focus on becoming more efficient in managing their networks and offering compelling services to consumers and businesses beyond phone bundles.

images.alt_text: For one customer, the lack of verification had resulted in hackers taking control of the phone line and gaining access to information.
The price moves by both StarHub and M1 have not gone unnoticed.
Simba's improving fundamentals and balance sheet suggest that it is well-positioned to continue taking market share, says analyst.

site_title: Investing in 2025 amid a changing world order
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's return to the White House in 2025 will bring significant resets in globalisation, multilateralism, and economic blocs. This geopolitical and economic regime change necessitates a rethink of investment portfolios to withstand uncertainty in the range of outcomes. The US is expected to support its growth and corporate earnings, while the rest of the world may respond by re-examining alliances, rewiring supply chains, or retaliating against prospective punitive tariffs. Key supertrends include elevated government debt levels, geopolitical conflicts, and the growing importance of Asia, particularly China and India.

images.alt_text: Analysts are bullish on India and Indian equities as they believe the country remains a secular growth story that presents long-term investment potential.

site_title: Malaysian lawmakers approve bill to broaden Internet control
summary: Malaysian lawmakers approved a bill broadening the government's control over the internet, allowing for stricter penalties on content violations and granting law enforcement sweeping powers. The bill, which was passed 59-40, aims to tackle online harm such as scams, cyber-bullying, and child pornography. Critics argue that the law risks suppressing dissent and free speech, but Communications Minister Fahmi Fadzil said it's necessary for public safety. The bill will now be brought to the senate for approval, joining efforts by governments in Asia to regulate online platforms and hold Big Tech firms accountable.

images.alt_text: Malaysia joins efforts by governments across Asia to clamp down on online platforms and hold Big Tech firms accountable for illegal content.

site_title: NYC’s five-star Pierre Hotel near Central Park is on the market
summary: The Pierre Hotel, a five-star luxury hotel in New York City, is up for sale. The 189-room hotel, operated by Taj Hotels since 2007, is being sold along with its retail space and restaurants, but not its 80 co-op residences. Douglas Harmon, co-chairman of Newmark Group, is handling the sale process. The sale comes amid a surge in interest in luxury hotels in the US, with several major deals in recent months, including the acquisition of W South Beach and the Hyatt Regency Orlando. A deal structure has not been determined.

images.alt_text: A rendered image showcasing a room in St Tropez.
Rates declined across hotel categories month on month.

site_title: Crypto volatility picks up as Trump-fuelled rally starts to fray
summary: Crypto prices plummeted as the optimism sparked by President-elect Donald Trump's support for the sector began to fade. Bitcoin fell below $95,000 and a smaller digital assets index slid 15%, its largest intraday drop of 2024. Speculators poured into crypto after Trump's pledge to create a supportive regulatory backdrop, but the market's volatility left investors prone to exiting bets quickly. The overall crypto market has lost $150 billion in the past 24 hours, with some analysts attributing the decline to caution ahead of US inflation data and interest-rate cuts.

images.alt_text: As Bitcoin sceptics and Bitcoin maximalists talk over each other, a third group – the opportunists – have bought and sold the stuff many times over.
The token’s six-week streak of gains through Sunday is the longest such run since the crypto frenzy of 2021.
Bitcoin has more than doubled this year, topping US$100,000 on Wednesday for the first time amid optimism crypto will move further into the mainstream during the upcoming Trump administration.

site_title: Reliance Industries seeks up to US$3 billion loan for refinancing
summary: Reliance Industries is in talks with banks for a US$3 billion loan to refinance approximately US$2.9 billion of debt due in 2025, including interest payments. This would be the conglomerate's return to the offshore market since 2023. The loan is being syndicated to a wider market in the first quarter of 2025 and comes amid the weakening Indian rupee and ongoing outflows from local equities. Moody's Ratings has reaffirmed Reliance Industries' rating at Baa2, citing solid credit metrics.

images.alt_text: The merger of Disney's and Reliance's Indian media assets will create India’s largest entertainment player, with 120 TV channels and two streaming services.
Reliance Power, a coal power generator, is looking to expand into the domestic and overseas renewable energy sector.
Reliance Industries posted a consolidated profit of 165.63 billion rupees (S$2.6 billion) in the quarter ended Sep 30, down 4.8 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Gold hovers near two-week peak as focus shifts to US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-week high on Monday, supported by China's central bank buying after a six-month hiatus. Spot gold remained near this level on Tuesday, awaiting US inflation data for further insights into the Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook. Gold prices are influenced by interest rate changes, with a quarter-point rate reduction seen as a possibility for the Fed's Dec 17-18 meeting.

images.alt_text: Gold is often seen as a safe-haven asset during times of economic or political uncertainty.

site_title: China’s exports slow sharply, imports shrink ahead of Trump tariffs
summary: China's exports slowed sharply in November, growing just 6.7% year-over-year, missing forecasts of an 8.5% increase, while imports unexpectedly shrank 3.9% for the first time in nine months. The disappointing trade figures come ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's expected return to the White House, sparking fresh trade risks. Top leaders have vowed to ramp up stimulus in 2025 to prop up domestic demand, amid calls for a shift away from an economic over-reliance on manufacturing and exports.

images.alt_text: Mao Geping Cosmetics keeps prices closer to those of premium international labels.
Falling prices have undercut the economy’s 4.8 per cent growth so far this year, eating into corporate profits and pushing companies to cut investment as well as wages.
Hybrids will be “at the core of BYD strategy in Europe.
The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) said Nvidia is suspected of violating commitments it made during its acquisition of Mellanox Technologies.
HKEX and SFC review all listing proposals in Hong Kong but there is currently no set timeframe to approve or reject an application.
China's President Xi Jinping looks on during the second session of the G20 Leaders' Meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on November 18, 2024. (Photo by Pablo PORCIUNCULA / AFP)
China has invested heavily for more than 15 years in developing electric cars, to limit its dependence on imported oil.

site_title: New Zealand plans to ban greyhound racing, citing high injury rates
summary: New Zealand plans to ban greyhound racing by 2026 due to high injury rates, with the percentage of dogs injured in races remaining significantly high despite efforts to improve animal welfare. The country joins the US, Ireland, Australia, and Britain as one of five nations where commercial greyhound racing is still allowed. The decision comes after three reviews of the industry over the past decade recommended major changes to protect animal welfare.

images.alt_text: A participant completes the POSB and Mandai Super Saver Mission booklet, which blends financial literacy concepts with fun animal facts.

site_title: Brainy, ‘normal guy’: the suspect in US insurance CEO’s slaying
summary: Luigi Mangione, 26, has been identified as the suspect in the murder of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and data engineer at TrueCar, Mangione was arrested in Pennsylvania after a tip from a McDonald's worker. He had previously written intellectual and philosophical posts on social media, which some have analyzed for potential ideological clues. Mangione's background and family connections have also been highlighted, with his family owning local businesses in Maryland.

images.alt_text: A New York City Police Department (NYPD) handout image of an individual wanted for questioning in connection with the killing of UnitedHeatlhcare CEO Brian Thompson.
Luigi Mangione was being held by officers in Altoona, Pennsylvania, after being found with a weapon that police described as a “ghost gun” capable of firing 9MM rounds and equipped with a suppressor.

site_title: Apac companies unprepared for full-scale sustainability reporting: LSEG report
summary: Asia-Pacific companies are struggling to meet the full-scale implementation of International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) reporting standards, which are set to come into effect in stages from 2025. Despite having high average disclosure rates for certain core metrics, many companies lack advanced metrics required under the ISSB framework, including strategic and financial metrics, management measures, and climate-related financial disclosures. Only 16% of companies reported their financial exposure to climate change, and 1% integrated their transition plans into financial planning. The report highlights the need for companies to improve their climate reporting and integrate climate considerations into their financial management practices.

site_title: Carro swaps growth for profitability, as losses fall 92% in FY24
summary: Carro, a used-car marketplace, reported a 92% decrease in operating losses to $9 million in FY24, despite a 6% year-on-year decline in revenue growth to $781 million. The company's gross profit margins improved from 8% to 12% during the same period, indicating progress despite a challenging market due to rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Kelvin Chng (left), co-founder of Carro and HSBC's Amanda Murphy at the signing ceremony.

Singapore-headquartered Carro, a South-east Asian online used-car marketplace, has acquired a 50 per cent stake in the rental unit of Indonesian automotive group PT Mitra Pinasthika Mustika Tbk for nearly US$54 million, both companies said in a joint statement on Monday.

site_title: C3.ai lifts annual forecast on strong demand for enterprise AI software
summary: C3.ai has raised its forecast for fiscal year 2025 revenue to between $378 million and $398 million, driven by strong demand for its enterprise AI software. The company's shares rose 14.8% in extended trading after the announcement. C3.ai's revenue for the second quarter was $94.3 million, a 29% increase from last year and above analysts' estimate. The company's partnership with Microsoft and its expanded role as the "preferred" AI application software provider on Azure cloud have contributed to its growth.

images.alt_text: The new version of the tool will be able to churn out videos up to 20 seconds in length and offer multiple variations of those clips.

site_title: Britain to make online marketplaces pay more for electricals recycling
summary: Britain plans to require online marketplaces like Amazon and eBay to pay more for recycling waste electrical items, aiming to level the playing field for UK-based firms. The government wants to collect data on UK sales of overseas sellers and calculate their financial contribution to waste electricals collection costs. The move follows the collection of 100,000 tonnes of household electrical waste annually. The plans will be subject to consultation and include a new category for vapes to ensure fair costs.

images.alt_text: A shopper walks past Black Friday sale signs at a store on Oxford Street in London, Britain November 28, 2024. REUTERS/Hollie Adams

site_title: Japan’s megabanks are flush with cash and hunting overseas deals
summary: Japan's megabanks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, and Mizuho Financial Group, are investing heavily in the US and India due to record earnings and excess capital. The banks aim to expand their presence in these markets through strategic investments, hiring, and partnerships. MUFG is focusing on India, where it plans to double its loan exposure, while Mizuho is prioritizing the US, with a focus on corporate and investment banking. The banks also plan to reduce their strategic holdings and allocate resources to balance growth investment and shareholder returns.

images.alt_text: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the top bank by assets, said second-quarter profit surged 90 per cent on higher interest rates and the sale of cross-held shares.

site_title: First agreement under Taiwan-US trade initiative to come into force
summary: The first agreement signed under the US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st Century Trade will come into force on Tuesday, covering areas such as anti-corruption, customs administration, and trade facilitation for small and medium-sized enterprises. This marks an important step in strengthening the US-Taiwan economic and trade relationship, with ongoing talks on a second agreement covering labor, environment, and agriculture. The agreement is seen as a strategic move for Taiwan to consolidate its relationships with key economic partners amid global volatility.

site_title: Australia business conditions worst since pandemic: survey
summary: Australia's business conditions have worsened since the pandemic, according to a National Australia Bank survey. The index of business conditions dropped to +2, its weakest reading since late 2020, and confidence fell to -3. Sales slowed, profitability declined, and employment intentions decreased. Conditions in the manufacturing and retail sectors were particularly weak. The disappointing results suggest the economy has not recovered from a soft third quarter, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to hold interest rates at 4.35%.

images.alt_text: ATI bonds were introduced in the aftermath of the global financial crisis to prevent taxpayers from picking up the cost for a bank’s failure.
Inflation has only come down slowly and at an underlying level remains above the central bank’s 2 to 3 per cent target.
Retail sales were unchanged from the prior month, versus economists’ estimate of a 0.3 per cent gain, data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed on Friday.

site_title: Newmont cuts management jobs in major corporate restructuring
summary: Newmont, the world's top gold mining company, has cut nearly a dozen management jobs as part of a corporate overhaul. The company plans to merge several business units to streamline its reporting structure, consolidating five units into three. This move aims to reduce standalone divisions and improve efficiency. The restructuring also includes the dismissal of one executive and at least 10 senior managers. The company's investment in mining operations in Australia, Canada, Peru, and Papua New Guinea is also expected to exceed initial estimates.

images.alt_text: Newmont is the first major gold miner to report results in an earning season that’s expected to see bumper profits for bullion miners.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records as Nvidia falls
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Monday, falling 0.5% as Nvidia's 2.6% drop due to an anti-monopoly probe in China weighed on the market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 44,401.93, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6% each. Despite individual gains, such as Interpublic Group's 3.5% rise after an acquisition announcement, the broader market paused its post-election rally ahead of key inflation data later in the week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 4.5 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 44,637.97.

site_title: CDL dialogue features Jane Goodall and Sylvia Earle to raise awareness of climate action
summary: CDL hosted a dialogue featuring Dr Jane Goodall and Dr Sylvia Earle to raise awareness about climate action and inspire collective action. The event, attended by 1,400 people, raised S$150,000 for environmental conservation efforts. Dr Goodall and Dr Earle discussed the importance of collaboration, inspiring young people to take action, and the interconnectedness of land and sea. They emphasized the urgency of climate action, citing the consequences of sea-level rise and the need for mindful consumption. The dialogue aims to engage and educate attendees, with CDL planning to refurbish an old train carriage into an Eco Train and expand its Singapore Sustainability Academy.

images.alt_text: As CDL’s first chief sustainability officer, Esther An quickly championed an ethos that still guides the company’s business practices today: “conserving as we construct”.

Front row: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (fifth from left), UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong (fourth from left) and BT editor Chen Huifen (first from right), with winners of the Sustainability Impact Awards 2024.

site_title: Bitcoin is in its post-usefulness phase, and that’s OK
summary: Bitcoin has entered a post-usefulness phase, where speculation and trading have overshadowed its original purpose. The article suggests that the cryptocurrency market has been co-opted by speculators, and that the value of Bitcoin is largely driven by trading profits rather than its intrinsic value. The author, a crypto observer, believes that the US should accept this reality and regulate the market accordingly, rather than trying to make Bitcoin more useful. This acceptance would help save individuals from themselves and prevent the market from being driven by the "greater fool" principle.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin has more than doubled this year, topping US$100,000 on Wednesday for the first time amid optimism crypto will move further into the mainstream during the upcoming Trump administration.
Crypto is but a get-rich-quick lie, wrapped in hype, bobbing on an ocean of libertarian technobabble -- that's the grim reality.

site_title: The UK Post Office scandal holds many important governance lessons
summary: The UK Post Office scandal highlights the importance of corporate governance, particularly for boards of directors. Top management and the board assumed a faulty computer system couldn't be the cause of alleged financial shortfalls, ruining the lives of thousands of innocent people. Key lessons include: directors must exercise true independence and question assumptions, corporate culture is crucial, directors should be IT-savvy, and boards should undergo regular assessments by independent parties. The Singapore Code of Corporate Governance may benefit from tweaks to address emerging issues like digitalization and AI, and mandatory SID membership could help ensure directors adhere to best practices.

images.alt_text: Good governance creates a structured, transparent environment where trust and accountability can thrive, and – for SMEs in particular – acts as a strategic enabler that facilitates growth, enhances resilience and protects their reputation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, Hai Leck, DBS
summary: The South African Supreme Court of Appeal has validated Sembcorp Industries' 718 million rand asset sale made in 2018. Shares of Sembcorp Industries rose 0.7% on Monday. Hai Leck's founder, Cheng Buck Poh, has proposed a privatization offer at S$0.55 a share, representing a 34.1% premium over the last traded price. DBS has appointed Han Kwee Juan as head of institutional banking, effective January 1, 2025, succeeding Tan Su Shan.

site_title: China signals bolder stimulus for next year as Trump returns
summary: China's top leaders plan to implement a "moderately loose" monetary policy and expand fiscal spending in 2025 to combat the country's slowing economy. The move comes as Beijing prepares for a trade war with the US under President Donald Trump, who has vowed to impose a 60% tariff on Chinese exports. The government aims to boost consumption and drive domestic demand, with officials pledging to "forcefully lift consumption" and increase fiscal spending. The decision is seen as a shift in stance, with the last time China adopted a similar policy being during the Global Financial Crisis in 2008.

images.alt_text: Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.
China's CPI rose 0.2 per cent last month from a year earlier, cooling from a 0.3 per cent increase in October, data from the National Bureau of Statistics showed on Monday.
Officials have mounted a major stimulus campaign since September to ensure China hits its annual growth goal, a high-profile political target that Beijing rarely misses.

Shipping containers are stacked at a port in Lianyungang, in eastern China's Jiangsu province on April 12, 2024. Chinese exports plunged more than expected in March, official figures showed on April 12, as the world's second-largest economy struggles to sustain its post-pandemic recovery. site_title: Dozens of Nobel laureates sign letter opposing Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as Trump’s health secretary
summary: Seventy-seven Nobel laureates have signed an open letter opposing Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s nomination as US Secretary of Health and Human Services, citing his lack of credentials and anti-vaccine beliefs. Kennedy, a nephew of John F. Kennedy, has expressed conspiracy theories linking vaccines and autism and spread misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines. The Nobel recipients urge the Senate to vote against his confirmation, citing the potential harm to public health.

site_title: Bank stocks drive Singapore shares higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by gains in local banks, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,813.55 points. The local banking trio, OCBC, UOB, and DBS, closed higher, with OCBC up 1.1%, UOB up 1%, and DBS up 0.8%. Despite this, shares of the Singapore Exchange fell 0.5% after posting a 51% increase in its November turnover value. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also experiencing changes.

images.alt_text: The South African Supreme Court of Appeal affirms Sembcorp Industries' 718 million rand (S$70 million) asset sale made in 2018 as valid and enforceable.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong, Shanghai rally on China optimism as Seoul rebounds
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks surged on Tuesday, extending a rally of 2.8% on Monday, after China pledged to adopt a looser monetary policy to revive the stuttering economy. The announcement, made by President Xi Jinping and other top leaders, included plans for a more active fiscal policy and relaxed monetary strategy. Seoul rebounded after days of losses fueled by martial law declared by South Korea's president, who later rescinded the order. The moves sparked hopes for more rate cuts and stimulus, but analysts remained cautious, citing the need for broader confidence boosts.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers at 92 to 59.
The Stoxx 600 index edged up 0.14 per cent to close at 521.22 points, notching its eighth consecutive session of gains.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.5 per cent lower at 44,401.93 on Monday.

site_title: Microsoft unveils zero-water data centres to reduce AI climate impact
summary: Microsoft is introducing zero-water data centers to reduce its climate impact. The new design uses a "closed loop" system to recycle water, eliminating the need for fresh supplies. Existing data centers will continue to use a mix of older technologies, but new projects in 2026 will utilize the zero-water designs. This move aims to conserve water, particularly in hot and dry areas where data centers are being built. Microsoft spent over $50 billion on data center construction in the past fiscal year, and plans to increase that figure in the current year.

site_title: OpenAI to release long-anticipated Sora video generator
summary: OpenAI is releasing its long-awaited Sora video generator, allowing users to create realistic-looking videos from text prompts. The tool will churn out videos up to 20 seconds in length and offer multiple variations. Sora will be available to paid ChatGPT users in the US and other markets, with limited availability in Europe due to tech regulations. The service will be offered as part of a $20/month subscription for 50 videos or a $200/month subscription for unlimited access to "slower" generations.

images.alt_text: “AGI is explicitly carved out of all commercial and IP licensing agreements,” according to OpenAI’s website.
OpenAI also offers a ChatGPT Plus subscription for US$20 a month, a tenth of the cost of the new option.
The partnership comes nearly a year after OpenAI did away with wording in its policies that banned the use of its technology for military or warfare purposes.
OpenAI, led by CEO Sam Altman, has seen its profile skyrocket over recent years as it has become a star player in the growing field of artificial intelligence.

site_title: Israeli PM says won’t stop Gaza war ‘now’
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated he won't stop the Gaza war "now," citing the need to prevent Hamas from regrouping and attacking again. Netanyahu reiterated his goal of "annihilating" Hamas, while US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed a desire to bring the war to an end with a ceasefire. Renewed negotiations, facilitated by Qatar, Egypt, and Turkey, are underway, with a potential breakthrough possible following the US election of Donald Trump.

Posters of hostages kidnapped during the Oct 7, 2023, attack by Hamas. Israel's response to the attack has weakened the ability of Iran to assert its position in the Middle East.

site_title: Manage risks in commodity financing by bracing for constant uncertainty: UOB’s Lim Chen Chen
summary: UOB's group head of structured trade and commodity finance, Lim Chen Chen, emphasizes the need to manage risks in commodity financing due to constant uncertainty in the market. She notes that the world has entered a new disorder, making it difficult to predict future events. Chen advises navigating worst-case scenarios to mitigate risks, as nothing is constant in the increasingly volatile world of commodities. This approach is crucial for managing risks in commodity financing.

site_title: Mondelez exploring takeover of US chocolate maker Hershey
summary: Mondelez International, the parent company of Ritz crackers and Oreo cookies, is exploring a potential takeover of US chocolate maker Hershey, which could create a food giant with combined sales of nearly $50 billion. The deal, which is still in its early stages, would require the backing of Hershey Trust, which owns 80% of the company's Class B stock. The move comes as the packaged food industry grapples with declining volumes, slowing growth, and a weakening global consumer.

images.alt_text: This week’s layoffs, which have not been previously reported, affected less than 1 per cent of the roughly 20,000 employees at the maker of Hershey’s candy bars and Reese’s peanut butter cups, a company spokesperson told Reuters.

site_title: WealthBT: Strategic investment insights to navigate 2025
summary: Investors can expect a balanced approach in 2025, with a focus on maintaining US exposure while managing expectations for future returns. Genevieve Cua's conversation with Hou Wey Fook, chief investment officer of DBS Bank, highlights the importance of a "barbell approach" with oversized positions in income-generating assets. This strategy can withstand risk and avoid frequent trading, which can lead to anchoring bias. Rebalancing portfolios and managing risk premium are also crucial, with a focus on unique objectives and proper asset allocation.

images.alt_text: Major players such as Nvidia, as well as the so-called "Magnificent Seven" stocks have seen significant returns.

site_title: The benefits and limits of privatisation
summary: The UK's 40-year experience with privatisation of publicly owned industries has yielded important lessons, primarily that basic economic principles matter. Private profit-motivated enterprises can provide goods and services efficiently when consumers have choices and are able to switch suppliers. However, when consumers are vulnerable or unable to make informed choices, the state must intervene through regulation. The British experience has shown that private suppliers can become ruthless rent extractors, and effective regulation is necessary to prevent this. The article concludes that private provision may not be the best way to provide essential services such as care homes and prisons, and alternative models like mutual or charitable provision should be considered.

site_title: Rare Roman coin sells for almost two million euros at auction
summary: A rare Roman coin featuring Brutus, the assassin of Julius Caesar, sold for nearly 2 million euros at a Geneva auction. The coin, originally priced at over 800,000 euros, was purchased by a European collector following intense online bidding among eight bidders. The historic item features Brutus' profile surrounded by a laurel wreath and war symbols on the reverse. The sale showcases the coin's significant historical value and rarity.

site_title: Huawei suppliers to face further US limits under defence bill
summary: US lawmakers are moving to ban Defense Department contractors from selling semiconductors and services to Huawei Technologies under the National Defense Authorization Act. The provision, likely to become law, would put pressure on global chip firms tied to Huawei, which has been targeted by US sanctions. The ban would take effect 270 days after signing, with a waiver possible for national security contracts.
