site_title: Super Micro Computer gets extension to file delayed annual report
summary: Super Micro Computer has received an extension from the Nasdaq until February 25 to file its delayed annual and quarterly reports. The company cited a need to assess its internal controls over financial reporting after a short position was disclosed by Hindenburg Research. Super Micro's AI servers with liquid cooling technology have seen strong demand from enterprises looking for hardware capable of powering AI applications. The company expects to file all required reports by February 25 to remain listed on the Nasdaq.

site_title: Intel’s lack of a clear plan makes Wall Street even more bearish
summary: Intel's sudden ouster of CEO Pat Gelsinger has led to a 13% stock drop in the past five days, marking its worst week in three months. The chipmaker's shares are down 58% this year, on pace for the worst annual performance since at least 1983. Analysts and investors are staying on the sidelines until a permanent new CEO is found, citing concerns about the company's direction and potential candidates. Intel's valuation remains high, trading at 24 times forward earnings, and analysts warn that a turnaround may take time, given the competitive nature of the chip industry.

site_title: Thailand’s auto crown under threat as Indonesia eyes Asean’s top spot
summary: Thailand's auto industry faces significant challenges as domestic sales and exports decline, threatening its status as South-east Asia's leading car production hub. Indonesia is expected to surpass Thailand in car production this year, driven by its growing exports and focus on producing global models. Thailand's pickup sales have taken a hit due to stricter lending conditions, while Chinese carmakers have entered the market with battery electric vehicles (BEVs), boosting sales. The industry's future remains uncertain, with Thailand's production target slashed to 1.5 million units, down from 1.7 million in 2023.

images.alt_text: Thailand extends battery electric vehicles production timeframe, offers hybrid EV incentives to support auto industry amid stagnant market and economic challenges.

site_title: Mah Sing Group remains focused on affordable residential properties, while eyeing data centres and industrial market for growth
summary: Mah Sing Group, a leading property developer in Malaysia, is optimistic about its 2024 sales target of RM2.5 billion, with the group already hitting RM1.85 billion for the first nine months. The company is focusing on affordable residential properties, with its M Series projects driving sales. Mah Sing is also expanding into the industrial sector, with plans for a new business park in Sepang, Selangor, and is looking to leverage Malaysia's Asean chairmanship and China-Plus-One strategy to boost demand. The company has partnered with Bridge Data Centre to enter the data centre sector and is exploring opportunities in the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: Property developers, tech firms and Sarawak-focused companies have emerged as top performers in Bursa Malaysia this year.
Malaysia’s economy grew more than expected in the second quarter of 2024, exceeding the 5.8 per cent advance estimates made by the Department of Statistics Malaysia.

site_title: Saudi Arabia cuts oil prices after Opec+ delays reviving output
summary: Saudi Arabia has cut oil prices by 90 US cents a barrel, more than expected, due to Opec+ further delaying production increases planned for January. The price cut affects buyers in Asia and north-west Europe, while north America prices remain unchanged. The move comes as concerns over sluggish demand growth and potential oversupply in the global market persist. Opec+ had previously delayed production increases twice, and the delay has led to a tighter range in benchmark oil prices, currently around US$71 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$71.12 a barrel, shedding 97 US cents, or 1.4 per cent.

site_title: Defence startups Palantir, Anduril to save data from battlefield to train AI models
summary: Palantir Technologies and Anduril Industries are partnering to accelerate the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in the US military by collecting and processing battlefield data. The data, including classified information, will be used to train AI models, and other companies are invited to join the effort. This partnership highlights the growing importance of AI to the US military and creates opportunities for contractors to deliver new technology, with Palantir's market capitalization now surpassing that of Lockheed Martin Corp.

images.alt_text: The partnership comes nearly a year after OpenAI did away with wording in its policies that banned the use of its technology for military or warfare purposes.

site_title: China’s central bank resumes gold purchases after six-month hiatus in November
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), resumed buying gold for its reserves in November after a six-month pause. The PBOC, the world's largest official sector buyer of gold in 2023, purchased gold to support Chinese investor demand. China's gold holdings rose to 73 million fine troy ounces at the end of November, and the value of its gold reserves fell to $193.4 billion. The resumption of gold purchases may signal the PBOC's readiness to build reserves despite record-high prices.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing, China, on Monday, Aug. 12, 2024. China’s central bank said it’s studying a plan to narrow the range within which short-term interest rates can fluctuate, extending an overhaul of its policy toolkit that aims to guide the market more effectively. Source: Bloomberg
Monetary policy support will be critical to China’s economy next year as the US president-elect has vowed to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods.

Expectations remain high that an ailing economy will prompt the PBOC to step up monetary easing, including cutting the RRR further and injecting more cash into markets, after it delivered a stimulus blitz in late September.

site_title: Man to be charged over threatening to crash aircraft he was boarding at Changi Airport
summary: A 36-year-old Australian man will be charged with two counts of using threatening words to cause alarm after allegedly stating he wanted to crash an aircraft he boarded at Changi Airport on November 23. The incident occurred after he was removed from the flight and escorted to a holding room, where he repeated the threat. He will be charged under Section 4(2) of the Protection from Harassment Act 2014, with a possible fine of up to S$5,000 for each offence.

site_title: GIC-backed manufactured-housing operator Yes! explores 2025 IPO
summary: Yes! Communities, a manufactured housing operator backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC, is exploring a 2025 initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to $1 billion. The Denver-based company, which operates nearly 300 communities in the US, is working with Goldman Sachs and other underwriters. Yes! is led by CEO Steven Schaub, who co-founded the company in 2008. The IPO would be the latest in a surge of real estate investment trust (REIT) listings in 2024, with $6.2 billion raised so far this year.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The LNG spot market remained stagnant, with rates flat amid limited activity. In contrast, the Capesize market declined, with the BCI 5TC dropping to $12,727, and the Atlantic market struggling due to oversupply and muted demand. The Panamax market was not mentioned in the article.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Nov 29, 2024).

site_title: King Charles III says felt ‘anxious’ about crown ‘wobbling’
summary: King Charles III expressed anxiety about wearing the coronation crown due to its weight and the fear of it "wobbling". In an upcoming documentary, Charles recalled his mother's coronation ceremony in 1953, saying he remembered bath time with his sister and his mother wearing the crown to practice wearing it. The 17th-century gold headpiece weighs 5 pounds and is 6.7 inches tall, according to Charles. The documentary, "Coronation Girls," will air in Canada on Boxing Day and internationally next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: King Charles III is crowned with St Edward's Crown by The Archbishop of Canterbury the Most Reverend Justin Welby during his coronation ceremony in Westminster Abbey, London. Picture date: Saturday May 6, 2023.   Victoria Jones/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

Britain's King Charles III and Britain's Camilla, Queen Consort wave as they greet the crowd upon their arrival at Buckingham Palace in London, on Sep 9, 2022, a day after Queen Elizabeth II died at the age of 96.

Britain's King Charles III and Queen Camilla exit their plane after arriving at Sydney International Airport in Sydney on October 18, 2024, for a six-day royal visit to Sydney and Canberra. (Photo by Saeed KHAN / AFP)

site_title: Canada pressured to respond to Trump’s tax cut regime
summary: Canada is under pressure to respond to US President Donald Trump's planned tax cuts, which could drive capital out of the country and exacerbate its productivity crisis. Trump's proposed 15% corporate tax rate would eliminate Canada's corporate tax advantage, mirroring the US rate. Canadian policymakers, including Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland, have estimated that tax rates on new business investment would rise to 16.8% by 2028, more than eight points lower than the US. The country's brain drain issue, with entrepreneurs considering moving to the US, has been exacerbated by high taxes and limited capital investment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of East Hastings street in Downtown Eastside of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada January 31, 2023. REUTERS/Jennifer Gauthier/File Photo

Gantry cranes and shipping containers at the IPC Container Terminal at Tanjung Priok Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Friday, April 19, 2024. Indonesia will release its trading figures on April 22. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Trump may cancel US Postal Service electric mail truck contract: sources
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's transition team is considering cancelling the US Postal Service's (USPS) contracts to electrify its delivery fleet, as part of a broader effort to roll back President Joe Biden's climate change initiatives. The move could impact tens of thousands of battery-driven delivery trucks and charging stations, valued at over $7.5 billion. Trump's administration plans to review how to unwind the contracts, despite the USPS being an autonomous federal agency with its own governing board.

images.alt_text: The US was Japan’s biggest export destination in 2023 with cars and auto parts making up a third of shipments, according to Japan’s Finance Ministry.
The anomaly has appeared in global trade data from early 2020, when China started to say it was selling more goods to the US than America reported buying from the Asian manufacturing behemoth.
With Trump already announcing plans to slap tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada, and China, we should certainly expect some new levies to be imposed.
Trump figurines also proved popular in 2016 when he won a first Presidential term, and in 2020 when he lost the election.

site_title: Navigating the new energy frontier: Investors can find opportunities amid the transition
summary: Investors can find opportunities in the transition to a lower-carbon future through various sectors, including renewable infrastructure and natural gas projects. Despite 80% of global energy coming from fossil fuels, renewable energy sources continue to grow, and emerging markets like India offer attractive investment opportunities. Investors can also consider debt financing in mature renewable projects and invest in dispatchable renewable energy sources like hydro and geothermal power. Meanwhile, lower-carbon fossil fuels like natural gas can play a key role in the transition, and companies like Big Oil majors can leverage their expertise in refining to operationalize green innovations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

site_title: Backers of most US mortgages have done little about climate risks
summary: US government-sponsored enterprises Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, which back half of the nation's outstanding mortgages, have failed to adequately address climate risks despite rising insurance costs and extreme weather events. The lack of action poses a risk to the financial system and taxpayers, as large losses could force government intervention. Concerns about raising housing costs for low-income households have hindered efforts to incorporate climate risk into mortgage underwriting. Experts recommend a carrot-and-stick approach to cushion the impact on vulnerable homeowners and encourage adaptation.

images.alt_text: Homebuyers are facing mortgage rates that have climbed in seven of the past eight weeks.

site_title: EV maker VinFast to build second production plant in Vietnam
summary: Vietnamese EV manufacturer VinFast plans to build its second domestic production plant in Ha Tinh province, doubling its output capacity to 300,000 units annually. The new facility, expected to start operations in July 2025, will primarily produce small and mid-sized models, including the VF 3 and VF 5. This move aims to meet increasing demand for VinFast's models and follows the company's delivery of 44,773 cars worldwide in the first nine months of 2024, exceeding 55% of its target of 80,000 units for the year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam officials have ordered that a quarter of two-wheelers across the country must be electric by 2030 to help battle the air crisis.

site_title: BlackRock sees retail traders snapping up municipal bonds in 2025
summary: BlackRock's head of municipal bonds, Pat Haskell, expects retail investors to be eager to buy local and state government bonds in 2025, with over $500 billion in new issuance anticipated. This could provide opportunities for good bonds at good levels, with demand from smaller investors expected to be a key factor. Haskell is bracing for potential policy changes, including the potential elimination of the tax-exemption status for municipal debt, but believes munis are an efficient way to fund infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Blackrock Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
BlackRock chief executive officer Larry Fink has moved aggressively to expand in private markets.
BlackRock is the world’s largest asset manager overseeing more than US$10 trillion.

site_title: Crypto lenders emerge from the ashes of last speculative bubble
summary: Crypto lenders are experiencing a resurgence in demand, driven by a market rally and increased leverage, as Bitcoin surpasses $100,000 for the first time. Crypto lending has nearly tripled in the first nine months of 2024 compared to the same period last year, with decentralized finance (DeFi) apps leading the way. Lenders are offering higher yields, but caution remains due to past failures, with some institutional lenders staying on the sidelines. Despite this, prime brokerages and exchanges are stepping in to fill the gap, and demand for crypto exchange lending offerings is "off the charts."

images.alt_text: The total was the largest in CFTC history, the regulator said in its annual report.
Crypto mining stocks have underperformed this year after the reward for mining Bitcoin was cut in half in April.
The crypto market has gained about US$1.2 trillion in market value since Trump’s election victory, CoinGecko data show.

site_title: As Big Tech profit growth slows, investors hunt for a new thing
summary: The US stock market's growth engine, driven by Big Tech companies, is slowing down. Analysts project a 34% earnings increase for the Magnificent Seven tech giants in 2024, down from 18% initially expected. This slowdown is forcing investors to look for alternative sectors. The S&P 500 Index is projected to see a 13% earnings growth in 2025, with the tech giants falling behind healthcare and materials groups. Investors are shifting focus to other sectors, such as energy producers and biotech companies, and are questioning the valuations of Big Tech stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished lower, shedding 0.3 per cent to close at 44,642.52.

site_title: Trillion-dollar gap shows diverging South Korea, Taiwan stock fortunes
summary: South Korea's equity market risks falling behind Taiwan's due to the latter's strong performance, driven by a 80% surge in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's shares. This has led to a historic divergence between the two tech-dominated markets, with Taiwan's market capitalization now exceeding South Korea's by $950 billion. As the global AI boom continues, investors see Taiwan as less vulnerable to US tariffs and more attractive to American firms relying on its technology, potentially solidifying its lead over South Korea.

images.alt_text: Despite the numbers, the tech giants still retain their allure with investors, especially if the economy deteriorates.

site_title: UK statistics failing on multiple fronts pose new policy risk
summary: The UK's data quality issues have raised concerns about policy missteps at a critical economic juncture. The Office for National Statistics (ONS) and the Bank of England (BOE) have faced criticism for their data infrastructure and accuracy. A misleading jobs report or dip in growth could provoke a financial market response, affecting borrowing costs. The government is spending millions on tackling inactivity, but flawed data may render the program ineffective. The BOE is cutting interest rates, and investors demand higher yields for UK government debt due to the data uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The UK economy is projected to grow at 1.6 per cent in 2025, the Confederation of British Industry said, down from a projection of 1.9 per cent made in June.

site_title: US regulator places Google Payment under supervision, company sues
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) has ordered federal supervision of Google Payment, citing nearly 300 consumer complaints, including reports of fraud and unauthorized transactions. Google Payment immediately filed a lawsuit challenging the decision, arguing the regulator relied on unsubstantiated complaints concerning a product no longer offered. The CFPB's move marks a government tussle with Google in the final weeks of President Joe Biden's administration, and the regulator's decision can be reversed after President-elect Donald Trump returns to the White House in January.

images.alt_text: Google is far from the only company trying to keep newer forms of communication out of the courtroom.
FILE PHOTO: Gemini logo is seen in this illustration taken May 20, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq hit new highs after ‘Goldilocks’ US jobs report
summary: The US stock market hit new highs on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records, driven by a better-than-expected November jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished lower, shedding 0.3%. The US economy added 227,000 jobs in November, beating expectations. The jobs report was described as a "Goldilocks" print, indicating a balance between job growth and inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6 per cent to 44,765.71, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2 per cent to 19,800.26 on Thursday.

site_title: Amsterdam airport faces capacity cut to curb noise emissions
summary: The Dutch government plans to reduce Amsterdam's Schiphol airport capacity by 4.4% starting next November, capping annual flights at 478,000, to reduce noise emissions by 15%. The move comes after residents complained about noise levels, but airlines have urged caution, citing concerns over operational impact and potential retaliatory measures from other countries. The government aims to achieve a 20% noise reduction target and will seek European Commission approval for the decision.

images.alt_text: Bali's Ngurah Rai airport (above) is currently the second-busiest airport in Indonesia, and is said to be struggling to handle the surge in air traffic.

site_title: Goldman explores possible sale of ETF client platform: sources
summary: Goldman Sachs is exploring options, including a potential sale, of its ETF Accelerator platform, which helps institutional clients launch their own exchange-traded funds (ETFs). The platform, launched in 2023, has handled the launch of 10 ETFs for four clients since its inception. If sold or shut down, the platform would not affect Goldman's own ETF products. Goldman has not made a decision on the platform's future and is assessing its options for the long-term benefit of clients and the bank.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs' decision comes against a backdrop of pressure from some Republican politicians who have suggested that membership of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA) could breach anti-trust rules.
Infini Garden (above) is located in Fukuoka and has a net lettable area of more than 360 square feet.
Goldman Sachs in talks with a number of market participants on the plans as it continues to build out the digital-assets platform’s capabilities and develop new commercial use cases.

site_title: Apple explores Macs, headsets with built-in cellular data
summary: Apple is developing its own modem technology, which will debut next year and gradually replace Qualcomm's parts over a three-year period. The in-house modem, code-named Sinope, will enable slimmer iPhones and potentially lead to cellular-connected Macs and headsets. The first device to feature the new modem will be the iPhone SE, followed by a slimmed-down iPhone in 2025. Apple plans to bring cellular connectivity to Macs by 2026 and is also exploring the idea of cellular-connected headsets, including the Vision Pro, and lightweight augmented reality glasses.

images.alt_text: Apple has spent years trying to replace the Qualcomm modem chip in its iPhones.
Apple’s long-awaited iPhone 16 launch in September had drawn scorn in China for its lack of artificial intelligence features.
FILE PHOTO: A man sits next to an iPhone 16 advertisement as the new iPhone 16 series smartphones go on sale at an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept. 20, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Indonesia banned the sales of Apple’s iPhone 16 after it failed to meet a requirement that smartphones sold domestically must comprise at least 40 per cent locally-made parts.

site_title: Macquarie explores sale of US$1.2 billion helicopter lessor
summary: Macquarie Group is exploring the sale of its US$1.2 billion helicopter leasing business, Macquarie Rotorcraft. The unit, led by CEO John Petkovic, provides financing and leasing for helicopters made by Airbus and Leonardo. This move comes as asset managers favor aviation-related leasing, part of the booming private credit market. The sale is still in the early stages, with no final decisions made, and could fetch US$1.2 billion. Macquarie has not commented on the sale.

site_title: Disney’s largest cruise ship targets Asia with Marvel heroes
summary: Disney's largest cruise ship, the Disney Adventure, is set to launch in Singapore on December 15, 2025, targeting Asia with Marvel heroes. The ship, which can hold 6,700 passengers, features seven themed areas based on Disney, Pixar, and Marvel films, including a Marvel-themed area with a 250-metre Iron Man rollercoaster. Tickets go on sale on December 10, with early bookings exceeding 50% on Trip.com's cruise page. The ship will be homeported in Singapore for at least five years, expected to attract several million local and foreign passengers.

site_title: WHO sends experts to help Congo diagnose mystery disease
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has deployed experts to the Democratic Republic of Congo to investigate an undiagnosed disease linked to multiple deaths in a remote area. The disease, characterized by symptoms including headache, cough, fever, breathing difficulties, and anaemia, is being analyzed through laboratory tests. The WHO will deliver essential medicines and diagnostic kits to support local health authorities in determining the cause of the illness. More information will be shared as it becomes available.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization (WHO) says such attacks on hospitals “can be issues of life and death”.
H5N1 first emerged in 1996 but since 2020, the number of outbreaks in birds has grown exponentially, alongside an increase in the number of infected mammals.

site_title: South Korea martial law fallout deepens as prosecutors close in on president, ex-defence minister
summary: South Korea's leadership crisis deepened as prosecutors named President Yoon Suk-yeol a subject of a criminal investigation over last week's martial law attempt. His former defence minister, Kim Yong-hyun, was arrested, and thousands rallied in front of parliament calling for Yoon's impeachment and arrest. The ruling party proposed that Yoon step down before his duties are suspended, but opposition lawmakers say it's unconstitutional. The crisis threatens to undermine allied efforts to deter nuclear-armed North Korea, with analysts warning that Pyongyang may exploit divisions in Seoul.

images.alt_text: A protestor wears a face mask of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol in a rally calling for his impeachment, who declared martial law, which was reversed hours later, near the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, December 8, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
President Yoon Suk-yeol said he would not seek to avoid legal and political responsibility for his decision, which he said was born of desperation.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon apologises for martial law, but does not resign ahead of impeachment vote
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol apologized for his attempt to impose martial law, but refused to resign ahead of a planned impeachment vote. Yoon acknowledged the decision was born of desperation and expressed regret for shocking the nation. His ruling party, the People Power Party, has called for his resignation, and lawmakers are set to vote on impeachment. If Yoon resigns or is impeached, the prime minister becomes interim president. Prosecutors have launched probes into Yoon and senior officials involved in the martial law decree, seeking charges of insurrection and abuse of power.

images.alt_text: A person watches the broadcasting of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivering an address to the nation, at a railway station in Seoul, South Korea, December 7, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Soo-hyeon
Opposition leader Lee Jae-myung warned about a possibility of another spontaneous late-night declaration to try to turn around the situation, though he did not offer substantive evidence.
A protester holds a poster with an image of South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol calling for his ouster in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 5, 2024.
Demonstrators calling on President Yoon Suk Yeol to step down after his brief imposition of martial law in South Korea outside the National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 5, 2024.
South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol, who briefly declared martial law on Dec 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.

site_title: India probe clears DHL, FedEx, UPS of price collusion
summary: An Indian antitrust investigation has cleared DHL, FedEx, and UPS of price collusion allegations. The Competition Commission of India found that the companies did not share commercially sensitive information amongst themselves and no evidence of collusion was found. The investigation, launched in 2022, reviewed thousands of emails and found that the companies levied a "Covid/Emergency/Peak Surcharge" due to operational costs beyond their control, but this was not done in a concerted manner. The report is due for review by top officials, but the companies are likely to be cleared.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia's gross transaction value for digital payments is expected to exceed US$1 trillion in 2025.

site_title: US issues order mandating bird flu testing of milk supply
summary: The US has issued a federal order requiring the national milk supply to be tested for bird flu, amid concerns of the rapid spread of the virus among dairy herds. The order, announced by Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, mandates testing of milk supply starting December 16, with a focus on California, Colorado, Michigan, Mississippi, Pennsylvania, and Oregon. The testing will involve monthly or weekly sample collection from bulk milk tanks and dairy processors, with the goal of detecting new virus outbreaks and monitoring the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: As bad as the Biden administration has been on pandemic prevention, of course, it's about to be replaced by something far worse.
H5N1 first emerged in 1996 but since 2020, the number of outbreaks in birds has grown exponentially, alongside an increase in the number of infected mammals.
Oceania is the last region of the world free of the H5N1 clade 2.3.4.4b avian influenza that has killed hundreds of millions of birds.

site_title: OpenAI aims to attract more investment by removing ‘AGI’ clause with Microsoft: report
summary: OpenAI is reportedly exploring removing a clause that restricts Microsoft's access to its advanced models when it achieves "artificial general intelligence" (AGI). The clause, included to protect the technology from misuse, would void Microsoft's access if AGI is achieved. By removing the clause, OpenAI aims to attract more investment and enable Microsoft to continue investing in and accessing all OpenAI technology after AGI is achieved. The decision is being discussed by OpenAI's board, with a final decision yet to be made.

images.alt_text: OpenAI also offers a ChatGPT Plus subscription for US$20 a month, a tenth of the cost of the new option.
The partnership comes nearly a year after OpenAI did away with wording in its policies that banned the use of its technology for military or warfare purposes.
OpenAI, led by CEO Sam Altman, has seen its profile skyrocket over recent years as it has become a star player in the growing field of artificial intelligence.

site_title: Discount fatigue – the new Grinch of the holiday season
summary: Retailers in Singapore face a challenge this holiday season as discount fatigue sets in, with consumers becoming increasingly resistant to price-driven promotions. A survey found that 53% of businesses in the region struggle to demonstrate value beyond price, and only 62% of consumers agree that they receive good customer engagement. To combat this, retailers must prioritize personalization, experience, and customer connection, leveraging data-driven insights and AI-powered personalization to deliver tailored experiences and drive customer loyalty.

images.alt_text: A person searches for specials on a computer during the Cyber Monday shopping event in Miami, Florida, Dec 2, 2024.

site_title: Lionel Messi named MLS Most Valuable Player after record-setting season
summary: Lionel Messi has been named Major League Soccer's Most Valuable Player (MVP) after leading Inter Miami to a record-breaking regular season campaign. Despite missing 19 games due to injuries, Messi finished the season with 36 goal contributions, including 20 goals and 16 assists, earning the club its first-ever Supporters Shield. This award marks Messi's achievement in a season marred by injuries, showcasing his exceptional talent and impact on the team.

images.alt_text: Messi has missed eight Major League Soccer games for his club and this month’s World Cup qualifiers for his country.

Jul 14, 2024; Miami, FL, USA; Argentina forward Lionel Messi (10) and teammates celebrate after winning the Copa America final against Colombia at Hard Rock Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Sam Navarro-USA TODAY Sports

A sell-out crowd paid from HK$880 (S$137.23) to see Lionel Messi in action on Feb 4 in an Inter Miami tour match against a Hong Kong select XI, but he remained glued to the bench with an injury, drawing boos from the crowd.
Hangzhou and Beijing have announced that they will not host the scheduled Argentina games for March as the fallout continues. Messi has now spoken in an attempt to ease the situation.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx closes up; French stocks outperform on expectations of new budget
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.2% for its seventh consecutive day, logging its strongest weekly performance in ten, driven by French stocks' 1.3% gain as President Emmanuel Macron announced a new prime minister to address the country's budget. European luxury stocks jumped 3% and German's DAX closed higher by 0.1% despite ongoing political uncertainty. US stocks also rose, with investors pricing in a potential rate cut in December, following a resilient jobs market.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 finished 0.4 per cent higher on Thursday, logging its sixth-straight session of advances.

site_title: Elon Musk’s millions for Trump make him biggest US political donor
summary: Elon Musk, the world's richest person, donated at least $270 million to help Donald Trump win the US presidency, surpassing any single donor since 2010, according to federal filings. Musk's financial backing, which includes $238 million to America PAC and $20 million to the RBG PAC, has earned him a cost-cutting advisory role in Trump's incoming government. Musk has been a close supporter of Trump since his election victory in November, and his new position raises concerns about conflict of interest due to his interactions with US and foreign governments.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk wears a black "Make America Great Again" ball cap while attending a campaign rally with Republican presidential nominee, former President Donald Trump at the Butler Farm Show fairgrounds on October 05, 2024 in Butler, Pennsylvania. This is the first time that Trump has returned to Butler since he was injured during an attempted assassination on July 13.   Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images/AFP. US President-elect Donald Trump on November 12, 2024, said Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk will lead a so-called Department of Government Efficiency alongside US entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy. (Photo by Anna Moneymaker / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: SpaceX gets US contract to expand Ukraine’s access to Starshield
summary: SpaceX has received a Pentagon contract to expand Ukraine's access to a more secure, encrypted Starlink signal, known as Starshield, which is more difficult to hack into or jam. The contract, worth an undisclosed amount, will add 2,500 terminals to the existing 500 connected to Starshield, bringing the total to 3,000. The move deepens SpaceX's involvement in the conflict, despite founder Elon Musk's ambivalence over the war.

images.alt_text: The potential valuation surge underscores the enormous gains that Elon Musk’s empire has seen since the US presidential election.
Elon Musk speaks with US President-elect Donald Trump and guests at a viewing of the launch of the sixth test flight of the SpaceX Starship, Brownsville, Texas, Nov 19, 2024.
The tender offer would value Elon Musk's SpaceX at more than US$250 billion.

site_title: Oil prices fall on supply glut fears despite Opec+ output cut extension
summary: Oil prices fell by 1.4% to $71.12 a barrel for Brent crude and 1.6% to $67.20 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, amid concerns of a supply surplus next year due to weak demand and Opec+ production cuts extension until 2026. Despite a rise in US oil rigs, production remains lower than last year, and analysts project a surplus of 0.2 million barrels per day in 2025.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled 22 cents, or 0.3 per cent, lower at US$72.09 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) settled 24 cents, or 0.35 per cent, down at US$68.30 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: EU and South America strike trade deal, but faces pushback in Europe
summary: The European Union and Mercosur bloc have reached a long-delayed free trade deal after 20 years of negotiations. EU President Ursula von der Leyen and Mercosur counterparts announced the agreement in Montevideo, Uruguay. However, the deal faces strong opposition from France and EU farmers, who cite environmental and farming concerns. EU farmers protest the deal, which they say would lead to cheap imports of South American commodities without meeting EU's green and food safety standards. The deal must now be approved by 15 of the 27 EU members and the European parliament.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (left) having a meeting with Uruguay's President Luis Lacalle (second right) at the Torre Ejecutiva, the government's headquarters in Montevideo, Uruguay, Dec 5, 2024.
Chinese Premier Li Qiang (left) and Lao Prime Minister Sonexay Siphandone at the 27th Asean-China Summit at the National Convention Centre in Vientiane, Laos.

(From left) South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol, Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and Lao Prime Minister Sonexay Siphandone link hands for the Asean handshake at the 27th Asean Plus Three Summit on Thursday (Oct 10).

site_title: US consumer borrowing jumps on surge in credit-card balances
summary: US consumer borrowing increased by $19.2 billion in October, with credit-card balances rising $15.7 billion, the largest advance since mid-2022. Despite rising incomes, lower-income Americans are experiencing greater financial strain. Non-revolving credit, such as loans for vehicle purchases and school tuition, also increased $3.5 billion. The Fed's benchmark rate has been lowered, but it will take time for cheaper financing costs to filter through. A New York Fed report showed 3.5% of outstanding consumer debt was in delinquency in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: SUNRISE, FLORIDA - JUNE 26: Elizabeth Brunner (L) and Hope Johnson (R), recruiters for the City of Pompano Beach, speak to job seekers during the JobNewsUSA.com South Florida Job Fair held at the Amerant Bank Arena on June 26, 2024, in Sunrise, Florida. More than 50 companies set up booths to recruit people from entry-level to management. Open jobs include police officers, food service, security, sales reps, technicians, customer service, IT, teacher assistants, insurance agents, and account executives.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Overall in October, the US trade gap was down 11.9 per cent to US$73.8 billion, from a revised level of US$83.8 billion in September.

Claims are at levels consistent with steady job growth, and have signalled a sharp rebound in nonfarm payrolls in November after the labour market was severely distorted by Hurricanes Helene and Milton as well as strikes by factory workers at Boeing and another aerospace company.

site_title: Arabica coffee’s premium over robusta widens on recent rally
summary: The premium for arabica coffee over robusta beans has widened to over 90 US cents a pound, its highest since April 2023, amid concerns over tight global supplies. Disappointing crops in Brazil and tight supplies of robusta beans in Vietnam are driving the price difference. The price surge is expected to continue, with demand potentially switching from robusta to arabica. This could lead to financial distress for coffee traders, who are struggling to meet margin calls after the rapid price increase.

images.alt_text: The tight supply of robusta coffee beans, which is used in nanyang coffee, is adding on to the business costs of coffee chains.
Coffee prices soared this year due to supply disruptions in Brazil and Vietnam, with budget-friendly robusta hitting a record high.

site_title: Apple plans three-year modem rollout in bid to top Qualcomm
summary: Apple plans to roll out a three-year modem rollout, starting with its first modem in 2025, which will be part of the iPhone SE, and a high-end version in 2026. The modem, code-named Sinope, will be produced by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company and will support four-carrier aggregation. Apple aims to eventually surpass Qualcomm's technology by 2027 with its third-generation modem, code-named Prometheus, which will support mmWave, six-carrier aggregation, and eight-carrier aggregation. The rollout will start in lower-end products, with the iPhone SE expected to debut in the spring.

images.alt_text: Apple’s long-awaited iPhone 16 launch in September had drawn scorn in China for its lack of artificial intelligence features.
FILE PHOTO: A man sits next to an iPhone 16 advertisement as the new iPhone 16 series smartphones go on sale at an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept. 20, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Apple and its rivals will ship 6.2 per cent more phones or an estimated 1.24 billion units in 2024.

site_title: LG Electronics’ India arm files for IPO amid strong consumer durables demand
summary: LG Electronics India has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) valued at 152.4 billion rupees, ranking among the top five in the country this year. The IPO will see 101.8 million shares sold by the parent company, with no new shares issued for sale. The company, which sells consumer durables like washing machines and refrigerators, aims to capitalize on India's growing demand for these products. The IPO is seen as a strategic move to raise funds and cash in on the country's appetite for IPOs.

images.alt_text: CEO William Cho has set a goal of growing the electronics business to an annual revenue of 100 trillion won by 2030.

site_title: Issue 128: Trend reversal on ESG-linked pay; COP29’s shortfall leads us back to private capital
summary: Singapore's top companies saw a sharp decline in the use of sustainability-linked compensation in 2024, according to KPMG. This trend reversal comes after the underwhelming results of the COP29 climate summit, which led to a decrease in private capital investment in climate-related initiatives. The decline in ESG-linked pay may signal a shift back to private capital investment in sustainability projects.

images.alt_text: CMG20231025-HengYY03 / 王彦燕 / 淡马锡 Temasek International office at Orchard Road [Temasek International Pte. Ltd. 60B Orchard Road #06-18 Tower 2. The Atrium@Orchard Singapore 238891]

At COP29, developed nations agreed on US$300 billion as a climate finance goal to help developing nations. But, it is estimated that South-east Asia alone needs US$210 billion annually to meet its transition needs.

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto looks on during a meeting with US President Joe Biden in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 12, 2024. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP)
President Prabowo Subianto has ramped up the climate ambitions of his country, one of the world’s top emitters.

INC-5 Chair Luis Vayas Valdivieso brings down a gavel, made with recycled plastic bottle tops from the Dandora landfill in Nairobi, to mark an agreement that talks will resume at a later date, during the UN Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution (INC-5) in Busan, South Korea, Dec 2, 2024. Negotiators have failed to reach agreement on a landmark treaty to curb plastic pollution.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit takes out up to S$760 million in sustainability-linked loan facilities
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit has secured up to S$760 million in sustainability-linked loan facilities. The loans, including a senior unsecured loan of up to S$420 million and another for up to S$140 million, will be used to refinance existing debts and cover general corporate purposes. The agreements also include an accordion feature, allowing borrowers to expand total commitments. The loans come with conditions, including the requirement for Lendlease Corporation to maintain ownership of at least 51% of the manager's share capital and the appointment of a replacement manager in case of the manager's resignation.

images.alt_text: The attractiveness of private leasehold land can be observed from recent transactions which includes 10 Toh Guan Road East and Admirax. (above)
Lendlease Global Commercial Reit's Sky Complex in MIlan, Italy.
CapitaLand Investment received a four-star rating for the standing investments benchmark, a decline from its five-star rating last year.

site_title: China Vanke sales slump worsens after debt cracks show up
summary: China Vanke's contracted sales for November declined 34.4% from a year earlier to 20.1 billion yuan, widening from a 22.8% drop in October. The developer's worsening finances have raised concerns over its liquidity, following its first loss in two decades in August. Vanke is seeking lender approval to waive certain covenants on two offshore loans, and its solvency in 2025 and 2026 may be at risk if sales continue to slide. S&P Global Ratings downgraded Vanke to B+ with a negative outlook, citing its slow progress in reducing debt.

images.alt_text: The state-backed developer, once considered one of the strong players in the industry, has been raising funds and looking to sell assets to calm investor concern over liquidity stress.
Chinese builders are facing relentless pressure from continued declines in property sales and growing worries about their liquidity.
China’s housing rescue package in May is losing steam as home sales slump deepened in August and prices are expected to plummet further.

site_title: Transforming opportunities: Why ETA is key for Singapore’s next-gen enterpreneurs
summary: Singapore is facing a succession crisis as legacy businesses struggle to find successors, threatening their cultural heritage and economic contributions. Entrepreneurship Through Acquisition (ETA) offers a practical solution, enabling aspiring entrepreneurs to buy into established businesses, ensuring continuity and ethos. ETA provides a win-win solution for founders and buyers, allowing for the transfer of legacy businesses to capable stewards, preserving cultural heritage and promoting sustainable growth. Policymakers and financial institutions can support ETA adoption through grants, mentorship, and financial tools, unlocking immense value for both founders and buyers.

images.alt_text: Balancing speed with sustainable growth
Making angels out of investors
From left: Potter Capital’s Aileen Seah, Amelia Lee and Goh Xin Ying. The trio, all aged 33, fully acquired a chiropractic chain in May 2019.

site_title: Lululemon surges most since 2018 on rebounding performance
summary: Lululemon Athletica's shares surged 16% on Friday, the company's largest one-day gain since 2018, following a strong quarterly report that edged up its full-year outlook. The company attributed the optimism to strong sales overseas, with revenue now expected to be between $10.45 billion and $10.49 billion. This marks a significant rebound from the year-to-date decline of 22%. The stock's performance is seen as a positive sign for the upscale activewear brand amidst increased competition and cautious consumers.

images.alt_text: Lululemon has benefited from its more targeted approach in its second-largest market China, where it has about 130 stores.
Sam’s has customers hooked with products ranging from fresh produce to baked foods and beverages to household supplies.
A Lululemon store in New York. Shopper preferences are moving towards styles that are looser than the leggings the company is known for.

site_title: Italy’s 1982 World Cup victory inspired Zola to make football his career
summary: Former Chelsea player Gianfranco Zola credits the 1982 Italian World Cup victory as the inspiration for his football career. He was 16 years old at the time and was inspired by Italian goalkeeper Dino Zoff, who led Italy to a 3-1 win over West Germany in the final. Zola, now 58, praised current Chelsea manager Enzo Maresca for grooming younger talent and singled out players like Cole Palmer, Moises Caicedo, and Malo Gusto for their potential to bring success to the team.

images.alt_text: Sheffield United is currently in first place in the EFL Championship.
Kiztopia founder and CEO Heidi Tian at the company's flagship outlet in Marina Square, which spans 18,000 square feet.
Foot Locker predicted adjusted earnings of US$1.50 to US$1.70 a share for this fiscal year, falling short of analysts’ expectations.
The Diamond Club comes with heated seats and blankets to help fans cope with the English winter.

site_title: Goldman Sachs quits global climate coalition for banks
summary: Goldman Sachs has quit the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), a global coalition of banks aiming to align lending and investment activities with climate change efforts. The decision comes amid pressure from Republican politicians who suggested NZBA membership could breach anti-trust rules. Goldman Sachs cited regulators' growing push for mandatory sustainability efforts and its own strategy for the future. The bank will continue to align with the world's aim of reaching net-zero emissions by 2050 and publish progress on its sustainability goals. No explicit reason for the departure was given.

images.alt_text: Bank of America is not allowing its SRT investors to take leverage from other US banks, according to a source familiar with the matter.
Goldman Sachs in talks with a number of market participants on the plans as it continues to build out the digital-assets platform’s capabilities and develop new commercial use cases.
Goldman Sachs has been regrouping in the nation as global investors signal renewed interest in the economy.

site_title: Lamborghini Revuelto review: Why it hits the bullseye
summary: The Lamborghini Revuelto is the brand's new flagship, named after a 19th-century bull that terrorized an arena. Powered by a 6.5-litre V12 engine and three electric motors, the Revuelto is a plug-in hybrid that balances brute acceleration with usability. It accelerates to 100 km/h in 2.5 seconds and can stalk the streets in near silence, propelled by 177 hp of electric power. With a price tag of S$2.68 million, the Revuelto is a thrilling and captivating car that strikes a balance between insanity and usability, making it a standout in the luxury market.

site_title: US appeals court upholds TikTok law forcing its sale
summary: A US federal appeals court upheld a law requiring Chinese-based ByteDance to divest its popular short video app TikTok in the US by early next year or face a ban. The decision is a win for the Justice Department and a blow to ByteDance, increasing the possibility of an unprecedented ban on the social media app used by 170 million Americans. The ruling must be appealed to the Supreme Court or full appeals court panel by ByteDance and TikTok.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the office of TikTok in Culver City, California, March 13, 2024.  REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after November job growth soars
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, December 6, after the November job growth report showed a surge. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 58.6 points, or 0.13%, to 44,824.29. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with gains of 6.3 and 43.2 points, respectively, at the opening bell. Traders are optimistic about a potential Federal Reserve rate cut this month, driving the upward momentum.

images.alt_text: Specialist traders work inside a post on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 2, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: 30 years of celebrating Singapore’s most enterprising businesses, Enterprise 50 - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore and the Netherlands are poised for significant growth opportunities in the green and digital sectors, as well as in circular economy areas, according to Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Grace Fu. The two countries are strengthening their trade ties and exploring collaborations in sustainable technologies, renewable energy, and eco-friendly manufacturing. This cooperation aims to drive economic growth, create jobs, and enhance competitiveness in these emerging sectors. The partnership is expected to promote innovation and investment, ultimately boosting bilateral trade and economic development. Circular economy and sustainability are key areas of focus for the Singapore-Netherlands partnership.

site_title: BP seeks buyers for US natural gas pipeline system stake
summary: BP is seeking buyers for a stake in its US natural gas pipeline network, aiming to raise up to $3 billion. The sale process is part of CEO Murray Auchincloss' efforts to reduce debt levels, which have risen to $24.3 billion. The company is facing investor pressure to improve performance and profitability amid concerns over its energy transition strategy. This sale follows plans to sell stakes in its solar and wind businesses, and Auchincloss will update the company's strategy in February.

images.alt_text: While BP is based in London, more than half of its assets and cash flows are in the US, and Auchincloss was bullish about the company’s output there till 2030.
BP added that CO2 recovered from its first carbon capture, utilisation and storage project in Indonesia would be used to boost production at the Tangguh facility.

site_title: An ethics case study: AI in investment management
summary: A Singapore-based investment manager, Simmons, uses artificial intelligence (AI) to identify promising investment opportunities in the global food service sector. However, his use of AI raises concerns about compliance with ethical principles, particularly the integrity, transparency, and client protection standards. Simmons relies on an AI technology consultant to analyze data and make recommendations, but he lacks a thorough understanding of the consultant's methods and may be misrepresenting the role of AI in his investment decisions. The use of AI in client communication also raises concerns about transparency and bias.

images.alt_text: Technology provides the tools to aggregate and analyse vast amounts of data to increase transparency and build client trust.

site_title: Brands should return to storytelling that makes us human
summary: Brands are at a crossroads, where the value of storytelling and entertainment is being undermined by a focus on transactional content. With the rise of social media and platforms prioritizing quick dopamine hits, the risk of a world flooded with content no one cares about is real. To combat this, brands should return to storytelling that makes us human, using universal messages that reflect the voices, values, and needs of their audiences. This can be achieved by exploring fresh, creative formats, going back to basics, and using real emotion to create meaningful connections with their audience.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of shoppers outside the luxury outlets/ stores at the Ion Orchard shopping mall on Oct 3, 2023.
A fresh branding emerges from deep dive into Singapore spirit
As an omnichannel brand partner, Buy Quickly also offers services such as operating online stores and shooting advertising campaigns for global brands.
The business of creative industries

site_title: China’s JD Logistics takes full ownership of Kuayue-Express with 6.48 billion yuan stake buy
summary: JD Logistics acquires 100% stake in Kuayue-Express for 6.48 billion yuan, aiming to enhance express delivery offerings and accelerate development. The acquisition enables integration of resources, cost reduction, and operational efficiency. JD Logistics had previously acquired a 36.43% stake in 2020 and raised its interest to 63.57% in 2022. The deal is expected to further synergies and expand Kuayue-Express' business, with growth exceeding industry standards. Shares of JD Logistics have surged 44% this year.

images.alt_text: JD.com said total revenue rose 5.1 per cent to 260.4 billion yuan (S$48.4 billion) in the third quarter.
Workers sort packages for delivery at a JD.com warehouse in Beijing on November 11, known as the Singles’ Day shopping festival in China.

site_title: US job growth accelerates in November; unemployment rate rises to 4.2%
summary: US job growth surged in November with a 227,000 increase in nonfarm payrolls, beating economists' forecasts of 200,000 jobs. The unemployment rate rose to 4.2% as wages advanced 4% over the past 12 months, the highest in over a decade. Despite this, labor market conditions are expected to continue easing, allowing the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again this month. The strong job growth is seen as a positive sign for the economy, but does not signal a material shift in labor market conditions.

images.alt_text: Claims are at levels consistent with steady job growth, and have signalled a sharp rebound in nonfarm payrolls in November after the labour market was severely distorted by Hurricanes Helene and Milton as well as strikes by factory workers at Boeing and another aerospace company.

site_title: Anticipating Trump’s foreign policy
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy is anticipated to align with a "personnel is policy" approach, prioritizing loyalty over traditional Republican views. His choices for Secretary of State and national security adviser, Senator Marco Rubio and Representative Michael Waltz, are hawkish on China, and Trump is expected to impose tariffs on imports from Mexico, Canada, and China. Trump may devalue multilateralism and alliances, potentially withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement and reducing US support for Taiwan. His approach to the Middle East and Europe is uncertain, but may extend his prior success in the region, including the Abraham Accords, while potentially weakening Ukraine's bargaining position in negotiations with Russia.

images.alt_text: A U.S. Coast Guard boat patrols outside U.S. President-elect Donald Trump's residence at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria
Posters of hostages kidnapped during the Oct 7, 2023, attack by Hamas. Israel's response to the attack has weakened the ability of Iran to assert its position in the Middle East.

A demonstrator in Israel calling for the release of hostages in Gaza. Various sources say Donald Trump wants to see the war in Gaza end and the hostages there freed before he assumes office in January.
Trump's campaign is proposing a second, much bigger hike in tariffs; lavish tax cuts; a labour-supply shock in the form of mass deportations; and attacks on the independence of the Federal Reserve.

site_title: South Korea's opposition leader warns of another martial law attempt
summary: South Korea's opposition leader Lee Jae-myung warned that President Yoon Suk Yeol might attempt to declare martial law again before parliament votes on impeaching him on December 7. Lee cited the president's past brief imposition of martial law as a reason for concern, saying it could be a last-ditch effort to turn the situation around. The impeachment requires support from two-thirds of the 300-member assembly, with at least eight of Yoon's ruling party members needed to vote for it, despite their official stance of blocking the impeachment.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators calling on President Yoon Suk Yeol to step down after his brief imposition of martial law in South Korea outside the National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 5, 2024.
The won has been among the biggest victims from the row that swept the nation and raised concerns about South Korea’s credit worthiness.

site_title: Superheroes checked
summary: The superhero film genre has experienced a decline in success, despite its enduring appeal. The over-reliance on computer-generated imagery (CGI) and special effects has diminished their impact. The genre's fundamental flaw lies in its reliance on superpowers, which have become normalized and no longer impress audiences. Well-scripted films with engaging storylines, well-acted heroes, and villains are more likely to succeed in the long term. Marvel films have generally fared better than DC films, but even they are beginning to flag. The future of the superhero film genre depends on quality writing, interesting storylines, and engaging characters, rather than relying on CGI and action.

images.alt_text: Deadpool & Wolverine has now topped the box office for four of its five weekends out, logging impressive total ticket sales of US$577.2 million domestically and US$634 million internationally.
Superstar Jay Chou's mum plans IPO of bulletproof coffee brand
Spider-Man continues to lift anaemic box office takings

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog clears EQT’s takeover of PropertyGuru
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has cleared EQT's US$1.1 billion takeover of PropertyGuru, a South-east Asia property tech firm. The watchdog found the deal unlikely to substantially lessen competition in the digital real estate advertising services market. Most respondents to a public consultation, including PropertyGuru's rivals, did not express concerns over the acquisition. The deal, which will take PropertyGuru private, is expected to be completed after a public consultation period. The company will remain headquartered in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Revenue for the second quarter was up 10.3 per cent amid higher contributions from its marketplaces segment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 6)
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) announced it will release land for over 5,000 private housing units via the confirmed list for the first half of 2025. Carousell cut 76 employees, representing 7% of its workforce, in a company-wide layoff. A separate category for private-hire cars in Singapore is being studied by Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat. Meanwhile, Temasek formed a $10 billion private credit platform and RHB advised Suntec Reit unitholders to reject a mandatory offer. Singapore shares declined 0.7% on Friday.

site_title: Airbus still has 127 aircraft to deliver to achieve annual goal
summary: Airbus delivered 84 jets to 42 customers in November, a monthly record, bringing this year's total to 643 units. To meet its annual goal of 770 jets, the company needs to deliver more aircraft in December than in any other month this year. Despite supply-chain constraints, particularly with large components, Airbus aims to achieve its target, with deliveries typically rising sharply in the final months of the year. The company's CEO, Guillaume Faury, will wait to set a new 2025 target to ensure clarity on the supply side.

site_title: IMDA investigates StarHub’s Giga for e-SIM security lapse
summary: StarHub's Giga e-SIM service is being investigated by Singapore's regulator, the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), for failing to verify users' identities before re-issuing eSIMs. This lapse allowed a hacker to gain control of a customer's phone line and access sensitive information. Experts warn that without proper verification, e-SIMs can be easily hijacked. StarHub has implemented two-factor authentication on its app, but the IMDA is still investigating the incident, citing a need for robust registration procedures for SIM and eSIM issuances.

site_title: Guardian owner to sell Observer to Tortoise for £25 million investment
summary: The Guardian Media Group has agreed to sell the Observer to online news startup Tortoise Media for £25 million. The deal includes a £25 million investment by Tortoise over five years, with a commitment to publish the print edition. The Scott Trust, Guardian owner, will become a key shareholder and take a seat on both editorial and commercial boards. The sale comes after two days of strikes by unionised journalists over the proposed sale, with opponents advocating for alternative proposals.

site_title: Indonesia's president agrees to selective VAT hike
summary: Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto has agreed to raise the value-added tax (VAT) to 12% starting January 1, 2025, but only on luxury goods, exempting staple items. The move aims to improve the structural health of the budget and is accompanied by fiscal stimulus. The higher VAT rate will only apply to luxury goods, while other goods will remain at 11%. The decision follows public pressure to delay the hike, which could have hurt purchasing power.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's VAT is set to rise to 12% on Jan 1, 2025, but public demand for delay mounts.

site_title: Broadcom unveils new tech to speed up custom chips amid rising generative AI demand
summary: Broadcom has developed new technology, called 3.5D XDSiP, to enhance semiconductor speeds and boost memory inside custom chips. The technology uses advanced packaging techniques and is expected to speed up chip performance. Five products are in development, with production shipments starting in February 2026. Broadcom's custom chip unit is a beneficiary of the growing demand for generative AI infrastructure, with forecasts of $12 billion in AI revenue for fiscal year 2024. The market for custom chips is expected to grow to $45 billion by 2028.

images.alt_text: OpenAI has dropped the ambitious foundry plans for now due to the costs and time needed to build a network.
Despite a sharp rise in orders for its artificial intelligence chips, Broadcom shares fell nearly 5 per cent in extended trading.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Broadcom logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: World Bank raises record US$100 billion for aid to poorest nations
summary: The World Bank has received record-breaking pledges of $100 billion for aid to the poorest nations, surpassing its previous record of $93 billion. The figure is the culmination of President Ajay Banga's efforts to secure funding for the International Development Association, which was replenished with $24 billion in donations from donor countries. The increased pledges, particularly from 17 donor countries that raised their contributions by 25%, will be leveraged about 3.5-4 times, supporting projects such as extending health services to 900 million people and connecting 117 million to electricity.

images.alt_text: The World Bank Group headquarters in Washington, DC. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg
World Bank Group President Ajay Banga speaks during a function at the Lowy Institute in Sydney on September 10, 2024. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)

site_title: ST Engineering makes foray into Central Asia with Kazakhstan defence vehicle contract
summary: ST Engineering has secured a contract with Kazakhstan Paramount Engineering to manufacture an amphibious multi-purpose armoured vehicle, marking the company's entry into the Central Asia market. The vehicle will be based on ST Engineering's field-tested Terrex Infantry Fighting Vehicle, with the company providing engineering and technical support for its construction, set to begin in 2025. This partnership is part of ST Engineering's strategy to pursue growth through localisation and in-country operations support.

site_title: Eurozone consumers finally start spending in boost to GDP growth
summary: Eurozone consumers have started spending, boosting GDP growth with a 0.7% increase in household expenditure and 2% growth in investments. This follows a slowdown in inflation and rising wages, but also a decline in trade and overall GDP growth of 0.4%. The European Central Bank expects this trend to continue, allowing for lower borrowing costs and a potential deposit rate of 2% by 2025. However, business surveys indicate flagging momentum in the economy, and the labour market is showing signs of softening.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde speaks to reporters following the Governing Council's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany September 12, 2024. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch/File Photo
A PMI covering the services industry fell last month to 49.5 from 51.6, its first sub-50 reading since January.
Foreign demand for European goods will worsen if President-elect Donald Trump imposes a 10 per cent tariff on all imports as proposed.
Consumers became more pessimistic on growth, as expectations for the next 12 months fell to -1.1 per cent from -0.9 per cent seen in September, the ECB said.

site_title: Vietnam’s November export growth slows as external demand remains soft
summary: Vietnam's November export growth slowed to 8.2% year-over-year, the lowest in nine months, due to weak external demand. The country's goods exports reached $33.7 billion, down from $38.7 billion in October. The trade surplus narrowed to $1.1 billion, the smallest in six months. Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh aims for 8% growth in 2025, despite the slowdown.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is a significant exporter to the US and has a large trade surplus with Washington.

From left to right: Nvidia Executive Vice President for Worldwide Field Operations Jay Puri, Nvidia Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang; Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, and Minister of Planning and Investment Nguyen Chi Dung
A vendor walks along a railway track as she sells cakes for tourists outside cafes in Hanoi, Vietnam October 8, 2019. Picture taken October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
The court ruled in April that Truong My Lan must compensate Saigon Commercial Bank a total of 674 trillion dong – an amount Lan appealed against but still committed to repay “at all costs”.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust manager names Gerry Chan as CEO
summary: Gerry Chan, 48, has been appointed as CEO of CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) effective January 1, 2025. He will also join the executive committee as an executive non-independent director, succeeding Tan Tze Wooi. Chan was previously appointed as deputy CEO on September 1. The appointment is part of CLCT's regular succession and leadership renewal process.

site_title: New York City approves a plan to create 80,000 new homes
summary: New York City Council approved a plan to create 80,000 new homes over 15 years, aiming to address the city's housing crisis. The plan, known as "City of Yes," includes zoning changes to build more housing in neighborhoods, with an additional $5 billion in affordable housing and infrastructure funding. The measure passed with 31 yes votes, despite opposition from some lawmakers, and is seen as a significant step forward in addressing high housing costs and homelessness.

images.alt_text: New York City’s housing agency is issuing the bonds as fixed-rate debt with multiple classes, similar to the way commercial mortgage backed securities are structured.

site_title: Uber launches first robotaxi service outside of US in Abu Dhabi
summary: Uber launched its first autonomous robotaxi service outside the US in Abu Dhabi, partnering with China's WeRide. Riders can request autonomous vehicles at tourist areas such as Saadiyat Island and Yas Island at UberX or Comfort rates. Safety operators will be present during the initial launch period, with plans for a fully driverless service in 2025. The move marks progress in Uber's efforts to become the go-to app for autonomous vehicles, but shares fell 9.6% after Waymo announced a similar service launch in Miami in 2026.

images.alt_text: The FTC is investigating Uber over enrollment and cancellation aspects of their subscription service, according to documents viewed by Bloomberg.
Founded in 2016, Pony AI develops and operates self-driving fleets in the US and China.
Uber is submitting its suggestions as the TLC prepares changes to the driver minimum wage rule.
Uber has been investing into new areas across both its ride-hailing and delivery businesses in the US and internationally, where the company said it has seen stronger growth.
Tesla has been under pressure to justify its high valuation and prove it can lead the industry in autonomous vehicle technology.

site_title: German industrial production unexpectedly declined in October
summary: German industrial production unexpectedly declined 1% in October, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 1% increase. This marks the third consecutive month of decline, weighing on the country's economy, which is headed for a second straight year of contraction. External factors such as lost Russian energy supplies and soft Chinese demand, along with a shortage of skilled workers, are contributing to the economic downturn. The decline has raised concerns about a downward spiral, with some companies announcing thousands of job cuts, and may lead to a further contraction in 2025 if US President-elect Donald Trump implements trade tariffs.

images.alt_text: Governments around the world have been investing public funds in the chip industry as part of an effort to localise production of components.

site_title: Thailand rules out raising value-added tax after public outcry
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra ruled out raising the value-added tax (VAT) to 15% despite Finance Minister Pichai's proposal to more than double the levy to address income inequality and boost the economy. The proposal was met with opposition from the main opposition party and a military-backed party in the ruling coalition, citing concerns over price hikes and economic impact. The government will instead conduct a comprehensive review of the tax structure to reduce inequality and boost competitiveness.

images.alt_text: epa11441020 Shoppers buy discounted clothes at the 28th Saha Group Fair shopping event in Bangkok, Thailand, 27 June 2024. The Saha Group Fair is an annual shopping event with thousands of products including food and beverage, groceries, healthcare products, household items, clothing, and daily necessities on sale with discounted prices offering lower deals to help consumers save expenses. The Bank of Thailand predicts its economy will grow slower in the upcoming third and fourth quarters of this year, resulting in Thailand's gross domestic product (GDP) expanding at 2.6 percent in 2024 and 3.0 percent in 2025, according to the Bank of Thailand.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

site_title: Barclays promotes 116 staffers across bank to managing directors
summary: Barclays has promoted 116 employees to managing director ranks, with the investment bank benefiting from increased debt underwriting fees and 17% rise in equities trading revenue. The promotions, the largest in the bank's history, saw women make up 28% and under-represented employees account for 7%. The move is part of a three-year plan to boost returns by focusing on profitable businesses and clients. Barclays shares have risen 90% over the past year, driven by a surge in advisory revenue to £472 million.

images.alt_text: Barclays currently runs booking centres in six locations, including India, the UK and Switzerland.

The fine by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) dates back to the height of the 2008-to-2009 financial crisis, when Barclays scrambled to raise funds from overseas investors including Qatar in order to avoid a state bailout.
A view shows signage on a branch of Barclays Bank in London, Britain, March 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

site_title: NBA to return to China with multiyear deal in Macau
summary: The National Basketball Association (NBA) has signed a multiyear deal to host two pre-season games annually in Macau from 2025 to 2029 at Sands China's Venetian arena. This marks the league's return to China after a five-year absence following controversy over Hong Kong protests. The first games, featuring the Brooklyn Nets and Phoenix Suns, are scheduled for October 2025. The deal aims to increase Macau's non-gaming revenue and diversify its economy, which relies heavily on casinos.

images.alt_text: Macau's gross gaming revenue reached 20.8 billion patacas (S$3.4 billion) for the month, according to data released by the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Bureau.
Sam, the ex-president of Macau’s Court of Final Appeal, was the sole candidate in the election for chief executive.
The project is part of the group’s efforts to bolster its non-gaming offerings and attract mass-market tourists.

site_title: Want work-life balance? You have to make sacrifices, say panellists at dialogue on careers
summary: Panellists at a discussion hosted by thrive, The Business Times' young audience initiative, emphasize that achieving work-life balance is not a one-size-fits-all concept, but rather a matter of finding work-life integration. They advise attendees to prioritize their needs, make sacrifices, and know what they value most. Key takeaways include: work should be a place where one can bring their true self, not a source of identity or fulfillment; it's okay to make sacrifices and put in extra hours; and finding one's calling often requires time and patience.

images.alt_text: BT
BT
A woman on her laptop working from home.

site_title: Temasek firm to sell shares in Malaysia 5G winner to tycoon Vincent Tan
summary: A Temasek firm, Straits Mobile Investments, is selling 28% of its stake in Malaysian phone company U Mobile to tycoon Vincent Tan's entity, Mawar Setia, reducing its shareholding to 20%. The deal, agreed on Dec 4, also involves Princess Aminah Ibrahim of Johor, who holds 30%. The sale comes after U Mobile won a major 5G contract, surprising analysts due to its smaller size and large foreign ownership. Regulatory approvals are required, with completion expected by 2025.

images.alt_text: Under a conditional share purchase deal, Mawar Setia will acquire the stake in U Mobile from Straits Mobile Investments, a unit of ST Telemedia.

site_title: Korean coup movie hits No 1 on Netflix after martial law chaos
summary: A Korean coup movie, "12.12: The Day," has become the No. 1 Korean film on Netflix since President Yoon Suk-yeol's imposition of martial law on December 3, 2024. The film, released in 2023, depicts a 1979 coup and has resonated with South Koreans, who are grappling with the aftermath of the president's decision, which reignited memories of the country's military dictatorship and the Gwangju Uprising of 1980. The movie and a Nobel Prize-winning novel by Han Kang have become memes, with many calling for President Yoon to be held accountable.

images.alt_text: A protester holds a poster with an image of South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol calling for his ouster in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 5, 2024.
Demonstrators calling on President Yoon Suk Yeol to step down after his brief imposition of martial law in South Korea outside the National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 5, 2024.
South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol, who briefly declared martial law on Dec 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.
The won has been among the biggest victims from the row that swept the nation and raised concerns about South Korea’s credit worthiness.

A woman holds a sign that reads "Yoon Suk Yeol should step down" during a candlelight vigil against South Korea President Yoon in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024. South Korea's opposition moved to impeach Yoon after his extraordinary but short-lived imposition of martial law that brought thousands of protesters to the streets.
