South Korean Defence Minister Kim Yong Hyun has been reported as having advised PM Yoon Suk Yeol to declare martial law on Tuesday, which was lifted after parliament’s vote demanding Yoon to reverse it.
People attend a candlelight vigil condemning South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's surprise declaration of martial law last night, which was reversed hours later, and to call for his resignation.
Protestors calling for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 4 after he imposted martial law.
Prime Minister Han Duck-soo (above) will step in to perform presidential duties if the President Yoon quits or is removed from office.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, December 6, 2024
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday as traders assessed the crisis in South Korea. In contrast, Indian central bank rates remained steady while cutting banks' cash reserve ratio, and Chinese stocks jumped ahead of expected stimulus and rate cut bets.

images.alt_text: Asian equities track a decline in US shares ahead of jobs data that may help shape the direction of the Federal Reserve’s policy path later this month.
Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Manila, Taipei stocks fell but Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Friday.
India’s annual retail inflation rose to 6.21 per cent in October, breaching the central bank’s tolerance band for the first time in more than a year.

site_title: Singapore’s maritime sector on track for another record year in 2024
summary: Singapore's maritime sector is on track for a record year in 2024, with container throughput growing 6.2% to 34.2 million TEUs from January to October, and bunker sales increasing 7.5% to 45.7 million tonnes. Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat expects a record year for container throughput and bunker sales, with Changi Airport also poised to exceed pre-Covid levels in 2025, handling 61.2 million passenger movements in the first 11 months of the year.

images.alt_text: Digital bunkering will speed up the process of refuelling ships and save up to 40,000 man-days a year.
The PSA Supply Chain Hub @ Tuas will also be able to handle sensitive goods and improve Tuas Port's competitiveness.
Though 2023 was a fruitful year for Singapore's maritime industry, choppy waters are said to lie ahead.

site_title: Temasek initiates wholly owned private credit platform of about S$10 billion
summary: Temasek has launched a wholly owned private credit platform with an initial portfolio of about S$10 billion, managed by a team of 15 credit professionals. Led by Nicolas Debetencourt, the platform aims to capitalize on the growing private credit market, which is expected to reach US$2.6 trillion by 2029. This move follows stricter regulations in the industry and Temasek's existing investments in credit funds, which have been a part of its portfolio for over 10 years.

images.alt_text: CMG20231025-HengYY03 / 王彦燕 / 淡马锡 Temasek International office at Orchard Road [Temasek International Pte. Ltd. 60B Orchard Road #06-18 Tower 2. The Atrium@Orchard Singapore 238891]
Temasek Trust receives its funding primarily from Temasek Holdings.

site_title: Gold heads for second weekly fall; spotlight on US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,631.60 per ounce, despite a 0.8% decline so far this week. The focus shifted to the US payrolls data, due later, which is expected to show a 200,000 job increase in November, following a 12,000 rise in October. The US Federal Reserve rate cut trajectory is also being monitored, with a 70.1% chance of a 25-basis-point cut this month. Higher interest rates are expected to dull the appeal of non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was flat at US$2,648.89 per ounce.

site_title: India central bank holds rates steady; cuts banks’ cash reserve ratio
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) kept its key interest rate unchanged at 6.5% but cut the cash reserve ratio (CRR) by 50 basis points to 4%, easing monetary conditions. The move aims to infuse 1.2 trillion rupees into the banking system and lower market interest rates. The RBI also retained its policy stance at "neutral" and lowered its growth forecast for the year ending March 2025 to 6.6%, citing a resilient economy despite recent growth slowdowns and rising inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A policeman walks past the logo of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) outside its head office in Mumbai November 2, 2010. REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui (INDIA - Tags: BUSINESS)/File Photo
The rupee has weakened nearly 0.5 per cent so far in November.
The RBI’s bullishness is underpinned by its view that rural spending is improving and private investment is picking up.

site_title: Carousell sheds 76 employees in latest round of layoffs
summary: Carousell has laid off 76 employees, representing 7% of its total headcount, across its regional offices. The company cited matching market reality in some business units and reallocation of resources to areas showing promise as reasons for the layoffs. This is the latest round of cuts, following a 110-employee layoff in December 2022. Affected employees will receive a one-month salary for every year of service, with additional benefits including leave, flexible benefits, and career support.

images.alt_text: Laku6 acquisition by Carousell
The acquisition will aid in the growth of Carousell’s luxury segment, with an offline presence to complement the current online channels and grow its luxury offerings.
From left to right: Carousell co-founders Lucas Ngoo, Marcus Tan and Quek Siu Rui.

site_title: Separate COE category for private-hire cars in Singapore being ‘carefully studied’: Chee
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat says a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private-hire cars is being "carefully studied" due to challenges in classifying and predicting demand. The review aims to address concerns driving up COE premiums, with a separate category potentially sparking price spikes or shortages. The second phase of the point-to-point transport sector review will also examine fair competition, increasing taxi drivers, and keeping the sector "competitive and contestable." The review is expected to conclude by March 2025, with potential updates on its progress at the Committee of Supply in March 2025.

images.alt_text: There are now more similarities than differences between private hire cars and taxis, which is why the former should not compete or bid for passenger car COEs.
Industry watchers say that forthcoming regulatory changes will reduce operating costs for taxis, but will not give them a significant advantage.
According to driver feedback, earnings may have dropped by 30 per cent in the past six months.
Major updates to improve taxi, private-hire car sector in Singapore effective from January
The issue of driver supply is not going to be easily solved by ride hailing platforms in Singapore.
Grab and Trans-cab have decided not to proceed with the proposed acquisition, and informed the competition watchdog on Jul 22.

site_title: Digital Core Reit acquires additional 15.1% stake in Frankfurt data centre
summary: Digital Core Reit has acquired an additional 15.1% stake in a Frankfurt data centre, bringing its interest to 65%. The US$76.6 million acquisition cost includes a purchase consideration of 71 million euros and an acquisition fee paid in newly issued units. The Reit's pro-forma distribution and net asset value per unit have been adjusted due to the acquisition and private placement of new units.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit’s data centre in Northern Virginia. The Reit currently owns a 49.9 per cent interest in the Frankfurt data centre and had announced in September its plans to raise its stake.

site_title: Marks & Spencer wins battle to demolish flagship London store
summary: Marks & Spencer won a long-standing battle to demolish its flagship London store on Oxford Street, with the government approving plans to replace it with a new development. The retailer had initially requested permission in 2021, but faced delays and opposition from the previous government. Labour's Secretary of State for housing and communities, Angela Rayner, formally approved the plans, following a legal challenge by M&S. The development is seen as crucial to the site's survival, with M&S CEO Stuart Machin praising the outcome as a relief after "three unnecessary years of delays".

site_title: UK house prices jump 1.3% to record high
summary: UK house prices reached a record high in November, with the average home price rising 1.3% to £298,083, according to Halifax. This is the fifth consecutive monthly gain, and prices are 4.8% higher than last year. The increase is attributed to an end to Budget uncertainty, interest-rate cuts, and low unemployment boosting buyer demand. Mortgage approvals also hit their highest in over two years, with Bank of England data showing a 1.2% rise in prices. Experts expect further growth, albeit at a modest pace, as borrowing costs remain above average.

site_title: First private residential sites in Turf City, former Keppel Golf Course among 7 new state land sites unveiled for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has unveiled seven new state land sites for sale, including the first private residential sites in Turf City and the former Keppel Golf Course. The Dunearn Road site in Bukit Timah Turf City can house approximately 370 units, while the other six sites are also expected to attract high demand as developers seek to gain a first-mover advantage in the Greater Southern Waterfront and Bukit Timah. Market watchers anticipate strong interest in the sites, with developers looking to capitalize on their prime locations.

images.alt_text: Developers remain concerned about elevated risks due to the spectre of new cooling measures following robust sales take-up at recent launches. Emerald of Katong is among the projects that achieved strong sales recently.

site_title: South Korea’s presidential office says Yoon did not order arrest of lawmakers: Yonhap
summary: South Korea's presidential office stated President Yoon Suk Yeol did not order the arrest or detention of lawmakers, according to Yonhap news agency. The claim comes amid protests calling for his ouster. The office's statement aimed to clarify the situation, but the exact circumstances surrounding the allegations remain unclear.

site_title: Musk’s xAI wraps up US$6 billion in funding in latest round
summary: Elon Musk's AI startup xAI has raised $6 billion in funding, valuing the company at over $40 billion, according to a regulatory filing. The latest round of funding, which includes stakes as small as $77,593, was led by 97 investors. The company's main product, a chatbot called Grok, is available to paying users of X, the social network formerly known as Twitter. This funding round follows a previous $6 billion round in May, which valued the business at $24 billion.

site_title: Johor property market still hot but watch out for pitfalls
summary: The Johor property market remains attractive to Singaporeans, with interest growing despite the strengthening Malaysian ringgit against the Singapore dollar. The upcoming Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) and Johor-Singapore Rapid Transport System (RTS) Link are expected to boost demand. Key areas near the border tend to yield higher returns, but demand fluctuates, and investors should remain vigilant about market trends. The average gross rental yield is between 3-6%, and prices have been trending up since 2019, with the average house price in Johor at around RM424,976. Despite the challenges of the Forest City project, the SFZ initiative aims to revive investor interest, and market experts expect the JS-SEZ and RTS Link to drive growth in the property market.

images.alt_text: The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.

Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
The multi-billion dollar Forest City development has faced challenges over the years in attracting attracting both residents and businesses.
Forest City will be the first location in Malaysia to offer zero per cent tax rate for family offices.

site_title: Renters in Rome struggle as coming Holy Year dries up housing market
summary: Rome's housing market is drying up due to the influx of tourists for the 2025 Roman Catholic Holy Year, with many landlords converting apartments to short-term rentals. Industry groups estimate a doubling of short-term rentals over the past year, and monthly rental rates have risen by around a third. Long-term rentals are becoming increasingly unaffordable, forcing many Romans to move further out of the city centre. The average local salary is under €2,000 a month, making it difficult for tenants to find affordable housing, with prices reaching up to €1,400 for a two-bedroom apartment.

images.alt_text: Visitors on the beach below the Cathedral of Santa Maria of Palma, also known as La Seu, in Palma de Mallorca, Spain, on Friday, July 26, 2024. Southern European cities including Lisbon and Madrid saw strong growth in residential-property values in the first half of the year, as an ongoing supply crunch buoyed the high-end housing market. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Victoria’s Secret lifts guidance with positive start to holidays
summary: Victoria's Secret raised its annual revenue guidance after reporting third-quarter sales that exceeded Wall Street expectations. Revenue is expected to rise as much as 2% this year, a 15% increase from earlier estimates, driven by a positive response to holiday merchandise. The company's new CEO, Hillary Super, attributes the improvement to good inventory management and cost controls. Despite facing waning demand and increased competition, Victoria's Secret shares have surged 62% this year, outperforming the S&P 500 Index.

site_title: Nasa delays first moon landing in more than 50 years to 2027
summary: NASA has delayed its first moon landing in over 50 years to 2027 due to safety concerns with the Orion spacecraft's heat shield and technical issues with the Boeing-built Space Launch System (SLS) rocket. The delay affects the Artemis II mission, which will send a crew of four to the moon's vicinity in 2026. The agency plans to keep the existing heat shield but alter the spacecraft's trajectory, with a new heat shield to be installed for subsequent missions. The 2027 target date is still ahead of China's planned 2030 moon landing.

images.alt_text: Boeing’s new chief executive officer Kelly Ortberg is assessing the company’s portfolio to raise cash, weed out under-performing units and rescue a company in crisis.
Video grab showing Boeing's Starliner approaching the landing site at White Sands Space Harbor in White Sands, New Mexico.

Nasa astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams pose ahead of the launch of Boeing's Starliner-1 Crew Flight Test (CFT), in Cape Canaveral, Florida, April 25, 2024. Nasa opted to bring the ship home without astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams despite Boeing’s assurances of a safe flight.
Nasa faces critical trade-offs of its own as it maps out the future of the commercial crew programme.

site_title: China to give its firms a procurement boost before Trump return
summary: China has proposed a draft rule to give domestic products a 20% price advantage in government procurement, aiming to boost technology self-reliance amid US curbs. To qualify, products must contain a certain proportion of components made in China and have key manufacturing procedures done within the nation. This move is likely to help domestic manufacturers weather possible tariff hikes by the US. The rule, published by the Ministry of Finance, seeks public feedback before being implemented.

images.alt_text: The words "Made In China" appear on an object displayed for a photograph in Tiskilwa, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, April 10, 2018. Trade talks between the worlds biggest economies broke down last week after the Trump administration demanded that China curtail support for high-technology industries, a person familiar with the situation said, signaling that a resolution may be some ways off. Photographer:  Daniel Acker/Bloomberg

site_title: The crowds are back—and buying—at Art Basel Miami Beach
summary: Art Basel Miami Beach saw a surge in buying activity, with collectors flocking to the fair after a nearly two-year hiatus. Despite a lingering chill in the market, sales were reported across 286 galleries, with several mega-galleries recording multiple million-dollar transactions. The fair's focus on abstract art and cultural connections seemed to appeal to collectors, who were eager to engage in a meaningful and social experience. Dealers noted a cautious optimism, with some expressing skepticism about the market's overall health.

images.alt_text: epa11650512 A woman looks at the works 'The Pier of Boulogne-sur-Mer' and 'Sailboats and Seagulls', by Edouard Manet, and 'Fishing Boats and The Nets of Pourville', by Claude Monet, from the new exhibition Vive l'impressionnisme! at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, 09 October 2024. The exhibition showcases the finest French Impressionist works from Dutch collections.  EPA-EFE/ROBIN VAN LONKHUIJSEN
In a room with yellow walls, three paintings are notably exhibited: two “Sunflowers”, which surround  “The Lullaby”, a painting representing a woman, seated on an armchair.

site_title: Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan’s death sparks questions over succession in vast business empire
summary: Malaysian billionaire T Ananda Krishnan, founder of Maxis and Astro Malaysia, has died at 86 due to lung disease. His business empire, worth billions, is expected to have minimal impact on operations due to professional management. Succession questions remain, with his three children potentially inheriting the business, but their involvement is unclear. Ananda's son has renounced wealth, and his daughters' interest in the business is unknown. The tycoon's companies continue to operate as usual, with independent directors overseeing governance and Khazanah Nasional remaining a major shareholder.

images.alt_text: Krishnan is also known for his philanthropic efforts, having established the Yu Cai Foundation to support education among ethnic Chinese communities in Malaysia.
Daim Zainuddin served as Malaysia's finance minister from 1984 to 1991 and from 1999 to 2001 under former premier Mahathir Mohamad.

site_title: South Korean ruling party says ‘dangerous’ president must go
summary: South Korea's ruling party is calling for President Yoon Suk Yeol's removal from office after his brief attempt to impose martial law, citing a "significant risk" of further subversion of civilian rule. The motion to impeach Yoon, which needs a two-thirds majority, is set to be voted on Saturday. The opposition has accused Yoon of ordering the arrest of key politicians and failing to act against military officials who intervened in the attempted martial law declaration. A fresh opinion poll shows Yoon's approval rating at a record low of 13%.

images.alt_text: South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol, who briefly declared martial law on Dec 3, 2024, has served a term plagued with problems and scandals following his narrow electoral win in 2022.
Market sentiment has been helped by the fact that martial law lasted only around six hours, and was quickly followed by central bank moves to restore calm.

A woman holds a sign that reads "Yoon Suk Yeol should step down" during a candlelight vigil against South Korea President Yoon in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024. South Korea's opposition moved to impeach Yoon after his extraordinary but short-lived imposition of martial law that brought thousands of protesters to the streets.
The won has been among the biggest victims from the row that swept the nation and raised concerns about South Korea’s credit worthiness.

South Korean Defence Minister Kim Yong Hyun has been reported as having advised PM Yoon Suk Yeol to declare martial law on Tuesday, which was lifted after parliament’s vote demanding Yoon to reverse it.
People attend a candlelight vigil condemning South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's surprise declaration of martial law last night, which was reversed hours later, and to call for his resignation.
South Korea’s opposition lawmakers have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon.
Protestors calling for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 4 after he imposted martial law.
Prime Minister Han Duck-soo (above) will step in to perform presidential duties if the President Yoon quits or is removed from office.
South Korean lawmakers submit an impeachment motion against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol at the National Assembly in Seoul. The vote could come as soon as Friday.

site_title: Singapore shares track regional declines on Friday; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,796.16, mirroring regional declines despite Chinese stocks gaining. Top gainer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while Singtel was the biggest decliner. Asian equities tracked US shares' decline ahead of jobs data influencing the Federal Reserve's policy path.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 197.

site_title: Japan eyes talks with Trump that include cutting auto tariffs
summary: Japan's Foreign Minister Takeshi Iwaya announced plans to resume trade talks with US President-elect Donald Trump, focusing on eliminating tariffs on cars and auto parts, a key issue from a 2019 trade deal. The talks aim to build on the existing agreement, which granted US farmers access to Japan's market while Tokyo avoided tariffs on its auto exports. The negotiations will be based on the assumption that tariffs will be eliminated, according to the 2019 agreement.

images.alt_text: Growth in nominal wages for all workers accelerated to 2.6 per cent from 2.5 per cent the previous month, matching estimates.
Firms were optimistic about their business outlook with the index of the future activity rising to the highest since July.
Stronger signs for the domestic economy and persistent inflation are fuelling speculation that the BOJ may raise its benchmark interest rate as soon as Dec 19.
The final au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped to 49.0 in November, the lowest level since March, from 49.2 in October.

site_title: Amazon successfully tests using delivery drones in Italy
summary: Amazon successfully tested delivery drones in Italy on December 4, 2024, marking the first European country where the e-commerce giant plans to introduce the service. The test was conducted in San Salvo, Abruzzo region, and used the MK-30 drone, a highly automated system with Amazon's computer vision program. The test aimed to ensure the safety of people, animals, and property, and to keep drones separate from other aircraft. Amazon plans to meet all requirements and launch the service in Italy next year, following successful operations in the US.

images.alt_text: AWS chief executive Matt Garman (left) and Keppel chief executive Loh Chin Hua at the ceremonial signing event in Las Vegas, US.
The announcements mark Amazon’s biggest step towards combating a reputation that it had been caught flat-footed in developing AI applications as competitors sped ahead.
AWS is expected to announce this week at its re:Invent conference that those chips are now available to customers.
Amazon says it injected S$2 billion into its Singapore businesses in 2023

site_title: UOB brings festive cheer to community with pop-up event, carolling sessions
summary: UOB organized a charity Christmas pop-up event in Raffles Place, featuring booths by charities and social enterprises to raise funds and awareness for various causes. The event included carolling sessions, art workshops, and gift-giving programs, with proceeds going directly to supported charities. One charity, New Life Stories, aims to improve the quality of life for children of imprisoned parents through education and counseling services. The event also marked the 7th year of UOB's partnership with New Life Stories, which includes a gift-giving program and volunteer excursions.

images.alt_text: SCM showcases vendors selling sustainable products.

Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry, as well as Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth, visits Market for Good's booth. The event aims to raise funds for underprivileged children from Singapore Red Cross' Young Hearts programme.

site_title: Asia: Most markets down as traders assess crises in South Korea, France
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, with Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Wellington, Manila, and Taipei stocks falling, except for Hong Kong and Shanghai, which rose. The decline comes amid a volatile week, with South Korea's stock market still under pressure due to the president's impeachment, and traders awaiting US jobs data and potential trade tensions with China.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 finished 0.4 per cent higher on Thursday, logging its sixth-straight session of advances.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6 per cent to 44,765.71, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2 per cent to 19,800.26 on Thursday.
Asian equities track a decline in US shares ahead of jobs data that may help shape the direction of the Federal Reserve’s policy path later this month.

site_title: Wall Street banks predict biggest China rate cuts in a decade
summary: Wall Street banks predict China's central bank will deliver the largest interest-rate cuts in a decade next year, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley forecasting 40 basis points of cuts to the PBOC main policy rate in 2025. This would be the largest reduction in a calendar year since 2015, aimed at boosting growth and arresting deflation. The PBOC has reason to be wary, as lower rates could compress banks' net interest margins, but policymakers are willing to take decisive steps to counter the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Monetary policy support will be critical to China’s economy next year as the US president-elect has vowed to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods.

Expectations remain high that an ailing economy will prompt the PBOC to step up monetary easing, including cutting the RRR further and injecting more cash into markets, after it delivered a stimulus blitz in late September.
The central bank also bought a net 200 billion yuan of sovereign bonds from dealers in November to ensure plentiful cash supply.
China has also been revamping its policy rate framework as it seeks to influence market borrowing costs more effectively.

site_title: EU chief in last-gasp push to close South America trade deal
summary: European Union President Ursula von der Leyen said a free-trade deal with South America's Mercosur bloc is "in sight" but her hopes of sealing it appear slim due to last-minute resistance. Despite a large majority of EU member states supporting the deal, Italy and Poland are opposed, and France is close to blocking it with a minority of four countries representing 35% of the EU population. The deal would create the world's biggest free trade zone, allowing for easier exports of goods like cars and machinery to South America.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Michel Barnier will be the shortest-serving prime minister in modern French history after he hands in his resignation.
Business investment is forecast to grow by just 0.9 per cent next year, compared to a previous forecast of 1.4 per cent growth.
Doing business in China had become tougher for five consecutive years and only 41 per cent of the lobby group's members were expecting to have a better time next year, the survey said.
British PM Keir Starmer stressed in his speech that Britain would “never turn away from” its special relationship with the United States, pledging “even closer ties with the US”.

site_title: RHB says Suntec Reit unitholders should reject S$1.16-per-unit offer, sees positives for the Reit
summary: RHB recommends Suntec Reit unitholders to reject a mandatory conditional cash offer of S$1.16 per unit, citing a 44% discount to the Reit's net asset value. The offeror, Aelios, aims to maintain the Reit's listing status on the Singapore Exchange. RHB believes the offer undervalues the Reit and sees potential for future rate cuts benefiting the Reit, maintaining its "buy" call and target price.

images.alt_text: The offeror intends to maintain the listing status of Suntec Reit on the Singapore Exchange, following the completion of the offer.
The fall in DPU was attributed to the completion of a S$5.8 million capital distribution which concluded in end-2023.
XX

site_title: ECB seeks to speed up approvals for significant risk transfers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is accelerating its approval process for significant risk transfers (SRTs) to help banks capitalize on booming demand for the deals. Under new proposals, banks can submit information for SRT transactions just two weeks ahead of deal completion, compared to the current three-month requirement. A pilot of the simplified process will start in January and run for six months, with the ECB aiming to ask banks for fewer details about proposed transactions. This move aims to reduce regulatory hurdles and capitalize on the growing demand for SRTs.

images.alt_text: ECB stated that the use of US dollar repos by eurozone banks has almost doubled in the past two years to 1.6 trillion euros (S$2.3 trillion).
Eurozone third-quarter negotiated pay rose 5.4 per cent from a year ago.

Last month, the ECB cut interest rates for the third time this year and four sources close to the decision told Reuters a fourth cut was likely in December unless data turned around in the coming weeks.

ECB vice-president Luis de Guindos stated that if a significant jurisdiction like the US were to impose tariffs of 60 per cent on another major jurisdiction, such as China, the direct effects, indirect effects, and shifts in commerce would be substantial.

site_title: Government maintains private housing land supply on H1 2025 confirmed list
summary: The Singapore government has confirmed 10 private housing land sites for the first half of 2025, yielding approximately 5,030 units, including 980 executive condominium (EC) units. Despite strong sales at recent launches, the government maintains land supply to cater to demand. The confirmed list includes sites near MRT stations, while the reserve list offers land for 3,475 private homes. Analysts expect developers to exercise caution due to concerns over new cooling measures and elevated development risks. The government's strategy to offer EC units may backfire if resale and ownership restrictions are not adjusted.

images.alt_text: PHOTO: URA
For the full year, the total supply of 11,110 private housing units will be the highest since 2013.

The method of distributing sales proceeds is often a contentious issue, particularly for mixed-use developments where expectations on the acceptable range of en-bloc premiums and what constitutes a ‘fair and equitable’ method of apportionment may differ.
The confirmed sites at Holland Link and Chuan Grove can potentially yield 785 units.
Together, the three sites potentially yield 1,340 private residential units.

site_title: Trump’s China tariff plan has US$64 billion import hole
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's planned 10% tariffs on Chinese imports may be difficult to fully implement due to a significant "import hole" of $64 billion. This gap is attributed to loopholes and underreporting of imports, including the "de minimis" tariff loophole, which allows small packages valued under $800 to evade tariffs. The US underreported imports from China by 20-25% in 2023, with an estimated $160 billion in uncounted imports. This distortion in trade data may hinder effective trade and supply chain policies, and may also lead to a rise in Chinese goods entering the US via other manufacturing hubs.

images.alt_text: The president-elect has threatened to impose 60 per cent tariffs on all Chinese imports, which would likely spur retaliatory action from Beijing.
Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.
Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that, as an overall principle, gallium, germanium, antimony, and superhard materials are no longer allowed to be exported to America.
The new duties announced on Nov 29 by the Commerce Department extend the US’ anti-dumping regime in South-east Asia to solar cells, from just finished modules previously.
Wired reported earlier that the US could come out with new export controls rules as soon as next Monday.

site_title: Japan base pay gains by record, keeps door open for Bank of Japan hike
summary: Japan's base pay for full-time workers rose by a record 2.8% in October, the biggest gain since 1994. This increase, along with a 2.6% growth in nominal wages for all workers, suggests a positive economic cycle and supports speculation of a near-term rate hike by the central bank. Real cash earnings remained unchanged, avoiding a decline for the first time in three months. The labor ministry's data indicates progress towards a positive economic cycle, fueling market expectations of a Bank of Japan interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Toyoaki Nakamura, who is among the most dovish members of the board, said there was a chance inflation may miss the BOJ’s 2 per cent target from fiscal 2025 onward.
Firms were optimistic about their business outlook with the index of the future activity rising to the highest since July.
Stronger signs for the domestic economy and persistent inflation are fuelling speculation that the BOJ may raise its benchmark interest rate as soon as Dec 19.
The final au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped to 49.0 in November, the lowest level since March, from 49.2 in October.

site_title: Even BlackRock is fleeing public markets
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is shifting its focus to private investments as it seeks to stay relevant in a market where investors are increasingly drawn to alternative bets. The firm's recent acquisitions, including private credit specialist HPS Investment Partners and data provider Preqin, reflect a desire to tap into the growing demand for alternative assets among retail investors and financial advisers. With the number of listed companies declining and unicorns emerging, BlackRock's move aims to capitalize on the trend towards private investments and alternative financing channels.

images.alt_text: The evolution of finance continues to favour the biggest Wall Street banks, such as JPMorgan Chase or Goldman Sachs Group, that can spend the most on tech and have tight relationships with the biggest private-market asset managers.
BlackRock is looking to expand from public stocks and bonds into private markets as demand for the asset class surges.
Blackrock Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, Suntec Reit, Digital Core Reit, SingPost
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a 10-year sale-and-purchase agreement with Chevron for 0.6 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas annually, starting 2028. Suntec Reit's property tycoon Gordon Tang made a mandatory cash offer to acquire all units at S$1.16 per unit. Digital Core Reit completed a €100.6 million acquisition of a 15.1% stake in a Frankfurt data centre. Singapore Post was placed on CreditWatch negative due to the sale of its Australian business and changed strategy.

site_title: South Korea’s ruling party leader says president ordered arrest of prominent politicians during martial law
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol has ordered the arrest of prominent politicians, labeling them as "anti-state forces," according to ruling party leader Han Dong Hoon. This comes after Yoon declared martial law on December 3, 2024, amid a term plagued by scandals and problems following his narrow 2022 electoral win. The arrests were allegedly instructed by Yoon, with intelligence agencies mobilized to carry out the actions, according to Han's televised remarks.

site_title: GuocoLand to redeem S$400 million perpetual securities
summary: GuocoLand's wholly owned subsidiary, GLL IHT, will redeem S$400 million subordinated perpetual securities on January 23, 2025. The securities will be redeemed at S$250,000 per S$250,000 nominal amount, plus accrued distribution up to the redemption date. The perpetual securities were issued under GuocoLand's S$3 billion multicurrency medium-term note programme with a 4.6% coupon.

site_title: Intel names two chip industry veterans to its board amid CEO search
summary: Intel has named two chip industry veterans, Eric Meurice and Steve Sanghi, to its board amid its search for a new CEO. Meurice, former CEO of ASML, and Sanghi, interim CEO of Microchip Technology, both have prior experience at Intel. The move comes as the company tries to reclaim its lost glory after Pat Gelsinger's ouster. Intel is seeking a CEO with manufacturing expertise and experience in the product side of the business, with a focus on addressing its struggles with advanced chipmaking and contract manufacturing.

images.alt_text: The move to replace CEO Pat Gelsinger – who took charge of Intel less than four years ago – came after the board decided that the pace of his costly plan to turn around Intel’s fortunes was not quick enough.
Pat Gelsinger, Intel's CEO since 2021, is stepping down after the company's turnaround efforts faltered, leaving it trailing competitors.
FILE PHOTO: A smartphone with a displayed Intel logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken March 6, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Intel’s depressed stock price has spurred takeover interest.

site_title: Beatles legend McCartney stars in new UK coin collection
summary: Paul McCartney, the 82-year-old Beatles songwriter, is featured on a new UK £5 coin collection. The coin's design, created with McCartney's input, features his band Wings' logo, a bass guitar, and music notes from his songs. The collection, available on the Royal Mint's website, starts at £15.50. McCartney expressed his "huge honour" at being part of the collection, which aims to recognize British history's greatest icons. The coins will not enter circulation, with a gold 5-kilogram coin signed by McCartney to be auctioned next year.

images.alt_text: Bought from a music store in the band’s birth city of Liverpool, Harrison played the Futurama guitar in the early 1960s when the band performed at the Cavern Club, toured Germany and made their first official records for Polydor.
FILE PHOTO: Musician Paul McCartney attends the British premiere of ''If These Walls Could Sing" in London, Britain December 12, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Lilly to boost obesity drug supply with US$3 billion expansion
summary: Eli Lilly is investing $3 billion to expand its US manufacturing footprint, primarily to meet the high demand for its diabetes and weight-loss drugs, Zepbound and Mounjaro. The new plant in Wisconsin will create 750 high-skilled jobs and 2,000 construction jobs, bringing the company's total investment in the state to $4 billion. The expansion aims to establish reliable supplies of the in-demand medications and comes as pharmaceutical companies seek to bring operations back to the US to fortify supply chains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Eli Lilly logo is shown on one of the company's offices in San Diego, California, U.S., September 17, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Eli Lilly logo is shown on one of the company's offices in San Diego, California, U.S., September 17, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo
Patients who were on weekly injections showed a 94 per cent reduction in the risk of progression to type 2 diabetes, compared with placebo.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall to lowest since October, hitting 6.69%
summary: US mortgage rates fell to 6.69% for a second consecutive week, the lowest since October 24. Borrowing costs remain higher than September levels, with a possible reduction in rates unlikely in 2025. Despite this, purchase demand has improved, and the supply of homes for sale is approaching pre-pandemic levels, but buyers are still facing affordability challenges due to high prices and mortgage rates. Experts predict the US Federal Reserve will reduce policy rates only twice next year if the economy stays strong.

site_title: Time in technicolour
summary: Two luxury watch brands, Grand Seiko and IWC, have unveiled limited-edition timepieces that blend traditional Japanese elegance with modern twists. Grand Seiko's SBGJ285 features a stunning purple dial inspired by the wisteria flower, while IWC's Ingenieur Automatic 40 boasts a blue dial with a unique grid pattern. Meanwhile, Zenith's Defy Extreme Jungle chronograph is the final installment of its series, inspired by the untamed allure of the jungle and featuring a water-resistant 45mm case.

images.alt_text: Kaws’ iconic character, Companion, playfully peers out from beneath the sapphire crystal.

site_title: New York museum unveils ‘Apex’ – an almost complete Stegosaurus
summary: The American Museum of Natural History unveiled "Apex", a nearly complete Stegosaurus fossil, on December 5. The 3.4-metre tall, six-metre long skeleton is one of the most complete specimens ever discovered of the plant-eating dinosaur. Found in Colorado, the fossil sold for a record US$44.6 million at a Sotheby's auction in July and has been loaned to the New York museum. Stegosaurus, known for its upright plates and spiky tail, lived in North America during the Jurassic Period, around 150 million years ago.

images.alt_text: epa11650512 A woman looks at the works 'The Pier of Boulogne-sur-Mer' and 'Sailboats and Seagulls', by Edouard Manet, and 'Fishing Boats and The Nets of Pourville', by Claude Monet, from the new exhibition Vive l'impressionnisme! at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, 09 October 2024. The exhibition showcases the finest French Impressionist works from Dutch collections.  EPA-EFE/ROBIN VAN LONKHUIJSEN
The Heritage Collection in the Qatar National Library includes more than 235,000 centuries-old manuscripts, books, maps, globes and other materials.
British Museum's “Silk Roads” exhibition  opens on Thursday (Sep 26) and runs until February.

site_title: Don’t let RFK Jr distract from the big health threat: Sugar
summary: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has targeted Froot Loops as an example of the US food regulation system's failings, citing artificial food dyes. However, experts argue that the dyes used in US food are considered safe. The real health threat, according to experts, is the excessive sugar consumption in the US, with the average American consuming over 30 kilograms of sugar per year. This can lead to metabolic derangement and Type-2 diabetes. While some countries have successfully reduced sugar consumption through taxation and warning labels, Kennedy's focus on artificial dyes distracts from the more pressing issue of sugar.

images.alt_text: Robert F Kennedy Jr campaigns against childhood vaccine mandates at a rally in Albany, New York, May 14, 2019.
Diabetes is a treatable condition, but many are unaware they have the disease.
In recent years, dozens of studies have found that people who eat lots of ultra-processed foods have a higher risk of heart disease, cancer, asthma, depression and other illnesses.

site_title: Horizon Terminals Limited Commemorates the Completion of Horizon JPUT Pipeline Connectivity Project in Singapore
summary: Horizon Terminals Limited (HTL) has completed the Horizon JPUT Pipeline Connectivity Project in Singapore, enhancing operational efficiency and reducing transfer times between two terminals. The new 24-inch pipeline for Fuel Oil and 20-inch pipeline for Clean Petroleum Products mitigates operational risks and offers substantial cost savings to customers. The project, built on Jurong Island, marks a significant milestone in HTL's international expansion and Singapore's oil and petroleum infrastructure development, solidifying a strong partnership between Horizon Singapore Terminals and Jurong Port Universal Terminal.

site_title: Citigroup promotes 344 executives to managing directors
summary: Citigroup has promoted 344 executives to managing directors, the highest cohort in the firm's history, following a reorganisation to simplify the bank and eliminate management layers. The move aims to reduce around 20,000 positions worldwide by 2026. The promotions are seen as crucial in ensuring compliance with 2020 Federal Reserve and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency consent orders. The reorganisation and promotions are part of Citi's ongoing efforts to transform the bank.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Citibank is seen on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., August 3, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia bucks global easing cycle with experiment on steady rates
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has bucked the global trend of interest rate cuts by maintaining its steady rates at a 13-year high of 4.35% since late 2023. Despite weak GDP data and stubborn core inflation, economists expect rates to remain unchanged until at least February, with money markets predicting no rate cut before April. The RBA's approach, which prioritizes maintaining employment gains, differs from peers, and its effectiveness is still being debated, particularly with a federal election looming in May.

images.alt_text: Inflation has only come down slowly and at an underlying level remains above the central bank’s 2 to 3 per cent target.
The RBA has kept interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent for an entire year now.
The RBA has kept policy on hold since last November, with its benchmark rate at a 13-year high of 4.35 per cent.

site_title: US trade deficit narrows from a more than two-year high
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to $73.8 billion in October, a 12% decrease from the prior month, as imports of consumer and capital goods fell. Exports declined 1.6% and the value of inbound shipments of industrial supplies, motor vehicles, and foods also dropped. The trade deficit, not adjusted for inflation, narrowed to $92.4 billion. Despite this, the risk of a widening trade deficit remains if companies accelerate imports ahead of potential tariffs.

images.alt_text: Claims are at levels consistent with steady job growth, and have signalled a sharp rebound in nonfarm payrolls in November after the labour market was severely distorted by Hurricanes Helene and Milton as well as strikes by factory workers at Boeing and another aerospace company.

The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said on Wednesday (Dec 4) that its nonmanufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) slipped to 52.1 last month after surging to 56 in October, which was the highest level since August 2022.

TYSONS, VA - AUGUST 22: A hiring sign is posted in front of a display at Talbots at the Tysons Corner Center mall on August 22, 2024 in Alexandria, Virginia. According to reports, over 800,000 fewer jobs were created within the U.S. economy than originally reported in the 12-month period, 30% less than the previously reported 2.9 million from April 2023 through March, 2024.   Anna Rose Layden/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Anna Rose Layden / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
“In order to keep the economy in a good place, we have to continue to recalibrate policy,” San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly said during an interview with Fox Business.
Job openings, a measure of labour demand, had risen 372,000 to 7.744 million by the last day of October.
The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said on Monday (Dec 2) its manufacturing PMI increased to 48.4 last month from 46.5 in October, which was the lowest level since July 2023.

site_title: Lululemon raises annual forecasts betting on robust holiday sales
summary: Lululemon Athletica raised its annual forecast, expecting fiscal year 2024 revenue between $10.45 billion and $10.49 billion, driven by robust holiday sales in the US and continued strength in its international business, particularly in China where revenue rose 36% in the third quarter. The company's shares rose 8% and it approved a $1 billion increase to its stock repurchase program.

images.alt_text: Sam’s has customers hooked with products ranging from fresh produce to baked foods and beverages to household supplies.
A Lululemon store in New York. Shopper preferences are moving towards styles that are looser than the leggings the company is known for.
Lululemon is expected to report results for its second quarter in late August.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat from records ahead of employment data
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on Thursday ahead of the release of key employment data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipping 0.2%. The S&P 500 dipped 0.2% to end a streak of four straight record closes. Investors are cautious ahead of the November employment data, which may influence interest rate decisions from the Federal Reserve. Despite this, some stocks rose, including American Airlines, which surged 16.8% after announcing a deal with Citi.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 24.4 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 45038.44.

site_title: UK employers cut growth forecasts as tax hikes weigh on economy
summary: The UK economy is projected to grow at 1.6% in 2025, down from a previous forecast of 1.9%, according to the Confederation of British Industry. The growth outlook for this year is trimmed to 0.9% due to tax hikes and increased social security contributions for employers. The Bank of England has also warned that over half of companies plan to raise prices and cut jobs in response to the budget. Despite this, the British Chambers of Commerce revised up its forecast for 2025 to 1.3% and the OECD raised its forecasts to 1.7%.

images.alt_text: British PM Keir Starmer said: “(This) is my plan for change. The driving purpose of this government and we will stay the course. We will fix the foundations, repair the damage, reform government.”
Business investment is forecast to grow by just 0.9 per cent next year, compared to a previous forecast of 1.4 per cent growth.

FILE PHOTO: Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, gestures as he addresses the media during a press conference at the Bank of England in London, Britain, August 1, 2024. Alberto Pezzali/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Lloyd’s Singapore hub to write over US$1 billion in premiums in 2024
summary: Lloyd's of London's Singapore hub expects to write over $1 billion in premiums in 2024, driven by growing wealth levels and increasing awareness of insurance needs in the Asia-Pacific region. The hub's parent, Lloyd's Asia, reported a gross premium of $897 million in 2022, with 17% from Australia/New Zealand and 13% from Singapore. Cybercover is the fastest-growing business, with a 25% market share, and Lloyd's is addressing systemic risks such as cyber, pandemic, and climate risks through innovation and research. The company's interim results show a 26% jump in pre-tax profits to $4.9 billion.

images.alt_text: Lloyd’s also said it proposed a new category of misconduct aimed at those who mistreat witnesses and whistleblowers. Other categories of misconduct include dishonesty and bullying and harassment.
Lloyd's of London chairman Bruce Carnegie-Brown said Insurance prices are starting to flatten.

FILE PHOTO: The interior of the Lloyd's of London building is seen in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, April 16, 2019. Picture taken April 16, 2019. REUTERS/Hannah McKay//File Photo

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish at one-month high, French politics in focus
summary: European stocks closed at a one-month high, with the Stoxx 600 rising 0.4% and the CAC 40 up 0.3%. The gains were driven by bank stocks, which advanced 3.2% as investors sought a new French budget. French lenders BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, and Credit Agricole rose between 2.3% and 4.3%. The uncertainty surrounding French Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government and President Emmanuel Macron's leadership led to a decrease in volatility.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6 per cent to 44,765.71, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.2 per cent to 19,800.26 on Thursday.

site_title: OpenAI adds US$200 monthly ChatGPT Pro subscription with new model
summary: OpenAI introduces a new paid tier, ChatGPT Pro, offering unlimited access to its AI models, including an improved reasoning model, for $200/month. The upgraded o1 model is faster and better at solving complex math and code problems. This move aims to offset the costs of building cutting-edge AI models and follows a similar strategy by other AI companies, such as Google. The new tier is part of a 12-day livestreamed product event, highlighting OpenAI's efforts to improve its AI systems and compete in the industry.

site_title: Killer of UnitedHealth’s Thompson still at large amid manhunt in New York
summary: A New York City Police Department (NYPD) manhunt is ongoing for a suspect believed to have gunned down UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson in Midtown Manhattan. Thompson, 50, was shot from behind early Wednesday morning, and authorities have released new photos of the suspect's face, which show a man wearing a hooded sweatshirt and a gray backpack. The motive behind the attack is still unknown, but investigators believe Thompson was deliberately targeted. The NYPD has searched a hostel on Manhattan's Upper West Side where the suspect is believed to have been staying and has requested the public's help in locating him.

images.alt_text: Aviva has made a fresh bid of about 261 pence per share as it seeks to convince Direct Line’s board to engage.
Bruce Carnegie-Brown, chairman of Lloyd's of London, says cybercover is its fastest-growing business, where it has a 25% market share.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens muted with jobs data in focus
summary: US stocks opened subdued on December 5, following record high closes in the previous session, as investors await upcoming employment data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 24.4 points, or 0.05%, to 45,038.44. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 2.5 and 21.3 points, respectively. The muted opening follows a week of record highs and amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Chevron slows Permian growth in latest hurdle to Trump oil plan
summary: Chevron, a major US oil explorer, plans to slow production growth in the Permian Basin, a key US oil field, in 2025, reducing capital expenditures by 10% to $4.5-5 billion. This move is seen as a sign that President-elect Donald Trump's plan to increase American energy output faces an uphill battle. Chevron's decision to prioritize free cash flow over production growth is also a reality check for Trump's "Drill, Baby, Drill" energy policy, which aims to cut energy prices in half.

images.alt_text: Chevron recently opened up a US$1 billion innovation hub in Bengaluru, India, which is hiring workers for engineering and digital services.
Chevron said it earned US$2.51 per share for third quarter, compared to analysts’ estimates of US$2.42.
Chevron is also acquiring Hess for US$53 billion, a deal that would boost its presence in South America.
Chevron’s announcement of the Hess deal followed ExxonMobil’s US$60 billion purchase of US shale giant Pioneer Natural Resources, which closed in May.
Chevron joins a long list of California emigres that includes Oracle, Hewlett Packard Enterprise and Tesla.

site_title: Sheffield United is latest football club to get US takeover
summary: A US-based consortium, COH Sports, has agreed to buy Sheffield United, currently leading the EFL Championship, in a deal valued by the English Football League as "full clearance". The takeover, led by Resilience Capital Partners co-founder Steven H Rosen and Guardant Health chairman Helmy Eltoukhy, is the latest US investment in an English club outside the Premier League. The deal's completion will allow the team to buy new players in the January transfer window, potentially boosting revenue and ending the club's relegation from the top league last season.

images.alt_text: The Diamond Club comes with heated seats and blankets to help fans cope with the English winter.

site_title: US judge rejects Boeing 737 MAX accord over diversity policies
summary: A US judge, Reed O'Connor, rejected a deferred prosecution agreement between Boeing and the Justice Department over the 737 MAX crashes, citing concerns over diversity policies at the Justice Department. The agreement, which would have seen Boeing comply with certain conditions, was blocked due to the judge's skepticism over the department's ability to select a monitor without racial considerations. The ruling also criticized the department's process for restricting court oversight, calling it "marginalising" to the court. The decision blocks Boeing's guilty plea and paves the way for a potential new prosecution.

images.alt_text: The airline aims to emerge from its debt-restructuring plan in 2025, five years after it filed for bankruptcy protection.
The key drivers pushing up airfares include rising wages and staffing shortages.
Many airlines are refurbishing their cabins as they aim to extend the life of their long-haul aircraft.
Boeing in February published a bulletin to inform flight crews of potential flight deck and cabin effects associated with severe engine damage.
Negotiations at Alaska are being closely watched because one airline’s contract tends to become an industry benchmark.

site_title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Eras Tour Book’ sold 814,000 copies in one week
summary: Taylor Swift's 'Eras Tour Book' sold 814,000 copies in its first week, surpassing Barack Obama's 'A Promised Land' and ranking as the second-highest adult nonfiction release in history. The 256-page hardcover, costing $39.99, was self-published by Swift through Taylor Swift Publications and exclusively released through Target, bypassing bookstores and Amazon. Some fans expressed disappointment over grammatical errors and unedited content, but the book's huge opening week is a testament to Swift's massive fan base and her unconventional retail strategy.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift merchandise on display at a Target store in New Jersey, U.S, November 29, 2024. REUTERS/Siddharth Cavale/File Photo
Taylor Swift is nominated in seven categories following the release this year of her 11th album The Tortured Poets Department.

site_title: China's Xi urges military to 'combat corruption'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the military to "combat corruption" to ensure absolute loyalty, purity, and reliability. This comes as Beijing reinforces its clampdown on graft in the armed forces, following recent efforts to remove high-ranking officials. Xi emphasized the military's focus on winning wars and enforcing discipline, amid simmering tensions in the region, including the Taiwan Strait and the South China Sea. The move is seen as part of Xi's broader campaign against official corruption.

images.alt_text: A former navy commander, Dong Jun (pictured) was appointed defence minister in December last year following the surprise removal of Li Shangfu just seven months into the job.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise moderately
summary: US initial jobless claims rose 9,000 to 224,000 for the week ended Nov 30, signaling steady job growth. This level is consistent with a sharp rebound in nonfarm payrolls in November, following distortions from Hurricanes Helene and Milton and strikes by factory workers. The data suggests the labor market remains strong, with historically low layoffs and a subdued hiring activity. The Fed is expected to cut interest rates this month, and economists warn of uncertain rate outlook for 2025 due to potential tariffs and tax cuts.

images.alt_text: The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said on Wednesday (Dec 4) that its nonmanufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) slipped to 52.1 last month after surging to 56 in October, which was the highest level since August 2022.

TYSONS, VA - AUGUST 22: A hiring sign is posted in front of a display at Talbots at the Tysons Corner Center mall on August 22, 2024 in Alexandria, Virginia. According to reports, over 800,000 fewer jobs were created within the U.S. economy than originally reported in the 12-month period, 30% less than the previously reported 2.9 million from April 2023 through March, 2024.   Anna Rose Layden/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Anna Rose Layden / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Rail: Enabling S-E Asia’s breakneck growth sustainably
summary: South-east Asia's rapid urbanization and population growth pose significant challenges, including road congestion, air pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. Rail transport is the most efficient and least pollutive mode of moving people and goods at scale, with the potential to unlock economic growth and minimize environmental costs. Investing in rail now can empower the region to pursue sustainable development, making cities liveable and economies resilient for generations to come. The International Energy Agency projects that rail must grow by over 40% by 2030 to achieve net zero in the transport sector by 2050, requiring substantial investments and effective policy frameworks.

images.alt_text: Eco-design promises sustainable future for railway industry
Alstom makes a sustained push for green solutions in the rail business

site_title: More HSBC senior managers to go as CEO continues overhaul
summary: HSBC has completed the first phase of a sweeping overhaul aimed at streamlining costs and improving decision-making. Senior managers, including global private banking head Annabel Spring and former Morgan Stanley and Barclays investment banker Matthew Ginsburg, have departed or left the bank. CEO Georges Elhedery has promoted Lisa McGeough to become president and CEO for the US, the bank's first female CEO in the region in over a decade. The overhaul, part of a plan to merge operations and split the bank's geographic footprint, is expected to create a simpler and more dynamic organization.

images.alt_text: The leadership transition coincides with HSBC navigating global macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Malaysia's jailed ex-PM Najib renews bid to serve sentence at home
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak has renewed his bid to serve the remainder of his prison sentence at home, citing an "addendum order" allegedly issued by the country's former king alongside a pardons board decision to halve his sentence from 12 years to six. Najib's lawyer claims the document confirms instructions for him to serve his sentence under house arrest, but its existence and contents remain unclear. The Court of Appeal has postponed proceedings to allow prosecutors time to review new evidence, which Najib's lawyer says will prove conclusively the document's existence.

images.alt_text: The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.

site_title: Sembcorp unit signs 10-year LNG supply deal with Chevron
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned subsidiary, Sembcorp Fuels, has signed a 10-year sale-and-purchase agreement with Chevron for approximately 0.6 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas per year, starting in 2028. This deal is expected to strengthen Sembcorp's existing natural gas supply portfolio and support Singapore's energy needs.

site_title: Oil falls as investors weigh ample 2025 supply outlook, delayed Opec+ output hike
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as investors weighed an ample supply outlook for 2025 against Opec+ delaying its planned output increase by three months to April 2025. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) settled 0.3% and 0.35% lower, respectively, at US$72.09 and US$68.30 per barrel. Analysts point to an oversupply of oil in 2025, offsetting support from the delayed Opec+ decision, which will gradually unwind 2.2 million barrels per day of cuts over 18 months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An OPEC flag is seen on the day of OPEC+ meeting in Vienna  in Vienna, Austria October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Leutner//File Photo
Sembcorp said its 10-year sale and purchase agreement with Chevron will strengthen its existing natural gas supply portfolio.

FILE PHOTO: The logo of Equinor is set up at the entrance of a building at Western Europe's largest liquefied natural gas plant Hammerfest LNG in Hammerfest, Norway, March 14, 2024. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner/File Photo
Brent crude futures fell US$1.31, or 1.78 per cent, to settle at US$72.31 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Adnoc signs 15-year LNG supply deal with Malaysia’s Petronas
summary: Adnoc, Abu Dhabi's state-owned oil company, has signed a 15-year liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply deal with Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned energy company. The agreement, worth one million tonnes per year, converts a preliminary deal to a definitive sales agreement and marks Adnoc's efforts to become a major LNG supplier. The deal will primarily supply fuel from Adnoc's Ruwais LNG export facility, which is currently under construction. The agreement follows a similar accord with Germany's SEFE and is part of the UAE's push to increase its gas production to support cleaner energy transition.

site_title: Muhammad most popular boys' baby name in Britain in 2023
summary: Muhammad was the most popular boys' baby name in Britain in 2023, surpassing Noah to take the top spot. This marks the first time Muhammad has held the top position, after being among the top 10 names since 2016. Muhammad had been in second place in 2022, according to the Office for National Statistics. Oliver replaced George as the third most popular name.

site_title: Memories of Mongolia
summary: A travel writer's two-week adventure in Mongolia explores the country's rugged landscape, nomadic culture, and history. The writer visits the Gobi Desert, where they stay in traditional gers, learn about the local nomads' way of life, and witness the majestic Flaming Cliffs where the first dinosaur eggs were discovered. They also visit Hustai National Park, home to Przewalski's horses, and Lake Khovsgol, a breathtaking freshwater lake. The writer discovers that Mongolian nomads live in gers, powered by solar panels, and experience the country's unique blend of modernity and tradition.

images.alt_text: The famed Christmas market at Old Town Square has a sparkling centrepiece.
luxetravelpacific5 - pacific - Seven Seas Explorer in Alaska - credit RSSC

site_title: Aviva set to buy Direct Line to create £16.7 billion British insurer
summary: Aviva has agreed to buy Direct Line in a £3.6 billion (S$6.2 billion) cash-and-stock deal, creating the UK's largest home and motor insurer with a combined market value of nearly £16.7 billion. The deal will be led by Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc, who aims to expand in core markets and less capital-intensive businesses like motor and home insurance. Direct Line shareholders will receive 129.7 pence in cash and 0.2867 new Aviva shares per share, with the combined company expected to have a significant share in both home and motor insurance in the UK.

images.alt_text: Logo for Aviva plc, a British insurer.
Aviva had a combined operating ratio in the first nine months of 96.8 per cent, compared with 96.3 per cent a year earlier.

site_title: Elevate Capital’s Ashish Manchharam sees opportunities in living sector, lifestyle spaces
summary: Elevate Capital's managing partner Ashish Manchharam is focusing on repositioning and refurbishing properties in Singapore to capitalize on the demand for flexible workspaces and lifestyle spaces. The firm has acquired the four-storey building in the City Hall area for S$132 million and plans to transform it into a mixed-use lifestyle destination with a co-working space, serviced apartments, and F&B outlets. Manchharam sees opportunities in areas like Little India and Boat Quay, and aims to grow the company's assets under management to S$500 million within the next 24 months.

images.alt_text: The four-storey Stamford Court has a distinctive clock tower on the building’s granite and glass facade.

site_title: Christmas with Tjin Lee: Of family, friends and Dirty Santas
summary: Tjin Lee, a 51-year-old entrepreneur and socialite, reflects on her year-end traditions, focusing on family, friends, and gratitude. Lee's childhood memories of Christmas Eve include opening one gift before bedtime and gathering with family to open more presents. As a busy mother-of-two, Lee tries to capture that childhood joy with her kids, hiding their presents and playing a game of "Dirty Santa" with friends. Lee and her husband, John Lim, will celebrate Christmas with family gatherings and quiet dinners, prioritizing relaxation and quality time with loved ones.

images.alt_text: House Ambassador Ana de Armas wears pieces from Le Damier de Louis Vuitton.

site_title: Opec+ delays revival of its oil production by three months
summary: OPEC+ has delayed the revival of its oil production by three months, pushing back the start of supply increases from January to April. This decision gives the group time to assess the impact of President-Elect Donald Trump's return to the White House. The group will now unwind cuts at a slower pace, finishing the process in September 2026, amid a looming global surplus in 2025.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures posted their biggest gains in two weeks, rising by US$1.79, or 2.5 per cent, to settle at US$73.62 a barrel on Tuesday.
Brent crude futures settled 1 cent lower at US$71.83 a barrel on Monday.
The longer Opec+ pushes for too high prices, the deeper the hole it digs for itself, unable to increase production.

site_title: Starmer pledges measurable ‘milestones’ to rebuild Britain after rocky start
summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has pledged to deliver measurable "milestones" to rebuild Britain after a rocky start. Five months into his government, Starmer aims to set targets for improved living standards and increased home building, with the goal of measuring his government's success before the next election in 2029. This plan is seen as an attempt to make his goals more concrete and understandable to voters, who are increasingly distrustful of politics.

images.alt_text: Business investment is forecast to grow by just 0.9 per cent next year, compared to a previous forecast of 1.4 per cent growth.
The Lloyds Bank Business Barometer sank by 3 points last month to 41 per cent, its lowest level since June but comfortably above the survey’s long-run average of 29 per cent.
The UK’s Office for National Statistics has been struggling to collect sufficient and accurate data on employment trends, leading to severe criticism from central bankers and politicians.
Banks and building societies approved 68,300 home loans in October, an increase from 66,100 the previous month.

Thursday’s survey showed that optimism among consumer services businesses sank to its lowest since August 2022 at -55 in November, down from -19 in August, while among business and professional services sentiment fell to -29 from +9.

TOPSHOT - Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves poses with the red Budget Box as she leaves 11 Downing Street, in central London, on October 30, 2024, to present the government's annual Autumn budget to Parliament. Britain's new Labour government unveils its first budget on Wednesday, the highly-anticipated fiscal update, the first under the centre-left government after 14 years of Conservative rule. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: France’s Macron seeks new PM after no-confidence defeat
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron sought a new prime minister after Michel Barnier's government was ousted in a historic no-confidence vote in parliament. This marks the first successful no-confidence action since 1962. Macron aims to appoint a new premier to avoid a vacuum, with more than two years of his presidential term left. The move comes amid growing opposition calls for Macron's resignation.

images.alt_text: A screen shows the result of the no-confidence vote against the French prime minister and his government at the National Assembly, Paris, France, Dec 4, 2024. The government lost the no-confidence vote after a total of 331 members of the parliament voted in favour of the motion.

site_title: Geopolitics: A critical agenda for the boardroom
summary: Singapore companies face risks and opportunities in the current geopolitical climate, particularly with rising US-China tensions and global conflicts. The Ukraine war has disrupted supply chains, while the Middle East conflict has strained energy markets. Companies must navigate these challenges by adopting flexible approaches, embedding scenario planning into their governance frameworks, and ensuring alignment with international standards. Singapore boards must prioritize rigorous due diligence, transparent business practices, and robust compliance frameworks to safeguard against reputational damage and sanctions. Effective governance of geopolitical risk requires proactive scenario planning, clear risk mitigation strategies, and adequate insurance strategies.

images.alt_text: While B Corps alone may not save the world on a grand scale, they are a critical component of the larger movement towards a more ethical and sustainable economy.
Cyber attacks can occur through user accounts, e-mail, text or phone calls, where scammers target companies through their employees.
Good board leadership strikes a balance between having talent and experience and complementing that by learning, practising and refining those skills along the way.

site_title: China vehicle makers pivot to hybrids for Europe to counter EV tariffs
summary: China's hybrid vehicle exports to Europe are expected to grow 20% this year and even faster next year, despite the European Union's electric vehicle (EV) tariffs, which do not apply to hybrid cars. Major brands like BYD, China's top EV maker, are likely to expand in the region, as the tariff scheme limits their electric vehicle sales. Analysts say China's hybrid exports will capitalize on the EU's EV tariff protection, allowing them to maintain market share and gain a competitive advantage. This shift may expose the limitations of the EU's EV tariff scheme.

images.alt_text: Tesla is offering five-year 0 per cent loans and a 10,000 yuan discount on its Model Y sport utility vehicle until the end of December.
Chinese sales of electric vehicles and hybrids have reached a tipping point this year in their tug-of-war with internal combustion engines.

site_title: S&P places Singapore Post on credit watch negative following strategy reset, sale of Australia business
summary: S&P has placed Singapore Post on credit watch negative following the potential sale of its Australian business, citing uncertainty over the company's future strategy and earnings contribution. The sale, worth S$870 million, is part of a strategic review aimed at enhancing business value and maximizing shareholder value. The loss of a key earnings pillar introduces uncertainty, and S&P believes the sale will be "transformative" for SingPost.

images.alt_text: The deal comes after a strategic review of SingPost's Australia business.

The Singapore Post board noted that incoming chief financial officer Vincent Yik is expected to lead "the continued transformation of our business, especially with Australia as a key part of our strategy".
SingPost's property leasing segment largely comprises SingPost Centre, where occupancy rates are up as at end-September compared to end-March 2024.

site_title: Indonesian parliament proposes VAT hike only for luxury items
summary: Indonesia's parliament has proposed a VAT hike of only 12% for luxury items, aiming to minimize the impact on low-income individuals. The current VAT rate is set to rise to 12% on January 1, 2025, but public demand for a delay has been mounting due to concerns about its effect on purchasing power. The proposed exemption of luxury items from the full VAT rate aims to balance revenue collection with the needs of the general population.

images.alt_text: With Prabowo’s agenda to ramp up spending for economic growth, tax revenue is seen as a vital tool for the president to fund his ambitious budget plans.
Indonesian businesses and unions have called for the legislated increase in the VAT rate to be paused because the economic environment is deteriorating.

site_title: Christmas across countries and seasons
summary: Habyt's CEO Asia-Pacific, Jonathan Wong, has brought his vision of connection and community to the global housing provider. He recently opened Kada At Maxwell, a heritage building in Singapore, offering a gym, co-working space, and wellness amenities. Wong, who married his wife Lilian Sun in 2015, believes in taking bold risks and connecting people, a philosophy that has guided his career and relationship. The couple, who have two children, have forged their own unique Christmas traditions, traveling the world to experience the holiday in different forms and strengthening their global network of friends.

images.alt_text: Glenn Yong wears a washed indigo sweatshirt by Coach.
