site_title: ST Telemedia sells majority stake in Malaysian telecom firm U Mobile
summary: ST Telemedia sells majority stake in Malaysian telecom firm U Mobile to Mawar Setia, a private company in Malaysia, under a conditional share purchase deal. Straits Mobile will retain a 20% stake in the company. The deal marks the end of U Mobile's status as a subsidiary of ST Telemedia. The financial details of the deal were not disclosed. U Mobile, founded in 2006, is Malaysia's youngest telecom company with a 5G network, and is reportedly planning a domestic IPO in 2025.

images.alt_text: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres reveals plans for two new data centres in Tokyo

site_title: Property tycoon Gordon Tang and wife make conditional offer of S$1.16 each to acquire all units of Suntec Reit
summary: Gordon Tang and his wife Celine have made a mandatory conditional cash offer to acquire all units of Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) at S$1.16 per unit. The offer was triggered after Aelios acquired 62.5 million units, bringing its total deemed interest in the trust to 31.5%. The offeror intends to maintain the Reit's listing status on the Singapore Exchange following the completion of the offer.

images.alt_text: The fall in DPU was attributed to the completion of a S$5.8 million capital distribution which concluded in end-2023.

site_title: Nvidia partners Vietnam government to set up AI research, data centres
summary: Nvidia has partnered with the Vietnamese government to establish a research and development centre for artificial intelligence (AI) and a separate AI data centre using Nvidia technology. The deal was announced during a meeting between Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh. This partnership comes as Nvidia deepens its ties with the Vietnamese government and firms, following previous deals to develop an AI factory and sell Nvidia AI chips to the country. The partnership also follows Nvidia's acquisition of a Hanoi-based AI health-tech company, VinBrain, and its establishment of a US$200 million AI factory in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, CEO and founder of Nvidia, said that the data stored on Thailand’s sovereign cloud server could be used to power a local “AI ecosystem”, such as a generative AI chatbot fed by Thai data.
CEO and founder of Nvidia Jensen Huang met with Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra while on a visit to Bangkok, and the two agreed to deepen cooperation on artificial intelligence.

Truong Quoc Hung, chief executive at VinBrain and Kimberly Powell, vice president of healthcare at Nvidia at the headquarters of Nvidia in the US in March, 2023.
Vietnam's FPT has been collaborating with US software firm Landing AI since 2022 to leverage what they call “large vision models” to implement computer vision solutions for industries.

site_title: Magical Christmas moments at The Raffles
summary: Raffles Hotel Singapore is transforming into a festive wonderland for the holiday season, offering a range of magical experiences, including gourmet feasts, exclusive cocktails, and bespoke florals. The hotel's restaurants, including Butcher's Block, Tiffin Room, and yi by Jereme Leung, are serving up festive and new year's Eve menus, while the Floral Boutique offers bespoke decor and florals. Festive Afternoon Tea is priced from S$118++ per guest and available until Jan 1, 2025, with wine pairing options.

images.alt_text: A la carte Christmas dishes from Il Cielo.
There's a treasure trove of treats at The Shop.

site_title: Christmas novelties from Tissot
summary: Tissot has unveiled two new Christmas novelties, the PRX Quartz 25 mm and the PRX 40 Powermatic 80 Forged Carbon. The PRX Quartz 25 mm features a 25-mm-wide case in various materials, including carnation gold, and is water-resistant to 100m. The PRX 40 Powermatic 80 Forged Carbon boasts a 40-mm forged carbon case with a full black aesthetic and a power reserve of 80 hours. Both watches are priced between S$430 and S$1,450.

site_title: Euro ticks up despite French government collapse; bitcoin breaks US$100,000
summary: The euro rose 0.16% to US$1.0525 despite the collapse of the French government, which had been widely expected. Meanwhile, bitcoin broke the US$100,000 mark for the first time, rising 5% to US$103,100, and the Japanese yen rallied as traders await the Bank of Japan's decision on December 19. The European Central Bank is expected to cut rates next week, and traders are pricing in around 157 basis points of easing by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro currency bills are pictured at the Croatian National Bank in Zagreb, Croatia, May 21, 2019. REUTERS/Antonio Bronic

site_title: Swift crisis response by Korea limits market impact of tumult
summary: South Korea's brief martial law period has had a limited impact on its market due to swift action by officials to restore democratic norms and reassure investors. The country's credit default swap and benchmark Kospi index have declined but appear to be stabilizing, and the won has largely retraced its losses. The Bank of Korea has promised unlimited liquidity and expanded repo operations to boost market stability. Analysts attribute the quick resolution to South Korea's institutional strength and functioning checks and balances, which are expected to mitigate the damage to investor confidence.

images.alt_text: A woman holds a sign that reads "Yoon Suk Yeol should step down" during a candlelight vigil against South Korea President Yoon in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024. South Korea's opposition moved to impeach Yoon after his extraordinary but short-lived imposition of martial law that brought thousands of protesters to the streets.
The won has been among the biggest victims from the row that swept the nation and raised concerns about South Korea’s credit worthiness.

South Korean Defence Minister Kim Yong Hyun has been reported as having advised PM Yoon Suk Yeol to declare martial law on Tuesday, which was lifted after parliament’s vote demanding Yoon to reverse it.

site_title: Timely gifts for the season
summary: Several luxury watch brands have introduced mini timepieces for the holiday season, including Cartier, Longines, and Panerai. Cartier's mini models, such as the Tank Louis Cartier and Panthere de Cartier, feature elegant designs and refined details. Longines' Master Collection Moonphase watch combines tradition with innovation, featuring a moon-phase indicator and an exclusive mechanical movement. Panerai's Luminor Due Metal Bracelet offers a striking burgundy dial and a progressive "V-shape" metal bracelet design. These mini watches are priced between S$10,100 and S$30,300.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 5)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended the deadline to cease the processing of corporate cheques to December 31, 2026, from its original December 31, 2025, as banks will stop issuing new corporate cheque books by the end of 2025. This change aims to reduce the risks associated with cheque processing and promote digital payment systems.

site_title: A perpetual calendar for everyone
summary: IWC continues to refine its perpetual calendar, a complication that simplifies the traditional calendar by automatically accommodating variations in month lengths and leap years. Introduced in 1985 with the Da Vinci Chronograph Perpetual Calendar, the watch features 81 cleverly arranged parts and is set using a single crown turn, a first in the industry. The latest iteration showcases the watch in Armor Gold and Obsidian black dial designs, offering a user-friendly timekeeping solution. The perpetual calendar remains a milestone in watchmaking, demonstrating IWC's commitment to innovative and accessible mechanical watches.

site_title: An iconic Christmas celebration
summary: Chanel's Christmas collection features iconic symbols such as the star and comet, number 5, and the camellia, showcasing the brand's enduring appeal. The brand's long necklaces, known for their versatility, can be worn in multiple ways using new moveable clasps. A variety of bracelets, including the new Coco Crush mini versions, offer design and stacking options. Additionally, Chanel's watches, rings, and other accessories feature the brand's celebrated icons, making for a perfect gift for the holiday season.

site_title: Economists cautious on Hong Kong, Singapore growth next year
summary: Economists predict Singapore's economy will expand 3.5% in the first two quarters of next year, while Hong Kong's growth is expected to slow due to US tariffs on China, potentially lowering Hong Kong's yearly estimate to 2.2% from 2.6%. Donald Trump's return to the White House with new tariffs may further slow China's economy, affecting Hong Kong and Singapore's growth.

images.alt_text: Fast food outlet takings shrank 1.5 per cent year on year.

site_title: Priciest UK mansion languishes on market after Qatar rejection
summary: The sale of Rutland Gate, a £500 million mansion in London, has stalled due to Qatar's loss of interest after a thorough inspection revealed the property required a full refurbishment that would take almost half a decade to complete. The Gulf state had considered purchasing the property as a potential embassy, but the complications surrounding converting it into a mixed-use building ultimately led to the decision. This setback reflects a broader slump in the luxury property market, with potential buyers deterred by tougher UK taxes for wealthy foreigners and higher financing costs.

images.alt_text: A new residential property development in an area of green belt land in Crowthorne, UK, on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024. Nationwide said the £2.3 billion gain from the Virgin deal was more than the £1.5 billion it had previously forecast earlier this year.

site_title: Tudor sets the mood for Christmas
summary: Tudor has released a limited-edition Black Bay 58 Bronze watch, featuring a satin-brushed bronze case and bracelet. Inspired by naval engineering, the watch's domed dial and bezel adopt a "brown bronze" tone. The timepiece is powered by an in-house automatic movement certified by COSC and is available for S$6,990. Tudor has also introduced the Clair de Rose, a refined and timeless feminine line with a new "Tudor blue" dial, available in three sizes for S$3,620.

site_title: Hongkong Land is said to weigh sale of Singapore developer MCL
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings is considering selling its Singapore-based property developer MCL Land at a premium to its book value of S$1.1 billion. The Jardine Matheson-backed firm owns 100% of MCL Land and is speaking with financial advisers to prepare for a potential transaction. Deliberations are ongoing, and Hongkong Land could still choose to retain the assets.

images.alt_text: Hongkong Land's crown jewel is its Hong Kong Central portfolio.
Hongkong Land says the new business strategy will generate growth in long-term recurring income.
Hongkong Land chief financial officer Craig Beattie (left) and chief executive officer Michael Smith announced the group's new business strategy on Oct 29.
Excluding non-recurring provisions, underlying profit was US$288 million, down 32 per cent from the same period the year before, said Hongkong Land.

site_title: An exciting new chapter in skincare and holistic wellness
summary: SENZE Boutique Spa, formerly SK-II Boutique Spa, has rebranded and introduced new treatments and services, including hair wellness, to expand its luxury skincare experience. The spa, led by Calvin Ng, offers advanced skincare treatments such as cell-based exosomes therapy and transdermal electroporation, as well as hair services led by Go Chee Wee. The spa's focus on wellness beyond skin deep and its commitment to staff growth and customer loyalty have contributed to its success. The spa now offers a range of services, including facials, hair treatments, and relaxation options, in a 4,000 sq ft location in Raffles City.

site_title: Country Garden sales drop worsens as China housing saga drags on
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese developer, reported a 52.3% decline in contracted sales for November to US$414 million, surpassing its peers. This worsens the company's liquidity concerns as it navigates a debt overhaul. The slump in sales comes despite China's recent efforts to stimulate the property market with policies such as cutting borrowing costs and relaxing buying curbs. Country Garden's slower sales growth is attributed to its focus on lower-end markets, which have been hit harder by deflationary pressure. The company is in talks with creditors for a debt overhaul, but has missed its self-imposed target date.

site_title: Equinor, Shell to form UK oil and gas joint venture
summary: Equinor and Shell have formed a UK oil and gas joint venture, set to produce over 140,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day in 2025. The new company, owned 50/50 by both, will be based in Aberdeen, Scotland, and aims to sustain domestic oil and gas production and energy security in Britain. The joint venture combines Equinor's stakes in several British North Sea fields and Shell's holdings in others, including exploration licenses. The plan is to complete the deal by the end of 2025, making it the British North Sea's largest independent producer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Equinor is set up at the entrance of a building at Western Europe's largest liquefied natural gas plant Hammerfest LNG in Hammerfest, Norway, March 14, 2024. REUTERS/Lisi Niesner/File Photo

site_title: Business leaders fear recession, labour shortages, World Economic Forum says
summary: Business leaders globally express anxiety over recession, labour shortages, and rising inflation, despite some economic improvement. The World Economic Forum survey of 11,000 business leaders from G20 countries ranks economic downturn as the top risk over the next two years. Extreme weather events, including record temperatures and wildfires, are a growing concern, ranking fifth on the list. Concerns about technology, including artificial intelligence, are also prevalent, particularly in Indonesia, the US, and Britain.

site_title: Britain approves US$19 billion Vodafone-Three mobile merger
summary: Britain has approved the US$19 billion merger between Vodafone and Hutchison's Three UK, creating the country's largest mobile operator. The deal, valued at US$14 billion, includes a pledge to invest in 5G networks and protect retail and wholesale customers, outweighing concerns about higher prices. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) accepted the measures, allowing the merger to proceed. The new operator will serve 50 million customers, boosting competition in the UK mobile sector.

images.alt_text: Vodafone's net profit totalled nearly 1.1 billion euros (S$1.6 billion) in the six months to the end of September.
Vodafone noted

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, December 5, 2024
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) jumped over 1% on Thursday, nearing a record high. OKH Global surged 38.9% after a proposed acquisition of Chip Eng Seng Construction, while Adaro Andalan shares gained 20% following Indonesia's largest IPO in 2024.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Thursday.

site_title: Praemia REIM is said to consider Singapore healthcare Reit IPO
summary: France's Praemia REIM is considering listing a healthcare real estate investment trust (Reit) in Singapore, which could inject momentum into the city-state's anemic IPO market. The hospital assets included in the Reit may be worth US$2 billion to US$3 billion, with the company seeking to raise several hundred million US dollars from the first-time share sale. Talks with prospective arrangers are underway, with a potential listing taking place as soon as 2025.

images.alt_text: Various stakeholders have expressed broad support for its proposed changes, says MAS.
Macquarie initiates coverage on S-Reits, positive on industrial and suburban retail sectors.
Data centre assets have been appealing to investors in recent years for their positive rental reversions as supply remains tight.

site_title: A shiny Rolex Christmas
summary: Rolex has released six festive timepieces for the holiday season, featuring precious metals and unique dial designs. The Perpetual 1908 in Platinum boasts a platinum case with an ice blue dial and guilloche rice-grain motif, priced at S$44,500. Other models include the Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 40 in 18 ct white gold with diamonds, priced at S$71,300; the Oyster Perpetual Rolex Deepsea in 18 ct gold with a blue ceramic bezel, priced at S$79,400; the Oyster Perpetual Cosmograph Daytona with 36 brilliant-cut diamonds, priced at S$106,900; the Oyster Perpetual Yacht-Master 37 in 18 ct Everose gold, priced at S$61,950; and the Oyster Perpetual Day-Date 36 in 18 ct white gold, priced at S$121,500.

images.alt_text: The Seamaster Aqua Terra

site_title: MAS extends deadline to cease corporate cheques to end-2026
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has extended the deadline to cease processing corporate cheques to December 31, 2026, from the initial end-2025 date. All banks in Singapore will stop issuing new corporate cheque books by December 31, 2025, but retail cheques will remain available. Two new electronic payment solutions, Electronic Deferred Payment (EDP) and EDP+, will be launched in mid-2025 to support corporate and retail cheque users transitioning to e-payments.

images.alt_text: The new rules were introduced by the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Friday, after it concluded a public consultation on the proposal to eliminate all corporate cheques by 2025.
The disruption of DBS and Citi banking services over the weekend has led to some merchants not receiving customer payments even by Monday.

site_title: Frasers Property alerted of scam accounts impersonating its subsidiaries
summary: Frasers Property has alerted authorities to scam accounts impersonating its subsidiaries, Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Frasers Commercial Trust, on Telegram. The phishing scam aims to solicit sensitive information from shareholders and the public under false pretenses. Frasers Property assures that it will never request financial or personal information through social media channels, and advises shareholders and the public to report suspicious accounts to Telegram immediately. The company warns that these accounts may attempt to engage with shareholders or solicit information under false pretenses, and cautions against responding or sharing personal information.

site_title: A festive tale of Omega precision
summary: Omega unveils four special Christmas timepieces, each showcasing the brand's precision and attention to detail. The selected watches include the Seamaster Aqua Terra, Speedmaster 38 mm, De Ville Prestige, and Constellation Meteorite, featuring black tones, stainless steel craftsmanship, and Omega's Co-Axial Master Chronometer movement. The watches are available in various styles and price points, ranging from S$7,100 to S$14,100, making them ideal gifts for the punctual loved ones on your list.

images.alt_text:
pmluxexmasomega5 - The Seamaster Aqua Terra

Credit: Omega

site_title: Trump Christmas 'pooper' figurine in 'massive' demand in Spain
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has become the latest world leader to be featured in Spain's traditional "caganer" (pooper) clay figurines, which depict people with their pants down and defecating. The figurines, originally designed as comical shepherds, have expanded to include Trump and other prominent figures, such as French President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Sales of Trump figurines have been "massive" and reflect the outcome of the US election, according to the CEO of online store Caganer.com. The figurines have been popular in previous elections, including 2016 and 2020.

site_title: Asean ministers to discuss Myanmar at Thailand meeting, Indonesia says
summary: ASEAN ministers will discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar at a meeting in Thailand on Dec 20. The meeting aims to address ways to implement the bloc's five-point consensus plan since the 2021 military coup. Indonesia's foreign minister is expected to attend, and the discussion will focus on the crisis's impact and potential solutions.

site_title:
Andre Chiang:
From chef to hotelier
summary: Taiwanese chef Andre Chiang is retiring from his restaurant business and has opened a unique guesthouse, Mitsumaya, in Kanazawa, Japan. The three-room guesthouse, designed by Chiang and his friends, features traditional machiya architecture and is decorated with locally sourced antiques. Chiang's passion for Kanazawa, which he considers one of his favorite cities in Japan, is evident in the guesthouse's design. The project aims to preserve the city's cultural heritage and revive the neighborhood, with plans to add two new modern houses in 2025.

images.alt_text: Only 400 bottles of Hibiki 40 Years Old are available globally.

site_title: Prudential Financial promotes Andy Sullivan to CEO, succeeding Lowrey
summary: Prudential Financial has promoted Andy Sullivan to CEO, succeeding Charlie Lowrey, amid a broader shakeup of the insurer's top management ranks. Sullivan, 54, will take the helm at the end of March, while Lowrey will remain as executive chairman for 18 months. The move comes as the search for higher returns intensifies due to rivalry between traditional life insurers and private equity-owned counterparts. Sullivan, who has held leadership positions in all of Prudential's businesses since 2011, plans to focus on asset management and growing the insurance and retirement business in concert with improving capabilities in the platform.

images.alt_text: Data from the CPF Board shows that from 2020 to 2022, 57% of Singaporeans and PRs who paid for higher coverage with IPs to complement their MediShield Life basic health insurance still chose subsidised wards.
Logo for Aviva plc, a British insurer.
In MAS' annual Financial Stability Review, it noted that the overall banking sector maintained or improved across the indicators for financial vulnerability.

site_title: Schneider Electric working with Nvidia to design data centre cooling systems
summary: Schneider Electric is collaborating with Nvidia to design data centre cooling systems for use in new AI data centres featuring Nvidia's flagship server with 72 AI chips. The servers consume up to 132 kilowatts of power and will require liquid cooling. Schneider's designs will be used in data centres sold to cloud computing firms or customers, with the partnership aiming to scale cooling system options up or down depending on server power consumption. The agreement does not disclose financial details.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, CEO and founder of Nvidia, said that the data stored on Thailand’s sovereign cloud server could be used to power a local “AI ecosystem”, such as a generative AI chatbot fed by Thai data.
CEO and founder of Nvidia Jensen Huang met with Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra while on a visit to Bangkok, and the two agreed to deepen cooperation on artificial intelligence.
Nvidia’s version generates sound effects and music from a text description, including novel sounds such as making a trumpet bark like a dog.
Jensen Huang, Nvidia's chief executive, say his company will support the incoming Trump's administration, as well as comply with any regulation.

site_title: NTT Data seeks to buy land in Johor Bahru to build data centre
summary: NTT Data, a Japanese IT solutions arm, plans to acquire land in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, to build a data centre. The 27.7-hectare site will be one of the largest in Asia-Pacific, with six buildings offering an IT load capacity of 290 megawatts. The first building, with an initial capacity of 48 megawatts, is set to launch in April 2027. The move follows Malaysia's boom in data centre construction to meet growing demand for infrastructure and computing power, driven by its proximity to Singapore.

images.alt_text: AWS chief executive Matt Garman (left) and Keppel chief executive Loh Chin Hua at the ceremonial signing event in Las Vegas, US.

site_title: Hong Kong leader unexpectedly sacks tourism, transport ministers
summary: Hong Kong leader John Lee unexpectedly sacked his ministers for tourism and transport, replacing Rosanna Law and Mable Chan with Kevin Yeung and Lam Sai-hung, respectively. Lee cited the need to deliver "societal and economic benefits" for Hong Kong, which has been struggling with weak retail sales and a decline in Chinese visitors. The moves come as the city seeks to revive tourism after protests, pandemic border closures, and the imposition of national security laws.

images.alt_text: The wider project is set to transform 30,000 hectares of land along the border, about a third of Hong Kong’s territory.
Hong Kong property market’s continuing struggles stemming from the city’s sluggish economy and changing demographics.
The government first introduced the idea to take back part of the site in 2019 to help solve the city’s housing crisis as the property market was overheated.

site_title: Hot stock: OKH Global surges 38.9% after proposed acquisition of Chip Eng Seng Construction
summary: OKH Global surged 38.9% after announcing a proposed acquisition of Chip Eng Seng Construction for S$118.5 million. The acquisition aims to revitalize the business and provide a financial foothold for future growth. Chip Eng Seng Construction has an order book of over S$2 billion and will hold more than 50% of OKH Global after the deal. The transaction is expected to be completed in 2025, with the company issuing new shares to pay for the acquisition.

images.alt_text: The spectacular crash in the shares of property company OKH Global last month raises a pertinent issue regarding disclosure of shares pledged by major shareholders for private loans.

site_title: STI rises 0.6% as banking shares make strong gains amid mixed Asia markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22.74 points or 0.6% to 3,822.68, with gainers outnumbering losers 280 to 244. Top gainer Hongkong Land gained 4% to US$4.69, while the three local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose. Retail sales in Singapore grew 2.2% in October, reversing a decline in previous months. The market eased by the close, with the STI near a record high.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment's self-storage platform Extra Space Asia enters partnership with Japan's biggest indoor self-storage manager

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Nakamura urges caution in raising interest rates
summary: Bank of Japan board member Toyoaki Nakamura urged caution in raising interest rates, citing a chance that inflation may miss the 2% target from fiscal 2025 onward. He expressed concerns over smaller firms' profitability and households' frugality due to rising prices. Nakamura emphasized the need for careful data analysis and adjustments to monetary support to ensure economic stability, as consumption lacks momentum. This dovish stance suggests a more measured approach to interest rate hikes.

site_title: Temu told to suspend Vietnam operations, state media reports
summary: Chinese online retailer Temu has been told to suspend its operations in Vietnam after failing to meet an end-November deadline for business registration. The Ministry of Industry and Trade requested the suspension due to Temu's incomplete registration procedures, which could block its internet domains and apps in the country. Temu has submitted required documents and is working with Vietnamese authorities to resolve the issue, but a timeframe for resuming operations has not been provided.

images.alt_text: This photograph shows the logo of Chinese e-commerce company Temu displayed on a mobile phone holding in front of a screen bearing a website page of the e-commerce company, in Brussels, on November 4, 2024. (Photo by Nicolas TUCAT / AFP)

site_title: Cognac and champagne makers seek to boost US exports to avoid tariff risks
summary: Cognac and Champagne makers, including LVMH's Hennessy and Moët & Chandon, plan to increase shipments to the US to avoid potential tariffs under President-elect Donald Trump. This move aims to provide a few months' respite from the risk of tariffs, which could impact luxury goods. The US is the biggest export market for Champagne and Cognac, with almost 27 million bottles of Champagne and 58.4 million bottles of Cognac shipped to the US last year.

site_title: Malaysia says any US tariffs on Brics nations could impact semiconductor supply
summary: Malaysia warns that US tariffs on Brics nations, including itself, could disrupt the global semiconductor supply chain, as President-elect Donald Trump has proposed 100% tariffs unless Brics members agree not to create a new currency or support another currency to replace the US dollar. Malaysia, a key hub for chip testing and packaging, is heavily reliant on US firms and the US dollar for trade. The country's trade minister, Tengku Zafrul Aziz, urges caution, stating that any tariffs would harm both parties and disrupt the global supply chain.

images.alt_text: The infrastructure that backs the US dollar, such as the cross-border payment system, will likely give the US currency a decisive edge for decades to come.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin speaks during the BRICS summit in Kazan on October 24, 2024. (Photo by Alexander NEMENOV / AFP)

epa11679350 Russian President Vladimir Putin (C) speaks during a plenary session in the outreach/BRICS Plus format at the BRICS summit in Kazan, Russia, 24 October 2024. The BRICS summit takes place from 22 to 24 October.  EPA-EFE/MAXIM SHEMETOV / POOL
Agustin Carstens, general manager of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS), stated that mBridge is not yet mature enough to begin operating and will require many more years of development.

site_title: Switzerland flunks its study of commodity speculators
summary: Switzerland's federal government commissioned a report on speculation's impact on agricultural-commodity markets, but the 28-page study failed to provide meaningful insights. The report, written by anonymous authors, ignored criticism of the industry, didn't name major players, and omitted details on their trading firepower and profits during recent price spikes. The lack of transparency has raised questions about the industry's influence and accountability, leaving many to wonder what role speculation truly plays in high food prices. The report's shortcomings have sparked criticism of the government's handling of the inquiry.

images.alt_text: Oxford Economics expects international soybean prices to take a direct hit from the upcoming Trump presidency and ensuing trade war with China.

Money managers piled a combined net-short position of almost 153,000 futures and options across 20 raw-material markets in the week ended last Tuesday (Aug 6), according to US Commodity Futures Trade Commission data compiled by Bloomberg.
Speculators resume bullish bet on sugar as energy prices soar
Shaken by spiking commodities, trading houses adapt to survive

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield slips to 3%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) cut-off yield fell to 3% in its latest auction, down from 3.08% in the previous auction on Nov 21. The auction received S$17.4 billion in applications, a 2.45 bid-to-cover ratio, and non-competitive bids totaling S$2.4 billion. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has raised its government securities issuance limit to S$1.515 trillion, with S$450 billion expected to be issued by 2029.

images.alt_text: The latest tranche offers a first-year interest rate of 2.66 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 2.81 per cent.
The issuance limit was last raised in 2021, from S$690 billion to S$1,065 billion.

site_title: Fortunes of Apac billionaires outstripped global wealth growth last decade: report
summary: Asia-Pacific's ultra-wealthy saw their fortunes soar 141% over the last decade, outpacing global wealth growth of 121% and growing at 69% faster than the rest of the world. The region now home to 981 billionaires, representing 40% of the world's total billionaire population. Tech billionaires led wealth growth, with their fortunes tripling from $788.9 billion to $2.4 trillion, while art and antique investments saw a 11% increase in interest. The report suggests that smart risk-taking, business focus, and determination will be key to success in the next decade amidst global uncertainty and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Dubai – and the rest of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) – has become a strong magnet for private wealth and talent in recent years.

site_title: Malaysia royal commission recommends criminal probe against Mahathir over Pedra Branca
summary: A Malaysian royal commission of inquiry has recommended a police report be lodged against former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad for his handling of a sovereignty dispute with Singapore over the island of Pedra Branca. The commission cited Mahathir's decision to drop the case as prime minister in 2018, resulting in permanent loss of Malaysia's sovereign rights to the island. The report recommends investigation into possible crimes of cheating under the Penal Code, citing Mahathir's responsibilities as prime minister to protect and defend Malaysia's interests and sovereignty.

images.alt_text: (From left) Brian Ng, Bernard Ng and Samuel Pei, co-founders of KC Group; and Song Yan Ho, Shin Ng and Kris Lee, co-founders of RushOwl.

site_title: UK companies jittery about rise in labour costs and Trump tariffs: survey
summary: The British Chambers of Commerce predicts a challenging 2025 for UK companies due to rising employment costs and potential US tariffs. Business investment is forecast to grow by 0.9% next year, down from a previous 1.4% growth. The UK's post-Brexit trade barriers with the EU and US president Donald Trump's proposed 10-20% tariffs on imports are expected to weigh down on trade prospects. These factors are likely to impact the UK economy, with the economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: The Lloyds Bank Business Barometer sank by 3 points last month to 41 per cent, its lowest level since June but comfortably above the survey’s long-run average of 29 per cent.
The UK’s Office for National Statistics has been struggling to collect sufficient and accurate data on employment trends, leading to severe criticism from central bankers and politicians.
Banks and building societies approved 68,300 home loans in October, an increase from 66,100 the previous month.

Thursday’s survey showed that optimism among consumer services businesses sank to its lowest since August 2022 at -55 in November, down from -19 in August, while among business and professional services sentiment fell to -29 from +9.

site_title: Asia: South Korea stocks drop, won stable as markets fluctuate
summary: South Korean stocks dropped 0.3% in early trade on Thursday, as President Yoon Suk Yeol clings to power despite a brief imposition of martial law. The won stabilized at 1,415 to the dollar, while Bitcoin broke past the US$100,000 mark for the first time on hopes of US President-elect Donald Trump's deregulation of cryptocurrencies. The crisis in East Asia, including a no-confidence vote in French Prime Minister Michel Barnier, injected uncertainty into already fraught situations in France and South Korea. Analysts see limited implications for the economy and financial markets, citing the resilience of South Korea's institutions.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 230 to 197.
All three major indices scored records on Wednesday, led by the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which finished above 45,000 for the first time.

site_title: How Citi lost US$17 million on biggest Aussie block trade in years
summary: Citigroup lost US$17 million on a block trade deal in Australia after outbidding rivals with a 1.4-1.5% discount to win a stake in property firm Goodman Group. The bank was unable to sell the entire block, leaving it with unsold shares worth A$27 million, more than the 23.4 million it initially sold. The deal highlights the intense competition in the Asia Pacific investment banking market, where banks are vying for lucrative mandates and facing pressure to deliver profits.

images.alt_text: Former BlackRock fund manager Kate Moore (pictured here in 2017) will become Citigroup's chief investment officer for its wealth division in February 2025.
Managers have been told that as many as 2,000 Citi employees could get promotions, with pay hikes limited to 15 per cent, in the next month.
Citi has doled out bonuses to staff particularly in the wealth unit and to some in the private bank business to reward them for staying into next year.

site_title: US Fed’s Jerome Powell expects good relations with Trump administration
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed confidence in maintaining good relations with the incoming Trump administration, downplaying potential tension. Despite inflation still not reaching the 2% target, Powell expects solid economic conditions to continue, citing a cautious approach to interest rate reductions. He also expressed confidence in working with Treasury nominee Scott Bessent, dismissing the idea of a "shadow Fed chair" that could undermine his influence. The Fed will meet on December 17-18 to discuss further rate cuts, with Powell indicating a gradual approach.

images.alt_text: “In order to keep the economy in a good place, we have to continue to recalibrate policy,” San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly said during an interview with Fox Business.

FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building is seen before the Federal Reserve board is expected to signal plans to raise interest rates in March as it focuses on fighting inflation in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022.      REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo
Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rates are also likely to continue falling next year, though the pace and degree of reduction remain to be determined.
While inflation is taking time to recede back to the Fed’s 2 per cent target, the policy path ahead will be complicated by President-elect Donald Trump’s economic agenda.

site_title: POSB partners Mandai Wildlife Group for financial literacy efforts
summary: POSB has partnered Mandai Wildlife Group to boost financial literacy among children and families through interactive learning journeys and workshops at Mandai Wildlife Reserve's parks. The partnership aims to teach essential financial concepts and environmentally friendly habits, with a special Super Saver Mission trail booklet guiding families through Singapore Zoo. POSB cardholders will receive discounts on park tickets and purchases within the reserve. This collaboration expands POSB's financial literacy outreach efforts, which will be extended to more children in pre-schools and primary schools.

images.alt_text: Karen Ngui, head of DBS Foundation and group strategic marketing and communications, says: "We need to spark a paradigm shift to tackle ageing holistically."
The mentorship programme was launched in 2019. Around 245 DBS mentors and 280 ITE mentees have participated in it since then.

site_title: FashionValet founders charged after sovereign wealth fund loss
summary: FashionValet founders Vivy Yusof and Fadzarudin Shah Anuar have been jointly charged with criminal breach of trust over the alleged misuse of funds by two government-linked firms, Khazanah Nasional and Permodalan Nasional Berhad. The couple, co-founders of FashionValet, pleaded not guilty and were set bail at RM100,000 each. The sovereign wealth funds lost RM43.9 million after investing RM47 million in the company in 2018, with RM8 million paid to a firm without board approval. The couple resigned and apologized to investors after the losses were announced.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on November 14, 2024 shows plus-size clothing brand owner and influencer Amanda Yao inspecting clothes in her office in Guangzhou, in Chinas southern Guangdong province. Surrounded by racks of colourful dresses and blazers in China's manufacturing hub of Guangzhou, plus-size clothing brand owner and influencer Amanda Yao is on a mission to promote body positivity. (Photo by GREG BAKER / AFP) / To go with AFP story China-lifestyle-women-clothing, FOCUS by Jing Xuan TENG

site_title: China warns against ‘worship’ of faster growth before key meeting
summary: China's state media has warned against prioritizing rapid growth over sustainable consumption, signaling a shift in focus ahead of a key economic meeting. Officials have launched a major stimulus campaign since September to meet the annual 5% growth target, but a "little to the left or right" deviation is considered acceptable. The warning cautions against the "worship of speed" mindset and urges policymakers to balance growth with long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: Shipping containers are stacked at a port in Lianyungang, in eastern China's Jiangsu province on April 12, 2024. Chinese exports plunged more than expected in March, official figures showed on April 12, as the world's second-largest economy struggles to sustain its post-pandemic recovery. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Beijing has responded with a series of policy measures, including increased fiscal support and monetary easing, to shore up economic growth.
Monetary policy support will be critical to China’s economy next year as the US president-elect has vowed to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods.

Investors are now turning their attention to this month’s Politburo assembly – one of three annually to typically focus on economic policy, although President Xi this year devoted an extra meeting to that cause in September.

site_title: Foot Locker to emphasise newer Nike styles at stores amid soft demand for its shoes
summary: Foot Locker is emphasizing newer Nike styles, including Vomero and Air DT Max, amid soft demand for the brand's products during the holiday shopping season. The retailer has expanded its Home Court partnership with Nike to rebuild sales, and CEO Mary Dillon expressed confidence in Elliott Hill's business revamp. Foot Locker lowered its annual sales and profit forecasts, expecting a 1-1.5% drop in annual sales, compared to a prior forecast of a 1% rise or fall.

images.alt_text: Foot Locker predicted adjusted earnings of US$1.50 to US$1.70 a share for this fiscal year, falling short of analysts’ expectations.

site_title: French government falls in historic no-confidence vote
summary: France's government, led by Prime Minister Michel Barnier, has been ousted in a historic no-confidence vote, with 331 lawmakers voting in favor of the motion. The vote was backed by the far-right and hard-left, marking the first time in over 60 years the National Assembly has toppled an incumbent government. President Emmanuel Macron now faces the task of appointing a new prime minister, with several possible contenders emerging. The move has plunged France into political uncertainty, with markets and unions bracing for potential instability and strikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro currency bills are pictured at the Croatian National Bank in Zagreb, Croatia, May 21, 2019. REUTERS/Antonio Bronic

A standoff over an austerity budget, which has caused jitters on financial markets, follows months of tension since President Emmanuel Macron appointed Michel Barnier (pictured) as prime minister in September.

site_title: US: Stocks surge to records on tech gains, Fed rate cut hopes
summary: US stocks surged to record highs on Wednesday, led by tech gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching 45,014.04 for the first time. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also scored records, despite weaker-than-expected US private-sector hiring data. Optimism about potential Federal Reserve interest rate cuts boosted the market, with tech stocks such as Nvidia and Microsoft leading the gains. The rally extended a post-election rally, with the market seemingly ignoring recent economic data and geopolitical concerns.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 235.5 points, or 0.53 per cent, at the open to 44,941.05.

site_title: BOJ rate-hike bets retreat as traders count down to key meeting
summary: Market expectations of a Bank of Japan interest rate hike in December have decreased, with overnight indexed swaps pricing in a 37% chance of a rate hike, down from 66% on November 29. The yen jumped 0.6% after a dovish BOJ board member said he wouldn't object to higher rates, but the Japanese government bond market fell. The BOJ's policy outlook remains uncertain, with the US Federal Reserve's outlook also unclear, contributing to the yen's weakness.

images.alt_text: Japan is no longer in any kind of potential competition to become the world’s biggest economy.
Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda suggests the central bank will avoid rushing to rate hikes as President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.

Japan's services producer price index, which measures the price companies charge each other for services, rose 2.9 per cent in October from a year earlier, BOJ data showed, accelerating from a 2.8 per cent gain in September.

site_title: Chinese hackers breached eight US telecom providers: White House
summary: Chinese hackers, known as Salt Typhoon, have breached eight US telecom providers, gathering intelligence on prominent US citizens, including President-elect Donald Trump and Vice-President-elect JD Vance. The US government is investigating the breach, with President Joe Biden receiving multiple briefings. China has denied US accusations of involvement. The hackers potentially accessed federal government systems for court-authorised network wiretapping requests and spied on communications of a "limited number" of people in government and politics.

images.alt_text: In the case of the alleged Singtel breach, one of the sources familiar with that incident said the attack relied on a tool known as a web shell.

Microsoft's report follows recent statements by senior US Intelligence officials that they’d seen Iran ramp up use of clandestine social media accounts with the aim to use them to try to sow political discord in the United States.
The disclosure underscores the breadth of the breach as Microsoft faces increasing regulatory scrutiny over the security of its software and systems against foreign threats.

site_title: OpenAI to partner with military defence tech company
summary: OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, has partnered with Anduril Industries, a military defence technology company, to use artificial intelligence for "national security missions". The collaboration aims to improve defences against drone attacks. The partnership comes nearly a year after OpenAI removed language from its policies banning the use of its technology for military or warfare purposes. The deal is seen as a way for the US to maintain an edge over China, and will bring together OpenAI's AI models with Anduril's systems and software to enhance national security.

images.alt_text: OpenAI, led by CEO Sam Altman, has seen its profile skyrocket over recent years as it has become a star player in the growing field of artificial intelligence.
Elon Musk has alleged that OpenAI bars its investors from making investments in rivals – which would put his own startup at a disadvantage in a sector where billions of dollars are at stake.
The lawsuit is the first by Canadian media against OpenAI.
OpenAI employees have until Dec 24 to join the new funding round, with stock prices matching the last round, funded by SoftBank’s Vision Fund 2.

site_title: Simple solution to Trump’s fears for US dollar status
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has threatened 100% tariffs on countries that stop using the US dollar in trade, citing a need to maintain the dollar's value. However, bilateral trade deals using alternative currencies, such as China and Russia's energy deal, show that countries can thrive without relying on the US dollar. The US could instead stop using the dollar as a political tool, addressing its own problems, rather than trying to force other countries to use it.

images.alt_text: The infrastructure that backs the US dollar, such as the cross-border payment system, will likely give the US currency a decisive edge for decades to come.
US dollar dominance has been strengthened recently given the robust US economy, tighter monetary policy and heightened geopolitical risks.
For now, the US economy is in a good place.  The biggest threat comes not from outside but has its origins in domestic strains.

The dollar is and will remain for the foreseeable future the main store of value for global investors. Geopolitical tensions favour the greenback as investors search for a haven and further escalations do not necessarily point to an imminent weakening of its dominant position.

site_title: South Korea urges calm in markets as it renews vow for action
summary: South Korea's government urged calm in financial markets after a martial-law row, renewing its pledge to control volatility amid concerns about the country's credit worthiness. The won has depreciated rapidly, but the government and central bank vowed to provide "unlimited liquidity" if needed. The impact of the drama has been limited, and South Korea's strong institutions are expected to mitigate any major implications for the domestic economy, according to a credit ratings company. The country faces external uncertainties with US President-elect Donald Trump's return to power next month.

images.alt_text: South Korean Defence Minister Kim Yong Hyun has been reported as having advised PM Yoon Suk Yeol to declare martial law on Tuesday, which was lifted after parliament’s vote demanding Yoon to reverse it.
People attend a candlelight vigil condemning South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's surprise declaration of martial law last night, which was reversed hours later, and to call for his resignation.
South Korea’s opposition lawmakers have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon.
Protestors calling for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 4 after he imposted martial law.

site_title: Keppel partners Amazon Web Services on generative AI, sustainable infrastructure
summary: Keppel, a global asset manager, has partnered with Amazon Web Services (AWS) to collaborate on data centers, subsea cables, and renewable energy initiatives worldwide. The partnership aims to accelerate AI and machine learning adoption, expand AWS' sustainable data center infrastructure, and improve network connectivity through subsea cable systems. Keppel is also developing a high-speed transmission cable across the Pacific Ocean, set to be the largest capacity cable when fully commissioned.

site_title: Philippine central bank to take ‘measured approach’ as inflation picks up in November
summary: The Philippine central bank has announced it will take a "measured approach" in its easing cycle due to slightly accelerating inflation, which rose 2.5% in November from 2.3% in the previous month. Typhoons led to higher food prices, driving inflation, which has averaged 3.2% for the year. The central bank's target range for 2024 is 2-4%, and the measured approach aims to balance inflation control with economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Philippine economy grew 5.2 per cent in the third quarter, its weakest in more than a year, as adverse weather disrupted government spending and dampened farm output.
The complaint adds to Duterte’s legal woes as she faces a probe into her alleged death threat against President Ferdinand Marcos and another inquiry into her use of government funds.

Sara Duterte (top) appeared to walk those comments back on Tuesday, describing them as an expression of “consternation” at the Marcos administration’s “failure to serve the Filipinos while it masterfully persecutes political enemies”.
The Philippine stock index has been one of the worst performers among the world’s major equity gauges this month, falling below the 7,000 level.

site_title: Bitcoin storms above US$100,000 as bets on Trump fuel crypto euphoria
summary: Bitcoin has surpassed $100,000 for the first time, more than doubling in value this year and rising 50% in the four weeks since US President-elect Donald Trump's election victory. Trump's nomination of pro-crypto Paul Atkins to run the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has fueled the surge. The total value of the cryptocurrency market has nearly doubled to $3.8 trillion, with Bitcoin's march into mainstream finance minting millionaires and popularizing "decentralised finance". Institutional adoption and advancements in tokenisation and payments are driving the momentum, with crypto companies jostling for a seat on Trump's promised crypto advisory council.

images.alt_text: The total was the largest in CFTC history, the regulator said in its annual report.
Crypto mining stocks have underperformed this year after the reward for mining Bitcoin was cut in half in April.
The crypto market has gained about US$1.2 trillion in market value since Trump’s election victory, CoinGecko data show.

site_title: Gold little changed; investors await US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged on Thursday, awaiting US payrolls data for cues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path. Spot gold was flat at $2,648.89 per ounce, as investors weigh the possibility of a 25-basis-point rate cut this month. Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled support for a slower pace of rate cuts, while Richmond Federal Reserve Bank president Thomas Barkin flagged risks for inflation and employment. US private payrolls grew at a moderate pace in November, but services sector activity slowed.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,644.42 per ounce.

site_title: 7-Eleven operators in Singapore, Thailand chow down on ready-to-eat segment
summary: 7-Eleven operators in Singapore and Thailand are shifting their focus from tobacco and alcohol sales to ready-to-eat food to drive growth. DFI Retail Group, which operates 7-Eleven stores in Singapore, Hong Kong, and China, and CP All, which operates 7-Eleven in Thailand, are introducing more pre-cooked food options. Analysts believe this strategy can counter declining sales in the convenience segment. The ready-to-eat segment accounts for 24% of DFI's operating profit in Singapore and 28-30% of 7-Eleven's quarterly sales in Thailand. The move is seen as a response to changing consumer lifestyles and the impact of alternative tobacco products.

images.alt_text: XX
DFI Retail Group’s pivot to ready-to-eat comes as cigarette sales in the stores have fallen.
Seven & i has yet to respond to the offers.
Miniso plans to buy a 29.4 per cent stake in Yonghui from DFI Retail Group Holdings’ the Dairy Farm, and two units of JD.com Miniso is offering 2.35 yuan for each share.
The Giant supermarket at Toa Payoh Lorong 4 is the supermarket brand's ninth closure this year.
One of the properties is a shop space at Block 181 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh, which was recently vacated by rival supermarket chain Giant.
DFI Retail Group has begun its strategic turn towards the higher-end of the retail grocery market, focusing on its CS Fresh labels.

site_title: CLI acquires Osaka facilities from self-storage manager to expand Japan porfolio
summary: Capitaland Investment (CLI) has acquired four Osaka self-storage facilities from Ambitious, expanding its Extra Space Asia (ESA) portfolio in Japan. The acquisition brings ESA's total self-storage assets in Japan to 14 and over 60,000 square feet of gross floor area. CLI plans to acquire two more Tokyo facilities by early 2025 as part of a strategic alliance with Ambitious to expand its presence in the Japanese market.

images.alt_text: Elmina Logistics Hub (pictured) is under development and is scheduled to be completed in the first half of 2025

site_title: Airbus cuts 2,000 Defence and Space jobs, taming earlier plans
summary: Airbus announced a job cut of 2,043 positions, about 5% of its Defence and Space division, due to heavy losses in the satellites sector. The majority of the cuts, 1,128 positions, will fall in the Space Systems business. The job cuts, which will be implemented by mid-2026, aim to reduce overheads and fixed costs, focusing on white-collar and management positions. The affected countries include Germany, France, Britain, and Spain, with no compulsory redundancies. This move follows the company's earlier plans to cut up to 2,500 jobs, and is part of a reorganisation plan called Proton.

images.alt_text: Spirit expects to burn through as much as US$500 million in free cash from the fourth quarter of this year through the second quarter of 2025.

epa11491594 The Airbus logo is pictured on the opening day of the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, Britain, 22 July 2024. The aviation summit is typically a platform for planemakers to rack up multibillion-dollar deals. The airshow runs from 22 to 26 July.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL

site_title: Nissan boss Uchida races to save the automaker - and his job
summary: Nissan CEO Makoto Uchida faces intense pressure to deliver a turnaround after the company reported dismal results, cutting 9,000 employees, 20% of global production capacity, and $2.6 billion in costs. The decline is attributed to weak sales and profitability in North America and China, despite Uchida's bet on an electric vehicle (EV) future. Uchida is under scrutiny for missing opportunities, such as offering petrol-electric hybrids in the US, and for the company's failure to keep up with changing market demands. Activist shareholders have built stakes in the automaker, and the incoming US president's tariffs on Mexico pose a significant risk to Nissan's production. Uchida has vowed to fulfill his duty as CEO, but the next few months will be critical for his job and the company's future.

images.alt_text: Nissan had an average of 109 days’ supply in October, well above the industry average of 85 days and Toyota Motor’s 35 days, according to market researcher Cox Automotive.
Nissan’s stock has fallen 47 per cent since Makoto Uchida became CEO on Dec 1, 2019, underperforming Japan’s Topix by more than 100 percentage points.
Stephen Ma joined Nissan in 1996 in North America and worked in financial roles in China and Japan before being promoted to CFO in December of 2019.

site_title: TikTok Shop triples Black Friday sales, topping US$100 million
summary: TikTok's US shopping sales tripled to over $100 million on Black Friday, surpassing expectations, despite a looming ban under a new law signed by President Joe Biden. The app's e-commerce feature, TikTok Shop, saw a 165% annual increase in shoppers for the two days between Black Friday and Cyber Monday. This surge in sales comes as ByteDance, TikTok's owner, aims to increase its US e-commerce arm to $17.5 billion, with the US being a key focus for the company.

images.alt_text: Influencers on Chinese shopping app Douyin entice shoppers with deep discounts.
US President-elect Donald Trump, who has suggested publicly that he thinks a TikTok ban is a bad idea, could try to thwart a law signed by President Joe Biden.
Platforms such as Facebook, TikTok and Instagram would be held responsible for enforcing the age ban and face potentially hefty fines for failing to do so.
Canada has banned the TikTok app from government-issued devices, saying it presents an unacceptable level of risk to privacy and security.

site_title: Musk’s xAI plans massive expansion of AI supercomputer in Memphis
summary: Elon Musk's AI startup xAI plans to expand its Memphis supercomputer, Colossus, to house at least 1 million GPUs, a significant increase from the current 100,000. The expansion aims to compete with rival OpenAI, with Nvidia and Dell establishing operations in Memphis. The move is part of xAI's efforts to train its chatbot, Grok, and solidify its position in the AI market. The expansion is expected to bring in new jobs and investment to the region, further solidifying Memphis' position as a hub for AI innovation.

site_title: Oil slips ahead of Opec+ decision on production cuts
summary: Oil prices fell nearly 2% on Wednesday as investors awaited an Opec+ decision on production cuts. Brent crude futures dropped US$1.31, or 1.78%, to settle at US$72.31 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell US$1.40, or 2%, to US$68.54. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies are likely to extend output cuts until the end of the first quarter of next year, according to industry sources.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in global demand and rising output outside the group pose hurdles to the plan to begin unwinding output cuts and have weighed on prices.
Brent crude futures posted their biggest gains in two weeks, rising by US$1.79, or 2.5 per cent, to settle at US$73.62 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Chinese billionaire’s RoyalFlush trading app is big winner of stimulus
summary: Chinese billionaire Yi Zheng, founder of RoyalFlush trading app, has added $6 billion to his wealth since China's stimulus package in September, boosting his net worth to $9.2 billion. The app has seen its shares more than double this year, making it one of the best-performing companies in half a decade. The stimulus package, which included interest rate cuts and incentives to buy homes, has led to a surge in trading volume and demand for financial information from retail investors.

images.alt_text: BlackRock is looking to expand from public stocks and bonds into private markets as demand for the asset class surges.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, Hong Fok, OKH
summary: CapitaLand Investment's self-storage platform Extra Space Asia partners with Japan's largest indoor self-storage manager Ambitious, expanding its portfolio in Japan by leveraging Ambitious's operations. This partnership brings Extra Space Asia's total self-storage assets in Japan to 14, spanning over 60,000 square feet. Hong Fok's property developer, Super Homes, acquires five ground-floor units in Singapore's International Building for S$27.8 million.

site_title: South Korea’s Yoon names new defence minister after botched martial law
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol has accepted the resignation of Defence Minister Kim Yong-hyun after he advised Yoon to declare martial law, which was lifted following a parliament vote demanding its reversal. Yoon has nominated Choi Byung Hyuk, a former army general and ambassador to Saudi Arabia, as the new defence minister. The nomination was confirmed by Yoon's office, praising Choi for his dedication and adherence to regulations. The move comes after a botched attempt to impose martial law, highlighting the challenges facing Yoon's administration.

images.alt_text: People attend a candlelight vigil condemning South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's surprise declaration of martial law last night, which was reversed hours later, and to call for his resignation.
South Korea’s opposition lawmakers have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon.
Protestors calling for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 4 after he imposted martial law.
Prime Minister Han Duck-soo (above) will step in to perform presidential duties if the President Yoon quits or is removed from office.
South Korean lawmakers submit an impeachment motion against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol at the National Assembly in Seoul. The vote could come as soon as Friday.
Protesters call for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol during a demonstration in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024.

Cho Kuk, leader of the minor opposition Rebuilding Korea Party, lawmakers and people attend a rally to condemn South Korean President’s surprise declaration of martial law last night and to call for his resignation at the national assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024.
The Korea Exchange in Seoul. South Korea's currency recovered, while its stocks fell in early trading on Dec 4 after President Yook Suk Yeol briefly declared martial law.

site_title: US CFTC relief reaches record US$17.1 billion with crypto crackdown
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has reached a record $17.1 billion in fines and investor relief, largely due to its crackdown on defunct crypto exchange FTX and its sister hedge fund Alameda Research. The regulator ordered $8.7 billion in restitution, $4 billion in disgorgement, and $2.85 billion in fines and relief for Binance and founder Zhao Changpeng. This marks the largest in CFTC history, with enforcement director Ian McGinley stating the agency will prioritize strong enforcement to deter future misconduct.

site_title: Disney boosts dividend 33% after achieving streaming profit
summary: Disney boosts dividend 33% after achieving streaming profit, raising annual payout to $1 per share. The two 50 US cent instalments will be distributed in January and July 2025. The move comes after Disney forecast earnings growth for the next three years and posted its second consecutive profit from its streaming TV business. The dividend increase follows a turnaround plan implemented two years ago, after Disney suspended its dividend in 2020 due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A martphone with displayed "Disney" logo is seen in front of displayed "Streaming service" words in this illustration taken March 24, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Robinhood to launch in Asia in 2025 with Singapore HQ
summary: Robinhood is set to launch in Asia in 2025, with Singapore as its local base, CEO Vlad Tenev announced. The expansion follows the company's efforts to grow beyond its home market, where trading activity has waned since the pandemic. Robinhood plans to offer its services across Asia and has approval to expand its product offering in the UK. The move comes as competitors like China's Tiger Brokers and Futu Holdings expand internationally, intensifying competition in the industry.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are digital tokens designed to keep a constant value.
Robinhood is now aiming to evolve into a comprehensive financial services provider and compete with established brokerages catering to institutional clients.
Robinhood and other brokerages are vying for customer loyalty after the pandemic prompted many novice investors to look into capital markets.

site_title: Futureproofing business resilience through good governance
summary: Singapore business leaders can strengthen their resilience and sustainable growth by prioritizing good governance, according to a study by Black Sun Global and the Singapore Institute of Directors. Companies with strong governance practices, such as seasoned CEOs, transparent executive pay, and balanced governance structures, tend to perform better in uncertain market conditions. Embedding environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles into core business strategies can also drive sustainable growth, as seen in the upcoming Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) climate reporting requirements. By elevating governance as a core component of their strategy, Singapore leaders can lead the next wave of innovation and growth.

images.alt_text: Good governance creates a structured, transparent environment where trust and accountability can thrive, and – for SMEs in particular – acts as a strategic enabler that facilitates growth, enhances resilience and protects their reputation.
From left: Kerry Mok, president & CEO, Sats; Stephen Ho, CEO, Hong Leong Asia; and Lim See Wah, chairman & CEO, Hyphens Pharma Intl.

site_title: Metropolitan YMCA raises more than S$200,000 for outreach programmes
summary: The Metropolitan YMCA (MYMCA) raised more than S$200,000 at its fundraising gala, exceeding its target and matching the amount with Tote Board. The funds will support over 2,000 vulnerable seniors, youth, and low-income families through various programmes, including M.Y HomeShine, M.Y Healthy Seniors, M.Y Strong Readers, M.Y Adventure, and M.Y Manna. MYMCA aims to expand its efforts in the upcoming year, including collaborations with global YMCA teams and increased fundraising for M.Y Sports Fiesta.

images.alt_text: Ten adults with special needs and their caregivers hike the 100-km long MacLehose Trail in Hong Kong.

site_title: Trump picks crypto-friendly lawyer to head US securities regulator
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump nominated Paul Atkins, a veteran Washington attorney and former SEC commissioner, to head the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Atkins, who founded a risk consultancy firm with clients in the banking, trading, and cryptocurrency industries, has been co-chairman of the Digital Chamber of Commerce since 2017. The nomination is seen as a positive move for the cryptocurrency industry, which has been critical of outgoing SEC Chair Gary Gensler's hostile stance. Atkins' appointment is expected to bring a more "common sense" approach to regulations, according to Trump.

images.alt_text: The total was the largest in CFTC history, the regulator said in its annual report.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4 per cent higher at 517.45 points and notched its fifth straight session of advances, with retail stocks leading sectoral advances by 2.2 per cent.
The job cuts are due to be implemented by mid-2026.
People attend a candlelight vigil condemning South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's surprise declaration of martial law last night, which was reversed hours later, and to call for his resignation.

site_title: Norway’s home prices gain for fourth straight month
summary: Norway's home prices have gained for the fourth consecutive month, exceeding the central bank's projection of a 0.2% increase. The seasonally-adjusted 0.4% gain in November adds to a streak of gains every month this year, bar July, and suggests lower odds of an interest rate cut before March. The housing market has largely defied post-pandemic declines, reaching new peaks since the spring, driven mainly by a shortage of supply.

site_title: Global and Singapore outlooks stay stable, but threats are on the rise
summary: DBS economist Chua Han Teng expects steady-to-lower interest rates globally in 2025, with inflation easing due to post-pandemic relief and commodity price stabilization. The US Federal Reserve has already reduced rates by 75 basis points, and DBS predicts further rate cuts to around 3.5%. Singapore's economy is expected to remain stable, with a 2.8% GDP growth rate, driven by external-oriented sectors such as manufacturing and trade-related services. However, the incoming US president Donald Trump's protectionist policies introduce uncertainty, posing a risk to the global economy and Singapore's trade-dependent economy.

images.alt_text: Daryl Ho, senior investment strategist at DBS, is optimistic about fixed-income assets.

site_title: Hong Fok acquires five units at International Building for S$27.8 million
summary: Property developer Hong Fok Corporation has acquired five ground-floor units at International Building in Orchard Road for S$27.8 million, bringing the group's ownership of the 12-storey commercial building to 100%. The units were bought on a 999-year lease from two third-party vendors and will be funded through internal resources and external borrowings. The acquisition is expected to be completed in February 2025.

site_title: US private sector adds fewer jobs than expected: ADP
summary: US private sector employment grew by 146,000 jobs in November, lower than the expected 170,000, according to ADP data. Manufacturing was particularly weak, with a 26,000 job loss. However, wage growth for existing workers rose to 4.8% and for new hires to 7.2%. Despite this, the US economy remains resilient, and the Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts are expected to give the economy a boost. The data follows a revision to October's job growth figure, which was lower than initially reported.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, had risen 372,000 to 7.744 million by the last day of October.

site_title: How not to react to Donald Trump
summary: Progressives and liberals have reacted poorly to Donald Trump's victory, with some blaming neoliberalism and others denying the election results. The author argues that these reactions are empirically shaky and politically self-defeating, as they fail to address the underlying issues of identity and respect. The problem lies not in the economic policies, but in the political diagnosis, which failed to understand the motivations of Trump's supporters. The author suggests that liberals and progressives need to engage in serious thinking, rather than Pavlovian calls to "abandon neoliberalism", to address the crisis of identity and respect that is driving the rise of populists like Trump.

images.alt_text: A Trump victory parade in West Palm Beach, Florida, on Nov 17, 2024. What’s fuelling the protest vote in America is an erosion of faith in the economic future.
Blaming “neo-liberalism” for the political earthquakes that may, among other events, lead to the election of far-right politician Marine Le Pen in France, sounds like an appealing theory.
