site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors await economic data, Powell comments
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 235.5 points, or 0.53%, to 44,941.05, as investors awaited economic data and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also hit all-time highs, with the S&P 500 rising 19.5 points, or 0.32%, to 6,069.39, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 106.6 points, or 0.55%, to 19,587.477.

site_title: No child’s play: Kiztopia looks to build indoor playground empire in South-east Asia
summary: Kiztopia, a children's playground and edutainment brand, has received a significant investment from Singapore-based private equity firm Tower Capital Asia, set to fuel its growth in South-east Asia. With 16 indoor playgrounds across five markets, Kiztopia aims to expand further, with plans to open outlets in Malaysia, Indonesia, and Taiwan. The company expects revenue to grow by 15-20% for the next financial year, driven by its regional expansion and intellectual property licensing. CEO Heidi Tian plans to diversify and innovate, aiming to transform outlets into "one-stop destinations" with various offerings, such as retail and food and beverage.

images.alt_text: The distillery's operations include a 1,000 sq ft cellar, housing more than 100 barrels, says Crystalla Huang, brewmaster at RedDot BrewHouse.

site_title: What makes the US truly exceptional
summary: The US stands out as both a prosperous and brutal country, with a homicide rate 6.8 times higher than the UK's and 30 times that of Japan in 2021. Despite its large deficit in its capital account, the US has persistently run high levels of innovation and economic dynamism. However, its high crime rate, incarceration rate, and poor health outcomes, including maternal and child mortality, are indicative of low welfare. The article raises questions about whether the US's pathologies are necessary for its economic dynamism and whether the country's decline in social cohesion and democratic institutions threatens its legacy as a beacon of prosperity and freedom.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Capitol building is pictured on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., April 23, 2024. REUTERS/Julia Nikhinson/File Photo
American exceptionalism seems to be fading

site_title: DBS sees risk assets in ‘sweet spot’ as inflation moderates and rate cuts loom
summary: DBS senior investment strategist Daryl Ho sees the current economic environment as a "sweet spot" for risk assets, driven by moderating inflation and potential interest rate cuts. He is optimistic about equities and bonds, citing a favorable risk-reward balance and expectations of further easing inflation. Gold has also emerged as a standout performer, with prices up 28% year-to-date. Ho advocates for a diversified and balanced portfolio, balancing quality growth assets with income generators, and expects steady returns despite market uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Inflation in Asia, which has been more supply-side driven, has eased, says DBS economist Chua Han Teng.

site_title: Opec+ likely to extend oil cuts
summary: OPEC+ is likely to extend its oil production cuts by at least three months, potentially through the first half of 2025, to support the oil market amid a slowdown in global demand and rising output outside the group. The group, which pumps half the world's oil, had planned to begin unwinding cuts in January. The decision aims to provide additional support and address a 300,000 bpd output hike for the UAE, which is scheduled to start in January 2025.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures posted their biggest gains in two weeks, rising by US$1.79, or 2.5 per cent, to settle at US$73.62 a barrel on Tuesday.
Brent crude futures settled 1 cent lower at US$71.83 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Europe: Germany’s DAX closes above 20,000 mark; France’s no-confidence vote eyed
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed 0.4% higher at 517.45 points, marking its fifth consecutive session of gains. German stocks finished above the 20,000 mark, while France's CAC 40 rose 0.6% ahead of a no-confidence vote in parliament. The vote is expected to oust Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government, which is struggling to address a massive budget deficit. The euro zone's business activity fell sharply, and France's services sector data showed political uncertainty weighing on the CAC 40, which is down 3% this year.

images.alt_text: All three major indices scored records on Wednesday, led by the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which finished above 45,000 for the first time.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, December 4, 2024
summary: South Korea's shares fell at the close amid ongoing political tensions, while Asia markets showed mixed results. Australia's economic growth remains tepid, challenging the Reserve Bank of Australia. ExxonMobil is considering the sale of its Singapore petrol stations for US$1 billion. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% amid these regional trading developments.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) was up slightly by 8.98 points or 0.2 per cent at 3,795.11 as at 9.01 am when the market opened on Wednesday.
The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.
Selling gathered pace through Wednesday afternoon to send the Aussie down 1 per cent to US$0.6422, breaking support at US$0.6443.
ExxonMobil is said to be eyeing the sale of its petrol stations in Singapore for US$1 billion.

site_title: Global effects of the Canadian longshoremen strike
summary: A strike by International Longshore and Warehouse Union Local 514 members at the Port of Vancouver in November 2024 has sent shockwaves through global supply chains, particularly those reliant on imports and exports through British Columbia. The 13-day strike has caused immediate disruptions in trade, with delayed container movements and increased dwell times. The impact is expected to extend beyond Canada's borders, affecting global supply chains, industries such as the automotive and technology sectors, and potentially leading to economic losses and government interventions. Long-term strategic shifts are anticipated, including diversification of ports, enhanced supply chain resilience, and investments in technologies to mitigate future disruptions.

images.alt_text: The Port of Montreal is closed after terminal operators shut down operations over a labour dispute with the Canadian Union of Public Employees.
On Canada’s west coast, a separate labour dispute is already disrupting an estimated C$800 million of activity per day.

site_title: JPMorgan to sponsor Arsenal FC’s ultra-luxury VIP lounge
summary: JPMorgan Chase has announced a sponsorship deal with Arsenal FC, becoming the first sponsor of the ultra-luxury Diamond Club, a VIP lounge at the Emirates Stadium in London. The lounge, named after a deceased director, features heated seats and blankets and hosts wealthy fans who pay tens of thousands of pounds a season to watch the team in luxury surroundings. JPMorgan's branding will be visible during tonight's match against Manchester United FC. The deal is the latest in a series of high-profile sponsorships by the US banking giant.

site_title: US services sector activity takes breather in November
summary: The US services sector activity slowed in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's nonmanufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) falling to 52.1, down from 56 in October. Despite the decline, the sector remains above growth levels, indicating solid economic growth in the fourth quarter. Consumer spending and construction spending rose, but business spending on equipment may have softened. The economy is expected to retain momentum from the third quarter, with a forecasted 3.2% annualized GDP growth rate.

Job openings, a measure of labour demand, had risen 372,000 to 7.744 million by the last day of October.
The Institute for Supply Management (ISM) said on Monday (Dec 2) its manufacturing PMI increased to 48.4 last month from 46.5 in October, which was the lowest level since July 2023.

site_title: Thailand to extend production timeframe for battery EVs
summary: Thailand extends its production timeframe for battery electric vehicles (BEVs) and offers incentives for hybrid EVs to support the struggling auto industry amid stagnant domestic market and economic challenges. The new incentive package requires local production of 1.5 vehicles for each imported vehicle in 2025, up from 1 vehicle in 2024. The move aims to avoid oversupply and support the industry, which has seen a wave of Chinese EV investments and faces tight credit conditions.

images.alt_text: Thailand has long been a hub for automaking and export, dominated by Japanese brands such as Toyota Motor and Honda Motor, which are also members of Evat.

The cut in sales forecast is bad news for Chinese makers such as BYD and Great Wall Motor, which have just started producing locally made cars this year after investing in factories to capitalise on Thai government incentives to drive adoption of new-energy vehicles.
The Hyundai factory, to be located just southeast of the capital city of Bangkok, will start production in 2026, according to a BOI statement.

Jensen Huang, CEO and founder of Nvidia, said that the data stored on Thailand’s sovereign cloud server could be used to power a local “AI ecosystem”, such as a generative AI chatbot fed by Thai data.
A view of Bangkok's port along Chao Phraya River is photographed during sunset in Bangkok, Thailand, July 19, 2022. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
At 0.95 per cent, Thailand's headline CPI was below the central bank’s target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent.
CEO and founder of Nvidia Jensen Huang met with Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra while on a visit to Bangkok, and the two agreed to deepen cooperation on artificial intelligence.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde sees weak growth, dominated by downside risks
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned of weak economic growth in the eurozone, citing slowing services and manufacturing sectors. The medium-term outlook is uncertain, with downside risks dominating, including geopolitical threats and trade barriers. Inflation is expected to rise in the final quarter of 2024 but will then fall back to target next year. The ECB is set to cut interest rates again on December 12, with economists predicting a 25 basis point rate cut.

images.alt_text: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), during the annual meetings of the IMF and World Bank in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2024. The International Monetary Fund lowered its global growth forecast for next year and warned of accelerating risks from wars to trade protectionism, even as it credited central banks for taming inflation without sending nations into recession. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: South Korean parliament introduces motion to impeach President Yoon; ruling party opposes
summary: South Korea's parliament introduced a motion to impeach President Yoon Suk-yeol over his surprise declaration of martial law, which was reversed hours later. The ruling People Power Party opposes the move, requiring support from at least eight party lawmakers to pass the bill. If successful, Yoon would be the second South Korean president to be impeached since 2017, and a new election would be held within 60 days if he resigned or was removed from office.

images.alt_text: Protestors calling for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol on Dec 4 after he imposted martial law.
Prime Minister Han Duck-soo (above) will step in to perform presidential duties if the President Yoon quits or is removed from office.
South Korea’s opposition lawmakers have filed a motion to impeach President Yoon.

Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.
South Korean lawmakers submit an impeachment motion against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol at the National Assembly in Seoul. The vote could come as soon as Friday.
Protesters call for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol during a demonstration in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024.

Cho Kuk, leader of the minor opposition Rebuilding Korea Party, lawmakers and people attend a rally to condemn South Korean President’s surprise declaration of martial law last night and to call for his resignation at the national assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024.

The announcement came after Finance Minister Choi Sang Mok and Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang Yong held emergency meetings overnight, and ahead of the BOK’s extraordinary meeting session abruptly scheduled for 9 am local time (0000 GMT) on Wednesday.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol did not cite any specific threat from the nuclear-armed North, instead focusing on his domestic political opponents.

site_title: Euro steady ahead of French no-confidence vote, won roiled by political crisis
summary: The euro remains steady ahead of a vote by French lawmakers on no-confidence motions, which are likely to oust Prime Minister Michel Barnier's fragile coalition. The vote is expected to deepen the political crisis in France and weigh on the euro, which has fallen since Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar tumbled to a four-month low due to slowing economic growth, while South Korea's won rebounded after President Yoon Suk Yeol backed down from declaring martial law.

images.alt_text: The euro, which had been the weakest G10 currency through November, began this month with a 0.7 per cent fall on Monday and was last up 0.2 per cent at US$1.05185.

site_title: From cheesecakes to quantum computing – panellists explore opportunities in the Johor-Singapore SEZ
summary: A panel discussion at DBS' Market Outlook 2025 – Beyond New Frontiers event explored opportunities in the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). The JS-SEZ is expected to deliver key infrastructure upgrades, including new data centers, office and logistics spaces, and renewable energy capacity. Singapore businesses can lower operational costs by relocating to Johor, and the zone may unlock opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through generative AI and collaboration with Malaysia. The discussion also touched on the implications of US President-elect Donald Trump's second term, with potential tariffs and taxes disrupting supply chains and urging businesses to diversify suppliers and broaden customer bases.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO clashes with workers as conflict over closures, pay deepens
summary: Volkswagen CEO Oliver Blume clashed with workers during a staff meeting, where he pushed for major cuts and plant closures to respond to Chinese competition. Workers, however, described these measures as red lines, threatening further strikes. The meeting was attended by German Labour Minister Hubertus Heil, who urged all sides to find a solution excluding plant closures. A fourth round of talks is set for December 9, with workers warning of increased pressure if no agreement is reached, potentially leading to longer and open-ended strikes.

images.alt_text: In Germany, unions often organise warning strikes – or temporary walkouts – to put pressure on management when wage negotiations are deadlocked.

The Volkswagen logo is displayed on the Volkswagen power plant on the day when Volkswagen AG and the industrial union IG Metall started talks over a new labor agreement for six of its German plants, in Wolfsburg, Germany, September 25, 2024. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

Employees carry out quality control tests as strip lights illuminate Volkswagen Phaeton automobiles at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Thursday, April 9, 2015. German industrial production was bolstered by investment-goods output in February, highlighting improved confidence in the recovery in Europe's largest economy. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Bankers can expect a bumper bonus after standout year, but hopefully it won’t be an obscene sum
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have reported record-breaking profits for the first nine months of 2024, with DBS' net profit reaching S$8.8 billion and OCBC's at S$5.9 billion. Their share prices have also hit multi-year peaks, with DBS and UOB experiencing total returns of 52.9% and 36.4%, respectively. However, Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters cautions that bumper bonuses may not be expected, as the banks' performance is driven by factors such as interest rates rather than exceptional earnings.

images.alt_text: In MAS' annual Financial Stability Review, it noted that the overall banking sector maintained or improved across the indicators for financial vulnerability.

The question that should be asked, both by index providers and the committee set up to study ways to inject more interest in local stocks, is whether to stick with the STI in its current form with such a lopsided dependence on the banks and property, or to revamp it to ensure broader coverage and adequate diversification.
DBS has raised its dividend payout and will also roll out a S$3 billion share buyback programme.

site_title: Co-working operators seek closer ties with landlords as new flex space take-up falls to five-year low
summary: Co-working operators in Singapore have slowed their expansion plans due to a cautious stance and increased competition. Flexible space take-up fell to its lowest in five years in 2024, with 45,000 square feet taken up, down from 700,000 in 2019. Landlords are also adopting a more cautious approach, with some co-working operators opting for asset-light strategies. Despite this, the flexible workspace market remains stable, with a 1% marginal expansion in the third quarter of 2024. Landlords are partnering with co-working operators or developing their own co-working spaces to meet tenants' needs.

images.alt_text: Since WeWork’s bankruptcy filing, TEC has been approached by 17 WeWork landlords across TEC’s 33 markets,  says founder and chief executive officer Paul Salnikow. TEC operates eight centres in Singapore

site_title: New Zealand house prices fell a ninth straight month in November
summary: New Zealand house prices fell 0.4% in November, marking a ninth consecutive month of decline. The average two-year mortgage rate dropped to 5.69% in October, but prices still dropped 3.5% from a year earlier. Economists attribute the slowdown to concerns over the sluggish economy and rising unemployment, despite interest rate cuts. The Reserve Bank projects a modest recovery in the economy and a 7.1% increase in house prices in 2025.

images.alt_text: New Zealand property prices have reflected a slump in confidence among buyers as the economy cools and rising unemployment begins to impact household incomes.

The residential property market has been buffeted by the Reserve Bank’s tight monetary policy, which pushed up home loan interest rates, and a flood of listings that allowed buyers to be more selective.

site_title: PM Wong named secretary-general of PAP
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has been named the new secretary-general of the People's Action Party, succeeding Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Desmond Choo, Lam Pin Min, Ng Chee Meng, and Sim Ann were also co-opted as additional members on Dec 4. The party's Central Executive Committee elected office holders, with PM Wong vowing to have the government's 'full confidence and support' in its mission to stay relevant.

site_title: Apple facing hurdles in adapting Baidu AI models for China, The Information reports
summary: Apple and Baidu are working to integrate Baidu's large language models into iPhones sold in China, but face challenges such as understanding prompts and accuracy in responding to common scenarios. The companies are adapting Baidu's AI models for iPhone users, but no immediate comment was provided. This effort aims to address criticism of iPhone 16's lack of AI features in China, potentially impacting phone sales.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man sits next to an iPhone 16 advertisement as the new iPhone 16 series smartphones go on sale at an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept. 20, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Apple is also facing at least three complaints from a US labour board claiming it has illegally deterred employees from discussing issues.
As the largest foreign phone maker in China’s smartphone-dominated market, Apple’s performance plays a significant role in the overall data on foreign-branded phone sales in the country.
Apple and its rivals will ship 6.2 per cent more phones or an estimated 1.24 billion units in 2024.
Tim Cook has promised to keep investing in the country and also underscored its vital role in the iPhone maker’s global operations.

site_title: GM sees US$5 billion hit to restructure troubled China business
summary: General Motors (GM) expects to write down the value of its joint-venture operations in China by $2.9 billion and incur $2.7 billion in charges to close factories and restructure its operations. The moves follow years of decline in the Chinese market, which has seen domestic automakers thrive with government subsidies and new models. The charges and writedowns are part of GM's efforts to salvage its business in the world's largest car market, despite a $347 million loss in China through the first nine months of this year.

images.alt_text: GM still has 50 per cent ownership along with LG in Ultium Cells, which owns the existing two battery plants in Ohio and Tennessee.
GM has one of its four North American plants making large pickup trucks in Silao, Mexico, with much of its production coming to the US.
FILE PHOTO: The new GM logo is seen on the facade of the General Motors headquarters in Detroit, Michigan, U.S., March 16, 2021. .  REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo
The move comes as GM shifts its approach from a one-type-fits-all battery strategy for its EVs.

site_title: Consortium proposes HK$55.2 billion privatisation of Hong Kong-listed ESR
summary: A consortium led by Starwood Capital Group, Sixth Street Partners, and SSW Partners has made a HK$55.2 billion (S$9.5 billion) offer to take Hong Kong-listed real estate fund manager ESR Group private at HK$13 per share. This is nearly triple ESR's unaudited net tangible asset value. Shareholders can choose to roll their shares into an unlisted investment holding company, EquityCo, or a mix of both options. The proposed privatisation, if successful, would be the largest on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2021 and transform ESR into an asset-light platform.

images.alt_text: ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.
ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.
ESR Group aims to appoint a full-time independent chairman by the first quarter of 2025.

site_title: Nvidia signs deal to help build Thai ‘sovereign cloud’
summary: US chip giant Nvidia signed a partnership with Thai tech company SIAM.AI to build Thailand's first "sovereign cloud", a cloud server controlled by the country. The deal aims to develop artificial intelligence in Thailand, with Nvidia supporting the development of AI infrastructure and data storage. The sovereign cloud can be used to power a local AI ecosystem, such as a generative AI chatbot fed by Thai data. Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang emphasized the importance of data belonging to the Thai people, and the partnership is seen as a step towards increasing Thailand's tech sector capabilities.

images.alt_text: Jensen Huang, CEO and founder of Nvidia, which makes chips used to train artificial intelligence technology, speaks with members of the media during the Siam.AI Cloud event in Bangkok on December 4, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Thai business group sees GDP growth at 2.8% this year, risks ahead
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 2.8% this year, driven by stronger exports and government spending. Exports are projected to rise 4% this year, up from previous forecasts, thanks to a strong baht. However, the economy faces risks, including a potential trade war, and may be impacted by floods that could cost up to $2.5 billion. Despite this, growth is expected to accelerate to 4% in the final quarter of the year and further next year.

images.alt_text: At 0.95 per cent, Thailand's headline CPI was below the central bank’s target range of 1 per cent to 3 per cent.

site_title: Political drama hits South Korean markets with investors likely to stay cautious
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's declaration of martial law on Tuesday led to a 1.4% decline in the Kospi index, with Samsung, Hyundai Motor, and Lotte experiencing losses. The decree was lifted within hours, but opposition lawmakers filed a motion to impeach Yoon, exacerbating market uncertainty. Foreign investors, already concerned about US tariffs, have been exiting South Korean stocks, with outflows reaching over $14 billion in four months. Asian markets were largely unaffected, but Singapore businesses are monitoring the situation and preparing for potential changes.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.
Market updates for Wednesday.
Prime Minister Han Duck-soo (above) will step in to perform presidential duties if the President Yoon quits or is removed from office.

South Korean lawmakers submit an impeachment motion against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol at the National Assembly in Seoul. The vote could come as soon as Friday.
The Korea Exchange in Seoul. South Korea's currency recovered, while its stocks fell in early trading on Dec 4 after President Yook Suk Yeol briefly declared martial law.

site_title: Bitcoin churns near US$97,000 as crypto awaits Trump’s next step
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's election has led to a 40% surge in Bitcoin's value, trading near $97,000, as investors anticipate further support for the crypto sector. Trump has promised to make the US the global home of crypto and has backed a strategic national Bitcoin reserve. His transition team is discussing the creation of a White House post dedicated to digital-asset policy, and crypto-friendly candidates are vying for key regulatory roles. This optimism has led to increased engagement with the market on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Crypto mining stocks have underperformed this year after the reward for mining Bitcoin was cut in half in April.
Bitcoin surges past key US$100,000 resistance as optimism gathers pace following Donald Trump's victory.

site_title: South Korea cabinet ministers offer to resign en masse: local newspaper reports
summary: South Korea's cabinet ministers are reportedly offering to resign en masse after President Yoon Suk Yeol's withdrawal of a martial law declaration. The move comes amid growing discontent with the government. Prime Minister Han Duck Soo is set to meet with the ruling party leadership to discuss the ministers' resignation. The development follows a tumultuous period in South Korean politics, with protesters calling for Yoon's resignation. The exact outcome of the meeting with the prime minister is unclear.

site_title: Bank Indonesia says it’s ready to intervene to steady rupiah
summary: Bank Indonesia is prepared to intervene in the currency market to stabilize the Indonesian rupiah, which has weakened towards the psychological level of 16,000 per US dollar. The central bank has previously stated that the currency's fundamental level is stronger than 16,000 per US dollar. Recent outflows, including a $1.7 billion pullout from Indonesia's stock market, are contributing to the rupiah's decline. Despite inflation remaining within the central bank's target band, the weak rupiah may keep Bank Indonesia on hold at its December meeting.

site_title: Warburg-backed BW Industrial is pursuing future Vietnam IPO
summary: BW Industrial, a logistics and industrial property developer backed by Warburg Pincus, is pursuing a potential initial public offering (IPO) in Vietnam, with market conditions dictating timing. Despite concerns over US tariffs, the company has seen no decline in leasing inquiries and has hosted more site visits from manufacturers. BW Industrial is well-funded, with plans to lease 1.2 million square meters of industrial space in 2024. The company aims to keep pace with construction of a million square meters of industrial leasing land a year.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong property market’s continuing struggles stemming from the city’s sluggish economy and changing demographics.
In Seattle, roughly 25 per cent of downtown office space was vacant in the third quarter, according to data from brokerage CBRE Group.
There are good reasons to invest in the groups building new condos instead of buying new condos for investment.

site_title: Eurozone business activity declines sharply in November: PMI
summary: The eurozone's business activity declined sharply in November, with the services sector contracting for the first time since January, according to a PMI survey. The composite PMI fell to 48.3, below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. Demand fell steeply, with new business index dropping to 46.8, but services firms increased hiring, with the employment index rising to 51. This broad-based decline is bad news for overall growth prospects, especially in the top-three euro economies.

images.alt_text: Foreign demand for European goods will worsen if President-elect Donald Trump imposes a 10 per cent tariff on all imports as proposed.
Consumers became more pessimistic on growth, as expectations for the next 12 months fell to -1.1 per cent from -0.9 per cent seen in September, the ECB said.
The composite new business index fell to 46.6 from 47.9, its lowest reading this year, suggesting no imminent improvement.

site_title: NXP, TSMC affiliate plan to expand US$7.8 billion Singapore plant
summary: NXP Semiconductors and its Taiwanese partner Vanguard International Semiconductor (VIS) are planning to expand their US$7.8 billion Singapore plant, a move to diversify chip production amid growing US-China tensions. The partners broke ground on a new facility, with an additional phase two expansion in the works. NXP executive vice-president Andy Micallef mentioned the expansion, but noted it has yet to be formally approved. The move comes as tensions between the US and China intensify, with the Biden administration imposing curbs on Chinese access to foreign technologies and Beijing retaliating with export bans.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for TSMC declined to comment beyond saying it was a “law-abiding company...committed to complying with all applicable rules and regulations, including applicable export controls.”
NXP Semiconductors is in talks with the automotive sector and other industries in India, where it has four semiconductor design centres, with about 3,000 employees.
By 2029, the factory is expected to produce 55,000 300 mm wafers per month and supply proportional capacity to its two equity partners.

site_title: What is martial law, and how does it affect South Korea’s business and economic activity?
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol briefly declared martial law, the first time since 1979, in response to emergencies. The declaration led to a slump in South Korean shares and a drop in the country's currency, the won, despite a brief recovery. The imposition of martial law can hurt investor sentiment and consumer confidence due to the suspension of civil liberties, censorship of media, and curfews. This can lead to a decrease in discretionary spending, disruptions to supply chains, and uncertainty in banking functions. The uncertainty has sparked calls for Yoon's resignation or impeachment.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.

site_title: Hong Kong mega development plan to devour villages, wetlands
summary: Hong Kong's government has approved a plan to develop a massive tech zone, known as the Northern Metropolis, which will transform 30,000 hectares of land along the border with mainland China. The project, which aims to deepen integration with mainland China, will house 2.5 million people and provide 500,000 new jobs, but has sparked widespread opposition from locals and environmentalists. The development will destroy villages, including the 100-year-old Ha Wan Tsuen, and damage a protected wetland area, prompting concerns over the project's environmental impact.

images.alt_text: The government first introduced the idea to take back part of the site in 2019 to help solve the city’s housing crisis as the property market was overheated.

Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan updated the deficit forecast at a legislative council meeting after taking into account proceeds from bond issuance, RTHK reported without explaining the change.
Hong Kong retail sales fell to HK$32.9 billion (S$5.7 billion) in an eighth consecutive month of decline after a 6.9 per cent slump in September and 10 per cent decline in August.

site_title: Christmas in style
summary: BT Luxe's Christmas issue drops on Dec 6, featuring personalities sharing reflections on the year and Christmases past and current. The issue includes travel guides, interviews with lifestyle experts and designers, and a Christmas Wish List with luxury gifts. Featured individuals include Glenn Yong, Tjin Lee, Jonathan Wong, Sacha Leong, and Andre Chiang, showcasing their experiences and gift lists. The issue aims to get readers in the festive mood with a colourful spread of holiday reads.

hyluxeglenn5 - Glenn Yong for BT Luxe.

site_title: South Korea’s political turmoil casts shadow over Asean trade and investment
summary: South Korea's ongoing political turmoil casts a shadow over Asean trade and investment, with foreign companies potentially delaying investment plans due to business stability concerns. Despite this, South Korea's FDI into Asean is expected to remain stable, with strategic sectors such as chips, batteries, and transportation remaining a priority. The country's close trade ties with Asean, valued at $196.6 billion in 2023, and its significant FDI flows into the region, totaling $10.9 billion, suggest that the impact on trade and investment will be limited.

images.alt_text: South Korea's main opposition Democratic Party leader Lee Jae-myung looks on as people hold placards that read "Step down President Yoon Suk Yeol" and "Investigate his act of rebellion immediately", at a rally to condemn South Korean President’s surprise declarations of the martial law last night and to call for his resignation, at the national assembly in Seoul, South Korea, December 4, 2024. site_title: Thai November headline inflation misses forecast, below central bank target
summary: Thailand's headline consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.95% in November, below the central bank's target range of 1-3%. This is the lowest inflation rate in 12 months, driven by higher food and energy prices. The core CPI was up 0.80% in November, slightly above forecast. The Bank of Thailand projects headline inflation to be 1.2-1.3% in December and 0.4-0.5% for the full year, with a target range of 0.3-1.3% for 2025.

images.alt_text: Rubber sap oozes from a tree at a plantation in Chawang district, Nakhon Si Thammarat province, Thailand, on Thursday, Jan. 31, 2019. Thailand is the world's largest rubber producer and exporter. The roughly one in 10 Thais who depend on the rubber trade are suffering after global prices fell 65 percent since 2011, the last time the Southeast Asian nation held a credible vote. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: Thai baht notes are seen at a Kasikornbank in Bangkok, Thailand, May 12, 2016. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Global tech players are stepping up the building of data centres to meet the demand for infrastructure and computing power to enable AI.
Bank of Thailand Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput also said debt support measures would be announced next week.

An aerial view shows houses surrounded by floodwaters after heavy rain in Tumpat, Malaysia's Kelantan state on December 2, 2024. More than 122,000 people have been forced out of their homes as massive floods caused by relentless rains swept through Malaysia's northern states, disaster management officials said on November 30. (Photo by MOHD RASFAN / AFP)
More than 13,000 people had been forced to flee their homes, with temporary shelters set up in schools and temples.

site_title: ESR buyout group close to making US$7 billion binding bid: sources
summary: A consortium of investment firms, including Starwood Capital Group and Qatar Investment Authority, is nearing a $7 billion binding bid for Hong Kong-listed ESR Group, a logistics real estate firm. The offer, valued at HK$13 per share, represents a 55% premium to ESR's undisturbed share price. Talks have been ongoing for several months, with the company's fragmented ownership being a key hurdle.

images.alt_text: ESR Cosmosquare OS1 Data Centre in Osaka, Japan. The registered name of the manager will be ESR-Reit Management from Dec 4 onwards.

site_title: Who steps in if South Korea’s president is forced out?
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol faces impeachment if he doesn't resign after imposing martial law. If he steps down, Prime Minister Han Duck-soo will assume presidential duties, as per the constitution. Han, a conservative, previously served as prime minister under President Roh Moo-hyun from 2007-2008. The opposition, led by the Democratic Party, has threatened to impeach Yoon if he doesn't resign immediately, with a two-thirds vote required in the 300-member legislature. A successor would need to be elected within 60 days if Yoon is removed from office.

images.alt_text: Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.

summary:

Singapore's HDB resale transactions declined 9.6% in November to 1,951, with prices up 0.9% and volumes in mature estates increasing 1%, while non-mature estates saw a 0.2% increase. StanChart plans to expand its affluent business in Singapore and Hong Kong, targeting US$200 billion in new assets and double-digit income growth over the next five years. Major updates to the taxi and private-hire car sector in Singapore will take effect in January.

site_title: OECD ups global growth forecast but warns of protectionism risk
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has raised its 2025 global growth forecast to 3.3% due to stronger US growth, but warns of a risk of protectionist measures sparking inflation and slowing the economy. The OECD cautioned that trade-restrictive measures could raise costs, prices, and lower growth. France and Germany downgraded their growth forecasts, citing mounting fiscal pressure. The warning comes ahead of US President Donald Trump's expected return to the White House, which may lead to increased tariffs on trading partners.

images.alt_text: The Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) logo is seen at the company's headquarters in Paris, France, on Friday, May 28, 2010. Slovenia, along with Israel and Estonia, are joining the Paris-based organization of 31 of the world's most developed economies. Photographer: Antoine Antoniol/Bloomberg

site_title: Major updates to improve taxi, private-hire car sector in Singapore effective from January
summary: Singapore's taxi and private-hire car sectors are set to undergo significant changes effective January 2025, as part of the Land Transport Authority's point-to-point sector review. Key updates include extended vehicle lifespan, new guidelines for managing disruptions, and increased transparency for operators. Taxis will have a statutory lifespan of 10 years, while private-hire car operators must inform authorities and the public of disruptions and exit plans. Smaller taxi operators will no longer be required to maintain call-booking services.

images.alt_text: The government says that having a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private hire cars is possible, but the trade-offs must be studied carefully.

Given changing travel patterns post-Covid, LTA assessed it would be able to inject up to 20,000 additional COEs across the vehicle categories over the next few years without the worries of causing traffic gridlock, said Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat.
James Ng, managing director of BYD Singapore and the Philippines, at the launch of the new version of the BYD Seal that uses a Category A Certificate of Entitlement on Wed (Jun 26).
Category B, for larger and more powerful cars, has a smaller fall of 2.7 per cent.

site_title:
Singapore investors think 
AI investments boost companies’ productivity, profitability: PwC survey
summary: Singapore investors expect generative AI to boost productivity, revenue, and profitability for the companies they invest in, with over half anticipating significant benefits. Climate action is also a priority, with 71% of respondents planning to increase investments in companies with climate-related actions. Investors value a range of data beyond financial information, including cybersecurity and supply chain management data. Notably, 84% expect businesses to upskill their workforce in tandem with AI investments, and 51% rank macroeconomic volatility as their top concern.

images.alt_text: 2024’s Financial Wellness Index score rose by 1 point to 61 points, which OCBC noted is in tandem with economic growth.

site_title: Mainstream car COE premium spikes by 4.6% to S$94,000
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for mainstream cars in Singapore increased by 4.6% to S$94,000 in December's first round of bidding, after a drop of S$10,000 in November. This marks the largest decrease in 2024. The commercial vehicle category saw a 1.9% increase, while the large-car category B decreased by 2%. In contrast, the motorcycle category D saw the largest drop, 9.1%, to S$7,878. Industry observers attributed the increase to a knee-jerk reaction in the COE market, following the significant drop in November.

images.alt_text: Category B, for larger and more powerful cars, has a smaller fall of 2.7 per cent.
The premiums for all Certificate of Entitlement categories dropped in November 2024's first round of bidding.
