site_title: Indosuez appoints new CEO for Asia
summary: Indosuez has appointed Laurent Proutiere as Asia chief executive officer and Singapore branch manager, effective March 1, 2025, subject to regulatory approval. Proutiere will succeed Omar Shokur and report to Isabelle Jacob-Nebout. He previously held the position of head of international trade and transaction banking for the Asia-Pacific at Credit Agricole Corporate & Investment Banking.

site_title: Gold steady; all eyes on US jobs data, Fed Chair’s speech
summary: Gold prices steadied at $2,644.42 per ounce, awaiting US jobs data and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech. The US ADP employment report is due later, followed by the payrolls report on Friday. Markets anticipate a shallow US rate cut cycle in 2025, but rising trade tensions and budget deficits support gold's long-term bullish trend. The Fed sees a 73% chance of a 25-basis-point rate cut this month, with 80 bps expected by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: Gold is often regarded as a safe-haven investment during periods of economic or geopolitical instability.

site_title: Arts galas show that extravagance never goes out of style
summary: Cultural galas continue to be a mainstay of fundraising for arts organisations, despite their high costs and perceived datedness. Despite rising costs and financial strain from the pandemic, most institutions feature galas as a crucial way to attract wealthy donors and reward their support. These events often feature speciality cocktails, live performers, and elaborate decor, and can bring in substantial revenue, with some institutions netting over $10 million. However, some organisations, such as the Katonah Museum of Art, are reevaluating their approach, considering alternative methods to justify high ticket prices and meet their financial needs.

images.alt_text: epa11650512 A woman looks at the works 'The Pier of Boulogne-sur-Mer' and 'Sailboats and Seagulls', by Edouard Manet, and 'Fishing Boats and The Nets of Pourville', by Claude Monet, from the new exhibition Vive l'impressionnisme! at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, 09 October 2024. The exhibition showcases the finest French Impressionist works from Dutch collections.  EPA-EFE/ROBIN VAN LONKHUIJSEN
In a room with yellow walls, three paintings are notably exhibited: two “Sunflowers”, which surround  “The Lullaby”, a painting representing a woman, seated on an armchair.

epa11547609 Recovered jewels and pieces from a burglary are on display at the Historic Green Vault (Gruenes Gewoelbe) in Dresden, Germany, 13 August 2024. Jewels that had been stolen during a burglary into Dresden's Historic Green Vault on 25 November 2019 were presented to media representatives on 13 August 2024. Despite continued seizure by the district court, it is now possible to display the jewels again in their original place.  EPA-EFE/CLEMENS BILAN
A woman looks at "Event" by Brice Marden during a media preview at Christie's, ahead of their 21st Century Evening Sale in New York City, New York, U.S., May 3, 2024. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz

site_title: YMCA’s Inclusive Challenge helps youths with special needs go beyond comfort zone
summary: The YMCA of Singapore's Inclusive Challenge, part of its Find Your Y initiative, allowed 10 youths with special needs to hike the 100-km-long MacLehose Trail in Hong Kong over five days. The challenge aimed to raise awareness that youths with special needs can overcome challenges and be more visible in the community. The event raised over S$109,000, which will be invested in community programmes for YMCA's beneficiaries. Participants, aged 22-34, with conditions such as autism spectrum disorder and Down syndrome, underwent intensive training and demonstrated resilience and determination.

images.alt_text: Isaac Thomas Komatt leads the Y Crops initiative, which allows PWDs to engage in sustainable farming practices.

site_title: Singapore’s first Olympic medallist Tan Howe Liang dies, aged 91
summary: Tan Howe Liang, Singapore's first Olympic medallist, died on Dec 3 at 91 due to pneumonia. He won a silver medal at the 1960 Rome Olympics, becoming a trailblazer in Singaporean sport. A weightlifter, Tan was born in 1933 in southern China and trained seriously in 1952. Despite financial struggles, he achieved an illustrious career, setting world records and winning gold at the Asian and SEAP Games. His legacy has inspired generations of Singaporean athletes, with his humility and kindness exemplifying the value of a true Olympian athlete.

images.alt_text: Krishnan is also known for his philanthropic efforts, having established the Yu Cai Foundation to support education among ethnic Chinese communities in Malaysia.
“Her sons Alain and Gerard, as well as the son from her second marriage Charles Gregoire, owe her everything” says Yann Kerlau in his book The Dynasties of Luxury.

The former US Army soldier, whose business began with The GI’s Guide to Travelling in Europe at 50 US cents apiece in the mid-1950s, became a household name for any vacationer seeking an affordable trip abroad.

(FILES) French singer Charles Dumont poses during a portrait session at his apartment in Paris on March 19, 2018. Musician Charles Dumont, composer of Edith Piaf's legendary "Je ne regrette rien", died in the night from November 17, 2024 to November 18, 2024 in Paris at the age of 95, his partner Florence announced to AFP. This singer-songwriter, who had also collaborated with Barbra Streisand, died following a long illness at his home. (Photo by CHRISTOPHE ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)
Sven-Goran Eriksson, who managed a number of high-profile teams and took England to World Cup quarter-finals in 2002 and 2006.

site_title: Former CEO of Citiraya Industries slapped with a misappropriation charge, after nearly 2 decades on the run
summary: Former Citiraya Industries CEO Ng Teck Lee, 58, has been slapped with a misappropriation charge, carrying a mandatory jail term of up to seven years. He allegedly misappropriated 6,791 kg of electronic scrap from five companies in 2005, worth an unknown amount. His wife, Thor Chwee Hwa, 55, faces a money-laundering charge related to the alleged ill-gotten gains of US$1.1 million. The couple was arrested in Malaysia after a 19-year manhunt and remains in remand for further investigations.

images.alt_text: Ng Teck Lee, who was the CEO of then listed recycling firm Citiraya Industries, and his wife Thor Chwee Hwa being handed over to CPIB officers on Dec 3.

site_title: South Korean opposition move to impeach president after martial law bid
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol's bid to impose martial law has led to his impeachment motion being filed by the opposition. The motion, which could be voted on as soon as Friday, accuses Yoon and his allies of "insurrection" and "anti-state forces." The opposition holds a majority in parliament and only needs a handful of defections from Yoon's party to secure the two-thirds majority needed to pass the motion. The move comes amid deep turmoil and alarm from South Korea's close allies, including the US, which has nearly 30,000 troops in the country to protect it from North Korea.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.
The Korea Exchange in Seoul. South Korea's currency recovered, while its stocks fell in early trading on Dec 4 after President Yook Suk Yeol briefly declared martial law.
Protesters call for the resignation of South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol during a demonstration in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024.

Cho Kuk, leader of the minor opposition Rebuilding Korea Party, lawmakers and people attend a rally to condemn South Korean President’s surprise declaration of martial law last night and to call for his resignation at the national assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec 4, 2024.

Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.

site_title: Japan’s service activity perks up as demand improves: PMI
summary: Japan's service sector activity saw a significant improvement in November, with the au Jibun Bank Service purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 50.5 from 49.7 in October, surpassing the 50.0 threshold separating expansion from contraction. This marked the highest level since July, indicating optimism among firms about their business outlook. The improvement in demand supported new business, suggesting a positive trend for Japan's service sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees of a seafood restaurant work in their kitchen space at Tsukiji Outer Market in Tokyo, Japan, Feb. 15, 2024.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Stronger signs for the domestic economy and persistent inflation are fuelling speculation that the BOJ may raise its benchmark interest rate as soon as Dec 19.
The final au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped to 49.0 in November, the lowest level since March, from 49.2 in October.
Manufacturers surveyed by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to fall 2.2 per cent in November and drop 0.5 per cent in December.

site_title: Dubai billionaire plans to build data centres across Asia
summary: Dubai-based Damac Group, backed by billionaire Hussain Sajwani, plans to invest around $3 billion in building data centers across Southeast Asia over the next three to five years. The company aims to establish a digital infrastructure hub for AI services, with initial facilities in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The project is part of a broader plan to expand Edgnex operations globally, with a potential market value of $5 billion to $7 billion. The investment will be supported by Nvidia chips, and the company is also exploring similar facilities in Vietnam and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: A Bangkok Mass Transit System (BTS) train station among residential and commercial buildings in Bangkok, Thailand, on Wednesday, Jan. 17, 2024. Southeast Asias second-largest economy is forecast to expand 3.2% this year, up from an estimated 2.5% in 2023, according to the World Bank. Photographer: Sirachai Arunrugstichai/Bloomberg
Founder of Dubai's DAMAC offers to take property firm private

site_title: 🌱 A Gen Z’s take on mental health concerns in Singapore
summary: A National Youth Mental Health Study in Singapore found that 30.6% of young people experience severe or extremely severe symptoms of depression, anxiety, and/or stress. Suicide remains the leading cause of death for young people aged 10-29, with 29.2% of deaths attributed to it. Social media usage is linked to mental health issues, with excessive social media use (3+ hours/day) and cyberbullying being common factors. However, social media is not the sole cause of mental health challenges, and individual circumstances and experiences play a significant role. Efforts to address mental health concerns are underway, including increased awareness, acceptance, and institutional support, but more needs to be done to reduce stigma and increase access to mental health services.

images.alt_text: BT
Organisations should take a holistic and proactive approach to mental health, ensuring employees have access to the right support, no matter where they fall on the mental health spectrum.

site_title: India’s services sector saw strong growth in November: PMI
summary: India's services sector saw strong growth in November, with the fastest pace of hiring since 2005, driven by solid demand and international growth. The HSBC PMI index remained steady at 58.4, despite a rise in prices, and business sentiment improved, with a record increase in future activity. The growth could boost slowing consumption and help the economy, but the Reserve Bank of India is expected to keep policy tight due to inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: High demand and capacity expansion led to a robust rise in the business outlook for the year ahead, pushing the sub-index to a six-month high.
GDP growth in July-to-September quarter eased from 6.7 per cent seen in the previous quarter.

site_title: A thrilling new London restaurant is elevating the Thai food game
summary: AngloThai, a new London restaurant from John Chantarasak, a Michelin-starred chef, has opened its doors with a boundary-pushing menu that combines Thai flavors with British produce. The restaurant, which took six years to create, offers a five-course chef's selection menu (£75) and à la carte options. The menu features dishes such as cornish monkfish with woodland curry and wild mushrooms, and Massaman curry with black fig. The restaurant's design blends modern Thai art with mid-century elements, creating a grown-up, convivial atmosphere. AngloThai is the latest addition to London's culinary scene, which has been elevated by other notable Thai restaurants in recent years.

images.alt_text: Sorn was upgraded to three stars, an honour that had eluded Thai restaurants since Michelin Guide made its debut in 2017.
Turbot from the United Kingdom's L’Enclume, which has retained its No 1 spot from last year with five other restaurants.
Daniele Sperindio, chef owner of Art di Daniele Sperindio.

site_title: Norway eases loan-to-value mortgage limit to 90%
summary: The Norwegian government has eased its loan-to-value mortgage limit to 90%, up from 85%, allowing borrowers to put up 10% equity when buying a home, down from 15%. The revised rule aims to protect the banking system and consumers, but will also enable more people to enter the housing market, according to Finance Minister Trygve Slagsvold Vedum. The change reverses a policy introduced in 2015 that had led to a decline in new home construction.

site_title: Vietnam pushes electric motorbikes as pollution becomes ‘unbearable’
summary: Vietnam orders that a quarter of two-wheelers must be electric by 2030 to combat air pollution. The move aims to reduce emissions from the country's 77 million motorbikes, with 19-year-old Phung Khac Trung, a taxi driver, embracing the e-bike trend. While affordable electric motorbikes are available for $500, challenges include charging time and habit-breaking for users. The initiative is part of Vietnam's efforts to address its severe air pollution crisis, which has become unbearable in cities like Hanoi.

images.alt_text: Vietnam is a significant exporter to the US and has a large trade surplus with Washington.
A vendor walks along a railway track as she sells cakes for tourists outside cafes in Hanoi, Vietnam October 8, 2019. Picture taken October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Vietnam is a significant exporter to the US and has a large trade surplus with Washington.

site_title: China can accept GDP growth of less than 5%, says People’s Daily
summary: China's state newspaper, People's Daily, has stated that the country can accept GDP growth of less than 5% without the "worship of speed". The editorial emphasizes the focus on qualitative improvements and reasonable quantitative growth, rather than specific targets. China's economy has struggled due to a prolonged property sector crisis and local government debt woes, with economists calling for more policy support to strengthen the recovery. The newspaper warns of economic risks from global instability and geopolitical uncertainties, including US President-elect Donald Trump's tariff threat.

images.alt_text: Beijing has responded with a series of policy measures, including increased fiscal support and monetary easing, to shore up economic growth.
Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that, as an overall principle, gallium, germanium, antimony, and superhard materials are no longer allowed to be exported to America.

site_title: Microchip pauses chips act application after scaling back plans
summary: Microchip Technology has paused its application for US semiconductor subsidies under the Chips and Science Act, making it the first company to step back from the program. The struggling chipmaker was set to receive $162 million in grants to support plants in Oregon and Colorado. This decision is a blow to Biden officials racing to finalize awards from the landmark bipartisan law. Microchip has also furloughed workers twice and announced plans to shut down a factory in Arizona, affecting around 500 employees.

site_title: JPMorgan bolsters Florida bet with 300 new jobs in Orlando
summary: JPMorgan is expanding its presence in Florida, particularly in the Orlando area, by hiring 300 new employees over the next two years. The firm will renovate its 250,000-square-foot campus, creating 400 construction jobs and contributing approximately $280 million to the local economy. The move is part of JPMorgan's largest expansion in the South.

site_title: Retailers point to solid US sales over holiday weekend
summary: US consumers made 197 million purchases over a five-day stretch including Black Friday and Cyber Monday, accounting for 59% of the US population, according to the National Retail Federation. This is the second-highest total ever, below the 2023 record of 200.4 million. The increased spending reflects a renewed desire to shop after pandemic years, with NRF President Matthew Shay stating it's a sign of consumers wanting to get out and about.

images.alt_text: Retailers have been coaxing cautious US shoppers on Cyber Monday – traditionally America’s biggest internet shopping day – with push notifications, emails and other ads touting heavily discounted cosmetics, electronics, toys, clothing and other products.
A person searches for specials on a computer during the Cyber Monday shopping event in Miami, Florida, Dec 2, 2024.

site_title: Australian dollar hits 4-month low as economy undershoots
summary: The Australian dollar hit a four-month low on Wednesday, falling 1% to US$0.6422 due to soft economic data that led to a rally in bonds and a forward rate cut to April from May. The economy grew just 0.3% in the third quarter, with annual growth slowing to 0.8%, the lowest since the pandemic. This led to a shift in market expectations, with a 44% chance of a rate cut in February, down from 27%.

images.alt_text: Inflation has only come down slowly and at an underlying level remains above the central bank’s 2 to 3 per cent target.

(From left) Australian Minister for Trade and Tourism Don Farrell, Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong, Australian Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong, Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan and Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen.
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) was up slightly by 8.98 points or 0.2 per cent at 3,795.11 as at 9.01 am when the market opened on Wednesday.
The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong to make up half of StanChart’s affluent business in ‘ambitious’ expansion plans
summary: Standard Chartered plans to expand its affluent business, targeting US$200 billion in new assets and double-digit income growth over the next five years. Singapore and Hong Kong will continue to make up half of the affluent business, with the bank investing US$1.5 billion to increase relationship managers and resources in key markets, including Singapore, Hong Kong, India, and London. The affluent business, which includes clients with assets over US$25,000, now accounts for 68% of the wealth and retail banking business, with double-digit growth expected.

images.alt_text: Bill Winters, Group Chief Executive, Standard Chartered,
Standard Chartered will aim to double the size of its relationship manager team by 2028, as well as upgrading branches and investing in technology to win new clients.
Chinese consumers have tightened spending in a slowing economy, shrinking the credit card market further.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia Leaders’ Retreat postponed due to PM Wong’s Covid-19 infection
summary: Singapore-Malaysia Leaders' Retreat scheduled for Dec 8-9 has been postponed due to Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's Covid-19 infection. The event aimed to finalize a joint agreement on the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone, which was set to be signed in December. The signing has been pushed to January 2025, with PM Wong self-isolating at home while working from home. The delay is expected to impact the zone's development, which was expected to bring mutual benefits to businesses and people from both countries.

images.alt_text: Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.

site_title: Indonesia must shut coal plants every year to hit climate goal
summary: Indonesia needs to shut multiple coal plants annually and triple its renewable energy output to meet its goal of exiting coal by 2040, according to climate consultancy Ember. The country must add 8 gigawatts of clean energy annually to reach its target, tripling its current 3.3 gigawatts. President Prabowo Subianto has set a new net-zero target of 2050 and pledged to boost renewables output. Systemic changes, including reducing red tape and confronting vested interests, are needed to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: Indonesian businesses and unions have called for the legislated increase in the VAT rate to be paused because the economic environment is deteriorating.
FILE PHOTO: A man sits next to an iPhone 16 advertisement as the new iPhone 16 series smartphones go on sale at an Apple store in Beijing, China, Sept. 20, 2024. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Indonesia banned the sales of Apple’s iPhone 16 after it failed to meet a requirement that smartphones sold domestically must comprise at least 40 per cent locally-made parts.

site_title: China’s services activity expansion eases in November: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector expanded at a slower pace in November, with the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 51.5 from 52.0 in October. The economy faces pressure from a prolonged property downturn, local government debt risks, and weakening global demand. Despite policy measures, including increased fiscal support and monetary easing, uncertainty from US President-elect Donald Trump's threat of tariffs on Chinese imports remains. Companies hired staff, but overall business confidence rose to its highest level in seven months.

images.alt_text: Monetary policy support will be critical to China’s economy next year as the US president-elect has vowed to impose steep tariffs on Chinese goods.
Both official and private measures of October factory activity exceeded analyst expectations.

China's industrial profits in October fell 10 per cent from a year earlier, following a 27.1 per cent slump in September, while earnings slid 4.3 per cent in the first 10 months versus a 3.5 per cent decline in January-September, National Bureau of Statistics data showed.
China is on track for a record trade surplus that could reach almost US$1 trillion this year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Digital Core Reit, Marco Polo Marine
summary: Digital Core Reit convenes an extraordinary general meeting to vote on a proposed acquisition of a data centre in Frankfurt, Germany, with its independent financial adviser and directors recommending a "yes" vote. Marco Polo Marine reported a 41.5% decline in net profit to S$10.7 million for the second half, due to lower revenue from its shipyard segment. Hai Leck, an industrial equipment supplier, halted trading pending an announcement.

site_title: China’s SenseTime reshapes to focus on generative AI growth
summary: China's SenseTime, a leading AI firm, has completed a major organisational restructuring to focus on generative AI technologies, following the industry-wide surge triggered by OpenAI's ChatGPT. The company, previously focused on computer vision and surveillance, aims to accelerate its transformation. SenseTime's shares have dropped 61% from their issue price three years ago, falling behind rivals amid the generative AI boom. The restructuring is part of a shift to capitalize on the growing demand for generative AI technologies.

images.alt_text: More than 150 AI-related products and solutions are being exhibited at the conference, with a small number of foreign firms such as Tesla and Qualcomm joining the predominantly Chinese line-up.
SenseTime is one of China’s AI pioneers, though it’s been placed on a US investment blacklist as part of sweeping American sanctions curbing the country’s advances in AI.
SenseTime is among a growing number of Chinese corporations and startups exploring ways to develop an answer to OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

site_title: Malaysia faces backlash over plan to broaden Internet controls
summary: Malaysia's government has introduced a bill to tighten internet controls, imposing stricter penalties for content violations and granting law enforcement sweeping powers. Critics warn the regulations could suppress dissent and undermine free speech. The bill would also hold service providers liable for user data and allow authorities to search and seize without a warrant. Representatives from major tech firms, including Meta and Google, could face arrest under the envisioned regime. The move has sparked backlash from human rights groups and opposition parties, with Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's pledge to protect free speech seemingly at risk.

images.alt_text: Dozens of state attorneys general have targeted Meta and ByteDance with suits accusing the companies of using harmful features to keep children on the platform longer to maximise profits.

(FILES) This photo illustration shows the social media platform X (former Twitter) app on a smartphone in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil on September 18, 2024. The social media network X on October 28, 2024 suspended an account that published Hebrew-language messages on behalf of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, just days after it was opened. (Photo by Mauro PIMENTEL / AFP)
Australia's landmark legislation would force social media firms to prevent young teens from accessing their platforms or face fines of up to A$50 million (S$43.9 million).
Elon Musk has previously clashed with Australia’s centre-left Labor government over its social media policies and had called it “fascists” over its misinformation law.
Platforms such as Facebook, TikTok and Instagram would be held responsible for enforcing the age ban and face potentially hefty fines for failing to do so.

site_title: No-confidence vote draws France into new political crisis
summary: France is headed into a new political crisis as opposition lawmakers have vowed to topple Prime Minister Michel Barnier's minority government in a no-confidence vote. The standoff over an austerity budget, which has caused jitters on financial markets, follows months of tension since President Emmanuel Macron appointed Barnier in September. If the government falls, it would be the first successful no-confidence vote since 1962 and would have the shortest lifespan of any administration since France's Fifth Republic was born in 1958.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 rose 0.4 per cent to 515.53 points on Tuesday, logging its fourth session of gains.
Barring a last-minute surprise, French Prime Minister Michel Barnier’s fragile coalition will be the first French government to be forced out by a no-confidence vote since 1962.

site_title: STI up 0.4% amid mixed regional trading on South Korea political drama
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, driven by gains from Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while regional markets were mixed due to uncertainty surrounding South Korea's martial law decree. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,799.94. Despite a short-lived martial law, near-term uncertainty over South Korea's leadership persists, and markets may remain cautious until a resolution is reached.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Therese Soh
Singapore shares open higher as overnight Wall Street gains lift Asian equities

site_title: South Korean president pressed to step down over martial law bid
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol faced widespread demands to resign after attempting to impose martial law, which was met with resistance from lawmakers and protesters. The move, which would have been the first in over four decades, was voted down by parliament and led to a national assembly meeting where Yoon was forced to retract the declaration. The United States expressed relief that martial law was lifted, while China urged calm. The opposition party has vowed to file charges of insurrection and push for impeachment, with the nation's largest labour union calling for an indefinite general strike until Yoon's resignation.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi opened sharply lower on Dec 4, after South Korea's President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight.

The announcement came after Finance Minister Choi Sang Mok and Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang Yong held emergency meetings overnight, and ahead of the BOK’s extraordinary meeting session abruptly scheduled for 9 am local time (0000 GMT) on Wednesday.

Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol did not cite any specific threat from the nuclear-armed North, instead focusing on his domestic political opponents.

site_title: Partner of ex-Abercrombie & Fitch CEO pleads not guilty to sex trafficking
summary: Matthew Smith, partner of former Abercrombie & Fitch CEO Mike Jeffries, pleaded not guilty to charges of sex trafficking and interstate prostitution, and was released on a $10 million bond. Smith and Jeffries, 80, are accused of running a prostitution and international sex trafficking operation, using a "casting couch" ploy to groom aspiring male models. Prosecutors allege the operation used force, fraud, and coercion to traffic men between 2008 and 2015, with 15 anonymous victims, and Jeffries faces the prospect of life in prison if convicted.

images.alt_text: The company now expects fiscal 2024 net sales to rise between 14 per cent and 15 per cent, compared with its prior forecast of 12 per cent to 13 per cent growth.

Mike Jeffries, the former chief executive of the Abercrombie and Fitch clothing empire has been arrested and charged with the trafficking of male models for sex parties around the world, US prosecutors said on Oct 22, 2024.

site_title: Trump cites Hunter Biden pardon in seeking hush money case dismissal
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's attorneys filed a motion to dismiss his conviction for 34 counts of falsifying business records related to a $130,000 payment to Stormy Daniels. The motion cites President Joe Biden's pardon of his son Hunter Biden, arguing that Biden used similar reasoning to dismiss the prosecution. Trump's team invokes presidential immunity and the Presidential Transition Act to seek dismissal of the indictment. The case will now be decided by Judge Juan Merchan, who has the option to dismiss the case or suspend any consequences until after Trump's term in office begins on January 20.

images.alt_text: (Right) Hunter Biden's case has long been a thorn in the Biden family’s side, particularly during this election year when Republicans have charged that Hunter was being treated too leniently.
Hunter Biden and his wife Melissa Cohen, leave court after his guilty plea in his trial on tax evasion in Los Angeles, California, Sept 5, 2024.

The 81-year-old Biden is expected to say that Harris – America’s first female, Black and South Asian vice president – is the best person to finish the job he started of protecting American democracy from Republican rival Donald Trump.

site_title: These airlines saw the most delays and complaints in 2024
summary: The 2024 AirHelp Score report ranks airlines globally based on customer claims, on-time arrival and departure performance, and passenger feedback. The worst-performing airlines include Tunisair, Buzz, Bulgaria Air, Pegasus Airlines, and Air Mauritius. Meanwhile, Brussels Airlines tops the list, followed closely by Qatar Airways and United Airlines. The report highlights the improvement in Brussels Airlines' ranking from No 12 last year.

images.alt_text: A passenger aircraft descends to land at Heathrow Airport, as British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a relaxing of COVID-19 travel testing rules for entering and leaving England amidst the continuation of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in London, Britain, January 5, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville - RC24TR9XXVEY

Some users are wondering whether maintaining airline loyalty status is worth it any more as they calculate how much they will need to spend and travel for the rest of the year in order to reach certain status levels next year.
The key drivers pushing up airfares include rising wages and staffing shortages.

site_title: Australia’s economic growth stays tepid in challenge for RBA
summary: Australia's economic growth slowed to 0.8% in the latest quarter, the weakest reading since 1991, as inflation remains above the Reserve Bank of Australia's 2-3% target. Despite a surge in government spending, the sluggish growth highlights the central bank's policy challenge. The data led to a drop in the currency and a decrease in interest-rate expectations, with swaps traders now fully pricing in an April interest-rate cut. The Reserve Bank of Australia faces a challenge to bring inflation back in line with its target.

images.alt_text: Retail sales were unchanged from the prior month, versus economists’ estimate of a 0.3 per cent gain, data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed on Friday.

Sydney fell 0.2 per cent in November from the prior month – its second straight monthly decline, property consultancy CoreLogic said on Monday (Dec 2). Melbourne, where values have fallen in 10 of the past 12 months, slipped too as prices in major cities rose just 0.1 per cent in November.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed its monthly consumer price index (CPI) rose at an annual pace of 2.1 per cent in October, unchanged from September and under market forecasts of 2.3 per cent.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.9% in November, but volumes decline: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.9% in November, with mature estates increasing 1% and non-mature ones 0.2%, year-on-year. However, volumes declined 9.6% from October, marking the fourth straight month of decrease. Demand for flats in mature estates, supported by central locations, drove the price increase. The seasonal slowdown and lingering effects of cooling measures also contributed to lower transaction volumes. Million-dollar transactions declined, but prices for all room types increased over November 2023 levels, with three-room units jumping 11.2%.

images.alt_text: There were 2,505 HDB resale transactions last month, down 0.6% from the 2,518 units sold in September, according to real estate portal SRX.
Notably, 4 of the latest multi-million dollar HDB resale flats sold were located in Bishan, while 6 were in Queenstown.
Condo resale volumes are 29.1 per cent higher year on year.
A vast majority of resale flats transacted during the latest quarter were at a price “much lower" than S$1 million, says HDB.

site_title: Qatar to invest £1 billion in climate technologies with UK
summary: Qatar has agreed to invest £1 billion in climate technologies with the UK, with the partnership expected to create thousands of jobs and launch world-leading climate technology hubs. The investment will focus on energy efficiency and support British industrial group Rolls-Royce. This is part of Qatar's £50 billion investment in the UK economy, with the emirate also planning to invest an additional £10 billion by 2027. The partnership will also include joint research initiatives in genomic medicine and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: The huge shortfall in climate finance at COP29, coupled with unfinished details on how the rest of the money is to be mobilised, leaves emerging markets, many of which are in Asia, facing the daunting task of having to undertake system-wide energy transition efforts, implement climate adaptation projects and cope with natural disasters all on a tight budget.
Climate activists at a protest at the UN Climate Change Conference COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan, Nov 23, 2024.

site_title: Larry Fink is making a new generation of billionaires richer than him
summary: Larry Fink's investment firm BlackRock has acquired private credit specialist HPS Investment Partners for $12 billion, adding three new billionaires to its roster. Founders Scott Kapnick, Scot French, and Mike Patterson will lead a new private financing solutions business, with estimated combined net worth of $8.6 billion. This deal, the third private-markets acquisition for Fink this year, cements his own net worth of $1.8 billion. BlackRock is expanding into private markets as demand for the asset class surges, with the new business offering credit solutions, asset-based finance, and more.

images.alt_text: Blackrock Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
BlackRock chief executive officer Larry Fink has moved aggressively to expand in private markets.
BlackRock is the world’s largest asset manager overseeing more than US$10 trillion.
Former BlackRock fund manager Kate Moore (pictured here in 2017) will become Citigroup's chief investment officer for its wealth division in February 2025.
ETFs have steadily taken over vast parts of the securities business in part because they are easier to shift in and out of rapidly, making them a draw to individual investors.

site_title: Cargill begins job cuts in drive to reduce headcount by 5%
summary: Cargill, a major US grain merchant and beef processor, has begun laying off 475 employees in Minnesota, representing a 5% reduction in headcount. The company is facing a downturn in cattle, grains, and oilseeds businesses due to a decline in returns. Cargill's rival Archer-Daniels-Midland is also seeking to control costs amid a challenging commodities cycle. The layoffs are part of a larger restructuring effort, which was initiated after the company missed internal earnings goals and reported a 9% decline in revenue to $160 billion in 2024.

images.alt_text: WindWings are being retrofitted on Pyxis Ocean at the COSCO shipyard, in this undated handout picture, in Shanghai, China, August 2023. Cargill/Handout via REUTERS    THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: Asia’s Transformative Era: Unveiling the “Asian Dream” through New Study Truth About Ascending Asia
summary: Asia is poised to enter a transformative era, characterized by the emergence of a distinct "Asian Dream" defined by socio-economic shifts, technological advancements, and cultural evolution. A new study reveals a markedly optimistic perspective among Asians, with 83% anticipating a more peaceful life in Asia compared to the West. The "Asian Dream" is composed of three pillars: commensurate (equity), composure (social stability and environmental protection), and captaincy (commercial and thought leadership). Brands are seen as crucial contributors to societal improvement, with 96% agreeing they must enhance everyday life and 86% believing they should engage in social issues.

site_title: Netflix Japan subscribers top 10 million with shows garnering attention
summary: Netflix has surpassed 10 million subscribers in Japan, with its Japanese-language programming gaining significant attention in the market. The streaming firm's subscriber base has doubled in the last four years, with shows such as "Tokyo Swindlers" and "The Queen of Villains" receiving high viewership. Netflix plans to produce more Japanese content, with a five-year contract signed with the director of "Tokyo Swindlers". The company's Japanese content is its third-most-viewed non-English content, with anime titles viewed over a billion times globally last year.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Jon Tigar in Oakland, California, said Netflix’s earlier claims to be “roughly 60 per cent penetrated” in the United States and Canada with “a lot of headroom” to grow were not false or misleading, because they referred to paid subscribers and did not imply that growth was certain.
Netflix is experiencing a faster rate of adoption for its ad-based plan, priced at US$6.99 per month in the US, as customers seek more affordable options.
Investigators specialising in financial crime and corruption raided Netflix’s offices in central Paris on Tuesday morning.
Netflix has resisted pressure from filmmakers and their representatives, arguing that it can deliver a huge audience at home without theatres.

site_title: Rakuten starts marketing its third dollar bond offering of 2024
summary: Rakuten is marketing its third US dollar bond offering of 2024, targeting a sale of up to $550 million of subordinated notes with a 8.375% yield. The funds will be used to redeem yen notes with call options late next year. This move comes as the company relies on the US high-yield market for funding, following a string of losses and lower credit ratings. The sale is taking advantage of strong investor appetite for junk-rated debt, with US spreads at their lowest since 2007.

images.alt_text: A plan to reorganise Rakuten’s banking, securities, credit card and insurance businesses under one umbrella had fueled optimism around the debt-ridden company.

The tie-up with Ebay, which started on May 8 with just seven vendors on Rakuten’s second-hand goods unit Rakuma, aims to capitalise on the currency effect and also a move towards bargain hunting as cost-of-living pressures around the world crimp spending.

Signage for Rakuten Group Inc. displayed at the Rakuten Optimism event in Yokohama, Japan, on Wednesday, Aug. 2, 2023. The annual event by the Japanese e-commerce Rakuten Group continues through Aug. 6. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg
Rakuten has been tapping financial markets this year to raise fresh funds to pay down its obligations.

site_title: Trump’s opening salvo on tariffs: Is he declaring war or applying a negotiating ploy?
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced tariffs of 25% on Canada and Mexico, and 10% on China, in a move seen as a negotiating ploy rather than a declaration of war. Financial markets reacted with caution, but shares of car makers were hit hard. Trump's nomination of hedge fund manager Scott Bessent as Treasury secretary suggests a shift towards market-friendly policies, potentially limiting the likelihood of trade wars. Trump's rhetoric may be an attempt to gauge government and market reactions before implementing policies.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks to reporters as he visits the Nantucket Fire Department in Nantucket, Massachusetts on Nov 28, 2024.

Many economists have warned that tariffs would hurt growth and push up inflation, since they are primarily paid by importers bringing the goods into the US, who often pass those costs on to consumers.
Beyond the knee-jerk US equity euphoria, there is disquiet as election uncertainty is replaced by uncertainty about everything else, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: December rate cut still up for debate: US Fed official
summary: US Federal Reserve President Mary Daly expressed uncertainty over a December interest rate cut, stating that policy needs to be recalibrated to keep the economy in a good place. Daly's comments come after Fed Governor Christopher Waller suggested he leans towards supporting a rate cut, citing strong evidence that policy is still restrictive. Financial markets currently assign a 70% probability of a rate cut at the December meeting, with a benchmark lending rate potentially between 4.25 and 4.50%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Federal Reserve building is seen before the Federal Reserve board is expected to signal plans to raise interest rates in March as it focuses on fighting inflation in Washington, U.S., January 26, 2022.      REUTERS/Joshua Roberts/File Photo
Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rates are also likely to continue falling next year, though the pace and degree of reduction remain to be determined.

site_title: Wells Fargo to sell San Francisco headquarters: WSJ
summary: Wells Fargo is reportedly set to sell its San Francisco headquarters, citing a shift in focus to the East Coast. The lender has engaged in informal conversations with potential buyers and may list its office in the financial district as early as this month. Wells Fargo has done business in San Francisco since 1852, but the company aims to build a stronger, more efficient organization. The decision is part of a multi-year effort to re-evaluate its real estate portfolio.

site_title: Oil rises on fears about Lebanon, further Opec+ supply cuts
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures gaining $1.79 to $73.62 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising $1.84 to $69.94 per barrel. The increase was driven by fears about a potential collapse of the truce between Lebanon and Hezbollah, as well as Opec+ supply cuts, which are expected to be extended until the end of the first quarter next year, potentially limiting market surplus and providing a softer landing for the oil market.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil is said to be eyeing the sale of its petrol stations in Singapore for US$1 billion.
Brent crude futures settled 1 cent lower at US$71.83 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: 19-year manhunt for S’porean tycoon involved in S$72 million embezzlement case ends in JB
summary: A 19-year manhunt for Singaporean tycoon Ng Teck Lee, who was accused of embezzling over $51 million, ended in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, on December 3. Ng, 58, and his wife Thor Chwee Hwa, 55, were arrested and handed over to Singapore's Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB). Ng faces one charge of criminal breach of trust, while his wife faces a charge under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes (Confiscation of Benefits) Act. The couple had evaded capture by assuming different identities and bribing officials.

images.alt_text: Singapore broadens scope of mutual legal assistance for cross-border crime under new law

site_title: South Korea vows ‘unlimited’ liquidity measures after political turmoil; BOK to meet
summary: South Korea's finance ministry has announced plans to deploy "unlimited" liquidity into financial markets if needed, amid the country's political turmoil. The move comes after President Yoon Suk Yeol lifted martial law, which pushed the won to multi-year lows. The Bank of Korea is set to meet on Wednesday to address the situation, which has led to a decline in US-listed South Korean stocks and a sharp fall in the Korean won against the yen. The government aims to stabilize the markets and mitigate the negative impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol did not cite any specific threat from the nuclear-armed North, instead focusing on his domestic political opponents.
The BOK sees the economy slowing to a growth pace of 1.9 per cent next year from 2.2 per cent this year, suggesting a moderation of export momentum.

site_title: Cyber Monday US spending breaches US$13 billion as steep discounts online drive sales
summary: US consumers spent $13.3 billion online on Cyber Monday, a 7.3% increase from last year, driven by steep discounts on electronics, toys, and clothing. The sales follow muted spending in stores on Black Friday, with retailers relying on push notifications, emails, and ads to lure cautious shoppers. Online shopping has become more efficient, with retailers using generative AI customer service and search features to make it easier for shoppers to find products.

images.alt_text: A person searches for specials on a computer during the Cyber Monday shopping event in Miami, Florida, Dec 2, 2024.

site_title: Blackstone refinances debt for luxury New York City condo tower
summary: Blackstone is refinancing $550 million of municipal debt for its luxury New York City condo tower, 8 Spruce Street. The building, designed by Frank Gehry, has 900 units and is 97% occupied. The refinancing is being issued as fixed-rate debt with multiple classes, similar to commercial mortgage backed securities. The debt includes $204 million of tax-exempt securities, part of a federal economic package approved in 2002. The bonds mature in 2031, and the refinancing reflects the building's high-quality nature, according to Blackstone.

images.alt_text: Amid the race to support the data centre boom needed to deploy AI, power grids are being strained by ageing infrastructure, extreme weather and soaring demand.
A sale to Blackstone would be the US asset manager’s biggest real estate deal in Japan and likely the largest purchase by a foreign fund.
Blackstone is one of the world’s largest investors in real estate, with US$336.1 billion in assets in the sector as at the end of June.

site_title: Mitsubishi Corp lost US$90 million in suspected China metal fraud, say sources
summary: Mitsubishi Corporation has lost over US$90 million in China due to suspected metal fraud by a rogue copper trader, Gong Huayong. Gong was dismissed after an internal investigation found he made unauthorized trades with local companies, including some with personal ties to him. The loss, which matches a reported 13.8 billion yen (S$124 million) loss in Mitsubishi's quarterly results, was primarily due to Gong's actions. Mitsubishi has filed a criminal complaint and will cooperate with authorities, but the incident is unlikely to significantly impact the company's conservative financial guidance.

images.alt_text: e-NG is a synthetic gas produced from renewable hydrogen and carbon dioxide.

site_title: Indonesia to press ahead with VAT hike, minister says
summary: Indonesia plans to hike its value-added tax (VAT) rate to 12% in January despite public pressure to delay, according to Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto. The move aims to improve the country's budget health, with a state bank predicting only a small impact on growth. However, businesses and unions have urged the government to pause the increase due to a deteriorating economic environment. The government will also announce fiscal stimulus to support labor-intensive industries affected by global demand growth slowdowns.

site_title: Meta seeks nuclear power developers for reactors to start in early 2030s
summary: Meta is seeking proposals from nuclear power developers to build one to four gigawatts of new US nuclear generation capacity starting in the early 2030s to meet its artificial intelligence and environment goals. The company aims to add new capacity to address expected electricity demand growth and will consider small modular reactors or larger nuclear reactors. Meta will take submissions until January 3, 2025, and will use a request-for-proposal process to approach these projects thoroughly.

images.alt_text: Australia this week approved a landmark law banning social media for children under 16.
FILE PHOTO: A keyboard is placed in front of a displayed Facebook logo in this illustration taken February 21, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Meta, then known as Facebook, overpaid for Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 to eliminate nascent threats instead of competing on its own in the mobile ecosystem, the FTC claims.
Meta plans to reduce the price of ad-free subscriptions by about 40 per cent for European users.

site_title: Salesforce’s third-quarter revenue beats on strong cloud demand
summary: Salesforce reported a 8% revenue increase to $9.44 billion in its third quarter, beating analyst estimates, driven by strong spending on its enterprise cloud portfolio and healthy client demand for its software products and data cloud. The company raised its annual revenue forecast to $37.8-38 billion and increased its operating margin forecast to 19.8%. Salesforce's new Agentforce product, which uses AI to autonomously complete tasks, is also contributing to the growth. The company's shares rose 7% in extended trading following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Salesforce is looking to grow its international revenue and reduce its reliance on the US market, said Brian Millham, president and chief operating officer, Salesforce.
The new pricing strategy also seeks to protect Salesforce if AI contributes to future job losses and business customers have fewer workers to buy subscriptions to the company’s software.
Own is Salesforce’s biggest deal announced since buying Slack in 2021.

site_title: South Korea shares fall at the close as political tensions continue; Asia markets mixed
summary: South Korean shares fell at the close on Dec 4, with the benchmark Kospi down 1.9% after President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law overnight, only to lift it within hours. Opposition lawmakers filed a motion to impeach him. The won also swung between losses and gains. Despite the initial sharp drop, the Kospi recovered marginally to close at around 2,464.

images.alt_text: Protesters against South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol call for his impeachment while occupying the street outside the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, Dec. 4, 2024. Yonhap news agency said the cabinet had agreed early on Wednesday to scrap martial law.

site_title: Amazon announces new slate of AI models
summary: Amazon has announced a new slate of AI models, known as foundation models, at its AWS conference, enabling text, image, and video generation, among other capabilities. The "Nova" models aim to combat Amazon's reputation for being late to the AI development game, with CEO Andy Jassy emphasizing better latency, lower costs, and fine-tuning capabilities. The new offerings pit Amazon against rivals such as Adobe and Meta, and will include features like video generation from text prompts and AI-powered speech assistants.

images.alt_text: AWS is expected to announce this week at its re:Invent conference that those chips are now available to customers.
Amazon says it injected S$2 billion into its Singapore businesses in 2023
Anthropic is also in talks with additional investors to raise more capital amid Amazon's backing, say sources.

site_title: Intel’s CEO-shortlist candidates include former board member Lip-Bu Tan: sources
summary: Intel's board has started shortlisting candidates to replace CEO Pat Gelsinger, who stepped down after the board deemed his turnaround plan too slow. Former board member Lip-Bu Tan is among the contenders, having been approached by the board to gauge his interest in the role. Intel's board is also evaluating other candidates and plans to make a final decision in the coming weeks. Tan, an industry veteran, previously served as CEO of Cadence Design Systems and was ousted from Intel's board after clashing with Gelsinger on Intel's turnaround plan.

images.alt_text: Pat Gelsinger, Intel's CEO since 2021, is stepping down after the company's turnaround efforts faltered, leaving it trailing competitors.

site_title: McDonald’s E coli outbreak tied to fresh onions is over
summary: McDonald's E. coli outbreak linked to fresh onions has been resolved, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The outbreak, which began on October 22, was caused by contaminated onions used in Quarter Pounders at many restaurants. The CDC and FDA have closed their investigations, providing "certainty and validation" for customers and communities. McDonald's temporarily removed affected burgers from menus during the outbreak.

images.alt_text: The E coli infections have been linked to McDonald’s Quarter Pounders and appear to stem from the slivered onions served on top of the sandwich.

site_title: US job openings rise in October, layoffs decrease
summary: US job openings increased by 372,000 to 7.744 million in October, while layoffs decreased 169,000 to 1.633 million, indicating a slowing labour market. Hires fell 269,000 to 5.313 million. Economists expect payrolls to increase by 200,000 jobs in November, potentially leading to a 4.2% unemployment rate. The employment report for November will influence the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, with a possible third consecutive cut.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly lower ahead of data, Fed commentary
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, December 3, with the Dow Jones falling 12.4 points, or 0.03%, to 44,769.58, following record highs in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The focus is on a crucial jobs report later this week and data from Federal Reserve officials.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit new records as markets eye Fed rate cut
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq adding 0.1% and 0.4% respectively, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%. The mixed labor market data kept interest rate cut possibilities alive, with futures markets increasing odds of a Fed rate cut on December 17. Individual stocks such as AT&T and Tesla also saw gains, while United States Steel and Tesla fell due to various reasons.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 12.4 points, or 0.03 per cent, at the open to 44769.58.

site_title: The mother of all bubbles
summary: The US stock market has reached unprecedented levels of dominance, with investors committing more capital to the country than ever before. The US accounts for nearly 70% of the leading global stock index, with its dollar trading at a higher value than at any time since the 1970s. However, experts warn that this "American exceptionalism" has gone too far, with the US market being overvalued and overhyped. The phenomenon is attributed to investors' faith in the US economy's strength, its global reach, and tech innovation, but may be a bubble waiting to burst.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs predicts that, even in 2075, America’s equity market will be almost as big as China’s and India’s combined.

site_title: Russian money ‘not our business’, says StanChart CEO Bill Winters, as bank doubles down on wealth management
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters has stated that the bank will focus on attracting US$200 billion in new assets over the next five years, primarily from the Asean region and Mainland China. However, Winters emphasized that the bank does not pursue Russian clients due to their "not our business" stance. The bank aims to expand its relationship-manager team by 50% by 2028.

images.alt_text: Bill Winters, Group Chief Executive, Standard Chartered,
Jude Chan

site_title: Singapore and Australia to deepen military ties, cooperation on green initiatives
summary: Singapore and Australia are set to deepen their military ties and cooperation on green initiatives as part of a new Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP) agreement to be signed in 2025. The agreement aims to increase access to each other's military facilities and enhance regional stability. Australia has also committed to investing US$50 million in Singapore's Financing Asia's Transition Partnership (FAST-P) initiative to support green projects in Asia. The CSP will be comparable to the one signed in 2015, which allowed Singapore to send larger numbers of personnel to Australia for training.

site_title: The Fed’s next big policy rethink needs rethinking
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to review its monetary policy framework next year, but critics argue that important aspects will be left out. The Fed is poised to scrap a regime aimed at preventing short-term interest rates from staying stuck at the zero lower bound, but lacks a framework for quantitative easing and a regime to assess its costs and benefits. Additionally, the Fed's interest-rate target, the federal funds rate, is considered obsolete, and changing it to the interest rate on reserves could simplify the central bank's job.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rates are also likely to continue falling next year, though the pace and degree of reduction remain to be determined.
While inflation is taking time to recede back to the Fed’s 2 per cent target, the policy path ahead will be complicated by President-elect Donald Trump’s economic agenda.

site_title: Europe: Shares settle at one-month high; French politics in focus
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% to a one-month high on Tuesday, driven by gains in retailers, defense stocks, and tech companies like SAP. Germany's DAX briefly reached 20,000 points, while Italy and Spain also saw gains. The Stoxx 600 logged its fourth consecutive session of gains. Investors are monitoring France's political turmoil, with the government on the verge of collapse, amid concerns about its impact on the region's economy.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured after the German index reached an all-time-high with over 20,000 points at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, December 3, 2024. REUTERS/Staff

site_title: Compass to buy Christie’s International in US$444 million deal
summary: Compass agreed to buy Christie's International Real Estate and other businesses in a $444 million deal. The acquisition, which includes brokerage owner @properties, will help Compass build an international presence. Compass will pay $150 million in cash and $294 million in stock, expanding its business to franchises and increasing its international affiliates to over 100 locations. The deal comes as the US housing market remains sluggish due to high rates and prices, with Compass CEO Robert Reffkin seeking a capital-light expansion path.

images.alt_text: Mr Anesone Tikeri, a process technician at The FoodBowl – part of New Zealand Food Innovation Network (NZFIN) – setting up production at NZFIN’s open-access food innovation facility in New Zealand.

site_title: Indonesia expects US$1 billion investment commitment from Apple in a week
summary: Indonesia expects Apple to commit US$1 billion in investment for a plant in the country, following the ban on iPhone 16 sales for failing to meet local content rules. The government initially rejected Apple's US$100 million proposal, citing a lack of fairness. Indonesia aims to increase local content requirements for electronics manufacturers, with plans to revise regulations to support the growth of domestic industry. The move is seen as a way to balance economic benefits with ethical standards.

images.alt_text: Despite the sales ban, the Indonesian government still allows iPhone 16 to be carried into Indonesia if they are not being traded commercially.
Indonesia banned the sales of Apple’s iPhone 16 after it failed to meet a requirement that smartphones sold domestically must comprise at least 40 per cent locally-made parts.
Apple is also facing at least three complaints from a US labour board claiming it has illegally deterred employees from discussing issues.
Apple and its rivals will ship 6.2 per cent more phones or an estimated 1.24 billion units in 2024.

site_title: Why the world is excited about Asean
summary: Asean is actively working to remove barriers to intra-regional trade, driven by its 10 member states' combined population of over 650 million, growing middle class, and $3.8 trillion GDP. Investors are flocking to the region due to trade links, digital transformation, and sustainable infrastructure demand. Foreign direct investment (FDI) reached $226 billion in 2023, with intra-Asean trade expected to grow 8.7% annually until 2030. Asean is also finalizing a Digital Economy Framework Agreement to enable faster and more secure cross-border e-commerce and payments, and has set sustainability standards to raise finance for large-scale energy infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: Sunil Kaushal, co-head for corporate and investment banking (CIB) at Standard Chartered, sees the bank's newly reorganised CIB as "a connector  across the world’s most dynamic and complex markets".

With Boston Consulting Group’s projection that Asean’s digital economy could treble to US$1 trillion by 2030, there will be opportunities for more data centres with enhanced capabilities to support the flow of data and information.

site_title: Trump can win against China – in Ukraine
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump could win a significant economic victory against China by forcing Russia to withdraw from Ukraine, according to experts. By cutting Russian oil exports, Trump can cripple the Russian war machine and boost US prestige globally. The US could impose heavy sanctions on companies paying over $15 per barrel for Russian oil, and countries not cooperating would face punitive tariffs. This approach would be more effective than tariffs on Chinese imports, which could lead to job losses and undermine American manufacturers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President-elect Donald Trump attends the America First Policy Institute (AFPI) gala at Mar-A-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S., November 14, 2024. REUTERS/Carlos Barria/File Photo
America’s allies around the world have to prepare themselves for a US that is less willing to serve in the global role of the “indispensable nation”.

site_title: Trump’s election powers US business sentiment to multi-year high
summary: US business sentiment has reached a multi-year high, driven by optimism over pro-business policies and reduced regulatory burden following Donald Trump's election. Regional Federal Reserve Bank surveys show improved outlooks for factory floors, construction sites, and service providers. While some economists expect cooler growth due to tariffs, the business community sees potential for a positive impact, with some industries expressing the most optimism in years.

images.alt_text: Technical analysis indicates the S&P500 remains in a strong bullish market with no hint of serious weakness.

site_title: Many China copper traders halt US scrap imports on tariff fears
summary: China copper traders have halted US copper scrap imports due to fears of 60% tariffs imposed by the incoming US president, potentially sparking retaliatory action from Beijing. The halt in purchases started in mid-November, as cargoes are expected to arrive around Trump's inauguration on January 20. This move follows the US imposing 25% duties on Chinese copper scrap imports during Trump's first term, leading to a tit-for-tat trade war between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Capital expenditure by the Chinese chip industry next year will likely fall by US$10 billion, or about 30 per cent year on year, to US$35 billion, as a result of these curbs.
The G7 and the European Union agreed to keep Russian oil on the world market, largely because Russia is such a large supplier – about eight million barrels per day.
Chinese Ministry of Commerce announced that, as an overall principle, gallium, germanium, antimony, and superhard materials are no longer allowed to be exported to America.

site_title: South Korea’s President Yoon backs down after declaring martial law
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law on Tuesday night, but backed down on Wednesday after the cabinet agreed to scrap the decree. The move came after parliament rejected his attempt to ban political activity and censor the media. Protests against the president's actions continued, with demonstrators calling for his impeachment. The decision to lift martial law led to a slight recovery in the South Korean won currency.

images.alt_text: The announcement came after Finance Minister Choi Sang Mok and Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang Yong held emergency meetings overnight, and ahead of the BOK’s extraordinary meeting session abruptly scheduled for 9 am local time (0000 GMT) on Wednesday.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol did not cite any specific threat from the nuclear-armed North, instead focusing on his domestic political opponents.
The BOK sees the economy slowing to a growth pace of 1.9 per cent next year from 2.2 per cent this year, suggesting a moderation of export momentum.

site_title: Robust outlook for Singapore’s three biggest banks
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, reached record highs in November due to strong third-quarter earnings and investor confidence. Despite high valuations, the banks' stability and resilience make them a good investment, particularly in a high-interest-rate environment. DBS raised its dividend payout and announced a $3 billion share buyback program, while OCBC and UOB also increased their interim dividends. The banks' strong earnings, non-performing assets, and capital rewards position them for healthy growth, with DBS favored for its highest return on equity.

images.alt_text: Over the five trading sessions from Nov 22 to 28, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, resulting in a net institutional inflow of S$188 million, reversing the net outflow of S$38 million observed over the five preceding sessions up to Nov 21.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS International downgrades IHH to ‘hold’, DBS maintains ‘buy’ call
summary: Analysts CGS International downgraded IHH Healthcare to "hold" from "add" due to expected earnings headwinds from accelerated renovations of Mount Elizabeth Hospital and its acquisition of Island Hospital. In contrast, DBS Group Research maintained its "buy" call, raising its price target by 18.3% to S$2.58, citing robust capital management and growth potential. The company's Q3 earnings remained flat at RM534 million, with Prem Nair forecasting completion of Mount Elizabeth Hospital renovations by Q2-Q3 2025.

images.alt_text: IHH said it saw higher patient volumes and increased revenue from taking on more complex cases during Q3 FY2024 across key markets.
Mount Elizabeth Hospital in Orchard is undergoing refurbishment, which was announced in January 2023.

site_title: India signals readiness to pursue China business ties after border row resolved
summary: India's foreign minister, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, signals the country's readiness to improve business ties with China after a four-year military standoff was resolved. Following the completion of troop pullbacks from the Line of Actual Control, India is willing to consider other aspects of bilateral engagement, prioritizing national security interests. The two countries must maintain peace and tranquillity in border areas before developing ties, Jaishankar stated. Top officials will meet soon to discuss future steps, including de-escalation and effective border management.

images.alt_text: The thaw is expected to boost economic ties between China and India that were hurt by the border tensions.

site_title: Why businesses must unlock climate resilience fast
summary: Singapore businesses face significant physical and transition risks due to climate change, including extreme rainfall, sea level rises, and disruptions to supply chains. Climate change is expected to cost the global economy up to US$24.7 trillion annually by 2060, with extreme weather events already accruing over US$2.8 trillion in costs. To act strategically, businesses must model climate risks, assess vulnerabilities, and adapt strategies to safeguard operations. By doing so, they can prevent massive disruptions and create new competitive advantages through innovation and operational efficiencies.

images.alt_text: The “Keep Singapore Clean” campaign mobilises communities to take responsibility for keeping their neighbourhoods clean, with residents organising regular clean-up activities and promoting anti-littering behaviour.
Annual investment in clean power sources now far exceeds that in fossil fuels.
Short term costs may go up, but in the long run this is the more resilient strategy, said SM Teo.

site_title: Japan to use AI to tackle online manga and anime piracy
summary: Japan plans to use AI to police online manga and anime piracy, targeting at least 1,000 websites offering free downloads of Japanese content, estimated to cost the country billions in lost revenue annually. The Tokyo cultural agency's 300 million yen pilot scheme will utilize an image and text detection system to identify pirated content. Inspired by a similar project in South Korea, the initiative aims to boost Japan's cultural exports and follows the country's revised "Cool Japan" strategy to increase exports of cultural assets to 20 trillion yen by 2033.

images.alt_text: Neal Rudge, co-founder and managing partner of Pacific Licensing Studio. The company brokers deals between licensors looking to monetise their intellectual property (IP), and licensees that create merchandise using such IP.
More than 38,000 GenAI inventions were filed by China between 2014 to 2023 versus 6,276 filed by the US over the same period, WIPO said

site_title: ExxonMobil considering sale of Singapore petrol stations for US$1 billion: sources
summary: ExxonMobil is considering selling its 59 petrol stations in Singapore for approximately US$1 billion, amid a decline in global petrol demand driven by electric vehicle adoption. The sale follows similar divestments by the company, including the sale of its majority stake in Esso Thailand in September last year. The potential sale comes as global petrol demand growth is expected to halve in 2024, with oil consumption displaced by EVs projected to rise to over 20 million barrels per day by 2040.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of ExxonMobil is seen during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

Exxon’s US$8.6 billion profit beats estimate as volume offsets price weakness

site_title: The world’s super rich are moving to Dubai, but keeping their assets in Singapore, Switzerland
summary: Dubai is attracting high-net-worth individuals, with the UAE projected to have the highest net inflow of millionaires globally in 2024, according to Henley & Partners. Despite this, many prefer to keep assets in established wealth hubs like Singapore and Switzerland due to perceptions of geopolitical risk and a lack of sophisticated financial products. Dubai aims to become a booking centre, but it still faces challenges, including limited depth in wealth management expertise and a harder business environment compared to Singapore. The UAE's tax policies and golden visa scheme are also seen as attractive, but it must play catch-up with established wealth hubs.

site_title: BlackRock to buy credit firm HPS in US$12 billion all-stock deal
summary: BlackRock agreed to buy HPS Investment Partners in an all-stock deal valued at roughly US$12 billion, expanding its alternative assets to almost US$600 billion. The transaction, expected to be completed in mid-2025, will propel BlackRock into the highest ranks of private credit. HPS founders will lead a new private financing solutions business unit, and the deal is part of BlackRock's efforts to transform into a formidable player in private assets, following its previous acquisition of Global Infrastructure Partners.

images.alt_text: BlackRock chief executive officer Larry Fink has moved aggressively to expand in private markets.

site_title: Euro tiptoes higher, France turmoil keeps investors on edge
summary: The euro rose 0.2% to $1.05185 on Tuesday, regaining some stability after French political turmoil sent investors scrambling for hedging protection. The euro was the weakest G10 currency in November. Meanwhile, the yuan hit a 13-month low due to tariff risks and weakness in China's economy. The yen retreated slightly against the US dollar, but remained near six-week highs as traders anticipate a potential interest rate hike in Japan.

images.alt_text: U.S. Dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Euro drops against strong US dollar amid fears of French government collapse, threatening deficit reduction plans.

site_title: Danish brewer Carlsberg sells Russian business
summary: Carlsberg, a Danish brewer, has agreed to sell its shares in its Russian unit, Baltika Breweries, for an undisclosed cash consideration. The deal follows President Vladimir Putin's decree ending state control of the business, which was previously under management. Carlsberg had announced its intention to leave Russia in 2022 after Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, but the Russian unit remained under management until now. The transaction is expected to close within the next couple of days.

images.alt_text: Consumer companies are grappling with shoppers reaching their spending limits and cutting back, after a period of high inflation left them feeling the pinch.

site_title: Long-term return expectations give clues on how to invest, but are not infallible
summary: US equities have defied expectations, but their high valuations and return expectations may soon change. Warren Buffett's cash-rich Berkshire Hathaway and the updated long-term expected returns suggest bonds may outperform equities due to higher inflation. However, expected returns are uncertain and US equities have defied expectations in the past. Instead of panicking, investors should stick to a diversified investment plan, allocating to equities, bonds, and alternative assets like private debt, private equity, and real estate to protect against inflation and grow wealth.

images.alt_text: financial, planning, report

site_title: Blended finance not a silver bullet to solving the climate financing gap
summary: Singapore's blended finance initiative, Financing Asia's Transition Partnership (Fast-P), aims to mobilize US$5 billion in climate finance for emerging markets in Asia. The initiative, launched at COP28, provides up to US$500 million in concessional capital and seeks to crowd in up to US$4 billion in commercial capital. While blended finance is not a silver bullet, the initiative is seen as a step forward in mobilizing capital for climate action in the region. However, the right enabling environment through policy support remains crucial to attracting private capital and solving the climate financing gap.
