The move follows China's efforts to strengthen ties with individual EU member states.

site_title: China skips Politburo readout as investors await stimulus clues
summary: China's Politburo, led by President Xi Jinping, skipped releasing a readout for its November meeting, fueling speculation about potential economic stimulus measures. The decision comes as investors await clues on this month's Politburo assembly and the upcoming Central Economic Work Conference. The conference typically sets monetary, fiscal, and industrial policies, drawing cadres from government and state-owned enterprises. Investors are betting on stronger measures to boost growth amid US President-elect Donald Trump's tariff threats, and Chinese stocks have rallied on rumors of an earlier-than-expected conference start.

images.alt_text: Both official and private measures of October factory activity exceeded analyst expectations.

China's industrial profits in October fell 10 per cent from a year earlier, following a 27.1 per cent slump in September, while earnings slid 4.3 per cent in the first 10 months versus a 3.5 per cent decline in January-September, National Bureau of Statistics data showed.
China is on track for a record trade surplus that could reach almost US$1 trillion this year.
China's prospects may have dimmed further with Trump's election, as the unpredictable US leader increased tariffs on Chinese imports during a broad trade war in his first term.

site_title: Castle Water to offer £4 billion equity to rescue Thames Water
summary: Thames Water, the UK's largest water and sewage company, is seeking £4 billion in equity from Castle Water to rescue the company from administration. Thames has enough funds until early next year and needs to curb chronic leaks and sewage spills. Castle Water, backed by The William Pears Group, aims to own a majority stake in the company, with plans to list Thames on the stock exchange. This move aims to tackle climate change and a growing population, with the company seeking at least £3.3 billion in equity over the next five years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen for British utility company Thames Water at a repair site in London, Britain, June 28, 2023. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong’s HKBN gets rival takeover interest from I Squared Capital
summary: Hong Kong telecommunications company HKBN has received a non-binding indication from US private equity firm I Squared Capital for a possible takeover. This comes after HKBN previously announced a possible proposal from state-owned China Mobile for an acquisition. The financial terms of the takeover proposals have not been disclosed. HKBN's market cap is HK$6.37 billion. Trading of its shares has been halted pending the release of the new takeover offer.

site_title: Singapore PMI up 0.2 point in November, echoes improved regional factory activity
summary: Singapore's overall factory activity rose to 51 in November, marking the 15th month of expansion and the 13th month for the electronics sector, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management. The 0.2 point increase from October's marginal dip suggests improved regional factory activity, potentially due to front-loading of production and exports ahead of proposed US tariffs.

images.alt_text: Electronics will remain the key driver of overall factory growth for the rest of the year, said DBS economist Chua Han Teng.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher as caution prevails in data-packed week
summary: Wall Street opened slightly higher on Monday, December 2, 2024, as investors maintained caution ahead of a data-packed week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 15.2 points, or 0.03%, to 44,925.86. Intel shares surged after its CEO retired amid struggles to keep up in the AI chip market. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 7.7 and 37.3 points, respectively. The focus remains on economic data releases this week.

site_title: Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone: opportunities and hotspots
summary: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) is a Malaysia-Singapore collaboration to drive connectivity and investments, attract multinationals, and navigate global trade shifts. Covering 3,571.3 sq km across six districts, the proposed SEZ includes nine flagship zones, with six already part of Iskandar Malaysia. The new zones added include Forest City, Pengerang, and Desaru, with priority sectors in aerospace, electrical and electronics, chemical, medical devices, pharmaceutical, and more. The JS-SEZ aims to attract businesses and investments, creating jobs and driving growth in Malaysia.

site_title: St James's Place to cut around 500 jobs, source says
summary: British wealth manager St James's Place plans to cut around 500 jobs, nearly a sixth of its 3,200-person workforce, as part of a £100 million cost-cutting strategy by 2027. The redundancies come after CEO Mark FitzPatrick's plan to simplify and standardize processes. The company has begun consulting with employees on the impact of the layoffs, with a decision expected next year.

site_title: Taiwan is a trusted partner for high-tech sector, president says in Hawaii
summary: Taiwan President Lai Ching-te emphasized the island's contribution to the global high-tech industry, particularly in semiconductors, during a visit to Hawaii. He highlighted the US-Taiwan partnership as a source of strength for the industry, describing Taiwan as a "trusted and reliable partner." The remarks came amid tensions with China, which claims Taiwan as its own territory and has increased military activities around the island. Lai reiterated Taiwan's commitment to strengthening its defense and upholding universal values of freedom and democracy.

images.alt_text: Lawmakers from the largest opposition party Kuomintang try to block plastic bags, some with a text reading “trash”, that were thrown by lawmakers from the Democratic Progressive Party during a session at the Parliament in Taipei.

Lai Ching-te, Taiwan's incoming president, during his swearing-in ceremony at the Presidential Palace in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday, May 20, 2024. Lai was sworn in as president of the democratic island, putting him right at the heart of a geopolitical rivalry involving the world’s two biggest powers. Source: Taipei News Photographer Association/Bloomberg

site_title: Investment banks will lose billions of dollars to private rivals
summary: Investment banks are expected to lose up to $50 billion in annual revenue by 2027, mainly in the US and corporate and investment banking, due to increased competition from private credit and electronic market makers. The industry can replace some of this loss by lending more to illiquid private markets, but the process favors larger Wall Street banks with the resources to invest in technology and maintain relationships with private-market asset managers. This shift threatens to concentrate financial leverage and increase risks in the years ahead.

images.alt_text: Bank of America dropped down to category two from three previously.
Demand for choice and comprehensive wealth management among the affluent in Singapore is lifting the fortunes of financial advisory firms

site_title: The Philippines tweaks 2024 GDP growth target, revises outlook for 2025-2028
summary: The Philippines has revised its economic growth target for 2024 to a range of 6-6.5% and 2025-2028 to 6-8%, down from previous forecasts, amid domestic and external uncertainties. The country's economy grew 5.2% in the third quarter, its weakest in over a year, due to adverse weather disrupting government spending and farm output. The revised targets reflect evolving uncertainties, including global events and US President-elect Donald Trump's tariff agenda.

images.alt_text: Philippines topped the 2022 to 2024 World Risk Index which assesses populations most at risk from earthquakes, cyclones, floods, droughts and sea-level rise.
BSP Governor Eli Remolona Jr (centre) sees inflation staying within the 2 to 4 per cent target this month, giving authorities leeway for easing.

The Philippines expects to lose 5.9 billion pesos (S$134 million) in tax revenue from the new law from 2025 to 2028, according to a document prepared by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr's communications office.
The US is among the Philippines’ biggest export markets and sources of investments from abroad.

site_title: How to conquer the fear of missing out
summary: The US financial markets have experienced a strong upward trend, with all risky assets, including tech stocks and crypto, performing well since the presidential election. However, many investors are struggling to keep pace, with only a small fraction fully invested in equities at the beginning of the year. The fear of missing out (FOMO) is driving investors to make poor decisions, resulting in lower investment returns compared to the average market returns. Experts recommend a rules-based investing process, starting with a core allocation to equities and bonds, and adopting a regular savings plan to neutralize volatility.

images.alt_text: financial, planning, report

site_title: RetailX Debuts Groundbreaking AI Agents to Disrupt the Digital Media Industry
summary: RetailX, a Singapore-based startup, has unveiled its cutting-edge AI agents designed to revolutionize digital media operations and elevate campaign performance. The AI agents, showcased at a product launch event, can automate complex marketing strategies, generate content, and provide personalized insights. RetailX's AI agents are equipped with memory, planning, and advanced capabilities, enabling them to learn, adapt, and execute marketing strategies with precision. The company aims to redefine retail media by integrating AI at every level of campaign execution, providing a seamless, efficient, and scalable solution for retailers and brands.

site_title: US manufacturing improves in November as orders rebound, input price gains slow
summary: US manufacturing activity improved in November, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI rising to 48.4 from 46.5 in October, the lowest level since July 2023. Orders grew for the first time in eight months, while input prices slowed. The PMI reading below 50 indicates contraction in the manufacturing sector, accounting for 10.3% of the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees work on solar panels at the QCells solar energy manufacturing factory in Dalton, Georgia, U.S., March 2, 2023. REUTERS/Megan Varner/File Photo

site_title: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust to acquire Selangor logistics property for RM180 million
summary: CapitaLand Malaysia Trust (CLMT) has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire Elmina Logistics Hub, a 40m-high automated warehouse in Selangor, Malaysia, for RM180 million. The 14,866.67 sqm property will be fully leased for 10 years at a monthly rent of RM1 million. The acquisition is expected to generate RM12.3 million in annual gross rent and increase CLMT's distribution per unit. The deal is the trust's first acquisition of a modern automated logistics property, doubling its new-economy assets to 6% of its total portfolio.

images.alt_text: xx
Tony Tan, CEO of CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust Management.
For the nine months ended September, CLI's total revenue amounted to S$2.1 billion, up from S$2.09 billion in the year prior.

site_title: New US solar tariffs on South-east Asia to raise prices, cut profit margins
summary: The US Commerce Department has imposed new tariffs on solar cells imported from South-east Asia, including Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, in an effort to protect the US solar industry. The tariffs, which range from 21.31% to 271.28%, are expected to raise consumer prices and cut into producer profit margins. Affected producers may shift production to Laos and Indonesia or reduce their profit margins, potentially benefiting local economies. The move is the second in a trade case brought by US companies against Chinese solar companies.

images.alt_text: Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam provide the bulk of US solar cell and module imports.
Sembcorp Industries has been to build, own and operate a 300 megawatt wind-solar hybrid power project in India, the company said on Tuesday (Nov 26).
Trina will retain a minority ownership stake in Freyr after the transaction closes, which is expected at the end of the year.
Countries like India and Brazil have optimal natural conditions, such as high solar irradiance and strong wind currents, which can make renewable projects highly productive.
Chinese solar firms have countered that their mastery of the technology makes them more competitive on price.

site_title: Norway wealth fund ethics watchdog to scrutinise shoe producers, crypto companies in 2025
summary: Norway's $1.8 trillion sovereign wealth fund's ethics watchdog will investigate shoe manufacturers, cryptocurrency companies, and casino firms in 2025 for potential ethical breaches. The Council on Ethics will scrutinize companies to ensure compliance with parliamentary guidelines, which could lead to divestments or public watchlists. The investigation will focus on work conditions, particularly in the shoe industry, where "gross, systematic breaches of workers' rights can lead to exclusions from the fund." The outcome of the investigations is uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view shows the building of Norway’s central bank (Norges Bank) in Oslo, Norway, June 23, 2022.  REUTERS/Victoria Klesty/File Photo

site_title: Latest US strike on China’s chips hits semiconductor toolmakers
summary: The US has launched its third crackdown on China's semiconductor industry, imposing export restrictions on 140 companies, including chip equipment makers Naura Technology Group and Piotech. The move aims to curb China's ability to access and produce advanced chips for military applications and threatens US national security. New export curbs include restrictions on high-bandwidth memory chips, chipmaking tools, and equipment made in countries such as Singapore and Malaysia. The restrictions will also affect Chinese companies, with nearly two dozen semiconductor companies, two investment companies, and over 100 chipmaking tool makers facing new restrictions.

images.alt_text: Wired reported earlier that the US could come out with new export controls rules as soon as next Monday.
China has recently stepped up soybean purchases in Brazil, but it’s still picking up American cargoes for supplies that will be put in reserve.

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, December 2, 2024
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, driven by positive China data, while the euro struggled. China's 10-year yield hit a record low, indicating bets that the PBOC will ease monetary policy. SingPost will divest its Australia business to a private equity fund for A$1 billion. Despite the positive Asia-wide trend, Singapore stocks closed up 0.3%. The euro's decline was attributed to a weak economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open
Hong Kong and Shanghai were among the best performers after data showed Chinese manufacturing activity expanded at a faster clip than expected in November.
The deal comes after a strategic review of SingPost's Australia business.

Expectations remain high that an ailing economy will prompt the PBOC to step up monetary easing, including cutting the RRR further and injecting more cash into markets, after it delivered a stimulus blitz in late September.

site_title: Thailand, Malaysia brace for fresh wave of floods as water levels ease
summary: Thailand and Malaysia are bracing for a second wave of heavy rain and potential flooding, despite some areas experiencing receding water levels. Since last week, 27 people have died and over half a million households have been affected by torrential rain and flooding, the worst in decades. In Malaysia, 128,000 people are in evacuation shelters, down from 152,000, while in southern Thailand, 434,000 households remain affected. Authorities warn of potential flash flooding and overflows in the lower south between Dec 3-5.

images.alt_text: More than 13,000 people had been forced to flee their homes, with temporary shelters set up in schools and temples.
Palm oil production in Malaysia may slump as much as 10 per cent during the first 25 days of November from a month earlier due to rain.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding bags US$2.6 billion in contracts
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured US$2.6 billion in shipbuilding contracts, bringing its total order wins to US$14.3 billion for the year to date. The contracts are for 21 vessels, including liquefied natural gas dual-fuel containerships and oil tankers, with deliveries scheduled between 2027 and 2029. This announcement follows the company's quarterly business update, which reported US$11.6 billion in order wins. The strong order book is expected to provide revenue visibility up to mid-2028.

site_title: Euro falls against strengthening US dollar amid French political uncertainty
summary: The euro fell 0.54% to US$1.0516 against a strengthening US dollar amid concerns over a possible government collapse in France, which would stall plans to curb a burgeoning budget deficit. French far-right National Rally leader Marine Le Pen has given Prime Minister Michel Barnier until Monday to meet her party's budget demands, while investors demand a higher premium to hold French debt. The euro's decline is seen as a sign of uncertainty in the French government, which could impact deficit reduction plans and the euro's value.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese 10,000 yen notes are spread out next to U.S. 100 dollar bills at Interbank Inc. money exchange in Tokyo, in this September 9, 2010 picture illustration. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo

site_title: Philippine groups file impeachment bid against VP Duterte
summary: Philippine activists have filed an impeachment complaint against Vice President Sara Duterte, accusing her of corruption and misconduct. The complaint, endorsed by opposition party Akbayan, adds to Duterte's legal woes, which already include a probe into her alleged death threat against President Ferdinand Marcos and an inquiry into her use of government funds. It remains unclear if the complaint will gain enough support to move forward to a Senate trial.

images.alt_text: Sara Duterte (top) appeared to walk those comments back on Tuesday, describing them as an expression of “consternation” at the Marcos administration’s “failure to serve the Filipinos while it masterfully persecutes political enemies”.

epa11709043 Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. delivers a speech after signing two new maritime laws during ceremonies at the Malacanang Presidential Palace in Manila, Philippines, 08 November 2024. The Maritime Zones Law identifies the archipelagic baselines and internal waters of the Philippines, while the Archipelagic Sea Lanes Law defines sea lanes that vessels may legitimately take within Philippine waters. The new laws come in the midst of the Philippines’ ongoing territorial dispute with China in several areas of the South China Sea.  EPA-EFE/ROLEX DELA PENA

site_title: EQT and GIC to acquire majority stake in UK’s Calisen from consortium of investors
summary: EQT and Singapore's GIC will acquire a majority stake in UK's Calisen, a smart metering company, from a consortium of investors including BlackRock, Goldman Sachs, and Mubadala Investment. The deal valued Calisen at £4 billion. Calisen was taken private in 2020 for £1.43 billion. Equitix will remain a minority investor. The acquisition is the result of a deal between EQT and GIC to buy the stake from the consortium.

site_title: Biden pardons son Hunter in final weeks of presidency
summary: US President Joe Biden has issued an official pardon for his son Hunter, who is facing sentencing for two criminal cases. The pardon, made in the final weeks of Biden's presidency, has sparked scrutiny over the independence of the US judicial system. Hunter Biden was convicted of lying about his drug use to buy a gun and pleaded guilty to tax evasion charges, but had not faced sentencing. Biden claimed that his son was singled out due to his relationship with him, calling it a "miscarriage of justice."

images.alt_text: Hunter Biden, son of US President Joe Biden, and his wife Melissa Cohen Biden and US first lady Jill Biden leave the federal court after the jury finds him guilty on all three counts in his trial on criminal gun charges.
Hunter Biden leaving after the third day of his gun charge trial at the J Caleb Boggs Federal Courthouse in Wilmington, Del.aware, on June 5, 2024.
Hunter Biden and his wife Melissa Cohen, leave court after his guilty plea in his trial on tax evasion in Los Angeles, California, Sept 5, 2024.

site_title: Canada pulls refugee welcome mat, launches ads warning asylum claims hard
summary: Canada is launching a global ad campaign warning asylum-seekers that claiming asylum is difficult and requires strict guidelines. The $250,000 campaign, in 11 languages, aims to combat misinformation and disinformation about Canada's immigration system. The move is part of a broader shift in tone by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government, which has been criticized for its immigration policies. The campaign comes as Canada faces a 260,000-case backlog in its refugee system and is hoping millions of people will leave the country on their own when their visas expire.

images.alt_text: Grocery prices have jumped 20 per cent over the past three years, while wages have grown by about 12 per cent, according to Statistics Canada data.

site_title: UK house prices up by most since March 2022
summary: The UK housing market saw a 1.2% increase in average home prices to US$340,000 in November, the largest rise since March 2022. This growth is attributed to rising real incomes and easing borrowing costs. Economists had expected a 0.2% increase. The market is on track for growth, with household balance sheets in good shape and debt levels at their lowest levels relative to income since the mid-2000s.

site_title: China’s 10-year yield sinks to record low on bets that PBOC will ease
summary: China's 10-year bond yield plummeted to a record low of 1.9995% as traders bet on the People's Bank of China (PBOC) easing monetary policy to boost the weak economy. The benchmark yield dropped two basis points after declining for a fifth straight week, while the 30-year yield fell four basis points to 2.17%. Analysts expect the PBOC to cut the reserve-requirement ratio and inject more cash into markets to stimulate growth, driven by concerns about escalating trade frictions with the US.

images.alt_text: The central bank also bought a net 200 billion yuan of sovereign bonds from dealers in November to ensure plentiful cash supply.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Dec 2)
summary: SingPost to divest its Australia business to a private equity fund for A$1 billion enterprise value. The deal follows a strategic review. JPMorgan has been fined S$2.4 million for misconduct by relationship managers, charging clients with spreads above agreed rates. Keppel DC Reit launches a preferential offering at S$2.03 apiece. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) also launches an open call for feedback on the upcoming Budget 2025, allowing Singaporeans to share their thoughts until January 12, 2025.

images.alt_text: XXXXX

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as China data provides hope but euro struggles
summary: Asia markets rose on Monday as China's manufacturing activity expanded at a faster clip than expected in November, providing hope that the world's number-two economy is turning a corner. The positive start to the week was not felt in the euro, however, as a budget standoff in France fueled concerns about the fragile government of the eurozone's second-biggest economy. The Dow and S&P 500 both ended at record highs in a holiday-shortened session, with Hong Kong and Shanghai among the best performers.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares open

site_title: Japanese companies boost capex in sign of confidence holding up
summary: Japanese companies boosted capital expenditure by 0.8% in the third quarter, driven by manufacturers, as corporate confidence remains strong. This increase in spending, excluding software, is a positive sign for the domestic economy and may prompt the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates as soon as December 19. GDP growth in the third quarter was 0.9% at an annualized pace, slightly beating expectations, and inflation accelerated faster than expected. The BOJ's governor, Kazuo Ueda, has stated that interest-rate hikes are "nearing" due to inflation and economic trends.

images.alt_text: The final au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) slipped to 49.0 in November, the lowest level since March, from 49.2 in October.
Shigeru Ishiba is likely to highlight his priority of trying to foster economic growth in Japan’s rural areas.
Manufacturers surveyed by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect seasonally adjusted output to fall 2.2 per cent in November and drop 0.5 per cent in December.
Public opinion polls in Japan generally show support for more defence spending, although there’s far less support for tax increases to pay for it.

site_title: A bird flu pandemic would be one of the most foreseeable catastrophes in history
summary: The US is facing a rapidly spreading bird flu pandemic among cattle, with no adequate response from the Biden administration to address the threat. The virus has infected a third of California's dairy herds and has the potential to spread to humans, with a child in California recently testing positive for the infection. The administration's failure to prioritize pandemic prevention and prepare for viral outbreaks has been criticized, with the incoming head of the public health agency, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., stating he would not prioritize research or vaccine distribution.

images.alt_text: H5N1 first emerged in 1996 but since 2020, the number of outbreaks in birds has grown exponentially, alongside an increase in the number of infected mammals.
A different variant of bird flu, H5N1, has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the United States, with a small number of cases reported among humans.
Observation of the virus has been spotty.

site_title:
Indonesia’s headline inflation eases 
to 1.55% in November
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation eased to 1.55% in November, slightly above the average forecast, but still within the lower end of Bank Indonesia's target range of 1.5-3.5%. The reduction in inflation reflects weak demand in the economy, with sectors such as housing, recreation, and education experiencing lower price increases. However, core inflation rose to 2.26% and telecommunication prices fell by 0.28%. Analysts predict a rise in inflation next year due to a potential increase in the value-added tax.

images.alt_text: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto looks on during a meeting with US President Joe Biden in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 12, 2024. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP)

epa11671455 Indonesia's newly inaugurated President Prabowo Subianto announces his Cabinet line-up at Merdeka Palace in Jakarta, Indonesia, 20 October 2024. Prabowo Subianto and running mate Gibran Rakabuming Raka were sworn in as the president and vice president after winning the 2024 presidential election.  EPA-EFE/ADI WEDA

Glinting in the sun by the world's biggest nuclear plant, the Sea of Japan is calm now. But as it gears up to restart Kashiwazaki-Kariwa has a new tsunami wall, just in case. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP) / To go with "JAPAN-NUCLEAR-POLITICS-CLIMATE-ECONOMY,FOCUS" by Simon STURDEE
Almost all products and services are subject to VAT, but staple foods and some items and services related to education and health are exempted.

site_title:
Asia’s factories perk up on China 
recovery but Trump risks loom
summary: Asia's largest manufacturing economies, including China, South Korea, and Taiwan, showed signs of recovery in November, with China's factory activity expanding at its fastest pace in five months. The improvement was driven by new export orders and a stimulus package launched by Beijing. However, risks to global trade from a potential second Donald Trump presidency loom large, with proposed tariffs on Chinese goods and weak patches in other parts of the region. Analysts say more stimulus is needed to sustain a stronger recovery.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s PMI stood at 49.7 in August, flat from the previous month, while that of Indonesia fell to 48.9 from 49.3 in July, the surveys showed.

site_title: JS-SEZ poised to attract ‘China Plus One’ investments with fast-tracked approvals, tax incentives
summary: The Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) is poised to attract "China Plus One" investments with fast-tracked approvals and tax incentives. Market experts expect the zone to drive high-value investments, diversify supply chains, and capitalize on shifting trade routes. The establishment of the JS-SEZ is timely, with US President Donald Trump set to return in January, and may provide an alternative to China for international companies. The zone is expected to create 100,000 high-quality job opportunities and encompass more than 10 key sectors, including manufacturing, logistics, and tourism.

images.alt_text: The proposed Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone covers Johor Bahru, Iskandar Puteri, Pasir Gudang, Pontian, Kulai and Kota Tinggi.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
Alvin Lee, country CEO of Maybank Singapore, says increasing SME support requires a greater risk appetite, but notes that this aligns with positive macroeconomic conditions.
Malaysia deputy investment, trade and industry minister Liew Chin Tong said that it is time for data centre players to form a trade association.
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.
South-east Asia’s data consumption and computing growth will require investments of as much as US$60 billion in infrastructure.

site_title: India factory growth softened in November on high inflationary pressures: PMI
summary: India's factory growth slowed to 5.4% in the July-September quarter, lower than expected, due to high inflationary pressures. Despite this, the business outlook for the year ahead improved, with a six-month high in the HSBC manufacturing PMI index. Strong demand from abroad and capacity expansion fueled growth, while inflationary pressures rose with input and output prices edging up. The Indian economy's inflation rate reached 6.21% in October, breaching the Reserve Bank of India's target range, leading economists to forecast a rate cut by the central bank in December.

images.alt_text: GDP growth in July-to-September quarter eased from 6.7 per cent seen in the previous quarter.
India, the world’s third-largest carbon dioxide emitter wants to attract investment and technology to be deployed on projects that would mitigate pollution and generate credits.

site_title: Indian central bank’s ballooning NDF position suggests more rupee losses: bankers
summary: The Reserve Bank of India's non-deliverable forward (NDF) position has surged to $49.2 billion, indicating the currency's significant pressure and likely further losses. The RBI is supporting the rupee after the US presidential election and India's economic slowdown, with bankers estimating the position to be around $65 billion to $70 billion. The surge reflects the RBI's efforts to manage the rupee's volatility, but experts warn that the currency's decline may accelerate amid multiple headwinds.

images.alt_text: GDP growth in July-to-September quarter eased from 6.7 per cent seen in the previous quarter.
High demand and capacity expansion led to a robust rise in the business outlook for the year ahead, pushing the sub-index to a six-month high.

site_title: Australia’s central bank says risks from non-bank lenders limited
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) stated that risks from non-bank lenders in securitisation are limited due to the small size of the sector and its funding from sophisticated investors. Despite rising mortgage arrears, the RBA noted that the financial system remains resilient, with only a fraction of loans in arrears being in negative equity. The RBA has maintained interest rates at a 12-year high of 4.35% for an entire year, driven by a resilient labour market. This suggests that the RBA is unlikely to cut interest rates until May next year.

site_title: Sembcorp stays on transformation course, but big bet on renewable energy comes with risks
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a Singapore-based company, is on track to become one of the purest renewable energy plays on the Singapore Exchange after making a strategic shift in 2021. The company has committed $14 billion to sustainability-related businesses over the next five years, with 75% earmarked for the renewables segment. However, the big bet on renewables comes with risks, including uncertain demand for renewable energy, which could dampen global trade and electricity demand. Despite this, Sembcorp's renewables business is growing, with its global capacity increasing to 16 GW, and the company is expected to remain active on the mergers and acquisitions front to shore up its finances.

images.alt_text: The proposed disposal of Sembcorp Environment was attributed to Sembcorp Industries’ intention to focus on growth in the energy sector.
Sembcorp Industries has inked an agreement to potentially build a hydrogen pipeline between Singapore and Indonesia.
Sembcorp Industries has been to build, own and operate a 300 megawatt wind-solar hybrid power project in India, the company said on Tuesday (Nov 26).

site_title: Chinese builder Shimao’s liquidation case is dismissed by court
summary: A Hong Kong court dismissed a creditor petition to liquidate Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese developer facing debt restructuring. The decision allows the company to push forward with its $11.5 billion restructuring plan. Shimao reported some banks and bondholders have indicated their approval of the plan, which includes added incentives. The company's shares rose 8.1% after the news, and it plans to request a meeting for a vote on the plan on January 16. This development adds to Shimao's momentum in completing its restructuring plan and continuing operations.

site_title: Nomura CEO to seek 28 billion yen in extra cost reductions
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, plans to seek an additional 28 billion yen (S$250 million) in cost reductions as part of its overhaul to boost profit. CEO Kentaro Okuda aims to rebuild the company's IT architecture, promote digitalization and automation, and review office locations. This move comes on top of a previous package of cost-saving measures, and follows recent setbacks including regulatory penalties and allegations of employee misconduct. Okuda will present his plans at the company's annual investment forum in Tokyo on December 3.

site_title: More pre-WWII former government quarters in Little India to be used for housing
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has set aside two rows of colonial-era terraced houses in Little India for residential use, following the rezoning of the properties in July 2024. The units, built in 1927 for government employees, were conserved in 1989 and previously marked for commercial use. The URA plans to conduct structural investigation work to assess the properties' condition and determine the needed "protection, structural restoration and strengthening" works. The rezoning aims to increase the area's live-in population and tap its central location and proximity to amenities.

Most households would be able to weather higher mortgage rates, even at higher interest rates and an income loss, says the Monetary Authority of Singapore.
There is growing concern among property players in Singapore over an excessive supply of new property launched, a survey by the National University of Singapore found.

site_title: Tesla, BYD ramp up China incentives in end-of-year sales push
summary: Electric vehicle makers Tesla and BYD have intensified their sales push in China by offering discounts and incentives until the end of December. Tesla provides a 5-year 0% loan and a 10,000 yuan discount on its Model Y, while BYD offers between 1,000 to 3,000 yuan off some models. The efforts come as smaller players compete with BYD, which commands about one-third of deliveries in the market, and as larger brands like Geely and Li Auto aim to meet annual sales targets.

images.alt_text: Discussions continue between the EU and China, but with little progress evident, a deal to replace the tariffs with price undertakings remains elusive for now.
JPMorgan sued Tesla in November 2021, seeking US$162.2 million.

site_title: HSBC starts search for next chairman: report
summary: HSBC has appointed headhunters to find its next chairman, with incumbent Mark Tucker set to step down by 2026. The leadership transition comes as the bank navigates global macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical tensions. Tucker, who became chairman in 2017, is the first outsider to hold the role, having previously worked at AIA. The bank will consider both existing non-executive directors and outsiders for the position, balancing its London headquarters with its key growth market in Asia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Nio, Keppel DC Reit, Boustead
summary: SingPost proposes selling its Australian business for A$1 billion (S$870 million), with proceeds used to repay borrowings and potentially issuing a special dividend. Nio delivered 20,575 vehicles in November, a 28.9% increase from last year. Keppel DC Reit opened a preferential offering of new units, and Boustead Singapore's joint venture will sell Como Orchard for about S$680 million. Trading halted for Dasin Retail Trust.

site_title: Malaysia urges Chinese firms to avoid using it to dodge US tariffs
summary: Malaysia's Deputy Trade Minister, Liew Chin Tong, has advised Chinese businesses not to invest in the country if they plan to rebrand products via Malaysia to avoid US tariffs. This comes amid US export restrictions on Chinese semiconductor toolmakers and equipment, including those manufactured in Malaysia, Singapore, and Taiwan. Malaysia, a major player in the semiconductor industry, is concerned about losing business as Chinese chip firms diversify overseas. The country is urging Chinese companies to explore alternative bases to avoid tariffs.

images.alt_text: Wired reported earlier that the US could come out with new export controls rules as soon as next Monday.
Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.

China has recently stepped up soybean purchases in Brazil, but it’s still picking up American cargoes for supplies that will be put in reserve.

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.

site_title: JPMorgan fined S$2.4 million by MAS for misconduct by relationship managers
summary: JPMorgan Chase Bank has paid a S$2.4 million civil penalty to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for misconduct by its relationship managers. The managers provided inaccurate or incomplete disclosures to clients, resulting in them being charged spreads above agreed rates for 24 over-the-counter bond transactions between November 2018 and September 2019. JPMorgan has strengthened its internal controls to prevent recurrence and separately compensated affected clients.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department usually jointly investigate market misconduct offences.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore says Credit Suisse has since strengthened its internal controls to prevent the recurrence of such misconduct.

site_title: Why Trump’s many erratic Cabinet nominations have the markets on edge
summary: US markets are on edge due to concerns about a second Trump administration, with economists warning that his economic policies are likely to cause more harm than good. Trump's erratic Cabinet nominations, including controversial picks like Robert F Kennedy Jr for health secretary, have weighed on Treasury bonds and caused some indices to give back post-election gains. Economists fear that Trump's tariff policy, if fully implemented, would be reckless, inflationary, and potentially destabilizing, and that the US government's growing deficit could lead to elevated Treasury yields.

images.alt_text: Market observers are optimistic that the establishment of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone will redefine economic dynamics between two countries, driven by infrastructure advancements and policy synergy.
China is in the midst of an export boom, with the value of shipments this year likely to hit a record.
Veteran diplomat Ted Osius believes the best way for the US to compete for influence in Asean is to lengthen the economic leg of the relationship.
Discussions continue between the EU and China, but with little progress evident, a deal to replace the tariffs with price undertakings remains elusive for now.

site_title: Swiss corruption case involving Trafigura and former executive opens
summary: Switzerland's top criminal court is set to rule on Trafigura's liability for allegedly bribing an Angolan oil official between 2009 and 2011. Four defendants, including a former Trafigura executive and a former Angolan official, will go on trial. Prosecutors claim the company paid bribes of over $5 million in exchange for oil and shipping contracts, resulting in a $143.7 million profit for Trafigura. The trial, which began on Monday, could lead to a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a fine of up to $7.53 million for Trafigura.

images.alt_text: The trading house heads to court on Dec 2 facing charges that its former parent company Trafigura Beheer BV failed to prevent unlawful payments over the 2009 to 2011 period, alongside former senior executive Mike Wainwright, a Swiss middleman who can only be named as P., and a senior Angolan public official Paulo Gouveia Junior.
Restored section of Brujula Verde project in Colombia
The debacle is shining another harsh light on Trafigura’s internal controls, and raises questions about why it took almost a year to fully disclose the situation.

site_title: Bulgari CEO eyes India for growth as China luxury demand weakens
summary: Bulgari CEO Jean-Christophe Babin is focusing on India for growth as China's luxury demand weakens due to an economic slowdown. Despite global luxury sales slumping in China, Babin sees strong growth potential in India's favourable demographics. The brand plans to enhance its e-commerce presence in China, reaching more luxury clients in smaller cities, rather than opening new physical stores. Babin downplays the luxury industry's slowdown, attributing this year's relative weakness to comparisons against an unusually strong 2023. India is expected to become one of the top 5 or 8 luxury markets worldwide.

images.alt_text: LVMH’s sales in the region that includes China fell 16 per cent in the third quarter, more than its 14 per cent drop in the previous three months.

site_title: Proposed Australia law would fine Big Tech over digital competition
summary: Australia has proposed a law that could impose fines of up to A$50 million on global tech companies for suppressing competition and preventing consumer switching. The law aims to empower the competition regulator to oversee compliance, investigate anti-competitive practices, and fine companies. The proposed law is similar to the European Union's Digital Markets Act and targets dominant platforms such as Google, Apple, and Meta. The consultation process is set to end on February 14, with specific obligations to restrict companies from pushing their apps with low user ratings to the top of their search list.

images.alt_text: Australia this week approved a landmark law banning social media for children under 16.
Dozens of state attorneys general have targeted Meta and ByteDance with suits accusing the companies of using harmful features to keep children on the platform longer to maximise profits.
