The social media network X on October 28, 2024 suspended an account that published Hebrew-language messages on behalf of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, just days after it was opened. (Photo by Mauro PIMENTEL / AFP)

site_title: Shiseido drops to eight-year low after growth plan underwhelms
summary: Shiseido shares plummet to an eight-year low after investors expressed disappointment with the company's growth plan, which aims to boost sales in Japan and other major markets to compensate for a slump in China. The company's operating profit margin target was lowered to 7% in 2026, down from 9% initially envisioned for 2025. The market reacted negatively to the plan, with shares falling 8.4% in early trading, their lowest since 2016. The company's CEO warned that the market will remain unstable for the foreseeable future.

images.alt_text: The chief executive of Japanese cosmetics giant Shiseido believes inbound tourism will return next year as the pandemic abates, beginning a gradual recovery in sales of high-end goods to travellers.

site_title: Germany‘s top diplomat will not ‘ignore’ China disputes on visit
summary: German Foreign Minister Anna Baerbock stated she won't gloss over points of contention with China during her upcoming visit, emphasizing cooperation over confrontation. She cited a recent climate summit example, but also addressed long-running disputes over China's subsidies and support for its businesses, which led to EU import tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles. Baerbock plans to discuss China's support for Russia in Ukraine and its "economic and military support" against European interests, stating "we cannot ignore this."

images.alt_text: Both official and private measures of October factory activity exceeded analyst expectations.
Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong's China tour has come shortly after a working visit to the US in the middle of November, after Donald Trump was re-elected.
Discussions continue between the EU and China, but with little progress evident, a deal to replace the tariffs with price undertakings remains elusive for now.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit launches preferential offering at S$2.03 apiece
summary: Keppel DC Reit launched a preferential offering of 148.4 million new units at S$2.03 apiece, representing a 4.5% discount from its six-month volume-weighted average price. The non-renounceable offering aims to raise S$1.1 billion in gross proceeds, part of an equity funding exercise. The offering opens on Dec 2 and closes on Dec 10.

images.alt_text: Proceeds from the private placement will be used to partially fund the purchase two data centres at Keppel Data Centre Campus (above).

site_title: Bangladesh estimates US$16 billion syphoned yearly in Hasina rule
summary: Bangladesh's interim leader Muhammad Yunus claims an estimated $16 billion may have been illicitly syphoned out of the country annually during former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's 15-year rule. A committee led by economist Debapriya Bhattacharya found that seven large projects had costs inflated from $1.14 trillion to $1.95 trillion. The report accuses crony capitalism of creating oligarchs who controlled policy-making. The findings are part of a 400-page white paper, which has raised concerns among leaders in Sheikh Hasina's party, who are either in jail, hiding, or have left the country.

images.alt_text: Supply from the 1,600 megawatt plant, which uses expensive imported coal, started last year and meets about a tenth of Bangladesh’s consumption.
Adani Power, controlled by Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, cut supplies after overdue payments crossed US$850 million.
Adani Power’s move exacerbates the electricity deficit in the country of about 174 million people.

site_title: SingPost’s turnaround: Can the mailman deliver?
summary: SingPost, Singapore's only public postal licensee, is making progress in its turnaround efforts. The company has identified non-core assets, such as its Australian business and freight forwarder unit, to sell, which could unlock S$900 million to S$1.1 billion of proceeds. SingPost aims to reduce debt and interest expenses, but faces a larger existential conundrum as it no longer provides a public utility service. The company has reported a S$900,000 operating loss in its latest half-year earnings period, but revenue from higher postage rates has boosted its Singapore operations.

images.alt_text: Share buybacks have been around for as long as our oldest and grumpiest millennials, but just as with millennials, no one can agree on whether they are good for business, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
South-east Asia’s e-commerce firms have something to show for all that financial sobriety, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.
Beyond the knee-jerk US equity euphoria, there is disquiet as election uncertainty is replaced by uncertainty about everything else, writes BT columnist Joyce Hooi.

site_title: MOF launches open call for feedback on Singapore Budget 2025
summary: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has launched an open call for feedback on Singapore's Budget 2025, which will be presented in February 2025. From December 2 to January 12, 2025, Singaporeans can provide suggestions on themes such as SG60: Building Our Singapore Together, skills upgrading, jobs for workers, and supporting Singaporeans across different life stages. Feedback can be submitted through online channels, physical platforms, and physical listening points. The MOF aims to engage with individuals, organizations, and businesses to inform the budget's focus areas, including economic strategies and jobs, to address the cost of living concerns.

images.alt_text: A “less hospitable” geopolitical environment – especially for small countries – is why Singapore must “work even harder” to strengthen its network of friends and partners, said PM Wong, who has made various overseas visits in recent months.
XXXXX

site_title: Singapore stocks close up 0.3%, tracking strong gains in Asia on positive China data
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% to close at 3,751.35, tracking gains in Asia led by Chinese shares. The Straits Times Index was boosted by a top gainer in Genting Singapore and gains in DBS and UOB. Macquarie expects heightened US-China tensions to fuel trends benefiting Singapore, including FDI and wealth inflows. China's factory activity expanded at the fastest pace in five months, with the Shanghai Composite gaining 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Telecom group Singtel was the top gainer on the Straits Times Index, rising 1.6% or S$0.05 to S$3.10.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity falls at fastest pace in 8 months: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted at the fastest pace in 8 months in November, with the au Jibun Bank Japan manufacturing PMI falling to 49.0 from 49.2 in October. Soft demand prompted firms to trim production, leading to a record decline in output and employment. Subdued demand in Japan and overseas, as well as weak exports, were the main factors behind the contraction. However, input cost pressures remained strong, and manufacturers remained positive about their business outlook, with confidence rising to the highest in three months.

images.alt_text: Tokyo’s core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food costs, rose 2.2 per cent year on year in November from a year earlier.
Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda suggests the central bank will avoid rushing to rate hikes as President-elect Donald Trump takes office in January.
Shigeru Ishiba is likely to highlight his priority of trying to foster economic growth in Japan’s rural areas.

site_title: Nine Volkswagen plants on strike as worker rift with management deepens
summary: Nine Volkswagen plants in Germany have gone on strike, bringing assembly lines to a halt, as workers clash with management over wage demands. The strikes, which include a 10% wage cut, are part of a broader dispute over cost-cutting measures and plant closures. The crisis has added to economic uncertainty in Germany and the wider automotive industry, with Volkswagen's production set to be reduced. The union is demanding concessions, including a halt to plant closures and wage cuts, while management is pushing for cost savings.

images.alt_text: The Volkswagen logo is displayed on the Volkswagen power plant on the day when Volkswagen AG and the industrial union IG Metall started talks over a new labor agreement for six of its German plants, in Wolfsburg, Germany, September 25, 2024. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

Employees carry out quality control tests as strip lights illuminate Volkswagen Phaeton automobiles at the Volkswagen AG factory in Dresden, Germany, on Thursday, April 9, 2015. German industrial production was bolstered by investment-goods output in February, highlighting improved confidence in the recovery in Europe's largest economy. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

The Volkswagen logo is displayed on the Volkswagen power plant on the day when Volkswagen AG and the industrial union IG Metall started talks over a new labor agreement for six of its German plants, in Wolfsburg, Germany, September 25, 2024. REUTERS/Annegret Hilse

Workers are prepared to make concessions worth 1.5 billion euros (S$2.12 billion) in savings in the ongoing negotiations, but said this was contingent on Volkswagen ruling out plant closures as well as stakeholder.

site_title: Countries fail to reach agreement in UN plastic talks
summary: Countries failed to reach an agreement on a landmark treaty to curb plastic pollution at the UN Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee (INC-5) in Busan, South Korea. The treaty aimed to cap plastic production, manage plastic products, and address chemicals of concern. Negotiators agreed to postpone key decisions and resume talks, citing entrenched divisions among countries. The treaty's failure underscores the complexity of addressing global plastic pollution and the need for further deliberations.

images.alt_text: Plastic fishing floats and other debris are being washed up along the shore of the Miaodao Archipelago in Yantai, in eastern China's Shandong province.

On Nov 24, German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock became the latest Western politician to slam petrostates for their “geopolitical power play on the backs of the poorest and most vulnerable countries".

A forklift moves bales of PET plastic bottles before they are recycled at the Plastipak Infineo recycling plant in Saint-Marie-La-Blanche, France, June 1, 2023. In 2019, the world produced around 460 million tonnes of plastic, a figure that has doubled since 2000, according to OECD.
Sacks of untreated and shredded plastic waste, which is left unattended, are piled at an inoperational recycling site in Asan, South Korea, Nov 19, 2024.
More than 90 per cent of plastic is not recycled, with over 20 million tonnes leaking into the environment, often after just a few minutes of use.

site_title: Japanese brewer hopes Unesco listing makes sake as popular as sushi
summary: Japanese brewer Ishikawa Shuzou hopes that a potential Unesco listing of its traditional brewing technique will boost the popularity of sake, a traditional Japanese beverage. The technique, known as "San-Dan-Jikomi," has been fermenting for 20 days and is expected to be formally endorsed at a Unesco committee session in Paraguay. The brewer, Koichi Maesako, believes that the listing will increase demand for sake overseas, where it has gained popularity alongside Japanese cuisine, and help the industry recover from a difficult couple of years marked by warm weather, high rice costs, and declining sales.

images.alt_text: The new brewery offers a look at the steps the Gulf’s rulers are taking to open their economies in a Muslim region with conservative social norms
The distillery's operations include a 1,000 sq ft cellar, housing more than 100 barrels, says Crystalla Huang, brewmaster at RedDot BrewHouse.

site_title: Oil inches up on upbeat China data, shaky Israel-Lebanon ceasefire
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, driven by upbeat factory activity in China and concerns over a fragile ceasefire in the Middle East. Brent crude futures climbed 8 cents to $71.92 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 9 cents to $68.09 a barrel. The increase comes despite a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Lebanon, which has been breached by both sides. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) is also discussing delaying its oil output hike, citing concerns over US President Donald Trump's trade policies and China's economic response.

images.alt_text: Opec+ is expected to decide on a further extension to production cuts at its next policy meeting.

site_title: Australian retail sales strengthen in positive sign for holidays
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.6% in October, exceeding forecasts, marking the third consecutive month of gains. The increase was driven by online discounting events and spending on discretionary items such as televisions and audio-visual equipment. Sales also rose 3.4% from a year earlier, with non-food industries, including household goods and liquor, experiencing significant growth. The data suggests a positive sign for the holiday season, but the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hold interest rates steady until 2025, citing high inflation.

images.alt_text: Sydney fell 0.2 per cent in November from the prior month – its second straight monthly decline, property consultancy CoreLogic said on Monday (Dec 2). Melbourne, where values have fallen in 10 of the past 12 months, slipped too as prices in major cities rose just 0.1 per cent in November.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed its monthly consumer price index (CPI) rose at an annual pace of 2.1 per cent in October, unchanged from September and under market forecasts of 2.3 per cent.

site_title: Meta tightens ad rules to curb financial scams aimed at Australians
summary: Meta Platforms has introduced stricter rules for advertisers of financial products and services targeting Australians to curb scams on its platforms. The new rules require advertisers to verify their beneficiary and payer information, including their Australian Financial Services License number, before running financial services ads. The move aims to protect people in Australia from sophisticated scammers using fake investment schemes. This follows Meta's previous efforts to crack down on "celeb bait" ads and comes ahead of a federal election in Australia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A keyboard is placed in front of a displayed Facebook logo in this illustration taken February 21, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Meta, then known as Facebook, overpaid for Instagram in 2012 and WhatsApp in 2014 to eliminate nascent threats instead of competing on its own in the mobile ecosystem, the FTC claims.
Meta plans to reduce the price of ad-free subscriptions by about 40 per cent for European users.

site_title: Gold slips as dollar strengthens; investors await US data
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.7% to $2,633.86 per ounce, snapping a four-session rally, amid a strengthened US dollar and anticipation of key US economic data. Investors await clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy outlook, with a 65.2% chance of a 25-basis-point rate reduction in December. Gold's appeal as an inflation hedge is dulled by higher interest rates, leading to its worst monthly performance since September 2023.

images.alt_text: Bullion is traditionally seen as a safe investment during economic, geopolitical uncertainties and tends to thrive in a lower interest rate environment.

site_title: Malaysia’s jailed ex-PM Najib to argue appeal for house arrest
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak will begin his defense this week against graft charges related to the 1MDB scandal, which led to his defeat in the 2018 elections. Najib faces six years in jail for corruption and abuse of power, with the option to serve the remaining sentence under house arrest if his appeal is successful. The case involves alleged bribes of over US$500 million and 1MDB's misuse of public funds, which sparked investigations in the US, Switzerland, and Singapore.

images.alt_text: The High Court of Malaysia granted a discharge not amounting to acquittal (DNAA) to former Prime Minister Najib Razak in a 1MDB-linked trial, citing significant delays since 2018 and the prosecution's failure to provide key documents.
The Kuala Lumpur High Court granted their bid for a discharge not amounting to an acquittal, due to procedural delays and the failure of the prosecution to disclose key documents, their lawyers said.
Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak issued a rare apology last week for his role in mishandling the scandal, which occurred during his tenure as prime minister and finance minister.

FILE PHOTO: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak escorted by prison officers, waves to photographers as the jailed politician leaves the court after court proceedings in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia January 19, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: UK business morale ticks lower but trading prospects healthy: Lloyds Bank
summary: UK business confidence dropped to a 5-month low in November, with the Lloyds Bank Business Barometer falling 3 points to 41%, still above the long-run average of 29%. Despite this, companies remain optimistic about trading prospects, with manufacturers, services, and construction firms showing increased positivity. However, retailers have become gloomier, echoing a downbeat Confederation of British Industry survey. This reflects ongoing price pressures and a slowdown in activity, but the overall outlook remains resilient.

images.alt_text: The UK’s Office for National Statistics has been struggling to collect sufficient and accurate data on employment trends, leading to severe criticism from central bankers and politicians.

FILE PHOTO: Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, gestures as he addresses the media during a press conference at the Bank of England in London, Britain, August 1, 2024. Alberto Pezzali/Pool via REUTERS/File Photo
Banks and building societies approved 68,300 home loans in October, an increase from 66,100 the previous month.
Dealmakers may be making a last push to secure fees before the end of the year.

Businesses that repeatedly flout visa rules or commit serious employment breaches, such as not paying the minimum wage, will be barred from recruiting foreign workers for two years, up from the current 12 months, the UK government said.
UK car production is down 10.8 per cent at 670,346 units to date this year, primarily due to a decline in exports, SMMT said.
Halifax said the average house in the third quarter of 2024 cost 6.55 times the mean annual full-time income, down from 6.62 in 2023 and a record high of 7.24 in mid-2022.

site_title: MAS is right to resist push for even looser leverage requirements for Singapore Reits
summary: MAS has implemented its proposals for a minimum interest coverage ratio (ICR) of 1.5 times and an aggregate leverage limit of 50% for real estate investment trusts (Reits), after receiving broad support. The proposals aim to strike a balance between allowing Reits to maintain financial stability and avoiding overly restrictive leverage requirements. The regulator rejected a suggestion to consider foreign exchange and interest rate volatility, as well as tenant defaults, as events beyond the control of a Reit's manager, to avoid breaching the minimum ICR threshold.

images.alt_text: A committee formed by Quarz Capital wants MAS and SGX RegCo to weigh in on whether ESR Group should be barred from voting on the extraordinary resolution to amend Sabana Reit's trust deed.
MAS wants to subject all S-Reits to a minimum ICR of 1.5 times, and an aggregate leverage cap of 50 per cent.
Various stakeholders have expressed broad support for its proposed changes, says MAS.
In MAS' annual Financial Stability Review, it noted that the overall banking sector maintained or improved across the indicators for financial vulnerability.
The debt maturity profiles of Singapore-listed companies are stable, says MAS in its report.

site_title: Vietnam’s premier aims for about 8% economic growth in 2025
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh aims for approximately 8% economic growth in 2025, significantly higher than the parliament's 6.5-7% target. The government forecasts record-high total imports and exports of $807.7 billion this year. To achieve this, the government will prioritize promoting economic growth while controlling inflation, ensuring a budget deficit and public debt within reasonable limits. This growth target is seen as "the year of acceleration" for Vietnam's economy.

images.alt_text: A vendor walks along a railway track as she sells cakes for tourists outside cafes in Hanoi, Vietnam October 8, 2019. Picture taken October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo
Vietnam is a significant exporter to the US and has a large trade surplus with Washington.

site_title: Modi’s government distances itself from US probe into Adani
summary: India's government has distanced itself from a US probe into Adani Group, a port-to-power conglomerate led by billionaire Gautam Adani, who is considered a close ally of Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The US Department of Justice is investigating Adani for allegedly promising to pay $250 million in bribes to Indian officials. India's External Affairs Ministry said the US probe is a "legal matter involving private firms and individuals" and that it has not been informed in advance. The ministry also stated that it has not received any request for service of summons or arrest warrant from the US side.

images.alt_text: The Japanese support underscores the divide among finance firms over Adani.
State Bank of India will not stop lending to ongoing Adani projects that are nearing completion, but will exercise caution when disbursing loans to ensure all terms and conditions are being met.
The Department of Justice’s indictment does not mention Gautam Adani (above), Sagar Adani or Vneet Jaain in any count related to conspiracy to violate the FCPA.

The Nov 20 bombshell indictment in New York accused billionaire industrialist founder Gautam Adani and multiple subordinates of deliberately misleading international investors as part of the bribery scheme.

site_title: South Korea’s factory activity picks up on strong Asia demand: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity showed a significant improvement in November, with the purchasing managers index (PMI) rising to 50.6, above the 50 mark that separates expansion from contraction. This marks the first increase in new orders in three months, driven by strong demand in Asia. Output fell, but the decline was milder than the previous month. The improvement in manufacturing conditions is attributed to the growth in new export orders, the fastest pace since July.

images.alt_text: South Korea's exports adjusted for working-day differences rose 3.6 per cent in November from a year earlier, rebounding from a dip in the prior month, data from the trade ministry showed on Sunday

South Korean K-pop girl group NewJeans members (from left) Haerin, Danielle, Minji, Hanni, and Hyein attended a press conference in Seoul on Nov 28, announcing their decision to leave their label ADOR, accusing the company of 'mistreatment.'
The Bank of Korea lowered its benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point to 3.00 per cent at its monetary policy review, an outcome only four of 38 economists polled by Reuters foresaw.

site_title: Singapore’s energy sector to offer highest bonuses in 2025, transport firms lead salary increments: survey
summary: Singapore's energy sector is expected to offer the highest bonuses in 2025, with all respondents planning to award at least one month or more. Transport firms are set to lead in salary increments, with 91% intending to raise salaries by 3% or more. 89% of employers plan to award bonuses averaging more than one month, a 5-point increase from the previous year, with 35% aiming for between one and one-and-a-half months. Salary increments are also expected to rise, with 82% planning to raise wages by at least 3%.

images.alt_text: Real income growth for 2019 to 2024 was just 0.7 per cent per annum, compared with 3.8 per cent per annum in the five years prior.
Singapore’s old-age support ratio nearly halves in 10 years, but foreign workforce provides buffer: MOM
In the manufacturing sector, a majority of the respondents say they will not implement a four-day work week in their organisations.

site_title: Bangladesh wants to renegotiate Adani power deal unless court cancels
summary: Bangladesh's energy minister, Muhammad Fouzul Kabir Khan, has stated that the country will renegotiate its 25-year power deal with Adani Group unless a court cancels it due to alleged irregularities. The deal, signed in 2017, involves the import of expensive imported coal from India's Jharkhand state, meeting about a tenth of Bangladesh's consumption. Khan emphasized that Bangladesh wants to lower prices unless the contract is canceled, citing the high cost of imported coal.

images.alt_text: Adani Power, controlled by Indian billionaire Gautam Adani, cut supplies after overdue payments crossed US$850 million.
Adani Power’s move exacerbates the electricity deficit in the country of about 174 million people.

site_title: BlackRock is near deal to buy private credit manager HPS
summary: BlackRock is near a deal to buy private credit manager HPS Investment Partners for $12 billion or more, valuing the firm at its current size. The acquisition would catapult BlackRock into the top ranks of private credit, bolstering its alternative assets to over $500 billion. The deal would also solidify BlackRock's expansion into private markets, rivaling private-asset leaders like KKR and Apollo Global Management, and adding significant revenue and profit to the firm.

images.alt_text: Former BlackRock fund manager Kate Moore (pictured here in 2017) will become Citigroup's chief investment officer for its wealth division in February 2025.
ETFs have steadily taken over vast parts of the securities business in part because they are easier to shift in and out of rapidly, making them a draw to individual investors.
BlackRock has been on an acquisition spree this year as it looks to become an all-in-one platform for investors by integrating public and private markets.
BlackRock is putting portions of about 300 first-lien loan positions into the deal, slated to be among the largest ever transfers of private credit into a so-called continuation fund.

site_title: EV maker Lion Electric wins temporary creditor relief, halts US factory
summary: Lion Electric, a US electric bus manufacturer, has temporarily laid off about 400 workers and halted operations at its Illinois factory due to a cash crunch. The company received a short-term lifeline from its lenders, allowing it to continue evaluating restructuring options or a sale of its business. Lion faces supply chain disruptions and a dispute with a battery supplier, leading to a 90% decline in shares since this year. The company will focus on bus manufacturing, sales, and customer support with approximately 300 remaining employees.

images.alt_text: November's figure was slightly lower than the 20,976 vehicles delivered in October.

site_title: SingPost to divest Australia business at A$1 billion enterprise value to private equity fund
summary: SingPost is selling its Australian business to Pacific Equity Partners for A$1 billion, generating a gain of about S$312.1 million. The deal, expected to be completed by March 2025, will reduce SingPost's debt and strengthen its balance sheet. The company plans to use some proceeds to repay debt and consider a special dividend. SingPost's Australia segment includes logistics services, courier delivery, and warehousing, which contributed S$574.8 million in revenue and S$30.4 million in operating profit in the first half of 2024.

images.alt_text: SingPost's property leasing segment largely comprises SingPost Centre, where occupancy rates are up as at end-September compared to end-March 2024.
ST20240503_202421361534 Kua Chee Siong/ pixgeneric/ Generic pix of the Singapore Post (SingPost) logo on the SingPost Centre building on May 3, 2024.

The Singapore Post board noted that incoming chief financial officer Vincent Yik is expected to lead "the continued transformation of our business, especially with Australia as a key part of our strategy".
SingPost’s Australian business logged a revenue of S$574.8 million for the half year ending Sep 30, up from S$398.8 million a year earlier.

site_title: ‘Moana 2’ sails to Thanksgiving record with smash North American opening
summary: "Moana 2" breaks the record for the biggest Thanksgiving opening in North America, earning $220 million over the long Thanksgiving weekend. The animated Disney musical surpassed expectations, with a 5-day start that exceeded the 3-day start of the first "Moana" in 2016. The film's success follows "Wicked: Part I" and "Gladiator II," which took second and third place, respectively. The Thanksgiving box office total reached a record $422 million.

images.alt_text: Maurizio Cattelan's conceptual work featuring a banana, being auctioned at Sotheby's in New York on  Nov 20. The work sold for US$6.2 million with fees.
People attend a projection of the Danish silent movie "The Mannequins" accompanied by a live piano performance, at the Cinema Museum, in London.

Hello Kitty merchandise is displayed for sale at the Sanrio Smile Shop at Universal Studios Hollywood in Universal City, California. Kitty’s appeal is often attributed to her expressionless, mouth-free face, which is said to allow fans to project their own feelings onto her.

site_title: Black Friday sales accelerate with online a bright spot
summary: US Black Friday sales grew 3.4% this year, outpacing last year's growth, driven by e-commerce sales that rose 14.6% to a record $10.8 billion. In-store sales, however, rose only 0.7%, lower than last year's pace. Consumers, burned out from post-pandemic inflation, are becoming more price-sensitive and intentional about their spending, with many cutting budgets and spreading out holiday purchases. Retailers are responding by offering more deals and discounts, particularly online, as the shopping season continues through the weekend and into Cyber Week.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 38.0 points, or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 44,760.05.

site_title: Australian home prices rise at weakest pace in almost 2 years
summary: Australian home prices rose at their weakest pace in nearly two years, driven by declining prices in Sydney and Melbourne. Major cities saw a 0.1% increase in November, the slowest pace since February 2023. Home sales over the past three months are estimated to be 4.6% lower than a year ago, with Sydney experiencing a 15.4% drop. Higher interest rates, a housing shortage, and population growth have triggered a housing crisis, with buyers priced out of the market in Sydney and apartments outperforming houses.

images.alt_text: The average price across 100 cities edged up 0.36 per cent, compared with the previous month’s 0.29 per cent, according to data released by property researcher China Index Academy.

site_title: F&B business openings slow so far in 2024, but observers say industry remains attractive
summary: Food and beverage (F&B) businesses in Singapore have opened at a slower rate in 2024, with a formation rate of 11% in the first nine months, down from 14% in the previous year. Despite this, the industry remains attractive due to its potential for growth, with the absolute number of formations being the second-highest in the last eight years. Observers attribute the slowdown to rising costs, but the F&B sector's resilience and adaptability are expected to continue supporting its attractiveness.

images.alt_text: Singapore's F&B industry has welcomed more businesses while consumer spending stagnated.
PHOTO: In the first nine months of 2024, 2,465 F&B businesses ceased operations. Restaurant Uni Gallery closed in August this year.

site_title: Nissan CFO set to step down as carmaker faces raft of challenges
summary: Nissan's CFO, Stephen Ma, is set to step down amid the company's challenges, including a 70% drop in operating income forecast and 9,000 job cuts. Ma's departure follows a recent executive change and comes as Nissan faces criticism from activist investor Effissimo Capital Management. The company's market capitalization has shrunk from a peak of $6 trillion in 2015 to $1.5 trillion, and CEO Makoto Uchida will be left as the sole top-level executive. Nissan's lineup and spending on incentives have been criticized, and the company now plans to cut production capacity.

images.alt_text: Nissan’s worldwide output for October decreased 6 per cent from the same month a year earlier to 290,848 vehicles.
Nissan builds cars and engines in Mexico and the spectre of steep tariffs on US imports adds to its woes.
NIssan earlier this month announced a plan to cut 9,000 jobs worldwide after posting worse-than-expected half-year earnings.
Roughly 1,000 US employees are set to leave Nissan by the end of this year as a result of the early retirements.

site_title: OpenAI’s Altman confident Trump will keep US in AI lead
summary: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman expressed confidence that US President-elect Donald Trump's administration will support the artificial intelligence sector, ensuring the US leads in AI technology. Altman believes massive infrastructure support, including electricity, data centers, and semiconductors, is needed to lead globally. He also emphasized the need for legislation to establish safeguards for AI use, stating it should be a societal decision rather than OpenAI's alone.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has alleged that OpenAI bars its investors from making investments in rivals – which would put his own startup at a disadvantage in a sector where billions of dollars are at stake.
Two years after capturing the public’s imagination, it seems that ChatGPT’s main legacy has been in padding the finances of tech’s biggest players.
The lawsuit is the first by Canadian media against OpenAI.
OpenAI employees have until Dec 24 to join the new funding round, with stock prices matching the last round, funded by SoftBank’s Vision Fund 2.
AI adoption today remains largely confined to narrow applications within existing operations, such as a financial-services firm using an AI app for fraud detection.
Nvidia’s version generates sound effects and music from a text description, including novel sounds such as making a trumpet bark like a dog.

site_title: Bitcoin stalls short of US$100,000. What next?
summary: Bitcoin fails to breach the $100,000 level despite a surge in investor interest and a more crypto-friendly regulatory climate in the US, following President-elect Donald Trump's win. Analysts believe the bull trend remains intact, with Bitcoin potentially reaching $120,000 and even $200,000 in 2025. The cryptocurrency's current bull run has more legs to go, particularly after the recent Bitcoin halving, which created a scarcity effect and could lead to a longer cycle.

images.alt_text: The digital asset fell as low as US$95,776 on Sunday after coming within US$300 of the six-figure milestone on Friday.

site_title: European-focused S-Reits broaden their mandate, confident that continent has moved beyond the market trough
summary: European real estate market recovery has started after a two-year repricing period, driven by rising interest rates and inflation. Property valuations have stabilized and recovered, with European transactions reversing a decline of 76% from 2021 peaks. S-Reits with European exposure are expected to benefit, with a recent acquisition by Stoneweg's proposed takeover of Cromwell's European business seen as a positive move. Enhanced European resources and a pivot to logistics are expected to provide investors with benefits.

images.alt_text: The manager of CapitaLand Ascott Trust said on Oct 1 that it was acquiring lyf Funan Singapore at an agreed property value of S$263 million.

site_title: Asean governments face risk of fiscal strain from climate change without policies to attract private capital
summary: Asean governments face significant fiscal strain from climate change if they fail to attract private capital, diverting funds from healthcare and education. The lack of a climate finance agreement, with the US$1 trillion target unsecured, puts pressure on emerging markets in South-east Asia to develop policy frameworks for climate-focused investments. Without sufficient funds, governments risk increasing financial strain, burdening public finances and diverting resources from other priorities, exacerbating the impact of climate change on vulnerable regions.

images.alt_text: Vehicles transferring coal in China. Over the past decade and even just last year, fossil fuel energy has increased twice as much as green energy.
Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Bahlil Lahadalia
India, the world’s third-largest carbon dioxide emitter wants to attract investment and technology to be deployed on projects that would mitigate pollution and generate credits.
Climate activists at a protest at the UN Climate Change Conference COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan, Nov 23, 2024.

A hoppy pilsner called NEWBrew made from recycled toilet water is given out for free at the Singaporean pavilion at COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan on Nov. 20, 2024. The hoppy pilsner from Singapore, where freshwater is scarce, is part of an effort to promote recycling solutions. (Douglas Alteen/The New York Times)

Nations had struggled at COP29 to reconcile long-standing divisions over how much developed nations most accountable for historic climate change should provide to poorer countries least responsible but most impacted by Earth’s rapid warming.
The shift in position comes after a previous proposal for the climate deal was deemed "insultingly low" by developing countries.

Peru’s Deputy Minister of Strategic Development of Natural Resources Raquel Soto (left) and Singapore’s Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu at COP29. The progress with Peru is the second bilateral carbon credit collaboration that Singapore has made advances in at the summit.
An installation is on display near the venue of the United Nations climate change conference COP29 in Baku, Azerbaijan November 16, 2024. REUTERS/Janis Laizans

site_title: SG Enable, Zero Project host first Apac symposium on inclusive hiring and workplaces
summary: SG Enable, in collaboration with Zero Project, hosted the first Asia-Pacific symposium on inclusive hiring and workplaces. The event aimed to boost disability inclusion across the region, focusing on employment for persons with disabilities. Companies signed a memorandum of understanding to enhance barrier-free access routes and scale inclusive infrastructure. Panel discussions highlighted the benefits of inclusive hiring, with companies sharing that it leads to more purpose-driven employees, innovative learning cultures, and increased staff retention rates. Attendees also toured accessible attractions, and the symposium is part of a three-year MOU between SG Enable and Zero Project to advance inclusivity.

images.alt_text: The Foundry's revamp managed to capture the "feel of an elections department", said President Tharman, who was present at the launch.

site_title: COP29 shows South-east Asia’s energy transition needs private finance; effective policies will catalyse that
summary: South-east Asia needs $210 billion annually to meet its renewable energy transition needs, far exceeding the $300 billion agreed upon by developed nations at COP29. The region's high carbon emissions and limited renewable energy capacity pose significant climate change risks, with potential 11% GDP loss by 2100 and 87 million people living in flood-risk zones. Effective policies are crucial to accelerate private investment in renewable energy solutions, as the region cannot rely solely on developed nations. China's successful energy transition, driven by policy and regulation, serves as a model for South-east Asia's transition.

images.alt_text: Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Bahlil Lahadalia

site_title: Technical indicators point to further upside for USDCAD
summary: USDCAD pair surged to a high of 1.417 on Nov 27, 2024, breaking out of a symmetrical triangle pattern and confirming a bullish outlook. The breakout, accompanied by a retest of support, suggests further upside, with potential targets at 1.467 and 1.5000. Historically significant resistance levels are in sight, and the pair's long-term uptrend remains intact, offering opportunities for traders aligning with the broader market direction.

images.alt_text: As long as USD/JPY remains above the critical support at 151.7, the bullish outlook for 2024 remains intact, with further gains likely in the coming months.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Future-proof your money from dementia
summary: A 2015 study found 1 in 10 Singaporeans aged 60 and above have dementia, with the number expected to double to 152,000 by 2030. To manage finances or help a loved one with dementia, forming a "financial squad" with professionals like lawyers and financial advisors is crucial. Early financial planning and exploring financial instruments and government aids can also help. Discussing financial management with a loved one showing early signs of dementia is essential, and resources like partnerships with AIC and Dementia Singapore can provide guidance.

images.alt_text: Will finance influencers replace traditional advisors?
How will changes to the CPF Act affect your retirement savings?
Pearlyn Phau, Group CEO, Singlife and Jason Foo, CEO, Dementia Singapore.

site_title: Yen hits 6-week high after faster-than-expected inflation support bets for a Dec BOJ rate hike
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a six-week high against the dollar after Tokyo's core consumer price index rose 2.2% year-over-year in November, beating forecasts and supporting bets for a Bank of Japan interest rate hike in December. The dollar declined 1.27% against the yen, with the dollar index expected to fall 1.78% in November. Stronger-than-expected inflation data and potential US interest rate cuts have boosted bets for a rate hike, with analysts pricing in 66% odds for a 25 basis point cut at the Federal Reserve's December meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japanese 10,000 yen notes are spread out next to U.S. 100 dollar bills at Interbank Inc. money exchange in Tokyo, in this September 9, 2010 picture illustration. REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo

site_title: FedEx throws weight behind freight to fire up Apac growth engine
summary: FedEx, a US-based logistics giant, is shifting its focus to freight forwarding to boost earnings in the Asia-Pacific region. With its three major hubs in Incheon, Tokyo, and Singapore, FedEx is well-positioned to serve the biomedical and pharmaceutical industries, which require specialized logistics. The company aims to increase freight shipping by one percentage point each year for the next five years, doubling its existing freight volumes. FedEx's strategy is driven by the huge potential for freight growth in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

images.alt_text: FedEx Singapore's Mercedes-Benz eVito 112 fully-electric delivery van can travel up to 321 kilometres on a full charge.

FedEx is in the process of integrating its Ground and Express delivery networks as part of a wider cost-cutting drive.
FedEx eyes freighter order as e-commerce soars: sources

site_title: Kamala's coda: What's next for defeated US VP Harris?
summary: US Vice President Kamala Harris has begun discussing her future plans after her defeat in the November election. Speculation surrounds a potential bid for California governor in 2026, a move that would give her a platform to reassert herself on the national stage. Harris has also considered continuing in politics without holding office, following a similar path taken by former President Bill Clinton's vice president Al Gore. A governorship in California would be a fitting culmination to her trailblazing career, but Harris faces challenges in regaining the party's faith after a significant loss.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump made inroads with young voters in part by stressing his economic pitch — a message that appeared to resonate with young adults struggling with student loans and high costs for everything from groceries to housing.

Supporters of Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris at a campaign rally. Devastating as the election defeat feels to many US Democrats, they can look internationally, including to the UK, for inspiration.

Democratic presidential nominee U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris delivers remarks, conceding 2024 U.S. presidential election to President-elect Donald Trump, at Howard University in Washington, U.S., November 6, 2024. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque

site_title: Social media is bad for kids. What’s being done about it?
summary: Australian lawmakers have passed a bill banning children under 16 from setting up accounts on popular social media sites, including Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, and TikTok. The ban, set to take effect in about a year, will be enforced by the platforms themselves, with penalties of up to $50 million for non-compliance. Similar bans are being proposed or discussed in France, Norway, and the UK, while US state lawmakers have filed hundreds of lawsuits against social media giants, accusing them of using harmful features to keep children on the platform longer to maximize profits.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The tanker and dry bulk market experienced a turbulent week, with rates fluctuating across various regions. The Capesize market saw a mix of gains and losses, while the Panamax market declined further. The Ultramax/Supramax sector also faced downward pressure. The LR2 market showed a welcome uptick in activity, with freight levels improving. The MR market remained in balance, and the VLCC market took a hit due to falling rates. The Suezmax market saw improvements, with owners gaining the upper hand. The market is expected to remain cautious, with limited optimism ahead of the holiday season.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Nov 22, 2024).

site_title: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon draws over 55,000 runners from 85 countries
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon drew over 55,000 runners from 85 countries, with 13,000 international participants, an all-time high for the region. The event, which wrapped up on December 1, featured five categories, including the return of the Ekiden relay. Kenya's Geoffrey Yegon won the men's title, while Fantu Zewude Jifar from Ethiopia won the women's category. The marathon also included initiatives to promote inclusivity, with 200 complementary slots given to beneficiaries with special needs and volunteers. The event raised funds for the Futuremakers programme, a global youth empowerment initiative.

images.alt_text: The Harlem Globetrotters’ Bull Bullard perches atop the basket during the team's previous visit to Singapore in April 2019.
Nadal won a record 24 Grand Slams in his long career, including 14 triumphs at the French Open.

site_title: DBS buys back nearly S$15m of its shares; AGT Partners becomes Oiltek’s substantial shareholder
summary: DBS bought back nearly S$15m of its shares, with 350,000 shares repurchased at an average price of S$42.04 per share. AGT Partners became Oiltek's substantial shareholder after acquiring 25,200 shares, increasing its direct interest from 4.98% to 5%. Other notable acquisitions include Wilmar International's chairman increasing his stake to 14.29%, Raffles Medical Group's executive chairman acquiring 2.4 million shares, and Wing Tai Holdings' chairman and managing director building his deemed interest to 61.58%.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks from Nov 15 to 21, resulting in a net institutional outflow of S$38 million.

site_title: UNRWA stops aid delivery via key Gaza-Israel crossing
summary: The UNRWA agency has halted aid delivery through the Kerem Shalom crossing between Israel and Gaza due to safety concerns, citing the theft of aid trucks by armed gangs. Over 1.8 million people in Gaza are experiencing high levels of acute food insecurity, with 133,000 facing "catastrophic" food insecurity. The UN has warned that hunger is "rapidly deepening" and humanitarian aid is becoming "impossible." The Israeli defense ministry claims that relief organizations cannot distribute large quantities of aid, while UNRWA's chief Philippe Lazzarini has called for a ceasefire and an end to attacks on humanitarian workers.

images.alt_text: Palestinian man Moein Abu Odeh searches for clothes through the rubble of a house destroyed in the Israeli military offensive, in Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip, November 18, 2024. REUTERS/Hussam Al-Masri     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY
People attend a vigil on the eve of the anniversary of the Hamas attacks in Tel Aviv, Israel, Oct 6, 2024.

site_title: Stellantis reels after CEO’s early departure leaves void
summary: Stellantis CEO Carlos Tavares' surprise departure has left the company without clear leadership amid industry pressure. The shares fell 8.9% on Monday, down 46% for the year, after Chairman John Elkann took over as interim CEO. Stellantis faces sales challenges in the US and Europe, where demand for electric cars is waning, and Chinese manufacturers are expanding. The company must now navigate a slumping market with economic slowdowns in China, and the threat of tariffs as Donald Trump prepares to return to the White House.

images.alt_text: CEO Carlos Tavares’ decision to slash manufacturing workers, such as those in Toledo, has angered the UAW union, which represents these employees.
France last week unveiled a draft budget that includes higher taxes on businesses and the wealthy in an effort to trim its large debt pile.
Stellantis CEO Carlos Tavares would retire in 2026.

site_title: Why falling fertility is not a crisis
summary: A declining global fertility rate is not a crisis, but rather a natural part of demographic transition. As societies shift from agriculture to urbanization, the need for large families decreases, allowing for greater prosperity and a more compact family structure. The UN projects a 700 million-person reduction in global population by 2100, bringing relief to cities struggling with services. Flawed approaches to addressing this issue, such as panic and emergency measures, should be rectified. Instead, policymakers should focus on constructive policies like education, social security, and labor market adjustments. With changing demographics, there is an opportunity to adapt and recognize the benefits of slower growth, including increased longevity and a more vibrant workforce.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical companies charge different prices in different countries for the same drugs. Income level and negotiating power are key factors. But in these aspects, Singapore is at a disadvantage because of its small population and relatively high GDP per capita.

site_title: ChatGPT’s US$8t birthday gift to Big Tech
summary: ChatGPT, launched two years ago, has become the fastest-growing app in history with 200 million active users, but its main legacy appears to be padding the finances of tech's biggest players. The six largest tech firms have seen their market capitalizations grow by over $8 trillion since ChatGPT's launch, defying the trend of small and mid-cap companies outperforming larger ones. This has raised concerns that the supposed AI revolution may not deliver on its promise of broad economic transformation, but instead concentrate wealth at the top.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit is the first by Canadian media against OpenAI.

site_title: Elon Musk asks US court to block OpenAi's for-profit conversion
summary: Elon Musk has asked a US court to block OpenAI's conversion to a for-profit enterprise, citing allegations that the company bars its investors from funding rivals, giving his own startup, xAI, an unfair advantage. Musk left OpenAI in 2018, accusing the company of abandoning its non-profit mission to make AI research available to all. OpenAI argues that Musk's lawsuit is motivated by sour grapes, and is currently seeking to become a for-profit public benefit corporation, which could attract more investment. Musk's injunction request is the latest development in a business feud between the two companies.

images.alt_text: Two years after capturing the public’s imagination, it seems that ChatGPT’s main legacy has been in padding the finances of tech’s biggest players.

site_title: Indonesia’s renewable capacity targets not enough to meet new net-zero aim: report
summary: Indonesia's newly announced net-zero target by 2050 may not be achievable due to its renewable energy plans, which only meet 35% of projected electricity demand by 2040. The country aims to add 75 GW of renewable energy by 2040, but experts say this is insufficient to meet its energy needs. Indonesia's economy is heavily reliant on fossil fuels, and progress in adding renewable capacity has been slow, making it challenging to achieve the ambitious target.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on August 6, 2024 shows a general view inside the reactor containment vessel of the unit 7 reactor building at the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear power station in Kashiwazaki, in Japan's Niigata prefecture. Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto said that the country planned to retire all coal and fossil-fuel-fired power plants within the next 15 years.
Fostering international collaboration may help more green technology diffuse to Asean, particularly for countries lagging in innovative capacity.
Singapore's industrial, commerce and services sectors each accounted for 40 per cent of the country’s electricity consumption in 2023.

site_title: Virtual power plants turn energy savings into cash for China’s industrial users
summary: China's virtual power plants (VPPs) are expected to reshape the country's energy market by grouping decentralized resources and promoting sustainable practices. VPPs, which rely on internet technologies to manage and optimize power loads from resources like energy storage, air conditioning, and electric vehicle charging stations, have caught the attention of investors, with VPP-related stocks surging since the start of this year. China's National Development and Reform Commission has unveiled a plan to accelerate the development of a new power system, positioning VPPs as vital to achieve carbon neutrality. Despite challenges in making VPPs profitable, industry experts suggest that they could play a greater role in balancing local power grids, and better price signaling and market transparency will encourage more users to actively participate in VPP networks.

images.alt_text: A pumped storage power station in Fengning, Hebei Province.

site_title: China new home prices rise at faster pace in November: survey
summary: China's new home prices rose at a faster pace in November, with an average price increase of 2.4% year-on-year, up from 2.08% in October, according to a private survey. This growth is attributed to supportive policies aimed at boosting the ailing property market. While a prolonged downturn remains a key drag on the economy, recent efforts to enhance affordability and loosen home purchase restrictions may start to bear fruit, with home prices expected to fall at a slower pace this year and next.

images.alt_text: Both official and private measures of October factory activity exceeded analyst expectations.

site_title: Think the stock market boom is too ‘extreme’? Think again
summary: Stock market experts argue that "extreme" years, such as 2024, are more common than "average" ones. Despite high returns in 2024, the writer claims that these are typical and not a cause for concern. Historical data shows that stock markets usually experience significant gains or losses, rather than average returns. In fact, the FTSE All-Share and S&P 500 have topped 20% in over half of their respective periods since the 1920s. The writer concludes that investors should not be swayed by short-term market fluctuations and instead focus on long-term trends.

images.alt_text: Few expected energy stocks to flounder as they did in 2023, after riding skyrocketing oil prices to 2022 outperformance.
bundle, jute rope, newspaper
The STI is hovering near record highs. But investors should not let a fear of heights drive them to 'safe havens'.

site_title: Adani says his empire will emerge stronger after US bribery case
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani said his conglomerate will emerge stronger after being indicted in a US$250 million bribery scheme in the US. Adani denied allegations of misconduct and blamed "vested reporting" for spreading negativity. He claimed every attack on his empire makes it stronger and every obstacle becomes a stepping stone for a more resilient Adani Group. The indictment has led to a decline in Adani stocks and triggered a query from India's market regulator, with Adani Green facing potential monetary penalties and a loss of nearly $55 billion in market value.

images.alt_text: State Bank of India will not stop lending to ongoing Adani projects that are nearing completion, but will exercise caution when disbursing loans to ensure all terms and conditions are being met.

site_title: Temasek among cornerstone investors for LeapFrog’s latest fund
summary: Temasek is among the cornerstone investors for LeapFrog's fourth fund, which closed with a total of US$1.02 billion in investments. The fund aims to accelerate high-impact healthcare and financial services companies in global growth markets, supporting 100 million people. LeapFrog drew significant commitments from global asset managers, healthcare strategic investors, and foundations, including Temasek, AIA, Prudential, and the European Investment Bank.

site_title: Britain’s jobs statistics crisis gives banks a growing headache
summary: Britain's job statistics crisis is causing banks to increase provisions to cover potential bad loans. The UK Office for National Statistics (ONS) is struggling to collect accurate data, leading to criticism from central bankers and politicians. HSBC, Barclays, Lloyds, and NatWest have set aside £21.8 billion to cover debts that could sour, citing uncertainty around the unemployment rate and other economic metrics. This may limit banks' appetite to lend and constrain economic growth, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Keir Starmer, whose Labour party swept to power in July, accused the previous Conservative government of running “a one-nation experiment in open borders”, with regular migration soaring since Brexit in 2020.

site_title: Anxious retailers look to deals, doorbusters to revive sales
summary: US retailers face softer-than-expected holiday sales, with early projections pointing to a 2.5-3.5% increase in online and in-person sales. Black Friday crowds were sparse, with many shoppers opting for early deals online. Macy's, Target, and Home Depot saw limited foot traffic, with some retailers struggling to draw crowds despite exclusive products and promotions. The National Retail Federation attributes the slowdown to early gift buying and inflation-weary consumers prioritizing essentials over discretionary spending.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift merchandise on display at a Target store in New Jersey, U.S, November 29, 2024. REUTERS/Siddharth Cavale/File Photo
Compared with other years, holiday shoppers in 2024 are “even more preoccupied and very focused around value and discounts,” said Vivek Pandya, leading insights analyst at Adobe Digital Insights.

site_title: South Korea’s exports regain momentum on steady chip demand
summary: South Korea's exports rebounded 3.6% in November from a year earlier, driven by strong demand for semiconductors, a key driver of the nation's economy. The country's trade surplus widened to $5.6 billion, with semiconductor exports increasing 30.8% to $12.5 billion. The positive sign for policymakers comes as US President-elect Donald Trump's tariff plans raise concerns about potential headwinds for the trade-reliant economy. The Bank of Korea has already lowered interest rates in anticipation of potential economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Both official and private measures of October factory activity exceeded analyst expectations.

site_title: Trump demands ‘commitment’ from Brics nations to use dollar
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has warned Brics nations that he will require a commitment not to create a new currency as an alternative to the US dollar, or face 100% tariffs. Trump has long emphasized the importance of the US dollar remaining the world's reserve currency and has threatened to use tariffs to ensure compliance. The move comes as the US prepares to retake power in January, with Trump's economic advisers discussing ways to punish countries that seek to engage in bilateral trade in currencies other than the US dollar.

images.alt_text: South Korea's exports adjusted for working-day differences rose 3.6 per cent in November from a year earlier, rebounding from a dip in the prior month, data from the trade ministry showed on Sunday

site_title: Markets undecided with easy solutions
summary: US markets remain indecisive, with no clear warning signs of a reversal. Despite concerns of a "mother of all bubbles" popping soon, the Dow Jones index has rebounded from support levels, suggesting a potential bullish trend continuation. Gold prices have also shown resilience, testing trend line support and potentially signaling a decrease in comfort with Trump's simple solutions. A break below trend line or trading band support could signal a change in trend, but no clear patterns have emerged to confirm a reversal.

site_title: Chinese toy maker Bloks Group files for up to HK$1.46 billion Hong Kong IPO
summary: Chinese toy maker Bloks Group is filing for a Hong Kong IPO, aiming to raise up to HK$1.46 billion (S$225 million) to ramp up product development and output. The company, which assembles Ultraman and Transformer toys, will use the proceeds to complete its self-operated factory and hire 400 employees. Bloks is China's largest player in the assembly character toy segment and has reported a first-half loss of 254.9 million yuan (S$47.5 million) despite posting 1.05 billion yuan in revenue, more than triple from a year ago.

images.alt_text: Zuru's plastic dart “blasters” compete with Hasbro’s Nerf on the shelves of Walmart and Target.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly down after Wall St losses
summary: Asia stocks declined on Monday, December 30, after US tech stocks fell, leading to a disappointing "Santa Claus rally." The Nikkei dropped 0.75% to 40,020.00 points, while the yen remained stable. Chinese stocks also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.09%. The US interest rate cut pace and potential import tariffs under President Trump weighed on investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: Stock markets have traditionally fared well in the last five trading days of the year and the first two in the new year, a trend known as the “Santa Claus rally”.

site_title: Vietnam approves public investment for US$67 billion North-South express rail
summary: Vietnam's parliament has approved a policy to use public investment for the country's largest-ever high-speed railway project, connecting Hanoi with Ho Chi Minh City, with a budget of US$67 billion. The project, expected to start in 2027 and complete in 2035, will travel 1,500 km at 350 km/h and create a US$33.5 billion construction market. Experts believe domestic funds will be sufficient for the project, but technology or expertise-intensive aspects may require foreign capital. The decision aims to drive inclusive growth and serve as a cornerstone of Vietnam's strategy to become a high-income economy by 2045.

images.alt_text: Hanoi still retain its hundred-year-old rails formed since the French colonial rule.

Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) has proposed to his Japanese counterpart Fumio Kishida that Japan provide ODA loans for the North-South railway project.

site_title: Rush to ‘value up’ may be Asia stocks’ best defence against Trump
summary: Asian stocks are turning to a "Japan-inspired" strategy of boosting shareholder returns, corporate governance, and market valuations to counter the threat of US trade policies under President Donald Trump. This "value up" approach, also known as "Corporate Value Up Program," is being implemented by governments and regulators in countries such as South Korea, China, and India. While some early results are mixed, fund managers see opportunities in the initiative, citing improved corporate reforms and increased dividend payouts in countries like India. The timing appears fortuitous, as Trump's trade policies threaten to undermine Asia's economic growth and corporate earnings.

US president-elect Donald Trump, who will be inaugurated on Jan 20, said on Monday (Nov 25) he plans to sign an executive order to impose a 25 per cent tariff on imports from Mexico and Canada, as well as an additional 10 per cent on top of existing tariffs on China.

site_title: Texas oil town Odessa now among US cities with highest wages
summary: Texas oil town Odessa has joined Denver in the top 10 US metropolitan areas with the highest weekly wages over the past year. San Jose and Midland, Texas, remained first and third, respectively, in October, while San Francisco's private weekly earnings fell. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that wages in oil towns are prone to swings tied to energy markets. Other metropolitan areas with high unemployment rates included Las Vegas and El Centro, while Sioux Falls and Rapid City had the lowest jobless rates.

images.alt_text: Nonfarm payrolls increased by 12,000 jobs last month after surging by a downwardly revised 223,000 in September.

site_title: Why the TikTok era spells trouble for the establishment
summary: The shift from traditional to social media has led to a rise in populism, with charismatic content creators and influencers dominating platforms like TikTok and Instagram. This shift has resulted in a decline in consumption of written news, with 50% of US adults under 50 getting their news from social feeds. The oversimplified and hyper-engaging nature of short-form video content has created an unfavourable environment for moderate and nuanced reporting, favouring radical and populist voices. This change has significant consequences for society, including a fragmented media landscape and increased comfort with controversial output, potentially impacting politics.

images.alt_text: Falsehoods and disinformation can derail companies as online fakery can morph and multiply quicker than ever before.
One worry about the IoT is that it turns everything around you into a spy. People are belatedly fretting about giving so much information about themselves to their computers and phones.

site_title: Nio delivers 20,575 vehicles in November; marks 10th anniversary
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, delivered 20,575 vehicles in November, a 28.9% increase from the same month last year. This brings cumulative deliveries to 640,426 as of November 30. The company's flagship premium EV line delivered 15,493 vehicles, while 5,082 came from its family-oriented Onvo brand. Nio recently celebrated its 10th anniversary. The company reported a net loss of 5.1 billion yuan for the three months ended September 30, up from 4.6 billion yuan in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People look at the newly unveiled Onvo L60 SUV, the first vehicle of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio's new lower-priced brand, in Shanghai, China May 15, 2024. REUTERS/Zoey Zhang/File Photo

Hot stock: Nio rises 17.4% on news of strategic investment in China unit

site_title: Hope and heartbreak in ChildAid’s 20th edition
summary: ChildAid 2024, a charity musical by BT and ST, raised over S$2 million for disadvantaged children, marking its 20th edition. The show centered on a fantasy musical where a powerful AI system makes children's dreams come true, but only half of them can be fulfilled. The poignant narrative weaved themes of hope, dreams, and resilience. President Tharman Shanmugaratnam attended the event, celebrating the funds raised. The event delivered a stirring performance, highlighting the importance of imagination and determination in overcoming life's challenges.

images.alt_text: Pianist Jessie Meng was only six when she was thrust into the limelight performing in ChildAid 2013. Now 17, she was earlier this year named Young Steinway Artist, making her the youngest pianist to be conferred the title.

site_title: Chipmaker Kioxia surges 12% in Tokyo debut after jumbo IPO
summary: Kioxia Holdings, Japan's third-largest NAND memory maker, surged 12% in its Tokyo Stock Exchange debut, valuing the firm at approximately 877 billion yen (S$7.7 billion). The company's shares rose above its initial public offering price of 1,455 yen, driven by strong investor demand. The IPO price reflects expectations of Kioxia's recovery and a relatively cheap price that helped lure buying. The company's listing follows years of negotiations involving Bain Capital, SK Inc, and the Japanese government, and its performance may be influenced by the multi-trillion-dollar spending on data centers fueled by big tech firms.

images.alt_text: The world’s No 3 Nand maker is listing at a time when Japan’s IPO market is seeing the largest volume since 2018.

site_title: Growing difficulty in owning a private landed home does not imply a lower standard of living
summary: Owning a landed home in Singapore has become increasingly difficult due to a lack of supply. Despite rising prices, the share of landed homes in private housing stock is declining. This challenges high-income earners, as it was once possible for them to purchase private landed homes, even on single incomes. Experts attribute this to a limited supply of new homes, with low mortgage rates providing some relief. The government's Master Plan 2025 aims to address this issue, but its success depends on developers and skilled migrants contributing to the development of new private housing.

images.alt_text: Orchard private apartments and properties with regards to higher ABSD rates

site_title: Sichuan food’s spicy revival at Shisen Hanten
summary: Shisen Hanten, a 10-year-old Japanese-Chinese restaurant in Singapore, has reopened after a five-month renovation. The restaurant, awarded two Michelin stars in 2016, lost one star in 2023 but retained its ranking. The new decor is impressive, with a grand ballroom-like atmosphere and attentive service. The menu features traditional Sichuan dishes, including mapo tofu, which remains a standout despite some overseasoning. The restaurant's set menu is a good way to sample its offerings without breaking the bank. Overall, Shisen Hanten acquits itself well as a hotel Chinese restaurant with decent food, but falls short of expectations when presented as a high-end dining experience. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: Canape-like black pepper choux puffs are filled with lobster salad.

site_title: Dollar stands tall in 2024, propped up by cautious Fed, Trump trade
summary: The US dollar is poised for strong gains in 2024, driven by a cautious Federal Reserve and President-elect Donald Trump's pro-growth policies. The dollar index is at 108.06, near its two-year high, and has risen 6.6% in 2024. Investors expect fewer US rate cuts and are wary of emerging market currencies, leading to a decline in the euro and other currencies, including the yen, which is at 157.02 per dollar, down 10% from its July high.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan expects further progress in hitting 2% inflation target in 2025
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) expects further progress towards achieving its 2% inflation target in 2025, with governor Kazuo Ueda stating the economy is moving closer to sustainably meeting the target. The BOJ may raise interest rates to 0.5% in January or March, with analysts expecting this move. The central bank will scrutinize wage negotiations and economic conditions to determine the timing of its next policy decision. Japan's economy has shown signs of improvement, with intensifying labor shortages pushing up wages, and the BOJ aims to balance supporting the economy with preventing excessive monetary support that could heighten inflation risks.

images.alt_text: The BOJ’s plan to almost halve its bond purchases from July 2024 to March 2026, which will result in its holdings dropping by 37.6 trillion next yen fiscal year.
The review warned that the negative effects of former governor Haruhiko Kuroda’s massive monetary stimulus  may last longer than expected and become bigger in the future.
Inflation has become a key economic and political topic in Japan after years of falling prices.

site_title: US probes China chip industry on ‘anti-competitive’ concerns
summary: The US has launched an investigation into China's semiconductor industry, citing concerns over Beijing's "extensive anticompetitive and non-market means" that undermine US commerce and economic security. The probe centers on foundational semiconductors used in critical US supply chains, including cars and medical devices. China has slammed the move as "protectionist" and vowed to defend its interests. The investigation, under Section 301 of the Trade Act, aims to strengthen US supply chains and revitalise domestic manufacturing, with officials expected to complete the probe within a year.

images.alt_text: A 900% increase in the cost of graphite would double the overall cost of an EV battery cell.
Washington is moving on a number of fronts to further restrict Chinese products.
At CEWC, Beijing sets targets for economic growth, the budget deficit, debt issuance and other variables for the year ahead.

site_title: New York financial district’s hip mystery tower
summary: The WSA building, a 31-storey office tower in New York's financial district, has become a hub for creatives after being redeveloped by developers who received a US$41.3 million tax break. The building, which was once the global headquarters of AIG, is now filled with artists, designers, and boutique agencies, with rents as low as US$2,800 per month for a 3,000-square-foot space. The project's driving force, Gabriella Khalil, and her husband Matthew Khalil, have attracted high-profile tenants, including fashion designers and chefs, but the economics of the project remain uncertain, with the developers facing significant costs and debt.

images.alt_text: The average price across 100 cities edged up 0.36 per cent, compared with the previous month’s 0.29 per cent, according to data released by property researcher China Index Academy.

site_title: Britain’s £2 billion shoplifting spree sparks security overhaul
summary: Britain's £2 billion shoplifting spree has prompted a significant overhaul of retail security measures, with retailers investing millions in body cameras, facial recognition technology, and other tools. The industry spent £1.2 billion on crime prevention measures in 2024, up from £720 million in 2022. Organised shoplifting gangs are becoming more common, with retailers and police working together to share information and catch prolific offenders. The government is reclassifying thefts of less than £200 as crimes and making assault of a shop worker a standalone offence, punishable by six months in jail.

images.alt_text: Sales volumes in Britain dropped by 3.3 per cent in the 12 months to November, the weakest reading since April when they fell 4.0 per cent, and below an increase of 0.6 per cent in the year to October, the British Retail Consortium said.
Shoplifting has become a growing issue for retailers during the cost-of-living crisis, and companies including Tesco will collaborate with the police to tackle the issue.

site_title: Singapore market unlikely to repeat 2024’s high; moderate returns expected for 2025
summary: The Singapore market is expected to remain stable in 2025, with moderate returns anticipated, unlike the significant gains seen in 2024. A global stocks sell-off in August 2024, triggered by recession fears in the US, had a lasting impact on the market. The Straits Times Index (STI) saw a sharp rally in the second half of 2024, with a 23% total return, but analysts predict a more subdued performance in 2025.
